context-en: This is the adult price.
context-en2: There are only three adults.
context-en3: The adults went to an izakaya.
meaning-exp: This kanji combines big and person. If you're a child, how do you think of adults? You just think of them like big people. That's why this combination of kanji means adult.
reading-exp: "I'm an adult, which means I have adult responsibilities. Oh, Toner (???)? I need some of that for my terrible printer..." ... now feel so sad you have such a terrible printer that runs out of toner every day. Ohhhh Toner!

context-en: I went to karaoke alone.
context-en2: One of them is American.
context-en3: My daughter did the errands by herself for the first time today.
meaning-exp: When there's one person, what are they? Well, they're either just going to be simply one person or alone.
reading-exp: The reading for this vocab doesn't follow any rules you learned previously. It's an exception, which means you have to learn the reading separately too. Spend a few moments trying to remember this word, look away for 10 seconds, and then try to recall its reading. Could you do it? Try again, this time in thirty seconds. Did you do it again? Okay, go ahead and move on. You may know it now, though you'll need to recall it again in the next 5-10 minutes if you want to remember it for good. Alternatively, if you know the reading for the vocab word ?? (in the same level as this word), you can know that it uses the same reading!

context-en: Is your brain really artificial?
context-en2: This river is man-made.
context-en3: I put artificial turf in the garden.
meaning-exp: A person of industry makes a lot of things by hand, so everything they make is artificial, and also means it's man made.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: This hat is too big.
context-en2: Can I get those two big peaches?
context-en3: My baby is about as big as a calf.
meaning-exp: This is the adjective form of big. It has the same meaning, though it is a word for describing. Words that end with ? are often adjectives, remember that for future words as well. So, as long as you know the meaning of this kanji, you can transfer that to the meaning of this word. It's the adjective big / large.
reading-exp: What do you do when you see something really, really big? You say ?? because you can't believe your eyes. Imagine something really large and say ?? out loud to help seal the memory in that brain of yours.

context-en: What’s under the desk?
context-en2: Please come down.
context-en3: I live on the floor below the Tofugu office.
meaning-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji with no okurigana (that's hiragana attached to the kanji) it tends to steal the meaning of the kanji it comes from. So, this one is below or down.
reading-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji and is alone it tends to use the kun'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi reading for this kanji, so now it's time to learn the kun'yomi reading to learn this vocabulary word. What's below you? What's below your foot? Oh no. The worst thing possible: It's ??.

context-en: Students will study page eight at home today.
context-en2: I put eight candies in my purse.
context-en3: Eight o’clock? Are you sure it’s eight o’clock?
meaning-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji it usually steals its meaning from its kanji as well. Same goes for this vocab word. It means eight.
reading-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji and all alone like this, it's usually going to use the kun'yomi. But, because this is a number (exception) it uses the on'yomi instead, meaning you already know the reading from when you learned the kanji!

context-en: There are eight potatoes in a bag.
context-en2: There are only eight of them.
context-en3: What has eight faces and six arms?
meaning-exp: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus ? on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for eight plus ?. So, this one is eight things.
reading-exp: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus ?), you really just have to remember the part before the ? (and then remember that the ? is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). So what eight things do you have? You have eight yachts (???). Go ahead and count them. They're beautiful. Also, be sure not to be confused by this particular reading mnemonic. It includes the ?, even though the ? is outside the reading you need to learn (just makes things easier for you overall). Since you can see the ? outside, it shouldn't be too difficult for you.

context-en: I will wait for you at the entrance.
context-en2: There are three entrances.
context-en3: Johnny Depp is at the entrance.
meaning-exp: A mouth that you enter is an entrance.
reading-exp: Because there's some okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) attached, you can bet that ?? will be a kun'yomi reading. This reading comes from the word ???. If you know that word already, this one will be easy. If not, then you'll have to think that the entrance you're going in is eerie (??). Then, because this word is really two separate words put together to form one word, you can guess that ? also uses the kun'yomi reading, though the ? in ?? changes to ? due to something called rendaku. Just remember that it's ?? and not ?? here.

context-en: It’s not a big deal.
context-en2: She is such a great woman.
context-en3: Being the president of McDonald’s would be a big deal.
meaning-exp: ?? is the past tense form of ?? (which means "to do"). So, essentially this word is "did big." What is something that "did big"? It's something that's great or considerable.
reading-exp: The reading for the ? part is actually the on'yomi reading you learned when learning its kanji. So, as long as you remember that (and remember to use that reading), you can read this word as well. ??? = ????.

context-en: I'll climb a mountain with my friends.
context-en2: This is the world's biggest man-made mountain.
context-en3: At 8 am, let’s meet naked on Bald Mountain.
meaning-exp: A vocab made of a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) usually has the same exact meaning as the kanji it's made from. So by that you know that this vocab's meaning is mountain.
reading-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's usually going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn when you learned the kanji. To remember this word's reading we'll use a mnemonic. What are you doing going up into the mountains? You're hunting for yams (??). Go ahead, imagine yourself doing just that, climbing up the mountain (it's hard work!) and then digging in the ground with your hands, then pulling up that sweet, delicious yam! Mmm!

context-en: There is some sauce on your mouth.
context-en2: Please put this in your mouth.
context-en3: I haven’t been able to close my mouth since yesterday.
meaning-exp: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's generally going to have the same meaning as the kanji it came from. From that, you know this word's meaning is mouth.
reading-exp: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's generally going to use the kun'yomi reading, which you did not learn from learning the kanji. To remember this word, you should use a mnemonic. With your mouth, make a "kuchi kuchi kou" (??) sound. Go ahead, make it. Focus on your mouth and try to imagine each shape it makes while zooming in on it. You're talking to a baby, which is why you're making all these ridiculous noises. Also, instead of "coo" at the end, you're saying "kou," because that's the reading of the kanji (??). ??????!??????! Sounds like something from Arrested Development, actually.

vocab-meaning: Mt Fuji, Mount Fuji, Mt. Fuji
context-en: I want to arrive at Mt. Fuji by around 11 a.m.
context-en2: There are always three adult French people, two small Americans, and one Canadian on Mt. Fuji.
context-en3: Mt. Fuji was covered in white bird poop.
meaning-exp: Just look at this word. What do you think it means? That's right - it's a name (Fuji) plus the kanji for mountain. Put those together, and you have Mount Fuji. In English the "Mount(ain)" part comes first. In Japanese, it comes at the end, sort of like the name ender ??, ???, and so on. You can add ? to the end of any mountain's name too, not just Mount Fuji.
reading-exp: Normally ?? would be in kanji, but I wanted you to see this kanji use in action since it's more useful than just being used on Mount Fuji. This is treated like a jukugo word (combo kanji word). In the case of jukugo, usually the on'yomi reading is used, meaning you just have to remember the on'yomi reading of ?. Luckily, you learned this when you were learning the kanji, so you should already know it!

context-en: I study for about nine hours every day.
context-en2: Please open the page 9.
context-en3: I used to have nine mynah birds.
meaning-exp: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it often has the same meaning as the kanji it's based off of. Same goes for the word ?, as well. It has the same meaning as its kanji counterpart.
reading-exp: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are the exception, as you might already know. When they're alone with no okurigana they're the on'yomi reading, which you should already know from learning the kanji that makes up this word.

context-en: There are nine questions that require a dictionary on today’s test.
context-en2: Is it true that a cat has nine lives?
context-en3: I made nine donuts.
meaning-exp: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus ? on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for nine plus ?. So, this one is nine things.
reading-exp: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus ?), you really just have to remember the part before the ? (and then remember that the ? is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). What thing do you have nine of? The nine things that you have are nine coconuts (???). Imagine yourself juggling nine coconuts in the air. Try counting them while you're doing this, arriving at nine things.

context-en: Let’s meet up once.
context-en2: First place was an American.
context-en3: I’m the weakest man in the world.
meaning-exp: As is the case with most vocab words that consist of a single kanji, this vocab word has the same meaning as the kanji it parallels, which is one.
reading-exp: When a vocab word is all alone and has no okurigana (hiragana attached to kanji) connected to it, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception, however. When a number is all alone, with no kanji or okurigana, it is going to be the on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji. Just remember this exception for alone numbers and you'll be able to read future number-related vocab to come.

context-en: Choose one answer.
context-en2: It's limited to one per customer.
context-en3: I met a one-eyed goblin yesterday.
meaning-exp: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus ? on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for one plus ?. So, this one is one thing.
reading-exp: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus ?), you really just have to remember the part before the ? (and then remember that the ? is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). So, you have one thing. What one thing do you have? You have one of He-Man's Toes, aka a single He-Toe (??). So what's the thing you have only one of? You have one He-Toe. Imagine He-Man walking around with one missing toe, trying to find you so he can get it back. At least you'll be able to run faster than him now.

context-en: What will the person the arrow is pointing at say?
context-en2: What is that person's nationality?
context-en3: People say he's a stupid person.
meaning-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji all alone, it usually has the same meaning as its kanji parent. That goes for this vocab word as well. Person is person.
reading-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Since you don't know the kun'yomi reading for this kanji yet, let's use a mnemonic to learn it. What does a person hate more than anything? They hate extreme heat (??). You can always put on more clothes to stay warm, but when the heat gets too high, you can only take off so much.

context-en: You need a ticket here, so please go buy one.
context-en2: Please give me two apples.
context-en3: Fugu, gently pinch me please.
meaning-exp: You know that the kanji ? means down and that ?? sounds like the word "sigh." You need to ask someone for something, so you look down, sigh, and say please give me that thing. You're ashamed that you have to ask. But you still need it. Please, please give it to me! We only use this kanji version of ???? when we're asking for something, that's why it's "please give me." If you're just saying "please" you don't need the kanji at all!
reading-exp: The reading for this word is an exceptional reading. You just have to be able to recall the ?? part, though (since ?? is already there in the form of the hiragana). So, think about why you have to be polite to this misbehaving kid. Turns out, if you don't, he has the power to initiate a Coup d'état against you and your family, who runs the government. Just imagine yourself thinking over and over "Okay... I have to be nice to this kid. If I don't... he'll initiate a Coup d'état... and that would ruin my family..." You're walking on thin ice, here.

context-en: Half the population is male.
context-en2: This village's population is only 23.
context-en3: Many Japanese people don’t know the population of their own town.
meaning-exp: The amount of people with mouths (that you have to feed) is the population that you have to feed.
reading-exp: Both kanji in this jukugo (combo kanji) use the on'yomi readings that you've already learned! So just make sure you know those and you'll be able to read this too.

context-en: I’m hungry and losing strength.
context-en2: That American woman has the power to move Mt. Fuji.
context-en3: My mom is more powerful than the rest of my family put together.
meaning-exp: When a vocab word is made up of a single kanji and that's it, it almost always takes the meaning from its parent kanji. So, this vocab word also means power.
reading-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading with the kanji, so for this vocab word, we'll use a mnemonic. The most powerful man in the world. All his power came from his cheek (???). Imagine him blowing up his cheek like a giant balloon, then unleashing his power on you. Thwap thwap thwap thwap.

context-en: There are a lot of fish swimming in this river.
context-en2: Japan's longest river is Shinano River.
context-en3: Whenever I see a river, I get so pissed off.
meaning-exp: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it will usually take the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. So, from that you know that this word means river.
reading-exp: You're in luck - the reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one you have to learn for this vocab!

context-en: Why don’t we meet at the station at seven tomorrow morning?
context-en2: There are seven mandarin oranges.
context-en3: I want to be friends with the seven dwarves.
meaning-exp: When a vocab is alone with no okurigana (that's hiragana attached to a kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji too. That goes for this word as well. So, if you know the kanji's meaning (seven) you'll know the vocab's meaning (seven).
reading-exp: Most single-kanji all-alone vocab words like this use the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this rule. That being said, four and seven are exceptions to this exception to the rule (because the on'yomi readings sound too much like the word for "death"). You should learn both readings for this word, though we're going to go with ?? for the main one here. You can remember that because you had seven nanas after you.

context-en: There are seven apples in a box.
context-en2: Just the two of us ate seven melons.
context-en3: After I count to seven, I will be a woman.
meaning-exp: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus ? on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for seven plus ?. So, this one is seven things.
reading-exp: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus ?), you really just have to remember the part before the ? (and then remember that the ? is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). What thing do you have seven of? The seven things that you have are seven Nanas (??). These are your grandmas, cloned. Just think, "It's lucky to have seven nanas. They can all cook my favorite foods for me!"

context-en: The size of this table is 100cm in width and 120cm in length.
context-en2: The size of the TV is 32 inches.
context-en3: Ronald McDonald always wore different-sized shoes.
meaning-exp: Words that end with ? are often words that have taken the adjective form (in this case ???) of the word and turned into words that describe what the adjective form is doing, if that makes sense. So ??? (big) goes to ???, and the word that describes what "big" describes is the word size.
reading-exp: When a vocab has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it is probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Since you learned the on'yomi reading with the kanji ?, we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember this word. When you saw the size of (pick something surprising), you said "?? *#$@!" Really imagine something surprising. Say the ?? part out loud, as well. Think about the size of whatever you're looking at, too, and how big it is.

context-en: I have ten swallows.
context-en2: It'll be December in two days.
context-en3: For ten years I lived with ten other people.
meaning-exp: When a vocab is alone like this with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it tends to steal its meaning from the kanji it came from. That means this vocab word also means ten.
reading-exp: When a vocab is alone and consists of a single kanji like this, usually it uses the kun'yomi reading for the kanji. But, numbers are an exception and they use the on'yomi reading (which you learned when you learned the kanji). That means you know that this word's reading is ??? already.

context-en: There are three pages of these questions total.
context-en2: I’m 32 years old.
context-en3: Turn around three times and bark!
meaning-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji and alone like this, it usually steals its meaning from the parent kanji. That goes for this word too, making the meaning of this word three.
reading-exp: When a vocab is alone like this with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually uses its kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception, though, and use the on'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi reading when you learned this kanji, so you already know that the reading for this vocab is ??.

context-en: I have three siblings.
context-en2: There were only two or three people in the river.
context-en3: Out of those three people, which one is your type?
meaning-exp: You have the kanji for three and person. Common sense will tell you what this word is. It's three people.
reading-exp: This jukugo (combo kanji) word uses the on'yomi readings that you learned when you learned the kanji. That means you should know the reading as long as you know the kanji.

context-en: You will hear three choices.
context-en2: Please put three balls in here.
context-en3: I got three mosquito bites.
meaning-exp: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus ? on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for three plus ?. So, this one is three things.
reading-exp: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus ?), you really just have to remember the part before the ? (and then remember that the ? is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). What thing do you have three of? The three things that you have are actually three versions of yourself. "Who is the real one?" you ask yourself. "It's me!" "Wait, no, it's me!" Just remember that there are three of you, and they're all saying "me me me me me" to try and prove that they're the real you.

context-en: I can go up to the roof.
context-en2: I climbed up stairs to the 10th floor.
context-en3: I saw a salmon swimming upstream.
meaning-exp: This vocab word is an exception in almost every way. It has a similar meaning to the meaning of the kanji, and you know it's a verb because it ends with an ? sound (?, in this case). But, the meaning is to climb. Comparing it to the other ? verb words, it has the least okurigana (versus ??? and ???). You could remember this and know that the thing you don't want to do the most is "to climb," so that's why it has the least okurigana.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is an exception from all the rules of the ? vocabulary. It consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, so it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to climb the mountain, but a gruff old man grabs your shoulder and says "No boy, you ain't climbing that thing, not today." If you're not a boy, think about how weird it is that he called you a boy. If you are a grown man, think how you wish he called you "dude" or something, not "boy." If you're a boy, well... think about how appropriate it is that he said "no boy."

context-en: Please stretch before getting in the pool.
context-en2: Please enter from the entrance.
context-en3: Let’s go in the room and draw our eyebrows on!
meaning-exp: When a kanji ends with an "?" sound (like ?, for this one), it's usually going to be a verb. When the vocab is a kanji + okurigana ending in this "?" sound, it's often going to be the verb form of that kanji. So in this case, the kanji ? is enter. The vocab ?? is to enter. Just the verb version of the kanji.
reading-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji with okurigana, chances are it's going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you don't usually learn in the kanji (you usually learn the on'yomi reading). So, let's learn the kun'yomi reading for this word using its meaning. When you enter the room, what do you do? You say "Hi" (??) to everyone to the point of absurdity. "Hi there. Oh hi Frank. Oh hi there Susan. Oh hi there lamp."

vocab-meaning: To Get Lower, To Fall, To Drop, To Come Down, To Hang Down
context-en: Stock prices all over the world fell.
context-en2: My temperature dropped to 37?.
context-en3: Unfasten your belt so that your pants will hang down.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means below so this means something gets lower, by falling or dropping. For example: Prices get lower or fall. Squirrels come down from trees. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to get lower or to fall.
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to remember the reading of the kanji: You know it means to fall so instead of using a saw (?) to cut down the tree, you decide to let it come to you. It has to come down all by itself. Picture yourself placing a saw at the foot of a tree then sitting back and waiting for it to drop itself at your knees. (This could actually work, don't you judge my methods!)

context-en: What will you put in the square?
context-en2: Please insert twelve pieces of origami paper here.
context-en3: I put a hamburger into the coffin.
meaning-exp: This is similar to the vocab word ?? (to enter), except in this case, instead of entering you're inserting something. So, it's like you're entering something into something else. You can remember that this one is to insert because it's longer than ?? (???/to enter). Why? Because it's more difficult to insert something than it is to enter somewhere, which is why you have more help (the extra kana stuck on the end).
reading-exp: When a vocab is a single kanji plus some okurigana (hiragana stuck on the end of kanji) it's almost always going to be the kun'yomi reading. This is one of two kun'yomi readings you'll be learning for the kanji ?. As long as you know that this vocab means to insert, you can use that to remember the reading as well. When you insert your hand into the mysterious hole, it feels cold and sticky inside. You scream: "?!" as an eagle flies out.

vocab-meaning: To Lower, To Hang, To Lower Something, To Hang Something
context-en: Please tell me how to lower my blood pressure.
context-en2: That shop has one wind chime hanging in its entrance.
context-en3: I tried to perform a rain dance to lower the temperature.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means below so the verb version of that is when you put something below you. It's to lower something. This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You lower something. Like your blood pressure!
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to lower a tree so you need a saw (?). Lower the tree to the ground gently while you slowly saw it down!

context-en: Please put this box on top of the refrigerator for me.
context-en2: Please raise it three centimeters.
context-en3: I raised my hands and let out a huge fart.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means above so the verb version of that is when you put something above you. It's to raise something. This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You raise something. Like your hands!
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to raise an aardvark (?) above your head. Why? Because even though aardvarks have long tongues, it can't reach the ants in the trees. But when you raise the aardvark it can get at those yummy ants!

vocab-meaning: To Rise, To Go Up, To Be Raised
context-en: My fever is rising steadily.
context-en2: Let's go up to the 3rd floor using the elevator.
context-en3: Smoke is rising.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means above so this means something rises. For example: A fever rises. The sun rises. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to rise or to go up.
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading, which also happens to be a reading you didn't learn when you learned the kanji. Let's use a mnemonic for the kun'yomi reading now, though. You have to remember at least the ? part to read it. You know that this word means to rise. Imagine something just rising on its own, like a floating tree or something. What would you say? Probably a "surprised" sound. Maybe you'd scream "?!" when you saw this floating tree.

context-en: We will work on question two on page twenty-one in class.
context-en2: My child is 2 years old.
context-en3: My uncle has two cats.
meaning-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's two!
reading-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

vocab-meaning: Two People, Pair, Couple, Two Persons
context-en: I am watching a DVD with my older sister.
context-en2: Those two want to be a couple all the time.
context-en3: She was arrested for double murder.
meaning-exp: When you have two and person and then put them together, what do you get? You get a pair or two people.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is quite strange. If you know ??'s reading, you can use that to remember the ? part (??). But, the ? that is the ? is a total exception, something you won't see too often (though you may have seen it in ??). If you can use the reading of ?? (aka if you've learned it already) then definitely use that. If not, do your best to remember the reading on your own. It's a strange one that doesn't connect to much else.

context-en: It’s two dialogues.
context-en2: Please put two apples in this basket.
context-en3: His second evil deed was the frog’s assassination.
meaning-exp: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus ? on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for two plus ?. So, this one is two things.
reading-exp: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus ?), you really just have to remember the part before the ? (and then remember that the ? is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). So what thing do you have two of? The two things that you have consist of one foot and another foot (??). Remember from the on'yomi how you had two knees (for the reading ?)? Now look further down your leg at one foot then over to the other foot. Two foot!

context-en: Please look at the chart above.
context-en2: The Tofugu office is three floors up.
context-en3: One of your socks was at the top of the stairs.
meaning-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji and alone, it tends to steal the meaning from the kanji. Same goes for this one too. It means above or up.
reading-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji and doesn't have okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually will use the kun'yomi. Since you learned the on'yomi reading of the kanji, we'll need to use a mnemonic to learn the reading of this vocabulary word. Above you is a huge weight. You're holding it up and struggling (it's heavy!). You look up and try to crane your neck to see how much it weighs (??), but you can't see the numbers on the side of it. How long can you hold it above your head like this?

context-en: Who is that woman?
context-en2: I'm a woman.
context-en3: I want a woman who will help look after my children.
meaning-exp: When a kanji is alone and doesn't have any okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's usually going to take the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. So in this case, you know that this word means woman.
reading-exp: When a word is a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it tends to use a kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji itself, so let's use a mnemonic to remember the vocab word. There's a woman in front of you. Who is she? It's just you and her in the store, and you're staring each other down. Oh. It turns out she's the store owner (???), which is weird, because you are in a store that makes only manly things. A woman owner of a manly things store? Strange...

context-en: You’ve deceived me again... boohoo!
context-en2: I'm American. And also, I'm French.
context-en3: Here I am again!
meaning-exp: As a vocab made up of a single kanji, you know that the meaning of this vocab word and the meaning of the kanji that makes it are the same: Again!
reading-exp: The reading you learned for the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. You won't have to learn it "again."

context-en: My birthday is April ninth.
context-en2: Since cherry blossoms are in bloom in April, the prince wants to go to Japan.
context-en3: My girlfriend suffered from so much stress after her parents divorced in April that she started to grow a little bit of a mustache.
meaning-exp: ? in Japanese means "moon" but it also means "month." Why? Probably because the moon takes about a month to get through its cycles. So, what's the fourth moon of the year? Here's a hint, it's the same as the fourth month of the year: April.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the ?? reading.

context-en: I played ball-toss during sports day.
context-en2: There are nine white balls here.
context-en3: Have you ever seen an animal that looks like a ball of wool?
meaning-exp: As an alone single kanji vocab, you know that this vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji: Ball.
reading-exp: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned when learning the kanji: ??.

context-en: Where did you buy this book?
context-en2: The book cover that Koichi bought from a spooky French person was covered with genuine leather.
context-en3: If you want to read a book here, you have to give me some gold.
meaning-exp: This vocab word is exactly the same as its parent kanji, including its meaning as well: book. It doesn't have those other meanings though, when it's just ? alone, it's just a book.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the single kanji it comes from.

context-en: I married a white man.
context-en2: I am black and from Kenya, but I was raised by a white family in America.
context-en3: Many caucasians hate summer in Japan.
meaning-exp: This word uses white and person ... put those together and you have a white person, aka a caucasian person.
reading-exp: As a jukugo word, it follows all the rules and uses the on'yomi readings from the kanji (both of which you know from learning the kanji).

context-en: This is a circle painted by Picasso.
context-en2: What's this circle drawn on the map?
context-en3: My black lab was shocked and his eyes bulged wide open.
meaning-exp: This vocab word and the kanji that makes it have the same meaning: Circle.
reading-exp: The reading you learned for this kanji is the kun'yomi one. Since this vocab word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Guess what? That means you already know it!

context-en: The ones Yamada made are the round onigiri.
context-en2: Earth is spherical.
context-en3: I wouldn’t say that my face is round.
meaning-exp: With an ? on the end, you can guess that this word is an ?-adjective. What is the adjective version of the kanji ?? "Circle" becomes circular, spherical or round. This, compared to another similar word (?), is more general purpose and can be used with 3D spherical objects as well.
reading-exp: This word uses the reading you learned for the kanji ?, though you'll need to tack the ? onto the end too.

context-en: He always thinks he’s right.
context-en2: The princess is always correct and the prince is always wrong.
context-en3: If you want to open the door to my heart, you need the right key, baby.
meaning-exp: Ending with an ? tells you that this word is an ?-adjective. So since you know that the kanji ? means "correct," what is the adjective version of that word? Well, it's also correct.
reading-exp: This word uses a reading you didn't learn from the kanji. You have to remember the ?? portion in order to read this word, so think about it this way: After you get the answer correct a clown jumps out of nowhere yelling "TA DA!!!" Imagine it scaring the crap out of you, too.

context-en: There is a dog and a cat.
context-en2: That king has six dogs.
context-en3: My dog likes Chinese cabbage.
meaning-exp: This vocab made up of a single kanji shares its meaning with said single kanji. That meaning is dog.
reading-exp: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

vocab-meaning: Eight Days, Day Eight, Eighth Day
context-en: My summer break is eight days long.
context-en2: Could you please give me some water? I haven't eaten anything for eight days.
context-en3: I’m going to get hemorrhoid surgery on the eighth of next month.
meaning-exp: Eighth day or day eight. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading-exp: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: Every eight days you have to buy yogurt to fuel your car (???). Your car runs on yogurt, but it needs to be refilled every eight days to keep running. It's really inconvenient because it's just ONE day more than a week. And a week just feels better. Oh well.

context-en: I went to a party last night.
context-en2: The prince in Denmark invited two French people to a musical evening.
context-en3: Last night I wrote the kanji for meat on my forehead.
meaning-exp: This vocab word has a weird little extra bit on it (the ?). You can sort of ignore that, it doesn't really mean anything in particular. The meaning of this vocab word and the kanji it comes from are the same: evening
reading-exp: When hiragana is attached to a kanji, you can usually assume that that kanji is going to be read using the kun'yomi reading, which is exactly what's going on with this word as well. By learning this word's kanji you've also learned the reading for this word.

context-en: That is not an exit.
context-en2: I heard that Mt. Fuji has a secret entrance and exit.
context-en3: This baseball stadium’s exit is over there.
meaning-exp: The mouth you exit out of is just a doorway (I hope), but an easier way to describe this word or concept is to call it an exit.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. ?? is an exception to this rule, however, and uses its kun'yomi readings. There's no particular reason why this is, but oftentimes a "body part" word (like mouth) changes a word to use kun'yomi readings instead of on'yomi ones. You already know the kun'yomi reading for ? (??) from learning the vocab, but to remember the reading for ? you can think the following: If I exit out this mouth, I'll end up in the ocean (you were swallowed by a whale) and I will surely end up dead (?). Also keep in mind that because of rendaku, ?? becomes ??.

context-en: Does Hanako have good eyes?
context-en2: In America, there is a mountain where people with three eyes live and they hold a festival on February 8th every year.
context-en3: I love men with beautiful blue eyes!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

context-en: I’ll use these potatoes for the snowman’s eyeballs.
context-en2: The princess' hobby is to collect eyeballs.
context-en3: I think these grapes look like monster eyeballs.
meaning-exp: What is an eye ball? Oh wait, that's easy. It's an eyeball!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. ??, however, is an exception. Perhaps this is because it includes a body part (the eye) in it, which often makes a word switch to kun'yomi readings. Either way, it doesn't matter too much. Both the readings you learned for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi, meaning you should know how to read this one. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.

context-en: I got married on February third.
context-en2: In February, air tickets to Japan are very cheap.
context-en3: Our affair began in February of last year.
meaning-exp: The kanji ? means both month and moon (because moon cycles take about a month, presumably). So, what is the number two month? It's not January... it's not March... it's February!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That is true with this word as well. Make sure to take note that ? is using the ?? reading and not the ?? one. This is true for all "month words" in Japanese.

vocab-meaning: Fifth Day, Day Five, Five Days
context-en: I took five days off from work.
context-en2: June 5th is my friend's birthday.
context-en3: On the fifth day I said, "That's it!"
meaning-exp: Day five or the fifth day. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading-exp: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: On the fifth day I have to eat (??) five cars (?). Now imagine yourself eating five cars. How did you manage to get past the first one? I'm impressed.

context-en: I ate fifty plates at conveyer belt sushi.
context-en2: One genius doctor invented a cure for gout for only 50 yen.
context-en3: I loved you for nearly fifty years, but yesterday that ended.
meaning-exp: What happens when you have ten five times? You get fifty!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's the case for this word too, which means you should already know how to read this word.

context-en: Please put the fire out soon.
context-en2: Have you ever started a fire with stones?
context-en3: The fire burned off all of his hair.
meaning-exp: This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: fire.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What comes off of fire? Lots and lots of heat (?). Feel it coming off the fire, touching and warming your face.

context-en: Tom bought five onigiri at the convenience store.
context-en2: My friend was born on May 5th in the 55th year of Showa.
context-en3: Once upon a time, there was a mother pig with five baby pigs.
meaning-exp: This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: Five.
reading-exp: Since numbers are an exception, this word is read using the on'yomi reading even though it's made from a single kanji all alone. Luckily for you, you learned the reading for this word when you learned the parent kanji.

context-en: I ate five pieces of mochi.
context-en2: Fifty white female Americans are competing against each other to obtain five manju.
context-en3: There are five hardships in life and one of them is migraines.
meaning-exp: From previous number+? words, you can probably guess that this word means five things.
reading-exp: The reading of this word is the kun'yomi reading of the kanji ?, meaning you didn't learn it when you learned the parent kanji reading. To remember this word, think of it this way: You have five things. What do you have to do with them? You need to eat (??) them. If you come up with something crazy you have to eat, and focus on the fact that you must eat five of these things, it will help a lot too.

context-en: There are no pictures for question four.
context-en2: There are four big, white, 10 million yen balls in the king's room.
context-en3: I had all four of my wisdom teeth pulled out.
meaning-exp: This vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji (single alone kanji usually do that!), meaning it means four.
reading-exp: When a vocab is alone like this with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually uses its kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception, though, and use the on'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to count to four. But you're tired. One... two... three... *YAWN* ... four. There, you did it. But *yawn* now you can't stop yawning. You're so, so sleepy. Four is too high a number to count without falling asleep. By the way! Both the reading ?? and ? are pretty common, but because the on'yomi reading ? sounds just like the word for "death," it isn't used as much. Generally when you're just counting (for example, "1, 2, 3, 4..."), you will use the reading ?. But when you are counting things or people, you'll use ??. There are exceptions to this, but you'll learn them as they come up.

context-en: He’s a shogi genius.
context-en2: That French woman is genius.
context-en3: That gorilla is definitely a genius.
meaning-exp: A genius from heaven is still a genius.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

context-en: The ladies' room is over there.
context-en2: I am not a girl but a woman.
context-en3: It is essential that I improve my strength as a woman.
meaning-exp: A woman child is just a girl!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Girl, Young Girl, Young Lady, Young Woman
context-en: The girl wearing the ribbon is Hanako.
context-en2: She is such a cute girl, isn't she?
context-en3: The girl who was my first love didn’t like carrots.
meaning-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana stuck in the middle you can guess that it is like putting two separate words that you've learned together into one word. This hiragana is ?, a particle that makes something possessive. In this case, the ? is of the ?. Basically, this suggests that the woman is a child, aka a girl.
reading-exp: Since there's hiragana in here, you can bet that these kanji will use the kun'yomi readings. You already know the kun'yomi reading for ?. The only thing I have to make sure that you know is ?. When you need to remember the kun'yomi reading of ?, just think about you fighting a child (you're a jerk, apparently!). When you hit him in the face, he flies to the floor, and the ref calls out "KO!" because you just knocked the poor kid out.

vocab-meaning: Good At, Skillful, Skilled At, Skilled
context-en: Satou is good at singing.
context-en2: Do you know any princes who are good at using olive oil?
context-en3: I’m good at making funny faces.
meaning-exp: Think of someone holding out their hand. This is average. Things rated below the hand are things you're bad at. Things rated above the hand are things you're good at.
reading-exp: Both of these kanji use on'yomi reading, though ? uses an on'yomi reading you didn't learn with the kanji. It's a rare reading, so it wasn't included (and we just have to deal with exceptions like this as we go along). To remember the reading for this word, here's a mnemonic: What are you good at? You're really good at taking Jourm (???) to the zoo (?). No one else can take Jourm to the zoo, he gets mad and throws them into the animal enclosures. But you? Jourm trusts you.

context-en: My hands got really dry.
context-en2: Don't hit on my girlfriend.
context-en3: Teacher, why are your hands so hairy?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Since this is a body part, the kun'yomi reading usually takes priority. That means you learned the kun'yomi reading already when you learned the kanji.

context-en: Pochi became a star in heaven.
context-en2: God in Heaven definitely saw me steal Koichi's 4000 yen.
context-en3: I won the rock-paper-scissors competition and I felt like I was in heaven.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it would normally use the kun'yomi reading. The kanji that makes this word only has one important reading, though, and that happens to be the on'yomi. Since you learned the on'yomi reading for this kanji, you've already learned the reading for this word.

context-en: I finished inputting the data.
context-en2: Please enter the prince's social security number here.
context-en3: Do you use "romaji input" or "kana input"?
meaning-exp: Enter something with all your strength and you will look down to see that what you're doing is inputting data. You're inputting it right now! Into this site! The answers you enter into WaniKani with all your strength can be said with this word. Wow. Full circle already, and you're only on level 2. Look at you go!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I learned one thousand kanji in January.
context-en2: Which do you think there are more of: Americans who were born in January or Italians who were born in June?
context-en3: It’s not bad to eat ice cream in January.
meaning-exp: Since the kanji ? mean both moon and month (because a moon cycle is about a month, presumably), what is the number one month? In English we have an actual name for it, and that name is January.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. This is a specific month, so it uses the ?? reading.

context-en: Japanese curry is delicious.
context-en2: I'm gonna live in Japan starting in October.
context-en3: I baked a cake shaped like Japan.
meaning-exp: Remember the secondary meaning of ?? It's "origin." So, this word technically means "sun origin." Does that sound familiar? Japan's known as "The land of the rising sun." That's why Japan comes from ??.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well, though take note that the ? portion is shortened a bit. So instead of being ?? it is just ?.

context-en: I went to Tokyo in June.
context-en2: I will buy two katanas in May and test them at the Tofugu office in June.
context-en3: The weather for June is cloudy with a chance of meatballs.
meaning-exp: Since the kanji ? means both "moon" and "month," what is the sixth month of the year? January, February, March, April, May, June!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the ?? reading.

context-en: You aren’t my real child.
context-en2: When that Russian kid grew up she got better than a salmon at swimming upstream.
context-en3: Don’t you think my kid looks similar to Beyoncé?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You see a child and walk up to him. Then, you punch him in the face (oh no, how could you!!?). He flies through the air, and he's knocked out. A ref nearby yells that it was a "KO!" (?). That's a knock out. Make sure you learn this reading pretty well too. Both readings for ? are going to show up a lot, and this is how you're going to learn the kun'yomi one.

context-en: I am the king of this country.
context-en2: Please show me the King's sword.
context-en3: Even kings eat curry.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Left And Right, Both Ways, Influence, Control
context-en: That really depends on the weather.
context-en2: Viet's suspenders have different colors on the right and the left, it's so fashionable!
context-en3: Make sure you look both ways before crossing the street.
meaning-exp: Put left and right together and you end up with left and right! Just make sure you say them in the right order!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I’m left-handed.
context-en2: What's the name of the mountain on the left?
context-en3: I will never forget the time that girl got her left ear pierced.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine hearing someone to your left saying, "Hi Da'ri!" (???) which is supposed to be "Hi There," or "Hi Dearie." You turn left and there's no one there. You hear it again, "Hi Da'ri!" Keep turning to the left until you find the person saying hi to you.

context-en: I went back to my country on May fourth.
context-en2: Golden week is in May.
context-en3: I’m going to a river in May.
meaning-exp: The moon kanji also represents a month, so when you have five of these months, what month of the year is it? That would be May, the greatest month of the year (because it has towel day in it!).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the ?? reading.

context-en: The air conditioning was working well in the house.
context-en2: Thank you for giving me a response while you were busy.
context-en3: The parents were sitting with their child between them.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Something is coming from the middle of the wall. It sounds like a knock (??), knock, knock noise. You break down the wall, and sure enough there's some creepy dude standing inside. He is the knocker.

context-en: This ticket is 3000 yen.
context-en2: The princess took 10 million yen from the Royal Family and flitted away with a fishy American into the moonlight.
context-en3: I want to exchange my yen into American dollars.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to omit the ? in your answer as it is only a placeholder for a number.

context-en: The moon is beautiful tonight.
context-en2: June is the month when Mt. Fuji officially opens.
context-en3: If the pink moon comes out, that’s our signal to leave.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Look up at that big, bright moon. You have to open it up and take what's inside. To do that, you are required to have two keys (??), and they have to be turned at the same time. Imagine you and a friend both turning your keys on opposite sides of the moon to open up the center.

vocab-meaning: Nine Days, Day Nine, Ninth Day
context-en: Would you like to go watch some soccer with me on the ninth?
context-en2: Since Koichi hasn't seen Nikka for nine days, he feels so lonely he could die.
context-en3: Mami’s birthday is April ninth.
meaning-exp: Ninth day or day nine. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading-exp: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You learned this reading for ? when you learned ??, so you should be able to read this one too!

context-en: Two years from now I will turn sixty in October.
context-en2: It should gradually be getting cooler in October.
context-en3: It’s my fault that he’s acting strange; I asked him to go swimming even though it is October.
meaning-exp: The kanji for "moon" and "month" are the same, probably because a moon cycle takes approximately a month to occur. So, what is the tenth moon cycle of the year? That would be the awesome month October!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the ?? reading.

vocab-meaning: One Day, Day One, First Day
context-en: I was studying for the test all day yesterday.
context-en2: The fact that an American and French couple succeeded to climb Mt. Everest on June 1st is still fresh in people's memory.
context-en3: Did you really read this book in one day?
meaning-exp: This word has two different meanings. One day and first day. No matter how you look at this word, those meanings make a lot of sense.
reading-exp: The first meaning is one day, and it has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so you should already know this reading. The reading for first day, however, is a big old exception. It doesn’t take the on’yomi or kun’yomi readings, and has its own special (weird) readings. Here’s a mnemonic to help you remember this one: On the first day of your new relationship you can get two touches (????) only. That’s the rule! You can touch their hand and maybe high five. But that’s all you get. Just think when you’re on your first day of dating, two touches! Two touches only!

context-en: Ten million people gathered at the live show.
context-en2: That katana is one thousand yen.
context-en3: I farted at an elevation of 1000 feet.
meaning-exp: If you have one thousand, you have one thousand.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The only thing that's a bit weird is the reading of the ?. The ? turns into a small ?, making the reading for this word ????.

vocab-meaning: One Thousand Yen, A Thousand Yen, Thousand Yen
context-en: This skirt is 1000 yen.
context-en2: The price of milk rose by 1000 yen.
context-en3: That baseball player makes 5,000 yen per year.
meaning-exp: A thousand of these yen things makes this word one thousand yen.
reading-exp: Since you know the on'yomi readings of these two kanji, you should know the reading for this vocab word as well!

context-en: When I cut the onions, I teared up.
context-en2: You must be a genius if you could make this onion stand up by itself.
context-en3: How many onions can you hold under your armpits?
meaning-exp: ?? means "onion" in Japanese. But, there are different kinds of onions, right? This happens to be a "ball onion," which is just one of those round ones, like a Walla Walla Sweet Onion. Do you know?
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can guess it will probably use the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, that's the reading you learned with the only kanji in this word, so you should be able to read it!

context-en: Why do people buy cars?
context-en2: I heard that many Papuan people can breathe underwater.
context-en3: The people in the area are all just good natured people.
meaning-exp: Person person, why, that's more than one person. It's people! It's everybody!
reading-exp: The reading is the vocab word ? twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd, turning it into ??.

context-en: The prince started horseback riding.
context-en2: The Prince's left hand is big.
context-en3: After the prince kissed the frog, the frog ate the prince.
meaning-exp: A king kid is the prince. Someday he'll be the ?, if he's lucky, but right now he's just the king's child.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also take note that the reading for ? (?) is changed to ?.

context-en: The prince was enchanted by the princess’ beauty.
context-en2: The king bought a wooden desk for the princess.
context-en3: The princess expresses her joy by doing backward somersaults.
meaning-exp: The "king woman" is the princess. How do you tell this word apart from ??, which means "queen?" Well, the ? part comes before the ? when it's a queen, because the queen always comes before the princess (they're usually pretty selfish in the stories, right?). As for the princess, the ? comes after the king, because she doesn't have as much power. That's why this one is princess.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The puppies were born this morning.
context-en2: The puppy that was standing at the entrance was given the nine balls around its neck by the prince.
context-en3: Let’s pretend we’re puppies!
meaning-exp: A child dog is a puppy!
reading-exp: Even though this is a jukugo word, it doesn't use the on'yomi readings. Both the kanji ? and ? often favor kun'yomi readings, and this word is no exception. The reading for ? is the one you already know, and the reading for ? as ? is a really common one (perhaps you've already learned that reading?). If not, just think about punching a puppy in the face, and giving it a KO (That's a knock out).

context-en: That is the queen’s chair.
context-en2: The queen hates the princess because she is cute and has big eyes.
context-en3: I started exchanging letters with Queen Elizabeth.
meaning-exp: The woman who comes before the king is no princess. This is the queen.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Tomorrow we’re tilling the rice field with the whole family.
context-en2: That French person purchased a rice field for 40 euros.
context-en3: My first kiss was stolen by a scarecrow in a rice paddy.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When you learned the kanji that makes up this word, all you learned was the kun'yomi reading, so you should be good to go.

context-en: The photo on the right was taken in Tokyo.
context-en2: On the right are fifty of the king's favorite maids and on the left is a genius scientist who worships the prince.
context-en3: When the horse turned to the right, the donkey glanced right as well.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Look to the right. There are meat geese (??) over there. What are meat geese, you ask? They're geese made of meat, that sit to the right of you, trying to get you to do bad things. Like the devil/angel motif you see in cartoons. Well there's nothing on your left. And on your right? Just meat geese. Watching you. Waiting. Geese made of meat. Telling you not to do the right thing.

context-en: Please line up the round plates on the desk.
context-en2: The room with the round window is the princess's.
context-en3: I’m afraid of the full moon.
meaning-exp: This word is made up of a single kanji with hiragana attached to it. That hiragana ends with ? which means it's an adjective. So, what's the adjective form of the kanji that's in this word? ? means both "yen" and "round" but in this case we're looking at the round one (because something isn't going to be "yenny"). The adjective version of round is round or circular. Just like a yen coin, this "round" is a flat round. As in, if you draw a circle on a piece of paper, you could use this word. Same goes with yen, which is why "yen" and "round" both use the same kanji.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The reading for the ? portion of this word is the same as a kanji you're learning in this level: ?. That kanji means something really similar to this kanji. And guess what? They also share a reading. So, if you know that the reading of ? is ?? then you'll also know that the reading for this word is ??!

vocab-meaning: Second Day, Day Two, Two Days
context-en: I will go see a movie with my older sister on the second day of next month.
context-en2: It's been two days since the prince followed the puppy and disappeared in the woods of Mt. Fuji.
context-en3: If you study diligently, two days is enough to learn hiragana.
meaning-exp: Second day or day two. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense!
reading-exp: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: The circus is in town this weekend and you can't wait to get there. You want to show off your new foots car (???) to all the circus clowns. But you have to use your feet to get it there and it ends up taking you two days! Darn this old fashioned foots car!

vocab-meaning: Seventh Day, Day Seven, Seven Days
context-en: I was in bed for seven whole days because of a cold.
context-en2: I visit our family grave on the 7th of every month.
context-en3: I left the company after only seven days.
meaning-exp: Seventh day or day seven. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading-exp: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: You've been stuck inside working for seven days and today you finally have a day off. Your friend asks you if you want to go for a drive but you say, "Nah, no car today" (???), because you've been cooped up long enough. Seven days is too long to be inside.

context-en: Is Yamamoto’s phone number 612-7736?
context-en2: Let's meet at Mt. Fuji at six o'clock.
context-en3: Six times six is thirty-six, right?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. Numbers, as you know, are the exception to this rule. They usually use the on'yomi reading, and the on'yomi reading is the one you learned along with this kanji, meaning you should be good to go!

context-en: I climbed Mt. Fuji on my sixteenth birthday.
context-en2: There is an American who hasn't moved away from the entrance of Mt. Fuji for 16 years.
context-en3: I am forever sixteen.
meaning-exp: You have ten and six (not to be confused with six tens!). When you have ten and six, you have a total of sixteen.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

vocab-meaning: Sixth Day, Day Six, Six Days
context-en: Where did you two meet on the sixth of last month?
context-en2: What were you doing when you took six days off of school?
context-en3: A bear came into the bar on the sixth day of the month.
meaning-exp: It's the kanji for six and day. Put them together and you have the sixth day (or day six).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This is an exception, though. When you're counting days (at least one through ten), the kun'yomi readings are used. So let's think about that sixth day - what does it entail? The cow (moo / ??) is standing on top of your car (?). Why? Because you only feed the cow once a week, and that is on the seventh day. He's standing there on the sixth day because he's super hungry and knows it's almost time.

context-en: In my room, there is one table and six chairs.
context-en2: I brought back six stones from the river.
context-en3: I bought six packs of cups.
meaning-exp: Any number with a ? attached to it means you are counting that number of things. In this case, it's six things.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you do that: What are the six things that you need to count? This time you are counting six cows (???). The reason it's six, you know, is because you wanted a half a dozen cows. No more, no less.

context-en: These clothes are small on me.
context-en2: In this class, there are kids who are still small while there are kids who are as tall as adults.
context-en3: My ideal marimo would look like a small onion.
meaning-exp: This kanji has hiragana attached and ends with an ? sound. That means it's probably an adjective (and it is!). So, if you take the kanji ? and its meaning (small), you can figure out the adjective version of it. What is the adjective version of "small?" Actually, it's the same thing: small.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the ?? portion: When you think of the word small, try to think of this cheese (??) store. You go inside, and all of their cheeses are so small. They hand you a magnifying glass to see all the cheeses. You look at them and exclaim: "Why are these cheeses so small???"

context-en: This is Koshien’s dirt.
context-en2: If you bury seven of these marbles, you will hear the voice of heaven.
context-en3: Matt’s hobby is digging dirt.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: You look through the soil. You're trying to find something. As you dig and sift, you come across not one but two cheeses (??). Pull them out of the ground and put them in your mouth. How do the two cheeses taste and compare?

context-en: It is time for the sun to rise.
context-en2: Today is the important day that Tofugu is getting married.
context-en3: Shortly after sunset, it became so dark that I couldn’t read my book anymore.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Take note that this word means both "sun" and "day," though. Why? because the sun takes a day to go around and come back!
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: What do you feel from the sun? You feel the heat (?).

context-en: My sword was stolen by that samurai.
context-en2: That American has two katanas.
context-en3: Who’s the guy who just whipped out a sword?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. I'm hoping you already know this word - that will make everything much easier. It's ??? (you know what a katana is, right?).

vocab-meaning: Ten Days, Day Ten, Tenth Day
context-en: Please take this medicine for ten days.
context-en2: Please complete it within ten days.
context-en3: The tenth of July is the anniversary of my grandfather’s death.
meaning-exp: Tenth day or day ten. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading-exp: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: Ten days is just TOO (??) long from now. Maybe less would have been okay, but ten is too much.

vocab-meaning: Third Day, Day Three, Three Days
context-en: Where did those two people meet on the third, two months ago?
context-en2: I haven't had water for three days.
context-en3: The third day of March is Girl’s Day.
meaning-exp: Third day or day three. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Counting days, however, are an exception (at least up to ten). You need to use the kun'yomi readings to read this word. You already know the kun'yomi reading for ? from when you learned the word ??. Here is a way to remember the reading for ?: On the third day you have to give me (?) a ride in your car (?). I don't have a car of my own, so don't forget me, okay?

context-en: This cookbook is one thousand yen.
context-en2: That French person is a one-in-a-thousand genius.
context-en3: I ate a thousand rice flour dumplings.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Normally a single kanji making up a word like this means it will use the kun'yomi readings. Numbers are generally the exception, though, which means this word uses the on'yomi reading. If you learned the kanji, then you should already know this!

context-en: Sit up straight.
context-en2: The prince's mistake was corrected and his pride was wounded.
context-en3: If you can correct my mistakes, I’ll give you a reward.
meaning-exp: This word is made up of a kanji with some hiragana attached, ending in an ? sound. That means this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "correct," so what is the verb form of that? It would be to correct.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: After you correct something for someone, you yell out ta da (??) very excitedly. Go ahead and imagine yourself doing this a few times to help you to remember.

vocab-meaning: To Exit, To Leave, To Attend, To Come Out, To Go Out
context-en: Please leave using that exit.
context-en2: It looks like you have to sneeze, but can't.
context-en3: I made a hasty exit from that pachinko parlor.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "exit" so what is the verb form of this? It is to exit. Don't get this word confused with ??, though, which means "to hand over" or "to take something out." You can remember that this word means "to exit" because it ends with ? which sounds like the beginning of the word "room." What do you do with a room? You exit it.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to exit the room you're in. Why? Because it has a dead (?) body in it. Seriously. You should exit now.

context-en: That person standing over there is my brother.
context-en2: Please stand on the stone.
context-en3: The person standing over there is your future child.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" so what is the verb version of that? It's to stand.
reading-exp: You have to remember the ? portion of this word to learn the reading of it. Think of it this way: You have to stand up in order to wave goodbye to someone. When you stand up, you also say ta ta (?)!

vocab-meaning: To Stand Up, To Stand Something Up, To Erect, To Erect Something
context-en: How many candles will you put out?
context-en2: I’m looking for an easel for this photo frame.
context-en3: Could you please stand some pencils up on my desk?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" so what's the verb version? It's also "to stand." Don't confuse this with ?? which also means "to stand." It's a different kind of "to stand." With this one, you're standing something up. As in, "I stood up the action figure" or "I will stand up the flag." You're doing the action of standing something up.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ? portion. In order to do that, think of yourself standing up a huge sign. On it, written in big words: "ta ta (?)!"

vocab-meaning: To Take Out, To Hand Out, To Remove, To Turn In, To Put Out
context-en: Please put the dictionary out on the desk.
context-en2: That American removed all the venom he got from two rattle snakes out of his leg.
context-en3: The thief handed out all the goods he stole.
