meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "exit" and this is kind of a verb form of this. The word means to take out or to hand out, so it's like you're doing the action of causing something else to exit (rather than exiting yourself). You can remember this because the hiragana ? is like the word "sue." Imagine yourself grabbing her and removing her from a box. ?????.
reading-exp: The part of the word that you have to learn how to read is the ? portion. So, you already removed Sue from the box. Who else is in there that you have to remove? It's your Dad (?) as well. Go ahead and remove him from the box as well.

context-en: There is a cherry tree in my garden.
context-en2: My American friend's house is made of wood and bones.
context-en3: It wasn’t my first time falling from the apple tree.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You walk up to the tree. You have to get inside, because it takes you someplace secret. So, you take out your key (?) and put it in the slot, opening the door in the tree so you can slip inside.

context-en: It can only be used underwater.
context-en2: When I looked to the right, there was an underwater world in front of me.
context-en3: I can’t open my eyes underwater.
meaning-exp: If you're in the middle of a bunch of water, then you're most likely underwater.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Unskillful, Unskilled, Bad At, Not Good At, Not Skilled
context-en: I’m still bad at the guitar, but I practice every night.
context-en2: The person, who is not good at imitating Americans, is good at imitating French people.
context-en3: I’m bad at brushing my teeth.
meaning-exp: Think of someone holding out their hand at shoulder level. Anything above that equals "skillful." Everything below that equals "unskillful. So, in the case of this word, "below hand" means "unskillful."
reading-exp: If you're bad at something and you complain about it, then you're just a hater (??). Don't be a hater.

context-en: I really can’t do it.
context-en2: That prince is quite good, huh?
context-en3: It’s not very easy to make oneself a master of Mario Kart.
meaning-exp: The ? symbol just repeats the kanji that comes before it. You'll see it from time to time, so take note of it, even though it doesn't really have any meaning of its own. So, essentially ?? is the same as ??. That being said, you have something that's middle x2. When something is even more middle than middle itself, it is very or considerably something or another.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading, since it's like putting two single kanji together rather than a true jukugo word. To learn the kun'yomi reading, take a look at this mnemonic: From the middle of the middle comes a sound. It is a knocking sound. Knock. Knock. Knock. You open up the walls around this thing. Then you open up the second set of walls (middle of the middle). Inside is an old man, who identifies himself as "the knocker." You go inside of him and find another knocker as well. That's why it's a knocker knocker (????).

vocab-meaning: Very, Much, Greatly, A Lot Of, Very Much
context-en: Let’s learn a lot!
context-en2: The king said to the prince and the princess, "Go ahead and use a lot of money from the citizen's taxes."
context-en3: Please drink a lot today.
meaning-exp: When you do something with (?) big, you do it very, or with a lot of something.
reading-exp: You learned this reading when you learned ???. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

context-en: There was a volcanic eruption too.
context-en2: Mt. Fuji is a volcano. It will erupt in 42 hours.
context-en3: I’m sure that’s a volcano.
meaning-exp: A fire mountain is probably what you think it is: A volcano.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? reading is ?? instead of ?? because of rendaku (sequential voicing).

context-en: Can I have some water or tea?
context-en2: Don't forget to bring water when you climb Mt. Fuji.
context-en3: Give me a cup of water and some love, please.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You take a look at some water. It jumps out and takes the form of a woman. "Hello, my name is miss (??) Mizu," she says.

context-en: Can you put the white dishes on the table?
context-en2: Three out of seven stones were white.
context-en3: The man was as white as snow, so he was named "Snow White."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: The word "sheer" means: "A very fine or diaphanous fabric or article." When you think of a sheer (??) piece of fabric, I think you generally think of a white piece of fabric.

context-en: Please read the sentence faster.
context-en2: To my surprise, that American's English writing was written better than mine, and I'm British.
context-en3: Whenever I read a sad story I can’t stop crying for exactly two minutes and twenty seconds.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: You only had to learn one set of readings (on'yomi) for the parent kanji of this word. That means this word uses those readings as well, specifically the ?? one when alone like this. You can remember this by thinking how whenever you're working on your writing, you get hungry and want to eat a "bun."

context-en: I am five years old.
context-en2: I'll turn 67 on the 2nd of the next month.
context-en3: On my dad’s fifty-fifth birthday, I was invited to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
meaning-exp: Although this word consists of one kanji that is all alone, it doesn't share its meaning with the parent kanji. The meanings are similar in a way, though. This word means years old or age. With more years comes more genius, right? That's why this word means "years old" and not "genius," like the parent kanji. Hint: Stick this word onto numbers to say how old someone is!
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it! Don't try to type the ? part though.

vocab-meaning: A Few, Few, Scarce, Not Much, Not Many
context-en: There are few people who live to be 100 years old.
context-en2: I don't know how to cook many things.
context-en3: I’m often told by hairdressers that I don’t have much hair.
meaning-exp: This word has a single kanji with hiragana attached, ending in a ?. This means you know it's an adjective. What is the adjective form of few? It's also few.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is fairly difficult, as it's the kun'yomi reading (you can tell it's kun'yomi because of all the hiragana attached). You have to remember the ?? part to remember the reading of this word. Think of it this way: You have a few of something. This something is suckers (??). Imagine putting all (three-ish) of them in your mouth at once. How does it taste? Can you taste the flavors from each of the few?

context-en: There is only little milk.
context-en2: There are only a few left.
context-en3: His proposal was a little vague.
meaning-exp: This word is a single kanji with hiragana attached, though there is no specific clue as to what type of word it is. That means you can usually guess it's a noun, adverb or na-adjective (in this case it's a noun / adverb). The meaning of this word is pretty much the same as the kanji, though, making it fairly easy. The kanji meaning for ? is few, and the meaning of the vocab form is a little or a few.
reading-exp: Did you know that this word created an English word you probably already know? Have you ever heard someone say "just a skosh"? That's ??! Hopefully you know this English word and therefore know this Japanese word as well.

context-en: Am I American?
context-en2: There are two American people.
context-en3: I made friends with an American girl.
meaning-exp: The ???? part is pretty easy so long as you know katakana. It's the word for "America." You know that ? means "person," so you can figure out that America + Person = American.
reading-exp: Often times when two kanji come together to form a combo kanji you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. So, the reading of ? is the on'yomi reading ??, which you learned already in the kanji. This pattern works with almost any location as well. Just add a country name + ? and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.

context-en: How many arrows are left?
context-en2: Cupid is about to fire an arrow.
context-en3: A Native American arrowhead flew towards me.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Big Machine, Big Device, Machine, Device, Machine Counter, Number Of Machines
context-en: How many buses do we need?
context-en2: I ordered three machines that makes your eyesight better.
context-en3: The rich company president has three luxury cars.
meaning-exp: This counter is used with some kind of machine or device, usually a fairly large one (so nothing itty bitty). Cars are a good example of this. But it can also be used for things like computers, which were once the size of rooms, but are now nice and small. Thanks technology!
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to omit the ? in your answer as it is only a placeholder for a number.

context-en: I was born in Osaka City.
context-en2: The new mascot of the city has been decided.
context-en3: I puked on a Kyoto city bus.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

context-en: Apparently the company president is raising a cow.
context-en2: She came to a gyudon restaurant in a cow-spot patterned dress.
context-en3: Dave keeps cows for milk.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: You're leading the cows around the field. To get them to move, you yell out "USH, USH, USH!" (??) because you have a speech impediment and want to say "MUSH MUSH MUSH." Go ahead and say this out loud, yelling it if you can.

context-en: A glove was dropped in the doorway.
context-en2: I eavesdropped it at the doorway by accident.
context-en3: There were three pieces of toast in my doorway.
meaning-exp: Do you remember the words ?? (exit) and ??? (entrance) from previous levels? The ? can be a doorway of some kind. This word is literally "door mouth" but I bet you can figure out that this actually means doorway.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is mixed. You get the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, even though it's a combo (jukugo) kanji. Since ?'s only reading is the kun'yomi reading you should know it. Also, you should know the kun'yomi reading for ? as well from level 1. That means as long as you remember that this is a kun'yomi fest over here, you should be able to read this word. Also watch out for the rendaku (also known as sequential voicing). That just means the ? becomes the voiced ?.

vocab-meaning: Extremity, Furthest Point, End, Outskirts, Outer Limits, Edge, Miss, Failure
context-en: He lives in the outskirts of town.
context-en2: The princess was wearing a dress that doesn't suit the season.
context-en3: I bought some ice cream that had, "If you hit, you get another" written on them, but they were all misses.
meaning-exp: The kanji ? alone means "outside." This word means extremity. How can you remember this? Just think of the ? as a "ray of sunshine." Where you are, in the extremity of space, even the ?s of the sun cannot be seen. So, when ? is combined with ? just think of this.
reading-exp: Let's continue the previous story: You're off in the extremity of the space. You are at the edge, and you look further. All you can see is a sticky yellow haze (??) out in the infinite beyond.

context-en: Yamada’s eyebrows are very thick.
context-en2: This shop's noodles are thicker than I expected.
context-en3: My mom is so fat.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of the fat? It's the same: fat.
reading-exp: This is the kun'yomi reading of the kanji (because it's a single kanji, all alone with hiragana attached). The part you have to remember is the ?? portion. Let's use a mnemonic. The fat guy looked down and couldn't see his foot (??).

context-en: My father eats an apple every day.
context-en2: Even your father has something he doesn't understand.
context-en3: My dad’s cat is adorable.
meaning-exp: This word begins with an honorific (?) making whatever comes after it more elevated. Then there's ?, which you know means father. Lastly, we have the honorific (things you put on people's names in Japanese) ??. This is a nice way to say father. You use it when you're talking to your own dad or talking about him with friends. You can also use this when you're talking about your friends' dads. If you need to talk about someone's father that you don't really know, or you aren't close to, you'll want to use ???, instead. Don't worry, you'll learn that last kanji in a few lessons. Until then, it's pronounced, ?????. Kay?
reading-exp: The part you have to learn to read is the ? portion. This uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn when doing the kanji. Imagine your venerable father standing in front of you. Except, instead of being a human, he is a giant toe (??). Imagine him talking to you, giving you high fives, whatever. Just make it as ridiculous as possible while you're saying "Yes father. Yes father. Whatever you say, father."

context-en: I’m not lonely because my father is here.
context-en2: My father is German.
context-en3: My father is very good at milking cows.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of father. You use this when you're talking about your own father to other people, especially if you aren't very close to them.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

context-en: I bought five scales.
context-en2: There are five police cars parked in front of that house.
context-en3: The five vans smashed into each other.
meaning-exp: As long as you know both of the individual kanji meanings, you should be able to put together this one to get five machines.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Tanaka’s daughter got married to a foreigner.
context-en2: A drunk foreigner tried to pick a fight with me on the train.
context-en3: Leg length is quite different between Japanese people and foreigners.
meaning-exp: An "outside person" is a foreigner. This word is fairly common, though it's not super polite, either. It's okay most of the time, but it can be used derogatorily depending on the situation. The more polite version is ??? (outside country person) but you won't learn that until you learn the kanji for ?.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Since ? has two on'yomi readings, you can remember that for this word it uses ?? because foreigners like to wear jeans (??).

context-en: I made a French friend.
context-en2: Two of them are American and the other three are French.
context-en3: I met a very sexy French chef.
meaning-exp: ???? is "France." So what is a "France person?" That would be a French Person.
reading-exp: You can treat this word and the ? kanji on the end like jukugo (combo kanji). Usually, in the case of jukugo, you use the on'yomi reading. So here you'll want to remember to use the on'yomi reading for ?. If you want, you can add ? to the end of any place name to describe the people that live there!

context-en: I made ganache.
context-en2: I don't like raw veggies.
context-en3: Give me a draft beer!
meaning-exp: Normally a single kanji alone like this would mean the same thing as its parent kanji, but in the case of ? it's a little different (but still related). When you think of something that has life, it's something that's very fresh or raw. Think sashimi or sushi, for example. You want that to be as close as possible to life as you can. That's why you eat it when it's fresh, and that's also when you eat it raw. You'll see this word at the beginning of other words. For example, ???? is "raw egg."
reading-exp: This uses one of the kun'yomi readings. To remember this one, though, think this: When you get a raw fish in Japan, you never want to name (??) it, because you'll probably have to eat it (and that would be traumatizing!). Just imagine yourself actually doing that - how terrible would that be?

context-en: I went to Tokyo for my friend’s wedding.
context-en2: An American friend will come to Japan to visit me the month after next.
context-en3: My brother’s friend told me he has feelings for me.
meaning-exp: A person who is a friend is just that, a friend!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My leg hair is bushy.
context-en2: Our dog's fur falls off a lot.
context-en3: Right now the most important thing to me is the hair on my head.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Look down! You're wearing something covered in fur. It's a fur kevlar (?) vest! All kevlar is just really tightly woven fur. Didn't you know?

vocab-meaning: Girl, Young Lady, Little Girl, Maiden
context-en: That young lady is a famous idol.
context-en2: A genius, girl golfer has appeared for the first time in a long time.
context-en3: The dog and the little girl ran on the beach.
meaning-exp: A little woman is a girl or a young lady, since they can be anywhere from a kid to an adult.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m coming to Paris now on official business.
context-en2: This is an official account.
context-en3: We’re gonna steal government money.
meaning-exp: A public task is going to be government business. You have to think of this public as government to know the meaning of this word easily.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’ve read halfway through this book.
context-en2: Half of this class's students are girls.
context-en3: Roughly half of all Japanese people are ninjas.
meaning-exp: You have half a part. Half a part is still half, right?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’ve watched this movie three and a half times.
context-en2: There is only a month and a half left until the JLPT.
context-en3: She is as cute as a half-cooked egg.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it's supposed to use the kun'yomi reading. But, there is no useful kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so even the single kanji vocab word version uses the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned!

context-en: My heart constricted with longing.
context-en2: I couldn't help shouting in my mind.
context-en3: I wouldn’t know what to do if Anpanman had a cruel heart.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine a giant heart sitting in a rowing boat. It's also drinking cocoa. Focus on all three of these parts and associate them into one story / memory. Once you've done that, sing the "cocoa row" (???) song! I don't know what that song is, but I want you to make one up and actually sing it, out loud. If you do, I bet you won't forget this word's reading too easily.

context-en: Hello, how are you?
context-en2: "Konnichiwa" is often written in hiragana.
context-en3: Let’s shout, "hello."
meaning-exp: This is a strange one. It's ?????, which you've probably heard before, but it's spelled using the kanji now and day. So when you say "now day!" you're really saying hello! Warning! Don't mix this up with ????! While they may look the same, they don't mean the same thing. We will only ever ask you for ?????, so please try to remember that! We usually don't use kanji for this, so don't use it when you're writing. But you'll probably run into it in the wild so it's good to know!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be aware that the ? at the end is actually the particle ? so it's pronounced like ?.

context-en: This is the doll that Mary treats with a great deal of care.
context-en2: You should cherish your friends, partner, and family who stand by you.
context-en3: Whenever I hear that a document is very important, I always want to look at what’s inside.
meaning-exp: Think back to the old old olden days. Back when decisions were made with swords. A big cut is going to be important. Just imagine a couple samurai squaring off, then charging, then making one big cut. It's the most important thing they'll do in their lives (if they live!).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please paint the inside of the box pink.
context-en2: There is an enemy within.
context-en3: The thoughts I hide inside myself were spelled out in my diary.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: There's something inside and you wanna get to what's within. Look inside. Ooh, cheese (??)! Your favorite. Ooh cheese, how I love you.

context-en: Please don’t knock on the door.
context-en2: My cat likes scratching the door.
context-en3: This door opens and closes hard.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: Let’s play a game that uses marbles.
context-en2: In America, there is a contest every January where French people who are good at marbles gather.
context-en3: He gave me a single marble as proof of our marriage.
meaning-exp: Presumably this ?? is short for the word "bead." Beads used to be glass, which means that if you have a glass bead ball, you probably have yourself a marble.
reading-exp: If you know katakana as well as the reading that you learned when you learned the kanji ?, you should be able to read this. Just watch out for the rendaku.

context-en: It’s a fifteen minute walk from here to the station.
context-en2: That onion is the queen's portion.
context-en3: Do you know what a blowfish would do if you tickled it for seven minutes?
meaning-exp: This word has two meanings, both of which you learned with the kanji: minute and part/ portion.
reading-exp: This word is almost always attached to something, which is probably why this single kanji vocab word uses the on'yomi reading instead of the kun'yomi one. If you know the kanji reading, you know this vocab's reading as well, but the reading is different depending on the meaning: If it means minute, it's read ??. If it means part or portion, it's read ??. Probably because your buns come in two parts. Ohoho.

context-en: Where’s mom?
context-en2: I'm your mother, so I can pay for your flight for you.
context-en3: My mom’s nose hair is long.
meaning-exp: This word starts with ? which makes it more polite. Then, there's the kanji ? which you know means mother. Last, there's the honorific ?? which further adds respect (to the mother). So, this is the nice way to say mother. You use it when you're talking to your own mom or talking about her with friends. You can also use this when you're talking about your friends' moms. If you need to talk about someone's mother that you don't really know, or you aren't close to, you'll want to use ???, instead. Don't worry, you'll learn that last kanji in a few lessons. Until then, it's pronounced, ?????. Kay?
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You have to remember the ?? portion. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: What does your super nice mother do for you (this is why you're so polite to her!)? She drives you all around in her car (??) taking you wherever you need to go... soccer, kendo, whatever. What a nice mother you have!

context-en: My mother got in a taxi.
context-en2: My younger sister is getting to look like our mother more and more.
context-en3: My mother likes tofu and fugu.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of mother. You use this when you're talking about your own mother to other people, especially if you aren't very close to them.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, your mother is a terrible person and won't stop laughing at you: "HA HA HA HA HA!"

context-en: My grandmother is hospitalized at the municipal hospital.
context-en2: Please tell me the direction to the municipal library.
context-en3: I stood on my head in front of Osaka City University.
meaning-exp: The city stand is municipal in nature. Municipal means "of or relating to a city or its governing body", and this vocabulary means just that. Or just city. City is fine too.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There is a hospital on the north side of the station.
context-en2: North Korea launched a missile again.
context-en3: The ghosts in North America are so scary.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're going to the far north where it's very cold (north pole, perhaps?). One of the most important things you bring with you is a survival kit (??).

context-en: I’m reading the newspaper right now.
context-en2: What was I doing until now?
context-en3: Now I’m going to say good morning to my helmet.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What'll you drink now? I'll have a Zima, ima. Say "ZIMA IMA" ten times fast.

vocab-meaning: Number Of People, People, People Counter, Counter For People
context-en: There were 10 people, altogether.
context-en2: How many workers are in Tofugu?
context-en3: I have three children.
meaning-exp: When you see this on a number, for example 7? or 3?, you're using it to count people. Just remember, both ?? and ?? have alternative readings. From 3 and up it's just the number plus ??, like this. 5? is ???, 10? is ?????, etc. This is the counter for people, which makes this word the number of people.
reading-exp: The reading is the ?? reading of this kanji. Just think of a number of people, all ninjas, standing there as you count them out.

context-en: Satou’s dog is very obedient.
context-en2: What's with that guy? He is just a quiet nerd at school.
context-en3: He’s an obedient kid.
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ?? means "adult?" Well this is the adjective version of that. The I-adjective (see how it ends in ??). What adjective do adults want to be able to use for their own kids? They want to say they are obedient, quiet kids!
reading-exp: You already learned this reading when you learned ??! You should be able to read this too!

context-en: Those clothes are old, so I don’t need them anymore.
context-en2: If you hold onto old stuff, you can't get anything new.
context-en3: I found an old pair of underwear in our garage.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of old? It's also old.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana attached, it's going to use the kun'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi when learning the kanji portion, so let's use a mnemonic to help you with the reading of this word: If you're old, you're also full (??) of memories. And you're probably full of old secrets. And you're full from old people food.

vocab-meaning: One Hundred Thousand, Hundred Thousand, A Hundred Thousand
context-en: I won one hundred thousand yen at pachinko.
context-en2: This iPhone cost me 106,900 yen.
context-en3: Whenever I drink vodka, I get pumped full of hundreds of thousands of electron volts.
meaning-exp: Ten ten thousands is equal to one hundred thousand.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: These televisions are forty-nine thousand yen each.
context-en2: We're living in an era where you can make a living with a single computer.
context-en3: Could you call me a taxi?
meaning-exp: As long as you know the two kanji that make up this word, you should be able to figure out the meaning of this word as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Life is wonderful.
context-en2: My life is over. \(^o^)/
context-en3: Life is like a banana, you never know how long it will be.
meaning-exp: The kanji for person and life combined makes you think about human life. What is your human life like?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Yesterday, I ran into my ex-wife.
context-en2: The original article was deleted.
context-en3: I’m originally from the moon.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're trying to trace a person back to their origin so you can learn more about them. You finally get there - it's a castle. The problem is that it's surrounded by a huge moat (??) and you can't get past it because the drawbridge is up. Feel the frustration of this. Think about your goal and how close you are to getting to it if it wasn't for this lousy moat.

context-en: Let’s wait outside.
context-en2: The cats are staring at the bird outside of the window.
context-en3: I kept yawning outside all day today.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look outside, it's totally frozen. You throw salt (??) outside to melt the ice.

context-en: I live in Seattle now.
context-en2: My mother grew up in Seattle.
context-en3: I will send that funny picture of you to Seattle.
meaning-exp: The name of the city (????/????) with a ? attached to it means it is "the city of ____." You can do this with any city (try it out on your hometown!). Because of this, you should know that this word means Seattle, or more specifically City of Seattle.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It’s used, but I bought a Benz.
context-en2: There are a lot of secondhand stores in this area.
context-en3: I don’t want to get married to someone who is like a piece of used furniture.
meaning-exp: The combination of kanji doesn't make perfect sense, but it's alright. Take something that's middle old and you have something that's used or secondhand. It's not 100% old yet... it's still in the middle, meaning you can give it to someone else to use, like your younger siblings.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The baseball game was called off due to rain.
context-en2: Sorry, but it was decided that this project will be canceled for now.
context-en3: The live show I had been looking forward to was canceled.
meaning-exp: When something is in the middle of an action but it's stopped, this means it's put into suspension. Imagine getting frozen while you're running. It's kind of like that.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Task, Use, Duty, Service, Business, Purpose, Function
context-en: I have nothing to do.
context-en2: Do you need me for something?
context-en3: Don’t call me unless you have a reason.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: We ordered ten computers.
context-en2: We installed ten surveillance cameras.
context-en3: I want ten calculators for my birthday.
meaning-exp: If you know the two kanji separately, you should be able to put them together to form the meaning of this kanji.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Ten thousand yen is all I have.
context-en2: If this gets ten thousand retweets, I'll confess my love.
context-en3: Crap! I was cheated into accepting a fake 10,000 yen bill.
meaning-exp: When you have one ten thousand you just have ten thousand. In Japanese, though, you specify how many ten thousands you have, though (which is weird in English, but should make sense if you think about it).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The plane ticket to Japan cost 105,000 yen.
context-en2: Every year Koichi receives tens of thousands of chocolates on Valentine's Day.
context-en3: The estimate on a congratulatory gift is approximately 30,000 yen.
meaning-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's ten thousand!
reading-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

context-en: There is an important exam this month.
context-en2: Please complete this by the middle of this month, at the latest.
context-en3: My stomach hasn’t been feeling well this month.
meaning-exp: The now month is actually this month.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: On Sunday, Yang’s child was born.
context-en2: Please watch these home runs produced by the strong swings of a pro player named Michael.
context-en3: Do not make a newborn baby drink alcohol.
meaning-exp: Since this is a kanji with hiragana attached that ends with an ? sound, you know that this word is a verb. What's the ultimate verb version of the kanji ?? That would have to be phrased to be born. You can distinguish this one from ?? because this word is longer. Why is it longer? Because "to be born" must be a horrifying feeling. Although giving birth must be painful too, just imagine how long and terrifying getting born must be. That's why it feels longer.
reading-exp: You have to remember the ? part of this word to read it. To remember that, let's use a mnemonic: Just imagine someone being born. All they do is scream: UUUUUuuUuuUUUuuuUUUuu (?) the whole time. Go ahead and imagine yourself being born and doing the same thing. Say UUUuuUUuuu out loud to help you to remember.

vocab-meaning: To Be Cut, To Snap, To Break
context-en: The tape was cut.
context-en2: I feel lonely as soon as the phone line disconnects.
context-en3: This knife cuts well.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means cut so this means something is cut. Something breaks or snaps. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to be cut.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the ? portion: Something is snapping. Turns out that something is your arm. Your arm is a ? (?) that grew out of you one day. "What's this ki doing here?" you ask. Then it suddenly breaks in half! "OW OW OW! My ki! It's been cut!!"

vocab-meaning: To Be Disconnected, To Come Off, To Be Out, To Be Off
context-en: The sliding door came off.
context-en2: I got injured, so I'm going to be taken off the starting players.
context-en3: Since the plug was disconnected, Mr.Robot was no longer able to say, "thank you," anymore.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means outside so this is when something goes too far outside and disconnects. Something comes off. No direct object here, see? That's why this verb means to be disconnected or to be out
reading-exp: You have to remember the ?? portion of this word. Think of it this way - you're on your phone and you are disconnected. Why were you disconnected? You look around and see a yellow haze (??) floating around, melting everyone's phones. Well that's lame. Too bad you can't call anyone to help you get your phone back.

speech-type: Suffix, Transitive verb, and Godan verb
context-en: Next, you will cut the paper with your scissors.
context-en2: I'm looking for thread nippers.
context-en3: Even though I accidentally cut my hair shorter than I intended, more people have been flirting with me since.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut, and the verb form of that is to cut.
reading-exp: When you think to cut something, what do you think about cutting? One thing is cutting down a tree, which is also known as ?, or ?. You ?? a ?.

context-en: Today’s homework is question two on page twenty-one.
context-en2: Today's sales are less than usual.
context-en3: Oh, was today my birthday?
meaning-exp: The now day is what day? Oh, it's today.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is a complete exception, though the word itself is incredibly common and useful. When you think of "today" think about what you have to do today for work. You have to work in one of those mall kiosks (???). Just think about how sad you are that you have to do this today. What a crummy day. It's sunny outside and you're stuck in a mall manning this hermit crab kiosk. Note: This reading mnemonic is pretty far away from the actual reading, as far as reading mnemonics go. Use this to get yourself close, and then use your own brain grapes to get the rest of the way there. This one won't be as easy as most of the others, but do some good old fashioned memorization and you should be okay. I won't ask you to do this much, fortunately. :)

vocab-meaning: To Get Fat, To Gain Weight, To Grow Fat, To Become Fat
context-en: I’ve gotten a little fat from overeating lately.
context-en2: I envy people who don't get fat even though they eat a lot.
context-en3: The fatter I get, the hungrier I become.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fat so the verb form of that is to get fat.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You have to learn the ?? portion of this word to be able to read it. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You're getting fat so quickly that you can see your body expanding. You look down - at first you can see your foot (??) but then a second later you can't. You can't see your foot because you're getting fat, even when you stick your foot way out. What's going on?

context-en: His remark produced problems.
context-en2: Please do not post things that could give rise to misunderstandings.
context-en3: Even though it wasn’t my husband’s, I had no choice but to give birth to the baby.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life" so what is the verb form of that? Would it be "to do life"? No, probably not. In this case it is to give birth. You'll have to differentiate this one from the word ???? as well. You can remember that this one means "to give birth" because when you compare, the act of giving birth probably feels shorter than the act of being birthed, at least in terms of sheer terror. The pain of giving birth will make it feel quick, when you look back on it... but just imagine how traumatized the baby must be from going through that as well. So, the act of giving birth is shorter, just like the word itself!
reading-exp: You have to remember the ? part of this word to be able to read it. It's the same as ????, so that could help if you've learned that word already. If not, just imagine yourself giving birth, and all you can do is scream: "UUuUUuuUUuUuu!" (?).

vocab-meaning: To Live, To Be Alive, To Exist
context-en: I lost the will to live from heartbreak.
context-en2: I don't even know if he's alive now.
context-en3: My favorite anime character is currently in a critical moment between life and death.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life," making this word mean "to live."
reading-exp: You have to remember the ? portion of this word to be able to read it. Think of it this way and you should be able to remember it, though: What does it mean to live? Life is pretty icky (?? ... the ? comes from the hiragana part), but you have to take that ickiness and roll with it if you want to have a good life... if you want to live!

speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Godan verb
context-en: Ten minus four equals six.
context-en2: He probably says that stuff just to get attentions from girls.
context-en3: I pulled the trigger and shot the frying pan.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pull and the verb version vocab means to pull. This word has another meaning! When you pull numbers away from other numbers, what you're really doing is subtracting them. That's why this word also means to subtract.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading (?) is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

vocab-meaning: To Separate, To Divide, To Part, To Split
context-en: Let’s split this meat bun between two people.
context-en2: It was a decision that spelt the difference between life and death.
context-en3: If you split the pizza, could you give me the bigger half?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? (in this case ?) sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means separate (at least, that's one of its several meanings). So, the verb form of that is to separate. You'll have to differentiate this word with ??? which is very similar but has a totally different meaning. You'll need to learn the reading to do this, but think of it this way: You must "separate" your Wake (??) time from your sleeping time.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are to separate a couple of children that really have fun together. When you separate them, they begin to cry and scream: WAAAAAAAAAHHHH (?). Poor kids.

context-en: The car stopped at the red signal.
context-en2: I was so surprised I thought my heart leapt into my mouth.
context-en3: I couldn’t stop on the ice.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes to a stop. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to stop.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You come to a stop sign and decide to stop because the sign has a picture of a toe (?) on it. This toe looks eerily like a toe your Ma (?) has too... and your Ma always taught you to stop and look both ways before crossing her toes.

context-en: Stop the music please.
context-en2: Please hold your breath for 3 seconds.
context-en3: We need to stop him from running away.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stop and the verb vocab version of that is to stop something. This particular word is when you're stopping something (i.e. doing the action of stopping it).
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to stop something from moving. Maybe a car... or a door... or a person... whatever you want. To stop this thing, you throw out your toe (?), getting it smashed in the process. Imagine it bleeding and swelling up. How much it hurts! You put your toe out to stop this big thing, what a mistake!

context-en: I don’t know if this tastes good.
context-en2: I kind of got it, but I am not sure if I understood all of it.
context-en3: Do you understand Japanese?
meaning-exp: This is a strange meaning for this kanji. This word means to understand and the kanji means many things (understand is one of the lower meanings, which is why I didn't include it in the kanji). This word will often be written in kana alone, but it's written in kanji enough that I thought you should learn it. Think about it this way: You have to separate cars (?) into different groups. Why? Because that's the only way to understand their behaviors and culture. All the Hyundais over here... All the Toyotas over there... Now study them to understand.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you separate all the cars out to understand them, they get really sad. They like being together with their car friends. So, they begin crying and wailing. "WAHHHHHH" (?) they cry out. "WAHHH."

context-en: There is a person who uses a name similar to Tofugu.
context-en2: North Korea uses nuclear weapon to threaten others.
context-en3: I tickled her with a brush used for painting.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Task and use. This verb is like a more formal way to say "use," and that is to utilize.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to learn the ?? portion of ????: What will you utilize to get the job done? You have mochi in your hand, so you'll use that. Now go think of some kind of imaginary task you'll complete with mochi, making it as ridiculous as possible.

context-en: These grapes were 20,000 yen!
context-en2: Congratulations on twenty thousand followers!
context-en3: I will bet twenty thousand dollars.
meaning-exp: When you have two ten thousands, you have twenty thousand.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Why do you have two cell phones?
context-en2: There are two pianos at Koichi's mom's house.
context-en3: There are only two televisions in our bathroom.
meaning-exp: When you combine these two kanji, you should be able to see how it forms the word two machines.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Which one do you prefer?
context-en2: Please go that direction.
context-en3: I don’t like the way she laughs.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but it can be either that or the on'yomi reading, depending on the context. You haven't learned the kun'yomi reading for ? yet, so there's a mnemonic to help you: You need to go a certain direction. How do you get there? By jumping into a catapult (??) and shooting yourself the right way. Need to get a particular direction fast? Consider the catapult next time.

context-en: My friend’s room is spacious and clean.
context-en2: That French person has a wide forehead.
context-en3: Wow, this place is huge!
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of wide? It's also wide.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned in the kanji section: ??, making this ???.

context-en: It snowed a lot this winter.
context-en2: It's an illustration I drew last winter.
context-en3: Don’t make light of winter or you’re sure to have a painful experience.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the kun'yomi reading you learned for the kanji, meaning you should know both!

context-en: I was bullied by a woman.
context-en2: The cafe was full of women.
context-en3: I’m not good at talking to women.
meaning-exp: The ? particle makes it so the ? belongs to the ?. Basically, this literally means "a woman person" or "a person of woman." It's a more polite way to say plain old woman, though, so all you have to remember is that.
reading-exp: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 1 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

context-en: Don’t rely on other people’s money.
context-en2: Being that you are someone other than myself, you may not understand, but this onion is my lifesaver.
context-en3: He was kinder to me than I could have ever expected from a stranger, but it was just because he thought that I was his aunt.
meaning-exp: When you have an other person, you really have another person.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: As Soon As, Just After, Immediately After, Promptly, Quickly
context-en: Thank you for your prompt reply.
context-en2: I wonder if this is because it's the end of year, but people are passing by quickly.
context-en3: It’s too cruel to demand money right after the start of the new year.
meaning-exp: Essentially you have the kanji ? twice, because ? is just a repeater kanji. When you have something early twice, it obviously has some kind of urgency to it. You'll need to take an action as soon as you finish whatever it is you're doing there.
reading-exp: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

context-en: I check the atmospheric pollution map everyday.
context-en2: The sky is blue because blue and green lights are scattered in all directions by the air molecules in Earth's atmosphere.
context-en3: Air conditions are unstable nationwide again today.
meaning-exp: If there is a big energy it's going to fill up the atmosphere! Think about big energies you feel in the atmosphere: thunderstorms, tornadoes, the aurora borealis. Just remember, this is the atmosphere in the sky, not the atmosphere in a fancy restaurant.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The baby girl was born without complications.
context-en2: This cute baby girl's name is Emma.
context-en3: I want to see a picture of you from when you were a baby.
meaning-exp: ??? is the honorific you put on a child's name. So, who is this mysterious child you're calling red? When a baby is born, what color are they? You got it, they're all red. And, because you want to be nice and cute you add ??? to that. That's why ????? is a baby.
reading-exp: If you know the reading of the kanji ? you should know the reading of this too.

context-en: These chopsticks are made of bamboo.
context-en2: If you cut a bamboo to about a meter high, it dies and even its roots wither.
context-en3: I love working with bamboo! I made my television out of bamboo. It doesn’t work, but it sure looks nice.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is also the reading you associated with the kanji, earlier.

context-en: I’m boiling bamboo shoots.
context-en2: If you go up north from the entrance of Mt. Fuji, there is a place where you can dig up a lot of bamboo shoots on your way.
context-en3: "Hey, man. It’s cool, it’s cool. Take all the bamboo shoots you want," said the panda.
meaning-exp: What is a child of bamboo? That would be a baby bamboo. Because "baby bamboo" doesn't really make sense, we'll instead call this word bamboo shoots. P.S. Fresh bamboo shoots cooked on a fire are delicious, make sure you try them sometime.
reading-exp: If you know the readings of the kanji for ? and the vocabulary for ? you should be able to read this word as well.

vocab-meaning: Bold Letter, Bold, Bold Character, Bold Text, Boldface
context-en: Make this character bold, please.
context-en2: When I got on the elevator in my apartment, the bold, red message appeared saying "Earthquake! Get out of this elevator right now," on the electric bulletin board so I got really scared.
context-en3: Let’s put this in bold to add more emphasis.
meaning-exp: What do you think a fat letter is? If I were to guess, I'd say a bold letter.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is a bit odd. The ? uses the ?? from ??? (kun'yomi) and the ? is just the normal on'yomi reading for "letter." You have to remember this weird mismatched reading pair on your own, I'm afraid. Perhaps if you think about how fat letters don't really fit with the rest of the text, kind of like how the readings of both kanji also don't fit in it will help?

context-en: The boy loved baseball.
context-en2: Police officers generally bring young offenders in to the police department's juvenile division.
context-en3: I wasn't a naughty boy, but a dimwitted and hesitant one.
meaning-exp: Someone of few years is someone who's young. But, back in the day the Japanese and Chinese tended to favor the boys, so this one means boy, usually a young boy. Sorry girls! Use your irritation at this kanji to remember it better.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I don’t like bugs.
context-en2: That insect is spinning white thread from its mouth.
context-en3: No, that bug doesn’t bite. However, I will bite you if you still kill it.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, which is also the reading you learned when you learned this kanji!

context-en: We have a white calf.
context-en2: This calf is very energetic.
context-en3: Daddy! Santa Claus gave me a calf last night!
meaning-exp: You have a child cow. What do you think a child cow is? Probably a calf or a baby cow.
reading-exp: Since you should know the readings of the words ? and ? from the previous level, you should be able to read this word too even though it's using the kun'yomi readings for the kanji.

context-en: How come you’re always so calm?
context-en2: The princess is a type of person who wouldn't get upset even if she lost her pet puppy.
context-en3: My husband was fired, but I’m surprisingly calm.
meaning-exp: You have a flat energy. What kind of energy would be a flat one? Probably a cool or calm one. You'd also tell people about this flat energy by saying you are all right or just okay.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Can See, Visible, To Be Visible, To Be Able To See, Able To See
context-en: Can you see the red flag over there?
context-en2: I can't help thinking about how others think of me.
context-en3: The sun was so bright, I could barely see how high the balloon had risen.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means see, and the ?? (with the ? in there) suggests that this is "potential" form. So, instead of just being "to see" this word means can see or just plain old visible.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). So as long as you know that you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: I went to the ocean in my car on Sunday.
context-en2: I wonder if somebody could give us a ride.
context-en3: My car wouldn’t be able to make it all the way to Florida.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You visit your mom who lives inside of a car. It's sad, and you feel bad. The first thing that pops out of your mouth is: "Cool Room, Ma (???) because you don't know what else to say about your ma's living situation. Be sure to sort of cut off the last letters of the first two words... something like "coo' roo' ma!" Sad thing is, there is only one room in this car your mom calls home.

context-en: That’s Tanaka’s older sister standing in the center.
context-en2: I’m waiting for you at the central ticket gate of Osaka station.
context-en3: I have a little dent in the center of my head.
meaning-exp: The middle of the central... that is really, really in the center if you ask me (and is very central as well). This is one of those "overdid it on the meaning" words.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please write the character more carefully.
context-en2: I married a man whose eyebrows are shaped like the character for eight.
context-en3: What does this character mean?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: You only learned one reading for the kanji that makes up this word, and it's the same as the reading for this word (of course). That means you should already know the reading.

context-en: This cat’s ears are brown.
context-en2: I love bread crusts.
context-en3: I named my left ear Mimi. My right ear doesn’t hear very well, so I named it Mama.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji. So you should be able to read this word already.

context-en: We arrived 15 minutes earlier than scheduled.
context-en2: I think it's too early to ask her out.
context-en3: A tofu maker always wakes up early in the morning.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of early? It's also early.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading, which you did not learn when you learned the kanji. You have to remember the ?? portion to be able read this word. In order to do that, here's a mnemonic: You're fast! You're early! Your chop comes down onto your opponent's neck so quickly! As you chop him, you yell "??!"

context-en: How is your father?
context-en2: Kana is full of energy.
context-en3: He seemed fine but apparently he had a bad diarrhea.
meaning-exp: What is the origin of your energy? It is your spirit and health (though this vocab word also means energy as well).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’ve been feeling great since this morning.
context-en2: I feel like going on a picnic now.
context-en3: If you marry me, I think I’ll be in a good mood for the rest of my life.
meaning-exp: Part of your energy is your feeling or your mood. Just think of it like you're breaking up your energy into parts. One part is sugar giving you energy. Another part is your happiness. So, when you combine these together you get the total: your mood!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The fireworks are only going off on Friday.
context-en2: I went to see a fireworks display with my family yesterday.
context-en3: Fireworks have a great smell, don’t they?
meaning-exp: The flower fire... what looks like flowers on fire? That would be fireworks. Totally makes sense, right?
reading-exp: The readings for the kanji that make this word are the kun'yomi readings, where fire's ? changes to ?. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for ? when you learned the kanji, so it's only a matter of remembering to use the kun'yomi for ?. If you do, you should be able to read this word.

vocab-meaning: First Of All, To Start With, Firstly, To Begin With
context-en: First, we do the prep work.
context-en2: Why don't you declutter the stamp collection you've been working on for fifty years first?
context-en3: First you need to pluck the chicken and then name each of the feathers.
meaning-exp: The kanji means previous. This is an adverb version of that word. It's a little thing you can begin sentences with. You can't start your sentences with "previous" but you can start it with "First of all" or "to start with." This is usually written without kanji though, so keep that in mind.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. In fact, the reading for this word is very rare, and kind of an exception. We'll use a mnemonic that uses both the kanji part and the hiragana attachment part. First of all and to start with, you have to make it through this maze (??).

context-en: Kawashita has a brother who is a first year student in elementary school.
context-en2: This April, I’m starting the first year of middle school, my little sister is starting the first year of elementary school, my older brother is starting the first year of high school, and my mother and father are starting the first year of university.
context-en3: I haven’t even learned the kanji that first grade elementary school students know yet.
meaning-exp: You'd maybe think this just means one year of life, but it actually means first year student. A second year student is a ???, and so on. Just think about how crazy the Japanese are about school. You can see why school is life, and not life itself, making this vocab word "first year student."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please memorize five hundred kanji by the end of March.
context-en2: Japan has 500-yen coins.
context-en3: "How are we going to get five hundred horses into one car?" asked the woman. "You’re right! Do you think I should have bought the van instead?" the man replied.
meaning-exp: When you have five hundreds you also have five hundred.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi readings for both kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

context-en: Put your PC somewhere flat, please.
context-en2: That girl put eight red marbles in a flat place.
context-en3: Do you remember the name of the pasta that is thin, long and flat?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same with a little hiragana sticking out. Because the hiragana doesn't really indicate what it is, it's okay to assume that they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a kanji plus some hiragana attached, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Something is very, very flat. Perhaps someone who doesn't eat much, like a model? Which model? Let's imagine it's Tyra (???) Banks.

context-en: The sunflower is a very beautiful flower.
context-en2: In the language of flowers, this one means bushy nose hair.
context-en3: I want to learn how to cook with flowers. Have you ever heard of flower soup?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned when you learned the kanji, so you're good to go. Don't forget to stop and smell the roses on the way, though.

context-en: I have a tattoo on my leg.
context-en2: When I was a kid, I thought hands were feet and feet were hands.
context-en3: If I cut off my foot it will grow back soon, right?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. A foot is a foot, you know?
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: If you remember in the radical/kanji mnemonic, you kick someone with your foot. But what happens after you kick them? Turns out they were made of fire, and you just burned your foot off, turning it to ashes (??). Imagine this happening.

context-en: I have forty T-shirts.
context-en2: That genius American is 40 years old.
context-en3: Since reaching my forties, my entire body has been itchy.
meaning-exp: What do you get when you have four tens? You get forty.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The only exception to this is ?, which uses the kun'yomi reading, since the on'yomi reading sounds too much like the word for "death." Luckily you know these reading already, so there's nothing new to learn!

context-en: Please make four hundred copies of this document.
context-en2: There was an incident where 400 people went missing overnight in the city of Seattle in the US.
context-en3: How did you spend four hundred dollars on a toothpick?
meaning-exp: When you have four hundreds, you have four hundred.
reading-exp: This word has a number in it, so it uses the kun'yomi reading for it. But the reading for ? is the on'yomi reading. This is pretty normal when it comes to counting numbers in Japanese. You know both of these readings already. Hooray!

vocab-meaning: Fourth Day, Day Four, Four Days
context-en: Why don’t you come watch baseball with me on the fourth of next month?
context-en2: July 4th is Independence Day in America.
context-en3: Four days after I met that bear, my back started growing mold.
meaning-exp: Fourth day or day four. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Counting days, however, is an exception (at least up to ten). You need to use the kun'yomi readings to read this word. You already know the kun'yomi reading for ?, so that's fine (the ? gets turned into a small ?, though). Think of it this way: On the fourth day you pour yogurt (??) all over your car (?) because on the fifth day you're going to have to eat (??) it. (?'s kun'yomi reading is ??).

context-en: There are four oranges in this box.
context-en2: Please give me four small onions.
context-en3: This morning, I ate four or five croissants.
meaning-exp: Any number with a ? attached is a word that means "NUMBER Things." In this case, it's four things.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can assume it uses the kun'yomi reading. The ? part of ?? gets converted to a small ? though, so watch out for that.

context-en: I hit four thousand followers.
context-en2: This is the only tofu in the world created by China with great 4000 years of history.
context-en3: I love you so much that I could knock down four thousand telephone poles at once.
meaning-exp: You have four and you have thousand. Multiply them together and you have four thousand.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's true for the ? part, but the ? reading is kun'yomi. You should know how to read this word as long as you've been studying your kanji!

vocab-meaning: Head Of Household, Husband, Head Of A Household, Head Of The Household, Landlord, Master
context-en: Did you and your husband go somewhere yesterday?
context-en2: I'm afraid you bought too many of them, master.
context-en3: My husband is a politician who doesn’t have any conviction.
meaning-exp: The master person isn't just a master. You have to think back to when they were making these kanji. Who was the master? It was the head of household. This head of household probably told servants what to do and was all bossy and stuff. He was the master person. Also, this often means husband. Because, I guess the head of household back in the day was the husband. Those sexist ancient people!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I watched a bunch of movies over the holiday.
context-en2: Have a nice holiday!
context-en3: I spent the holiday in my tree house.
meaning-exp: When you have a rest day you have a holiday.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ? reading is the alternate reading, ??.

context-en: I read one hundred pages in one week.
context-en2: When you get to Level 100, Prince, you can change your job from prince to king or queen.
context-en3: I can buy a bunch of different things with a hundred yen.
meaning-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's one hundred!
reading-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

context-en: Please make the ice.
context-en2: I ordered a bubble tea without ice.
context-en3: "Why did that woman forget to put ice in my glass?" "She was hit by a car earlier today. She must have been a little dizzy still while making your drink."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is what you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: In Its Entirety, Whole, Wholly, Entirely
context-en: I’m memorizing the whole song.
context-en2: Please give me the whole cow, not half.
context-en3: This cake is filled entirely with apples.
meaning-exp: If you go to (??) a circle, you need to go to it in its entirety. That means you have to circle around the whole thing. Otherwise, it isn't even a circle. It's like a line or a squiggle or something.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading, so you should be able to read this too!

context-en: Who did something dishonest?
context-en2: There was unauthorized access from China and all of Tofugu's social media accounts were hacked.
context-en3: My aunt always talks about her personal acts of injustice and deception.
meaning-exp: When you have something that's not correct, you have no justice. In fact, you have injustice. Just imagine yourself being put in an unjust situation, and think about how not correct it is.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Inside The Car, In The Car, In A Car, Inside A Car, Within The Car, Within A Car
context-en: Please wait in the car for a bit.
context-en2: There was a fidgety-looking man with a Starbuck's cup on a bus in Seattle, but it was actually a handsome prince from Dubai.
context-en3: It seems like somebody left some bacon in the car.
meaning-exp: The car inside is simply that, inside the car.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That ring with the red jewel is somebody's lost property.
context-en2: That billionaire has his maids use cleaning tools decorated with jewels.
context-en3: The princess turned the beautiful jeweled bracelet clockwise.
meaning-exp: A treasure stone is a very valuable stone. What kind of stones are considered treasures? How about a jewel?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I met Tanaka last month.
context-en2: I saw your older brother in the municipal hospital last month.
context-en3: They had a cosplay party last month.
meaning-exp: The previous month is last month.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I came to Japan in April of last year.
context-en2: Last year, I participated in the Summer Comiket for the first time.
context-en3: He is fatter than he was last year because he eats hamburgers every day.
meaning-exp: The past year is just last year.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My older sister has a mole on her left hand.
context-en2: Please raise your left hand.
context-en3: I got a light bulb tattoo on my left hand.
