meaning-exp: The kanji for "left" and the kanji for "hand." Put them together and you have a left hand.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This word, however, uses the kun'yomi readings, combined. This is possibly because of ?, which is a body part. When a body part is present in a word, oftentimes it gets changed over to kun'yomi reading for who knows what reason. Either way, both kanji use the reading you learned in this word, so you should already know it.

vocab-meaning: Letter (Of The Alphabet), Character, Letters, Characters, Letter
context-en: Make this letter yellow, please.
context-en2: Michael took eight hours to write a letter to Koichi in hieroglyphics.
context-en3: It looks like that email from you contained corrupted characters, what did you write?
meaning-exp: A writing letter is simpler than it sounds. It's really just a letter, right? You're reading ?? right now, in fact!
reading-exp: The reading for this word is just the jukugo, but the reading for ? is a little bit modified. Instead of the reading ??, which you learned with the kanji, it's just ?. You can remember this because you're shortening this word in a way as well. The "writing letter" is shortened to "letter." So, think of ?? being shortened to ?.

vocab-meaning: Lifetime, One Lifetime, Generation, One Generation
context-en: He made the company this much larger in just one generation.
context-en2: Koichi went to take a once-in-a-lifetime gamble.
context-en3: He amassed an enormous fortune over the course of his lifetime and his son doubled it.
meaning-exp: This word has the kanji for one and period. You only have one period to live in so this is the only lifetime you get. Unless you're reborn, but that will probably be in the next age, not this one. So one lifetime for you!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m mainly studying Japanese.
context-en2: Primarily red and white cars are sold in Portland.
context-en3: He is a researcher who is mainly interested in bananas.
meaning-exp: ? means main so when you add ? it becomes the adverb mainly.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You mainly spend your time talking to your master Moe. But you mainly address him like, "Oh Moe The Great!" (??). That's because he's above you. Imagine yourself saying "OH MOE THE GREAT!" as you walk into his room, bowing low.

context-en: Who is that man?
context-en2: I have a plan to go play pachinko with my guy friend.
context-en3: I developed quite a rapport with a man I didn't know at a fireworks show.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: There is a man. Think of the manliest man you can. He works in an auto shop. As a child, he was an auto ? (???), working at the auto shop from an early age. This turned him into a man very quickly. Like other mnemonics that aren't lined up quite perfectly, your goal here is to get close enough to remember the true reading. Step, step, step, jump!

context-en: He is a kendo master.
context-en2: She is one of the four haiku masters in this country.
context-en3: Not only is he an expert at chess, he’s also a master at cards.
meaning-exp: A person whose name is known (because he's famous?). Why is this person's name known? Why is this person famous? It's because they are a master / expert at something. How else does someone become famous or well-known? That's pretty much it, even if they're just an expert at being an idiot.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please teach me how to bow.
context-en2: My French friend taught me how to greet people in the French way.
context-en3: "How to Drive" became a best-selling book this year.
meaning-exp: The doing way is basically a "way of doing" something. More simply put, this is the method. "What's your way of doing this?" No no no. "What's your METHOD." There we go.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji ?, and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji ?. You've learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to read this already!

context-en: I heard that this CD sold a million copies.
context-en2: We are planning to make a Tofugu ornament made of gold with the million dollars we profited from WaniKani.
context-en3: A million people attended the AKB48 court case.
meaning-exp: one hundred ten thousands is how much? Multiply the two together and you get a million.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Month Before Last, The Month Before Last
context-en: I took a trip to Cuba the month before last.
context-en2: Two months ago, due to the heavy rain in the city of Seattle, the city's famous onion field was entirely destroyed.
context-en3: My mom paid my cellphone bill the month before last.
meaning-exp: The previous previous month (remember that ? just repeats the kanji before it) is the month before last.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m making rice dumplings for moon viewing.
context-en2: I am planning to have a moon viewing party with my friends tonight.
context-en3: My grandpa passed away from choking on a mochi cake on a moon viewing day.
meaning-exp: When you moon see something, you're doing a moon viewing.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. For ? you already learned the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji. For ? you'll have to think back to the vocab word ? which uses the ?? reading. Combine these two together and you have ???.

context-en: Please tell me the name of this flower.
context-en2: Last summer, the movie "Your Name" became popular in Japan.
context-en3: I still don’t know her name.
meaning-exp: This vocabulary word is the same as the 'name' meaning of the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll have no trouble remembering this word as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Just think of the first part of the English word name. What is it? It's na (?), just like this word!

context-en: Which train car are you going to ride in?
context-en2: The first fortune-telling robot with 100% accuracy was made by a genius scientist and a genius engineer.
context-en3: In Japan, we usually hand out an extra issue of the newspaper for free.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This word is made up of a single kanji all alone, but it uses the on'yomi reading. This is probably because you'll usually see this word attached to other things, like numbers. This shows the edition or number of an item. So, even though it's alone, it's usually used like jukugo, which is why the reading for this one is the same as the reading you learned when you learned the kanji.

vocab-meaning: One Breath, One Go, One Sitting
context-en: I drank the bitter medicine down in one gulp.
context-en2: It was such a relief to see my father, who looked well.
context-en3: My great-grandma ate two hundred gyoza in one sitting.
meaning-exp: It's weird to think of having one energy. But, what gives you energy? You do it one time every couple of seconds. That would be taking breaths. So, "one energy" is one breath.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the individual kanji, though ?? from ? is shortened to ??.

context-en: He has a really single-minded personality.
context-en2: I feel that many men who are not popular among girls are naive and single-minded.
context-en3: My best friend has a one-track mind; he’s 90 years old and still has feelings for his first love.
meaning-exp: You have only one book energy. No other books cross your mind. Only this one book. Why? Because you have such a one track mind.
reading-exp: The reading is based off the on'yomi readings for everything, though every reading is slightly altered. ?? getting shortened to ??, ?? changing to ??, and ? gets changed to ?. They're based off the readings you know already, though, so making this shift shouldn't be too hard... that is, unless you have an ???, ammiright?

context-en: Any other questions?
context-en2: It looked like the other students in the class weren't great.
context-en3: Let’s throw these eggs at his house some other day.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need to go for a drive to the public gardens, but you aren't going to get your normal car, you're going to get your other car. Your hoe car (??)! It's a car made entirely out of garden hoes. You can drive it and hoe with it at the same time! Your other car can't do that!

context-en: My absolute favorite band is on hiatus.
context-en2: Could you tell me the difference between sleep mode and hibernation mode on the computer, please?
context-en3: I'm trying to take little breaks and exercise frequently during work.
meaning-exp: A stop that's just a rest (aka not permanent) isn't a straight up stop. You're planning on continuing again. That's why this is a pause.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I did the dishes and then went to bed.
context-en2: Arrange these bamboo shoots on a plate and it's done! \(*?* )
context-en3: Stop using our good plates for target practice!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is also the reading you learned when you learned the kanji.

context-en: This beer is very popular.
context-en2: I am probing into why that doujinshi is so popular.
context-en3: "I am the most popular berry collector around here," said the bear.
meaning-exp: If a person has a lot of energy then they're very charismatic and fun! What's another feature of charismatic / fun people? They are most likely popular as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Then I’m going to go to the post office and buy stamps.
context-en2: That foreigner bought 10,000 postage stamps.
context-en3: Since I lost her, I've lost interest in stamp collecting.
meaning-exp: To remember the meaning of this word, just think about how in the olden days, before perforation was invented, people had to cut their postage stamps by hand. It took forever, especially if you had a lot of friends to mail things to. Be thankful that perforation was invented to save you time cutting them.
reading-exp: You'd think that the reading for this would consist of the on'yomi readings, but human body parts (hand) do funny things to words. In this case, it's the kun'yomi readings of both the kanji. You should know the kun'yomi reading for ? and ? from the previous levels, meaning you should be able to remember the reading for this word fairly easily. Watch out for the small ?, though.

context-en: You should start with the problems you can solve.
context-en2: If you go straight up this street and over the river, you will enter North America.
context-en3: I’m sorry, but I have a prior engagement with my ex-boyfriend today, so I can’t meet up with you.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When I think about the word "previous" I think of the beginning of a TV show where they say "previously on..." Let's go with that. Previously on Lost (or some other show), everyone gets stuck inside of a sack (??). Imagine all the characters in the TV show writhing around inside of a sack, trying to get out. You can differentiate this from ?? (??) because it doesn't have a hiragana add on. It's plain. It's boring. It's just a sack (and also means the same thing as the kanji it comes from because it's a single kanji with nothing attached, which gets you to previous, which gets you to ??).

context-en: Please take the red shoes.
context-en2: I’m thinking of dyeing my bangs red next time.
context-en3: My cheeks still go red when I hear the name Orlando Bloom.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: Could I have the red necktie?
context-en2: This year the red nail polish is popular.
context-en3: The girl wearing the red knit hat is skating.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of red? Why, it's red!
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: When is Kato’s next day off?
context-en2: During lunch break, I ate shaved ice at a cafe.
context-en3: Tomorrow is my day off, so I’m planning to play Mario Kart by myself for the entire day.
meaning-exp: The kanji rest has a little hiragana attached, but it's nothing that would suggest it's anything but a noun (it is!). It means the same thing as the kanji, rest.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: So, do you want a rest from work or school? You should say "Yes!" (??).

context-en: Yamashita has a black umbrella in her right hand.
context-en2: There was a little girl holding a marble in her right hand.
context-en3: I prefer to use my right foot, right hand, and right eye.
meaning-exp: The kanji for "right" and the kanji for "hand." I don't think it gets any clearer than this!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This word, however, uses the kun'yomi readings, combined. This is possibly because of ?, which is a body part. When a body part is present in a word, it usually changes to the kun'yomi reading for who knows what reason. Either way, both kanji use the reading you learned in this word, so you should already know it.

context-en: He’s one of the second generation Japanese-Americans.
context-en2: Not many children of celebrities can be celebrities too.
context-en3: I didn’t know that my father is a second generation Japanese-Britain.
meaning-exp: The two generation is the second generation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How soon before you make a serious effort?
context-en2: Koichi is finally getting serious.
context-en3: You didn’t seriously think I pulled that guy’s hair out, did you? Give me some credit.
meaning-exp: What is book energy? It is energy you put into reading - it is your studies! In order to have book energy, though, you have to be very serious.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I eat shaved ice a lot in hot summers.
context-en2: This shaved ice with red syrup is tomato flavored.
context-en3: The best feeling in the world is when you throw super cold shaved ice with syrup on someone you hate.
meaning-exp: This is ?? ice, which is shaved ice.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the same as the one you learned (???) except it gets converted to ??? because it comes after ??, so it's rendaku'd.

context-en: Shall I buy clams on my way back?
context-en2: My body gets itchy when I eat shellfish.
context-en3: I swallowed my engagement ring because I hadn’t noticed he put it in the oyster shell.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.

vocab-meaning: Shortage, Physical Shortage, Insufficient, Not Sufficient, Not Enough
context-en: I don’t have enough change.
context-en2: Due to the lack of funds, the project that the central government planned was suspended.
context-en3: You are fired because you lack experience and are always sleep deprived.
meaning-exp: You have something that's not sufficient. When something isn't sufficient, you have a shortage. Keep in mind that this is a physical shortage, not a shortage of mental ability or something like that. To remember this, just think about how ? also means "foot." What is a foot? Something physical. That's why this is a physical shortage.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Small Plate, Small Dish, Little Plate, Little Dish
context-en: Please set the small plates on the table.
context-en2: Why don't we just serve foods into small plates by ourselves and eat at our own pace?
context-en3: It’s impossible to put this huge steak on that tiny dish.
meaning-exp: You have a small plate. Wait, is that it? Yep, that's it.
reading-exp: ?? uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, except it's ?? this time because of the rendaku. ? uses an alternate kun'yomi reading. You can remember it by thinking "What are small? Kids (?) are small. Bwahaha."

context-en: She suddenly lost consciousness.
context-en2: Please come back safe.
context-en3: Are you out of your mind?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji that makes up this word. Lucky you!

context-en: You shouldn’t throw stones at people.
context-en2: A stone got in my shoe.
context-en3: The sound of stones colliding annoys me.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: You pick up a stone. You throw it through a window. Huh. That was surprisingly easy. Do it again. Throw the stone again. It's so easy, just do it.

context-en: The girl got angry and her mouth pursed into a straight line.
context-en2: After wiping moisture off the fish with paper towels, score the skin straight across.
context-en3: The swans flew in a straight line from our bathtub to the lake.
meaning-exp: When you have one writing letter what do you have? Here's a hint, there's one kanji in this word that consists of one writing letter (aka a straight line).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The ball landed on the green in one stroke.
context-en2: In tennis, a shot to start a point is called "service."
context-en3: Just one hit would turn the tables in our favor.
meaning-exp: You have one hit. What is (just) one hit? It is a strike or a blow.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I substituted yogurt for sour cream.
context-en2: You can use stockings as a substitute for the cord you wear under your kimono.
context-en3: We didn’t have glue so we substituted grains of boiled rice for it.
meaning-exp: A substitute task is a substitution.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What is Sakura’s last name?
context-en2: If you tell me Koichi's surname, I will give you a figure of Tetsujin 28 in return.
context-en3: I will never tell you my family name.
meaning-exp: A name written in letters is the surname. Back in the day your surname was the important name (it's your family name after all, and family was king back in the day). This is the name you'd write out in kanji... aka in letters. So, that's why this combination of kanji means "surname."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ? portion is the alternate reading, so adjust your thinking accordingly so you can get to ???. Just imagine someone saying "more" with a funny accent. They say "myou" instead of "more". Imagine them saying they have myou people in their family than yours. Their surname is spread amongst myou people than yours.

context-en: The teacher wrote a letter to Anna.
context-en2: When is Dr. Darin's next day off?
context-en3: What do you think of love between a student and a teacher?
meaning-exp: Previous life... So we're talking about someone who has a previous life, or maybe previous life experience? When you have previous life experience, you can teach others about it, making you qualified to be some kind of teacher.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Telephone Hello, Hello, Hello On Telephone
context-en: Hello? Hanako?
context-en2: Hey, hello? Are you listening???
context-en3: "Hello? This is Suzuki calling. Could I speak to Mr. Satou, please?"
meaning-exp: It's kind of like you're saying say say. This is what you say when you answer or greet someone on the telephone. There's a strange story about this. One reason you say ???? is because it's hard for foxes to say. So, you're confirming that the other person isn't a fox. The other explanation is that operators would say this, letting the person know on the other line that they're talking by saying "say say" but in a humble way. Either way, this is a telephone hello, so say it next time you talk to someone on the phone who is Japanese... just to make sure they aren't a fox. We usually don't use kanji for this, so don't use it when you're writing. But you'll probably run into it in the wild so it's good to know!
reading-exp: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji. You should know it already.

context-en: I wanted to thank you.
context-en2: I got a beer as thanks.
context-en3: I’d like to thank Spider-Man for taking back the streets and making our city safe again.
meaning-exp: The meaning of this word is the same as the kanji, except it has an ? before it, which just makes the thing you're saying elevate the other person more. Basically, it's more polite and awesome.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: The Other Day, A Few Days Ago, Other Day
context-en: Thank you so much for the other day.
context-en2: I heard that the festival I went to the other day in Hokkaido is held for twenty days.
context-en3: She was lying about being sick in bed for a few days.
meaning-exp: The previous day isn't necessarily yesterday. It can be any recent day, which is why this word means the other day.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ? reading is the alternate reading, ??.

context-en: Louis III was a French noble.
context-en2: Most of the third generation Koreans residing in Japan cannot speak Korean.
context-en3: I watch the anime "Lupin the Third" every day.
meaning-exp: The three generation is the third generation. You can use this alone to say you're third generation Japanese or you can specify and say you're third generation something else.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Coil the thread here, please.
context-en2: Do you believe in the red string of fate?
context-en3: I used a needle and thread to stitch up the gash in my leg.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it should use the kun'yomi reading (which is the reading you learned with the kanji).

context-en: The basketball game was a tie.
context-en2: The battle to determine the best pickup truck in America is currently a draw between Toyota and Ford.
context-en3: I was so upset that our rock-paper-scissors game ended in a three way tie.
meaning-exp: When you pull something and separate it, you are making everything even. In a game, this would be a tie or a draw.
reading-exp: See the hiragana stuck in there? That's hinting that these use the kun'yomi readings. You learned the kun'yomi readings of these two kanji separately in the previous level, so if you know those you should know this word's reading as well.

vocab-meaning: To Be Enough, To Be Sufficient, To Suffice
context-en: I wonder if this much will be enough.
context-en2: Because the princess in Monaco is ignorant to most things, she thinks that 100,000 yen is enough to buy a car.
context-en3: I vow to drink enough wine to make something crafty with the corks tonight.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leg and sufficient. Of course, sufficient is the one we're going to go for, because you can't really "do foot" but you can "be sufficient." What's another word for this? To be enough.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the ? portion. Whenever we need to remember the ? we use the word "taco." What do you have enough of? What is sufficient? Turns out it's tacos (?). Your bunker is filled with them and it's going to be enough to last the winter.

context-en: Is your brother in these pictures?
context-en2: Among the 500 pictures I took this year, 103 of them had my father who had died last year in them.
context-en3: The guy in this picture was my first kiss.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means copy, but what is a copy? It is basically a photograph, which is why this word means to be photographed. You know this one is "to be photographed" because it ends with a ?. Someone thinks you're "rude" so they're photographing you.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? part. You're being rude, right? That's why you got photographed. Why are you rude? You're doing beatboxing, constantly saying ?????? over and over again. Say it out loud, too.

vocab-meaning: To Be Pleased With, To Be Satisfied With, To Be Happy With, To Be Pleased, To Be Satisfied, To Be Happy
context-en: I’m very happy with this hat.
context-en2: In order to please Prince Onion, I bought all the onions in America and built an onion palace.
context-en3: I hope you’re happy with your new puppy.
meaning-exp: You enter into the energy. When you're entering (positive) energy into something, you are going to be pleased with it. Just imagine yourself adding some physical, happy energy into something you're pleased with. Smile and feel pleased as well!
reading-exp: The ? portion is pretty straight forward. The ?? portion looks like it's supposed to be ??? but it's not. Do you remember ???/???? This one is kind of a mix of both of them. It's just ??. Just imagine you're so pleased with something that you just put everything together and end up with a combination of both of them (they both are so pleasing!). So it's not ??? and it's not ??? it's ??.

vocab-meaning: To Copy, To Photograph, To Take A Picture
context-en: Please copy the characters on the next page of your workbooks.
context-en2: I'm a big fan of the photos Viet takes.
context-en3: You must pay 1,000 yen in order to transcribe a sutra by hand.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means copy so you know this means to copy. You know this word means "to copy" because it ends with ?. You're copying the documents you need to sue (?) someone who screwed you over.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? part. To remember that, think of yourself as a beatboxer. You're saying ?????? over and over again. Thing is, the other beatboxer is going to copy everything you do. That's why you're suing him.

vocab-meaning: To Distinguish, To Tell Apart, To Differentiate
context-en: I can’t tell whether it’s real or fake.
context-en2: Is there a way to find out if my significant other is a psychopath?
context-en3: We should have put collars on our dogs, because now it's difficult to tell which one is mine and which one is yours.
meaning-exp: You see something, then you separate (???) it. This is the same thing as to distinguish.
reading-exp: You should know the reading of ? already. The second part, ??? is a word you should have learned in the previous level. Combine that knowledge together and you get the reading for this word.

context-en: Mom went out shopping at the department store.
context-en2: Since my husband went out with kids, I can play Dragon Quest as much as I want.
context-en3: I’m going out to the beach with my family on Sunday.
meaning-exp: You exit but you do it with ??? added to it. Just think of that ??? as you exiting while being "cocky" about it. You do this when you want to go out or to leave. You go out in a cocky way! This word can only be used for a person going out. You can't say a train ????'d.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned ??, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

vocab-meaning: To Hit, To Pound, To Type
context-en: Cabrera hit a home run.
context-en2: My teacher is the world's fastest keyboard typer.
context-en3: My mom went crazy and pounded my butt with a carrot.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hit so the vocab is to hit or to pound.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you haven't learned yet, but never fear! A mnemonic is here: Something is coming toward your face. It's black and spiky and it's definitely going to hit you right in the eye. It's an uni (?). Have you ever seen one of those things before? You definitely aren't going to be happy with whoever is trying to hit you with an uni.

vocab-meaning: To Replace, To Substitute For, To Substitute, To Be Replaced, To Be Substituted, To Be Substituted For
context-en: If you don’t mind, can I take your place?
context-en2: The prince found a new way to amuse himself, replacing kendama.
context-en3: I am looking for another genius to replace Steve Jobs.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means substitute, so we can get to the meaning of this word through that: To replace / to substitute for.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the ? portion. You have to replace your car (?). It is getting old, and seems like it will explode at any moment, literally.

context-en: I’m resting at home.
context-en2: You should rest up well when you can, and then work hard when you have to.
context-en3: The only time that I rest each day is when I’m sitting on the toilet.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rest, so what's the verb version of that? It's to rest.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to rest, right? Answer the question! You should say yes (??).

vocab-meaning: To Say Humbly, To Say, To Humbly Say
context-en: I am Koichi of Tofugu.
context-en2: Tofugu gives frank advice to young Japanese people!
context-en3: It goes without saying that my boss underwent a sex change operation. Now she’s very happy.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Say / Say Humbly. This is just the verb form, to say humbly. Please note that this is a very polite and humble way to say "to say" so it's used in especially polite situations. Because of this, it's probably going to be the ?? form, which is ????. You can also call this "to say" as well, just remember that it's humble and polite!
reading-exp: The reading for this kanji is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. High Fives.

context-en: In this problem, please listen to the questions while looking at the pictures.
context-en2: When I looked closer, the driver of the car the woman was in was my husband.
context-en3: Can you please look at my hand and tell me if it is shrinking?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means see so the vocab here means to see.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji (kun'yomi) so you should be able to read this.

context-en: What picture did the shop worker show the woman?
context-en2: It seems tops that show a bit of skin are popular this summer.
context-en3: If I win this poker game, I’ll show you guys my Charizard card.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. Also present is the ? which means you're causing someone to do something. You could say you're causing someone to see something, but that sounds weird. A better translation would be to call this word to show.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one that you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read it.

context-en: There are a lot of convenience stores in this town.
context-en2: It's dangerous to walk alone in this town at night.
context-en3: My town is famous for making the best invisible guitars.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You walk into this town. You hate it (because it's vocab, and who doesn't hate vocab?). So what do you do? You pull out a match (??) and burn this town to the ground. Whoa, you some kind of psycho?

context-en: Where did you hide the treasure?
context-en2: Could you magnify this treasure map by three and print it out for me, please?
context-en3: The Summer Jumbo Lottery ticket that I hid in the treasure chest is missing!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Anyone with some treasure is going to be a real talker about it. In fact, they act like they're the Egyptian Sun God, Ra, and they have way more treasure than they really do. Making them a talker like Ra (???), a Takara, if you will.

vocab-meaning: Twentieth Day, Day Twenty, Twenty Days
context-en: There is a test on the twentieth.
context-en2: It will be 2019 in twenty days.
context-en3: Payday is the twentieth day of every month.
meaning-exp: Two times ten days is twenty days.
reading-exp: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. The readings for ?? are exceptions, and ? takes the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help with that: If you make one hat for twenty days you'll have enough hats (??) to fill up your car (?) completely! That's a lot of days and a lot of hats.

context-en: Please preheat the oven to two hundred degrees.
context-en2: I got two hundred likes on Facebook.
context-en3: I gave the cashier two hundred dollars and told her to buy some deodorant.
meaning-exp: When you have two hundreds, you have two hundred.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Viewing Cherry Blossoms, Sakura Viewing, Cherry Blossom Viewing
context-en: I didn’t go sakura viewing this year.
context-en2: I'm gonna introduce you to the best cherry blossom viewing spots in Hokuriku region.
context-en3: Before I die, I want to have a drinking party under the cherry blossoms one more time.
meaning-exp: When you have flowers that you see you are viewing flowers. But not just any flowers. What flowers do Japanese people love viewing? That's right, this word refers to viewing cherry blossoms.
reading-exp: The reading for this vocab is all kun'yomi, but you learned the kun'yomi readings of both these when you learned their kanji. So no worries there. You can spend the extra time viewing the cherry blossoms.

context-en: There is a village nearby.
context-en2: Your mother was born in this village.
context-en3: Yes, I have definitely stepped in the horse poop in your village.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned already with the kanji. Huzzah!

context-en: The villagers are all old people.
context-en2: That line is kinda like something a villager would say in a fantasy game, isn't it?
context-en3: Pessimists say, "the glass is half empty," but the villager surprised me by shouting "Refill!"
meaning-exp: You have a village person. That isn't someone dancing while wearing construction worker clothes, that's a villager.
reading-exp: This word uses double kun'yomi for its reading, probably because it's like two separate words (village and person) put together into one big word. You should know these two kun'yomi readings (it's the main reading for ? that you learned and you should know ? by now), though you will need to look out for the rendaku'd ?? reading.

vocab-meaning: Way Of Seeing, Point Of View, Perspective, Viewpoint
context-en: I don't know how to look at this chart.
context-en2: There are various ways of seeing and understanding.
context-en3: If you look at it from a different point of view, we could consider Tofugu to be tofu that's fugu flavor.
meaning-exp: The way you see is the way of seeing something. This is like when someone has a dumb opinion and you're like "oh, okay, so that's one way of seeing it..."
reading-exp: This word uses the readings of the kanji you've already learned, even though they're kun'yomi.

context-en: The weather is bad today.
context-en2: Let's check the weather forecast.
context-en3: What’s the difference between weather and climate?
meaning-exp: What is the heaven energy? If you think about it, that's all the stuff that falls on us from the sky. Lightning, rain, snow, hail... What is all of that? It's the weather.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I have work on weekdays.
context-en2: Sadly, I probably won't be able to go because it's on a weekday.
context-en3: I am a chef but because I’m busy working on weekdays I usually don’t cook at home.
meaning-exp: The flat days are boring. They're the same. One day after another. That's definitely not your exciting weekends... that's your boring, flat weekdays.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ? in this one uses its ?? reading.

context-en: There was white snow falling outside.
context-en2: Our black cows are more energetic than the white ones.
context-en3: A fluffy, white rabbit was hopping in the field.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of white? White, of course!
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the vocab ? you learned, so you already know the reading. Go you!

vocab-meaning: Within A Year, Within The Year
context-en: It should be complete within the year.
context-en2: I'm aiming to reach 100,000 followers by the end of this year.
context-en3: The assassination must be carried out before the year is over.
meaning-exp: The inside of a year is what happens within a year.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This app still isn’t world famous.
context-en2: The world really is coming to an end.
context-en3: Other than assassins, nothing in this world is scarier than wasps.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: Since you have generations of people making up this world, think of the rapper generation. What do they say all the time (obviously I don't know anything about rap)? They say "Yo yo yo!" (?).

context-en: I hope you have a happy New Year!
context-en2: Once again, I was able to age this year without issue.
context-en3: The next year, Erika met a prince riding a white cow.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: This year I refuse to watch tosh.0's (??) show. It is terrible.

context-en: I went to Japan in 2011.
context-en2: My husband has been working on Mars since 2011.
context-en3: My father finally admitted to drug use in 2011.
meaning-exp: It's the 2011 year. I think the meaning is pretty obvious. This just means year 2011 or simply 2011.
reading-exp: The reading is a little trickier. You start with two thousand (??/???), then you need to add eleven to it (??/?????). Then, you simply add the reading for ? which you already know. You can assume it's the on'yomi reading because it's attached to something else, like a jukugo. From there, you get the entire reading.

vocab-meaning: Year Round, All Year, Whole Year, Throughout The Year, All Year Round
context-en: The sky in this town is dull all year.
context-en2: Tofugu employees work twenty four seven, year round.
context-en3: It rains year round in this country and my wife complains about it year round as well.
meaning-exp: The year middle sounds like it should be something like "the middle of the year," but it's not. Think of something that happens in the middle of the year and then all other parts of the year. It's just referring to everything within this year, which is how we get year round.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. ? does have a strange reading, though, which is ???. This is basically just ??? changing to ???, but since nobody uses ? it just switches to ? and you end up with ???. That's called rendaku.

vocab-meaning: Absent From School, Absence From School, School Absence, Leave Of Absence
context-en: I’m taking a one year leave of absence from university.
context-en2: When Viet was a college student, he took a year of leave from school and went on a journey of self discovery.
context-en3: "Do you know why Kelly has been absent from school for the past three weeks?" "Yes, apparently she has a really serious case of pink eye."
meaning-exp: When you rest from school you are absent from school. This is only for very long absences though, not a day or a week, but months or years. Think about it like taking an extended leave of absence from school.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Action, Acting, Gesture, Bearing, Treatment, Behavior, Behaviour, Movement
context-en: I love to see her picking flowers.
context-en2: What kinds of female gestures do men usually like?
context-en3: I was appalled by the smoking adults’ behavior.
meaning-exp: Things you end up doing in the grass and not inside probably take a lot of big actions and gestures. You have to do them outside on the grass because if you did them anywhere else you might break something.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this. Just watch out because rendaku makes ?? become ??.

context-en: Teach me about the effects of alcohol.
context-en2: I learned Newton's third law of motion at school today.
context-en3: Does this cake-flavored medicine have any side effects?
meaning-exp: When you make a task you're looking for a certain action and/or effect. What task can you make right now to get the effect of learning more kanji?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Remember when you learned the kanji for ? and we said you'll see some that take just ? instead of the whole ??? This is one of those!

context-en: Please just take the hint.
context-en2: The morning winter air is cold.
context-en3: The monkey in the pirate’s space ship will be reentering the atmosphere in 3 hours. He can’t wait to draw as much air into his lungs as possible.
meaning-exp: The sky energy... once known of as a mystical thing that kept us from flying into space. Now we know this is the air. It can also mean atmosphere, though, because that's what a bunch of air between the earth and space is called. ?????????!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That actor is popular with everyone.
context-en2: I heard that everybody likes the smell of parakeets.
context-en3: This seems to be the common impression among everybody.
meaning-exp: If we're talking about ten thousand persons, then we might as well be talking about all people and everybody, because that's a lot of people, you know?
reading-exp: The reading for ? is a bit weird. It's ?? instead of ??. So, when you think of this word and think of all people, think about how they're all cheering "banzai!" at the same time, together. BANZAI BANZAI ALL PEOPLE RULE.

context-en: The kappa is an ancient Japanese yokai.
context-en2: In ancient times, this pond was known as "WaniKani Pond."
context-en3: The toilet is a wonderful invention that has been handed down since ancient times to the present-day.
meaning-exp: If you come to the party wearing something really, really old, everyone will know you're from ancient times (as if your wrinkles didn't give it away already, right?).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: An Epic, Epic, Epic Saga, Masterpiece, Masterwork, Magnum Opus
context-en: This movie is a Hitchcock epic.
context-en2: The title of the most epic film this century is said to be, "A Life of Fugu."
context-en3: Every score that Beethoven wrote was a masterpiece.
meaning-exp: The big make! What is your big make? Bigger than anything else. It is your epic (as in an epic that you write). Also could be an epic, epic saga, and masterpiece.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please turn left at the next corner.
context-en2: I heard that the teacher got knocked out from hitting her head on the corner of a block of tofu.
meaning-exp: All three internal angles of an equilateral triangle are equal.
reading-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
kanji: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. But this word has two different meanings and each one has its own reading. You should make sure you don't mix them up. The first one is the reading you learned with the kanji. ?? means angle. The second reading (??), is something you haven't learned, and it means corner. Just picture a deck of cards (??). Now take one card at a time and fold them to make a corner. Now tape those cards into all the corners of your house. Why? Because it's artsy!

context-en: I’m interested in Japanese archeology.
context-en2: I'm going to quit this archeology job at the end of the month.
context-en3: You can study archeology at this university.
meaning-exp: If you often think about studying old things, it's called archeology. All archeology involves thinking about old things, at least a little bit.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The odds of winning the lottery are very low.
context-en2: Such a weak-hit grounder can't be a hit.
context-en3: The party I threw for my father’s 50th birthday was a success and he even found a new girlfriend there.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji right. What happens when you get "a right?" You get a success.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ? portion of this word to read it. What is the correct answer that will give you a success? It is the first answer, A (?).

vocab-meaning: At Once, Right Now, Immediately, Right Away
context-en: Let's go meet them right away.
context-en2: You can read season 1 of TextFugu right now for free.
context-en3: Be quiet and come over at once!
meaning-exp: You'll have to learn this word in two parts. You already know the meaning of ? because of the kanji, which means "now." The ?? part, however, is a new word, meaning "soon." The two words even start with the same "soo" sound. If you put these two together, you get "now soon." Put in better English, that's at once or right now.
reading-exp: Since you already know the vocab word ? (read ??), you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: I got off the train at a station near my home and went to the grocery store to buy beef.
context-en2: Last year, the import of UK beef was resumed.
context-en3: The beef is so undercooked. I may have a kitchen nightmare tonight because of this.
meaning-exp: What do you call cow meat? You call it beef (what's for dinner?).
reading-exp: Both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

context-en: I’m Japanese, but I was born in San Francisco.
context-en2: My wife is American-born Japanese.
context-en3: My birthplace is Osaka, but I was raised in Nara.
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ???? means "to be born?" Well once you're born that place where it happened becomes your birthplace!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned ????. Just drop the ? off the end and you have your reading!

context-en: There is a blue bird.
context-en2: That apple hasn't ripened enough yet, has it?
context-en3: Wow, this blue paint smells exactly like the red paint.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of blue? It's still blue!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? portion to read this word. Think of blue things on your body. Those are bruises. Touch them. What would you say? OW! (??).

context-en: When I take a bath, I wash my body first.
context-en2: Jamal, why is your body so flexible?
context-en3: My entire body is so itchy for some reason.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have your body. It's nice - looking good! What would really mess up your body? It would be a car raider (???). I'm talking about a dude who is a raider of some kind driving a car. If he runs into your body, you're done for, so watch out for the car raider. Of course, this mnemonic is only meant to get you close to the reading. Hopefully it is close enough to get you to the actual reading, ???.

context-en: The boy in front of them is Okada’s child.
context-en2: Congratulation, mom. It's a cute baby boy!
context-en3: That boy has so much energy. He just threw twenty eggs at his aunt’s head and managed to run away.
meaning-exp: A child of a man is no man, it is a boy.
reading-exp: If you know the kun'yomi readings of both of these kanji you should be okay. You have two separate single-kanji words put together by a ?. That's why it's the kun'yomi reading - they're separate.

vocab-meaning: Bread Loaf Counter, Counter for Loaves of Bread, Loaf of bread counter
context-en: I ate four loaves of bread in one sitting from stress.
context-en2: It'd be cheaper to bake your own bread if you're buying five loaves of white bread at a time.
context-en3: Eight loaves of bread will make twenty-three egg sandwiches and twenty-three tuna sandwiches.
meaning-exp: This has the ? for counters, so you can bet this shares the bread loaf counter meaning with the kanji.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: I have two siblings.
context-en2: Were Mario and Luigi brothers!?
context-en3: I like those brothers, but I hate their stuffed animals.
meaning-exp: You have an older brother and a younger brother. Wow! Both are here. These are brothers!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: There was a caterpillar on the cabbage.
context-en2: I thought it was a caterpillar, but it was actually my sister's fake eyelashes.
context-en3: I videotaped a giant caterpillar fighting a giant centipede.
meaning-exp: When you think of a fur insect what do you think of? My mind immediately goes to a caterpillar. Imagine the furriest caterpillar you can and touch it. How does it feel? Furry?
reading-exp: The readings for this word are strange. Both use the kun'yomi readings - ? uses the reading you learned with the kanji, so that's easy. The ? part is like the vocab word ? you learned in the previous lesson.

context-en: My house is close to the station.
context-en2: I'm wearing close to no makeup today.
context-en3: Drinking American beer is like doing somersaults in a canoe. It’s too close to water.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of near? It's close or nearby.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? portion to be able to read this word. Imagine someone close to you... Too close. They are so close to you that they're touching their cheek (??) to your cheek. Feel the cheek on yours, it's getting awkward.

context-en: What color do you like?
context-en2: Bell peppers turn from green to red when they ripen.
context-en3: I’m color blind, so my reds appear orange and my blues appear black.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji and uses the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, though, so enjoy.

context-en: How do you go to your company?
context-en2: Tofugu is a company that deals with things like developing Japanese language learning materials and delivering Japanese-related information.
context-en3: The president of the company I work for looks like a hamster.
meaning-exp: The place where your company meets is your company. Sony is a company. Nintendo is a company. Etc.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please hand this essay in to professor Nakagawa.
context-en2: I got 100 percent on the essay exam.
context-en3: My essays are still full of mistakes.
meaning-exp: When you make writing, what are you doing? Simply put, you're writing. If you want to be fancier about it, you could say this is composition.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Construction is not my strong point.
context-en2: I failed to set up a reasonable alibi.
context-en3: When I was in elementary school, I made a machine that makes ice cream for my school crafting project over summer break.
meaning-exp: What is the "industry of make"? Well, it's an industry where you make things, obviously. That can only be construction!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I am participating in the soccer tournament on Sunday.
context-en2: At fireworks events, ice cream sells well.
context-en3: I won the marathon because I couldn’t stop farting and all the other runners slowed down whenever they smelled them.
meaning-exp: When you have a big meet there's a lot of people together. Why would you have a bunch of people gather together? Probably for a convention or some kind of competition or tournament.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please look at the diagram below.
context-en2: If you click it, an enlarged view will appear.
context-en3: Your brother drew a simple diagram of the relationship between him and his girlfriend.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: While words that are made up of a single kanji usually take the kun'yomi reading, this one takes the on'yomi reading. Luckily, this is the same reading you learned with the kanji, so it shouldn't be too hard to remember.

context-en: We discussed Japanese diplomacy today.
context-en2: We have a shortage of diplomats.
context-en3: Japan isn’t very good at diplomacy.
meaning-exp: You want to mix opinions from outside your country into the way you handle things. That's called diplomacy. If you mix your country with the ones outside of your own, you'll all profit!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I grew up downtown.
context-en2: I'd like to go to a good old fashioned saloon in the backstreet areas of the old cities of Tokyo.
context-en3: A shitamachi is an old Japanese style of downtown; it isn’t the same as the downtown we think of today.
meaning-exp: You have the below town. Does this sort of sound familiar? We have another word for it in English, but it's essentially the same thing: downtown. It isn't the downtown you might be used to though. In Japan, this is an old word that was used for the commercial districts literally, physically down (lower than) the main city. So picture an old, urban Japanese area!
reading-exp: The reading for this word is all kun'yomi despite being jukugo. Just think of sketchy things going on in the downtown, just like how there's sketchy kun'yomi readings for this word. You should know both the kun'yomi readings from the previous level, though, so if you do you know the reading for this word as well.

context-en: My specialization is engineering.
context-en2: The engineering class at Harvard University was excessively difficult.
context-en3: I’d be perfect for this job, but I need an engineering degree in order to apply.
meaning-exp: Someone with the study of industry is someone who creates things. That would be the study of engineering.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I study every day at a Japanese language school.
context-en2: I'm commuting from Nagoya to Americamura in Osaka every day.
context-en3: I eat anywhere between 17-21 cheeseburgers every day.
meaning-exp: Every day is daily (or just every day).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There is a test at my school every month.
context-en2: Although my family wasn't rich, my parents sent a living allowance to me when I was in university.
context-en3: How much do you pay for rent each month?
meaning-exp: Every moon is every month (as you know from all the month-related vocab). This can also mean monthly.
reading-exp: The most common reading for this word has the on'yomi reading for ? plus the kun'yomi reading for ?. That makes it ????. But it can be read ???? using both on'yomi readings too. You can use either!

context-en: I enter this marathon every time.
context-en2: Koichi wiggles during each meeting.
context-en3: Every time I try to smile, my gums start bleeding.
meaning-exp: Every times is really just every time. Do you get your kanji readings correct ???
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Every Year, Yearly, Annually, Each Year
context-en: Where does Yamada go for her trip every year?
context-en2: That singer hints at retiring every year, so he must be saying it again this time just to get people to react.
context-en3: I’ve built a new door for the Johnson family every year for the past decade. Why don’t they just stop letting the troll use it?
meaning-exp: You have every and year to combine into every year (yearly works as well).
reading-exp: The reading for ? is what you'd expect. The reading for ? is the kun'yomi reading, though. So, use your knowledge of the vocab ? to help yourself to remember the reading for this word. You'll need to remember that the reading for this word is strange to get it into that brain of yours. That being said, the reading ???? works as well. I don't like this one as much as ???? but it's equally acceptable.

context-en: The small bird flapped its wings.
context-en2: I have eaten deep-fried chicken wings before, but I've never eaten deep-fried butterfly wings.
context-en3: "Do you know what kind of bird this feather is from?" he asked me, holding out some of his own nose hair.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with nothing attached it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read this.

context-en: Every morning I walk in the forest.
context-en2: I happened to catch Mrs. Hayashi speed walking in woods.
context-en3: I couldn’t wait until I got to the house, so I left my wet socks in the woods.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. You've already learned this reading with the kanji, though, so you should be able to read this.

context-en: When you talk using desu and masu forms you sound polite.
context-en2: A person who starts conversations with negative form sentences is likely to have some difficulties in communicating with others.
context-en3: Why did you just say that in past tense?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word share one of the same meanings: form. It doesn't just mean form though, it means tense too. Like verb tense.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: He’s been my friend for thirty years.
context-en2: My long-cherished wish has finally come true.
context-en3: I’ve been trying to ask her out for a few years now, but she always says she will be busy washing her hair.
meaning-exp: When you have years coming and going, you know it is for some years. Don't confuse this one with ?? which means "next year." The kanji ? comes after the kanji for year, so instead of "coming year" it's "years that come (and go)." At least, you can think of it that way to differentiate. You can also add numbers to this word. For example 5?? means something to the tune of "for five years." But this is a pretty formal word. Just keep that in mind.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That’s about right.
context-en2: We are about the same height.
context-en3: I generally get up at 6 o’clock.
meaning-exp: If all you can see is a big body of a person, then you'll only have a general idea of what they look like. You know their outline is quite big, but you don't know anything else.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I gave her a gold necklace.
context-en2: If I had money, I would like to buy the gold Rolex that Kim Jong-un has.
context-en3: This yarn will turn into gold in 24 hours and I’ll give you some as a Christmas present, so you should appreciate me more.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji you would normally think it uses the kun'yomi reading. Not this word, though. It still uses the on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji. Don't confuse this one with ??, though. That one uses kun'yomi which you know because it has a hiragana attached.

context-en: You have to cut the grass soon.
context-en2: I don't have money, so I live by eating grass.
context-en3: Why does my neighbor have such green grass? And why is his house so big?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Headquarters, Hq, Head Office, Company Headquarters
context-en: The headquarters are in Tokyo.
context-en2: On Monday, I visited Tofugu HQ.
context-en3: It’s so quiet in the head office today, I can hear myself not working.
meaning-exp: The origin company is where everything in your company comes from. This is your main base. This is your headquarters.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m a bit homesick.
context-en2: The nostalgic melody made me homesick.
context-en3: This puppy may be crying because he is homesick, but who cares?
meaning-exp: You have your home village and your heart. Your heart always resides in your home village, so when you leave you feel homesick. Young people don't really use this word anymore. It's more for the oldies. If you're an oldie, go right ahead. If you're a youngie, then talk to more oldies!
reading-exp: The readings are double kun'yomi. The kun'yomi reading is what you learned with ? already, though you'll have to pull out the ? vocab reading to remember it all. Not only that, the ? gets rendaku'd here making it ???. Make sure you watch out for that.

vocab-meaning: Home Village, Village, One's Parents' Home, Home Town, Hometown
context-en: When will you come back to the village?
context-en2: If you use language like that, you'll give away where you're from.
context-en3: I’m traveling to my hometown and I’m hoping I don’t run into anyone I know.
meaning-exp: This is the village you came from. This is where your parents live. This is your home village (same meaning as the kanji you learned).
reading-exp: The reading is the same as with the kanji you learned. It's like the village vocab word goes home to its kanji every once in a while. They share the same reading origin because of this.

vocab-meaning: How Many Days, What Day, Which Day
context-en: How many days of work were you taking off?
context-en2: What day would be good for you?
context-en3: How many days were you stuck on that island?
meaning-exp: What day equals the fairly obvious translation "what day." But, it also means how many days.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How many people participated in the party?
context-en2: How many people have been killed by the killer fish in this pond?
context-en3: How many people will be joining us for dinner?
meaning-exp: When you ask what people you're not actually asking "what people?" You're asking how many people. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that ?, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for ? and the on'yomi reading for ?. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that ? uses its ?? reading here.

context-en: Including this time, how many times have you come to Japan?
context-en2: This video is so funny that I have to watch it a bunch of times.
context-en3: How many times do we have to have this conversation until it finally sinks in? I am not Luke Skywalker. I played him in a movie. My name is Mark. I live in Chicago.
meaning-exp: What times? This doesn't make any sense. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that ?, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you. So, for this one it's how many times.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Imported words are written with katakana.
context-en2: I'm worried because the patient who would come to the outpatient clinic every day stopped coming.
context-en3: I’m really interested in foreign things because they’re so different from what’s in Japan.
meaning-exp: From foreign lands it has come. How would you describe that item? Simply by calling it imported or foreign. This word is also used in hospitals for outpatient clinic. That's pretty good to know if you plan on going to the hospital to get checkups in Japan.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My son is finally starting to be self reliant.
context-en2: I'm thinking of being on my own, if I recover from autonomic dysfunction.
context-en3: Share this if you are a strong, independent Japanese woman who doesn’t need a man.
meaning-exp: You are able to stand using your self. Nobody is helping you. Nobody is holding you down. This is your independence!.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Internal, Within The Body, Inside The Body
context-en: Do you know what function blood has within the body?
context-en2: The kabocha squash is high in beta-carotene and it's converted into vitamin A in the body.
context-en3: Blood circulates through the body regardless of whether it’s the body of a human or the body of a vampire.
meaning-exp: Something that's inside your body... hmm, could be a lot of things, but we can generalize and just say it's internal.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That’s really ironic, isn’t it?
context-en2: That butcher is a such a sarcastic person.
context-en3: Not one thing in the song "Ironic" is a proper example of irony.
meaning-exp: The skin on the meat is kind of like the outer shell. It's not very nice, and people who eat only meat skin tend to use sarcasm and irony. That being said, Japanese people don't really understand sarcasm. So, maybe that's why "meat skin" means "sarcasm." Is this ironic? Now I'm not even sure.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Joining A Company, Entering A Company
context-en: I joined this company in April.
context-en2: Tofugu's employment exam is more difficult than Google's.
context-en3: As soon as I graduate from college, I hope to either join a big financial firm or be the president of the United States.
meaning-exp: When you enter a company you're actually joining a company. Welcome, new recruit. Prepare to be hazed!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Large Voice, Loud Voice, Big Voice
context-en: Please don’t use such a loud voice.
context-en2: I couldn't help laughing out loud.
context-en3: Christina has a loud voice, and unfortunately, she’s not afraid to use it.
meaning-exp: A large voice is probably pretty large. Maybe even annoying, too. That's why this is a large voice or a loud voice.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is ?? (rendaku'd version of the reading you know: ??). The reading for ? is the kun'yomi reading, like with the word ??? (????). Just imagine a loud voice saying "??!."

context-en: The light from the sun is blinding, so please close the curtains.
context-en2: In the moonlight, your teeth look just like pearls, Kanae.
context-en3: There is still a slight glimmer of hope left for your child who was lost in North Korea.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have a ton of sunlight where you live. This creates heat. With this sunlight heat you're able to make your favorite food in the world: hickory (???) smoked bacon. Mmm, taste that delicious bacon.

context-en: It is four one hundred millionths of a light year from the earth to the moon.
context-en2: If we go north from the center of Portland for four light years, where will we be?
context-en3: A light year is the distance that light can travel over the course of one year. You are 10,000 light years too early to be facing me.
meaning-exp: What happens when light travels a year? You have a light year.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What’s the significance of reading literature?
context-en2: I was majoring in English literature in university.
context-en3: I think Haruki Murakami's work is pop literature pretending to be pure literature.
meaning-exp: If you study writing it's called literature. You'll get to study lots of things other people wrote before you!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Ah! Is that guy Suzuki?
context-en2: The lady next to the foreign guy standing over there is THE famous Kazuyo Matsui.
context-en3: The tall guy is wearing a T-shirt and the short guy is wearing a sweater.
meaning-exp: The ? particle makes it so the ? belongs to the ?. Basically, this literally means "a man person" or "a person of man." It's a more polite way to say plain old man, though, so all you have to remember is that.
reading-exp: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone).
