That being said, in level 4 you learn about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

context-en: There is too much food.
context-en2: There are many people who firmly believe that they are right.
context-en3: I wasn’t able to sleep because there were far too many people on the train, so I just sang loudly instead.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of many? It is also many (or you could say much). Speaking of which, there are so many kanji to learn, ammiright?
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of something that is many. Doesn't matter what it is as long as you imagine a ridiculous number of them. Many of them. So many that they start avalanching into you and crushing you. The last thing you yell is "??!!!" as you get smushed.

context-en: Maybe the umbrella is outside.
context-en2: Perhaps, she is a cosplayer.
context-en3: It’s probably going to snow tomorrow, so let’s make a snowman.
meaning-exp: You have many parts. Look at them all. You have to choose one of the parts. You can't decide which one you want. This one? Maybe. How about this one? Hmm, maybe that one too.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: On Wednesday, meat is cheap.
context-en2: Among beef, pork, and chicken, which meat do you like the best?
context-en3: Meat is the most important component between two slices of bread.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Luckily for you, this word uses the on'yomi reading that you learned even though it's a single kanji all on its own. So, you should know it already!

context-en: I’m having a girls-only party on Friday night.
context-en2: The assembly with those members sounds very interesting.
context-en3: Let’s open this meeting again!
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji meet. So it means meeting.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: This photo is more important than money.
context-en2: If you're careless with money, it's going to bite you in the butt.
context-en3: You should be aware that this machine takes your money and gives you nothing in return.
meaning-exp: The ? is an honorific that makes this word a bit more fancy. When you're talking about money you gotta be fancy, after all. So, you're basically saying "gold" in a nicer way. What was gold back in the day? It was money.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Makes sense since this is a single kanji with hiragana attached. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You've saved up a ton of money. With it you're going to buy something awesome. Then, suddenly someone hits you in the knees with a bat. Now you have to spend all your money buying a cane (??). Sucks for you :(

context-en: The moonlight was very beautiful that night.
context-en2: The bright moonlight was beaming down onto a white flower.
context-en3: She looked so beautiful in the moonlight.
meaning-exp: The moon light (not sunlight!) can be bright sometimes. This is night when you're stumbling home from a nomikai after work. What is this light from the moon called? It's moon light. This word can also mean a moonbeam as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi readings put together, though ? is modified and shortened a bit. ?? goes to ??. Make note of the different sized ? otherwise you'll be confused why you keep getting this one wrong over and over again!

context-en: I am having a birthday party next month, so please come too, Kanae.
context-en2: What day next month is the day of the fireworks display?
context-en3: Next month I’ll start scuba diving to find the glasses I lost at sea today.
meaning-exp: The next month is the next month! It isn't this month or the month before, it's the next one!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m thinking of going back to America next year.
context-en2: I plan to continue being a NEET this year, next year, and the year after that.
context-en3: Come at this time next year. I’ll have the biggest trailer in the trailer park.
meaning-exp: The next year is next year! It isn't last year or this year, it's the next one!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The airplane is heading northwest.
context-en2: If you drive about an hour and a half northwest from Portland, you will arrive at a city called Seaside.
context-en3: I lost my pantyhose somewhere northwest of here.
meaning-exp: This word is so simple. North + West = Northwest.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Older Brother, Big Brother, Elder Brother
context-en: You look like my older brother, Mr. Yamashita.
context-en2: A month ago, my older brother came home with a black labrador.
context-en3: My older brother likes eating tofu covered in coffee.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This implies that it is your older brother, by the way. Not somebody else's.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your older brother is different from everyone else's. He has odd powers... some would say powers of the force. Do you know what his name is? It's Ani (??), short for Anikin... wait a sec, does that sound familiar?

context-en: I finished the homework perfectly all by myself.
context-en2: That's the color you can only choose if you are confident with yourself, isn't it?
context-en3: Of course I talk to myself. Sometimes I need expert advice.
meaning-exp: You have your self part. Part of your self is you. This is oneself. This is myself. Wait, who is this part of me? You're not sure... wait, no, it's myself. Is it? Be a little psychotic for a moment as you try to remember this vocab word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please say it once more.
context-en2: I take a shower once a day during the week, but not at all over the weekend.
context-en3: Do you want it one more time, honey?
meaning-exp: One times is one time. How many times? Just one.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that ? is shortened (as it often is) to ??.

vocab-meaning: Open Taxi, Free Taxi, Empty Parking Space, Open Cab, Free Cab, Available Taxi, Vacant Taxi, Available Cab, Vacant Cab
context-en: When a taxi is displaying "Open Taxi," there are no customers aboard.
context-en2: I'm really curious why the parking lots around here are always empty.
context-en3: No empty taxis have passed us.
meaning-exp: When a car has sky in it (and not, say, a bunch of people) it is free to give you a ride. If you see this sign lit up on a taxi feel free to hail it down, it will be able to take you somewhere. It is an open taxi.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: This site was originally used as a turtle habitat.
context-en2: Do you know the original meaning of that word?
context-en3: Kanji in and of itself isn’t a bad thing.
meaning-exp: You want to talk about the origin where something comes from. That's where it is from originally.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Physical Strength, Physical Power, Stamina, Endurance
context-en: I have practically no physical strength.
context-en2: Koichi doesn't have stamina to do 80 push-ups.
context-en3: The fever weakened his body, but he was still strong enough to drink water by himself.
meaning-exp: You have your body power. This is just another way to say physical strength. Watch out, if you use too much of your physical strength you may run out of physical stamina and endurance completely! They're tied together, so make sure to pace yourself.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Public Corporation, Public Company, Government Agency, Federal Agency
context-en: If I remember correctly, he works at a public corporation.
context-en2: This passenger rail services were operated by the Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa.
context-en3: On April 1st, a public company called Japan Post opened for business and it wasn’t an April Fools’ joke.
meaning-exp: This is a public company, which can also be called a public corporation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It hasn’t rained yet.
context-en2: Unfortunately, I was born prince of a country that has rain all year long.
context-en3: I like the smell of rain and you smell like it. That’s why I love you.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, you learned this reading with the kanji.

context-en: Is that true?
context-en2: I heard that these days university students write essays on their smart phones, but I wonder if that's true.
context-en3: I’m really awful at it.
meaning-exp: What is real is right. It is the reality. It is also the truth. Don't believe anything that is not real and right.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There has been another boom in Japanese alcohol in recent years.
context-en2: It's a total lie that Disneyland hasn't been that packed in recent years.
context-en3: The existence of a tofu-eating fugu has slowly been coming to light in recent years.
meaning-exp: The close years are years that aren't too long ago. They are the recent years.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I forgot to buy rice.
context-en2: I heard that the weight of 100 million yen is about 10kg, so I tried to imagine what it would be like to hold 100 million yen while holding a bag of 10kg rice.
context-en3: My favorite breakfast consists of uncooked rice and miso soup.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word refers to the grains of rice more than something that's a meal. If you're eating rice at a meal you'd call it ???. This is like when you're talking about the rice in the fields or rice grains or something like that.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: "Everyone, we have rice! Come (??) and get it!"

context-en: There is a sentence that means basically the same thing as this sentence.
context-en2: This exam was almost the same questions as last time.
context-en3: I want to make ramen that tastes the same as that shop’s no matter what.
meaning-exp: This word is the kanji same with hiragana attached. Since the hiragana doesn't suggest it's a verb or adjective, you can assume it's a noun. What's the noun version of "same"? It's also same.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you think of the word "same" think same owner (??). You're looking at a restaurant that has a sign that says, "New owners!" However, when you walk in you see it's the same terrible owner you remember from before. What a liar.

context-en: Those were launched on the same day.
context-en2: The bands I like have concerts in different music clubs on the same day and I'm really not sure which one I should go to.
context-en3: On the same day of my father’s death, Apollo 11 succeeded in landing on the moon’s surface.
meaning-exp: You have the same day, which comes out to same day.
reading-exp: The readings follow the regular jukugo rules (on'yomi reading) but take note that ? is read as ??, the alternate on'yomi reading. You've been seeing this reading a lot lately, so hopefully you know it by now and it's easy!

vocab-meaning: School Admission, Entry Into School, Admission Into School, School Entry, Entering A School
context-en: Here is a congratulatory present for getting into school.
context-en2: My father forgot to pay the enrollment fee.
context-en3: Tom thought he got into Oxford, but apparently the acceptance letter was an April Fool’s joke his parents made.
meaning-exp: You enter into a study (place). When does this happen? It happens when you get accepted into a school, aka school admission.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: School Grade, Grade In School, School Year, Year In School
context-en: He is in the same year as my older brother.
context-en2: Tofugu not only has fans in early elementary school, but also elderly fans over 100 years old.
context-en3: One third of the third grade threw up after school lunch.
meaning-exp: Your study year is kind of like the years you've studied. Where do you study? School. What is a year of study in a school? It's your school grade.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There were orange peels laying in the garden.
context-en2: I bought a natural cowhide rug on Rakuten.
context-en3: My jacket is made of 100% dragon skin.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: As a human (we think), you have a lot of skin. But sometimes a normal shower isn't enough to wash all that skin. What do you do when you can't fit all your skin in the shower or the tub? You get your skin cleaned at the car wash, of course!

context-en: There is a beautiful rainbow in the sky.
context-en2: They say that women's minds and the autumn skies change quickly, but men's minds change quickly too.
context-en3: I hope the sky tonight is clear enough for us to see the famous scene from the movie E.T.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: In the sky, you are the ruler. You are known as "The soarer!" (??). Imagine your theme song and make sure it includes "soarer of the sky" or something awesome like that.

vocab-meaning: Sky Blue, Light Blue, Light Blue Color, Sky Blue Color
context-en: I want that light blue bag.
context-en2: Tofugu T-shirt is breezy sky blue.
context-en3: Why is the sky light blue today?
meaning-exp: You'd think that water color would have something to do with watercolors, but it doesn't. No, it has to do with the color of water, which, ironically, is sky blue in English. Light blue works as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word consists of the kun'yomi reading of ? and the kun'yomi reading of ?. For ? you'll know this reading via your vocab studies. For ? it just so happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Soon, In A Few Days, Coming Days
context-en: This game is scheduled to be released soon.
context-en2: The movie Mr. Tanaka was looking forward to will finally be released in a few days.
context-en3: Let’s hang out in person soon and talk about things we saw online.
meaning-exp: The near day is a day coming very soon. It's a day coming in a few days.
reading-exp: The readings are both on'yomi readings that you've learned. Just take note that ? is the alternate reading ??.

context-en: There was a loud noise upstairs.
context-en2: I can hear the sounds of a very good recorder coming from next door.
context-en3: Have you ever heard the sound that a goldfish makes when it cries?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Did you hear that sound? It's barely audible (??). Go ahead and say the word "audible" with the pronunciation of ?? to help you to remember this.

context-en: Cut the potatoes into squares, please.
context-en2: I want the twitter icon to go back from the current round shape to the square one.
context-en3: Why are most windows either squares or rectangles? They should start making windows shaped like Italy.
meaning-exp: What shape has four angles? The most common one is a square.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word!

context-en: Which parts will students study at home today?
context-en2: Do you have student discount?
context-en3: "We are all students of life," my dad said while farting.
meaning-exp: Who has a study life? Only one person that I know of, and that's a student.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Bathing too long in the sunlight isn’t good for your body.
context-en2: I'm being as careful as possible to not get exposed to direct sunlight.
context-en3: Seeing sunlight always makes me sneeze for some reason.
meaning-exp: You have sun light. What kind of light would this be? Obviously sunlight.
reading-exp: The reading for this one uses the on'yomi readings, though ?? gets shortened to ??, so take note of that. Otherwise, you should be able to read this one!

context-en: My testicles sting.
context-en2: I'm sure that my testicles are working twice as hard as the other mens'.
context-en3: The surgery to make testicles gold in color is fully booked for the next six months.
meaning-exp: You have some gold balls. What balls are more important than any other balls, at least for a dude? That would be his testicles. This word came about because tanuki scrotum skin would be used to pound down gold into sheets. Tanuki scrotums are apparently very good at this because they are very strong and very flexible. Strange, yeah? That's why Gold balls = testicles.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi for ? and the kun'yomi for ?. If you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I decided to pass this time.
context-en2: I was the first place winner at this marathon.
context-en3: I’ll drive the fishing boat this time because last time you drove it, we almost ran into the shore.
meaning-exp: The now times is this time.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’ve practiced thousands of times.
context-en2: Suddenly, thousands of bacon strips dropped from sky.
context-en3: Victims of the titan attack numbered in the thousands.
meaning-exp: What thousand? Could be five thousand, two thousand, or ten thousand, since you're asking. Let's generalize. How do you say all of those amounts at the same time? You say "thousands."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just take note that ? is read as ?? and not ?? because of rendaku.

context-en: I’ve been to Japan once.
context-en2: I've made plans to swim from America to Japan, but they've been put on hold eight different times now.
context-en3: I can’t count the number of times I’ve eaten sand.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji. This is probably because this word gets attached to numbers usually, which makes it behave more like jukugo. So, you can have 1?, 2?, 3?, or even 100? if you're into that sort of thing.

vocab-meaning: To Be On Target, To Hit, To Touch, To Guess Correctly, To Guess Right, To Be Right, To Hit The Target
context-en: If a person was hit with a stone, what would you do?
context-en2: In a packed train, my hand accidentally touched the butt of the woman next to me and I was so worried I’d be mistaken for a molester.
context-en3: I’m glad my guess was right.
meaning-exp: You know this is a verb because it ends with an ? sound. The kanji for this word is right or success, so what's the verb form of that? Turns out it's a ton of things. Like, a crazy amount of things. I tried narrowing it down for you, but it will still be a lot. This word tends to be about getting an answer right. As in, to guess correctly or to be on target. It means many other things too, but I think these are the two meanings you'll see the most, so focus on those.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the ? portion. You need to guess the correct answer. What do you choose? You guess A (?) and hope it's right. Turns out you were right on the money. Well done! Imagine yourself winning a fabulous prize.

vocab-meaning: To Carry Out A Task, To Carry Out, To Perform, To Perform A Task, To Do A Task
context-en: We will perform in the athletic meet on Sunday as planned.
context-en2: The students are scheduled to hand out free uchiwa fans at the station next Monday.
context-en3: I’ve been entrusted with the job of delivering a pig heart to Tokyo hospital and if I don’t carry out my task someone won’t be able to finish the meal they’re cooking.
meaning-exp: The meaning of this word is pretty strange, having very little to do with the kanji meaning you learned. This word means to carry out a task. Maybe you can think of it like someone is saying "You (?) go do that task!" to get yourself to carry out a task. Whatever you do, just know this is a weird exception word, so you may have to do some extra work to remember it.
reading-exp: The reading is also a strange exception. You have to remember the ??? portion. Think of it this way: You have to carry out a task but you have to wait for the go-ahead to start. Then, your boss tells you "Okay now! (???) and you can begin. The reading mnemonic isn't totally close to the actual reading, though, so be sure to make note in your mind that this mnemonic is only supposed to get you part of the way there. You'll have to get yourself the rest of the way for this one.

context-en: I came from America.
context-en2: She will come. I'm sure she will come.
context-en3: Never come back!
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means come so you know this word means to come.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is pretty strange. It changes depending on the type of verb form you use (it's a pesky exception verb). To remember the reading of this word, here's a mnemonic: "I want you to come to the cool (?) side, Luke," says Darth Vader. "What?" replies Luke. Just replace this line into the famous line from Star Wars. Say it out loud. Do the Vader voice. It'll help you to remember.

context-en: In the morning I do things like shop and clean.
context-en2: Something came up, so I'm not able to make it.
context-en3: I wouldn’t want to go to Mars because they don’t have Taco Bell there.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go so the verb form of this is to go.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ? portion. To remember ? we use the word "eagle." You want to go somewhere (anywhere!) but you can't. An eagle (?) blocks your path. You try to go forward and it opens its wings and bites at you. You try to go back and it jumps at you. There's nowhere for you to go with this eagle standing there.

vocab-meaning: To Grow, To Spring Up, To Sprout, To Come Out
context-en: My beard grows quickly.
context-en2: "Weeds grow," is Japanese Internet slang used when you think something's funny. It started because "w" (lol) looks like weeds.
context-en3: Do mushrooms grow in places like this?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how ??? means "to live?" Well this is what happens right after it starts to live. It begins to grow!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When something starts to grow it also learns to laugh. Imagine a little plant growing out of the ground laughing. "Ha (?) ha ha ha!" it says, as it sprouts out of the ground.

vocab-meaning: To Learn, To Study In Depth, To Study
context-en: I’m learning Japanese through self-study.
context-en2: Why don't you learn how to make weird faces and poses with Tofugu, instead of studying Japanese?
context-en3: Learning is important, but perhaps what’s more important is how you learn.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means study or learning. When you do these things, what ends up happening? You learn. That's why this word means to learn. There is another word that means "to learn" that is going to be more common, which is ??. You'll learn this one later on. ?? sounds a little more serious compared to ??, so keep that in mind when you use it.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? part to learn this word's reading. Think about a class you're taking. It's a manners class, and you're there to learn manners (??). Imagine this study of manners and imagine yourself practicing it.

vocab-meaning: To Make, To Build, To Create
context-en: Today, I will make yakisoba for supper.
context-en2: Can you teach me how to create multiple Facebook accounts, please?
context-en3: I wish I knew how to make a Tesla coil.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means make. The verb form of that is to make.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? portion. In order to do that let's think about something that you're going to make. Imagine something really awesome. You complete it and look at your masterpiece. It's amazing. You realize right then and there that it's too cool (??) for the general public to see. You proceed to smash it. It's way too cool.

context-en: We’re meeting on Sunday.
context-en2: I ran into Koichi at the Portland airport.
context-en3: I get to meet my favorite actor tomorrow afternoon.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means meet so the verb form of that is to meet or to encounter.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ? part but let's include the ? as well for this one. Who do you want to meet more than anyone? Think about it. Then, imagine meeting them. The first thing they do is grab your arm and pinch it. You yell out "OW!" (??) and they laugh and run away.

context-en: Mix the cards up well, please.
context-en2: Why did you mix one woman into group with a bunch of men?
context-en3: It’s dangerous to mix tofu and puffer fish.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb version is to mix. There are similar words to this one, including ??? which means "to be mixed" and ??? which means "to intersect." This one is when you're doing the mixing. Like ???, the connotation is that the things being mixed are distinguishable from each other, like two types of fish, or books being mixed together. They don't become homogenous like paint or something would.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ? portion. Who would mix things for you (like cakes and other goodies) growing up? That would be your Ma (?).

vocab-meaning: To Revolve, To Go Around, To Rotate
context-en: I went around 18 holes with a customer today.
context-en2: That 100 yen coin is still spinning on the desk.
context-en3: Those kittens revolve around their mother like the planets revolve around the sun.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means times. There's no good verb for the word "times" but you can probably imagine something doing something over and over and over again. What word would represent this? It would be to revolve.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have a bag of walnuts that you're bringing to a friend's house but you trip and drop them all on the ground. You shout, "Mah Walnuts! (??)" as they start to revolve around you on the ground. Picture your walnuts going around you, getting all dirty.

context-en: I ran because I was almost late for the movie.
context-en2: Koichi can run faster than a turtle.
context-en3: I’ve come to the conclusion that having my head cut off by a samurai would be much worse than running for my life.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means run so now you know the verb version of that is to run.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? portion. Think of yourself running. It's nice. As you run, though, you notice the ground changing into something weird and mushy. Everything is turning into hash (??) browns. You start to get sucked in, and soon you can't run anymore. Smell the hash browns and taste them too. What a terrible run this was.

context-en: Please say it slowly.
context-en2: How can I say, "Thank you always," in English?
context-en3: Are you going to say sorry to Jake for stepping on his foot?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means say, so the verb version of that is to say.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To remember the reading "?" we use the word "eagle." You're trying to say something, but every time you try to say anything an eagle swoops down and pecks at your face then flies away. Just imagine yourself saying tiny bits of words, then an eagle crashing down on your face. Then, you wait in silence. Nothing happens. You try to say something again, and the eagle swoops down on you again.

vocab-meaning: To Think About, To Consider, To Give Thought
context-en: Please let me think about it a little.
context-en2: Don't think. Just feel!
context-en3: My daughter thinks that the movie Titanic would have been better if the ship never sank and everyone went to Disney World instead.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think, so the verb version is to think about or to consider. Note that this isn't the "to think" that is like "I think that he is a power ranger." No, this is more like the actual thinking action. That's why this word is "to think about" or "to consider" rather than plain old "to think" which is ??.
reading-exp: If you want to think, the best way to do so is to do the conga (???). Imagine yourself doing the conga and thinking away. You're so inspired! The thoughts are flowing as freely as your sweet, slow dance moves.

context-en: One shinkansen ticket for Shin-Osaka, please.
context-en2: I'm thinking of walking both ways.
context-en3: This train is bound for Tofugu Office Station.
meaning-exp: This is a weird word. Call it exceptional. You'll see this at train stations, especially. You know the kanji means go. So, something is going somewhere. Now just use the ? to help you to remember that this word means train direction (aka it tells you which direction a train is going), because this word is the key (?) to you knowing what direction you're going in so you don't get lost. You could also remember this word as "bound for" aka "Bound for Tokyo Station."
reading-exp: The reading is also an exception. It can be ??, but instead we're focusing on the ?? reading. You have to remember the ? portion, so think of it this way: Just think about the train direction that you (?) need to go in. It's all about you. Not your friends or anyone else. You. You are the most important person at this train station.

context-en: Can you tell me the mileage of your car?
context-en2: Leaving your seat while the bus is moving is dangerous.
context-en3: The train will start running to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry again as soon as the strike is over.
meaning-exp: A vehicle that runs goes is running and it's moving you somewhere else. You're traveling! We usually use this word to describe moving or running vehicles like cars and trains. Keep an eye on those context sentences to make sure you're using it right. ;)
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please go buy triangle crackers.
context-en2: I am stuck in a love triangle now.
context-en3: Canadians must have been inspired by Picasso quite a bit. Square boxes, round pizzas, and triangle pizza slices are everywhere.
meaning-exp: When you have something with three angles, what shape is that? It's a triangle.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There are a lot of Chinese people in my university.
context-en2: What are the main differences between American universities and Japanese universities?
context-en3: I studied anatomy in college, but I never opened a textbook.
meaning-exp: What's the big study? If I had to choose, I'd probably say this is college or university.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Until Now, Up To Now, So Far
context-en: What have you been doing until now?
context-en2: Koichi had a million girlfriends up until now, but he is finally about to settle down with one woman.
context-en3: You are the best girlfriend I’ve had so far.
meaning-exp: You know that ? means now. What you probably don't know is that ?? means "until." So, this word means until now.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading which you learned previously when you learned the vocab word ?. You can tell this is a kun'yomi reading because it has hiragana attached. So if you know that, you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: I saw a bear in that valley.
context-en2: In Hakone, there is a valley called Owakudani, which used to be called "Death Valley" a long time ago, and it is a famous tourist spot nowadays.
context-en3: The guy who committed suicide in Death Valley was dressed as Darth Vader.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so don't feel like you're stuck in a valley of despair or anything. Rejoice!

context-en: I’ve read various types of novels.
context-en2: After thinking about various things, I've decided to hold a takoyaki party on Sunday.
context-en3: There are various species of trolls that live under my bed.
meaning-exp: This is the kanji color repeated twice (the ? character just repeats the kanji before it). When you have colors and colors and colors, you have a lot of variety. That's why this word means various.
reading-exp: The reading for this kanji is just the kun'yomi reading twice. Since you've learned the kun'yomi reading already, you should be able to read this word as well. Nothing tricky about it.

context-en: Hashimoto’s voice is very low.
context-en2: My friend's voice and her kid's voice are very alike.
context-en3: Your voice sounds awful!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji making it easy to remember!

context-en: The building on the west side of the hospital is my apartment.
context-en2: Darin is heading west.
context-en3: Meanwhile in West Portland, the Crabigator was crossing the road.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go off to the west. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a niche (??) for your snake oil business.

context-en: What would you say?
context-en2: Who do you think you are?
context-en3: What was the name of that drink we had at the hotel in Thailand?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. What? Yeah, that's what.

context-en: What month do you start school?
context-en2: When did it happen? What year, what month, what day, what time, what second was it? How many times did Earth spin when it happened?
context-en3: What month were you born in, Ms. Tanaka?
meaning-exp: You have what month - as in: what month is it? It's 10?, you fool. Get a job, hippy.
reading-exp: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. ? is technically the kun'yomi, but it feels pretty on'yomi-ish if you ask me. The ? uses the on'yomi, though.

context-en: What year were you born?
context-en2: What year did your kid enter college?
context-en3: How many years did the American Civil War last?
meaning-exp: You have the kanji what and year, as in: "what year is it?" This also means how many years too, depending on the context. As in: "How many years did you play soccer?"
reading-exp: The readings are both the readings you learned with the separate kanji, meaning you should know them. How many years have you been studying kanji now? You should be able to read this one.

context-en: I have a wheat allergy.
context-en2: What's the difference between barley and wheat?
context-en3: "Squats, squats, squats, squats, oats and squats," he sang while squatting.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji that uses the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Whole Life, Entire Life, A Lifetime, All Through Life, One Existence, A Generation, An Age
context-en: I’ve taken care of this ring my whole life.
context-en2: My father remained single all his life.
context-en3: I’ll make up for it with my life.
meaning-exp: One life is all you get. It's your whole life.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for ? though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who has been in charge of you your whole life? The shogun (???). He owns everyone and that's how it will stay for your entire life.

vocab-meaning: Within The Company, In House, Inside The Company, Inside A Company, In The Company, Within A Company
context-en: Next Sunday there will be an in house basketball tournament.
context-en2: Hana left the company after she married a man who worked in the same company.
context-en3: Recently, there is a strange new trend in our company. Workers put names on food in the company fridge. Today, I had a rice ball named "Suzuki."
meaning-exp: When you're doing something inside the company you're doing it within the company or in-house. For example, we do our kanji in-house. It gives it that artisan flavor.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Do you have green yarn?
context-en2: It is very cold today, so I am wearing the wool sweater that my friend knitted for me.
context-en3: "Unwind a ball of yarn please. Please. Please!" the ghost asked me over and over again.
meaning-exp: When you have fur string (aka string made of fur) what do you think of? Hopefully wool yarn.
reading-exp: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. With ? you should have learned this reading via the vocab word in the previous level. With ? it's actually the main reading for the kanji, so you should already know it.

context-en: My little brother doesn’t watch TV.
context-en2: That young man with blue hair is my younger brother.
context-en3: I ended up going to the hospital last night because my younger brother threw a pool ball at my head.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your younger brother. He's a scheming one. He's smiling up at you. Why? Because he's lit a firecracker on your foot. It explodes, sending your toe flying. You yell "OH. Toe? TOE!" (????) as you realize what's going on.

context-en: He was a very invigorating young man.
context-en2: That young man is a member of a motorcycle gang.
context-en3: Why do youths in Japan try to hide their nasty smiles when they’re up to something?
meaning-exp: Someone who is blue in their years. This makes sense when you know that Asian babies are often born with blue butts, which you can associate with being young. So, Blue = Young (not only in this word, but in others as well). Someone who is blue in their years is a youth.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Why don’t we have some tea together later?
context-en2: Don't make me say, "I told you so," later.
context-en3: After the movie, we headed across town to watch it again in another theater.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: After. Everything happens after. It's a cause and effect chain. One thing happens, and then another thing happens after. This is life. This is the universe. Everything is after. It's an automatic (??) cycle that just keeps going and going and going. You can differentiate this one from ?? because it has a ? on the end. "Day" (?) follows night which follows "day" again, automatically.

context-en: It all went smoothly.
context-en2: I am sorry, but all the seats are fully occupied at the moment, so...
context-en3: I was the first to do it. Wikipedia copied my entire homework assignment afterwards.
meaning-exp: This has a little hiragana attached to it but nothing that suggests it's a verb or an adjective. That means you can assume this word has the same meaning as its parent kanji.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? part, which is an admittedly difficult sound to remember. You have to think of the concept of all or entire. When you think of that concept, think of someone's entire fortune. All their money. You want to get all of Beth's money, so you sue beth (??) for all she has.

context-en: This is a picture of a Japanese National Volleyball tournament match.
context-en2: Koichi is in Japan to watch the All Japan Kendo Championships.
context-en3: All of Japan is covered in whipped cream.
meaning-exp: You know ?? means "Japan." So, now you have the kanji for all added to it, making this word All Japan (as in "All Japan Railways" or something like that).
reading-exp: You know the reading of ??. Now just add the on'yomi reading of ? and you should be able to read this word.

context-en: This department store opens at 10:00 am.
context-en2: My son still needs to take a nap in the morning.
context-en3: I’ll be posting telepathically at 9AM today, so if you think of something funny, that was me.
meaning-exp: You have something that's before (or in front of) noon. What is before noon? That is AM.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: America, United States, United States Of America, Usa
context-en: Do you know the name of the president of the United States?
context-en2: I never expected anything from America anyways.
context-en3: Many people immigrate to America solely for the super-size combos at McDonald’s.
meaning-exp: America is the country of rice. I guess this is from all those rolling plains and such we have. Another way to say America in Japanese is ????, but this is another more formal (and older) way. "Rice Country" aka America.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I twisted my ankle.
context-en2: My right ankle hurts a lot.
context-en3: I sprained my ankle while running away from a feather floating in the air.
meaning-exp: What is the neck of your leg? Think about it. It's your ankle.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know the kun'yomi reading of ? from previous vocab and you know the kun'yomi reading of ? from learning that kanji. So, you should be able to read this kanji so long as you remember that it's all kun'yomi.

context-en: Let’s decide on this year’s annual project.
context-en2: How much annual paid leave do you get, Mariko?
context-en3: We write an annual report on how much our Japanese language students are improving.
meaning-exp: The year that is next is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is annual?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please close the door behind you.
context-en2: You must install the child carseat on the rear seat of the car.
context-en3: If you turn around to look behind you and then do it again, you’ll see me.
meaning-exp: The hiragana attached to this word doesn't suggest it's a verb or an adjective, so we can assume it's a noun. While ?? (you may or may not have seen this word yet) means "after," this one means all the other meanings you learned with the kanji: behind, back, and rear. Think of the ? as a hint. It's like saying you're on the "road" (?) and you're driving so fast you're leaving everything "behind."
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Continue to think you're driving on this road. You hit something, then look behind you, seeing you hit a cow. Know the word for cow in Japanese? You should. It's ??, which is also the reading for this word.

context-en: The bleeding won’t stop.
context-en2: Tofugu is providing you with a huge discount!
context-en3: I think my nose would stop bleeding if I kept my finger out of it.
meaning-exp: When the thing that is exiting is blood, you are probably bleeding.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ??? from ? gets shortened to ???. That's a small ? there, not a big one.

context-en: There is blood on your shirt.
context-en2: Why does my bum bleed when I poop?
context-en3: I like steak when it still has lots of blood in it.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You cut yourself and there's blood everywhere. You need to stop the bleeding with something, but the only thing nearby is a block of cheese. You grab the cheese and stuff it into your gash, but the blood comes out the holes (it is Swiss cheese, blargh!). Imagine this in great detail to be able to remember it well.

context-en: My older and younger sisters both live in Osaka.
context-en2: You've got time, so why don't you try it both ways?
context-en3: Nope. They’re both mine.
meaning-exp: Here you have both directions / ways. Every time you have to choose between something it's like having to choose between two ways. That's why this word is simply both. Close to the kanji is the meaning both sides, as well. Learn either for ??, they're pretty similar.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I’ll be in a meeting both days.
context-en2: The tofu festival had good weather for both days.
context-en3: I attended the iPad lecture session on both days, but I still have no clue how to use it.
meaning-exp: Kanji doesn't go together much better than this. Both plus day equals both days. This is a bit of a formal word though, you'll hear important people say it more than your friends.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ? uses the reading ?? for this one instead of ??.

context-en: They raised both hands and shouted banzai.
context-en2: Viet is between two beautiful women.
context-en3: A balanced diet is a chocolate cookie in both hands.
meaning-exp: Don't use one hand when you can use both hands. This is simply both plus hand put together.
reading-exp: This word uses the readings you learned with both kanji. No problemo for a kanji master such as yourself.

context-en: This room is bright.
context-en2: Tofugu workers are all happy people.
context-en3: Your future is still bright, Grandpa.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of bright? It's also bright.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? portion. What is ?? in Japanese? It is "red." So, think of something that's really bright. Now, imagine it being totally red (aka ??). In Japan, the color red is associated with the sun, and the sun is pretty bright. If you can remember this you can also remember the reading of this word.

context-en: Please color the number that best matches the ? with brown.
context-en2: I'd like to dye my hair light brown, please.
context-en3: All of my white t-shirts have brown armpit stains on them.
meaning-exp: What is the color of tea? You'd think it would be green, assuming it's Japanese... but this word came from China. What color is Chinese tea? It tends to be more brown. Think Oolong tea, for example.
reading-exp: The readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.

vocab-meaning: Can't Be Helped, It Can't Be Helped, No Use, It's No Use, It Is No Use
context-en: If he’s angry, it can’t be helped.
context-en2: There's no use in just crying.
context-en3: You’re really hopeless!
meaning-exp: The kanji part of this word is like saying "the doing way" ... aka the way you do something. So, when you don't have a way to do something, there's nothing you can do. Thus is born the popular Japanese phrase: ?????, which means can't be helped. This is a very good word to know if you're in Japan.
reading-exp: The readings for the kanji portion are in line with the readings you learned with the individual kanji, so as long as you know those you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: Also, the cheap train is better.
context-en2: Prices in Thailand are cheaper than America.
context-en3: I bought a very cheap radio yesterday just so I could throw it off the roof of my apartment and watch it shatter.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cheap? It's also cheap. Time to go to a 100? shop and get some ?? goods, ammiright?
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Would you like this item for cheap?" "Uh, yes (??) please!"

context-en: Next month I’m traveling to China on business.
context-en2: During winter break, I watched the meteor shower in China.
context-en3: Why did Japanese people stop calling China "Shina" and start calling it "Chuugoku?"
meaning-exp: The middle country... who could that be? Let's think about it. Who invented kanji and therefore probably thinks they're the middle of the world? Who also is just a huge country that ruled much of Asia? That would be none other than China.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.

vocab-meaning: Company President, Manager, Director, President Of A Company
context-en: The company president is in a meeting.
context-en2: The president of Tofugu is insane to lower the price of that popular service.
context-en3: All my coworkers hate my boss, but I just think he’s a little mean.
meaning-exp: The company leader is the company president, manager, or director. Be sure to greet your ?? with a hearty good morning when he stumbles in!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Today we will learn verb conjugation.
context-en2: I make use of small pockets of time and study Japanese on WaniKani.
context-en3: I don’t know if I can put this data to good use.
meaning-exp: What do you use to show that a word is lively? Conjugation! Lively things are happening, so you have to conjugate your words to match. It also has another meaning. When you want to actually use something lively you are making practical use of it. I mean, you're using it, after all. So as long as you aren't pretending to use it, it's probably practical.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Which country are you from?
context-en2: I thought this country was safe, but now I'm disappointed.
context-en3: In my country, there is a shop that sells apple pies made by a cat.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Tell me about your country. Now imagine your country covered in raccoons (??), taking up every inch of the ground. In your country you have to walk on top of them there are so many. That's why your country is known as "(rac)coon country."

context-en: I’m interested in Japanese culture.
context-en2: Have you adapted to the culture of this country yet?
context-en3: Is cosplaying part of Japanese culture?
meaning-exp: Writing has changed our entire culture. In fact, when someone reads a good piece of writing it changes them, and changes their culture too. What writing has changed you so much it has changed your culture and the way you act?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Who found the dead body?
context-en2: Who did you say was arrested for abandoning a corpse?
context-en3: The first time I saw a dead body was when I was six years old.
meaning-exp: The kanji for death and body put together make for a dead body. Hopefully you don't have to use or see this vocab too much.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Their death was too soon.
context-en2: People cannot escape death, except for Koichi.
context-en3: I’m stricken with grief over the death of my pet dog.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: I’m making a dialect dictionary.
context-en2: Damn! My boyfriend's dialect has rubbed off on me.
context-en3: People from the eastern part of my country use such an odd dialect that they are impossible to understand.
meaning-exp: The way you say things could be translated as your accent... but this is much bigger. This is an entire "way" of speaking. This is a dialect. You can even think of the ? as being "direction" where you go in different directions in a country and discover different dialects, if that way of thinking helps.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I lost my bearings.
context-en2: I'm super terrible with directions!
context-en3: Are we going in the right direction? I thought Chuck E. Cheese was the other way.
meaning-exp: The direction yonder over there is still just the direction of something, though a complicated way to say it, I think. This direction is the "what direction did he go in?" sort of direction.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Why did you come to school early yesterday?
context-en2: Please get plenty of rest and feel better!
context-en3: Eat quickly.
meaning-exp: This is the adverb version of the kanji early It's a little thing you can begin sentences with to say you're doing something early or quickly.
reading-exp: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word ??, you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: One leaf fell lightly to the ground.
context-en2: Koichi used to be a big shot, but his reputation hit rock bottom after he lost a battle against a wild boar.
context-en3: And yet, Koichi himself remains charmingly down-to-earth.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Although this is a single kanji all alone, it uses the on'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

context-en: Let’s meet in the cafe that's on the east side of the station.
context-en2: Which direction is east?
context-en3: I live on the east side of the airport.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You see a man walking east, toward the sun rising behind that tree, but it's too bright. He trips and he gashes (???) his foot on a root that was sticking out of the ground. His foot is torn up really bad, but he tries to take another step and, oh no, he gashes his foot again! This guy is not having an easy time going east.

context-en: The eastern sky grew bright.
context-en2: That foreigner lives about five kilometers east of Osaka Station.
context-en3: Japan is to the east of Great Britain.
meaning-exp: The East direction is Eastward.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: This city is very lively.
context-en2: Nikka is always full of energy.
context-en3: The market was overflowing with energy.
meaning-exp: If you have lively energy you have more than enough energy for everyone to start noticing. They come up to you and compliment you on your amazing liveliness.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful because ?? is being shortened here to ??. It's a pretty common change for on'yomi ending in ?, so keep your eyes open for more that do this!

context-en: There is a famous sushi restaurant near my house.
context-en2: This article suddenly made Tofugu super popular.
context-en3: I’m famous, are you?
meaning-exp: When you have a name (that is known to people) or you have famousness, you are probably someone who is famous.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Famous Music, Famous Song, Famous Tune, Masterpiece
context-en: Speaking of famous Christmas songs, what do you think?
context-en2: This is known for being an excellent piece of music, but to me it's just like all the others.
context-en3: Beethoven’s "Smoked Salmon" is a masterpiece.
meaning-exp: Famous music that you know the name of is famous music.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Fast Talker, Fast Talking, Fast Speaker, Fast Speaking, Quick Talker
context-en: My older brother is a really fast talker.
context-en2: Why did you say that you love me the most so quickly?
context-en3: I’ve never seen such a fast talking baby before.
meaning-exp: When you have a fast mouth, you're probably a fast talker, right motormouth?
reading-exp: Remember how body parts often change even jukugo words to kun'yomi readings? That's what happened here too. Both readings are kun'yomi, making this one ????. Alternatively, you can read this as ???? as well.

context-en: We haven’t gone to other countries yet.
context-en2: This is my first time making an overseas call.
context-en3: I wouldn’t mind being a celebrity if I was in a foreign country.
meaning-exp: An outside country is one outside of your own country. That is a foreign country.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Today, I went shopping with my foreign friends.
context-en2: That foreigner's eyes were bloodshot.
context-en3: No, I’m not racist. I’ve met every kind of foreign person on the planet and I just hate each of them equally.
meaning-exp: You know ?? the word that means "foreigner," but that word is a bit informal and can come off as rude. The nicer, more politically correct version of the word is the one above. An outside country person. To differentiate this from "foreigner" we're going to use the more polite English version of this word as well (just like in Japanese): Foreign Person.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I took a forty-two day trip around Southeast Asia.
context-en2: The French gourmet had 42 plates of Sara udon in May only.
context-en3: My grandma bought forty-two rolls of toilet paper.
meaning-exp: Four tens plus two. That equals forty two. P.S. Please don't panic. "The Answer" is NOT a correct answer for this. It is just a reference to the greatest book of all time. Sorry for the confusion and so long and thanks for all the fish.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But! Don't forget, ? uses the kun'yomi reading, since the on'yomi reading sounds too much like the word for "death."

context-en: In front is a flower shop and next door to it is a fish shop.
context-en2: Every morning I do 500 squats before leaving for work.
context-en3: When I’m in front of a red light, I get very excited at the thought of it turning green soon.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What's in front of you? Think about it. Make it something ridiculous. Now look at a tag that's on it. Who does this thing belong to? Oh, wait, it's my (??) thing there in front of me. Say that out loud for better memory.

vocab-meaning: Full Effort, Every Effort, Best Effort, Full Power
context-en: I ran with all my might to the station.
context-en2: That Chinese woman tried her best to persuade the prince to marry her, but she failed.
context-en3: That zombie is using up all its strength trying to come back from the dead.
meaning-exp: When you put all your power into something, you're putting your full effort into it. Hopefully that's what you put into your kanji learning as well!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Kawata is a very honest person.
context-en2: I like his honesty.
context-en3: I try to be honest all the time because I’m an underwater-breathing Martian prince and I need to set an example for people.
meaning-exp: You have correct and fix. When you're always fixing things to make them correct (for example, someone's lies!) you are a very honest person.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: After this I plan on going to Honshu.
context-en2: Where the heck in Japan is Honshu?
context-en3: If you don't know where Honshu is, why don't you look it up on your computer?
meaning-exp: You have your origin state. For Japan (since this is a Japanese word), that would be the main island, the big one in the middle: Honshu. You'll have to know some minor Japanese geography for this. Go look at a map of Japan and study it over real quick to see where I'm talking about if you don't know already.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please remove me from your email list.
context-en2: I'm the director of the sales division.
context-en3: I went to a bar for the first time last night. I feel like I’m slowly becoming an adult.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: If you're lucky, you already know this (very) common word's reading. It's the word for "I," probably one of the first things you'd learn in Japanese. The reading for this is ???. If you don't know that already, just think: "What, a ??" referring to the reading of the kanji, which is ?.

context-en: That king is very greedy.
context-en2: I'm starting to understand the king.
context-en3: I became the king as a youth of 18.
meaning-exp: A country king is still a king, just of a bigger area.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Poochie is definitely in heaven.
context-en2: I am so disappointed to learn the Kingdom of Heaven is that kind of place.
context-en3: Let’s smoke cigarettes in Heaven.
meaning-exp: This is heaven country. Where is that? Probably just in heaven (or if you want to be fancy, the kingdom of heaven).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? is changed to the reading ??, though because of rendaku. Even heaven changes a little bit.

context-en: Kyushu cuisine is delicious.
context-en2: It takes an hour to get to Kyushu by ferry.
context-en3: There are many beautiful women in Kyushu.
meaning-exp: The nine states. This refers to a section of Japan from a long time ago that was presumably made up of nine states. Now it's just one big island, though, and that island is Kyuushuu. Go take a look at a map and find this giant island, it's a cool part of Japan!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This isn’t your land.
context-en2: Koichi owns a vast tract of land in Minecraft.
context-en3: If I had some land of my own, I’d finally get my own bedroom.
meaning-exp: The soil of the earth is the portion of the earth that is made up of land.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi reading, but ? gets modified to ? for some reason. Just remember that the land you're standing on is made of toes... millions of them. Yuck.

context-en: Please tell me the difference between American and Japanese life?
context-en2: I want to get back together and live with you again.
context-en3: I would be very happy if I could watch cartoons and eat marshmallows every day of my life.
meaning-exp: When you have life and are lively that right there is true life. What is your ?? like? Do you live?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This movie was long.
context-en2: That lady with long hair standing by the door is the one in charge.
context-en3: I'm thinking about breaking my own legs to avoid going long distance running.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of long? It's also long.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have something that's really long. It's this crazy hair growing out of the tip of your nose. You don't really care either way if it stays or goes, but you're too lazy to cut it off. Your parents, though, keep trying to nag (??) you to trim it. Imagine this process happening and be irritated about it. What naggers.

context-en: "My little sister won the lottery." "Oh cool! How much?" "10,000 yen."
context-en2: It's wishful thinking, but I'll probably win the lottery at some point next year.
context-en3: My dad's secretary won the lottery, but I made a spelling mistake when I posted it on Facebook. Secretary was spelled secretly. It confused people and I got a lot of congrats.
meaning-exp: ? is a treasure. ?? is a lottery. So if you have a treasure lottery (you win treasure if you win the lottery) then you have yourself a lottery.
reading-exp: The reading uses the ? vocab reading, ???.

context-en: How do you switch from lowercase to uppercase?
context-en2: Passwords must contain at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter and a number.
context-en3: Is your email address in all lowercase letters? Is it really? Are you crazy?
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means "letters". So, what are "small letters"? That would be lowercase letters.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is an exceptional reading. You know it means "small," so think about what else is small: a child. How do you say "child" in Japanese? ?. You also know how to say the ?? portion from the previous level, so combine those together and you have ???.

context-en: I got out the map on my smartphone.
context-en2: I walked around Tokyo with a map.
context-en3: Teacher, if you forget your world map I have one tattoo'd on my forehead.
meaning-exp: The diagram of the earth. What could that be other than a map?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There was a cow walking leisurely in the meadow.
context-en2: There are a lot of pastures and grasslands in Ireland.
context-en3: Let’s hide this money in the meadow over there.
meaning-exp: Grass covering the earth is a meadow. Or, if you're less creative, it's grassland.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

context-en: Mercury does not have an atmosphere.
context-en2: This isn't what I asked for, but I've been homeless for 10 years on Mercury.
context-en3: I can only see Mercury just before sunrise and right after sunset.
meaning-exp: The water star is the planet Mercury. That's where we hid all of our secret moon water. Mercury looks enough like our moon, so we put it there so no one could find it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I watched the news on the Middle East on TV this morning.
context-en2: You can't help it that you couldn't make it to the wedding because you had to go to the Middle East for an emergency.
context-en3: What is the most played game in the Middle East?
meaning-exp: The middle of the east is more simply known as the middle east.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I heard that when you eat a lot of vegetables you can lower your risk of mortality.
context-en2: What is the cause of Mr. Yamada's younger brother's death?
context-en3: Since the invention of the cheeseburger, mortality rates in all first-world nations have tripled.
meaning-exp: Death and deceased. That's a lot of death. This is mortality.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If I remember correctly, this is not a national treasure.
context-en2: "Why is this vacuum cleaner a national treasure?" "Because Nic Cage used it before."
context-en3: A national treasure is hidden in the Tofugu office.
meaning-exp: A country's treasure is their national treasure.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The flu is spreading nationwide.
context-en2: Which prefecture is the largest producer of apples nationwide?
context-en3: He was involved in a nationwide cyber bullying scandal.
meaning-exp: When something involves all the country you know it's nationwide or national.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’ve been using my computer too much so my neck hurts.
context-en2: I cricked my neck in my sleep.
