context-en3: Is the bubonic plague the illness that made people grow boobs on their necks?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: You learned the reading for this word via the kanji, so you should be able to read this word just fine.

context-en: Neptune is the eighth planet from the sun.
context-en2: I've always dreamed of going to Neptune.
context-en3: Neptune was discovered on September 23rd, 1846.
meaning-exp: The star named after the king of the ocean is Neptune! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Let’s catch the next train.
context-en2: I'll let you know once we decide on the next plan.
context-en3: The next destination on this bus tour is Michael Jackson’s house.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Someone yells out "NEXT!" because the first thing didn't work on you. That was a single guillotine. Now they are going to try two guillotines (??) and see how that works on your thick neck. NEXXXXT!

context-en: I’m looking forward to the next production.
context-en2: There is no next time. We only live once.
context-en3: Don’t worry, bro. We’ll get them next time, yo.
meaning-exp: The next time you look at this kanji, you should know that it means next time.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I went to a party last night.
context-en2: Last night, I was so excited that I barely slept.
context-en3: Night is the time when monsters crawl up through the floor to have tea parties under my bed.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: It is the night, but it is your (??) night.

context-en: This airplane is nonstop to Tokyo.
context-en2: Today after the meeting with Japan, I'll go directly to the appointment with Tofugu.
context-en3: I’m sorry, I can't talk right now. I’m on a nonstop trip to the bathroom.
meaning-exp: If you think about direct going (aka transportation) how would you make it better? You'd make it so everything was nonstop and direct. Just imagine how much nicer it would be if every airplane you took was direct and you never had to stop. So nice!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The ??? of ? is shortened with a small ?, though, so make sure to take note of that.

vocab-meaning: Northeast, Tohoku, Tohoku Region, Touhoku Region, Touhoku
context-en: I was volunteering in Tohoku.
context-en2: I'm living by myself in Tohoku now.
context-en3: A magnitude 8.9 earthquake slammed into Japan’s northeastern coast.
meaning-exp: The East North is also known as the Northeast. But, it's not just the Northeast, it's a region as well. You may have heard of the Tohoku Region before? It was the one hit by the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Not Enough, To Not Be Sufficient, To Not Be Enough, Insufficient, Not Sufficient, To Be Insufficient
context-en: I’m ten yen short.
context-en2: If there is insufficient space, attach a separate sheet with additional information.
context-en3: Bill Gates is my son, but there isn’t enough evidence to prove it yet.
meaning-exp: You know the word ??? from Level 4. What is this one? it's the opposite (negative form on a verb is ??). So, what is the opposite of ??? (To be sufficient)? The opposite is to not be sufficient or not enough.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??? (???) which you should have seen in Level 4.

context-en: The teacher is talking to her students in Marine Park.
context-en2: I got red eyes after swimming in the sea.
context-en3: The movie Water World was actually written by a race of super-intelligent fish that live at the bottom of the ocean.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You visit the sea. Strangely, it asks you who is visiting. You're so full of yourself (even in front of the sea/ocean) that you reply: "um, me?" (??). Imagine yourself feeling this full of yourself.

context-en: This is my first date with an older person.
context-en2: Life is unpredictable. It's not a zero percent chance that you will get married with a beautiful older woman.
context-en3: My dad says that my mom’s mom is older than the pyramids.
meaning-exp: When you're years above someone else, you are older than that person.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is an exception, because it uses kun'yomi readings even though it is a jukugo kanji. You already know the separate kun'yomi readings from the vocabulary of the last level, but you will have to remember to actually use this knowledge when this word comes up.

vocab-meaning: Older Sister, Big Sister, Elder Sister
context-en: I’m just about to go to my older sister’s house.
context-en2: I have five times as many books as my older sister does.
context-en3: My big sister works as a stewardess.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is your older sister, by the way. Not somebody else's.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Picture your older sister (even if you don't have one), her birthday is coming up and there's only one thing she wants from you. A necklace (??). She's wanted a necklace for years and you're finally going to give her one. She'll be so happy.

vocab-meaning: Older Sister, Big Sister, Elder Sister
context-en: Midori’s older sister is wearing glasses.
context-en2: I totally thought you were Viet's older sister, but you aren't, eh?
context-en3: My older sister thinks that buying a motorcycle will help her get a boyfriend.
meaning-exp: The ? makes the word more polite. You're elevating the "older sister" title because you're a good younger sibling. Otherwise, the meaning of this word is the same as the kanji - just the feeling is different.
reading-exp: The reading is different too. It has some hiragana attached to it, which is a clue that this uses a kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to learn that reading. Imagine your older sister (even if you don't have one). She is, for some reason, a horse. Imagine petting her, giving her carrots, and doing other horse-related things with her. What do horses say? They say nehhhh (??).

context-en: I’ve finally taken one step forward toward my dream.
context-en2: They say, a journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, right?
context-en3: It takes courage to take the first step forward.
meaning-exp: If ? is "walk" and you take one walk, then really you are just taking one step. When there's a number before ?, it refers to the number of steps you're taking. The most common is this one, and you'll see it on urinals when they kindly ask you to please take one step forward because peeing isn't a game and somebody has to clean up after you.
reading-exp: The reading is pretty standard in its trickiness. The ?? shortens to an ?? and the ? rendakus to ?. One step at a time, right?

context-en: I want to work overseas in the future.
context-en2: After having worked in the insurance industry for eight years, I went to America to study abroad.
context-en3: I want to live somewhere overseas, but I hate traveling.
meaning-exp: The outside of the sea is someplace overseas. It can also be foreign or abroad if those words are easier to remember for you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When was the Heian period?
context-en2: The WaniKani forums don't have any trolls, so it gives me peace of mind.
context-en3: Walking through the old growth forests in British Columbia was so peaceful.
meaning-exp: Something is flat and relaxed. That is you. What words does that describe? To me, that would be peace and tranquility. Just imagine something that is flat and relaxed, like a field of grass with happy people in it. It's so peaceful! It's so tranquil!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Personal Life, One's Personal Life, Private Life, One's Private Life
context-en: Koichi's personal life is cloaked in secrecy.
context-en2: My immune system has been weaker than most people's since I was born, so I usually wear a mask when I'm on my own.
context-en3: Koichi has a lot of stress from work and his personal life is getting messed up. Could you advise him? I believe he needs someone to listen to him.
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? before, right? So what about the "life" of I? Whose life is that? Why, that's my own personal life.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What are the women going to do tomorrow afternoon?
context-en2: What's the closest time in the afternoon that's available for an appointment?
context-en3: I have an appointment with my doctor at 3PM to remove an ingrown toenail.
meaning-exp: What is noon after? That is PM or the afternoon.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I have a fever of 38.9 degrees.
context-en2: Compared to what's in this closet, I have 2.5 times as many clothes scattered around in the other rooms.
context-en3: I agree with your point that the movie was really bad, but I didn’t realize it was such a waste of time until it was over.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the reading for the kanji that makes it.

context-en: The private kindergartens are closed on the Christmas Day.
context-en2: Go out of here and walk left along the street until you come to the third intersection and you'll get to the private hospital.
context-en3: I found out that the guy Koichi secretly met at the cafe was a private detective.
meaning-exp: The place where I stand is my own private area. Think of the "circle of personal space." This is where you stand plus an arm's length. This area is very private to you. Who knows what you do in your own private area.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Railroad Car, Vehicle, Train Car, Railway Carriage, Railcar
context-en: Hi there, I’m examining the railroad cars.
context-en2: In Japan, vehicles drive on the left side of the road.
context-en3: This railroad car is a women-only carriage.
meaning-exp: A car with more cars on both sides is a car that hooks into other cars... specifically other railroad cars. They have hooks on both sides, they hook into other cars, and they fit all the requirements of this vocab word's kanji.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: That’s a relief.
context-en2: I never know what that kid will do next, so I can't get peace of mind.
context-en3: I feel so relieved now that I know my dad no longer has cancer.
meaning-exp: When your heart is relaxed, how do you feel? What if this is after something startling happens? You would feel relief or peace of mind.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Come into the classroom, please.
context-en2: This game is too difficult. I never have enough time to get to room number 1569 in this stage no matter how hard I try.
context-en3: I was sleeping in the school infirmary.
meaning-exp: You'll see this attached to other words... like "waiting" or "guest." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ room, making this word mean room (same as the kanji).
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi reading. Don't type the ? out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

context-en: If I come here, I’m safe.
context-en2: I don't mind if we're a little slow, so just please drive safely.
context-en3: My motto is safety first.
meaning-exp: When you are all relaxed you are finally in safety.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Do you know which one is Saturn?
context-en2: How can I get to Saturn?
context-en3: I’m an alien from Saturn.
meaning-exp: The ground star is Saturn. That's why it's called "sat"urn. Because the first people to find it sat on the ground there. It's a star made completely of sit-on-able ground.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Her major is science.
context-en2: Japan is very advanced in the fields of science and technology.
context-en3: Science is really amazing because it allowed us to make mosquito repellent.
meaning-exp: The study of science is plainly known as science.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I got to feed the sheep at the zoo.
context-en2: Anything can happen at any moment, so if you want a sheep, get it.
context-en3: Do you think sheep feel embarrassed when they have their wool sheared off?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine a sheep fighting with Jesus. The first thing it does is hits Jesus (???) in the stomach with its fists, then hits Jesus again with its horns. Try to imagine this playing out, with an announcer calling the shots as well.

context-en: I still haven’t been to Shikoku.
context-en2: Have you gotten used to life in Shikoku yet?
context-en3: I was traveling through Shikoku to learn how to make the best udon noodles.
meaning-exp: The four country is another section of Japan. It's quite nice, too. Look on a map and try to find it. So, the meaning of this word is a also the reading, which you should be able to figure out because it's all on'yomi: Shikoku.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

context-en: Please draw a map from the station to the store.
context-en2: The restaurant is already fully booked for the rest of the year.
context-en3: You’re going to love this shop. They have the best meatloaf in the world.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think of your favorite shop. Okay, now imagine yourself going to it. When you arrive, the entire shop is totally missing (??). Feel the shock and awe of this. It's as if it picked up and left overnight. No building, no anything. Just missing.

context-en: Those two sisters look so alike.
context-en2: Hey, you two kinda look like sisters.
context-en3: There is a bond between sisters that isn’t shared between girls who are just friends.
meaning-exp: Your older sister and your younger sister. These are your sisters.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There are many types of people in the world.
context-en2: In this society, not knowing the truth is sometimes better.
context-en3: We live in a great society where pizza gets to your house before the police.
meaning-exp: The middle of the world is the society. It's what holds everything together, for us humans. You can also call it the world.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. Why? Because this word is really two separate words connected together into one bigger word. You know the kun'yomi readings from vocab practice in previous levels.

context-en: There is a police station on the south side of the library.
context-en2: Why isn't there a North Japan Railway Company and a South Japan Railway Company, even though there's an East Japan Railway Company and a West Japan Railway Company?
context-en3: I saw Brad Pitt at the south baseball stadium.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about the south. What's down there? Mean Amy (???) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky.

context-en: The car continued heading southeast.
context-en2: I totally thought the sun would set in the southeast today.
context-en3: I saw a shooting star in the southeast.
meaning-exp: The South East is the Southeast.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That night the stars were really pretty.
context-en2: I hope we can see a lot of shooting stars tonight.
context-en3: Dad, why are you wearing star-shaped glasses today?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A star is just a whole sheep (??) floating in the sky. If it wasn't a whole sheep, it wouldn't shine so brightly and you wouldn't be able to see it from Earth. Don't let anyone tell you stars are made of gas. The whole thing is sheep, okay?

context-en: I’m from New York state.
context-en2: There are fifty states in the United States.
context-en3: The headquarters of Tofugu is located in Portland, Oregon.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi reading that you learned with the kanji, probably because it normally gets added on to other things, like the names of the state. Examples: ????????, ???????, etc.

context-en: We’re looking for a substitute teacher.
context-en2: There is no replacement for him anywhere in the world.
context-en3: I can teach you English and in exchange you can teach me Japanese.
meaning-exp: You've seen that ??? means "to substitute for" or "to replace." This is the noun version of that (no ? sound on the end). So, what is the noun version of those verb words? It would be substitute or replacement.
reading-exp: You should be able to figure out the reading from learning ??? in the previous level.

context-en: The table of contents page was torn out.
context-en2: First, I would like to explain the table of contents.
context-en3: Do I have to read this whole book? Can’t I just read the table of contents?
meaning-exp: Your eye is on what's next. How is this possible to see what's coming up? That's because you're looking at a table of contents.
reading-exp: The readings are the on'yomi readings, but you learned the kun'yomi reading for ? before. So, you have to remember that this word uses ?? instead of ?. To do that, imagine yourself looking at a table of contents. Instead of being a normal table of contents there, it's just line after line of text trying to mock (??) you. Come up with what those lines are and think about how you're being mocked.

context-en: I didn’t drink tea.
context-en2: I want to eat bacon rice covered in tea before I die.
context-en3: I can’t drink tea anymore because it makes me fart.
meaning-exp: The ? just makes the word more polite. Since tea is so important in Japan, it gets the ?. Otherwise, you should be able to figure out the meaning as it's the same as the kanji.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi reading, just like you learned with the kanji.

context-en: Where is your family going to go on winter vacation this year, Yamashita?
context-en2: The coming-of-age ceremony in Okinawa went wild again this year.
context-en3: As soon as I got used to writing 2013 as the date for this year, 2014 arrived.
meaning-exp: The now year is which year? It is this year.
reading-exp: With the first reading (the more common one), the ?? of ? is actually just ?. This gets shortened sometimes, so look out for it. Also, the ? is the kun'yomi reading for some reason. It's a total mystery why this is. Perhaps the ancient aliens know, but I do not. You're going to have to remember this exception with that brain of yours and rely on the SRS to bestow this knowledge upon you. The second reading, which is less common but still common enough, makes more sense. It is ???? and just follows the jukugo patterns.

context-en: I have three hundred manga.
context-en2: When I was taking a nap, somebody rang the doorbell 300 times.
context-en3: One year is three hundred and sixty-five days.
meaning-exp: You have three hundreds. What does that come out to? Three hundred.
reading-exp: The reading is a little bit weird, so be careful. You should already know the on'yomi readings, but the ??? rendakus to ???. This pattern will repeat itself with ? + many counter kanjis that can rendaku, so pay attention for it as you read Japanese.

context-en: Three plus two is five.
context-en2: Maybe it would be better to add more water to this soup.
context-en3: Can you add a little more to this sentence here?
meaning-exp: Remember ???? That is "to be enough." How can you make something be enough? You keep adding things to the pile until you reach that point where there are enough! That's why this verb is to add, because you keep adding until you ???. Maybe you add so much that someone tries to sue (?) you for that nasty pile of squirrels you keep outside.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???, so if you know that you can add things up to this.

context-en: I was finally able to pass JLPT N1.
context-en2: I could do up to here, but the last question was really difficult and I couldn’t do it.
context-en3: I ate my make-up to be pretty on the inside. Can you do that, too?
meaning-exp: When you exit and come, apparently it means to be able to do. I think of it like you're leaving a location (?) to do a task and then you come (??) back after you did it. Perhaps you were waiting in a room training like someone from Dragonball. When you leave the room, you are ready to fight the enemy and win. You train in that room to be able to do whatever you need to do, and only leave and come back alive because you were able to do it.
reading-exp: The readings are a bit strange. Both kun'yomi, where ? is ? and ?? is ??. This is different from the reading you learned with ?? (??), though, so be careful. If you can remember that and remember the kun'yomi readings from the previous vocab, you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

context-en: When can I get my broken car fixed?
context-en2: If it makes you feel better, then I don't mind at all, Aya.
context-en3: The farmer’s broken tractor was fixed.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix so the verb version is similar to that, to be fixed. This word is for when something is fixed, but you're not the one fixing it.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to learn the ?? part. Think of it this way. Something needs to be fixed. It's urgent! You have to fix it now! (??). This will also work with the similar word, ??, which you'll learn soon if you haven't already.

context-en: I thought I would die.
context-en2: My grandmother died from cancer.
context-en3: I promise you that I will never die.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means death, so the verb version is to die.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: I eat natto every morning.
context-en2: I never have enough time to eat healthy foods.
context-en3: I like to eat while I’m sleeping. It’s just like sleepwalking, but it’s called sleep-eating.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means eat so the verb version is to eat.
reading-exp: You have to remember the ? portion if you want to be able to read this word, which uses the kun'yomi reading. Think about yourself eating some tacos (?). Imagine yourself eating it, that raw beef taste in your mouth (either like it or hate it).

context-en: Turn this way, please.
context-en2: This room is facing South, so it gets very sunny.
context-en3: Now, let’s turn toward your dad and ask him why he’s wearing a baby costume.
meaning-exp: You know that the kanji means yonder, which is like "over there." This is the verb version of "yonder." That being said, "to yonder" isn't really a thing, so you have to think of what happens when you "look yonder." This word means to face or to turn toward. You're looking yonder, but you have to turn towards said yonder to look that way.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You turn to face a new direction and look out into the distance. There is a single cow out there. It turns to face you too, and says moo (?).

vocab-meaning: To Fix, To Repair, To Fix Something, To Repair Something
context-en: My PC broke. Can you fix it?
context-en2: You'd better think it through again.
context-en3: You don’t need to fix something if it’s not broken.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix so this vocab word means to fix. This is when you're fixing something, as in doing the actual physical action of fixing.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to learn the ?? part. Think of it this way. You need to fix something! It's urgent! You have to fix it now! (??). This will also work with the similar word, ??, which you'll learn soon if you haven't already.

vocab-meaning: To Get Fired, To Be Fired
context-en: I was fired from the company last month.
context-en2: Of course you would get fired, if you used up the collected money.
context-en3: I got fired yesterday for bringing a marching band into work with me.
meaning-exp: The ??? part means "to become," so literally this means "to become neck." If you think about it, when something becomes neck, it has to do with you getting your head cut off (at the neck). But, in today's modern society we don't do that too often. Instead, this means you lose your job, aka to get fired.
reading-exp: This word contains the reading you learned with the kanji. Everything else is hiragana.

context-en: We still have a little mayonnaise.
context-en2: There is only one train per hour.
context-en3: There is gold in his house as well as silver on his roof.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means have and so the verb version means to have. An alternative meaning is to exist though this refers only to non-living inanimate things, not moving and living things. So really, this is similar to "to have" as well. These kanji aren't used too often, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize them!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To have something is very nice. But now, the only thing you possess are screams. Imagine this. You are in a totally empty room with no possessions. You open a little box and look inside. It contains screams that yell: "AAAAHHHH" (?).

context-en: I don’t know anything.
context-en2: Do you know how to reboot the router?
context-en3: As you know, Koichi is a robot.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means know so the verb version means to know.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to know everything there is to know about sheep (?). Why? Because you are a busybody who wants to know everything. But for now, you'll settle for sheep. Right now all you know is that sheep are soft, come in many colors, and that they have 360 degree vision with their weird, rectangle eyes. There's even more to know, so you better get on it!

context-en: We will take a train from Tokyo station to Nakagawa station, and then we will take a bus from Nakagawa station to Mikan mountain.
context-en2: I have to go to Tokyo now, so may I have the bill, please?
context-en3: As soon as I arrived in Tokyo, I went to McDonald’s.
meaning-exp: The East Capital in Japan is Tokyo. If you look on a map and compare it to ?? (Kyoto, the other capital in history), you'll see it's East of Kyoto, making it the East Capital, Tokyo.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Would you like to go out for drinks with me tonight?
context-en2: The exam is coming up tomorrow, so I am gonna burn the midnight oil tonight.
context-en3: I feel like eating chicken wings for dinner tonight.
meaning-exp: The now night is the current night, aka tonight.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Pass Away, To Become Deceased, To Die
context-en: I heard that Matsumoto passed away.
context-en2: My younger sister died of pneumonia when she was five.
context-en3: If my mom passes away, the person who makes food for me will be gone.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This word is actually two words put together, though. ?? means "be deceased." ?? means "to become." So put that all together and you have to pass away or to become deceased. It's basically a polite way to say something died (??).
reading-exp: To learn to read this kanji you have to remember the ? part of ??, though our mnemonic will use the whole thing. If you're about to become deceased, you are probably knocking (??) on death's door.

vocab-meaning: To Replace, To Substitute, To Exchange, To Replace Something, To Substitute Something, To Exchange Something
context-en: The coach is replacing the pitcher, I think.
context-en2: I usually substitute yogurt for sour cream.
context-en3: I can’t exchange this ring for money.
meaning-exp: You know the kanji is substitute, and you know this is a verb. There are other similar ones, but this one means to replace. In order to remember that this particular word means "to replace" focus in on the ?. You have an egg in your hands that you notice isn't any good (it's black and moldy). So, you replace it with another egg (or substitute it with another egg, or exchange it with another egg, etc).
reading-exp: The reading for this one is the same as ??? which you learned in a previous level. As long as you know that one you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

context-en: I think he’s coming too.
context-en2: Do you think I should avoid going to Mexico during hurricane season?
context-en3: The simple act of thinking is not illegal, yet.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think so the verb version is to think.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? part to read this word. To do this, though, you'll have to think about that guy... hmm... what was his name? He's on The Simpsons... he's the bartender? I think? Oh! Moe (??) is his name! Thank you. Now I remember. If you don't know Moe from the Simpsons use a different Moe, perhaps the one from the Three Stooges? You should be able to come up with one.

context-en: I’m planning to walk to school.
context-en2: It's the first time we've walked holding hands in a long time.
context-en3: I’m so fat that when I walk down the street and step on a penny, I squeeze a booger out of the Queen’s nose.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means walk so the verb version means to walk.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ?? portion. Imagine yourself going to walk outside. But, as you walk, you walk like a pirate. You have a peg leg, a parrot, and a hook. Lastly, you say "arrrrr" (??). Go ahead, say it out loud while walking around your room like a pirate. It will help.

vocab-meaning: Tune, Piece Of Music, Song, Melody
context-en: What was the name of that song?
context-en2: Are there any songs you would recommend?
context-en3: He played a tune for us on the piano, but for some reason, the piano sounded like a guitar.
meaning-exp: This almost shares the meaning with the kanji. It's essentially the same thing, though when it's alone it refers to a specific piece of music (aka a tune).
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well, so you should be able to read it.

context-en: Underground it’s warm in the winter and cold in the summer.
context-en2: Many of the lakes are connected by subterranean channels.
context-en3: What do I need to do to gauge the temperature underground?
meaning-exp: If you're in the middle of the ground, then you're most likely underground. Are you a moleperson? That's pretty cool.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: There is a restroom in the basement of this building.
context-en2: I ate a lot of food samples at the food section of the department store basement.
context-en3: The Apocalypse is coming soon so I’m building an underground cellar.
meaning-exp: Below the ground is underground.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m anxious about passing.
context-en2: I'm so nervous about the impending childbirth.
context-en3: Since I witnessed the murder, I haven't been able to rid myself of these feelings of anxiety.
meaning-exp: When you're not relaxed how do you feel? Uneasiness is what you'd feel.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The author of this story is unknown.
context-en2: This milk doesn't have an expiration date on it.
context-en3: Huh? When you were sleeping you used an onion for a pillow? I don’t really get what you’re saying.
meaning-exp: Something that is not bright is cloudy and fuzzy. What do you think when you look into the fuzzy clouds? It is the unknown, the unclear, the uncertain.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please capitalize the first letter.
context-en2: Please rewrite the title in uppercase letters.
context-en3: For some reason I like uppercase more than lowercase.
meaning-exp: You have big writing letters. What do you think these are? THAT WOULD HAVE TO BE UPPERCASE LETTERS, RIGHT? Whoops, sorry, caps lock was on for a moment, there.
reading-exp: The readings for the kanji in this word are a bit strange. The ? portion is actually read using the kun'yomi, the same reading as you learned with ??? (????). Everything else is just on'yomi. So, you'll need to remember the one exception with ?. If you do, you should be okay.

context-en: What you see over there is Venus.
context-en2: Do they have Sports Day in the school on Venus?
context-en3: Someday humans will migrate to Venus.
meaning-exp: The gold star is Venus. It's the only planet in our solar system that's the same color as gold.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Whisper In Ear, Whisper In One's Ear, Whisper In Someone's Ear
context-en: He secretly whispered in my ear.
context-en2: I happened to witness Koichi whispering something in Nikka's ear during the meeting.
context-en3: I told him to whisper something sexy in my ear and he said, "Do you like tapes and CDs?"
meaning-exp: A hit to someone's ear... you'd think that would be like yelling into their ear, but it's not. Think of it like you're hitting your mouth to their ear so that it's nice and close so you can whisper in ear.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

vocab-meaning: Winter Holiday, Winter Break, Winter Vacation
context-en: During winter break my family stayed in a hotel in the mountains.
context-en2: Winter holiday was pretty tough because my sons fight so often at home.
context-en3: During winter vacation, I jogged everyday, all day long.
meaning-exp: The winter rest! Wait, nobody calls it that. This is a winter holiday or winter break.
reading-exp: The readings for these are both the kun'yomi readings. Hopefully you learned them when you were doing vocab in the previous levels so that all you have to do now is combine the two separate words into one bigger word. Please don't take a winter break until you figure this word out.

context-en: I got a wool blanket as a Christmas present.
context-en2: I'm so happy to have come across this wool felt doll.
context-en3: Woolen mittens are great for stuffing pillows.
meaning-exp: A sheep's fur is wool.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I fell and twisted my wrist.
context-en2: Hot oil splashed on my wrist and I got burned.
context-en3: My twin sister has a mole on her wrist.
meaning-exp: Your hand's neck is your wrist!
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

context-en: Morita has a younger girlfriend.
context-en2: Koichi is 38 years younger than Arnold Schwarzenegger.
context-en3: Even though that kid is younger, he’s really mature.
meaning-exp: When you have someone who has years below your own, this person is younger than you.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is kind of strange. It is the kun'yomi reading for both of the kanji. You know the kun'yomi readings from earlier, back when you learned the vocab ? and ?.

context-en: Who is Tanaka’s younger sister?
context-en2: I feel betrayed by my little sister.
context-en3: My younger sister just cut off all of her hair so she could make wigs for her Barbie dolls.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your younger sister is really into emotes (????). Look up this word if you're not a teenage girl. Just imagine her sending you these on your phone over and over. You tell your younger sister: "HEY, STOP SENDING ME EMOTES."

vocab-meaning: After This, From Now On, After, Since
context-en: "After this you need to be more careful so this doesn't happen again." "Yes, teacher. I'll be more careful from now on."
context-en2: Viet hasn't been heard of since October 29—Tofugu Day.
context-en3: After that, the writer stopped drinking alcohol, not even a single drop.
meaning-exp: From after, just means after this or from now on.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Anticipation, Anticipate, Going Ahead, Arriving Ahead
context-en: Let’s go ahead and ambush them!
context-en2: Riku is very impatient, and always tries to guess what I'm going to say before I've said it, and it's been really annoying me.
context-en3: He beat me to the top of Mt. Fuji and then laughed at me for being slow.
meaning-exp: If you know of something that happens previous to something rotating (??), you will then be in anticipation of its actions and rotations based on previous knowledge.
reading-exp: This consists of a couple kun'yomi readings put together. You can tell it's kun'yomi because of the hiragana sticking out at the end. In the previous level you learned both the words ? and ?? (verb version of ??). If you know those, you should be able to put them together to learn the reading of this word as well.

context-en: Is there a hotel around there?
context-en2: They have very heavy snowfall in that region.
context-en3: I can calculate the height and area from the length of an equilateral triangle.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: The area fell silent.
context-en2: Oh, I forgot to tell you that there is no station in this neighborhood.
context-en3: His bathroom must be somewhere around here.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji for area. This makes it have the same meaning as the kanji: area or vicinity.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you think about an area that you're in, it's the place you're at (??).

context-en: There aren’t many people around here, so it’s quiet.
context-en2: Is there Starbucks around here?
context-en3: You have to be careful about what you say around here. People on this side of town will spit in your face just for whistling.
meaning-exp: ?? means "this" so ??? just means this area.
reading-exp: The reading for the kanji portion is just what you've already learned with the kanji ? so this shouldn't be a difficult one to read for you.

context-en: I got an autograph from an aspiring author.
context-en2: This novelist pushed things pretty far, eh?
context-en3: That best-selling author’s hobby is playing soccer.
meaning-exp: This is a strange one, but only at first glance. You make a house. You'd think this would mean something like "building a house" or "construction" or something. Instead, it means author. Think of it this way: An author makes (writes and creates works) in their home. Authors don't make their word magic in a corporate office!
reading-exp: The readings are on'yomi readings, though ?? from ? gets shortened to ??. Just be sure to remember that and you should be able to read this word just fine.

context-en: That clown made a dog out of a balloon for me.
context-en2: Please use this balloon as a motion sickness bag when you feel air sick.
context-en3: Some people actually made a house float using balloons.
meaning-exp: A wind boat. This is a strange one for sure. You may assume this is like one of those giant balloons you can go ride around in, and you'd be partly right. Really, this word covers the general word balloon, though it especially has to do with the toy-style balloons (or smaller balloons). It's a little round wind ship!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I think there will be an announcement about it soon.
context-en2: We're supposed to get snow soon, so if we get a lot, I will make a snow igloo.
context-en3: You’ll get cancer before long if you keep smoking.
meaning-exp: When something is close close (the ? character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen before long.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi reading twice; that's the one you learn with the vocab word ?? from the previous level. The second ? gets converted to ??, though, so take note of that.

context-en: Could you give me change for a 10,000 yen bill?
context-en2: Can you break this 2,000 yen bill to two 1,000 yen bills, please?
context-en3: Apparently, there are many hundred-dollar bills hidden all over the Tofugu office.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. When you see this word after number, it’s for physical bills of money.
reading-exp: This is a suffix that takes the on’yomi reading, which you’ve learned already!

context-en: There are a lot of beautiful birds in this park.
context-en2: When I opened my curtain this morning, everything was covered with bird poop.
context-en3: I wish I was a bird because then I wouldn’t get made fun of for walking like one.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you think about birds, what is the most common bird you can think of? What bird do you hate the most or like eating the most? Either one will work. Now, imagine yourself going up to that bird. You did something terrible. You tore (??) off its wing and started eating it (pretend it's cooked first, if that makes you less nauseous).

context-en: Can you get me the black hat up there?
context-en2: That man with the black goatee is notorious for being black-hearted.
context-en3: My favorite channel on TV is called "Black Screen." It only airs when the power goes off.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of black? It's also black. Special Note: The noun version of black also exists in Japanese. It is just ? with the same pronunciation, but minus the ? which makes it adjective-tastic.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of black things. One very common black thing is the common crow (??). Associate those two together.

context-en: I can’t understand how there are still people who discriminate against black people.
context-en2: I'm black, he's white. What's wrong with that?
context-en3: Peanut butter was invented by a black person named George Washington Carver.
meaning-exp: A black person is simply a black person, kind of like how a ?? is a "white person," but a different color.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Is the ocean blue because of the blue sky?
context-en2: Let our future generations have the same beautiful sky as we do.
context-en3: Today, it was sunny all day and the blue sky was above us.
meaning-exp: This is simply a blue sky (aka a blue sky!).
reading-exp: You'd think that this word would use on'yomi readings to read it, but it doesn't (shake that angry fist at the kanji gods!). Instead, it's double kun'yomi, probably because this word is really like two separate words put together, "blue" and "sky." In the previous level you unlocked these two separate words, learning their readings. That means you should be able to read this as well. One quick note is the rendaku-fication of ? as well. It becomes ??.

context-en: What time will the next ship leave?
context-en2: I always feel sea sick when I'm on a boat.
context-en3: I’m the captain and I run this entire ship by myself.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're riding in a boat. It's great. Imagine it being the best time you've had in your life. You tell everyone: "This is fun, eh?" (??). You're on a Canadian ship, which is why you add the "eh" in there. Say this out loud wherever you are right now while imagining the sea smell, the wind, and the excitement of boats.

context-en: What will the students do in the classroom first?
context-en2: The teacher witnessed him putting a cigarette in his mouth in the classroom.
context-en3: The teacher had only been gone for five minutes, but the university students had completely trashed the classroom.
meaning-exp: The teaching room is just a classroom.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please teach me the conjugated form of this verb.
context-en2: Yesterday, I started re-learning the conjugated form of auxiliary verbs.
context-en3: In this dictionary app it’s possible to look up verbs using their conjugated forms.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means "conjugation" and that ?? means "form, so that means this is the conjugated form!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I’m going to leave your diary with this book here.
context-en2: We don't have a culture of diary exchange in North America.
context-en3: I read Fugu’s journal last night and, to be honest, it was really sad.
meaning-exp: When you write down your day (and do it every day) that's your diary.
reading-exp: This jukugo word uses the on'yomi readings, except the ? (??) is shortened with a small ?, making the reading ???.

vocab-meaning: District Of A Town, City Block, Town District, District
context-en: My girlfriend Miiko lives in 2-chome too.
context-en2: The typhoon flooded both 1-chome and 2-chome.
context-en3: I got this peach from Tanaka of 3-chome.
meaning-exp: A street you can see with your eye isn't soooo big you can't see it (like a town would be), but it's still pretty big because it has a street. This section of the town is the district of a town, or a city block (though specifically one of an irregular size).
reading-exp: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, so use those and you'll be A-Okay.

context-en: I’m going to bring a doll for her birthday present.
context-en2: Put the doll back the way you found it.
context-en3: Until the age of 17, my best friend was a sock puppet.
meaning-exp: Something that is person shaped that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of doll or puppet.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is pretty normal, though the reading for ? is different from the one you learned. To remember this, think of a doll... made totally of gyoza (???) dumplings. This doll is crazy (like most dolls) and it's eating itself and trying to get you to eat some of it too. Hey... why you no eat me? Mmmm. Gyoza doll.

vocab-meaning: Elementary School Student, Primary School Student, Elementary Schooler, Primary Schooler, Grade Schooler, Grade School Student
context-en: I may just be an elementary school student, but if you underestimate me, you'll regret it!
context-en2: When I opened the classroom door, there was a grade schooler sleeping like a rock.
context-en3: When I was an elementary school student, I always made my decisions by flipping a coin.
meaning-exp: You know ?? is student, so what is a small student? Think young. That would be an Elementary School Student.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: End Of The Month, Month End
context-en: I’m going to lose five kilos by the end of this month.
context-en2: This company exploits its employees too much, so I'm bailing out at the end of the month!
context-en3: My boss pays me in koala bears. I get two at the end of every month.
meaning-exp: You know how ? can also mean month? If you add ? on there you have the "month end" aka the end of the month.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I like fish, but I don’t like it raw.
context-en2: I always eat granola and fish for a well-balanced breakfast.
context-en3: I’ll never buy fish from the back of a pickup truck in Mexico again.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine a fish. Now imagine the fish playing soccer, while wearing a nun's outfit. This is a soccer nun (???).

vocab-meaning: Frantic, Desperate, Certain Death, Sure Death
context-en: Even if I try desperately, it might still be futile.
context-en2: I heard that my grandfather went to the war front prepared to die.
context-en3: "Captain, I really need to return to Mars. I left my iPhone there," he said desperately.
meaning-exp: Your future consists of certain death. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very frantic and desperate. Another translation for this word is simply certain death, though I'd rather you learn one of the first two before this one if you can.
reading-exp: The readings are the on'yomi readings, though ? (??) gets shortened to ??. In your desperate situation just imagine that you're trying to get out of it, and to do so you move the ? only to find a smaller ? blocking your way. It is certain death.

context-en: I started living by myself and I have some free time to spare.
context-en2: To obtain freedom, we still have a long way to go, but we will never give up.
context-en3: The money Japanese salarymen can use freely every month is, on average, usually only 35,000 yen.
meaning-exp: When you have self reason, you are able to think for yourself. When you can think for yourself, you have freedom. Very philosophical this vocab is.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Full Name, First And Last Name
context-en: You at least want to be able to write your full name in Japanese, right?
context-en2: For your information, my name is Ichiko Ko.
context-en3: If you would please write your first and last name on the waiver, we will proceed with shooting an apple off of your head with a cannon.
meaning-exp: Both of these kanji have to do with names. You have both family name and name. Both of those names together makes for a First And Last Name... a full name if you will.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Future, The Future, Distant Future, The Distant Future
context-en: If I could time travel, I’d want to go to the future.
context-en2: On the weekend, I was traveling back and forth through time.
context-en3: Koichi has a bright future as an astronaut, so please don't interrupt him.
meaning-exp: What has not yet come? The future.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I like studying geography by myself too, but it’s more fun to study with my friend.
context-en2: My American friend is not good at geography at all, so I heard that she used to think Japan was the capital of China until very recently.
context-en3: What do you mean we’re lost? Aren’t you a geography teacher?
meaning-exp: The reason the earth is the way it is is because of the geography of it. Though it may seem kind of strange that geography is bringing reason to the earth, if you think of geography as a study, then you can think about how you try to get reason through that, as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I scooped this goldfish at a goldfish scooping booth during a summer festival five years ago.
context-en2: Can goldfish get colds, too?
context-en3: Goldfish only have three second memories so they’re always surprised when they realize that they live in a castle.
meaning-exp: A gold fish is really just gold in color, but it's still called a goldfish.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: After this, we’ll be splitting into two teams.
context-en2: Our group is famous around here.
context-en3: I heard Koichi in grade 3 class 2 was asked out again.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're part of a special group. It is the cumin group, and they deal with all things cumin (the spice / seed). Smell the cumin. Touch it. Taste it. You live and breathe the stuff, because you are the president of this cumin group. P.S. This can also be spelled ?? (same overall reading: ??).

context-en: This table was handmade by Hayashi.
context-en2: I try to have a homemade, well-balanced diet every day.
context-en3: Handmade presents are pretty scary because they reveal that you have too much free time.
meaning-exp: When something is made with hand, it is handmade.
reading-exp: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. Just think of this word as two separate words put together (? and ??). The ? in ?? gets changed to ? because it's an adjective, and the ? in ??? gets changed to ? because of the way the words are combined with each other. You should know most of the reading that is in this word, though it will probably take a little bit of thinking to sort out the little changes in those readings.

context-en: The unpleasant feeling vanished when I looked up at the sky.
context-en2: Airi became a star in the firmament.
context-en3: The eagle flew leisurely in the heavens.
meaning-exp: The big thing in the sky is the heavens. The heavens where birds and planes soar, not the one you go to after you die if you've been really good.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that ?? becomes ?? because of rendaku here.

context-en: It only takes 10 minutes to get to the high school if you drive.
context-en2: What kind of food do you guys usually have for lunch in high school?
context-en3: I didn’t start talking until I went to high school. Now I can’t shut up.
meaning-exp: The tall school is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's high school, when most people stop growing taller.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Everyone, please stop by my house.
context-en2: You really need to clean your house.
context-en3: Home is where the heart is. And the food.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You visit your friend's home. However, this home isn't any normal home. They live at the video game company EA (??). Imagine yourself going to your friend's home from school every day. You go to EA, settle in, and play some video games. What a great home that would be to visit. There's another reading as well, though, and it's ??. This reading is used for your own home. For someone else's home you'd use ??, though.

vocab-meaning: How To Make, Way To Make, Way Of Making
context-en: Please teach me how to make delicious macaroni and cheese.
context-en2: There are three ways to make barley tea; steeping it in boiling water, steeping it slowly in boiled water, and steeping it slowly in cold water, and each comes with pros and cons.
context-en3: Do you want to know how to make a ninja star?
meaning-exp: This is the way to make something. This is how to make something. You'll see this for directions on building something.
reading-exp: You should know the kun'yomi readings for both of these from lower level vocab. Use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

context-en: Who graffitied the hull?
context-en2: The kraken smashed its tentacles through the ship's hull.
context-en3: The hull was bigger than I thought.
meaning-exp: A boat's body is called the hull.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: In A Big Way, On A Grand Scale
context-en: Please exhale deeply.
context-en2: This Tofu & Fugu pizza chain is expanding its franchise in a big way.
context-en3: The value of yen has risen greatly.
meaning-exp: This is the adverb version of the kanji big It's a little thing you can put in front of things to say that they are "in a big way" or "on a grand scale."
reading-exp: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word ???, you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: School was out last week.
context-en2: You sure have grown a lot! You were still tiny last week though.
context-en3: I was interviewed by a talking dog about the Comecon convention I attended last week. He was so insulting.
meaning-exp: The previous week was last week.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Less Than, Or Less, Not Exceeding, Below
context-en: I’m looking for a bookshelf that’s 5,000 yen or less.
context-en2: The list of cat breeds that Koichi likes is as follows:
context-en3: Those below are the same.
meaning-exp: Compared with this, it's below. That's another way to say that what you have is less than it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I sent a letter to a foreign country.
context-en2: Why don't you put up the letter from Kim Jong Il for online auction? I think somebody would buy it.
context-en3: I’m going to write a very heated letter to Coca-Cola and ask why there is so much sugar in their products.
meaning-exp: A hand paper being a letter seems kind of strange, but think of it this way: Paper that you can fit in your hand? That's good for a letter. Also, you could write a letter on your hand if you want, though it would hurt a lot to chop off your hand and send it (imagine doing this).
reading-exp: The reading is double kun'yomi (body parts tend to make kanji in words change to a kun'yomi reading). Both kanji in this word had you learn that reading right from the start, though, so you should be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku making it ??, not ??.

context-en: Why are they both whispering?
context-en2: "I want you to try on a school uniform. I think you'll look good in it." Koichi whispered to Viet in my fantasy.
context-en3: The man started speaking in a low voice.
meaning-exp: A small voice is so small that you can hardly hear it. It's a low voice or a whisper.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because, like in ??, the ?? becomes ?? thanks to our old friend rendaku.

context-en: I want to be able to manipulate cats' minds as much as I want.
context-en2: Men, with the exception of Haruto, don't understand the delicate psychology of women.
context-en3: Can you depict the mental state of Salmon and those she deceives in your novel? I think people would love it.
meaning-exp: The reasoning that your heart makes decides what you do. Probably when kanji was being made people thought that the heart directed our actions, not our brains. So, if you think about it that way, the reasoning of your heart is your mental state. Nowadays that's known as psychology.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Middle School Student, Junior High School Student, Middle Schooler, Junior High Schooler, Junior High Student
context-en: You are a middle schooler now, but you're still taking baths with your mom?
context-en2: Even a junior high student knows that you should choose your battles wisely.
context-en3: When I was a middle school student, the biggest lie I said to myself was, "I can remember that without writing it down."
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? (means student). Now let's look at a student who's in the middle. Perhaps we can call this a middle school student or a junior high school student, depending on where you're from.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: As we all know, Mr. Abe’s statements never change.
context-en2: Mr. Koichi and Mr. Viet have good chemistry.
context-en3: Yo, Mr. White, why don’t you just sit down?
meaning-exp: The kanji means family name because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word mister. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji.

vocab-meaning: More Than, Or More, That's All
context-en: Only people 18 or older can watch this movie.
context-en2: That's all for the paperwork.
context-en3: People who are 100 years old or older must wear bras.
meaning-exp: Compared with this, it's more. That's another way to say that what you have is more than it. That's all. ;)
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m currently living with my sister near the school.
context-en2: Seen close up, that teen idol is not pretty at all, huh?
context-en3: Don’t you want to have a drink at the yakitori shop nearby?
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji near. So it also means near, or in the neighborhood of something.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned ??, so you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: I’m going to a restaurant next Sunday.
context-en2: I wonder how much snow we'll get next week.
context-en3: The drinking party was postponed until next week.
meaning-exp: The next week is the next week. It isn't last week or this week, it's the next one!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: There’s still never been a person who’s lived to two hundred years old.
context-en2: I’m still jet-lagged.
context-en3: I’m not sure if I got the job yet. It seems like they still have to interview twelve other applicants.
meaning-exp: This is the adverb version of ?, meaning it means the same thing: not yet.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone's telling you "not yet... not yet.... not yet..." you have some food on your nose, but you're not allowed to eat it until your ma says it's okay. "Not yet... Not yet..." Why would your mom treat you like a dog like this? Oh well... maybe she'll let you eat the food soon, at least.

context-en: Is salmon a saltwater fish? Or is it a freshwater fish?
context-en2: In the sea, there were a lot of colorful ocean fish swimming around.
context-en3: There is a wide variety of saltwater fish at the aquarium, but the staff said we’re not allowed to eat any of them.
meaning-exp: An ocean fish is simply an ocean fish. They also happen to be the most delicious kind of fish.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When it’s three o’clock let’s have our afternoon snack break.
context-en2: Let's meet up at Koichi's kitchen at 2:30, ok?
context-en3: What time do you usually do your WaniKani reviews?
meaning-exp: If there's a number before it's referring to the hour. For example, if you see 1? it is "1:00." If you see 23? it's 23:00 or 11pm.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Older Brother, Big Brother, Elder Brother
context-en: Which one is Takashi’s older brother?
context-en2: The mailman's face was totally my type today.
context-en3: I can’t help thinking about my older brother’s nose hair.
meaning-exp: This word starts with an ? to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji ? which you already know. Lastly, it has ?? which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying "older brother" (versus plain old ?).
reading-exp: The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the ? part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Your (kind) older brother pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your knee (??), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you ????!"

vocab-meaning: One Loaf of Bread, One Loaf
context-en: Loaves of bread are often sold in slices of six or eight.
context-en2: I need to survive on only one loaf of bread until payday.
context-en3: I can live off of a loaf of bread and some Nutella.
meaning-exp: One bread loaf counter is counting one loaf of bread.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening though!

context-en: I take a bath for about an hour every day.
context-en2: Put your toys away by one o'clock.
context-en3: If you worked for me, your shift would start at one o’clock in the afternoon and end at three o’clock at latest. Sounds good?
meaning-exp: When it's one o'clock it's time to eat lunch, or take a nap, or something. It's also one o'clock.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m okay with anything other than beer.
context-en2: I read nothing but manga.
context-en3: Other than the groom looking down the front of the bride’s dress during the ceremony, it was a nice wedding.
meaning-exp: Compared with this, it's outside what you wanted. You'll have anything other than that.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please put some paper, a pencil, and an eraser on your desk.
context-en2: I'm so looking forward to buying a new piece of paper.
context-en3: Yesterday, I saw a wolf writing a poem on a piece of paper.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but lucky for you that's the reading you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this vocab too.

context-en: In this era, you can buy anything on the Internet.
context-en2: Akari is my friend from college.
context-en3: Murasaki Shikibu was a female writer and poet from the mid–Heian period.
meaning-exp: You have a period of time and it's called a period or era! Simple!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I met you once before at a party, right?
context-en2: I used to get seasick all the time, but not anymore.
context-en3: My best friend is from a planet that was previously unknown to astronomers.
meaning-exp: From before, just means previously or before now.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You should study psychology if you work in sales.
context-en2: According to the psychology explanation, it looks like when you are able to say something mean to a person, you're actually being dependent on them.
context-en3: My major was criminal psychology in college.
meaning-exp: The reason your heart does what it does is all psychological. The study of that is psychology.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Japanese people are really kind.
context-en2: This product has gotten truly expensive.
context-en3: Is this really the way?
meaning-exp: ?? is reality or truth (level 5 vocab). If you go towards truth and reality, you are saying that it is really and truly true. ???! It is!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It shares the reading with the level 5 ?? as well, but just has a particle on the end to show you're going towards reality. Really!

context-en: I don’t have any specific reason.
context-en2: Do you have any reason for not having settled your business expenses yet?
context-en3: Using logic and reason, he solved the case of the rubber gloves and the culprit was the balloon maker.
meaning-exp: The reason reason is so reason-ish! That's why this word means reason as well, how could it not? Do you have a reason why it shouldn't be? I thought not.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Room Number Counter, Counter For Room Numbers, Suffix For Room Numbers, Room Number
context-en: Your room is 302.
context-en2: The room 444 of this apartment is known for being haunted.
context-en3: I’m Sakamoto from room 102.
meaning-exp: This is a counter that can be used after numbers to let you know what number room it is. It's a room number counter that you use in apartments and hotels to know exactly which room you're looking for.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Excuse me, but can you speak Japanese?
context-en2: If you use "anata" in an actual conversation, it often sounds impolite.
context-en3: Would you think I’m rude if I told you that you’re fat?
meaning-exp: When you do something that's your fault and then you say "thanks" after you do it, that's super-duper rude, wouldn't you say? Imagine doing something like this and then thinking to yourself after... wow, I was really rude.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: At the same time teacher came in the classroom, the bell rang.
