context-en2: I was using the microwave and the toaster at the same time, and the circuit breaker tripped.
context-en3: "Good lesson today. I’ll see you this time next week," the professional cosplayer and the anime nerd said at the same time.
meaning-exp: The same time? Okay, let's say what we think this word means at the same time. Whoops, I just said it, sorry.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I go to school on foot.
context-en2: I have to submit an absentee notice to my school, so can I have one, please?
context-en3: Why are we barbecuing hot dogs at school during class today?
meaning-exp: A study school is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a school.
reading-exp: This jukugo word consists of on'yomi readings, except ? (??) is shortened with a small ? to make it ????.

context-en: I spoke with my wife and we decided to go with this shape, because we value substance over form.
context-en2: With this, I could somehow manage to keep up appearances.
context-en3: Hey, do you want to rub my butt-shaped belly?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You really want to eat food that's in neat shapes, so you decide to use a cutter (??) on your cheese (?) to make it a new shape. Square cheese is so boring. After you cut it up you have mouse shaped cheese! It just tastes better like that.

vocab-meaning: Shortcoming, Fault, Defect, Flaw, Weakness, Weak Point
context-en: Everyone has some sort of weakness.
context-en2: Oh, I just remembered, she doesn't have any faults.
context-en3: I’ll never become a professional soccer player because I have too many shortcomings, for example, I don’t have any legs.
meaning-exp: You have a lack of points. These are things about yourself you wish were better. These are your shortcomings.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because ?? is being shortened to ?? here!

context-en: Does it snow in Japan too?
context-en2: Did you also get snow over there?
context-en3: The first time I ever saw snow was when I was 46 years old.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this vocab word. Enjoy the snow!

context-en: Even if I leave home right now, I think I’ll probably be late for social studies.
context-en2: As a member of the international society, I will not yield to food porn.
context-en3: As a society, we need to be concerned about youths taking ’selfies’ at funerals.
meaning-exp: Not to be confused with ??, which is a company, this is society. When a company meets together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a society.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: This glue is pretty strong, so please be careful.
context-en2: I was taught how to make a powerful, mini water pump.
context-en3: When I look at her, I feel as though I have the strength of ten men.
meaning-exp: You have strong power. This is your strength.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Who is the strongest among these people?
context-en2: By the shape of the beak and color of the feathers, this would probably be a very strong crow.
context-en3: The ocean's currents were too strong for the cat and it was carried away.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strong? It's also strong.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: So you wanna be strong huh? Well, all you have to do is eat these two yogurts (??). One is filled with horse steroids, the other is full of bull steroids. They will make you so strong.

context-en: This summer is hotter than last year.
context-en2: I want to go buy some summer dresses sometime soon.
context-en3: Summer is only good for three things. Movies, video games, and duck carving.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for the vocab.

vocab-meaning: Summer Vacation, Summer Break, Summer Holiday
context-en: Summer vacation is one month long.
context-en2: I can't believe all the different kinds of fish we saw when diving in Okinawa during summer break.
context-en3: When I was a kid, my parents took me to Disney Land for summer vacation, but they forgot me there when they left. It was the only time I was happy to be lost.
meaning-exp: You know that ? means summer and ? means rest. What is a "summer rest" though? It's a summer break or summer vacation.
reading-exp: The readings are kun'yomi readings because this word is essentially two separate words put together into one word. You should know the reading for ? from the kanji and the reading for ?? from the vocab.

vocab-meaning: Surely, Certainly, Without Exception, Always, Definitely
context-en: He’ll definitely come back, so I’m okay.
context-en2: You should always take out your contacts before going to bed. Otherwise your eyesight will get worse.
context-en3: I will certainly complete WaniKani no matter what.
meaning-exp: This word looks like a verb but it's not (sorry!). It's an adverb. The kanji itself means certain and the vocab version means all sorts of variations on that: surely, certainly, and without exception to name a few.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ra, the Egyptian god asks you: "Can you do it? Are you certain you can build the pyramids?" "Yes I can ra (???). Yes I can," you reply.

context-en: Pulling a swan out of the lake just to take a selfie with it is too cruel.
context-en2: They say that white wine goes well with fish, but do you know what kind of wine would go well with swan?
context-en3: Swans are so pretty, but they use foul language.
meaning-exp: There are many white birds out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the swan. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please put this amulet on the inside of your front door.
context-en2: You should be careful not to show your hand.
context-en3: Jello is really disgusting. There should be a picture of a skull and crossbones on the label.
meaning-exp: This word is almost the same as the kanji, but only half of it. It means tag or amulet. They're about the same shape and size as money, but you can't buy a house with them (...probably).
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You can't find your tag anywhere. It was on your luggage, you swear, but now it's nowhere to be found. You forget about it for a while, then you eat your dinner (you're at a fancy dinner party). As you finish up your meal you see something. Your label fell into your food (??)!

context-en: This restaurant is expensive, but delicious.
context-en2: That is too high for me to reach, so I've brought James Stewart, who is very tall, down from Heaven.
context-en3: Why are suits from the "Big and Tall" store so expensive?
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of tall or expensive? It's the same: tall or expensive. Weird that this word means both of these things, yeah? Just imagine money piled up to be really tall. That money is tall because it needs to buy something expensive.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There's a tall dude trying to sell you something really expensive. He's really going off on how great this item is and how you should buy it. This guy is a real salesman. A real talker (??).

context-en: If this kind of game is popular, then it’s the end of the world.
context-en2: You must be looking forward to seeing what your son might end up being in the future.
context-en3: After a heated discussion, my youngest son left to bury my gold somewhere.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You've reached the end of the universe. Nothing is there. You step out, and you're surprised because you get greeted by Sue. Imagine meeting this Sue, and talking to them for a while. You should come up with a Sue that you know or a famous Sue that you know. Just pick something you can remember.

vocab-meaning: The Heck, In The World, On Earth
context-en: What the heck is going on?
context-en2: What the heck does, "There's a thin line between love and hate," mean?
context-en3: What the heck did you say I did?
meaning-exp: Okay, so this one is really weird, sorry. Each of us only get one body in our lifetimes, right? Well what the heck! What if I want more than one body. Let's all be mad about this together.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because ?? is shortened to ?? here!

context-en: Will the people really give us their approval?
context-en2: How do you become a citizen of Japan?
context-en3: The people waiting in line for the new PS4 game last night froze to death.
meaning-exp: The country peoples are the people of your country. They are the people.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There is a lot of work to do this week.
context-en2: Let's meet up in front of the Hachiko statue at 11 a.m. this Tuesday.
context-en3: This week is going to be really busy because I just bought four new video games.
meaning-exp: The now week is this week.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can never explain my own thoughts well.
context-en2: Your thoughts are too optimistic.
context-en3: Can I buy your thoughts for 100 yen?
meaning-exp: This is a noun version of think. What is "a think"? It's a thought.
reading-exp: You learned this reading with ???, just cut off the ?!

context-en: When you want to turn on the air conditioning, please press the white button.
context-en2: We can do nothing but wait for time to solve this.
context-en3: Whenever I’m happy, I always think it would be nice if I could stop time.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What time is it? It's time to key (??) your enemy's car. Imagine yourself looking at your watch, waiting until the correct time to perform a synchronized keying of someone's car. Who do you hate the most? Whose car would you like to key?

context-en: Are you one of those people who puts ketchup in their grilled cheese?
context-en2: Why did you name your doggy Nikka?
context-en3: Why are you attaching leeches to your head?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attach so the verb version is to attach.
reading-exp: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this one just fine.

vocab-meaning: To Be Found, To Come Upon, To Come Across
context-en: I can't find my wallet.
context-en2: I looked for it, but couldn't find it anywhere.
context-en3: I can’t find my reading glasses.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. It's made up of the kanji for see and right, so what happens when you see the right thing? You manage to come upon what you're looking for or to be found, if you're the one who's lost and you see the right people that are looking for you. Note: This verb is almost always used in the negative form. It is very, very rare for it to be positive. So when you're using it, make sure no one found the thing you're talking about!
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: To Lack, To Be Lacking, To Be Chipped
context-en: I fell off my bike and chipped my front teeth.
context-en2: Hypothetically speaking, if we got fired because the spout of Koichi's favorite teapot got chipped, are we still entitled to apply for Employment Insurance?
context-en3: I lack the willpower to stop watching Sailor Moon.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lack so the vocab verb version means to lack.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You lack something... it's a car (?). You can't stop thinking about this because you have to walk 40 miles to get to your destination. If only you didn't lack a car this would be easier. Imagine the sweat... the pain... the thirst... all because you lack a car.

vocab-meaning: To Lose, To Part With, To Lose Something, To Part With Something
context-en: I already have nothing to lose.
context-en2: The information that Tofugu gambled away its entire assets is not reliable.
context-en3: The worst day of my life was when I lost my AKB48 Barbie doll.
meaning-exp: The kanji portion means fault, so you would think the verb version is "to fault." It's a little different, though. Think of it this way, if you "fault" something, you're messing up. What's a great way to mess up? By losing something. That's why this word means to lose. Pretend like you are supposed to hold on to someone's wedding ring. You make the biggest fault of all. You lose it. Ouch.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How did you lose this wedding ring? An ? Nun (?? + ?) ate it. The only way to get it back is to cut open this cow nun and get it back.

context-en: This road is narrow and difficult to pass through.
context-en2: It seems impossible to become fluent in Japanese, but everybody who learns a new language travels along the same road.
context-en3: I stopped by Canada on the way to England to get some maple syrup for the tea party.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pass through so the verb vocab version means to pass through.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There's something in front of you that you have to pass through but you can't. It's a wall. In order to pass through it, you decide to kick it as hard as you can to knock it down. Unfortunately, it is way stronger than you, and your toe explodes on contact. You yell: "TOE! OH!" (??) and then just scream a lot.

context-en: The stars are shining.
context-en2: You've got some glittery paint on your right shoe.
context-en3: I’m sure I saw something shining over there.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sunlight, so the verb is to shine or to glitter. Just imagine what happens when sunlight hits things!
reading-exp: Remember how you learned the reading for ?? Well this is almost the same thing. Just change the ? to ? and you'll know this reading!

context-en: Please teach me how to answer.
context-en2: There aren't any "demon coaches" among people who teach Japanese on WaniKani, are there?
context-en3: Good morning, class. Today I’m going to teach you about the dangers of eating eggplant.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means teach so the verb vocab version means to teach.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about your favorite teacher. Now think about him/her teaching you the following: "Today I'm going to teach you about the ocean (??)." It is big. Really big. Inside it are krakens, space aliens, and lost cities. Here is where you continue the lesson in your head, making it the most ridiculous lesson about the ocean you've ever heard. Focus in on the ocean part, since that's the reading, always coming back to it.

context-en: The townspeople should find shelter right now!
context-en2: These townspeople are all able to clean up after themselves.
context-en3: I feel like all the people in this town boast about being townspeople here.
meaning-exp: Town peoples are the townspeople!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Traffic accidents happen a lot here.
context-en2: There's heavy traffic on the street in front of the building the Tofugu office is in.
context-en3: I wish my car had helicopter blades so I could fly over this traffic jam.
meaning-exp: When things get all mixed up while trying to pass through each other it becomes a mess. This can be people, cars, bikes, what have you. Anything that has to move around and pass through each other. When this happens things slow down and you get traffic.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How do you make onigiri into a triangle?
context-en2: A big triangle, consisting of three magnitude stars from Lyra, Aquila, and Cygnus, stretches out in the summer night sky.
context-en3: There is a triangle park there.
meaning-exp: You already learned that ?? means "triangle." Well this means triangle too, but it's the mathematical term. You should use it in math class.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Two Loaves of Bread, Two Loaves
context-en: If you buy two loaves of bread it will be 100 yen cheaper.
context-en2: Even though I baked two loaves of bread, we finished it all.
context-en3: Do you think we can finish these two loaves of bread even though they're expiring the day after tomorrow?
meaning-exp: Two bread loaf counters are counting two loaves of bread.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Two Thirty, Half Past Two, Half Two
context-en: The film begins at two-thirty.
context-en2: I have an important appointment at 2:30, but I overslept and now I'm freaking out.
context-en3: "I’m meeting my mom’s father’s daughter’s niece tomorrow at two-thirty in the afternoon." "Why didn’t you just say you’re meeting your older sister for lunch tomorrow? Jeez!"
meaning-exp: When it's two o'clock and a half what time do you think it is? That would be two thirty.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This typhoon is weak, so it seems that we don’t have to worry too much.
context-en2: Strong typhoon Tofu made landfall in western Japan on Monday.
context-en3: A large typhoon is approaching the Japanese islands.
meaning-exp: A machine that pumps wind can malfunction and make too much, causing a typhoon. It's a really powerful machine to be able to move that much wind.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Instead of ?? for ? though, this uses the reading ??. Remember it like this: When a typhoon is coming you have to tie (??) down all of your stuff. Or, you know, if you already know the word typhoon, that's fine too.

vocab-meaning: University Student, College Student, Uni Student
context-en: A male university student and a female university student are talking.
context-en2: That college girl is on a diet.
context-en3: How do university students have the energy to study all day and drink all night when all they eat is macaroni and cheese?
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means "student" and you know that ?? means university/college. Combine the two and you have a university student / college student.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What do you think is the most unpopular anime this year?
context-en2: The Koichi vs Michael sumo match is unpopular because it lacks the intensity when you watch it on YouTube.
context-en3: He was unpopular among his classmates because his favorite phrase was, "I’m gonna tell your mom."
meaning-exp: You already know ?? which means "popular." And you also know that ? means "not." So what do you get when you combine the two? Something that's not popular or unpopular.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Way Of Saying, Way Of Talking, Speaking Style
context-en: That makes sense, but you should think about the way you say things!
context-en2: Oh, sorry for changing the subject, but don't you think the way Koichi says the word cat is so cute?
context-en3: Your way of saying that is so stupid.
meaning-exp: The way of saying something is your way of saying. This could be your accent or simply the way you talk.
reading-exp: You've seen ??. Let's steal that word's reading. And, you already know ? and its reading. Combine those together and you have the reading for this word.

context-en: People have their own way of thinking.
context-en2: My mom and dad's thought processes are totally different to begin with.
context-en3: Even if you really are an awful woman, thinking badly about yourself still isn’t a healthy way to think.
meaning-exp: The think way is really the way someone thinks. That's why this word means way of thinking.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

context-en: I am not a morning person.
context-en2: Yui is physically weak, but she is a person who understands others' pain.
context-en3: Even superman gets really weak when he gets the flu.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of weak? It's also weak.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You just got beaten up because you're weak. Then the bully asks you: "Yo! Why (??) you so weak?"

context-en: I finally discovered his weak point!
context-en2: That gymnast's weakness is that her personality lacks flexibility.
context-en3: My weak point as an employee is probably that I have no weaknesses.
meaning-exp: The weak point is your weakpoint.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I was in Okinawa over the weekend.
context-en2: We got 10 centimeters of snow last weekend.
context-en3: We just won the lottery, so do you want to go to Rome this weekend for pizza?
meaning-exp: The end of the week is the weekend... that is, unless you work on the weekend, but we can't cater to everyone here.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What time will your plane leave?
context-en2: What time did you start to feel dizzy?
context-en3: What time are you going bowling tonight?
meaning-exp: This is a good word to know to ask for the time. What is the time? This is how you ask what time it is.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Cold winds were blowing outside.
context-en2: The wind is picking up, isn't it?
context-en3: When the wind blew the wig off of her head, I realized that I’m really attracted to bald women.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Do you know the word "kamikaze" from WWII history? Well, it means "divine wind." The "kaze" part is the wind part, and this word uses the same reading, making it ?? as well.

vocab-meaning: Year End, End Of The Year, End Of Year
context-en: I’m sorry, but I’ll be super busy around the end of the year and I probably can’t make time for it.
context-en2: Michael was transferred to Sales Division II of Tofugu at the end of the year.
context-en3: I hope to have gotten over my addiction to ice cubes before the end of the year.
meaning-exp: The year end is the year end aka the end of the year.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Are there yellow or green pens?
context-en2: An American crow is well known for the beauty of its yellow wings.
context-en3: If your urine changes from clear to yellow, you should drink more water.
meaning-exp: The yellow color is just the color yellow.
reading-exp: The readings are the same as the readings you learned with the kanji meaning you should be able to read this word right off the bat.

context-en: The leaves fell to the ground.
context-en2: Koichi has a Secret Base 1km above ground.
context-en3: When you look at Tokyo Tower from the ground it feels tremendously powerful.
meaning-exp: Remember ??, which is "below ground." Well, this is ground and above combined together, so I bet you can guess that this means above ground. But usually things above ground don't float (unless you're in space), so it's really on the ground.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Please write down your home address here.
context-en2: Can you please give me your address so I can send you a Christmas card?
context-en3: Does the land I purchased on the Moon have an address? I want to mail myself some oxygen tanks.
meaning-exp: Your dwelling place is the place you live. How do you identify one's dwelling place? By using the address.
reading-exp: This word is made up of the on'yomi readings that you've already learned with the kanji. Have at it!

context-en: My mother will be admitted to a nursing home next spring.
context-en2: Please write down your admission date here.
context-en3: My yakuza boss is in jail now.
meaning-exp: You enter a place. So, you have been given (or forced) admission into this place. You have been given entrance. For example, "admission" into a prison is something you could gain by not doing your WaniKani reviews in certain Crabigator ruled countries.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: But your advice wasn’t helpful at all.
context-en2: In keeping with his girlfriend's advice, Koichi finally quit smoking.
context-en3: I will give you advice, if you give me that chocolate.
meaning-exp: When you say things that help you are giving advice, though not everyone will think it's good.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is a mega-hit blockbuster that brought all of America to tears.
context-en2: Hideki Matsuyama finished second at the 2017 U.S. Open.
context-en3: What's the No. 1 song on the U.S. hit chart now?
meaning-exp: Do you remember how ?? can mean "America?" That ? means America sometimes. So, when you see all rice (I mean, America), you can think of this word as meaning All America (sort of like how ??? means "All Japan.").
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Aren’t memories things you lock safely away in your chest?
context-en2: I used to play with my friends until it got dark. It's a really great, nostalgic memory now especially because I don't have any friends anymore.
context-en3: My dad making chocolate covered bacon for us every Sunday morning is such a good memory of mine.
meaning-exp: Do you remember the word ??? It means "to think." What you are thinking is exiting—it's coming out of your head! You're recalling a memory and/or memories.
reading-exp: The readings are both kun'yomi, but based off of previous experience with the two separate words that make up this word, you should be able to read it. Just remember that it's kun'yomi. One hint is the hiragana sticking out of the ?.

vocab-meaning: Amount Of Time, Interval Of Time, Time Interval, Period Of Time
context-en: When I came to, I had been sleeping for almost five hours.
context-en2: For heaven's sake, can't you just be quiet for three minutes?
context-en3: The test involved having to hold my breath for fixed intervals of time. The most difficult one was for 3 hours, but I did it.
meaning-exp: When you stick this onto the end of another word that talks about an interval of time in some way, you're indicating the amount of time that has gone past. For example, ??? is "two years." ??? is "one hour." Any amount of time + ?? will make it an "amount of time" instead of just a specific time.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. This should save you at least ???.

vocab-meaning: Another Place, Somewhere Else, Other Place, Elsewhere
context-en: Not here, let’s go to another store somewhere else.
context-en2: Don't compare us to other families.
context-en3: I moved somewhere else to escape from my abusive husband.
meaning-exp: When you're talking about some other place you're talking about another place.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please choose the best answer among 1, 2, 3, and 4.
context-en2: Mr. Yamaguchi's response was the same as usual.
context-en3: What did you write as an answer for the first question on the test? The one that said, "Write Name Here." Did you put down your own name or did you just write "name?"
meaning-exp: You can guess this is a noun version of the kanji because the hiragana sticking out of it isn't an ?-related sound or an ?-related sound. So, what is the noun version of answer? It's also answer.
reading-exp: The reading is kun'yomi, but this is also the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this and then give your ?? correctly.

context-en: Thank you for your assistance at this time.
context-en2: Koichi made a phone call to Quentin Tarantino seeking help to increase his YouTube view counts.
context-en3: You don’t need to request Spider-Man’s assistance.
meaning-exp: When you have the power to help someone, you are giving them assistance and support.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I just can’t remember this novel’s author’s name.
context-en2: We could finally meet with the writers of TextFugu.
context-en3: My brother was an author of Greek mythology, but now he’s unemployed.
meaning-exp: Someone who makes is someone who creates things. Back in the day, a creator like this may have been known as many things, but the big one that stands out is an author.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This toy train moves with batteries.
context-en2: Mom, look! The battery came off.
context-en3: I’m heading to town to buy a battery for the robot dog I created.
meaning-exp: A pond for electricity? May seem weird at first, but if you think of something that's gathering all the electricity into one pond... that thing is like a battery (and is a battery).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My body and my mind are torn apart from getting fired and divorced.
context-en2: This fish meat tastes light and delicate, doesn't it?
context-en3: You should always carry cash on you.
meaning-exp: The kanji is somebody, but the word is body. I guess somebody is somebody's body, so they are similar at least.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Who is that somebody? Who is that body? Why, of course it is me (?).

vocab-meaning: Body And Mind, Mind And Body
context-en: I think his body and mind were both worn out.
context-en2: My only strength is being of sound mind and body.
context-en3: Yoga is excellent for the health of your body and mind.
meaning-exp: Technically this kanji is heart and somebody, but think about it this way. Where does everything come from inside somebody? The heart! It keeps things going by pumping blood, providing the foundation for both a good mind and body.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I think they’re both at fault for that.
context-en2: Player Koichi and Player Michael both seem to be pretty equally matched so far.
context-en3: Both of the people involved in the car accident were talking on their cell phones at the time of the crash.
meaning-exp: When you have both someones, you have both people. You'll notice over time that ? is often used to indicate a person or type of person, so keep that in mind for future words as well!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Boy Name Ender, Male Name Ender, Boy Name Suffix, Male Name Suffix
context-en: This summer, I stayed in a hotel in Disney Land with Yamada.
context-en2: I heard that Viet runs the laundry machine seventy-seven times a day.
context-en3: "Kun" is used as a suffix for boys’ names in Japan. It’s too bad there aren’t a lot of kids with the name "Ra."
meaning-exp: Add this to the end of someone's name, it's like saying ______buddy. It's generally used as a name ender (like ??) for boys and young men. Don't use this on people who are higher ranked than you (socially or literally). As in, you wouldn't use it on your boss. Use it on your younger male subordinates as well as boys who aren't adults yet.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (on'yomi), probably because it usually is attached to other words (aka names, like ?????) making it act more like jukugo words do.

context-en: I was transferred to the Chiba branch office.
context-en2: I got invited to the takoyaki party for the agents of FBI field office in Tokyo.
context-en3: I sneezed in front of the Kyoto branch of Television Osaka, Inc.
meaning-exp: The support bureau is the group that supports a business. It is the branch office. If it helps, this word has the same meaning as ?? which you will also be learning in this level.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My husband is the branch manager of the Osaka branch.
context-en2: In this branch shop, there are workers who like to do things alone as well.
context-en3: Our branch manager’s mustache is a bit too long.
meaning-exp: The support shop is the branch office. Presumably this is because the regular "shop" is the "shop" and anything that supports it is the local (branch) office. If it helps, this word has the same meaning as ?? which you will also be learning in this level.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I ate bread and eggs for breakfast.
context-en2: Of course breakfast has to have bacon! Why can’t you understand something so obvious?
context-en3: Have you ever been so hungry that you ate six rotten eggs for breakfast?
meaning-exp: ??? is a food or meal (maybe you'll learn the kanji for it later, but it's not usually used, so you're learning it this way now). What is your morning meal? That is breakfast (not to be confused with second breakfast, you hobbit).
reading-exp: The reading for ?? is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read everything here.

context-en: There is a post office and a hospital, too.
context-en2: Let's take over that TV station!
context-en3: He tried calling the Federal Bureau of Investigation because he had to wait too long in the drive-thru at McDonald's.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The kanji and the vocab are exactly the same, even the reading. This one uses the on'yomi probably because it's often attached to other words (specifying a bureau, for example), so that's why it follows jukugo conventions despite being all alone.

context-en: It was a blue sky without even a single cloud.
context-en2: I'll give you that cloud over there as thanks for when you treated me to a meal.
context-en3: The plane disappeared behind a cloud and was never seen again.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading because it's a single kanji on its own. Luckily, that's the reading you learned with the kanji already, so you should be able to read this.

context-en: You only think about taking the easy way out!
context-en2: This chair is very comfortable!
context-en3: I am most at ease when I am with my dog, Toto.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, too, making this one an ease to learn!

context-en: If you're going to be like this, then I can't take it seriously.
context-en2: Koichi never asks for anything in return when he helps people.
context-en3: Condoms aren’t completely safe. My friend was wearing one and got hit by a pickup truck.
meaning-exp: This is the adverb version of the kanji all. So, it's like you add an 'ly' to it. But, that doesn't work too well (allly? c'mon). So, instead think of this word as completely, entirely or one of the other definitions listed above.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The person who completely doesn't understand this vocab word is matt (???). Be sure to take note of the small ?, too.

context-en: The older and younger brothers are in opposition over the succession dispute.
context-en2: Why don't we cooperate and work hard together instead of competing?
context-en3: I’ll punch you in the face if you say I’m a non-confrontational person one more time.
meaning-exp: When you stand up versus someone, you're looking to get into a confrontation. Just imagine yourself doing this to someone bigger than you. You stand up to versus them and then realize this confrontation is a bad idea.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: A man and a woman are having a conversation in the hallway of the university.
context-en2: I can't understand fast-paced Japanese dialogue yet.
context-en3: Why are our conversations always about baseball?
meaning-exp: When you meet your talk with someone else, you're having a conversation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Well then I think that’s the decision I want to make.
context-en2: It seems that it's taking a while to make a decision, right?
context-en3: John, you made the decision to start making hotdog ice cream and that’s why you got fired.
meaning-exp: Noun version of decide? It's a decision.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji!

context-en: Thanks to you, I’ve decided to get plastic surgery.
context-en2: Tofugu's resolution to being an Instagram celebrity is as firm as Tofu.
context-en3: I’ve finally made up my mind about where you’ll be buying me drinks for my birthday... In Japan. Enjoy!
meaning-exp: When you decide with your heart you have true determination, unlike when you decide with your mind.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you take note of the shortened ?. So, ?? goes to ??.

context-en: I have to go see a doctor today.
context-en2: One night, in a shady restaurant, there were three doctors stuffing themselves with shark.
context-en3: I want to be a doctor, but I hate touching people. Do you think that will be a problem?
meaning-exp: Someone who works in medicine is a doctor.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My duty as a hero is already over.
context-en2: Sarah, it is your business to take care of visitors, right?
context-en3: Unfortunately, I wasn't able to fulfill my duty.
meaning-exp: If you have an eye for service, then you always think helping people is your duty! If you see it, then you offer your service. It's the right thing to do!
reading-exp: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ?. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!

vocab-meaning: East Exit, East Entrance, Eastern Exit, Eastern Entrance, East Gate
context-en: There’s someone doing a street performance at the station’s east exit.
context-en2: The photo taken at the east gate is a bit blurry, probably from the camera shaking.
context-en3: In the case of an emergency, please evacuate the building through the east exit. There will be coffee and donuts waiting for you there.
meaning-exp: Remember how ??? means entrance and ?? means exit? This is just the ? part with a direction on it. That means it can be both entrance or exit. So when you have East up there this word can mean both East exit and East entrance. This is a great word to know if you need to know which side of a train station you need to leave on to go somewhere or meet someone!
reading-exp: This word uses kun'yomi readings, possibly because of ?, which is a body part (body parts do that quite a bit in words and kanji). You should hopefully have seen both the kun'yomi readings from previous levels meaning you can read this word as well. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes ?? to ??.

context-en: Please turn on the light.
context-en2: I told you not to leave lights on. You don't earn very much, so you'd better cooperate to save on the electricity bill!
context-en3: When I was little I was afraid of the dark. Now, when I get my electric bill I’m afraid of the light.
meaning-exp: Electricity energy is just a fancy way to say electricity.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Can you tell me everything you know about the Electricity Liberalization that started in Japan in April of 2016.
context-en2: I don't want to pay the bill to that electric company.
context-en3: Power was restored in roughly three hours and I was able to fix my hair with my electric hair clippers before the interview.
meaning-exp: The electricity power of something is its electric power.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How much does an electron weigh?
context-en2: How long do you think it will take to fix the electric piano?
context-en3: The Tyrannosaurus Rex was shocked with 10,000 electron volts.
meaning-exp: An electricity child. What is a really small part of electricity? What makes up electricity? That would be the electron. This word can also refer to things that are electronic as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Do you all use emoji?
context-en2: If I had to choose, I like this emoji.
context-en3: Can you tell me which emoji you use the most?
meaning-exp: When you use a drawing to replace your letters to type, you're using emoji! Those are the faces you send when you text or email.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Who’s the robotics engineer that invented the Roomba?
context-en2: I helped that engineer, even though I don't like him, because I thought it was the right thing to do.
context-en3: To become an engineer, you have to put in long hours of studying.
meaning-exp: Do you remember ?? from a couple levels ago? This is someone who is in ??. If ?? is "engineering" then ??? is an engineer.
reading-exp: The readings are just the on'yomi readings of the kanji. All things you should know now.

context-en: You need a ticket to enter the venue.
context-en2: Last admission is at 5 pm.
context-en3: Damn it! The entrance to the "Room of Certain Death" is blocked.
meaning-exp: The location from which you enter is where you make your entrance. It has to do with things like "entrance fees" and "entrance was not permitted," etc.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I take a shower every morning
context-en2: I had a really great time with you every morning. Thank you so much.
context-en3: I do radio exercises every morning.
meaning-exp: Every morning is every morning!
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

context-en: I’d like to go to the Toyota factory - which way would be the most convenient?
context-en2: It's my husband's job to lock up the bacon factory every night.
context-en3: The only factory I would want to work in is a factory that makes cookies.
meaning-exp: A construction location is a factory. A factory is a place where you or machines do a bunch of construction!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Can you tell me about some Portland tourist spots?
context-en2: I'll get in touch with you when we get closer to the day we're visiting famous places.
context-en3: I’m going to New York to see all the famous places like Starbucks, Denny’s, and the New York City post office.
meaning-exp: A famous place is a famous place. When traveling around Japan, you should ask about the ?? if you can.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How did Japan’s foreign policy change postwar?
context-en2: We are recording a podcast about Japan's foreign policy.
context-en3: Is it just a coincidence that my personal debt shot past $5 million when America’s foreign debt shot past $500 billion?
meaning-exp: Something is versus the outside. Back in the day, everything was a battle with the outside. You had the Mongols... the rebels... and the foreigners. So, when you say something is "versus the outside" you're just saying it's something compared to where you are right now. It's something that's foreign or from overseas.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This game is really fun and interesting.
context-en2: It's more fun to watch TV than chatting while eating.
context-en3: Jumping out of an airplane is so much fun!
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pleasure? Well, you could say it's "pleasurable," but I'm afraid that's not what we're going for here. In this case, this word is a little more innocent. It just means fun.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How much fun did you have? You just had a ton o' (??) fun!

context-en: I’ve gone yukigassen snowball fighting in Hokkaido.
context-en2: I've arrived in Hokkaido! Time to eat some real sushi!
context-en3: Speaking of Hokkaido souvenirs, what’s famous?
meaning-exp: The north sea road is the road you take to get to the northern sea. That is an area of Japan, actually. That area is known as Hokkaido. It's a very nice place, be sure to visit it if you can for some of the freshest seafood around.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ?? does get shortened though, so be careful!

context-en: Is it okay to give that horse carrots and apples?
context-en2: My horse has overcome yet another difficulty.
context-en3: I find it unreasonably funny when old people fall off of horses one after another.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine someone riding a horse. Who is that person? It's Uma (??) Thurman, the famous actress.

context-en: What’s the best way to increase a car’s horsepower?
context-en2: Asahi, your grandpa is such an energetic person, isn't he?
context-en3: I tinkered with my lawnmower for about four years and now it has 450 horsepower.
meaning-exp: This word was probably made pretty recently. A horse's power? That is horsepower.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the reading for ? is the ?? version of the reading. You can remember this by thinking about how it's Ricky who drives the high horsepower cars. Vroom vroom Ricky!

context-en: A while ago I saw a shiba inu drinking coffee like a human at a cafe.
context-en2: My favorite poem is Mitsuo Aida's, "It’s ok to stumble, isn’t it, we are humans after all." I like this because the kanji for humans is written in hiragana.
context-en3: Humans have always wondered about the purpose of life. I believe I have found the answer: studying on Tofugu.
meaning-exp: The person interval. Just think of different intervals each with a different type of species. The raccoon interval... the dog interval... the person interval... they are the humans.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. For ? that's okay. For ? it's something weird, something you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this, think of the humans, living on this earth. They are only a small part of this earth's existence, though. This human generation (??) is hopefully going to be a long one, but we'll see how that goes.

vocab-meaning: Important Task, Great Duty, Important Role
context-en: I will try with all my might to successfully accomplish this important task.
context-en2: You volunteered for such a great duty, eh?
context-en3: Frodo, of the Lord of the Rings, was given the most important task and he did it all without putting on shoes.
meaning-exp: A big duty is a great duty. It can also be an important task. Think about some kind of big duty you have. Then, think about what an important task it is too. Feel proud of your important task.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Interval, Interval Of Time, Time Interval, Between, Room
context-en: Usually, I turn off the heater while I’m sleeping.
context-en2: Meanwhile, I shoved my lunch in my mouth.
context-en3: In the time it takes to build a raft we’ll die of starvation! Wouldn’t it be safer to just swim across the river?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Don't confuse this with ?? which is similar in meaning but different in reading. The ?? means it's attached to something. This is a standalone word.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: In terms of intervals of time, time goes stagnant when you arrive in Idaho (???). No time intervals move when you're there. Imagine this actually happening. You're looking into the state of Idaho and seeing everyone move at a snail's pace because time moves differently there. If you don't know where Idaho is, you can alternatively think about a mnemonic you'd make. You say: "In terms of a new mnemonic, I'd uhh... (???) uh... I can't think of anything better, that's a hard one!"

context-en: Are you really going to investigate the truth?
context-en2: The true motive behind Koichi's strange words and deeds have not yet been brought to light.
context-en3: One of the classes I’m taking in college is currently investigating whether the chicken or the egg came first.
meaning-exp: When you brighten your research it's like you're shedding light on it. To do that, you have to perform an investigation. This word is particularly used in academic and scientific situations.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I was so absorbed in my research that when I noticed it was already past 12 o'clock.
context-en2: I'm a Tofugu researcher taking part in the study of biopharmaceutical production.
context-en3: We are currently accepting applicants to participate in our research study of Titans.
meaning-exp: When you sharpen research you're just doing a study or investigation. Oh, and to make things simple, you're also doing research as well!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Last Time, Recently, Lately, Previous, Previously
context-en: That reminds me, last time I was at the shopping district I ran into Sakurako.
context-en2: I recently bought a Japanese music CD.
context-en3: When was the last time I saw a sunset so perfect that I had to take note of it?
meaning-exp: ?? means "this." And, you know what the word ? means (front/before). So "this before" has to do with something that happened previously. That's why this word means last time, recently, and lately.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the kun'yomi, like the reading for the vocabulary word ?. So long as you know that word, you'll be able to read this one too. The reason it's not on'yomi is because it's like two words put together. The word ?? and the word ?.

context-en: Last class we dissected a frog.
context-en2: Okay so... we will continue from where we ended last time.
context-en3: Did you guys review the last lesson at home properly?
meaning-exp: The before time was last time.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Weird, I was sure I measured the length properly.
context-en2: This snake is sold in three centimeter long pieces.
context-en3: The length of the bridge was one of the main reasons why I faltered. It was just too long for me.
meaning-exp: You know the word ?? from a couple levels ago. This is like the word ??? versus ???, where ??? is "size" and ??? is "big." So, ?? is "long" and ?? is length.
reading-exp: If you know the reading of the word ?? from level 6 you'll know the reading for this word too. Only difference is the ? at the end, which is hiragana so it should be easy to read.

context-en: I made a cushion out of Marimekko fabric.
context-en2: This curtain is made of parachute material.
context-en3: Please go buy a frozen piecrust.
meaning-exp: Life that comes out of the earth is made up of different kinds of materials. Sometimes it's cloth, sometimes it's dough, but everything has to be made out of something.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for ? and the on'yomi reading for ?. You haven't learned either of these readings yet, sorry! Here's some mnemonics to help you: If you want the best material to make clothes or pies out of, the key (?)is asking Jesus (?)! He knows everything, including where to find the materials for whatever weird thing you're making. Just remember: Who's the key? Jesus!

context-en: Ms. Kawashita is a mathematics teacher at Ishida junior high school.
context-en2: The math exam is tomorrow, but Kaito doesn't seem to have any sense of urgency.
context-en3: Dear Math, please grow up and solve your own problems by yourself.
meaning-exp: The study of numbers is mathematics (or math).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Lately, I’ve been reading about three medical science books a month.
context-en2: My older brother is trying to get into a medical school.
context-en3: Medical science is always discovering new medications. Just yesterday, my doctor gave me a pill that makes it so I can wash dishes.
meaning-exp: The study of medicine is medical science. It can also be called medicine, but make sure to think of it as the "medicine" where it has to do with "medical science."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Medical University, Medical School, Med School
context-en: I’m studying to get into medical school.
context-en2: I pretended to be a med student and snuck into med school to find a future doctor boyfriend.
context-en3: I paid my tuition for med school by selling my Pokémon collection.
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? to mean "college." So take the ? and put it with medicine to create "medicine college," or medical university.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Lately, I’ve been obsessed with Mediterranean cooking.
context-en2: I'm on my way home from the Mediterranean Sea.
context-en3: I went on a cruise with my family on the Mediterranean Sea over summer vacation.
meaning-exp: Earth's middle sea is the Mediterranean Sea. It may not look like it's in the middle of the earth, but a long time ago that's what people thought. It's the sea between Southern Europe and Northern Africa.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Method Of, Way, Style, Way Of
context-en: The teacher is going to teach the rules and the methods of Judo.
context-en2: I'm gonna master the way of sword in Hokkaido.
context-en3: Could you please explain the difference between bushido and chivalry?
meaning-exp: This is a word that's attached to the end of various other words. Think of a "road" as a way or method of something. For example, the ?? in Judo is the soft "way." There are many words that end with ?, and you'll see them later on. For now, know that this means method of or way.
reading-exp: This word is added to the end of many different words, meaning it's treated like most jukugo (and uses an on'yomi reading). You know the on'yomi reading, so you should be able to read this word. Be sure to drop the ? when writing in the reading in the test, though. It's only there to show that it's added onto things and not part of the correct answer.

context-en: Japan has an emperor, so is it a monarchy or a democracy?
context-en2: Ah, I'm finally back in this monarchy!
context-en3: The British Monarchy is long overdue for making another rap music video.
meaning-exp: When you're buddy-buddy with the master of a country, you are rewarded splendidly. Why? Because this is a monarchy where being buddies with the master is a very advantageous thing!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please say the morning greeting.
context-en2: Every morning I eat over easy and sunny-side-up eggs.
context-en3: I have to wake up early tomorrow morning because I have a long day of Xbox playing to do.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Hopefully this means you won't have to wake up too early in the morning to study kanji, now.

context-en: Would you like to climb a mountain with me tomorrow morning to see the morning sun?
context-en2: Why did you take the picture of the rising sun off of the wall?
context-en3: Japan is known as "the Land of the Rising Sun," which is excellently depicted on its "Rising Sun" flag.
meaning-exp: The morning sun is not only the morning sun, but it's the rising sun as well (because that's when the sun rises, right?).
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which is convenient since you've learned both of them by now with the words ? (??) and ? (?). Put them together and what do you get? ???!

context-en: I’ll listen to music after I study.
context-en2: Do you think it isn't good to work while listening to music?
context-en3: I wonder if another type of music will be created. Do you think mankind already made every possible genre?
meaning-exp: What is the sound of pleasure? What sound puts you at ease? For most people that is some nice music. Just be sure you don't put on any Bieber... that would be like ??? or something... I kid, I kid.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you play your music too loud, people will come and gawk (??) at you. But if you try to turn it off and say, "OH WHAT I DON'T LIKE MUSIC ANYWAY!" they'll gawk at you even more. Learn proper music etiquette and people won't gawk at you so much, okay?

vocab-meaning: Name, First Name, Full Name, Given Name
context-en: What is that person’s name?
context-en2: I've heard the name, but I don't know much about it.
context-en3: I want to change my first name to "Ah" and my last name to "Soso."
meaning-exp: Your name that's in the front. That is not your last name, that is your regular name or your first name.
reading-exp: This word uses both kun'yomi readings (oh darn!). That being said, you've seen the kun'yomi readings for both the kanji that make up this word. The word ? (?) and the word ? (??) both are kun'yomi, so use those words and Voltron them into a single word, ???.

vocab-meaning: Natural, Reasonable, Obvious, Usual, Common, Ordinary
context-en: This is normal stuff, why can’t you get that?
context-en2: Don't take it for granted though.
context-en3: Shouldn't we be thankful we're able to have an ordinary day like today.
meaning-exp: You've seen how ??? means success. If you've experienced success before, everything after that seems to be pretty obvious.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Notice, Notification, Flier, Pamphlet, Handbill, Flyer, Leaflet
context-en: Excuse me, I have something that I’d like to tell you - do you have some time now?
context-en2: Did you read the notice from the school already?
context-en3: I have some bad news. Someone broke into our home last night and stole all the ice cream we had stored in our freezer.
meaning-exp: This is a strange word, so you'll have to bear with me. You know that ? means know. But in the case of this word, what do you know? Look at the second half. ?? sounds a bit like "race." So, you know about a "race." How do you know about this race? You got a notice or notification about it.
reading-exp: Remember ??? This is the same reading (?). So, if you know that, you'll be able to read this one as well.

context-en: Oh weird, the numbers don't match for some reason.
context-en2: What was the death toll of the 1985 New York earthquake?
context-en3: In this movie, the role of the math teacher who is good at counting is played by Koichi, who is known for playing the role of numerous older brother figures in countless Japanese films.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine yourself counting by playing a kazoo (??). Each number you count, you toot your kazoo. How fun!

context-en: What is your exam number?
context-en2: You have 30 minutes to memorize a series of numbers.
context-en3: I’m really disappointed right now because she gave me a fake phone number.
meaning-exp: A number in a series plus a number. You know what happens when two kanji with basically the same meaning get combined into one by now, right? It just turns out to be the same meaning, basically. This word means number.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Number One, The First, First, The Best, Best, The Most, Most
context-en: I like the strawberry flavored candy best out of all of these.
context-en2: The first textbook I read in my life was TextFugu.
context-en3: Sydney Crosby is the number one hockey player in the world.
meaning-exp: When you're the number one in a number in a series, you're number one ba-bay!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I got second place in final exams for my year.
context-en2: This is the second oldest Godzilla movie.
context-en3: Carlos Slim fell to the number two spot on the list of the world’s richest people.
meaning-exp: When you're number two in a number in a series you're number two. Not quite as good as being ??, but take what you can get, you know?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Regardless of the increase in numbers, you shouldn’t publish vulgar news stories.
context-en2: This child is a genius who memorized a 15,672-digit number.
context-en3: Eleven is the number I always wear when I play volleyball.
meaning-exp: A number letter isn't a letter like the ones you're reading now, it's more like a numeral, like 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, etc.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: One By One, In Succession, One After The Other
context-en: Seemingly unbelievable events were occurring one after the other.
context-en2: Last night, Director Koichi had a dream that he made one Youtube hit after another.
context-en3: One by one, the cities of Europe fell to the plague.
meaning-exp: When something is happening next, next (next next next), it's happening in succession, or one by one. Just imagine a line of people going through to get stamps on their heads. The person at the stamp counter is saying "Next! Next!" and then shouting "C'mon people, one by one, alright?"
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the word ? (so it's ??), but this time you do it twice. No strange rendaku or anything like that either, which makes everyone happier.

context-en: I’m opposed to the idea.
context-en2: The Statue of Restriction is standing on the opposite side of the Statue of Liberty in middle of the Upper Bay.
context-en3: He’s the complete opposite of what he used to be like ever since he moved to Changeville.
meaning-exp: The anti versus... You'd think this would be a double negative, but it's like a lot of other words where you have two similar words combined... it just means the same thing as those two words. In this case, the anti-versus of something would be the opposite. Alternatively, it can be the opposition. You choose.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Over There, Opposite Side, Other Side, Far Away
context-en: Let’s buy bread at the bakery over there.
context-en2: Ichika might have come from the other side of the world.
context-en3: I’ll tell you my secret if you go stand on the opposite side of the road.
meaning-exp: You know that ? means yonder. So, think of a "yonder ????." All you know is that he's over there on the other side / opposite side of where you are. Basically, he's just pretty far away, wherever he is.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Standing with ???? is a cow. It is saying moo (?). Weird, now ???? is saying it too. Also, if you know the reading of ?? you should be able to read this one as well.

context-en: The picture gets bigger when you click it.
context-en2: Could you put this picture back on the wall?
context-en3: Five Picasso paintings were stolen out of the museum last night, but nobody seems to care.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Pending, Unsettled, Undecided, Not Yet Decided
context-en: The details are undecided.
context-en2: Please put the pending documents in the red tray on Koichi's desk.
context-en3: Her court case has been pending for nearly 13 years. It’s so unfair to have to wait that long.
meaning-exp: Something that is not yet decided... it is pending... it is unsettled.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Personally, I'm indifferent to the zoo's issues.
context-en2: As for me, as long as it isn't too extreme, I think any kind of diet is okay.
context-en3: You’re way off base if you think you know me better than I know myself.
meaning-exp: "When it comes to somebody like myself... aka I..." When you say this you're really saying "personally" or "as for me."
reading-exp: The readings are a bit weird here. The ? is ??? and the rest is on'yomi kanji readings. So, it's a mix of both, I'm afraid. "When it comes to me, I like mixing up on'yomi and kun'yomi because I hate myself."

context-en: How much is the doll of the pitcher, Darvish?
context-en2: The pitcher, Tanaka, lives in 2-Chome.
context-en3: Who do you think today's starting pitcher will be?
meaning-exp: The person who throws with their hand is the pitcher in a baseball game. Other games don't involve throwing with your hand, they've got kicking with feet. So when you picture a hand throwing, picture your favorite pitcher!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To be a good pitcher, all you have to do is put the ball into the chute (??). Pitchers don't actually throw the ball. There is an invisible pitching chute right on the mound. You slide the ball into the chute and off it goes!

context-en: If there’s a spot you don’t understand, please raise your hand.
context-en2: We are still searching for common ground.
context-en3: I think we’re lost because we’ve walked by the same place 72 times now.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Here's the place! Either you have to talk or row (???). If you talk, maybe you can talk your way out of this problem you're in. If you row, you may be able to escape. Either way, this is the place for it.

context-en: Usually we gather in the classroom, but the location is different tomorrow, so make sure you don’t go to the wrong place.
context-en2: You should know your own battlefield.
context-en3: This is the place where I first met Rose. But, I forget why I took my shoes off that day.
meaning-exp: A location place is either a place or a location, just like the kanji it's made from.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi reading for the second. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is this place you're in? You look around and listen. You hear, "Baa (?) baa baa!" You must be in a baa place! (It's a place full of sheep.)

context-en: If you were to give WaniKani a score out of 100, how many points would you give it?
context-en2: These points are in return for the present you gave me.
context-en3: "Why did you get such a low grade on that test?" "Because of absences. I mean, the kid who sits next to me was absent."
meaning-exp: The number of points is how many points there are (aka the score).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I asked for directions to the embassy at the police box.
context-en2: Himari, the new girl in this police box, is Miss Popular.
context-en3: Excuse me, officer. Where is the nearest police box? I need to call the police because some man just called me fat.
meaning-exp: I have no idea how this one works, admittedly. You mix a number in a series and you get a police box. A police box? Who would want to work in one of those? Think of it this way: all the police have to draw numbers from a hat (they're all mixed up in there). Those who pull out the wrong numbers are on police box duty. That's why mixed numbers in a series = police box. Do you see it?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This pond is too big.
context-en2: When I dropped a bamboo arrow in the pond, God came out of it and asked me, "Did you drop this bamboo arrow or this gold arrow?" So I answered honestly, "I dropped the bamboo arrow, but I want the gold arrow, too."
context-en3: My neighbor keeps tossing the dead birds that he shoots into my pond.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: If you fall into a pond, what sound do you make? EEEEK (??)! Or maybe you're just afraid of ponds (I don't blame you, there are probably snakes or leeches or alligators in there) and you EEEEK when someone mentions them.

context-en: Tuition for private universities is more expensive than that of public universities.
context-en2: Waseda University is a famous, private university in Japan.
context-en3: The private college that’s on fire is the college I’m currently attending.
