meaning-exp: You've seen ??, which is "private," and you've seen ??, which is "college" or "university." So, combine them together and you have a private college / private university.
reading-exp: If you know the readings of the words ?? and ?? you'll be able to read this. It's also all jukugo on'yomi readings too, so you can read it that way.

context-en: This TV program wasn’t interesting, but my favorite actor was in it.
context-en2: In yesterday's program, those two finally managed to work out a compromise.
context-en3: I haven’t watched anything but variety programs lately.
meaning-exp: Use a number in a series to group the things you watch and listen to. That makes them your programs. Your TV and radio programs, specifically. If you watch TV you'll hear it a lot!
reading-exp: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ?. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

vocab-meaning: Public Official, Government Official, Public Servant
context-en: You shouldn’t carelessly disobey politicians or public officials.
context-en2: Koichi is not only the president of Tofugu but also an official in the Ministry of Education.
context-en3: One of my city’s public officials is under investigation for lying on camera.
meaning-exp: A person with duty is someone who works for the government... a government official or public official.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you argue loudly so late at night, you’ll bother your neighbors.
context-en2: After talking it over, forest-dwellers and lake-dwellers agreed to buy 100 swords together.
context-en3: I am a resident of planet Earth. Welcome to the party.
meaning-exp: A person of a dwelling is someone who lives at that dwelling. They are a resident.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: A man is stopping by a police box for directions.
context-en2: They say a journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, right?
context-en3: Drive down this road for about twenty minutes and you’ll come to the place where an unidentified creature was spotted.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Don't confuse this with the word ??, though. This one doesn't have a ? at the beginning, meaning it's not attached to other words. This word is just plain old road. It has its own meaning!
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're walking down the road. On the road, you bump into your friend, Mitch (??). Imagine saying hello, then continuing down the road. What's weird is you're both walking down a paved road with cars on it. Seems dangerous, but you and Mitch, you know what you're doing. If you don't know anyone named Mitch, think of a famous Mitch or a Mitch you've made up.

context-en: Koichi played the role of Kumaman in the drama.
context-en2: In order to prepare for the part, Koichi became a homeless for a year.
context-en3: Michael is throwing himself into the role very well, eh?
meaning-exp: If you have a certain duty then it's your job to play that role. You have to play the part. Like in a play!
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, meaning you should be able to read this one as well.

context-en: His father is a splendid scholar.
context-en2: That scholar is a resume faker.
context-en3: I am a world renowned scholar of Hello Kitty.
meaning-exp: Someone who does study for a living. That is a scholar.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Several years passed.
context-en2: I lived in Japan until a few years ago.
context-en3: It will take several years for that painting to be complete.
meaning-exp: When a number of years have passed you say that several years have passed! You don't want to say how many years, so just say several years.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Why can’t bicycles travel on sidewalks?
context-en2: You are approaching the end of the moving walkway. Please watch your step.
context-en3: Bicycles should be ridden on sidewalks, not on busy city streets.
meaning-exp: The road you walk on is the sidewalk... at least I hope that's where you walk.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Soon, Before Long, In A Short Time, Shortly, Momentarily
context-en: The curtain rises soon.
context-en2: I'll probably get a reply regarding the postgraduate research scholarship before long.
context-en3: Supper will be ready really soon but I still can’t stop eating these cookies.
meaning-exp: The ??? part is like saying "also don't have." So, when you "also don't have an interval of time," things will happen soon or before long.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is weird, though. It's a second kun'yomi reading (there is also ???), read as ?. So what is happening soon? Your Ma is going to be here before long. You better hurry and prepare, because your room looks terrible... "????, your mom is about to show up!"

context-en: When will Jenny be released from prison?
context-en2: When you get out of the prison, please return the favor, okay?
context-en3: Please present the source of the quoted section.
meaning-exp: You exit a place. It's a release from prison for you! Note: this word can also mean source or origin, often found in copyright law documents (for all you lawyers out there).
reading-exp: The reading follows on'yomi protocols, but you just have to be careful of the shortened ??? which becomes ???. Note: There is also the reading ???? which is used with the meanings origin and source. It's usually written as ???? when used in this way.

context-en: In my school days, I took a backpacking trip through South America.
context-en2: This hotel's tap water is the best water I’ve ever had in South America.
context-en3: I’m sorry. I thought South America was a part of the United States of America.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? can also mean America? That goes for North and South America, actually, not just the United States. So, south America is South America.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: South Exit, South Entrance, Southern Exit, Southern Entrance, South Gate
context-en: If you’re going there, leaving from the south exit is the fastest.
context-en2: You can see a UFO at the southern entrance of this mall right now!
context-en3: I was hit on at the south exit of Shinjuku station.
meaning-exp: The South mouth isn't actually a mouth you find in the south pole or anything, it's an entrance or exit. This is kind of like how ??? means entrance (the ? represents a doorway). You'll see this word a lot in places like train stations or airports. It means both South exit and South entrance.
reading-exp: The reading for these kanji are both kun'yomi. Probably because it's two words put together (South + Exit) rather than a single word. Also, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings as well. So, you've seen vocab words that give you the kun'yomi reading of both ? and ?, right? Now you just need to combine the two vocab readings into one to be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes ?? to ??.

context-en: Just being in the same space as that person can heal your heart.
context-en2: Some Japanese people think that strollers should be banned in crowded trains because they take up a lot of space.
context-en3: Even though there is no air in space, I still want to live on the moon.
meaning-exp: The sky interval is an area of the sky. In places that are just empty sky, there is only space. Of course, not technically... there's something there, but back in the day when kanji was being made, nobody knew that. This word can mean both space in regards to outer space as well as the space around you in your room.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Tell me about your strong subjects and weak subjects.
context-en2: I probably have to retake that course.
context-en3: What subjects do you like?
meaning-exp: If you've got an eye on a certain course, it's a subject you really want to take. Maybe you're in school and that means you'll be taking a lot of courses. Maybe you're a teacher and you're planning out your curriculum. Either way, you have your eye on the course-prize.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: That samurai committed suicide.
context-en2: President Koichi reiterated Tofugu's strong and wholehearted support for our right to self-determination.
context-en3: He was depressed during his imprisonment and committed suicide.
meaning-exp: When you decide with your self, that is your own decision. That comes from you. That comes from your self determination. But the word is mainly used in Japan as a euphemism for suicide. It's kind of important that you know that.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m talking on the phone with my family.
context-en2: Sorry to call you so late at night.
context-en3: I wonder what ringtone Alexander Graham Bell had on his telephone.
meaning-exp: An electricity talk. What is this witchcraft? The only way to talk via electricity is with a telephone.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There will be body measurements tomorrow at school.
context-en2: Is there a handicap accessible restroom in this library?
context-en3: At the airport, they searched me for hidden drugs.
meaning-exp: Somebody's body. This refers to the very general word the body. As in, "the human body" or something like that. This can also refer to health as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: The Number Of People, Number Of People, The Amount Of People, Amount Of People
context-en: What’s the total number of people going to karaoke?
context-en2: What are the recruitment numbers for the new Tofugu writers?
context-en3: There are a great number of people who disagree with my proposal that everyone in this country must wear the same pants.
meaning-exp: The person count is the number of people. Don't confuse this with the "population" or something like that, though. This is more like "how many people are at this event?" What's the ??, you know?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to take note of the rendaku for the second half, where ?? goes to ??.

context-en: When do you have time, professor?
context-en2: Are there any available spots for a checkup this afternoon?
context-en3: Superman then asked Aquaman the most serious question, "Do we have enough time to go on the waterslides again?"
meaning-exp: The time interval of time is just the time. As is often the case, if two similar meaning kanji are combined into one word, they tend to produce a word with a similar meaning. Excuse me, friend, what's the ???
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Answer, To Reply, To Respond
context-en: Please answer this question using a dictionary.
context-en2: Why can't you respond to my questions?
context-en3: I didn’t know how to answer when the interviewer asked me if I have ever lied before.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means answer so the verb version means to answer.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi reading as you'd expect with all the hiragana, but luckily that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

vocab-meaning: To Be Bent, To Bend, To Curve, To Turn
context-en: Please turn right at the third light.
context-en2: Your curry colored necktie is a bit crooked.
context-en3: Since getting hit with a baseball my pinky finger bends slightly to the left.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means both music and bend. In the case of this word, we're looking at "bend." So, the verb form of bend is to be bent. This is when something bends on its own, not when you're doing the bending. It's just bending.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something, let's say a road, starts out straight. But, with some magic, a witch causes it to curve.

vocab-meaning: To Be Finished, To Be Completed
context-en: The delicious curry was finished.
context-en2: Our Japan travel plans were finished at the last minute.
context-en3: The tofu and fugu hamburgers are done!
meaning-exp: You've seen the word ??? (to be able to do), which is the first part. Then the second part, ??? means "to rise." So, think about it this way: once you're able to do something, you rise because you're finished. That's why this verb means to be finished.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of the readings from ??? and ???. So long as you were paying attention in lessons past, you should be able to read this word as well just by combining those other words.

vocab-meaning: To Be Mixed, To Be Blended With, To Join
context-en: The place where the sky and the sea meet is the edge of the world.
context-en2: My anxiety is mixed with excitement.
context-en3: After snatching my wallet, the pickpocket quickly blended in with the crowd and disappeared.
meaning-exp: You know that ??? means to mix and that the kanji means mix as well. So, this probably has something to do with mixing things. This word means to be mixed. This is when something is mixed but it's not mixed by you. It's just being mixed. Think of it this way - the ? in ??? is Jesus, who just uses Jesus magic to mix something. So, you're not mixing it. It's just when something is to be mixed.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as with ???. So long as you know the ? portion of that word's reading, you'll be able to read this word as well.

context-en: Next, please bend your right knee at a 90 degree angle.
context-en2: In this Youtube video, Koichi just keeps bending 100 spoons.
context-en3: Superman can bend anything, even something that is already bent.
meaning-exp: This is a verb because it ends with an ? sound. What does the kanji mean? It's music and bend. In the case of this word, we're going with the "bend" version. The verb of that is to bend. This is when you're doing the bending. You can remember this because ? is the gentleman you're bending. He looked good before you bent him in half.
reading-exp: How did you bend this gentleman? You bent him using magic (?). Just imagine yourself bending a gentleman with magic. Go ahead, do it in your mind.

vocab-meaning: To Be Useful, To Be Of Use, To Be Helpful, To Be Of Service
context-en: I found a website that is helpful for studying Japanese.
context-en2: In Hungary there is a proverb meaning, "Running away is a shame, but it's useful."
context-en3: Would a sword be more useful than a gun for walking through a city full of zombies?
meaning-exp: When you stand up to do your duty you're standing up and finally being useful. That's why this verb means to be useful.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the one you learned with the kanji. The ?? reading is that of the ?? vocabulary, which you should be familiar with by now.

context-en: I want to buy toilet paper, meat, vegetables, and soy sauce on the same day.
context-en2: Why did you end up buying the smartphone?
context-en3: There was a long line of people waiting to buy the Koichi bobblehead.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means buy so the verb form is to buy.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be just fine.

vocab-meaning: To Compare With, To Face Each Other, To Oppose, To Compare, To Contrast, To Contrast With
context-en: The egg ratio of white and yolk is 2:1.
context-en2: You're lacking in consideration for your parents, don't you think?
context-en3: It’s clear now that their relationship will never work because their opinions on Star Trek are the complete opposite.
meaning-exp: When you do (??) versus you're putting two things together to compare with each other. Imagine putting two dogs in a ring (show dogs, not fighting dogs, c'mon). Then someone announces the start, and the judges look at them, trying to compare one to the other to decide which is better. Alternatively, you can use this to say to face each other as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this word no problem.

context-en: When you can’t sleep, why do you count sheep?
context-en2: If you value your own life, get lost in ten seconds.
context-en3: There are two students missing, Mr. Smith. I only counted thirty-eight children.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means count, so obviously the verb version is to count.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You begin to count vocabulary words. You're out of control and you can't stop. One after another. Scientists have to come in, but they can't figure out the cause (??) of your counting. They drag you away to a padded cell where they keep testing you trying to figure out the cause of your craziness.

context-en: Have you decided what you’ll do after graduating from university?
context-en2: I'm too hungry to decide what we eat, so it's your choice where we go, Yui.
context-en3: How do people decide what they’re going to do for the rest of their lives? There are so many jobs to choose from.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decide so the verb version is to decide.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to decide. You have two keys (?) in front of you. You have to decide on one of them and use it to unlock the door to get away from the monster. Why do monster attacks always come down to keys and doors?

vocab-meaning: To Get Close, To Approach, To Draw Near, To Near, To Bring Near
context-en: When the cameraman approached it, the turtle ran away.
context-en2: Don't go anywhere near my girlfriend!
context-en3: Strange as it is, the zombie approaching us right now is actually my type.
meaning-exp: Because this word ends with an ? sound, you can tell it's probably a verb. The kanji portion means near. The verb version of that is to draw near, to get close or to approach. Essentially, the general idea is that you're getting closer to something. You're becoming more nearby. You're approaching.
reading-exp: There's hiragana attached to this kanji, which means it's probably the kun'yomi reading (and it is). You've seen the kun'yomi reading via the word ??. So, as long as you know that word, you should be able to read this one as well.

vocab-meaning: To Guess, To Guess Something, To Hit, To Apply
context-en: Put this shell to your ear and you’ll hear the sound of the waves.
context-en2: We played a game trying to guess who was lying during lunch break.
context-en3: I wanted to say, "I hit the ball really well with my bat," but I accidentally said butt.
meaning-exp: You know that the kanji ? means right or success. So since this is a verb, you're doing right and success (which doesn't make much sense). Instead, you're guessing something and getting it right. So, this word means to guess or to guess something. Hopefully you don't have to guess too hard when it comes to the meaning of this word as well.
reading-exp: The reading can be remembered via the word ??? which you learned a few levels ago. Use that knowledge to remember that this word is read as ???. The important part is the ?.

vocab-meaning: To Help, To Save, To Rescue
context-en: If WaniKani and Tofugu were drowning, which one would you save?
context-en2: Is there anybody who can rescue this poor abandoned puppy?
context-en3: Does anybody need any help eating their chili and cheese burrito? I’m really good at it!
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means help so the verb version is to help. Don't confuse this with ??? which means "to be helped." You know that ??? is "to help" because you're doing the helping. You know that you're doing the helping because you care (??).
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to help someone. Someone is hanging off a cliff and out of reach. They ask you, the person standing above them, to toss (??) them a rope, but you refuse. "TOSS IT!" they yell. "I WILL NOT TOSS IT," you respond. You're a jerk.

vocab-meaning: To Intersect, To Cross, To Mingle
context-en: I love the evening sky when orange meets indigo blue.
context-en2: In this office, Japanese and American culture sometimes intersect.
context-en3: My grandma’s boobs are so long that they sometimes cross over each other.
meaning-exp: You know that the kanji means mix and the word ??? means "to mix," so it probably has something to do with that. This word means to intersect, which is kind of like mixing. When two things intersect with each other, they're getting mixed up, so that's where this word gets its meaning. To remember that this one means "to intersect," remember the ? as walk. You're walking around, and then you intersect with some people on the street.
reading-exp: The reading is almost the same as ??? which you should be familiar with by now. It has the ? but it also has an extra ? in there. That ? is there because you intersect with a group of mages (??) that catch you on fire as you walk past.

vocab-meaning: To Live, To Dwell, To Reside
context-en: I live with my father and mother.
context-en2: Aokigahara's Jukai is a terrifying place to live.
context-en3: I want to live in a hobbit hole, but I don’t know how to dig.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dwelling, so the verb version means to dwell. It can also mean to live or to reside. Basically, someone is living somewhere. Where do you live?
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have a place to live... but not for long. You are being sued (?) out of your house and home so you will have nowhere to dwell.

context-en: Let’s go to the hospital tomorrow.
context-en2: Tomorrow is another day.
context-en3: I need to call the school tomorrow to inform them that I’m going to Italy for a month.
meaning-exp: A bright day isn't today (because today was terrible), it's tomorrow, because you can always look to tomorrow to be a better, brighter day.
reading-exp: The reading makes no sense at all. You have to learn it straight up, and can't rely on the kanji it's made from. Why is tomorrow going to be such a bright and awesome day? Because you're making ash tacos for dinner, and that's your favorite. Imagine imagining tomorrow, full of ash tacos and deliciousness. Maybe you could use some of those Dorito taco shells? A note about the other two readings ?? and ?????: ?? is used in the news and in weather reports, and ????? is really only used in business, so you should really only be using ??? for now. But it's good to know that the other two readings exist!

vocab-meaning: To Reevaluate, To Look Again, To Reassess
context-en: Let’s look at the plans one more time.
context-en2: On the last junk removal day, my husband was much more dependable than I expected and it made me look at him differently.
context-en3: I think you should reevaluate your choices in university classes. I don’t think catching dodo birds is a good career path.
meaning-exp: You know the word ?? from a couple levels ago. It means "to fix." So, when you fix what you see, what are you doing? You're reevaluating something. That's why this word means to reevaluate.
reading-exp: The readings are all kun'yomi readings, like the vocab you've seen already. This is like two vocab words put together, which is why it's using the kun'yomi reading. The hiragana on the end is a hint!

context-en: When I leave home, I always remember my puppy that got run over in front of the house.
context-en2: I was so panicked because I couldn't recall my 4 digit PIN code.
context-en3: The best way to make somebody remember you is to borrow money from them.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means to think (so ?? is a thought). You also know that ?? means to remove. So, when you remove a thought, you are remembering something. This is a verb, so the verb form of remembering something is to remember.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi readings. You should know the words ?? and ?? and their readings, so you should be able to read this word if you know those words.

context-en: Nikka is always running around the office.
context-en2: My kid completely recovered from the traffic accident and now he's just running, full of energy.
context-en3: After Koichi shot the bee hive, we ran around for nearly ten minutes trying to escape from all the bees.
meaning-exp: You've seen the words ?? (to run) and ?? (to revolve). So, when you're running and revolving while you're doing it, you're running in circles. So, the verb form of that is to run around.
reading-exp: The readings are those like the words ?? and ??. Make sure you know those words from before and apply that knowledge to read this word as well.

context-en: A woman and a man are talking while looking at a picture.
context-en2: I want to become fluent in Japanese soon.
context-en3: Every time I hear you speak, I feel like jumping off of a bridge without a bungee cord for some reason.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means talk so the verb version of this is to talk or to speak.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Every time you try to speak, ?s (??) just sprout out of your mouth preventing you. Imagine your mouth full of flowers. Taste them, spit them out, and try to speak again. Same problem.

context-en: After all, it’s difficult to support a family on just my income.
context-en2: The United States economy is supported by Tofugu.
context-en3: It was very fun for me to support myself up against the wall.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means support so the verb version is to support.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to support someone. In order to support them, you grab two saws. One saw and another saw. A saw saw (?? combination good enough to do all the supporting you need - and maybe cut some supports too).

context-en: This new ball is very easy to throw.
context-en2: Why are those people throwing dried soy beans?
context-en3: The pitcher threw the ball and it struck a pigeon flying in front of the batter.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw so the verb version means to throw.
reading-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached, so you can bet it uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're at a baseball game watching people throw balls around. But you're hungry so you call for a snack from a vendor. You raise your hand and they throw some nachos (?) at you. Oh no! Oh ouch! The nachos are hot and they hit you in the face. The vendor just threw a bunch of hot, sauced nachos at you! WHY?!

context-en: She’s famous for transforming into a beautiful woman with makeup.
context-en2: That yokai can transform to a person.
context-en3: My house was so completely transformed after the renovation that my son didn't know which home to go to after school.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means change so you'd think the verb version is "to change" but it's a little different. This word means to transform, which is a lot like "to change" but this is more like when a person transforms into something else, like a dinosaur.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You try to transform. You want to turn into something awesome, like a dinosaur, but then *poof* you turn into a sheep. "Baaaa," you say. "Baaa."

vocab-meaning: To Turn, To Rotate, To Turn Something, To Rotate Something, To Spin
context-en: I practiced spinning pizza on my index finger all day yesterday.
context-en2: The door knob turning noise made the baby wake up.
context-en3: If I spin a one dollar coin fast enough, maybe it will turn into a one hundred dollar bill.
meaning-exp: You've probably seen the word ??, which means "to revolve." This word is similar, except for you're doing the turning/rotating action on something else. You can simply say to turn or to rotate when answering this question, but be sure to think of yourself actually turning/rotating something. Remember this by using the ? on the end. You've taken your friend Sue and put her on a stick. You're rotating her over a fire on a spit because you're a sick cannibal.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the word ?? (??). So long as you know that level 5 word, you'll be able to read this one as well. Use both of these words together to remember their readings.

vocab-meaning: To Turn On, To Switch On, To Light Up
context-en: Turn on the light.
context-en2: I don't know how to turn on the radio.
context-en3: Can you turn on the TV?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means point so the verb version is something you need to point your finger to do. Picture pointing your finger and pushing a lightswitch to turn on the light. You won't be able to switch on a lamp if you can't point your finger.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You aren't able to turn on the light with just one finger though, you need to use two (?). Either you have really weak fingers, or that's a really strong lightswitch. Either way, you need two fingers to switch on the light.

vocab-meaning: To Turn Towards, To Point, To Turn (Something) Towards
context-en: I have a huge phobia of cameras suddenly pointing toward me.
context-en2: Please turn your attention from your phone to your kid.
context-en3: The man slowly pointed the muzzle of the gun at me.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means "to face" or "to turn toward" - so, this is a different version of that. This is when someone turns or points something, but you aren't turning. That's why it means to turn (something) towards and to point. In order to remember that this particular word means "to turn (something) towards," focus on the ?. You have a bottle of ketchup in your hands and you're turning it toward your worst enemy to spray them. Picture yourself pointing the ketchup toward them.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is the same as ?? which you learned in a previous level. As long as you know that one you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

context-en: As for the chart below, it shows "train times" and "bus times."
context-en2: Get on this train, get off at Totoro Station and transfer to the Catbus.
context-en3: The Hogwarts Express isn’t an electric train, it’s a steam train.
meaning-exp: You would think that an electricity car was an electric car, but this word was made before the days of the Prius. This refers to a train, which I guess was electric at some point.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Water Supply, Water Service, Waterworks, Aqueduct, Conduit, Water Line
context-en: This tap water is safe to drink.
context-en2: I couldn't pay the water bill, so my water was shut off.
context-en3: The water line froze.
meaning-exp: A water road carries your water supply. In the old days, these were called aqueducts.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I love men whose entire bodies are covered in wild, thick hair.
context-en2: Apparently Koichi is looking to get his whole body tattooed. What do you guys think?
context-en3: I went running for the first time in seven months yesterday and now my whole body hurts.
meaning-exp: The all of somebody is someone's whole body.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: On Saturday, we had a picnic in the woods.
context-en2: You can't see the wood for the trees, mom!
context-en3: Little Red Riding Hood was walking through the forest when she came upon a dead wolf. Then she went on her way and had a lovely visit with her grandmother.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too.

context-en: I want to live my whole life with you.
context-en2: I really hate men who call women "you."
context-en3: The gyoza you make is really tasty.
meaning-exp: The ? is added to elevate someone in front of you. But it's done in a sarcastic way, so this word means you. That's right, plain old "you." This "you" is usually used casually, between men.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the kun'yomi, like the reading for the vocabulary word ?. So long as you know that word, you'll be able to read this one too.

context-en: You and I will always be together.
context-en2: You're pretty short, so I'm worried if you'll be able to reach the shower head and take it off the hook.
context-en3: You are the worst person to be stuck with in an elevator.
meaning-exp: Okay, so the kanji itself means buddy and so does the word, but it also means you as well. This is one of the several ways to say "you" in Japanese, and this one is kind of an "affectionate" you. Maybe you'd say it with someone you're close to. Maybe you'd say it with a girlfriend or boyfriend. You wouldn't want to use it with your boss or teacher, though. Make sure to keep that in mind. It's kind of like saying "hey buddy" or "hey you," after all.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Who's your buddy? It's Kimmy (??)! If you know a Kimmy, imagine her. If you don't, find a famous Kimmy or make up a Kimmy to imagine. You ask... is it you?? Wait, you're my buddy?

context-en: All of it?
context-en2: Who ate the whole box of my bacon cookies?
context-en3: These socks are all holes.
meaning-exp: If you take all parts and put them together, you have all things. The entire collection. It is whole.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Nikka really is an angel.
context-en2: I think I need to distance myself from the angel for a while.
context-en3: I met a girl who was as cute as an angel.
meaning-exp: One who uses heaven to their advantage is someone from heaven, like an angel.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Let’s try looking again from a different angle.
context-en2: The Leaning Tower of Pisa sure stands at an odd angle.
context-en3: If I can see Miley Cyrus singing my favorite song from this angle, I will believe in God because it would mean that He made my dream come true.
meaning-exp: The degree of the angle shows what the angle is. 90 degrees? 160 degrees? They're all still angles when you come down to it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This evening there will be an important announcement from Koichi.
context-en2: Pikachu announced his retirement from Pokemon this morning.
context-en3: I'm nervous because I have to give a presentation about my social media research outcome in front of everyone tomorrow.
meaning-exp: I'm going to express my departure. That is my only announcement.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ??? changes to ??? and the ?? gets shortened, though, so just about everything about this word is weird.

vocab-meaning: Article, News Story, Report, Account, News Article
context-en: I wrote an article about American education.
context-en2: Kristen, I've just found your article in this month's National Geographic magazine!
context-en3: This news story is nonsense.
meaning-exp: When you write down a lot of stuff focusing on one thing it's called an article. If it's on something that just happened it will probably be a news story.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: But that’s just an assumption, right?
context-en2: For example, if we say one dollar is one hundred yen, then one can of $1 coca cola is one hundred yen, right?
context-en3: Since seeing that pile of money on her bed, crazy assumptions have been flying around in my head.
meaning-exp: A temporary determination is something you're not totally sure about. You've decided to think of something in a certain way, but only for now. If more information comes to light, you may change. That's why this word means assumption or hypothesis.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please go straight on this street and turn left at the third light.
context-en2: This road is busy all day long.
context-en3: Were there any gas stations on Bacon Cheeseburger Avenue?
meaning-exp: You know the word ?? hopefully by now. That is the verb version of this word, which means "to pass through." So, if this is the noun version, what is it that you use to pass through something? To drive or walk along? That would be an avenue (or street, road, etc). This is a pretty common word in Japan, and good for not getting lost.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the word ??, so as long as you know that, you should be able to read this one as well. Mind the strange long ? sound!

context-en: Thank you for the beautiful scarf. I’ll cherish it.
context-en2: Princess Kristen's red hair is so beautiful it makes me cry.
context-en3: Oh my, your eyes are as beautiful as jewels, Christine.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of beauty? It's beautiful.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you. It's a long reading for a mnemonic, but try your best. You look at someone who is beautiful. What an easy life they've lived. No hard work and all they do is pamper themselves to stay beautiful. Feel disgusted. You walk up to this person and say: "U too cushy! (?????). Sorry for adding the whole word in there for the reading mnemonic, but I thought it worked out better that way. Just know that the word isn't ??????? or something weird like that. The hiragana on the end is part of the mnemonic as well.

context-en: Your wife is beautiful and so refined.
context-en2: It's a matter of how you put it, so you should have just told her that she is beautiful instead of being foolishly honest.
context-en3: He says he never needs advice from anyone, but as soon as a beautiful woman offers him some, he’s all ears.
meaning-exp: A person who is beautiful is a beautiful woman. Wait, why isn't this a beautiful person? Because of course only women can be beautiful - men tend to be handsome, or just generally not as good looking. So, while both "beautiful woman" and "beautiful person" are technically correct, you're generally only going to hear it as beautiful woman, so remember that meaning.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When you cook using oil be careful you don’t start a fire.
context-en2: This mug is hot. Be careful.
context-en3: You need to be more careful when you eat snow from now on. You're color blind, so you can’t tell even if it is yellow.
meaning-exp: This word contains the words ? (energy) and ??? (to attach). So, when you attach energy to something you're focusing in on it, right? This word is a sort of "order" as well, since it's te-form there at the end. It's a set phrase people say to other people who are doing dangerous things. It's kind of like saying "Attach energy to what you're doing! Stay focused!" A simpler way to translate this would be to say this word means be careful or take care, though. Learn this word so that you can always show that you're caring for your friends!
reading-exp: The readings come from the two words ? and ???. So long as you know those from the previous levels, you should be able to read this one as well.

context-en: This bacon is a little bitter.
context-en2: This medicine is very bitter, so brace yourself!
context-en3: Be careful not to let the caramel burn or it will taste bitter.
meaning-exp: The kanji for ? means suffer. This word, however, is quite different. It means bitter tasting. Just think of ways you can suffer, though. Then, think of putting the most bitter thing in the world in your mouth. You feel sick, your mouth gets all weird, and you try to spit it out but the bitterness remains. Bitter tasting things are super gross.
reading-exp: Like the word meaning, the reading is an exception as well. You can remember it by thinking: The taste is so bitter that you fall to your knees really, really hard. Luckily, you were wearing your knee guards (??). Feel the relief that you were wearing them. Ack, no relief now. It's still bitter in your mouth.

vocab-meaning: Black And White, White And Black
context-en: Let’s make it clearly black and white.
context-en2: This black and white photo is very lovely.
context-en3: I agree that Kanae always wears very chic clothes, but today that black and white dress just makes her look like a panda, doesn’t it?
meaning-exp: Something is both white and black. It is black and white (you can also say white and black if you prefer).
reading-exp: The readings are kun'yomi, but you should have seen both ? and ?? separately as vocabulary by now. It's the same readings here, so you can apply that knowledge and read this word!

context-en: What is Anna’s body weight in kilograms?
context-en2: I can’t wait to weigh myself at my next body measuring.
context-en3: Don’t ask me how I know your weight. I promised Jessica that I wouldn’t tell you that she told me.
meaning-exp: How heavy is your body? Figure that out and you'll have your body weight.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I go to that bookstore often.
context-en2: This bookshop has a lot of tourist guidebooks.
context-en3: I work part time at the bookstore cash register.
meaning-exp: A book shop is a shop that sells books. A bookstore.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Butcher Shop, Meat Shop, Meat Store
context-en: Could you buy 100 grams of ground beef and pork from the butcher shop over there?
context-en2: I heard that butcher shop is creating a new flavor of vegan tofu burgers.
context-en3: My small town had a restaurant called The Butcher Shop, so I was really surprised to learn what a real butcher shop is. I’m a vegetarian now.
meaning-exp: A meat shop is a place that sells meat. Who sells meat? A butcher shop.
reading-exp: For ? you use the ?? reading (which you learned with the kanji). For ? you use the kun'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Basically, if you learned the kanji readings, you can read this word!

context-en: Please put your clothes in the drawer.
context-en2: How cute! They are wearing matching clothing.
context-en3: It’s so hot today. You’re wearing too many clothes.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji and uses the on'yomi even though it's a single word. Very strange, but convenient for you so long as you remember this exception reading word.

context-en: As for that manga, we have the whole series in the clubroom.
context-en2: For some reason, there is a cat with a fish in its mouth in the clubroom.
context-en3: I forgot something in the clubroom.
meaning-exp: A club room is a clubroom!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I worked all night last night, but I haven’t been able to sleep at all because of the loud construction that started this morning.
context-en2: Because there's construction going on all day, all over town, there are roads closed everywhere and I'm sick and tired of it.
context-en3: This construction finished today, right?
meaning-exp: Industry actions are things industries do. The actions of industry create a lot of construction, whether it be the construction of items or the construction of roads, factories, and more.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The consultation time is from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m.
context-en2: If you don't mind, I'd like to discuss something with you in private. Do you have a minute?
context-en3: I consulted my doctor about my hemorrhoids.
meaning-exp: A mutual discussion. Both sides are talking to each other and the feelings are mutual. Imagine you're discussing a problem. You want to get help with it, so you get some consultation from your friend. This discussion was very helpful.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The dream of Koichi and Steve Buscemi talking came true!
context-en2: Unfortunately, it's time to bring this conversation to a close.
context-en3: I want to talk with a famous writer.
meaning-exp: A versus discuss is when you sit and look at another person. You are discussing something versus them, so you talk back and forth to each other. In this way, you are having a conversation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: They’ve decided to turn the Kumaman manga into an anime!
context-en2: This will be your final decision and it can't be changed later. Is that okay?
context-en3: I’ll leave the decision of whether we’re going to attend your little sister’s wedding or my mother’s funeral to you.
meaning-exp: It's been decided and determined. The decision has been made.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to take note of the shortened ?? in ?. It goes to ??.

context-en: My brother has a cold and a fever of 38 degrees Celsius.
context-en2: What temperature do you usually set the AC to?
context-en3: I think about 24 degrees is just right for me.
meaning-exp: The kanji degree can mean both degree in terms of angles and degree in terms of temperature. This word is how you talk about these things. Just attach it to a number and you have yourself the number of degrees that something is.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned. When writing out the answer to this reading, omit the ? as it's only there to let you know that some other word should come before it.

context-en: Could you call the head of the editorial department ASAP?
context-en2: I belonged to a kendo club back in junior high school.
context-en3: I’m the head of the accounting department.
meaning-exp: You'll see this attached to other words... like "sales" or "tennis." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ department, or a ___ club, making this word mean department or club, similar to the kanji meaning.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi reading. Don't type the ? out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

context-en: There are five minutes until departure.
context-en2: I'm going to leave for Tokyo in two weeks.
context-en3: Thank you so much for inviting me to a drinking party to celebrate the departure of a co-worker that I rarely spoke to.
meaning-exp: You exit and then make a departure. This is just a departure.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ??? gets shortened and ?? changes to ??. No wonder you want to make a departure, you want to get away from crazy readings like this.

vocab-meaning: Discomfort, Inconvenience, Disability, Impairment, Poverty, Destitution
context-en: You’ve been living in such comfort. You shouldn’t ask for too much.
context-en2: This is priority seating for the elderly and disabled, okay?
context-en3: My older brother’s legs are disabled.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means freedom? Well when you add not it causes you discomfort and really inconveniences you. That not is in the way of your freedom.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I found hornworms on my balcony.
context-en2: It’s very important to have early detection for cancer.
context-en3: I discovered how to make money from Facebook. It’s easy. Just go to your account settings, deactivate your account, and go to work.
meaning-exp: You make departure from your home off into the great beyond. You will go to see the unseen, and hopefully make a great discovery.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the ?? part, which gets shortened to ??. The ? is unlike what you learned with ?, though. In order to remember that this is ??, imagine you're going out to make a discovery of some strange new lands. With strange new lands, there comes strange new people. This one has a samurai named Ken ?? on it. He's trying to discover new things too!

context-en: Please draw double lines under kanji you don’t know.
context-en2: Japan doesn't allow dual citizenship.
context-en3: "Well, let’s stop the small talk and cut to the chase. What was the topic of today’s meeting?" "We were going to talk about your double chin, sir." "Right, right. Let’s get started."
meaning-exp: When you have two heavy things, you have double and dual the heavy (compared to one, at least). This word is a prefix attached to other words to show that it is "double." ?? kanji time!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m sorry for all the times I’ve troubled you.
context-en2: Sora can't make up his mind about which one to order, as usual.
context-en3: Thank you for your continued patronage.
meaning-exp: When something happens at every occurrence and at every degree, it's something that happens frequently. It happens each time.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This test was a piece of cake.
context-en2: ”How was the JLPT5?" "Thanks to WaniKani, it was easy peasy."
context-en3: The side who has better technology in a war will usually have an easy victory.
meaning-exp: A win that was an ease. That is an easy victory or an easy win. Don't hope for a lot of these, though. Hope for tough wins instead, they actually make you better.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Elementary School, Primary School, Grade School
context-en: I'm reading various picture books to little children in elementary schools.
context-en2: In that elementary school, there is a sixth grade boy who is a Koichi wannabe.
context-en3: I’ve had feelings for you since I was in elementary school.
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? from a couple levels ago. Now we're adding a small to it. What is a "small school"? That's a school for small people, making it an elementary school.
reading-exp: The reading is the regular on'yomi reading of ? plus the vocab word ?? that you've seen previously. Combine these two things for the reading of ???.

context-en: Would you mind if I asked you to do some errands?
context-en2: Sorry! I have to take care of something and I have to cancel my lesson today.
context-en3: I have an important matter to attend to so I will not be able to work tomorrow.
meaning-exp: A task action is something you have to do (because ? is all about actions). What's another way to say "an action that is a task," though? I would say errand or even business.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: They’re important documents, so please be careful not to lose them.
context-en2: For this country, it is a very important that each citizen raises one swan.
context-en3: The most important thing in my life is beer? I didn’t say that! Don’t put words in my mouth.
meaning-exp: When something has a heavy need, you know that that thing is essential. It is important.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I just got out of the bath.
context-en2: The bath temperature is just right.
context-en3: What a coincidence! I was just about to call you!
meaning-exp: Okay, we're going to cheat a little bit to remember the meaning of this word. Let's say you take the temperature of the street. It is exactly one hundred degrees. That's exactly what it is. Just 100 degrees, not one degree more or less. You put your eggs on the street and watch them cook.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Oh! Is tomorrow examination day? I almost forgot about it.
context-en2: We made several tests, but none of them have gone well yet.
context-en3: "By the way, how was the exam?" "Stop talking about that, dad."
meaning-exp: If you attempt a test, you're taking an examination. There are a lot of these in Japan, so make sure you know this word if you want to fit in with all the whining and whinging that students do, especially come the final year of high school.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The number of applicants for the rice harvesting experience activity reached five hundred.
context-en2: In Japan, the number of people who have experienced war has been decreasing year after year.
context-en3: This is a story based on Koichi’s own experiences from when he studied abroad in Japan.
meaning-exp: Your body goes through tests and each time it does, it gains a little more experience. What has your body experienced? What tests has your body been through?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I borrowed a car for an experiment.
context-en2: We experimented to find out what things we could say to make Viet angry.
context-en3: Who wants to be a guinea pig for the experiment for our new fugu flavored tofu project?
meaning-exp: A test that tries to find truth is an experiment. This is because you don't know the truth, so the only way to find it is to try things out and test them. Thus, experiment!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The fire was on the fifth floor of the apartment.
context-en2: I smell something strange! Maybe a fire?
context-en3: Yesterday I had a dream that my house caught on fire.
meaning-exp: Fire is a thing that makes more fire. Basically fire is fire.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Fish Shop, Fish Market, Fish Dealer, Fish Store, Fishmonger
context-en: We went to buy splendid red bream at the fish store.
context-en2: This fish shop floor is very slippery, so be careful.
context-en3: The fish shop gave me a 100 yen discount.
meaning-exp: A fish shop is a fish shop, a place from which you buy fish. Especially in Japan, very important.
reading-exp: The kun'yomi reading is used for the ? (so it's ???) and the kun'yomi reading is used for ? (?). You'll have to use the reading of ? from the vocabulary from a couple levels ago to remember the reading of this one.

vocab-meaning: For Sale, Selling, Item For Sale, Sale
context-en: We’ve decided to sell bacon and okonomiyaki cheese tarts from Tofugu this summer.
context-en2: Portland's famous Tofugu tea, with the dirt of Koichi's nails, is now on sale on the Tofugu website!
context-en3: I can’t wait until the Tofugu dating pillows are on sale.
meaning-exp: You want things to depart from your store so you have to sell them. You put all these things up for sale. They are selling these items.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Front, Surface, Exterior, Face, Outside, Appearance
context-en: Please paint the front pink.
context-en2: Koichi's public face is the president of Tofugu, but his private face is the most well-known juggler in the world.
context-en3: Which side of a ten yen coin is the face?
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji express. If you want to understand what something is trying to express you usually look at its front or its exterior. This word is usually used for the exterior face of buildings.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're standing in front of a building, staring at its front. You spend some time gazing at it before you realize what it is. "Oh, motel (???)", you say aloud. A little time looking at the exterior and you're able to figure it out.

context-en: I plan to go buy furniture for my new house this weekend.
context-en2: You have such wonderful furniture, Princess! Very impressive.
context-en3: We moved the furniture to your new house but you should act quickly to get the doors and windows installed.
meaning-exp: Your house tools aren't the tools you use to build a house. They're more like the things that are a part of your house that you use like tools. Those things would be your furniture. So, remember, your house tools are just furniture.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When customers come in, this bell rings.
context-en2: I met up with my guest at Tokyo Station.
context-en3: What do you think I should do to get customers?
meaning-exp: The ?? on the end is the name honorific ??. It's there to show some respect. It's like saying "Mr. Guest!" or something like that. But that sounds dumb in English. We'll just call this word guest, visitor, or customer. You'll hear this word a lot when you're at a store or you're a customer somewhere in Japan. You are the ????, in that situation. Alternatively, you'll also hear ???? which is a more polite version of this word (because it ends in ?? and not ??).
reading-exp: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just add the hiragana on the end and you'll be good to go.

context-en: My dream is to stay in a guest room attached to an open air bath with the idol I love.
context-en2: In this hotel, all the guest rooms have concierge service.
context-en3: I just finished renovating the guest room. Come over and tell me what you think.
meaning-exp: A guest's room is the guest room (the room you put guests in, duh!).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m looking for a heart shaped stone to use on my fake nails.
context-en2: Kristen was swinging a heart shaped hammer around while holding nails in her mouth.
context-en3: When flamingos kiss, their heads and necks form a heart shape.
meaning-exp: ??? is of course "heart" and you know that ? means shape. You've probably already figured this one out. It's heart shaped. You can add this kanji to all sorts of other things too to say "____ shaped." Give it a try!
reading-exp: The reading for the kanji portion uses the kun'yomi reading. This is kind of like the reading you already learned for ? just without the ? part. And rendaku happens too, so it becomes ??. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this reading too!

context-en: That luggage looks heavy.
context-en2: This car is so heavy that my arm is about to fall off.
context-en3: "I’m sorry I stepped on your foot." "No problem. It was a little heavy, but no harm done."
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of heavy? It's also heavy.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're lifting something that's really heavy. Oof! You lift it above your head. You're so awesome. You scream: "OH! MORE!" (??) they put more. You yell it again: "OH, MORE!" and again: "OH, MORE!" Go ahead and act this out wherever you are, pretending like you're holding a couch or two or three over your head, saying "OH MORE!"

context-en: His excitement levels are dangerously high, right?
context-en2: Tofugu's cactus has grown to a height of 1.5 meters.
context-en3: "What do you think about the height of this building? Is it too high?" "Sorry, but I don’t know. It’s over my head."
meaning-exp: You've seen the word ?? from a couple levels ago. This word is related to that. It's like ??? versus ???, where one describes the other. In this case, the ?? is the height of something (while ?? is tall). This word isn't "price" though. For that you'd ask ??????? (how much is it?).
reading-exp: Use the reading of ?? (???) to help you to learn and remember the reading for this one. They are the same with just the hiragana at the end different.

context-en: Today, high school students are coming to this bread factory on a field trip.
context-en2: When I was a high school student, I would go to the sea every day to catch fish and eat them.
context-en3: He's just trying to look cool because he’s in high school now.
meaning-exp: You know ?? means "high school." So, a "life" that does high school is a high school student. This is like how ??? are middle school students and ??? are elementary school students!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Use the reading of ?? from before to learn the reading of this word as well, if it helps.

context-en: Housework is really annoying, but I’ll do my best.
context-en2: My husband has me do chores all the time and I'm not happy about it at all.
context-en3: I’m bad at all of the housework.
meaning-exp: The only action you should be doing in my house is the housework and my chores. This isn't a hotel. Get moving! Clean my dishes!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: How Many Times, How Often, What Temperature
context-en: We all have really important moments, a few times in our lives.
context-en2: Tofugu has almost been eaten by the hungry shark many times.
context-en3: How many times do I have to say the same thing before you understand?
meaning-exp: If someone asks you what occurrence or what degrees they're really trying to ask you how many times something happened. Sometimes they're asking what temperature it is too.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

context-en: The important thing is to greet them properly.
context-en2: Logging onto WaniKani and doing your reviews every day is very important for your Japanese learning.
context-en3: Taking time to relax is important.
meaning-exp: A big action means something big is going down. This is no ordinary action. It is an action that is important.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I do like Japanese flavors.
context-en2: Can you get Japanese sesame dressing from a grocery store on the way back?
context-en3: This is the Japanese style hotdog.
meaning-exp: The Japanese style style. The Japanese often like to think they're very unique and have a very special kind of style (and often times they do). So, you'll hear this word used when someone wants to describe this unique sense of style. Wafuuuu! Note that this word uses alternative kanji meanings in both of the kanji. They're in the kanji explanation, but they're not the primaries, so it may take a little extra effort to learn this word depending on what you studied!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Japanese Style Clothes, Japanese Clothing, Japanese Style Clothing, Japanese Clothes
context-en: You look good in Japanese style clothes too.
context-en2: How many Japanese style clothes do you have?
context-en3: Have you seen Japanese people running marathons in Japanese style clothes?
meaning-exp: Japanese style clothes (Japanese Style Clothes). We're talking kimonos and yukata and things like that. Basically, this differentiates Japanese clothing from Western clothing. What kind of clothes will you wear to the festival tonight? Oh, probably some ??.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Well I like having Japanese style food for breakfast.
context-en2: There's been an increase in Americans who prefer Japanese cuisine to Western cuisine.
context-en3: Japanese style food doesn’t always mean sushi.
meaning-exp: Japanese style eat ... well, let's change "eat" to "food" and you have Japanese style food. This is a good way to differentiate between an American style restaurant and a Japanese style restaurant. What kind of food you feeling like tonight? Oh, how about some ???
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is my first time sleeping in a Japanese-style room.
context-en2: Don't you think this Japanese-style room smells like a mix of dog food and your feet, Koichi?
context-en3: My older brother has a huge pet spider in his Japanese-style room.
meaning-exp: A Japanese style room tends to be pretty small. This mainly refers to the kind of room that's covered in tatami mats, though. If you're looking for places to stay in Japan, a ?? will be something like that. You'll pull the futon out of the closet and sleep on the floor. So comfy, these Japanese style rooms!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: First, let’s begin by practicing writing kana.
context-en2: In order to study kanji on WaniKani, you must first know all of the kana.
context-en3: Could you add kana to all the kanji in this document, please?
meaning-exp: The temporary names. These are the kana (that's hiragana and katakana). Why are the "temporary names" kana, though? Perhaps they were never meant to be a main way to write the names of the kanji... They are just a temporary way to write the name of kanji you don't know how to write the "correct" way (aka kanji)? That's just a guess, but it should help you to remember that this word means "kana," at least.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the one you learned with the kanji. The ? portion is not, however, and uses its kun'yomi reading (?), which you saw with the kanji ? (?). How to remember all this, though? Think of it this way: The people who made kanji really don't want you to know kana. It's bad for business. They want anyone who uses the word "kana" to suffer, so they decided to make one part on'yomi and another part kun'yomi. Don't let them get you!

context-en: Well of course your life insurance is the reserve type, isn't it?
context-en2: In Japan, the health insurance system is all-inclusive, so you don't really need to purchase life insurance separately.
context-en3: Life insurance saleswomen are called "seiho ladies" in Japan and there are rumors that some of them sleep their ways into big commissions or promotions.
meaning-exp: A Life guarantee is something you get on someone else. If their life ends, it's guaranteed with money. That's a life insurance policy, for yah!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: A mysterious creature was discovered at a dry river bed.
context-en2: The largest living thing on the planet isn't blue whale but blue blowfish.
context-en3: Can I see your notes from the other day in Bio?
meaning-exp: A thing that has life is a living thing!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Local Specialty, Famous Product, Specialty, Famous Goods
context-en: What is Portland’s specialty?
context-en2: I got Tokyo's famous "Tokyo Banana" from the Tofugu's famous-for-being-unique president.
context-en3: Takoyaki is definitely one of the most famous foods in Osaka.
meaning-exp: The famous thing of an area is their famous product, but it sounds better in English if you say it's the local specialty. When you're traveling around Japan, be sure to be on the lookout for the ??! It's always fun.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Main Point, Gist, Main Idea, Essence
context-en: Please state your opinion after rearranging your main point a bit more.
context-en2: I don't think Yusaku got the gist.
context-en3: Come on! Get to the point!
meaning-exp: The needed point is the main point. It's the gist of what you're trying to say.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The match ended in a tie.
context-en2: This is a contest decided by a single round.
context-en3: I think this is the year things happen for me.
meaning-exp: Win, lose... both will happen in tonight's match! What a showdown it will be!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that ? becomes ? because of rendaku here.

context-en: I’m in the middle of eating a meal, so I’ll call you back later.
context-en2: Please relax and enjoy your meal!
context-en3: If you could only have one meal every day for the rest of your life, what would you choose?
meaning-exp: The action of eating is when you have your meal.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: All that aside, you should choose the photo taken in front of the junior high school.
context-en2: Give me a sec, I'll look up the location of the middle school for you.
context-en3: I’m a middle school teacher, right? To save time, let’s just always assume that I am never wrong, okay?
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means school. So, people who are in the middle school are in... wait for it... middle school. And, of course, if you're one of those people that call it junior high school you can do that too.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of ?? and ?. Really, it's all on'yomi too, so you should be able to read this one. Take note of the ?? turning to ??, though.

context-en: Nagoya has a lot of delicious food.
context-en2: I had work in Nagoya today again.
context-en3: When I visited my friend in Nagoya, I was treated to a delicious pork cutlet called yabaton.
meaning-exp: The place that's famous for old roofs. I don't know why, but it's the city of Nagoya. Just associate the two things together and it'll be hard to forget (so long as you've heard of Nagoya before - if not, read up about it!).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji (except for ? and ?, which are kun'yomi here). If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. For ? just think to ?? (???) which uses the ? reading. The "name" (??) of this city is what? It's Nagoya. Watch out for rendaku changing ? to ? too.

context-en: I have to walk a little while after getting off the bus.
context-en2: What is necessary to pass the JET interview?
context-en3: What would I need if I went to Japan?
meaning-exp: It's certain that you need it. This thing is necessary. It is needed.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Does this neighborhood have a convenience store?
context-en2: There are many foreign viewers nearby as well.
context-en3: Is there a public restroom in this neighborhood?
meaning-exp: If you attach things near you, they end up being in the same neighborhood as you. They're attached nearby so they can't go much further.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for ? though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your neighborhood is full of fools (?). Fools everywhere. You're probably one too, since you live nearby.

context-en: This pencil is new, isn’t it?
context-en2: I'll see you at the new Starbucks!
context-en3: I can’t believe he used my new scarf to bungee jump!
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of new? It's new.
