reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your family buys you a new Atari! You're so excited! But wait... what's this? This is no Atari. This is an Atara... a knockoff video game system :(

context-en: Happy New Year!
context-en2: Have you decided your New Year's resolution yet?
context-en3: We went around to our relatives houses exchanging New Year’s greetings.
meaning-exp: A new year is a new year. Hope you had / have / are having a good one, depending on when you read this.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I ate too much and it’s painful.
context-en2: I'm agonizing over the fact that I'm not able to confess my love to Tofugu.
context-en3: Are you suffering from a broken heart? Has the bank recently foreclosed on your house? If so, we have just the thing for you... "Instant Alzheimer’s." Our new medication will allow you to put your woes behind you.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of suffering? It's a description of that word, making it painful.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everything is really painful right now. Why? You have something heavy on top of you, crushing (??) you.

context-en: First, you will listen closely to what your partner has to say.
context-en2: According to my fortune, my future partner is a prince in some country. I wonder if it's true.
context-en3: I don’t want a stupid talking companion.
meaning-exp: Your mutual hand is someone else's hands (or just someone else, if you remembered that ? can also refer to a person as well). Whose hands are these? These are your partner's hands. That's why everything is mutual.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For ?, that's no problem for you. For ?, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way: Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: I (??) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."

context-en: So when do you think the world will find peace?
context-en2: I want to live in a safe and harmonious community.
context-en3: Why does everyone in Japan use the peace sign in pictures?
meaning-exp: The flat peace. This is a peace that will last, because there's no waves... no ripples... just flat. This is plain old peace.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Hey, can I make plans on Sunday?
context-en2: The asteroid is on a direct path to Earth and is estimated to hit somewhere in the North Atlantic Ocean.
context-en3: I hate when I schedule out my day, but nobody follows the script.
meaning-exp: Something has been determined beforehand. What is this thing? This action? It is a plan.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What color do you want for this part?
context-en2: What was the front part of the brain again?
context-en3: The movie was full of parts I sympathized with and I cried all over myself.
meaning-exp: Part of a part? That's a portion, a section of that part, and even a part in itself!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

context-en: What prefecture are you from?
context-en2: There are many elementary schools in Nara that require students to wear uniforms.
context-en3: Which prefectures in Japan have you been to?
meaning-exp: Attach this word onto the end of a prefecture place name and you have the prefecture portion of _____ prefecture. These are a lot like states or provinces.
reading-exp: The reading for this is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's always attached to things (so it's like jukugo). Don't write the ? when you're writing in the answer, just the ?? portion, and you'll get this one correct.

context-en: Please teach me the pronunciation of this word.
context-en2: Taylor, your Japanese pronunciation is so good.
context-en3: Wow, the pronunciation of the Spanish word "una casita" sounds similar to "I’m hungry" in Japanese.
meaning-exp: The sound that departs from your mouth is you talking. Imagine yourself saying things and words departing your mouth. They are bent in different ways and have different colors, highlighting your pronunciation of certain words and phrases.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What is this kanji’s radical?
context-en2: Someone who laughs over radicals will eventually cry over radicals.
context-en3: I remember all of the radicals.
meaning-exp: Picture the part of your body that makes up your neck. Are you picturing it? That's a building block that makes up your body. A really important one. If you didn't have that neck, you wouldn't look like a person at all. Sound familiar? It should! Because that part of your neck is a radical! Just like part of your neck is a building block of your body, the radical is a building block of kanji. Get it? I sure hope so!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you need a radical to make a new kanji, you just press a button and the radical comes tumbling down the radical chute (??). There's definitely no rhyme or reason to radical picking, it's just whatever pops out of the ol' chute.

context-en: I haven’t responded yet.
context-en2: Thanks for your RSVP.
context-en3: I sent Bill Gates over one hundred messages about giving me money, but he still hasn’t replied.
meaning-exp: The action of returning. That is a reply.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The city established a shelter and appealed to the citizens to take refuge.
context-en2: The residents got along with each other right away.
context-en3: The residents of that apartment are given free air-conditioning, but only in winter for some reason.
meaning-exp: The peoples who make their dwelling here are the residents.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I heard that Koichi is some kind of world-record holder.
context-en2: What do you think about the retention of nuclear weapons?
context-en3: Tofugu will contribute our humble efforts to maintain Mars peace.
meaning-exp: When you hold on and preserve something you are doing the act of retention or maintenance on it. This is preservation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My younger sister cleaned the room.
context-en2: I heard that there is a room that only appears at night in the music room of my school.
context-en3: I can’t clean my room because whenever I try I just get distracted by all the stuff I find.
meaning-exp: If you have a part of a roof, that part is your room. Just imagine a roof divided into sections in a house, with the sections going all the way down to the ground. Each section is its own room, right?
reading-exp: The reading is kind of an exception. The ? is normal (?) but the ? is weird. It is ?. Just imagine that you rent out a room and the only one they have is just the hay (?) room in the barn, so you sleep there for the night. Imagine the smell of hay and how scratchy it is to sleep in this room.

context-en: Try a sample before you complain about it.
context-en2: I was invited to the sample party for Koichi’s Old-Timey Soft Serve Cream Cheese Emporium.
context-en3: The person who offers food samples in grocery stores is called "Ms. Mannequin" in the Japanese food industry.
meaning-exp: Go ahead and try an eat. How was that little try? That little sample? That little taste?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There is a pharmacy and a butcher shop nearby too.
context-en2: Before I changed my job to being a princess, I was working at a flower shop.
context-en3: It’s my dream to marry someone who owns yakiniku restaurants.
meaning-exp: You'll see this attached to other words... like "meat" or "fish." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ store, making this word mean store (same as the kanji).
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi reading. Don't type the ? out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

vocab-meaning: Sure Victory, Certain Victory, Sure Win, Certain Win
context-en: I prayed for certain victory at a shrine.
context-en2: I saw a person wearing a headband that said "Sure Victory" at the karate match.
context-en3: If tigers were to go to war against turkeys, it would mean certain victory for the tigers. Chicken farmers would be happy, as well.
meaning-exp: A certain win sounds like a great thing. When these two kanji are put together, a certain victory is inevitable.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the ? in ?? is turned into a small ?, though.

context-en: Michael's swimming is better than the fish's!
context-en2: I admired frogs' swimming so I frantically practiced the breaststroke until my arms and legs got longer.
context-en3: I’m not very good at swimming.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji swim, so it means swimming.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

vocab-meaning: Take An Exam, Take An Examination, Take A Test, Taking An Exam, Taking An Examination, Taking A Test
context-en: My older brother is going to take university entrance exams next year.
context-en2: I've been studying to take the exam from morning to night every day lately.
context-en3: I forgot to take the exam admission slip, but my mom dropped it off for me.
meaning-exp: When you accept a test you are going in to take an exam. Good luck! A++++!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: You keep my father’s teachings alive and well.
context-en2: It's such a great lesson, isn't it?
context-en3: When I follow your teachings nothing goes well.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji teach. So it means teaching.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned ???, so you should be able to read this word as well.

vocab-meaning: Tea Shop, Tea Store, Tea House
context-en: The Tofugu tea shop in Portland has popular fugu mochi.
context-en2: When Koichi traveled to Kyoto, he enjoyed teahouse entertainment every night.
context-en3: Japanese people call modern cafes "Cafe," slightly old fashioned coffee lounges "Kissaten," and traditional tea shops "Chaya."
meaning-exp: A tea shop is a tea shop. Mmm, delicious, delicious tea.
reading-exp: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Even if Koichi said, "Tofugu’s female," I believe many users would have opposing opinions.
context-en2: If the worst were to happen to Tofugu, what would happen to lifetime members?
context-en3: What? Her boobs are made of balloons? Suppose that were true, who cares?
meaning-exp: The kanji itself means temporary. When you add the ? on there you're going towards temporary, which is temporarily.
reading-exp: The reading is kun'yomi, so here's a mnemonic to remember it: Would you mind carrying (??) this temporarily?

context-en: However, neither of them exist in this world.
context-en2: Mt. Fuji is registered as a World Heritage Site.
context-en3: He lives in his own world and doesn’t want to leave it.
meaning-exp: The generations (and society!) that make up the world create our world. The World.  This word is used more like "the biggest dog in the world" or "the fattest cat in the world." For example, you'll hear words like ???? (number one in the world) thrown around a lot.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What is that thing Masaru has?
context-en2: Don't treat my dog like a thing!
context-en3: My three favorite things are chicken, fried foods, and rice.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: What game has the most things in it? Monopoly (??). You can choose from a bunch of random things to play as, you know? And no one actually knows what those things are. What's a thimble anyway? Just call it a thing.

context-en: Why do you think Ms. Sumomo wears so many pink clothes?
context-en2: I often have trouble understanding what my junior colleague is saying.
context-en3: I’m sorry but I’ve been busy recently because I have a lot of things to do.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Additionally on top of thing there are the meanings matter and action as well. Like the kanji, this word has to do with action things... things that you do, for example, rather than physical things.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: It's hard to start a mnemonic with the word "thing" or "action," so let's continue off the kanji mnemonic where you're brushing your teeth with a cross shaped thing. After you're done, it's time to go out. You put on your coat (??) and walk out the door.

context-en: Okay, then let’s do it next time.
context-en2: I'm really, really serious about studying Japanese this time.
context-en3: The next time I make you cry it will be because you are happy.
meaning-exp: In the now occurrence you'll learn your kanji, no? This word means this time (same like "now occurrence"). Despite being "this time" it has the feeling of next time, though. It's like saying "okay, this time we'll get it" where "this time" really means "next time," making it a little bit different from ??.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Thousand Yen Bill, Thousand Yen Note, One Thousand Yen Note, One Thousand Yen Bill
context-en: I don’t have change for a thousand yen bill.
context-en2: This is a game in which you scoop thousand yen bills with a paper scoop from a water tank.
context-en3: "Are you burning a thousand dollar bill?" "No, it’s just a thousand yen bill."
meaning-exp: You know what ?? is (1000 yen). So if you add a bill to that you get a thousand yen bill. That's just the little rectangular piece of money that is worth 1000 yen.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you buy this computer now, you’ll get something thrown in, so it’s a deal.
context-en2: Michael's t-shirts have a lot of salad dressing stains on them.
context-en3: What’s that thing attached to your earlobe?
meaning-exp: You know the that the word ??? means "to attach" and you know that the kanji ? means attach. So, this word probably has something to do with attaching. This is the intransitive version, though, where something is attached (and you're not doing the attaching). You can use the ? as a hint. You see something attached on the wall. You say "Coo'"
reading-exp: The reading can be derived from ???, a word you should have seen a few levels ago. If you know that word's reading you should be able to figure out this word's reading as well (and vice versa).

context-en: This game will definitely sell well.
context-en2: I'd say, if you put up the thousand yen bill for online auction, it would easily sell for five hundred yen.
context-en3: I will teach you how to write novels that sell.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sell, so the verb version is to sell or to be sold.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should be able to read it!

context-en: But it’s not okay to express your discomfort so bluntly.
context-en2: All citizens are expressing some dissatisfaction with the high tax.
context-en3: I can’t begin to express how good this apple cinnamon whiskey is.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means express so the verb vocab version is to express.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're trying not to say it directly, and trying to figure out how to express that you are a wuss (????). Sorry, had to be expressed.

context-en: The moment you find a bug bite it makes you itchy, don't you think?
context-en2: This hat might help us find Koichi's wig.
context-en3: I spent over four hours this morning trying to find the pot of gold that they say is at the end of the rainbow.
meaning-exp: You know that ??? means "to attach" and that ? means "see." So, when you attach your seeing to something, it's like you're looking around trying to find something. When you find what you're looking for, imagine your eyeballs flying out and attaching to that item, then yelling "I FOUND IT!"
reading-exp: The readings come from ?? and ???. If you use those readings, you'll be able to read this word too.

vocab-meaning: To Give A Ride, To Give Someone A Ride, To Place On
context-en: It’s dangerous to let children ride in the passenger's seat.
context-en2: Putting your feet on a table is bad manners.
context-en3: The man saw that the woman’s bicycle was completely destroyed so he offered to give her a ride back to town.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ride so this word has to do with riding. There's another word that's similar (?? which means to ride). This particular one means to give a ride. Use the ? as a hint. The ? is a "sail" (?) that you use on your boat to give someone a ride. How nice of you.
reading-exp: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be okay with this. Allow me to give you a ride to the next item to study.

vocab-meaning: To Hold, To Carry, To Own, To Keep
context-en: Do you have an eraser, Araki?
context-en2: Actually, Koichi has a license to be a soft baseball referee. ...actually, that's a lie.
context-en3: When I realized I won the grand prize, the hand I was holding the lottery ticket with couldn’t help but shake.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hold so the verb version is to hold. This word is for when you're carrying or holding something, simply.
reading-exp: If you try to hold something in your hand long enough it will mold (?). And then that mold will cover your hand, then your arm, then your entire body. Basically, you should never hold anything for too long or you'll become a mold person.

vocab-meaning: To Let Pass, To Overlook, To Continue, To Keep, To Make Way For, To Persist In
context-en: Please heat the meat thoroughly.
context-en2: You guys should go through the proper channels.
context-en3: Threading a needle is difficult.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that ?? means to pass, but this is a little different. You aren't the one passing, Sue (?) is. So you have to let Sue pass. That's why this means to let pass.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned ??. Switch the ? for a ? and you'll be all set!

context-en: My favorite team lost, so I’m frustrated and heartbroken.
context-en2: Breadman was badly defeated in a chess game by Anpanman.
context-en3: "Where do you want to eat tonight?" "It’s your call. I lost the rock-paper-scissors."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lose so the verb vocab version means to lose.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You lose your tournament/soccer game/whatever (you decide something applicable to you). You're sad about this. Who's there to comfort you? Your Ma (?). She's a nice lady.

vocab-meaning: To Miss, To Fail, To Fail To Attend
context-en: Don’t forget to warm up with some visual training.
context-en2: All workers are indispensable for Tofugu.
context-en3: I cannot live without my cell phone.
meaning-exp: Remember how ??? means "to lack?" Well this is a stronger version because you cuss (??) at the end. So it means to miss. You're cussing because you aren't just lacking something, you completely missed it: I missed it?! Well $*&%!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

context-en: You need onions, tomatoes, and daikon.
context-en2: Do you need any bags?
context-en3: Write out a list of things you do and don’t need.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means need and the verb vocab version is to need.
reading-exp: Since the reading isn't like the one you learned, think about what you are going to need... like, what you're really going to need, more than anything. Then, think of an eagle, because you really need an eagle. You'll need to come up with the reason why you need an eagle though, so hopefully it's a good one.

context-en: This is the tool that you told me you wanted to borrow, Rob.
context-en2: Out of all of Doraemon's tools, which one would you want to use the most? Obviously the Anywhere Door, right?
context-en3: I bought a tool pouch yesterday that had a Babe Ruth rookie card hidden inside it.
meaning-exp: The tools you use on the road of life are important to have. What is your most important tool?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Preserve, To Keep, To Maintain
context-en: What's the secret to preserving your youth?
context-en2: Thanks to Viet, Koichi was able to maintain his face.
context-en3: The doctor told me that it’s important to exercise regularly to maintain your physical health, but he is so fat.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means preserve so the verb vocab version is to preserve.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to learn how to preserve fruits and veggies, you should start with tamots (??), that's slang for delish tomatoes. Once they're preserved, you get to make everyone you love eat those yummy tamots. Mmm!

vocab-meaning: To Receive, To Accept, To Catch
context-en: If you’re taking the exam, please come to reception at the university by 13:00.
context-en2: You don't have to take Tofugu's word as is.
context-en3: Even though my hands are fifteen times larger than anyone else’s, I still can’t catch a baseball very well.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means receive and so the verb vocab version means to receive.
reading-exp: What do you want to receive from another person more than anything else in the world? Delicious uni (?). Accepting uni from someone is (not only yummy) but it means they really, really like you.

context-en: Today I have to go to the library to take back a book.
context-en2: I have nothing to say back to you.
context-en3: "Could you return the cookies I gave you yesterday?" "Huh? You mean, I should throw them up?"
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return so the verb version means to return. This is more like "to return a thing" rather than returning home, which would be ??, a word you haven't seen yet (but will soon, I'm sure!).
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to return the Car egg (??) you found on the side of the road. It will birth a little car, but it needs its mother. So, you try to figure out how to return it. Go ahead and think through that process in your mind. Also think about how weird a car egg would be.

context-en: I took a bus to go to the sea.
context-en2: Make sure you take the train headed to Ueno and Ikebukuro and not Tokyo and Shinagawa.
context-en3: I love to ride on roller coasters but they always smell like vomit.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ride so the verb vocab version means to ride.
reading-exp: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. Enjoy the ride!

context-en: Are Japanese dictionaries sold here?
context-en2: In this village, people make a living by selling barley.
context-en3: I need to sell my car to pay the bills, but if I do that I won’t be able to get to work.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sell, so the verb version of that is to sell.
reading-exp: You want to sell something, but what? What can you sell that will take the least amount of work? Uni (?)! They're just hanging out in the ocean, ready for the taking. Go scoop some up, watch out for the pointy bits, and sell them for some quick cash!

context-en: I sent a letter to Mr. Smith.
context-en2: I'll send you the photos later on LINE.
context-en3: It’s getting late. Let’s call it a day. I’ll walk you home.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means send so the vocab verb version is to send.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to send an entire oak (??) tree in the mail, but it's too big. Imagine yourself dragging one to the post office. They tell you that you can't send that here... Go to the oak sending facilities.

context-en: Do not swim here.
context-en2: Hey, your eyes are shifty.
context-en3: I exercise by swimming in an invisible pool on my bed.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swim so the verb vocab version is to swim.
reading-exp: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana sticking out?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji.

context-en: I've attempted the method that Viet told me about five times, but it never worked.
context-en2: Apparently Viet's follower tried to escape from prison.
context-en3: Tofugu is looking for someone who always tries to do something new.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means try so the verb vocab version is to try or to attempt.
reading-exp: You know how when you try to do something you put your whole heart into it? Well, think of that in Japanese. You put your whole ? (???) into it.

context-en: I want to use my friend’s dictionary.
context-en2: I'm not good with pain, so please use anesthetics.
context-en3: Don’t be afraid of that. You should use the Japanese you know as much as possible.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means use so the verb version is to use.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Mr. Tsukalos (??), the famous Ancient Alien theorist, is always trying to use "aliens" to explain everything. Go read more about him to help you with this mnemonic.

context-en: At the soccer game, we managed to win 1-0.
context-en2: When I was four, I won the match but I felt like I lost anyway.
context-en3: I’m entering my pet rabbit in tomorrow’s dog race and I guarantee it's going to win.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means win so the verb version is to win.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What did you just win? You won a new car (?)!

vocab-meaning: True Strength, True Ability, True Power
context-en: Koichi's hula dancing abilities are genuine.
context-en2: There is no one who has witnessed Viet's true power yet.
context-en3: They usually say, "luck is what you make of it."
meaning-exp: The truth behind someone's strength is their true strength. It is also their true ability.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That may be true, but I'm still not convinced.
context-en2: What that politician has been saying contradicts the facts.
context-en3: It is a scientific fact that a man with a mustache looks creepy.
meaning-exp: The action of truth is just truth itself, though it's also facts and reality as well. Really, it's the idea of "truth" in a way.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Well actually, even though I don’t look like it, I used to be an Olympian.
context-en2: To tell you the truth, we are not your real parents.
context-en3: I’m sorry, Honey. The truth is I spent all of our savings on baseball cards and bubblegum.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi reading, same like you learned with the kanji. That is the truth, I promise.

context-en: I don't know how to use this coupon.
context-en2: I want to use the meeting room at nine tomorrow. Is it available?
context-en3: "Oh! Shiyounin is used for an employee too? I always thought it just meant servant." "Yup. And shiyousha not only means user, but employer too."
meaning-exp: Something you use that has a use has... well, use. You can even use it for practical applications.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My son, who was such a weakling and a crybaby, is already an adult.
context-en2: Many Americans are cowards who can't even eat a bit of natto.
context-en3: Cowards should be treated like hairy caterpillars - picked up and thrown out!
meaning-exp: A weak insect. This is what people call weaklings in Japan. This is a good word to know if you're a bully, or something.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is a weird one. It uses the kun'yomi readings for both, meaning you'll have to pull your knowledge of the word ?? from earlier and apply it here. ? should be okay, though, as this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, only weak bugs use kun'yomi, and that weak bug is you in this instance.

vocab-meaning: Weak Looking, Frail, Weak Seeming, Seemingly Weak
context-en: I was starting to worry about you because you had such a weak singing voice.
context-en2: My father, who used to look strong, gradually began looking weaker year after year.
context-en3: That weak looking patient is suffering from puffer fish toxins.
meaning-exp: Something that is double weak is probably pretty weak. You also know that this is an adjective because it ends with ?. You know that ?? is weak, so it probably isn't that. Instead, this one is weak looking or frail. If you know the grammar ??? you can kind of use that as a hint. The ?? on the end reminds me of ??? which is like "seems to be." So, "seems to be weak" = "weak looking."
reading-exp: The reading is double kun'yomi, as you can probably guess due to all the hiragana involved. So, you double up on ?? and then add the ?? to read this vocabulary word.

context-en: Only the winner will advance to the next stage.
context-en2: There are no winners in wars, so please stop such a meaningless fight.
context-en3: Viet emerged the victor in the 72 hour Scrabble game.
meaning-exp: Someone who wins is the winner / victor.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I graduated from Tofugu Academy in 2014.
context-en2: Many students from Kwansei Gakuin University get to study abroad while at college.
context-en3: Hey! This guy is WaniKani, a.k.a. the Crabigator. He works for Tofugu Institute for Industrial Education.
meaning-exp: A study institution is an academy. That's where all the fancy people study, anyways.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can’t do addition.
context-en2: Can I participate in the addition contest as a spectator?
context-en3: Today we studied addition in school.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means "to add?" Add calculate to that and you'll have addition! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you add.
reading-exp: This is the kun'yomi reading for ? and the on'yomi for ?. And the ?? reading is rendaku'd into ??. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

context-en: Six projects are currently progressing.
context-en2: The doctor told me that I have advanced cancer.
context-en3: The new drug made from Fugu extract has suppressed the progression of the disease.
meaning-exp: When something advances and goes, it is moving forward. If you do this you will advance. You will progress.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We started farming the deserted island last year.
context-en2: In Japan, there have been more young people who are interested in agriculture recently.
context-en3: I’m not interested in sex right now. I just really want to focus on agriculture.
meaning-exp: What's another way to call the farming business? If you encapsulated it into one word (assuming we're talking about plant farming, here), you could call it agriculture.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Our store is in a small alley off of Western Street.
context-en2: That path is a bit sketchy at night, so be careful.
context-en3: The policeman chased the mugger who stole the strawberries down the alley.
meaning-exp: If you think about it, an earth road isn't going to be the main road. It will be the road less traveled. You could call it a path (you know, like a dirt path!). Alternatively, another less traveled street that would probably be made out of dirt back in the day (before everything was paved) would be an alley. Imagine yourself walking down a dirt alley at night with no shoes. Scary!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too! And remember, that it's the ? reading that you learned with ?? here.

context-en: Don’t forget a ruler and a protractor for math class tomorrow.
context-en2: I need to ask you a personal question. Between reading, writing and arithmetic, which one are you the best at?
context-en3: "I’m sorry it took me so long to get back to you. I’ve been tied up with work." "What was your job again?" "I’m a math teacher at an elementary school."
meaning-exp: What is it called when you calculate numbers? That is the study of math and arithmetic.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Dr. Watson isn’t just Sherlock Holmes’ assistant, he’s his friend till the end.
context-en2: My aide got a torn muscle at the end of the year.
context-en3: If I’m the assistant to an assistant who was just fired, does that mean that I’m fired too?
meaning-exp: Someone who gives you a helping hand is an assistant.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: At Once, Immediately, Without Delay, Right Away, Right Now
context-en: I used it immediately.
context-en2: Thank you for your immediate response.
context-en3: I will send the eggplants to him at once.
meaning-exp: Doing something both fast and early probably requires you to do it at once or immediately. Whatever it is, be sure to do it without delay.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is strange. The reading for ? (??) is what you'd expect (on'yomi), but ? gets a reading you haven't seen before, meaning you should treat this as an exception. Just think about how you're learning this word at once and without delay so there's no time for any sass (??), just kanji learning.

context-en: I’m worried because it’s unusual for him to be so down.
context-en2: I got worried about whether the ship was heading east or west.
context-en3: Don’t worry, everything is going to be fine. You can believe what I say.
meaning-exp: When you distribute your heart around you, it's like your heart is everywhere at once, but not in your body. You feel frantic, you don't know what to do because your heart is out there. This represents the feeling you have when you have a worry or concern. ???????!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the ?? in ? got rendaku'd from ??, as well.

context-en: I go to work by bike.
context-en2: I'll buy you a new bicycle, no strings attached.
context-en3: "I’m sorry. I thought for sure you were the one who broke my bike." "What? That’s awful. You know me better than that."
meaning-exp: A self revolving car. You'd think this would be a regular car, but bicycles were probably introduced before cars were, meaning the self revolving car is the bicycle, not the car. Just imagine yourself on a bike, and you don't even have to move the pedals. They revolve themselves, but now you're going too fast and it's scary.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: He’s from Chiba.
context-en2: My mom loves peanuts made in Chiba.
context-en3: It usually takes an hour and a half to two hours for a one way trip from here to Chiba.
meaning-exp: There is only one place in Japan that has a thousand leaves and that's Chiba. Picture all of those leaves swirling around you on your vacation to Chiba. Beautiful.
reading-exp: This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned kun'yomi for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: While you're admiring all of the leaves in Chiba, you realize you're craving something. What goes well with watching leaves? Why, cheese (?) of course. Delicious Chiba cheese.

vocab-meaning: Close Friend, Best Friend, Good Friend
context-en: Well, I was objected to by a close friend.
context-en2: Koichi and Viet are good friends. They are more than friends, but not lovers.
context-en3: "Hey, you know what? Sara is going out with Beth." "What? I didn’t know that. I thought she was my best friend but she never told me about that."
meaning-exp: A friend who is like one of your parents is someone who will look out for you. They are like family, in fact! That's why this word means best friend or close friend. Just imagine someone who watches over you like a parent would. This is the way to describe them.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We collected money from everyone and bought a bunch of flowers and a message board.
context-en2: Don't worry about collecting money anymore. What will be, will be.
context-en3: I’ve got tons of work I have to catch up on. Anyway, maybe I should start collecting money from my clients.
meaning-exp: When you collect gold you are collecting money (or doing money collection). Of course, back in the day gold was like money, which is why this word works the way it does. Hopefully you don't have to deal with too much ?? in your daily life. We'll try to keep WaniKani nice and reasonably priced for you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We were too concentrated on the meeting and we missed the last train.
context-en2: Concentrate! Focus! Give it your all!
context-en3: Hey! Stop breathing down my neck. I can’t concentrate.
meaning-exp: When you collect to the middle of yourself, you are collecting towards your brain. All energy is going towards there, massing up in the middle, giving you extreme concentration abilities. Just imagine a light in the middle of your brain, so concentrated that you're able to concentrate, shooting a little laser out of your forehead onto the thing you're concentrating on.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’ll keep doing my best!
context-en2: How's Tofugu doing lately?
context-en3: I hate that guy because he only says things that flatter the listener.
meaning-exp: Imagine yourself investigating a child. You heard this child was having a rough time, so you need to come check on the condition of his home and life. You find the condition to be terrible, and you tell the parents you have to take the child away because of these conditions (imagine them being ridiculously bad... perhaps they raise raccoons in their kitchen?).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This dress gives me beautiful curves.
context-en2: The curve of Koichi's butt protruding from the speedo is very... nice!
context-en3: I really love the soft, slanted curve of your cheek when you get mad.
meaning-exp: A bend in a line is merely a curve.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Laborers demanded higher wages.
context-en2: The company's demands were feudalistic and disgust me.
context-en3: These requirements are absurd!
meaning-exp: You need this request to happen, so you don't just request it, you demand it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The development team will answer everyone’s questions.
context-en2: Please tell us about the story behind Tofugu's development.
context-en3: Koichi pulled an all-nighter to develop a new Japanese learning site.
meaning-exp: You are now open for departure. You get on your boat and leave this place. You are going to another place to start its development where you will create a new world.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I suffer from Ménière’s disease, so I often get dizzy.
context-en2: The reason I haven't been able to get further than Level 1 on WaniKani must be because I have "can't-learn-foreign-language" syndrome.
context-en3: Don’t make a big deal out of what he said. It’s definitely a lie that he’s suffering from an incurable disease.
meaning-exp: As you can probably imagine, when you add the kanji sick to another word, you're saying what kind of sickness it is; you are mentioning what disease it is.
reading-exp: Since this is attached to other words, it's treated like jukugo and gets on'yomi treatment. This is the reading you learned with the kanji.

context-en: According to the Tokyu Corporation, the Tokyu Toyoko line has currently suspended operations due to an accident involving personal injury.
context-en2: My dream is to work for an electric railroad company.
context-en3: "Here you are, dear. Some of those Hankyu Railway pictures you like." "Oh wow, I absolutely love the Hankyu Railway!"
meaning-exp: The electricity iron sounds scary, but if you think to back in the day and to where iron was used a lot, you probably think of the railway systems... big hunky pieces of iron on the ground to make the railway. So, you can advance this by adding electricity instead of coal, creating an electric railway.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'd like to emphasize that Tofugu articles are super high quality, interesting, and helpful.
context-en2: Highlighting important words with a highlighter helps you memorize them.
context-en3: I’d just like to stress again that dressing neatly and being polite are very important for this job.
meaning-exp: If you use a strong tone on certain words, then you are putting emphasis on whatever it is you're talking about it. It's the stress you put on things that are important because your tone gets stronger on those words or syllables.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The first day of the Osaka performance has ended!
context-en2: The main character died and the game was over.
context-en3: "What if I got fat again? " "Well, our relationship wouldn’t end, that’s for sure."
meaning-exp: It's the end. It's the finish. This word means end. Or finish! How convenient.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m glad I’m able to recognize how much I progress every day.
context-en2: Thanks to you all, Tofugu made such tremendous progress.
context-en3: Jeez, you’re really dumb. Darwin’s theory of evolution is not the title of a Disney movie.
meaning-exp: Think of things that advance and change. Does this sound familiar? Does this sound like evolution?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Taeko still looked like a kid back then.
context-en2: That miniature Husky has such a gallant facial expression.
context-en3: Boy, have you ever grown up, young man. You are the spitting image of your father.
meaning-exp: The thing that is attached to your face isn't a big booger or anything like that. It's something that's always there. It's your expression.
reading-exp: The readings are both kun'yomi, but they're the readings you've already learned when you learned the kanji.

context-en: My eye started hurting yesterday, I went to the eye doctor, and it was a sty.
context-en2: I'm looking for an eye doctor who is open on weekends.
context-en3: Listen, Mr. Eye Doctor. The cat's out of the bag, so there's no need to pretend you don’t know anything about eyes.
meaning-exp: Do you remember ?? (doctor)? What happens when you add eye on there? You have yourself an eye doctor.
reading-exp: The reading is just the vocab word ?? (???) plus the reading ? (?), the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

context-en: I already forgot the face of the travel agent I met yesterday.
context-en2: Koichi has very defined facial features, don't you think?
context-en3: "Hey, buddy. Are you picking a fight with me? Why are you staring at me like that?" "Well, your face looks really pale. Are you okay?"
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is kun'yomi, since it's a kanji all alone with nothing attached. Luckily, that's also the reading you've already learned, so associate that with this vocab word.

context-en: I went to a farm on Sunday to experience the wheat harvest.
context-en2: I was asked if I'd like to keep working at the farm.
context-en3: I’m planning to start an organic farm.
meaning-exp: The place you do your farming is a farm!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The shinkansen is faster than a normal train.
context-en2: We had a competition to see who could swim from Portland to Tokyo the fastest.
context-en3: In my family, we eat dinner really fast.
meaning-exp: Just like the meaning of the kanji (fast) this adjective also means fast.
reading-exp: Remember how ?? means "early"? If you are early to something, it probably means you moved fast to get there. These two words share a reading (and have similar meanings, in a way, as well!).

context-en: The first thing that comes to mind after finishing this wonderful breakfast is that bacon is delicious, as we all know.
context-en2: Please write down the name of the person you like in the first column.
context-en3: "The first thing I do every morning is run five kilometers." "Big deal! I run ten!"
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? (number one), so what in the world is this eye on the end? This eye (?) signifies the order. So, add this to "number one" and you have the first thing / the first.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is just the vocab word ?? plus the word ?. If you know both of those readings you'll be able to read this one as well.
kanji-name: One, Number In A Series, Eye

context-en: Many Japanese words are used as loanwords in modern day Chinese.
context-en2: Is rucksack a foreign word, or Engrish?
context-en3: Hey, did you know that there's kanji for the word tobacco even though it’s a loanword?
meaning-exp: You know the word ?? to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for language and you have an imported word, aka a borrowed word. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a ???, in fact.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My daughter can speak both French and English.
context-en2: In many African countries, both English and French are used as their official languages.
context-en3: Learning French is too difficult! I can’t take it anymore. Give me a break!
meaning-exp: I bet you can guess that ???? means "France." So what happens when you add language to it? You get the "France Language" aka the French Language.
reading-exp: The reading is just the on'yomi reading for ? which is the reading you learned with the kanji. This is probably because it gets added onto a lot of other words so it's treated like a jukugo. For example: ??? = "Japanese Language." ??? = "Chinese Language." ????? = "Spanish Language."

context-en: It's that time of year again when the leaves make my eyes burn.
context-en2: There are a lot of bugs on the young leaves in our garden!
context-en3: Your head smells a little weird. It’s like dried up leaves or something.
meaning-exp: So there's this weird thing with Japanese people. Many things that most people would consider "green" are actually "blue" in their eyes. So, things like plants and street lights are "blue" even though you may think of them as green. Remember that for this word, where we talk about a blue leaf. In your head, though, think "green leaf." Now think of all things that have green leaves. This is greenery.
reading-exp: The readings for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi readings. Since you've already seen the word ?, hopefully you can just combine it with ? (you learned the reading for this part with the kanji). Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku, though. ? goes to ? in this word, making it ???.

context-en: I graduated from grad school, but I can’t find a job.
context-en2: You can only buy cold drinks from the vending machines at this grad school.
context-en3: I’m thinking about going to graduate school.
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ?? means "college?" Well the institution you go to after college is graduate school!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I’ll wash your head.
context-en2: Taking a nap usually refreshes my mind.
context-en3: I have a headache so please stop talking.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji earlier. No problem!

context-en: We will explain the job offer later.
context-en2: Nowadays, almost all companies use the Internet for recruiting.
context-en3: I’m calling regarding the position advertised in the Tofugu blog. I’d like to apply for the programmer position, but is Mr. Viet still alive? I sent an assassin after him this morning.
meaning-exp: When you're requesting people you're seeking workers. "Help wanted!" is what this word is basically saying.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It takes about a thousand yen to get to the hospital by taxi.
context-en2: The head of this hospital can't even do his multiplication tables.
context-en3: I hate being a doctor in this hospital. The patients are all idiots.
meaning-exp: A sick institution is a place where sick people go. That is a hospital.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Hospitalization, Hospitalisation, Hospital Admission, Admission To A Hospital, Institutionalized
context-en: His condition deteriorated and they decided he's to be hospitalized.
context-en2: While I was hospitalized, I was so bored that I couldn't stop yawning.
context-en3: I'm going to be hospitalized due to breast cancer soon.
meaning-exp: If you end up in a situation where you have to enter an institution it's called hospitalization. Hopefully you aren't there for very long.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Japan has an advanced industry.
context-en2: The industrial designer, Mr. Nakayama, uses WaniKani for stress relief.
context-en3: "How is your industrial technology project going? " "So far, so good."
meaning-exp: The business of industry is... well... industry.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I've only told this to close friends.
context-en2: They say, "A hedge between keeps friendship green," right? We're good friends, but don't peek at me when I'm on the toilet.
context-en3: Oh Koichi. Calm down. I’ll ask my close friends if anyone can lend you the 80 cents.
meaning-exp: Your parents are very close to you, most likely. They are your closest relatives. They are the ones who are intimate and friendly with your affairs. They want to know everything!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Those who are most intimate with you hang out with you even when you're doing gross things, like sitting on the sh*tter (??). Gross, your family is.

context-en: Okay? Not English, Japanese.
context-en2: If you subscribe to WaniKani right now, it will come with Tofugu's autograph in Japanese.
context-en3: Don’t be afraid of making mistakes. Speak in Japanese. Give it a shot. I think you can do it.
meaning-exp: You know ?? is "Japan." So, when you add language onto the end of that you have Japanese language.
reading-exp: The reading is just the vocab word ?? (???) plus the reading that you learned for ?. Combine them together to get the reading for this word.

vocab-meaning: Japanese Style Alcohol, Japanese Alcohol, Sake
context-en: I don’t really like Japanese alcohol.
context-en2: Could you remove the price tag from the Japanese sake bottle for me?
context-en3: "What are you drinking?" "Japanese rice wine. Would you like a sip?" "Well, I suppose I’ll give it a try."
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "Japan" so when you add alcohol onto the end of that you have Japanese Style Alcohol (what's the big Japanese style alcohol that everyone knows? That's sake).
reading-exp: The reading is just the vocab ??'s reading plus the reading you learned for ?, put together.

context-en: I’m bad at writing kanji.
context-en2: The kanji for my name includes the meaning, "you may live in Wisconsin."
context-en3: "Here is a gift for your birthday." "Wow! A Kanji textbook! Thank you so much. You really made my day."
meaning-exp: The Chinese letters... you're finally learning the word for them, the thing you've been studying this whole time for so long! This is kanji, your new best friend (they came from China, which is why they're Chinese letters).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Thank you for always being kind.
context-en2: I've never seen a company as kind as Tofugu.
context-en3: Wow. Oh my, it’s so creamy. Oh my gosh, this is the best cheesecake I have ever had. You are awfully kind to give me the last piece. Don’t you think? Thank you. Thank you.
meaning-exp: When your parents cut you you'd think they are being mean... but they're not. They are bleeding all the bad blood out of you. They are truly being kind. Just think of how crazy it would be for your parents to cut you... then think about some kind of twist to make it so they are being kind instead.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My mother is cooking in the kitchen.
context-en2: I heard that in Michael's kitchen, there are 3,008,917 empty natto boxes.
context-en3: I smell something burning in the kitchen.
meaning-exp: What place in your house has most of the machines in it? Your kitchen! Just think about it. Refrigerator, freezer, dishwasher, stove, microwave, WOW! That's so many. The kitchen definitely has the most machines.
reading-exp: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ?. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

vocab-meaning: Laboratory, Lab, Study Room, Professor's Office, Teacher's Office
context-en: When I was a child, my dream was to work at a laboratory.
context-en2: Excuse me for repeating myself, but talking about Mr.Yamada's wig is a big no no in this study room, okay?
context-en3: I’d like everyone to move into the laboratory now so that we can start dissecting the frogs.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means “research?” Well the room where you do research is a laboratory!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What are the popular programming languages right now?
context-en2: I joined an offline gathering where language geeks got together and talk about language all night long.
context-en3: I started to study a new computer language.
meaning-exp: When you say words in a language, you are speaking a language. Not sure what that language is, but since you're saying it it must be real.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Last, Final, The Last, The Final
context-en: I missed the last part of my favorite drama and cried.
context-en2: The train we just took was the last one of the day, so we can't go back anymore.
context-en3: This is our final offer. Now the ball is in your court.
meaning-exp: The most end thing is the last thing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Last, The Last, End, Conclusion, Final
context-en: This is the last time I give you money.
context-en2: My wife always ends up with one word too many.
context-en3: At any rate, just listen until the end. Then you’ll understand.
meaning-exp: The thing that is the most after everything else is at the very end. It is the last.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I often fall asleep on the train and have to be woken up by the driver at the last stop.
context-en2: What's the name of the last stop on the Amtrak leaving from Chicago?
context-en3: You have to do me a favor. No matter what I say, no matter what I do, please do not let me get out of the train until it gets to the last stop. Okay?
meaning-exp: The end point is where everything ends... but for this example, think of a map with a route on it. The last spot on the route is the "last point." It is the last stop.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Yesterday, the wind was so strong that all the leaves fell off of the trees.
context-en2: In fall, the leaves on the trees had changed to different colors.
context-en3: I made furikake with daikon leaves.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: This box is lighter than that one.
context-en2: This pair of tweezers is surprisingly light.
context-en3: Every day I eat a light breakfast.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of lightweight? It's also lightweight.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the reading you'll be using here. Because of that, this word is kind of a lightweight.

context-en: The line in the middle of a fraction is called the "vinculum."
context-en2: Please get on the Yamanote Line at Shibuya.
context-en3: You really thought this line was perfect? It’s not even close to straight!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This also works for "train lines" as well. You'll see this attached onto the ends of names describing them.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same for this vocab word. Enjoy it!

vocab-meaning: Looking Forward To, Hope, Expectation, Anticipation, Pleasure, Enjoyment
context-en: I’m looking forward to seeing you.
context-en2: I think there are lots of different fun activities during summer break, like going to beach and camping and stuff.
context-en3: We are all looking forward to burning turtles, aren’t we?
meaning-exp: You've seen the word ???, which means "fun." This is obviously very similar looking, though this one means looking forward to. Why? Because it has a ? on the end, saying "who is going to have fun? It's me! That's why I'm looking forward to it!"
reading-exp: The reading is just like ???, so make sure you know that and you'll be able to read this one as well.

context-en: I’ve been really lucky lately for some reason.
context-en2: You are so lucky to have such a beautiful wife.
context-en3: I got an A in Japanese, but I think I was just lucky.
meaning-exp: The ?? portion means "good." So, when what you carry is good you are lucky. Just think of it in terms of luck being a physical item you carry in your hands. Now imagine yourself carrying it. Now think to yourself "what I'm carrying is good, it's lucky!"
reading-exp: The reading for the kanji in this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this.

vocab-meaning: Made For, Intended For, Aimed At
context-en: This work isn’t intended for children.
context-en2: This curry was made for Japanese tastes.
context-en3: Aren’t the underpants Koichi is wearing for children? He’s outgrown his clothes.
meaning-exp: You've hopefully seen ?? and ??? by now. They mean "to face" and "to turn toward." This has a similar idea. When you add ?? to something imagine you're turning it, aiming it at someone. It's aimed at them, meaning it's made for them. Turn a book toward someone, now it's aimed at them, it's made for them. See the connection?
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the word ?? so work off of that word to be able to read this one.

context-en: Are the neighbors quiet?
context-en2: Many chic shops are gathering in the neighborhood of the Tofugu office.
context-en3: There is a laundromat in the neighborhood.
meaning-exp: The place you live near is your neighborhood!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you remember the rendaku on ?? making it ??.

context-en: My father reads the newspaper every morning.
context-en2: Tofugu and Domo-kun were collaborating on the front page of the local newspaper this morning.
context-en3: This newspaper is so highbrow. No wonder Scott had to read it so many times.
meaning-exp: The new hear is what it sounds like. It's new things that you're hearing about in your ear... at least that's what it was back a long time ago. Now those new things that get to your ear get to you via other mediums. In this case, a newspaper.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please take a numbered ticket and wait your turn.
context-en2: Excuse me, wasn't there a number tag left around here?
context-en3: Here is the numbered tag for your luggage.
meaning-exp: You know ?? means "number" so add a tag to it and you have a numbered tag.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word (??) with a single-word kanji added. That means you have two on'yomi readings from the jukugo word and the kun'yomi reading from the single kanji (??). Put them all together and you have the reading of this kanji!
kanji-name: Number In A Series, Number, Bill

vocab-meaning: Opening A Business, Opening Of Business, Starting A Business
context-en: We also had a ton of debt when we opened our business.
context-en2: As of this year, this eye doctor has been in practice for 35 years.
context-en3: I blew off school yesterday to help Koichi prepare for the opening of his business.
meaning-exp: This is one of those words that has kanji that basically tell you the meaning. You open a business... aka opening a business.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When will the video be released to the public?
context-en2: A documentary movie of half of Koichi's life has been open to the public to commemorate Etoeto's release.
context-en3: "I only published that picture to show people that you look much better in person, Hanako." "That is such a lie!"
meaning-exp: When something is public open it is open to the public. You can go look at things that are ??.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My parents moved near the hospital last week.
context-en2: I think my parents are overprotective.
context-en3: This is so unfair! Midori gets everything that I want. And, on top of that, she doesn’t have my mom and dad for parents.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Just imagine your parents saying oh yah (??) over and over at you. What did you do at school today? I beat up this kid. "Oh yah?"

context-en: It looks like the highway is closed because of the heavy snow.
context-en2: So many roads are under construction in Minnesota during the summer.
context-en3: This town is really dull. There are basically only paved roads and houses. Ugh! Where can I get some action?
meaning-exp: A road road is obviously the best kind of road. It's double road, after all. So, what is this ultimate road? It is a paved road.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That doesn't mean all peasants in the Edo period were poor.
context-en2: Farmers in this village want to know how to swim the forward crawl.
context-en3: Wow! That farmer has some amazing abs.
meaning-exp: The peoples who work in the farm are the farmers... the peasants.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "???" are the phonetic kanji used for "liqueur."
context-en2: Lately, there've been a lot of kids with bizarre names using phonetic kanji.
context-en3: Sometimes kanji are selected solely for their sounds and the meaning is ignored as in ???? (????). These are called phonetic kanji.
meaning-exp: ?? means something like to guess correctly. ? means letter. So, this is a letter you guessed correctly. This refers to phonetic kanji, which are kanji that are used in words simply for their sounds, not for their meanings. They are there to be phonetic, and that is all. That is why this word refers to phonetic kanji.
reading-exp: The readings are the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ??. You've seen ??? in the past, though, so you should be able to read this portion as well. Combine the two together and you have yourself a nice reading.

vocab-meaning: Private College, Private University, Private Uni
context-en: Private college tuition sure is expensive.
context-en2: I'm teaching English at a private uni in Osaka.
context-en3: As for the school festival at the private university you told me about the other day, could you count me out this time? I’m sorry, don’t get mad at me. I’ll contact you when I have free time.
meaning-exp: You know how ? can mean private and how ? is the first half of ??? Well, combine those together and you have the shortened version of private college or private university.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Private railways in Tokyo are too complicated to understand.
context-en2: When you arrive at Shinjuku Station by JR, please transfer to a private railway.
context-en3: I work for one of the major private railway companies in Japan.
meaning-exp: A private iron (remember how ? often has to do with railroad tracks and the like? Same goes here) is a private railway. There are a good number of these in Japan.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Railroad Track, Train Track, Railway Track, Track, Line
context-en: It seems that the earth beside the train track collapsed from the heavy rain and covered the tracks.
context-en2: The train has stopped since somebody trespassed on the train tracks.
context-en3: "Well, sorry. I’m not really in that kind of mood right now." "Honey, what’s going on? " "Well, I just saw a guy commit suicide on the railroad track over there."
meaning-exp: A line that runs on a road is a railroad track. First you have to get into your mind that the "line" in question is a railway line. Then, what railway line runs on a road and what kind of road is it? It's a railroad track.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can’t read sheet music.
context-en2: How do you read this word in the 7th line of the 3rd paragraph?
context-en3: How do you pronounce the kanji in your name?
meaning-exp: You know that this has something to do with reading and you know that ? means way or method. So, when you think of a "way of reading" you can think of a couple other better words, such as reading (aka the reading of a word) or pronunciation. Anytime you need to know how something sounds, this is what you'll ask for.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're the readings you've learned with the kanji. ? is like many other words you've come across as well, such as ?? or ???.

context-en: How many books has she read recently?
context-en2: I can't follow the latest fashion trends anymore.
context-en3: The term "Gozaru" doesn’t seem to be used as much lately.
meaning-exp: The most nearby is something that happened close to now. It happened recently.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Research Institute, Research Laboratory, Research Establishment, Research Lab, Research Facility
context-en: I heard that a certain American lab has made a pill that will make you fluent in Japanese.
context-en2: There is an emergency drill in the Miso Soup Research Facility today.
context-en3: I work for the Burger King Research Institute. My job consists of eating french fries and then having my body weighed.
meaning-exp: You've seen that ?? is research from previous vocab. So, a "place" that is a research place could be many things, though mainly a research institute or research laboratory.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know the reading of ?? already. Also note that ? is normal for one reading, but also gets the rendaku treatment, meaning ?? becomes ??, for the secondary reading.

context-en: My pet hamster is vigorously rotating his hamster wheel.
context-en2: Have you been to the conveyer belt sushi restaurant over there? Apparently their sushi chefs hate plates there, so the sushi is directly on the rotating, hot conveyor belt.
context-en3: The moon revolves around the earth and the earth revolves around the sun.
meaning-exp: You revolve X number of times. Really, the times isn't so important, but the revolving is. That's why this word is revolve or rotate.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. P.S. Ever heard of "?????"
