That's the kind of sushi that's on conveyer belts, rotating around and around, bringing you delicious plates of things.

context-en: I drank alcohol at the party.
context-en2: That sake is out of season now, so I'm afraid it's not available.
context-en3: "Let’s split the bill." "No, it’s on me this time. I drank a lot of alcohol, but you didn’t drink anything"
meaning-exp: This is just the noun version of the kanji ? - it has an ? there to be nice. This word can mean both alcohol (same like the parent kanji) or sake (the main kind of Japanese alcohol, at least back in the kanji days).
reading-exp: The reading is kun'yomi, which isn't what you learned with the kanji. But, it should be pretty easy. You know what Japanese alcohol is called already, right? It's ??, simple as that. So long as you've heard of sake you should be A-Okay with this reading.

context-en: Tracing a good picture is a shortcut for improvement.
context-en2: Do you really think memorizing kanji on WaniKani is actually a shortcut to Japanese acquisition?
context-en3: "Oh my God! You are such an airhead! Why are we going down a one-way street?" "I thought it would be a shortcut!"
meaning-exp: Taking the nearby road will get you to your destination more quickly (because it's more close by!). This is a shortcut, aka the short way.
reading-exp: The reading is a bit weird in this one. Its kun'yomi reading for both kanji, even though it looks just like it should be all on'yomi reading. It's like you're taking a shortcut with your kanji readings and doing the native Japanese readings (kun'yomi) instead of the more intellectual Chinese ones (on'yomi). Luckily, you've hopefully seen both of these kanji as vocab already. You have ?? for ? (short for ??) and you have ? (??), just like the word "street" you learned before. Combine these together and you have the reading for this word. Perhaps it's like this because you're combining a couple concepts together into one word, at least when it comes to "short + way."

context-en: My mother’s illness still hasn’t improved.
context-en2: I got a disease that makes me fart all the time, so I've haven't been able to go outside.
context-en3: "Can you fix my mom’s illness, doctor?" "I’ll give it a try, but don’t count on it."
meaning-exp: When your energy is that of sickness, you are probably sick.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you don’t want to catch something, you shouldn’t go near sick people.
context-en2: The fortuneteller told me that my previous life was as a sick person.
context-en3: "How’s it going?" "Couldn’t be better." "Good. I’m surprised to hear that from a sick person though."
meaning-exp: A person who is sick is a sick person. They are also a patient, at least we can hope they are, for their sake.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that this uses the ?? reading for ?. This is because every sick person enjoys laying in bed playing nintendo.

context-en: There is a diner next to the cafe.
context-en2: If a robber breaks into the Tofugu office, just run to Koichi's desk and crouch down next to it because it's the safest spot.
context-en3: During my afternoon nap I sleep on my side.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Please note that this word refers to "the side of something." Not "the right side," for example. That would be ??.
reading-exp: The reading for this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, lucky you!

context-en: My mother had a large influence in my becoming a singer.
context-en2: That singer got quite a tan, didn't she?
context-en3: I used to be a singer when I was kid. Well, who am I kidding, I’m still a singer now.
meaning-exp: Remember how ? can sometimes refer to a person? In this case, we have a song person (or perhaps a "person who handles songs"). What is a song person also known as? A singer.
reading-exp: The readings are on'yomi readings. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this like a singer sings with a bunch of cashews ??? in their mouth. FAST AND LOUD!

context-en: But I don’t know Japanese songs very well.
context-en2: It feels like this isn't just a song, but a secret code too.
context-en3: "Jason! You made a song for Amanda?" "Ah, this isn’t what it looks like." "Come on! Don’t give me that."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about a song... but not just any song... think about the utter (??) song, and make it up right now and sing it out loud. What does the utter song sound like? Why do you love utterances so much that you made a song about them?

context-en: There’s a Spanish quiz tomorrow!
context-en2: That Spanish textbook is currently sold out, so it's not available.
context-en3: Garlic in Spanish is "ajo," which is pronounced "aho." "Aho" means "stupid" in Japanese.
meaning-exp: You can probably figure out that ???? is "Spain" just by reading it. Add the kanji language on there and you have the Spanish language (or just Spanish), if you'd like.
reading-exp: The reading for the kanji portion is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Since it's attached to something, it's like a jukugo word.

context-en: The internet speeds are too slow and it’s pissing me off.
context-en2: Please drive a little bit slower.
context-en3: When I opened the door, a wintry gust rushed in with great speed and force.
meaning-exp: The degree of fastness is a measurement of speed, plain and simple.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Stand And Drink, Drink While Standing, Drinking While Standing
context-en: In summer you can stand and drink on the terrace.
context-en2: There are a lot of stand-and-drink bars near Shinbashi Station in Tokyo.
context-en3: Did you get any action last night after leaving the standing bar?
meaning-exp: The meaning is the same as the kanji. When you stand and drink, you're probably at a stand and drink place.
reading-exp: The readings are from the words ?? and ?? put together.

context-en: This game will be released tomorrow.
context-en2: We've started accepting preorders for EtoEto.
context-en3: Tofugu is currently still working to catch up in the pillow market, so they started selling new models.
meaning-exp: The open of the start is the start or beginning.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: And then you will listen to the story and choose the best answer between 1-4 on the answer sheet.
context-en2: I didn't sign up for this!
context-en3: "Now, I’d also like to say something else, Brittany!" "Jeremy! Give it a rest! I’m tired of listening to you."
meaning-exp: The kanji version of ? means talk. This word also means talk, but it means a few other things as well. This can refer to a speech or story as well. Basically anything that involves a talking session. So, before you go, I hope you stay awhile and listen to my ?.
reading-exp: Who tells a great story? Hana, she (???) tells a great story! If you know someone named Hana or Hanna you can use that person to help you to remember this one better too. You can also use ??'s reading to help you to remember this one, as well.

vocab-meaning: Strong Man, Badass, Iron Man, Macho Man, Tough Guy
context-en: My company president is way too much of a macho man.
context-en2: The TV program I like most is Iron Chef.
context-en3: I saw a tough guy playing peak-a-boo with a baby in a grocery store.
meaning-exp: A man made of iron is a strong man... aka a huge badass. Have you seen "Iron Chef?" The Japanese translation is ?????, which means "Chef Iron Man" aka "Chef Badass," at least in my book.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Can you make the subject clear?
context-en2: This new service that clarifies the subject is very useful.
context-en3: Japanese is a subject-object-verb language whereas English is a subject-verb-object language.
meaning-exp: The main thing you talk about in your language becomes the subject of the sentence.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Of course I can do subtraction!
context-en2: Subtraction class is so long that I can't stop yawning.
context-en3: What year of grade school will we learn subtraction?
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means "to subtract?" Add calculate to that and you'll have subtraction! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you subtract.
reading-exp: This is the kun'yomi reading for ? and the on'yomi for ?. And the ?? reading is rendaku'd into ??. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

vocab-meaning: Subway, The Underground, The Metro, The Tube
context-en: I’ll go on the subway.
context-en2: Tokyo's subway is extremely complex.
context-en3: What a relief! I thought I missed the subway train.
meaning-exp: The iron below ground isn't a deposit of iron. It's man made. And what is made of iron? Trains and subways. In this case, because it's underground, it's definitely a subway, though.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: The Best, Best, Supreme, The Most, Most
context-en: Beer when work ends is the best.
context-en2: I'm enjoying the best moment, looking at the night view of Tokyo Bay.
context-en3: "Wow, you made the best chocolate cake. But, what’s gotten into you? You’ve never baked before." "Nothing, I just wanted to do something new."
meaning-exp: The most tall isn't literally the most tall. When you think of something high above the rest, you think of something that is the best.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The summer solstice is the shortest night of the year.
context-en2: Mt. Fuji is the tallest mountain in Japan.
context-en3: Do you know what he ate tonight? He went to an all you can eat yakiniku restaurant. We’d better prepare for the smelliest farts imaginable. Better safe than sorry.
meaning-exp: This is the adverb version of the kanji, so it has the same meaning, basically. You can say this is the most or just most. You can also use it as extremely.
reading-exp: The reading for this is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). To learn it, let's look at a mnemonic. Think of the most ridiculous motto (???) you've ever heard. Now imagine a motto that's even more ridiculous. Here are some actual totally real mottos that are the most ridiculous: "What Can Brown Do for You?" "It's Not for Women" "If It Doesn't Get All Over the Place, It Doesn't Belong in Your Face" and of course, "Why Not Enjoy the Go?"

context-en: I forgot to take my medicine this morning.
context-en2: My legs have been hurting since I woke up this morning, so I can't move as much as I'd like.
context-en3: This morning there was a multi-vehicle accident here.
meaning-exp: Now morning is just another way of saying this morning. It's the closest morning to right now!
reading-exp: This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it: This morning you want a quesadilla (??) for breakfast. You can't wait until tomorrow morning, you NEED it this morning! Imagine eating a delicious quesadilla first thing this morning. Mmm!

vocab-meaning: To Advance, To Go Forward, To Progress
context-en: Are you making any progress in your work?
context-en2: Tofugu always goes one step ahead, doesn't it?
context-en3: Your daughter is advancing faster than the other students.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means advance so the verb vocab version means to advance.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order to advance, you must sue Sue for her misdeeds against you. Imagine her standing in your way, literally. She keeps saying, "You'll have to sue me if you want to get past me!" So you do. You sue Sue.

vocab-meaning: To Be Decided, To Be Settled
context-en: Since I got the job, I’ve lost interest.
context-en2: Every morning Koichi is late for work because he hasn't decided on a hairstyle yet.
context-en3: "That’s a really good idea. Let’s do that." "Okay, then it’s been decided."
meaning-exp: You've seen the word ??? before, hopefully. This is similar, except for instead of doing the action of deciding, something has just been decided (by something or someone else). You are not the decision maker, here. That's why this word is to be decided.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???, so make sure you know that word so you can apply that knowledge over here.

vocab-meaning: To Begin, To Start, To Begin Something, To Start Something
context-en: I don’t know what to start from.
context-en2: Will your daughter start any extracurriculars when she reaches fourth grade?
context-en3: You need to mix all the ingredients together before you can start transferring the batter to the pans.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means start, so the verb version is to start something. This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You start something. Like studying! You should have started studying earlier though, huh?
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Right now it's time to begin Haj (??). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). You need to start Haj right now!

vocab-meaning: To Be Helped, To Be Saved, To Be Rescued
context-en: Is there still a chance it will be saved?
context-en2: I was rescued by the relationship advice that my teacher Koichi gave me.
context-en3: "So, are we going out or what? Make it clear!" "Um…" (The front doorbell rings: ring-ring.) "Phew, saved by the bell."
meaning-exp: You know that ??? means "to help" - so, this is a different version of that. This is when someone is helping someone else, or something is helping you, but you're not doing the action of helping someone. Use the ? to help you remember: The "car" helps you to drive around. That's why this word means to be helped. It also can be used to talk about how you were rescued, which is like being helped, right? If you want to memorize it that way, that's fine too.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???, so hopefully you know that word and can apply that knowledge over here.

vocab-meaning: To Be Sick, To Fall Ill, To Be Ill, To Come Down With, To Suffer From
context-en: Stress interviews make you feel really sick afterwards, don't you agree?
context-en2: My coworker got sick from work-related stress.
context-en3: I never thought that he would get mentally ill.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sick, so the verb version is to be sick. It can also be used as to come down with when you have the flu or some other illness.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There is only one time you allow yourself to be sick, and that's when the Yankees (?) are playing. You can't miss any games so you just happen to fall ill whenever they're playing so you can stay home and watch. That's pretty convenient, isn't it?

context-en: Tanuki and foxes are good at bewitching humans.
context-en2: My friend enchants men with makeup all the time.
context-en3: "I’m sorry I’m late. I was bewitched by a fox." "No worries. Things like that can’t be helped."
meaning-exp: You've seen the word ??? (to transform) before. Now we have a similar word. This word means to bewitch because when you cuss (??) you are saying a magic word and bewitching the person in front of you. Imagine yourself yelling out cuss words, and every time a new enchantment falls upon your victim.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???, so make sure you know that word and you'll be able to learn this word's reading as well.

context-en: Do you know the equation to calculate your income tax?
context-en2: We hired an AI that can calculate WaniKani user increases and decreases.
context-en3: This program calculates the advertising cost corresponding to the number of times a banner advertisement is selected by the user.
meaning-exp: When you calculate and determine (the calculation), you are determining the calculation. That's why this word is to calculate.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Carry, To Transport, To Move
speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Godan verb
context-en: Oh, and don’t forget to move the desk.
context-en2: My duty as a father is to put food on the table and have tea parties with my daughter.
context-en3: I want a bag to carry these textbooks.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carry so the verb version is to carry.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine you have to carry a hawk (??). Imagine carrying it in your hands, it trying to claw and peck itself free, but you don't let go. It is your job to carry this hawk with you everywhere.

vocab-meaning: To Chirp, To Bark, To Make An Animal Sound
context-en: The puppy is barking.
context-en2: The guy mimicking a rooster's cock-a-doodle-doo over there is our president.
context-en3: Let’s go to the new, chic Japanese restaurant tonight. Did you know that it has a few cute Japanese bush warblers singing with their beautiful voices?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chirp so the verb vocab version would be to chirp. Alternatively, this word can also be used for the sounds other animals make as well, though the primary definition has to do with birds chirping (it has bird right in the kanji, after all).
reading-exp: The reading is the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. So, spend more time chirping and less time memorizing, okay?

vocab-meaning: To Collect, To Gather, To Assemble
context-en: Please assemble the people wearing blue shirts.
context-en2: We've been gathering feedback from users.
context-en3: I am collecting pictures of foreign food.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means collect so the vocab verb version means to collect.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you only have one thing, there's only one thing. Nothing is collected. But when you have two... "ah two!" (??). Now you're starting to collect things.

vocab-meaning: To Distribute, To Pass Out, To Deliver
context-en: For Valentine’s Day we’ll distribute handmade sweets.
context-en2: I wonder how much I could earn from the newspaper delivering job.
context-en3: This party blows. Even passing out pocket tissues on the street would be better.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distribute so the verb vocab version is to distribute.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to distribute some fliers to everyone. On the fliers it talks about a striptease show where kublai (??) Khan does something naughty. Imagine this show, and imagine your shame of being the person handing out these fliers. How far the Khan has fallen.

context-en: I’m thirsty, so let’s drink something.
context-en2: Can you drink this tap-water?
context-en3: What would you like to drink? Gin, vodka, beer, wine, sake, or shochu? You name it, we’ve got it, but only if it’s alcohol.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drink so the vocab verb version is to drink.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go have a drink in the great Allicrab's name!

context-en: I really like driving around aimlessly when I’m on holiday.
context-en2: I never look back when I drive. I'm like a shark—only looking forward.
context-en3: This Fugu model car is amazing! I love it! I can’t wait to start driving it every day.
meaning-exp: A thing that carries rotations (think wheels!) is most kinds of vehicles. So, it's kind of like saying you're "doing vehicles" here... but that doesn't make sense. What do you do to vehicles though? You drive them. That's why this word means to drive.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When I finish school, I'll go shopping.
context-en2: My life was over when I lost it all gambling.
context-en3: Hey, man! Back off! I told you to stay away from me until the atomic bomb has finished being dismantled.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means end and so the verb version of this is to end (or to finish).
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It is time to end this. You are the debt collector and so you go to the ower (??) to collect what is due. Hey, it's time to end this fool! You are the ower!

vocab-meaning: To Enjoy, To Enjoy Oneself, To Have Fun
context-en: You can enjoy the beautiful ocean view from the window.
context-en2: We are having a lot of fun with this project.
context-en3: Snap out of it, Usagi. Forget Tuxedo Mask and enjoy your life!
meaning-exp: You've hopefully seen the word ???, which means "fun." Now you're going to figure out the verb version (ends in an ? sound, right?) of it. That would be to enjoy. Speaking of which, I hope you're enjoying WaniKani so far!
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the word ???, so be sure to know that word and you'll be able to apply it over here.

vocab-meaning: To Fall Down, To Drop, To Fall
context-en: Your eraser fell under the desk.
context-en2: On the day I failed the exam, I dropped my teeth from exhaustion.
context-en3: "What are you guys playing? Let me in!" "Really? We’re playing a game called Stair Fall where a stickman just keeps falling down the stairs." "Sounds fun!"
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fall so the vocab verb version means to fall.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you start to fall down, what do you yell? "OHHHH (?)!"

vocab-meaning: To Hear, To Ask, To Listen
context-en: We are going to listen to the text.
context-en2: Let's ask the teacher since we don't understand this Japanese.
context-en3: Listen to me, Amy. This is not your fault. He is not justified in sleeping with someone else just because you two had a fight.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hear so the vocab verb version is to hear.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to hear something very important, but you can't. In order to hear, you have to take a key (?) and unlock the doors covering your ears. Go ahead and imagine yourself doing that, focusing on the key.

vocab-meaning: To Investigate, To Examine, To Research, To Look Into, To Search
context-en: This afternoon, I looked up things about the war at the library.
context-en2: When the police investigated inside Koichi's car, a drunken blowfish came out.
context-en3: Can you research capybaras and see if they are edible?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means investigate so the vocab verb version means to investigate.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are hired to investigate someone's wife. It is said that she loves (??) another man... but you need to investigate her to find out if that's true, for her husband of course.

context-en: I’ve learned many different words since I came to Japan.
context-en2: My son is learning calligraphy.
context-en3: I’m going to learn how to make the world’s best fugu cookies today. Kids will love that, right?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means learn so the vocab verb version means to learn.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to learn about Nara, the city of deer... lots and lots of deer. If you don't know about it, how about learning about it?

vocab-meaning: To Meet By Chance, To Meet Unexpectedly, To Come Across, To Encounter, To Run Into
context-en: It looks like we happened to run into each other a little too early.
context-en2: Last night, I met a guy who's looking for no strings attached fun at a club and I know I shouldn't be into him, but he was really my type.
context-en3: "Are you seeing anyone now, Nicole?" "Yes, I’ve been seeing Eric for a year." "Wow, where did you guys meet?"
meaning-exp: You exit your house and you meet someone. You didn’t mean to meet them, but it happened anyway. That’s why this word means to meet by chance.
reading-exp: The reading is that of the word ?? and the word ??, both of which you've hopefully seen. The ? portion may be confusing, but you can usually assume that if one part of the word is kun'yomi / vocab reading, the other part is too, which is why ? uses the vocab reading. Oh by the way, this word can be written like this too: ???. It’s not as common, but you may come across it every now and then, so it’s good to know!

vocab-meaning: Tone, Tone Of Voice, Verbal Expression
context-en: I don’t really like her because of her harsh tone.
context-en2: Koichi said, in a very stern voice, that luck is just part of his talents.
context-en3: She scolded me violently in a severe tone.
meaning-exp: When your mouth makes tones we call it your tone or tone of voice. They're different kinds of sounds you make with your mouth that make you sound happy, sad, mean, etc.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet. Remember when you learned the vocabulary word ?? Just take the ? off and you get its other on'yomi reading ?. That's easy, right?

context-en: Please open your Japanese dictionary.
context-en2: My boyfriend always opens the car door for me when I get in.
context-en3: "Can you open this bottle of wine for me?" "Of course. Piece of cake."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means open so the verb vocab version is to open.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to open the door. When you do, a huge scream comes out: "AAAHHH!" (?). Imagine giant ? characters flying out of the door you opened as well.

context-en: Please read the following text and answer the questions.
context-en2: I secretly read the hush-hush diary that is exchanged between Viet and Koichi.
context-en3: Did you read the note your boyfriend left you about your trip? It says that you should bring two or three umbrellas with you.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means read so the verb vocab version is to read.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go read something else, now.

vocab-meaning: To Roll, To Tumble, To Lie Down, To Be Scattered About
context-en: Your cell phone was left somewhere around here.
context-en2: Darin discovered the dead body of a blowfish, lying in front of the Tofugu office.
context-en3: A rolling stone? Do you mean the English rock band The Rolling Stones?
meaning-exp: You know that the kanji here means revolve. The verb version of this is similar. It means to roll or to tumble. When something is doing these things it is revolving, right?
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine something rolling down a hill. Inside is a very important uranium core (??) that you need to keep spinning. That's why they have it rolling down hill after hill, because they don't have anything else to keep it spinning like that, preventing it from exploding. This core is very important!

vocab-meaning: To Talk, To Tell, To Recite
context-en: What do you plan to talk about at the next seminar?
context-en2: Mr. Tanaka, time is up, so please wrap up your adventure tale.
context-en3: I can’t talk about this case with people.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means language, so when you do language you're going to talk.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Sometimes when you're trying to talk, there will be that one person who always cuts you off to tell everyone what they want to say. We call them language cutters (??). They cut you off and make everyone pay attention to what they're saying. Don't be a language cutter.

vocab-meaning: To Throw Against, To Throw At
context-en: My daughter threw a vase at my head and gave me a serious injury that needed seven stitches.
context-en2: On the Setsubun, we threw dried beans at Koichi and chased the evil spirits away.
context-en3: "Salmon, I’m mad about you." "Fugu, I’m actually mad at you! Why did you throw garlic at me? "S..sorry I’ve heard that salmon like the smell of garlic."
meaning-exp: You know that you're throwing something that is attaching to something else. How else can you say that? The best way would be to say to throw against or to throw at.
reading-exp: The readings just come from two vocab words you've hopefully seen already: ??? and ???. So long as you know the readings for those words, the reading for this word should be no problem for you.

context-en: My father gets up at six o’clock every morning.
context-en2: You're always up so early! It's still 4 o'clock, you know.
context-en3: I do 100 sit-ups every morning right after waking up to get rid of my three pack.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wake up so the verb vocab version is to wake up.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so tomorrow when you wake up you hopefully won't have to relearn this vocab's reading.

vocab-meaning: To Want, To Request, To Demand
context-en: Tofugu wants a person who has a poker face.
context-en2: Sometimes we get emails requesting refunds.
context-en3: Increasingly, Tofugu clients are demanding environmentally friendly Japanese learning products.
meaning-exp: What's the verb form of request? It's to request. It also is for when you want something (to want), because when you request something you probably want it.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is it that you want? You want a moat (??) around your home. Your neighbor's cats keep pooping on your lawn, but if you had a moat they wouldn't be able to get to your lawn in the first place, since cats hate water (and alligators). You request a moat!

vocab-meaning: Town Hall, Town Office, Public Office
context-en: Please get the certificate from the town hall.
context-en2: The town hall's wallpaper is peeling off the wall.
context-en3: I went to the town hall and submitted my change of address information.
meaning-exp: A service location is a place that people go when they're in need of a service. The best place for this is the town hall. Everyone goes to this one location to voice their complaints and in return their needs are serviced by the officials in the town hall.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. That's all you have to remember, though, because you've seen both of these readings before!

context-en: Could you forward that email to me?
context-en2: Japanese people who reside overseas often buy things from Japanese websites and have them forwarded to the foreign addresses.
context-en3: Could you please forward my mail to this address?
meaning-exp: So, you're sending something that revolves. It's a little transfer / transmission, going through the wires. Little messages that revolve around as they zip through the lines to get to their destination. Try to imagine this happening in slow motion, getting to the other end.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I spoke of my real intentions unintentionally.
context-en2: Koichi farted sooooo loudly that everybody reflexively covered their ears, but we should have covered our noses instead.
context-en3: I saw the delicious looking picture and involuntarily started drooling.
meaning-exp: This is the adverb version of the kanji think. You can't help but think, you do it unintentionally. So put this in front of things to say that you did them involuntarily.
reading-exp: The reading for this is the kun'yomi reading which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: I’m not making any progress in my work.
context-en2: Yesterday, I was working on making an operations handbook all day long.
context-en3: Do you understand that all manufacturing operations were shut down because of you?
meaning-exp: If you want to make a business successful you need to be prepared to do a lot of work.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Advanced Level, High Grade, Advanced Grade, High Level
context-en: I have trouble following the advanced level class.
context-en2: Koichiko seems to have been bullied by high level students.
context-en3: Some non-native speakers speak English at a native or advanced level, while others do not.
meaning-exp: When you are at an above rank, you are at an advanced level. This is referring to things like proficiency in Japanese, or things like that.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I thought that at least Tofugu would support me.
context-en2: Actually, Koichi was an enemy disguised as a friend.
context-en3: Who the heck are your allies?
meaning-exp: The flavor of this direction is one I'd like to follow and go in, along with you. You have a good flavor and you're going in a good direction. Will you be my ally? I'll be your supporter.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ?. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to read this word!

context-en: Sales gradually decreased.
context-en2: The DVD of the Hollywood movie in which a popular American actor played the main character has sold eight million copies in Japan alone.
context-en3: Sales have decreased rapidly because of that sexist advertisement.
meaning-exp: The selling that you've raised (??) is the amount sold or number of sales. Think of a graph going upward, where it's rising as you sell more things.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the one you learned with ??. The reading for ?? is the same as the reading for ???, a word you learned previously. If you know those two separate things, you should be able to combine them into one awesome vocab thing.

context-en: It feels like Viet kind of has bad-boy hair today, don't you think?
context-en2: Substandard potato chips were sold at half price, so I bought one and ate it. Then I got diarrhea.
context-en3: That delinquent girl’s grades suddenly dropped drastically and then she joined a gang.
meaning-exp: Something that's not good is bad. Alternatively, it can be substandard.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: We made a video to teach you the ABCs of how to use WaniKani.
context-en2: My father taught me the basics of the Japanese game "Shogi."
context-en3: I’m starting to study the basics of French.
meaning-exp: The first thing you walk through when you learn something new will always be the basics. You never start by running, you always have to start slow and work your way through the ABCs before you start to run.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Koichi looks like a battle-weary soldier today.
context-en2: Whether it's quiet or noisy, I still don't like conflict.
context-en3: On the way to McDonald’s he got in a bloody fight but that didn’t stop him from getting his Big Mac.
meaning-exp: Don't let this word confuse you. It may end in ?, but it's not an adjective, it's a noun. There are no rules in war, after all. This word describes what happens in war. Those things are battles, fights, and conflicts.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In a fierce battle, there's always a lot of collateral damage. One of the things that gets destroyed is your car. But you can't do anything about it, it's battle time! So you wave goodbye to your car saying, "Ta ta car (???)!" as you punch some jerk in the face.

context-en: Nobody wants to be killed, even on the battleground.
context-en2: The Tofugu office turned into a Yakuza battlefield because of Viet.
context-en3: Koichi is a dependable guy. He would never let us down even if we were on a battlefield.
meaning-exp: A war location is the battlefield. That's where the wars are fought, anyways.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Beforehand, In Advance, Previously, Ahead Of Time
context-en: I knew it would happen, so I prepared ahead of time.
context-en2: I checked in online a day before the flight so that I wouldn't miss it.
context-en3: Preparing the lesson in advance was worthwhile.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What did you do beforehand? You had a raw casual (????) encounter with a raw Cage, Nic Cage. You probably should have planned something better ahead of time.

vocab-meaning: Beginner Level, Elementary Level, Beginning Level
context-en: I'm moving to the intermediate level class from the beginner level class next week.
context-en2: EtoEto was divided into 3 levels: beginner level, intermediate level, and advanced level.
context-en3: My Japanese is still at an elementary level, but I’m working hard at it.
meaning-exp: The first rank of something is the beginner level. Compare this to ?? and ?? (vocab from this level) to get a fuller understanding.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The pitcher's life story was interesting.
context-en2: The stuff that was written in the writer's biography was very surprising.
context-en3: Well, I think I might feel like this because I was influenced by a biography I read recently.
meaning-exp: If you want to transmit the story of someone's life, you have to write down all of it in a biography.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Two of my favorite subjects are biology and biochemistry.
context-en2: Ms. Kawada's older brother is a scholar who specializes in biology.
context-en3: If you want to become a designer, you should also study biology.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means "living things?" Well when you study living things you're studying biology.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Bus Stop, Taxi Stand, Train Platform, Place For Boarding Vehicles
context-en: Where is the gondola terminal?
context-en2: I'm waiting for a taxi in the airport taxi stand right now.
context-en3: At the moment, I’m chilling at the bus stop in front of my house looking at cars passing by.
meaning-exp: You've seen the word ?? by now, hopefully, and know it means "to ride." So this word has to do with a "riding location." Where do you go to get a ride somewhere? Most likely, it's a bus stop or taxi stand.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you've learned already. Also, use ?? to help you to remember the reading for ??.

context-en: Today, I got a warning from my boss.
context-en2: When you’re reading in Japanese, pay attention to interesting words and grammar.
context-en3: I’m worried that he’s going down the wrong path. I cautioned him, but he doesn’t listen to me.
meaning-exp: When you pour your ideas into something, you're thinking a lot about it. You're paying close attention and using caution. You'll see this on a lot of signs marking dangerous things in Japan, so be sure to pay attention to them!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Clothes, Western Clothing, Western Style Clothes
context-en: Thanks for lending me your clothes.
context-en2: I have trouble deciding which clothes to wear, Japanese-style or Western-style.
context-en3: You should get dressed really quickly or you’ll be late for school.
meaning-exp: Western style clothes is just Western clothing (or Western style clothes). But nowadays, because Japanese people wear Western clothing all the time, we use it to just mean clothes. We're talking things that aren't kimonos, etc.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I don't know what to talk about because Koichi and I have nothing in common.
context-en2: We discovered an amazing similarity between Tofu and Fugu.
context-en3: "I heard a rumor that Koichi likes older women." "Seriously? If that was true it would mean that he and I have something in common."
meaning-exp: We pass through this point together. This point is our common point. It is where our ideas, philosophies, and bodies pass through each other.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm in the middle of the exam week, so I have to wait to hang out with my companions until it's done.
context-en2: Me and my comrades are like brothers who are always together, fooling around, and picking on each other.
context-en3: Me and my group of friends relaxed after a hard day at school.
meaning-exp: Your relationship intervals... this doesn't make much sense at first, but if you think about it, at certain intervals from within your friends, you'll run into someone who's your companion... not just any old friend. Something better. Something part of your group.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the one you learned. The reading for ? (?) is one you didn't learn with the kanji. Think through all your companions in your life. Imagine one of them is your Ma (?). She's on your pirate crew, and a pretty awesome pirate.

context-en: Today's breakfast is the bread I got from the bread eating competition yesterday.
context-en2: I'm really not in the mood for a competition or anything right now.
context-en3: These guys really need to chill out. They're always competing with each other and they both hate losing.
meaning-exp: When you compete to the point of conflict, you know that this person / entity is your competition. Gotta beat out that competition. For example, in order to beat out the competition, WaniKani has a mascot that can eat every other small furry animal that the competition has for their mascot. Case closed.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This app is really handy, right?
context-en2: If you know some items that are convenient for parenting, please let me know.
context-en3: Life is getting more convenient day after day.
meaning-exp: When you profit from your convenience, that means you have something very convenient or handy. Remember, you can profit in other ways besides money. This convenience could be giving you a profit in happiness or extra time as well. All these things are very handy to have.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Apparently Tofugu and Nisshin are going to collaborate to make tofu and fugu flavored cup noodles.
context-en2: Tofugu produces golden Kim Jong Il dolls in cooperation with a North Korean firm.
context-en3: He secretly used up our joint savings.
meaning-exp: People working together on the same thing is cooperation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I saw Koichi walking with a different girl.
context-en2: This and that are two different stories.
context-en3: Aside from that case, it's usually okay to separate the sexes in this way.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

vocab-meaning: Different Person, Changed Person, Changed Man
context-en: Koichi is a changed man ever since he quit drinking.
context-en2: I thought it was my friend and said hi, but it was a completely different person.
context-en3: Koichi used to diss AKB48 pretty often, but now he's a crazed AKB48 fan. It’s as though he's a different person.
meaning-exp: A separate person is someone who is different from who they were before. I saw you a year ago and you were someone else. Now you're a different person, in a good way! You're a changed man.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The place we are going today is the education center.
context-en2: In Japan, education is mandatory through elementary and junior high school.
context-en3: Do you remember who said, "It is a thousand times better to have common sense without education than education without common sense?"
meaning-exp: Teach and nurture. That's what your education is supposed to do.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Entrance Exam, Entrance Examination, Admission Test, Admission Exam, Admission Examination, Entrance Test
context-en: My son flew back home smiling after finishing the entrance exam.
context-en2: What? The entrance examination fees are that expensive? I'm gonna go bankrupt!
context-en3: What! She’s failed the entrance exam?
meaning-exp: For school admission (??) you're taking an examination (??). What exams do you have to take to get into a school? How about entrance exams? The Japanese ones are pretty hard. Another word for them is "hell tests."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It'll also help if you know the two separate words that make up this longer word.

context-en: You have to be quiet, especially in the hospital.
context-en2: This melon is particularly hard. It's like a squash.
context-en3: "What would you like for supper?" "Anything is fine. I’m not especially picky."
meaning-exp: Something is towards (?) special. That thing is especially special, wouldn't you say?
reading-exp: The reading is the same reading you learned for this kanji.

context-en: Do you believe in destiny?
context-en2: I thought those two were tied together by the red thread of fate, but it seems that their hearts are growing ever distant.
context-en3: Rest in peace iPhone. I just dropped it in a toilet filled with more than just water. Maybe this was just fate but I am so sad right now.
meaning-exp: Everyone has to carry their fate. So what is the thing you're carrying? It's your fate.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I think it all depends on how you feel about it.
context-en2: A guy I met today told me I'm kinda bony, what's up with that?!
context-en3: He is a pleasant, honest kid.
meaning-exp: Your heart holds a lot of feelings. They can be overwhelming and sometimes it feels like there are none in there at all, but that doesn't mean they aren't there in your heart.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I know exactly how you feel.
context-en2: I feel sick, like I'm going to throw up.
context-en3: Here’s a little something for you. This is just a small token of my appreciation. Go ahead, open it.
meaning-exp: The energy you hold in your body is your feelings. It can take the form of all kinds of things. Good feelings, bad feelings, that "strange feeling." Now, don't confuse this with the future vocab word ????? which means "good feeling." This one just means "feeling" because it doesn't have an adjective attached to it, telling you more about this feeling that you're having.
reading-exp: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji, though ? is on'yomi and ?? is kun'yomi. One of those weird exception readings, but it'll work out for you anyway, as long as you're studying the kanji well enough.

context-en: You have such beautiful fingers.
context-en2: Wow. It's already been a month since I took the lesson of drawing fingers last time, huh?
context-en3: I just had a sudden pain in my middle finger.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. The only difference is that this word can mean finger or toe. What are toes but small, walking fingers?
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What do you use your finger for the most? For pointing, of course! Imagine going up to people and saying, "What will you be (??) when you grow up?" Point your finger at the next person, "What will you be?" Keep going until you're just saying, "You be? You be?" with your finger out.

vocab-meaning: First Place, Head Position, Leading Position, First Position
context-en: I got the first place in an academic test.
context-en2: Since our leading hitter got injured, we fell six games behind first place.
context-en3: That old person seemed to have zero interest in both teams' fight for first place.
meaning-exp: If you’re at neck rank you’re in first place. Haven’t you ever heard the phrase, “neck and neck” when two people in a race are both super close to first place? Just remember that and you’ll never forget this word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you get first place, I'll make you karaage every day for a week.
context-en2: My kid won first place in a piano competition.
context-en3: Mom! I really aced that test! I ranked at the top of my class!
meaning-exp: Rank one is the first place.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Folk Tale, Legend, Old Story, Folklore
context-en: Is this a Japanese folk tale?
context-en2: That's like a princess in a legend.
context-en3: While waiting for a bus in the bus shelter, I read a folk tale picture book for my child.
meaning-exp: Long ago people used to talk about all sorts of things. Most of them weren't true. Long ago people liked to lie a lot. Now we call those things they talked about folk tales and legends.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the rendaku of ??? to ???.

context-en: Please bring some food, Ms. Yasuda.
context-en2: I've always had issues with eating whenever I get sad or depressed.
context-en3: When you waste food, heaven will punish you.
meaning-exp: An eat thing (aka "a thing you eat") is food. Eat those things. Eat that food. Because it's a "thing" you know it's a noun. Interesting how this kanji can turn a verb like this into a noun, right? Look out for it because this pattern will show up with other verbs as well!
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

context-en: This baked sweet potato is a sign of our friendship.
context-en2: Tofugu played a role in promoting Japan-U.S. friendship.
context-en3: Kana is a very friendly and experienced Japanese teacher, right? Actually, she is also a secret member of the Yakuza.
meaning-exp: If you have a friend you like, well, that's true friendship!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Get Even, Retaliation, Get Back At, Revenge, Get Revenge
context-en: It was mortifying, so I wanna get even.
context-en2: Catwoman! You are so evil! I’ll get you back soon!
context-en3: I ate Koichi's favorite yogurt to get back at him for eating my pudding.
meaning-exp: When you return the doings of another person, you're doing it to get even (whether it's a nice thing or a mean thing).
reading-exp: The readings are a bit weird, here. ? gets its on'yomi reading... you should be okay with that. ?? gets the kun'yomi reading, though, which is the reading you saw with the word ?? in level 9. You can tell this part uses the kun'yomi vocab reading because it has that hiragana attached to it. Just remember to distinguish between the two parts of the word to remember the readings.

context-en: Do you believe in gods?
context-en2: How much longer will you make God wait?
context-en3: God may be able to walk on water. But I can swim on land.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Do you know the word "Kamikaze"? Also, do you remember the word ? from a previous level? Kamikaze means "divine winds" or "godly winds." If you know the word "Kamikaze" you can apply it to this single word, that means "god" or "gods." Use your prior knowledge to remember this reading.

context-en: Aries and Libra are compatible.
context-en2: Don't they say, "The closer you are, the more you fight?"
context-en3: That’s a good idea, but the fact is that we don’t have enough money for it.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of good? It's also good.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: A good way to pass the time is with a yo-yo (?). But it better be a good yo-yo. A bad one will just fall apart.

vocab-meaning: Good Feeling, Feeling Good, Feels Good
context-en: This down duvet feels really good.
context-en2: Doesn't it feel good to have a clean house?
context-en3: This massage feels good. I'm enjoying this good pain!
meaning-exp: When you have a feeling (???) that is ?? (that means "good" by the way), you have a good feeling.
reading-exp: The reading comes from the vocab word ???, so if you know that (or the vocab words ? and ?? you should be A-okay on this one. Maybe even feeling good about it?

context-en: There is a saying, "Your efforts will not betray you," but it's a lie.
context-en2: In spite of his grueling efforts, he didn't win the lottery.
context-en3: Even if you make a great effort, it doesn’t mean you get results.
meaning-exp: You toil and use your strength. Ugh! How difficult. You really put in a great effort.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My life was full of hardships until I came across WaniKani.
context-en2: "I spent a great deal of time and effort on Koichi's autograph." "Good work on that!"
context-en3: Since the shower head’s position is fixed in my bath tub, it’s such a pain to rinse the tub out when I wash it.
meaning-exp: Suffering and labor. Sounds like the kind of thing these soft hands wouldn't want to deal with. These are hardships and troubles. Hopefully you don't have too much of this with kanji anymore!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Hard To Deal With, Weak Point, Poor At, Not Very Good At, Bad At
context-en: Silence is hard to deal with.
context-en2: "What is your weak point, Koichi?" "I'm not good at singing."
context-en3: You and I used to be inseparable, but you know, now it’s like… things are different. Honestly, I feel uncomfortable with you.
meaning-exp: A "suffering hand" is a little misleading. Think more in terms of the words ?? (bitter) and ? (person... remember how that happens sometimes?). Now think of this word like you're bitter about having to work with someone. Why? Because they are extremely hard to deal with.
reading-exp: The reading is that of ?? (???) plus regular old ? (?). Remember, this is your bitter person, the person who's "hard to deal with." So, it uses the strange ??? reading.

vocab-meaning: High Class, High Grade, High Level
context-en: The high level version of WaniKani sold really well and made the Tofugu name increase in value.
context-en2: Let me buy you some high class tea.
context-en3: This high end restaurant is for VIPs only. In order to enter, you need an invitation or a letter of referral.
meaning-exp: A tall grade item is really just a high grade or high class item.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can read hiragana but I can’t write it.
context-en2: Could you write it in hiragana, please?
context-en3: Viet developed an app that make it so people can memorize all hiragana in five minutes.
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ?? means "kana?" Well this is flat kana. Flat kana is just hiragana.
reading-exp: You should know the reading for this word because it's the same as the English meaning.

vocab-meaning: How To Use, Way Of Using
context-en: You should be more careful about how you use language.
context-en2: I don't know how to use iPhones.
context-en3: I’m going to train my dog how to use a hammer and bring him to work with me.
meaning-exp: You've seen the word ?? hopefully by now. If you have, you know it means "to use." So, the way to use something is the way of using (aka how to use). This will be a word you see when you're looking at directions for how to use something.
reading-exp: The readings come from the vocab words ?? and ?. So long as you're okay with those you can apply that knowledge over here.

vocab-meaning: Including, Included, Furnished With, Attached To
context-en: This vacuum cleaner comes with one year warranty.
context-en2: I'm looking for a Japanese style hotel that includes dinner and breakfast.
context-en3: This room is furnished with a refrigerator and a washing machine.
meaning-exp: You know that the kanji ? means attach and words like ?? mean "to be attached." This has the same idea. When you see this attached to another word, for example, you might know that something is attached to something else, or perhaps included with it. For example, if you stay at a hotel room, maybe it is a breakfast??, i.e. "including breakfast."
reading-exp: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji as well as from words like ?? and ???.

context-en: Not having a car around here is really inconvenient.
context-en2: How is WaniKani working out for you? Have you experienced any issues?
context-en3: Welcome to my man cave. Beers are in the refrigerator. It may be a bit inconvenient for you, but you’ve got to go outside to smoke.
meaning-exp: Something that is not convenience is inconvenient.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Intermediate Level, Intermediate Rank, Intermediate Grade
context-en: How difficult is the intermediate level?
context-en2: I have to go back to the intermediate class from tomorrow on.
context-en3: The ability to communicate with people who speak English at an intermediate or beginner level is actually a skill that can be developed over time with practice.
meaning-exp: Something at the middle rank or grade is at an intermediate level.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Does this job reimburse transportation costs?
context-en2: The business of a baby is to cry.
context-en3: "Do you think we can finish this work in time?" "Well I wouldn’t bet on it."
meaning-exp: Your "doing actions" are the things you do. What do you say when someone asks "what you do"? You tell them what your job is.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ?. Please note that ? uses the reading ??, which you didn't learn with the kanji, but you have come across it once or twice by now, and because of the way rendaku works, it's changed to the voiced ??.

context-en: Wow! Speak of the devil!
context-en2: It's not too big or too small. It's just the right size.
context-en3: This temperature is just right.
meaning-exp: If ?? is "exactly", then "exactly good" is going to be just the right amount, aka just right.
reading-exp: If you know the reading for ?? you'll know the reading for this too. Your knowledge should be just right, as they say inside my head.

vocab-meaning: Laborer, Blue Collar Worker, Manual Laborer
context-en: What does president Koichi think about the shortage of blue-collar workers?
context-en2: What happened between you and all the laborers?
context-en3: Can I use the photocopier? I’m making up flyers to try to get new laborers.
meaning-exp: Someone who does labor for work is a laborer.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We all owe our lives to Koichi.
context-en2: Please, please value your life more than learning kanji on WaniKani.
context-en3: Sailor Moon’s life is in danger!
meaning-exp: The kanji for this means fate... but what is your fate, really? Your fate is to live out your life the way you're being fated to live out your life. Then, when your life runs out, your fate runs out.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: The Book of Enoch (???) has passed down your fate and told you how to use your life. You must read the book of Enoch and find out what you're supposed to do.

context-en: I like Textfugu, but I looove WaniKani.
context-en2: I love just staying home and doing nothing with someone I love.
context-en3: I like you just the way you are. So please don’t try to change yourself for anyone.
meaning-exp: You know that ? means like and this vocab word means the same thing: like!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who do you like more than anyone? Your friend Sue. If you know someone named Sue, pretend you like her. If you don't, think of a famous person you know named Sue and use her, pretending you're good friends that like each other a lot.

context-en: He’s literally a genius.
context-en2: In order to become an employee at Tofugu, you literally have to like tofu and fugu.
context-en3: "Tsundere" literally means "when in public, he/she is cold but in private, he/she suddenly become love struck."
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned the words ?? and ??? Well an "avenue" made of "letters" is literally to the letter. Wink.
reading-exp: This is a combination of the words ?? and ??, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this one. Just make sure you remember that ??? becomes ??? because of rendaku.

context-en: Koichi used to be good at hopping on one leg a long time ago.
context-en2: I got a corn on my right foot once a long time ago.
context-en3: "What are your plans for tonight Darling?" "I’m going out with my old drinking buddies."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is a good way to start stories, by the way: ???… (Long, long ago).
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. ??? sounds like a kun'yomi reading, doesn't it? It's so long.

context-en: I'm aware that I'm a loser who loves to just stay home and watch TV all day.
context-en2: I can't stand the fact that the loser is taking over my job tomorrow.
context-en3: You are a loser and really creepy!
meaning-exp: You've hopefully come across ??? by now, which means "to lose." So, you can figure out this word means "losing dog." Well, calling someone a dog isn't so nice, so you're probably just calling them a loser. As Ace Ventura would say: "Lehuzeherrrr. LOSER."
reading-exp: The readings are kun'yomi, but you should be familiar with ??? and of course ? well enough to learn the reading here.

context-en: I like a guy with a low voice.
context-en2: Our daughter is a little shorter than average.
context-en3: "Hey, Yuki. You don’t look so good." "Yeah, I know. I was diagnosed with hypotension." "What’s that?" "It just means that my blood pressure is really, really low." "How low is that?" "Well, this morning was about 80/40."
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of low? It's low.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You look down and very low to the ground is a man, looking up at you. Your friend is there too, but you don't know this little man. Your friend says "He coo', he coo," referring to the low to the ground man.

context-en: How many hours do you work per week?
context-en2: My husband is old, so manual labor would be a bit too hard for him.
context-en3: You know what I need? A man cave and a new car. I need to properly reward myself for my labors.
meaning-exp: The labor work is when you're doing work with your body, right? That's manual labor.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Look at Koichi's meaningful look!
context-en2: Do you understand what these eyes imply?
context-en3: "I thought you were smarter than that." "Hey what’s that supposed to mean?"
meaning-exp: The flavor of an idea, what is that? Imagine yourself licking an idea to figure out what it tastes like. What do you think you'll be tasting? Probably the meaning of said idea.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi invented a novel diaper-making technique.
context-en2: I feel like September is going to be a fresh start for me.
context-en3: Every time I reread this novel I make a new discovery.
meaning-exp: This is the adjective version of the kanji new, so it means new too.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your parents put a newly wrapped present under the Christmas tree. You don't want to wait to see what new thing they got you so you rip it open to find they got you a raw (??) steak. Getting a new steak is cool and all, but a raw steak is pretty gross. It's dripping blood all over the place.

vocab-meaning: Not Particularly, Separately, Not Really, Not Exactly, Not Especially
context-en: Can you use a separate bag for the warm stuff?
context-en2: I don't really have a difficult time dealing with human relationships at work.
context-en3: "Hey Fugu! What are you up to lately?" "Nothing in particular. How about you Wani?"
meaning-exp: If someone asks if you want a separate knee (?), you'll say not particularly. I mean, you've never thought about it, but do you really need more knees? Not really...
reading-exp: The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Well done!

vocab-meaning: Now On Sale, Now For Sale, Currently On Sale
context-en: Is the Year-End Jumbo Draw Lottery still for sale?
context-en2: This is a tenugui towel that's sold on Tofugu store.
context-en3: The June issue of Shonen Jump is now on sale, to critical acclaim.
meaning-exp: You have ??, which refers to an item for sale, and then you have ? which is middle. So, an item that is in the middle of being for sale is an item that is now being sold. It's now on sale! You'll see this for items which have recently been released or when a shopkeeper wants to let you know that they're selling something now, finally, or whatever.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? and ? (kanji reading) put together.

context-en: In Japan, more and more elderly people are living alone or in pairs.
context-en2: Did you patch things up with that elderly person?
context-en3: Wow! That old man is such a hunky beefcake.
meaning-exp: An elderly person is an old person (or an elderly person). Don't call a person a ???, though. ?? is used for things, not people. Be nice, they're your elders.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Don't hold your opinions back, please.
context-en2: Even though they were my close friends, I would probably have difficulty openly telling them about this.
context-en3: This is just my personal opinion, but I sometimes think that Japan is a really weird country.
meaning-exp: The idea you see in your head is your opinion. As the dude once said... "That's just, like, your ??, man."
reading-exp: The reading is all on'yomi, meaning ? is just fine. ?'s on'yomi (??) is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji because it's so much less useful, but you do have to know it here. You've seen it with ?? a couple levels ago, so that should help. In this case, just think about how your opinion is that Ken needs a new girlfriend. Barbie doesn't treat him right and he's always coming to the bar with new bruises... That Ken. Tell him your opinion.

context-en: I don't really understand how to order at Starbucks.
context-en2: You didn't forget to place an order, did you?
context-en3: That’s an unreasonable request but we don’t have a choice.
meaning-exp: You pour writing onto a form. You're filling out this form to order something new for yourself. It's a formal request to get this new thing (imagine it being something you're excited about ordering right now, and imagine yourself ordering it by pouring writing onto an order form).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We have to follow the every command of King Koichi.
context-en2: Huh? That was a request? That's BS! That definitely sounded like an order.
context-en3: "C’mon! What are you waiting for? Run!" "Don’t order me around!"
meaning-exp: Your fate orders are the orders you get from above. You are ordered and commanded to carry out said orders.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The Tofugu team is planning a company retreat to travel across the Pacific Ocean on a luxury cruise.
context-en2: That Pacific bluefin tuna in the fridge is Kanae's souvenir.
context-en3: Nowadays, most pufferfish are harvested in the spring during the spawning season, then farmed in floating cages in the Pacific Ocean.
meaning-exp: The fat flat ocean is the Pacific Ocean. I guess it's fatter than the Atlantic? Whatever it is, it's the ocean that China/Japan would have known the most about when they were coming up with words and kanji, which is why this is the Pacific, not the Atlantic.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I got matches and candles ready in case of emergency.
context-en2: Because school lunch is not provided on Fridays, we have to prepare our own lunch.
context-en3: We will do all the nabe party arrangements to celebrate the release from jail, so please take care of making arrangements for bail on your side.
meaning-exp: When you have an idea for a task you are in preparation for actually doing it. Because it's still just an idea you're still getting ready.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Please call me when you've gotten ready for school.
context-en2: Mom is preparing dinner in the kitchen and dad is making arrangements for a trip in his room.
context-en3: How long are you sleeping? Get up now and get ready!
meaning-exp: This one's a little weird. When you want to support someone in degrees you need lots of preparation. It takes time and planning to support someone over a period of time like that.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.
