You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember them together: In preparation for getting sheared, a sheep will sit on a tack (???). This sheep tacking makes it so that the shearing part is nothing! Imagine watching some sheep getting ready by sitting on tacks. Yikes. You want to tell them being sheared doesn't hurt and that sheep tacking is worse, but something makes you think they won't listen to you.

context-en: I used to volunteer at a public facility.
context-en2: One again, I want you to think about what public actually means.
context-en3: Hey, Rei and Ami. Y’know, this is probably none of my business, but weren’t you guys supposed to not be seen in public together? You guys are celebrities, right?
meaning-exp: When the public comes together you have yourself a nice community made up of the public.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I wonder where I'll rank this year.
context-en2: In terms of black garlic consumption, Koichi might be number one in Portland.
context-en3: I came in first at the marathon rally, so my parents bought me a mountain bike.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi reading, which you learned. This is probably because you'll see this word attached to other words, showing the rank of that thing.

context-en: This building is made of concrete, so it can't be penetrated by radio waves.
context-en2: How could he say such things on public radio! Nasty jerk.
context-en3: Sorry, you sound kind of choppy. It seems like I’ve got bad reception here.
meaning-exp: The electricity wave is a wave of electricity going through the air. There are many words one can use to describe this, but the easiest one is reception (aka the reception on your phone, for example). Other more technical meanings are radio wave and electromagnetic waves. Which one you like is up to you, but reception is going to be the most common meaning on the street. Luckily people in Japan don't have AT&T otherwise you'd hear this word a lot more...
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? from ? rendakus to ?, so be careful. Maybe it's your pa who has bad reception every time you try to call him?

context-en: I heard that receptionist lady has a big corn on her left foot.
context-en2: Arnold Schwarzenegger will be Tofugu's receptionist starting tomorrow.
context-en3: Huh? I don’t know. Didn't someone at reception explain it to you?
meaning-exp: Imagine someone accepting something and then attaching something. This person is a receptionist, because they are accepting the call, writing down the information, and then attaching said information to a sticky note for you to read. You say, "No, I'm not available."
reading-exp: For this reading you have to think back to the verb words that get used with this kanji, namely ??? and ???. Then just drop off the ?s and put them together. ? becomes ?? and ? becomes ?? and you're left with ????. This is what's called a compound word. And now you know it. Nice!

context-en: Let’s let bygones be bygones and just make peace with this.
context-en2: I can't make up with her that quickly.
context-en3: How did Koichi bring about a reconciliation between the Mario brothers?
meaning-exp: When you fix a relationship you are going through reconciliation.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For ? you're fine. That's what you learned with the kanji. For ?? think back to the vocab word ??. That's what's going on here.

context-en: I don't get along with my mother very much.
context-en2: I saw a harmonious elderly couple at a cafe and it made me feel warm inside.
context-en3: Kinnikuma: "Wow! You guys have a close relationship don’t you?" WaniKani and Tofugu: "How so? It’s just a bromance."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi reading since it's a single kanji, all alone, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji, so you should be okay and have a great relationship with this word going forward.

context-en: He’s rich though…
context-en2: I want to marry someone who is filthy rich.
context-en3: I used to run small errands for a wealthy neighbor of mine to make money when I was young.
meaning-exp: When you hold gold you are a rich person.
reading-exp: Do you remember the word ??? This is the ? in this word. The reading for ?? is the ? you learned with ??. So, combine the ?? of ?? and the ?? and you have the reading of this word. Alternatively, you can say this word as ???? as well.

context-en: We're doing a rooftop barbecue today.
context-en2: I worked out on the rooftop in the morning even though I work the night shift.
context-en3: Why don't we go up to the housetop and catch the star light shining down from the heavens?
meaning-exp: Above the roof is the rooftop. What else would be up there?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for ? though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: One place in the world has more rooftops than any where else, and that's Oklahoma (??). They get so many tornadoes that they need extra rooftops for when the first few blow off.

context-en: I like seeing couples walk along the seashore in yukata on days when there are fireworks.
context-en2: I know a good cafe at the coast. Do you wanna get tea with me?
context-en3: "Do you want to go to the seashore with us today?" "I’ll take a rain check this time."
meaning-exp: The ocean/sea coast is the seashore. Then again, it could also be the coast as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I sent a LINE message to Koichi and he replied to me in a second. That made me chuckle.
context-en2: When I go to bed, I usually fall asleep in three seconds.
context-en3: Your pronunciation can reach native-level in just twelve seconds.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji. It's presumably because it's usually attached to other things, like numbers, making it act more like a jukugo word would. Anyway, you should only need a second to learn this reading, since you should already know it.

vocab-meaning: Sell Cheaply, Discount, Bargain Sale, Sale
context-en: If you sell yourself too short, it’ll be tough later.
context-en2: I really love this jacket, but can't afford it. Are there any upcoming sales?
context-en3: Yes, the TV was broken when I sold it to you, but that’s why it was on sale.
meaning-exp: When you sell something cheap, you're selling it at a discount. Alternatively you can remember this word as sell cheaply or bargain sale. These are good deals!
reading-exp: The hiragana on the end hints that the readings are the kun'yomi readings. Use your memory of ?? and ?? to help you to remember how to read this.

context-en: I was cheated by that vendor.
context-en2: This's the hottest seller's market ever.
context-en3: The guy selling that house told me he’s selling it because his neighbor is a real jerk.
meaning-exp: The hand that sells the items is connected to a person who is known as the seller or the vendor.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too! One hint that this is a kun'yomi reading word is the hiragana in the center. It's like two separate words combined together, and when a word is a single kanji / a single kanji with hiragana attached it is usually kun'yomi. This is like two of those, combined.

vocab-meaning: Separate, Different, Another, Separate Thing, Different Thing, Another Thing
context-en: Why don't we try a different approach?
context-en2: I think this and that are separate issues.
context-en3: I own two houses. I bought this place about three months ago and I own another place down in the valley.
meaning-exp: The ? is there to indicate that it is the difference of something. For example this is like saying "the separate ______" or "the different _____" or "another ______". ? by itself just means separate, different, or another.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned. Move on to a ????, mmk?

context-en: They're twins, but they each think separately.
context-en2: Please plant this separately from the cactus.
context-en3: "Now do we really have to go our separate ways?" "Yup, but I believe we’ll see each other again soon."
meaning-exp: When you separate separate you're putting things off into their own areas. You're marking them off separately and individually.
reading-exp: The reading is just the ?? reading you know, twice.

vocab-meaning: Shared, Co Ownership, Joint Ownership, Share
context-en: "That is a very nice yacht. Is that yours, Mr. Tanaka?" "I'm a co-owner with my brother."
context-en2: These One Piece figures are the shared assets of Koichi and Viet.
context-en3: Raising a kid works better when husbands and wives share information properly.
meaning-exp: The things you together have are the things that are shared.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is one Shinto ritual.
context-en2: Last night, I had a dream that I was just explaining Shinto to Koichi forever.
context-en3: Why doesn’t Shinto have an absolute God?
meaning-exp: The way/road of the god(s) is, as you can probably guess, a big Japanese religion. There's two, and I'll give you a hint, this one isn't Buddhism (that would probably have the kanji for Buddha in it, no?). So what's the other big one? It's Shinto. If you're having trouble remembering this because you've never heard of it before, skip to the reading. The reading will help.
reading-exp: The reading is a bit wonky. ? should be no problem. ? on the other hand is almost the one you learned (??) but now it's ?? for some reason. Perhaps the gods took away the dakuten to make it ??, who knows. All I know is that it's best not to question said gods. If you already know of Shinto in English, though, this reading should be really easy. If you don't, perhaps you can use this reading to help you to remember Shinto the religion.

context-en: When I visited a shinto shrine at the beginning of the new year, I saw Koichi and Viet having a fist fight.
context-en2: I totally forgot about the charm I bought at a shinto shrine in Japan.
context-en3: Yo! Very cool selfie, but why were you in a shinto shrine instead of at school?
meaning-exp: A God company... think of this as "what 'company' does the god's work?" Well, the answer to that is a shrine, probably. In this case a Shinto Shrine because of the ?? in the ?.
reading-exp: But wait! ? is read ?? in this word for some reason. Darn them gods, always messing around, adding dakuten. Maybe this will help, though: Imagine yourself at a Shinto Shrine. You are praying to the Gods, asking for food. Out from the sky rains Ginger (????). You are pelted with it and not sure if you should be happy or upset.

context-en: I’m shopping at the grocery store.
context-en2: As for shopping, I usually just do it online.
context-en3: We’re going Christmas shopping today! I’m so excited!
meaning-exp: You've hopefully seen ?? by now and know it means "to buy." So, ?? is going to be similar to that. Add that to thing and you have a "buying things" sort of word. What does "buying things" describe? It describes shopping.
reading-exp: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Also, you can use the reading for ?? to help you with ?? as well. ? is just ??, like you learned.

vocab-meaning: Sightseeing, Sightseer, Watching, Watcher, Viewing, Viewer
context-en: It seems fun, so let’s have a look.
context-en2: We watched the Christmas parade from the office windows.
context-en3: Mom would have gone sightseeing in Tokyo.
meaning-exp: If you try to see a bunch of things at once, you are probably sightseeing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: That magazine is sold out.
context-en2: I almost cried when I learned that tickets for the Tofugu lecture were sold out.
context-en3: I’m terribly sorry Mr. Jones, but we are all sold out of animal crackers.
meaning-exp: When the selling is cut, that means something is sold out. You'll see this word a lot in stores (or, hopefully you won't...) in Japan. Look out for it if you're able!
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

context-en: Sometimes I read Tofugu articles in a restaurant on the top floor of the Tofugu hotel.
context-en2: At the beach, sometimes a pleasant breeze would gently caress my cheek.
context-en3: Tofugu gets into trouble with its customers at times. One time it even led to a fist fight that ended in a death, so you should be careful with them, really.
meaning-exp: You know the single word ?, right? It means time. This is that twice. So you have one time, and you have another time. They are separate. Things don't happen in every of these times you have. They happen sometimes.
reading-exp: The reading is the vocab word ? twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd.

context-en: I got a special coupon for the new Tarantino film.
context-en2: Is this the special car designed by Tofugu?
context-en3: Even though she isn't especially cute, she is very popular among boys, yeah?
meaning-exp: Something that is special and separate from the rest is, well, special.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Splendid, Magnificent, Beautiful, Admirable, Praiseworthy Act, Feat
context-en: It’s a splendid pine tree, isn’t it?
context-en2: Splendid! Wow, that was such a beautiful shoot!
context-en3: She rejected me magnificently clearly.
meaning-exp: Every single thing you see is splendid. You saw it after all, so of course it's magnificent. Your eyes are so great that they make everything reflect you. And you're beautiful.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Don't worry. Failure teaches success.
context-en2: I wish you success in your new job.
context-en3: I created a curry-flavored toothpaste when I was told, "If you want to be successful in business you need to think outside the box."
meaning-exp: When you become achievement, you have probably gained plenty of success.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: At 9 p.m. I want to talk about our strategy for tomorrow.
context-en2: Let's work out a strategy one more time.
context-en3: Koichi thinks that Tofugu needs new sales tactics.
meaning-exp: When you make war, you're building it up like you'd build a building. You have to make strategy, you have to plan, you have to come up with awesome tactics.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I think she's acting like she's the main character of a story.
context-en2: The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter is a famous Japanese legend.
context-en3: I’m writing a story right now. It’s about a sad guy who is obsessed with puppies.
meaning-exp: A language about things. This is a confusing one. Just think of it more like someone talking about things, anything, really. Someone who just talks about things is someone who tells stories. So, this word means tale or story or legend (not the Tom Cruise one, though).
reading-exp: The reading for this is messed up. You have ? as ??, which is fine, but ? decides to go all crazy on you. Maybe you've heard the word ????? before (it's in some film names / book names). If not, think of a story being told about a great gatling (???) gun that wandered the land, mowing everything down in its path. It's a terrible legend, but what if it were true???

context-en: Our city decided to use a tank instead of a garbage truck.
context-en2: We have to wash this tank soon.
context-en3: "How are the tires on my tank?" "I think you should either pump them up a lot more or switch to tank treads."
meaning-exp: A war car is probably a little more dangerous than the Honda you drive. No, a war car is a tank.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I hope the flavor will suit your tastes.
context-en2: It's past the expiration date, so it might not taste the same, but I think it's still edible.
context-en3: This blowfish sashimi tastes is amazing! Just what I wanted!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You may have the ability to taste things now, but just wait until you get up there in age (??). You'll find that the tastes and flavors you once liked will become bland, and you'll need a lot of Sriracha to make things taste better.

context-en: I'm gonna start with a draft beer!
context-en2: Koichi's first girlfriend's name was Koichiko.
context-en3: You’re awful at this! Even a newbie couldn’t be that bad! When I played this game for the first time I was way better than you.
meaning-exp: The most first thing is the first thing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I got the first-press limited edition of Koichi's new song.
context-en2: We have a special offer for first time customers!
context-en3: Oh, is this your first time attending our Japanese language club? Okay everyone, he’s a newbie, so let’s go easy on him.
meaning-exp: The first of something you'll do several or many times is the first time.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: The Lowest, The Worst, Lowest, Worst, Nasty, Terrible
context-en: How can you drink such terrible, garbage alcohol?
context-en2: Maybe it was the worst kiss ever.
context-en3: Wow, I can’t believe you got the lowest score on the test. What a bummer!
meaning-exp: The most low is the lowest. It's also what you call something when you think it's the worst or just plain terrible. Try yelling this out when you're disgusted about someone or something.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: The Real Thing, Real Deal, The Real Deal, Real Thing, Genuine Article, The Genuine Article
context-en: Current CG is so realistic that it feels real at a first glance, and I think that’s really cool.
context-en2: I heard a dark rumor that Tofugu is making fake bills that look exactly like the real thing.
context-en3: When I was a kid, my dad always told me that real men stay faithful, but he ended up cheating on my mom and now they’re going to get a divorce.
meaning-exp: The real thing is the real thing, aka the real deal. If you learned ? as book you can also think of this word as the "book thing." What is this book thing? Is it the real version of the book? Is it the real deal? If so, I'll pay you a million.
reading-exp: The readings are on'yomi plus kun'yomi (kun'yomi is ?). This word uses the reading you learned for both of these kanji, though, which means you should be able to read it.

context-en: How many Tofugu fans are there in the West?
context-en2: India has a very low divorce rate compared to Western countries.
context-en3: That’s a Western ghost.
meaning-exp: The Western styled West is still known as the West. The one everyone refers to over in Asia when they talk about Western countries in Europe and North America. This is the place you'll hear people say you're from if you live in Canada or something.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: To Appoint, To Assign, To Designate, To Specify
context-en: The meeting place was designated by the client.
context-en2: Can I specify that I want a seat by myself even though I'm booking the ticket online?
context-en3: There is a designated smoking area over there, so you should go there and complain how stinky smokers are instead of just telling me.
meaning-exp: When you determine and use your finger to point at someone or something, you're going to appoint them. Just imagine yourself determining who's the best for the job then pointing with your finger. That is who you will appoint. The ?? on the end makes it a verb, so ?? would be "appointment" or "designation" or something along those lines. Cool how ?? works.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: To Attempt, To Try Out, To Test, To Test The Limits, To Try
context-en: I'll try out this medicine.
context-en2: Let's try to see how fast we can say Japanese tongue twisters.
context-en3: I don’t know if I can lick my elbow, but I’ll give it a try.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attempt or try. The verb vocab version is to attempt or to try out. Why don't you try out the meaning of this verb, while you're at it?
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Okay. Here's the deal. We have this wild animal. I want you to attempt to tame (??) it. Now, imagine trying to tame this wild animal. Yeehaw!

context-en: You're worrying for nothing. What will be, will be.
context-en2: I'm visually impaired because I looked directly at an eclipse.
context-en3: Oh my God! Koichi finally became the President of the United States! Where there's a will, there's a way!
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means become so the vocab verb version would be to become.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are starting to become something else. You're transforming, but you're not sure what it is. First, you get fins... uh oh, something in the water. Then, you gain a tail and rubbery skin... hmm, something sea mammal-like. Oh, and then a huge horn flies out of your nose. You are going to become a narwhal (?).

context-en: I was born and raised in Tokyo.
context-en2: I was raised on bacon in a very strict household.
context-en3: I really like the Meiji Shrine because its forest was carefully designed to mimic a natural forest and because of that it’s beautiful and has a very natural atmosphere.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means raise so the verb vocab version means to be raised. P.S. This word is for when you are being raised, not when you are doing the raising of someone. That's ???. You'll learn it later.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you were raised, you were raised completely on soda (??). That's all you drank. No water, no juice... just tons and tons of soda. Imagine this.

vocab-meaning: To Be Returned, To Return, To Come Back
context-en: When he came to, he was lying on the sofa in the Tofugu office.
context-en2: The precious keepsake pendant from my mom that I thought I'd lost was returned to me before I knew it.
context-en3: Thinking my money would be returned properly was a huge mistake.
meaning-exp: You hopefully know the word ??, which means "to return" (as in, you're doing the direct action of returning something). This word, on the other hand, is the version where something just returns (and you're not doing the action of returning). Use the ? to help you to remember this. ? the Kangaroo is returned to you. You don't do any of the returning, it just happens or someone else does it. That's why this word means to be returned.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??, so as long as you know that you'll be able to apply it here to learn the reading of this word as well.

context-en: Various legends of Viet before working for Tofugu have been told to the employees.
context-en2: Even though you can't speak Japanese well, if you try to speak with your heart, people will understand.
context-en3: A message about how the Tofugu ninjas crept towards the castle during the night was transmitted to Shogun Koichi.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something is transmitted. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to be transmitted.
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as ???.

context-en: It’s been a while since this drama was broadcasted.
context-en2: A rebroadcast of the game is scheduled to run on NHK at 5pm today.
context-en3: President Koichi’s important announcement will be broadcast on television tonight.
meaning-exp: You are going to release and send something out. Imagine this message going out through the sky to everyone around you. You are going to broadcast it to the world! The ?? is on there to make this noun a verb. Without the ?? it would be the noun "broadcast."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: In Japan, there is a proverb that says, "If you chase after two hares, you will catch neither."
context-en2: Koichi always chases after the latest fashion.
context-en3: I’ll follow my dream no matter how hard it is and I want you to understand that if you are going to be my husband.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means follow so the verb version is to follow (it's also to chase, because when you follow something you are chasing it too).
reading-exp: You've learned this reading already, so you should know how to read this word!

vocab-meaning: To Commute, To Attend, To Go Back And Forth
context-en: What!? Are you going back and forth between Hokkaido and Okinawa every day?
context-en2: Koichi commutes to the Tofugu office on a Harley-Davidson.
context-en3: My younger sister will attend Tofugu Academy starting in April.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means pass through but we already know the word ?? which means to pass through. This word means a different kind of passing through, like how you pass through the halls of your school everyday. But we don't say to pass through school, we say to attend school, or to commute to school.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You live in the middle of three different school districts so you need to decide which of the three schools you want to attend. You decide you don't mind that you have to commute to the farthest of the three because their mascot is Wile E. Coyote (??). He's your favorite Looney Toon because he always has the energy to go back and forth after that road runner.

vocab-meaning: To Compete, To Argue, To Quarrel
context-en: Please don't argue about me!
context-en2: Tofugu workers are competing with each other for the position of president.
context-en3: You are so chill. It’s great hanging out with you. You know what? We’ve never had an argument yet, either. That’s crazy, isn’t it?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conflict so the vocabulary means to compete or to argue. Your views conflict with someone else's so you're going to compete with them to see who's right.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're starting to compete with your rival. You're yelling, and punching each other in the faces, causing a huge scene, and making people call the cops on you. Because of your quarrel, you have both now been arrested (???) and are now spending time in prison. This isn't the perfect reading, but it hopefully can get you to the correct reading with a few tries. Try to make the connection.

context-en: The children raced over to the new teacher.
context-en2: Tofugu is so unique that there is nobody else to compete with. They are the so-called sole winner.
context-en3: Koichi and Viet competed with each other to demonstrate their prowess at the annual Kendo competition held in the Tofugu office.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compete so the verb vocab version means to compete.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to compete for kisses (??) from that boy/girl you like. Imagine yourself doing this, competing with a rival.

context-en: This work should be done by five if everyone concentrates.
context-en2: Right now you should be focusing on your most important task.
context-en3: Currently, Team Tofugu is concentrating on a secret project called XXX.
meaning-exp: You collect and focus in on the middle. Really zoom in on it. When you do this, you're concentrating on this spot, thus making the meaning of this word to concentrate.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Once they've decided on a name for Koichi's baby I'll let you know right away.
context-en2: Koichi has the right to decide his employee's salaries.
context-en3: ROFL! This TV show is hilarious, man. I’ve decided that this is now my new favorite show.
meaning-exp: A ?? is a "decision." So, when you add ?? to it you're making it a verb, meaning this word means to decide.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ?? with ?? added. Make sure you know ?? and you'll know this word as well.

context-en: You should go to the bathroom when you fart.
context-en2: It seems that Satoshi finally got serious about cleaning the bathroom.
context-en3: Oh yeah! Nothing but net! I really love that this restroom’s trashcan has a basketball net on it.
meaning-exp: *Ahem.* This is the place of convenience. What place above all others do you want to be convenient? Just in case, you know... that would be the toilet.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Maintain, To Preserve, To Retain
context-en: Koichi retains the world record for being the fastest broccoli eater.
context-en2: In order to preserve the peace around here, we need the help of Viet's yakuza group.
context-en3: You should prioritize maintaining your own country’s status first.
meaning-exp: This is the verb version of ??, from two levels ago.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??, so if you know that word's reading, you know this one too.

vocab-meaning: To Open Up, To Throw Open, To Open To The Public
context-en: They decided to open this warehouse as a refuge.
context-en2: This pool is open to the public in the summer.
context-en3: I want to know how to open ports to give access to this one game.
meaning-exp: When you open then release, say, a door, you're opening it up for everyone to come in. That's why it means to open up or to throw open.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Pick Up, To Find, To Gather
context-en: When one God gets rid of you, another picks you up.
context-en2: I found a 500 yen coin on that sidewalk on the way back home.
context-en3: Someone threw a couch away on the side of the road, but it still looked useful, so I picked it up.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pick up so the verb vocab version is to pick up.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done!

context-en: Which way is the arrow pointing?
context-en2: In Japan, it's rude to point at people with your finger.
context-en3: Oh, you’re color blind, eh? So that means you can’t point at which one is red and which one is green, then.
meaning-exp: The kanji means finger. So, if you "to finger" something, what are you doing? You're pointing. That's why this word means to point.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are pointing at something in fear. It is a saw (?). Thing is, you're pointing at this saw with a missing finger. It just cut off your finger and you're freaking out, trying to point with a bloody non-finger.

context-en: Did you pour milk in my coke by any chance?
context-en2: Koichi is pouring all of his energy into supporting AKB48 this year.
context-en3: "Can you pour some more wine for me, please?" "Sure. Just say when." "Yes! There! That’s perfect. Thank you."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pour so the verb vocab version is to pour.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are going to pour some sauce (??).

context-en: Don't pretend like you didn't notice.
context-en2: I think I realized my feeling for Koichiko three days after we met.
context-en3: I can’t believe you gave me your ice cream. I didn’t realize that you were so kind until now.
meaning-exp: When you attach your energy (imagine someone suddenly looking up at something, attaching their energy to it), they have noticed or realized something. That's why this word means to realize or to notice. Don't confuse this with ????? which is similar in that it has all the same kanji. It's just used a little different. Try to remember the difference before moving on.
reading-exp: The readings come from the ? kanji (which you know) and the word ?? which you should know by now. Combine these together and you have the ability to read this word. Take note that the ?? part is rendaku'd, though, so it is a tiny bit different.

vocab-meaning: To Release, To Let Go, To Release Something, To Let Go Of Something
context-en: Let go of me!
context-en2: Koichi finally released Viet's hand after thirty minutes.
context-en3: Every time I let Fugu loose in the sea, he swims off and when I call him he doesn’t listen. What should I do to teach him to not run away?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means release so the verb vocab version is to release.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine you are going to release something. It is a ? (??). You release it from your hand and it falls, hitting the ground in slow motion. You have the power to release and you are doing the releasing (versus ??? where something is just released). You can remember this because even though you did the releasing of the flower, you're going to sue the pavement company for breaking your flower. It's all a big scam you're running.

context-en: I'll go to the airport to see you guys off.
context-en2: I wonder which is harder, being the person who sees someone off or being one who is seen off by someone.
context-en3: Koichi burst into tears after seeing them off.
meaning-exp: You know the words ?? and ?? by now, hopefully. Here you're "seeing" the "sending." You're seeing someone off, so this verb is to see off.
reading-exp: The readings come from the vocab words ?? and ??. Make sure you know those and you'll know this word's reading as well.

context-en: It’s really hard to understand Tofugu's way of thinking.
context-en2: I'm struggling under intense pressure from Koichi, who aided and abetted me in a crime.
context-en3: I’m just thinking about your new wife at home. Okay? Do you really want to make her suffer from your death for the rest of her life? So, don’t commit suicide.
meaning-exp: You learned the word ??? (hopefully) in level 9. That word means suffering. So, if you make that into a verb version, you have to suffer.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ???, so as long as you're on top of that word, this word should be readable for you as well.

vocab-meaning: To Transmit, To Tell, To Pass Down, To Pass Along
context-en: Tofugu invented a machine that transmits Japanese pronunciation directly to your brain.
context-en2: I told my teacher that I was so tired that I could have fallen asleep in his class earlier.
context-en3: Please give your mother and father my regards.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transmit, so the verb version is to transmit or to tell something.
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to transmit a signal to the stars (??)! Trying to tell your message to anyone on earth would be too boring and too easy. Aim your message at the nearest star and transmit it into space!

context-en: I had to labor through the day with a headache and an empty stomach.
context-en2: I'm studying Japanese to work in Japan.
context-en3: "Would you like to come read Tofugu articles on Friday?" "I’d like to but I have to work late Friday night." "That’s too bad. Maybe some other time."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means work so the verb vocab version means to work.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are as mad as a hatter you'll need to work very hard to regain your sanity. You know The Hatter from Alice in Wonderland? Imagine how hard he would have to work to be considered "normal".

vocab-meaning: To Work Well, To Be Possible
context-en: My bike's brakes don't work well.
context-en2: I had a skilled cook make food for me today.
context-en3: Koichi is a pretty flexible man.
meaning-exp: You know the kanji means profit. When you make it into a verb, though, it means to work well. If you think about it, when something works well it makes you a profit.
reading-exp: What works so well? Your special key (?) that can unlock anyone and anything's potential. Imagine putting it into a key slot in someone's back. Someone who's a good for nothing can't-do-anything is now an effective member of society! Go around using your key on other non-effective things and show them that anything is possible!

context-en: Unexpectedly, my dad approved of it right away.
context-en2: Liking soft pasta that's been cooked too long was an unexpected aspect of Canadian culture.
context-en3: Fugu is a really fast runner. The surprising thing is, he was never a good swimmer in the sea and never raced on land until he was in college.
meaning-exp: Something outside your normal idea of how things work will come as unexpected to you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please don’t smoke in vehicles.
context-en2: I got motion sickness.
context-en3: "How was the ride?" "Oh, it was terrifying! I spent the whole time trying not to pee my pants."
meaning-exp: You know that ?? has something to do with riding and that ? is a thing. So what is a "riding thing?" Nowadays, at least, that would be a vehicle.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

vocab-meaning: Victory, Win, A Victory, A Win
context-en: Koichi won the belly dancing competition hands down.
context-en2: Japan's national snow ball fighting team made a comeback to clinch the victory.
context-en3: It’s first come, first served. Let’s get a move on! I really want the Fugu keychain. I don’t want to miss out on this chance.
meaning-exp: You've hopefully seen ?? by now, which means "to win." This is a nouny version of that. So, what's the noun version of "to win?" It's a win or a victory.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??. So as long as you have some understanding of that reading, you should be able to read this one as well.

context-en: This is the first time I've gone to war in six months.
context-en2: Can you list up to ten reasons why we shouldn't go to war?
context-en3: I want to get a six pack before the war begins.
meaning-exp: You have war and conflict. Of course, conflict comes with war, so this word just means war.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Today's waves are very high, aren't they?
context-en2: OMG! Koichi has been swallowed by a wave!
context-en3: The rocking of the waves to and fro feels good.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You jump on a wave and ride around the world on it. It doesn't drop you off anywhere, until you reach a certain location: Vietnam (??). You jump off the wave and look at Vietnam. Imagine the most Vietnamese things you can think of to help you to make this wave-Vietnam association.

context-en: The Western food restaurant was made in cooperation with famous sushi restaurants.
context-en2: I'm working part-time at a so-called old fashioned Western family restaurant.
context-en3: Oh, did you eat the western-style lunch set at that restaurant? Hahaha. No wonder you still feel full.
meaning-exp: The Western eats are Western food. Mmmm, 'dem hamburgers.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Tonight's supper is western style pot-au-feu.
context-en2: A refined western-style song was played in a western style cafe.
context-en3: My house is entirely furnished in the Western style, so there are no tatami mats.
meaning-exp: Remember how ? can mean "style" as in ??? Well, this is now Western style style, more simply put as Western style.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When Koichi made that comment, everybody in the western style room froze.
context-en2: This western style room looks strangely familiar, though I know I've never been here before.
context-en3: My room is a western style room, about ten square meters, with my favorite color of light blue on the walls.
meaning-exp: A Western style room is a Western style room. We're talking something that's not a tatami mat filled room. Good to know this word if you're staying in hotels or ryokans and prefer not to sleep on a futon, etc.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is the result of your conduct.
context-en2: Koichi's behavioral patterns are always the same.
context-en3: What they say and what they do don't match up, so I always have a hard time and get confused.
meaning-exp: When you go to move you're actually making an action. It's these behaviors when you go and move that determine what people think about you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Kristen is an active cosplayer on weekends.
context-en2: I study biology in the mornings and afternoons at college, and in the late afternoon, I engage in religious activities.
context-en3: Action verbs are one of the four verb types categorized from the aspect perspective.
meaning-exp: The lively moves you make are actions. They're the activities you do every day to stay fit and healthy!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I saw a couple having a huge fight at Narita Airport the other day.
context-en2: Are there bathrooms with changing tables in this airport?
context-en3: I think I left my passport in the car I rented at the airport.
meaning-exp: Put aside your steampunk blimp fantasies for a moment. A sky harbor is an airport, nothing more.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: He likes dried cuttlefish, even though he is a kid, eh? He could be a boozer in the future.
context-en2: Koichi likes drinking, but he isn't like an alcoholic.
context-en3: He’s a heavy drinker but he doesn’t like red wine.
meaning-exp: You've seen ??, so you know this has to do with drinking alcohol. Someone who's known as someone who drinks alcohol is an alcoholic.
reading-exp: The readings are the vocab words ?? and ?? combined together into one. You can guess it's a kun'yomi reading because of the ? on the end of ?, which should make you think back to vocab words that use these kanji and the kun'yomi readings. If you can do that, you can read this word (and many others, probably!).

vocab-meaning: All Members, All Hands, Everyone, Everybody
context-en: They are all males.
context-en2: They decided that every Tofugu employee will take the bacon sommelier exam.
context-en3: Looks like it'll be difficult for everyone to make it, yeah?
meaning-exp: All members means all members. This is also a fancy way to say everybody.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I don't like animals.
context-en2: Do you have any animals?
context-en3: Koichi hosted a party at the Tofugu Zoo for one hundred very important animals and for some reason, I wasn’t invited. I thought I was one of the VIA to him too.
meaning-exp: A moving thing... think about the "things" that move. Technically it could be a lot of things (aka basically anything), but in this case we are talking about moving living things. We won't include humans, because humans are too good to be called things. This refers to animals instead.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Animal Cry, Animal Sound, Animal Noise, Chirp, Tweet, Roar, Bark, Meow
context-en: Have you ever heard what a giraffe sounds like?
context-en2: I thought I heard Koichi outside, but it was a little bird's chirps.
context-en3: I hear a puppy barking under the vending machine.
meaning-exp: The chirp voice is a sound an animal makes. Sure, it works for birds (which chirp), but it also works with most other animals as well. So, we call this an animal cry.
reading-exp: The readings are those that you learned with the kanji. ? gets changed to ??, though, so take note of that in your head. Perhaps you can imagine an animal that does a "GOEEEEE" cry.

vocab-meaning: As One Pleases, One's Own Convenience, One's Own Way, One's Way
context-en: You are so selfish!
context-en2: Don't say whatever you want.
context-en3: "Salmon! Fugu cheated on you five times. Never trust a guy like that." "I know… but he says he can’t live without me." "Well, suit yourself then!"
meaning-exp: The hand (or person, as you know ? often refers to a person) that wins gets to do as one pleases.
reading-exp: The reading for this is weird. It's all kun'yomi, which luckily you've seen before, but still strange. I guess when you do as one pleases you can read kanji however you want, in this case the kun'yomi readings. Do note that there's a small ? in there before, presumably to connect the two readings of the two kanji together.

context-en: I'll get in touch with you as soon as possible.
context-en2: Depending on the circumstances, Koichi's wedding ceremony may be postponed.
context-en3: "Which day is convenient for you, Saturday or Sunday?" "It makes no difference to me."
meaning-exp: This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you join together with someone at a metropolis, you do it at your convenience. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about. This word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!"
reading-exp: The reading for ? is an exception from what you learned with the kanji. To remember this, just think about someone who does something at their own convenience. They say, I'm going to go (???) where I want, when I want, at my own convenience. The ? (??) part is a reading you know from the kanji, though, so if you can get to "to go" with the mnemonic, you should be able to put two and two together to know that it's a long vowel ??.

context-en: This all-you-can-eat sushi restaurant's customer service is unbelievably bad.
context-en2: Sorry to bother you, but can you steam these veggies for me?
context-en3: The milk went bad, but I didn’t care.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of bad? It's also bad.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you know how in the Mario universe all the bad versions are called "WARU" (??)? For example: "WARUIJI" and "WARIO." That's because they are bad. They come from this kanji. So, if you ever need to remember this reading, just think back to Wario and Waruigi.

vocab-meaning: Bad Person, Villain, Evildoer, Bad Guy, Wicked Person, Evil Person
context-en: He is a villain, but his hobby is gardening.
context-en2: Koichi is just playing an evildoer.
context-en3: Do you really think it’s possible to differentiate between good people and bad people?
meaning-exp: A bad person is a bad person.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We are just about to go to a professional baseball game.
context-en2: I like baseball, but I heard you have to act like you're in the army if you belong to the baseball club, so I don't want to join it.
context-en3: I fractured my knee while playing baseball.
meaning-exp: Field Sphere! The greatest sport to grace this earth since a very similar (aka the same) sport, baseball. Think about it, you play on a field and you use a little sphere. Awesome!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What's the drink that Koichi's drinking?
context-en2: Beverages containing alcohol shouldn't be drunk during pregnancy.
context-en3: "Would you like something cold to drink?" "Well then, could I have two cartons of milk?"
meaning-exp: A thing you drink is a beverage.
reading-exp: These are both the kun'yomi readings. You've learned them already, so you already know how to read this word!

context-en: After the funeral, we will have a gathering of blood relatives.
context-en2: Koichi's blood relatives are all tall.
context-en3: My dad isn’t a blood relative but I still think of him as my real dad.
meaning-exp: Your tribe's blood (lots of inbreeding) are the blood of your relatives. These are blood relatives.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I walked by a yakuza kingpin in the underpass.
context-en2: Between Koichi and Viet, which is the boss and which is the henchman?
context-en3: The chief will chew us out if we let it slip.
meaning-exp: Who is part parent to you? Your boss! They make it so you can take care of yourself by paying you, don't they? They'll break the legs of someone who crosses you. But they won't help you get back to sleep after you have nightmares. So they're only part like a parent.
reading-exp: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for ? and the on'yomi reading for ?. You've learned both of these so you should be able to read this already!

context-en: Your breath is so stinky that I could die.
context-en2: You knocked the breath out of me!
context-en3: Please do not breathe underwater.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You smell someone's icky (??) breath. It's gross. Your skin crawls and your eyes roll back in your head from the icky, icky smell. You might die.

context-en: Let's go into business and make a fortune together!
context-en2: My business has dried up recently because of that convenience store.
context-en3: After leaving school I went into business for myself, but I soon learned that running a business is no easy task.
meaning-exp: A place that sells merchandise is a business.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned them both already!

context-en: Thank you for laughing my cares away.
context-en2: Apparently he's got some worries.
context-en3: My biggest worry is volcanic ash falling over the city.
meaning-exp: The actions and things you have to ?? about are your cares and worries.
reading-exp: The reading is the reading of ?? (which you've hopefully gotten down okay by now) and ? using the (??) reading. It is rendaku'd, as well, so beware of the ?? (just another ???, ammiright?).

context-en: Today, I had my decayed tooth extracted at the dentist.
context-en2: Streptococcus mutans bacteria, the cause of tooth decay, can be transferred from adults to the kids around them as they grow up.
context-en3: I have so many cavities but I don’t have dental insurance and I can’t afford to get them treated.
meaning-exp: A tooth bug... Luckily, it's not some bug living in your tooth, though you can see why someone might think this is what happens. A tooth with a "bug" in it is a tooth with a cavity.
reading-exp: The readings are both kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with these kanji. Notice that ? turns to ?, though. Presumably this is because you might yell out "BAH!" when you find out you have a cavity.

context-en: Chapter one was good, but two was meh.
context-en2: This is gonna be the second chapter of your life, yeah?
context-en3: No way! Are you reading that book too? I’ve just finished chapter two. Don’t tell me anything if you’re farther than me.
meaning-exp: The ordinal prefix number two chapter has a much simpler way of describing it, which is chapter two.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Cheerful, Jovial, Merry, Lively, Spring Season, Warm Weather
context-en: You are really blessed to have such a cheerful wife who's good at cooking and loves her children.
context-en2: I got carried away by the warm spring weather and fell asleep before I knew it.
context-en3: My family is poor but jovial.
meaning-exp: If you have a spirit of sunshine you're a really cheerful person.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: This fairy tale will actually make you cry.
context-en2: I'm finally getting serious about writing children's stories.
context-en3: Miyazawa Kenji’s fairy tale "Night of the Festival" was my favorite story when I was a child.
meaning-exp: Don't think of this as a juvenile talk. Think of ? the vocab word, which means "story." If you do that, you get a "juvenile story." What's a juvenile story? It's a children's story.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What was the on'yomi for this kanji again?
context-en2: We usually read place names that we see for the first time with on'yomi.
context-en3: What’s the difference between the Chinese reading and the Japanese reading in the Japanese language?
meaning-exp: The sound reading. What could this be...? Wait a sec, think to Japanese and kanji. What's the reading that uses sounds from another place, specifically China? That's the Chinese reading, aka the on'yomi. Sounds familiar?
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the ???. ?? uses the kun'yomi, though, strangely. Way to mess up the one word that should be all on'yomi, Japan. Way. To. Go.

context-en: I'm fed up with the busy urban life.
context-en2: This is why I don't like city-bred people.
context-en3: I want to work in the city, not in the countryside like this.
meaning-exp: When metropolises meet they become a city. Usually a nice big one.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: City, A City, Town, Municipal, Urban
context-en: This bronze statue of Koichi has become the symbol of this city.
context-en2: I prefer life in the city as opposed to life in the countryside.
context-en3: Do you know any interesting urban legends?
meaning-exp: A metropolis city is a city. When you're referring to just a plain ol' city, sans name, you can use this word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: It's too cold to get out of bed.
context-en2: I had to wait an hour in this cold for the bus.
context-en3: I’m going to Hawaii not only to escape the cold, but to see my family.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cold? It's cold.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji (Samurai (??)). Remember?

context-en: My husband is just an ordinary office worker.
context-en2: We're people before we are employees.
context-en3: That employee got busted for drug possession.
meaning-exp: A "company" (??) member is someone who works at a company. This is a company employee. There are many of these in Japan. Most of them are drunk.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Conclusion, Final Result, The End, Punch Line, Slip, Omission, Outcome
context-en: I was interrupted before I said the punch line and I got annoyed.
context-en2: That was the outcome, huh?
context-en3: His speech didn't have much of a conclusion.
meaning-exp: When you're talking or writing a paper, the part that falls at the end is the conclusion.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

context-en: I've tried to grow daikon once, but they all withered and died.
context-en2: My family hangs up stockings and dried Japanese radishes for the Christmas season.
context-en3: Hey, check it out! These are really nice Japanese radishes. Do you want one of these too?
meaning-exp: This will be easier if you've seen or heard of daikon before. It's a really big root in the ground that's pretty delicious. It's known as daikon in the grocery stores for the most part, though occasionally you'll see it as Japanese radish instead.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. ? uses the ?? reading because if you try to put the whole thing in your mouth at once you'll probably end up choking and dying.

context-en: The water suddenly got deep, eh?
context-en2: I saw Koichi letting out a deep sigh, has something happened?
context-en3: Is it true that fish tend to maintain a deep connection with their parents, siblings, and high school friends?
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of deep? It's also deep.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Because the reading sounds just like a dirty word, and there may be innocent children about, I'll let you come up with your own mnemonic for this one. Maybe someone pushes you into a deep hole that will surely kill you so you yell something out as you fall down it?

context-en: Japan's deepest subway line is the Oedo line, which goes as low as 48 meters below ground.
context-en2: Jealousy is the deepest sin of human sins.
context-en3: Salmon and I had our wedding ceremony in a romantic hidden cave located at the deepest part of the ocean that light can still reach.
meaning-exp: The most deep is the deepest.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It's better to go see a dentist at least once every six months.
context-en2: Ms. Handa is too good for this dentist.
context-en3: I think he’s just a wannabe delinquent. I doubt he’ll end up being a real one because he’s still afraid of going to the dentist.
meaning-exp: You know that a ?? is a doctor. So what is a tooth doctor? A dentist. Seriously, don't forget to floss. ??? hate when you forget to floss.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This medicine will stimulate your digestion.
context-en2: Koichi's having a touch of diarrhea, so please have him eat something easy to digest.
context-en3: I haven’t finished digesting the ramen I ate for lunch.
meaning-exp: What is something that will first extinguish something and then change it? One thing I can think of is your body. It takes in food, extinguishes it in your stomach, then changes it into things your body can use (and then excrete). That's why this "extinguish-change" process is your digestion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This stock's price doubled just in two days.
context-en2: Don't forget to dilute the noodle soup base two times.
context-en3: Wow! Your brother weighs twice as much as you, huh?
meaning-exp: Something that is two times is double (or it is just simply two times). Of course, this all works with things like ??, ??, and ???? as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When I took the taxi, the driver happened to be Tofugu's Koichi.
context-en2: I ended up getting in an argument with the bus driver.
context-en3: The driver seemed okay but his car was totaled in the accident.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? has to do with driving, right? And you know that ? often has to do with a person doing something in words like these. So, a person who does driving is what? A driver.
reading-exp: The reading is all on'yomi, because it's jukugo. You should know the on'yomi reading of ? by now just by seeing similar word patterns to this one.

vocab-meaning: Employee, Staff, Company Employee, Company Staff
context-en: All of the staff know the ABCs of getting along with Koichi.
context-en2: How are things with that employee lately? Patch things up yet?
context-en3: The employees in this company are all weird and wonderful.
meaning-exp: The company members are the employees and the staff.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I don't want to lose my racial identity.
context-en2: This ethnic group is known for being very cautious.
context-en3: India has a lot of ethnic diversity but I wonder if all of them still eat curry.
meaning-exp: A peoples tribe (or tribe of peoples) is a group that all stick together. They are one single ethnic group. What's your ???
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Evil Woman, Wicked Woman, Bad Woman
context-en: That bitch sure has good ears!
context-en2: She is a wicked woman, but is always on time.
context-en3: The evil woman took my breath away. I was crazy about her.
meaning-exp: A bad woman is an evil woman. Surprisingly, "mother in law" is not one of the meanings for this word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I feel like I haven't had enough exercise recently.
context-en2: I want to exercise, but I don't have time.
context-en3: I read neither books, nor newspapers, nor magazines because I like exercising more than reading.
meaning-exp: When you carry your movements (or carry something along with your movements, like weights, for example) you are doing exercise. Speaking of which, perhaps you've been studying kanji a little too much lately. Time to get up and do some squats.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I expected more from the grad student.
context-en2: The new snack that I bought and had sent all the way from Japan the other day was not as good as I anticipated.
context-en3: Wall Street always needs top-level talent and I’m pretty sure that Koichi will be able to live up to those expectations.
meaning-exp: For a period of time you have to wait. During this waiting period, you are expecting or anticipating something to happen. Waiting, expecting, waiting, expecting...
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: There was a carpet of fallen leaves that stretched out around us.
context-en2: I picked up some fallen leaves and made tempura with them.
context-en3: "Look, when it started I was just trying to be nice to Fugu because he was my big sister’s boyfriend. Then, one thing led to another and before I knew it, we were... raking fallen leaves together." "T-Tuna. Why would you do that?" "Salmon, wait. We only did it once. It didn’t mean anything to me."
meaning-exp: The leaf that falls are fallen leaves.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is a bit strange. You'll have to pull from your knowledge of ??? and use that for the first half. Then, ? is rendaku'd to ?. Because, when a leaf falls, Scrooge says "BAH! Humbug!" (probably because he's losing money).

context-en: I want to get married and build a loving home someday.
context-en2: My hobby is to pick up each household member's waste with my bare hands.
context-en3: Compared to Japanese women, foreign women tend to be pretty strict about separating family time and working time.
meaning-exp: This is a strange one. Your house garden is your family. Why? Think of your house as a garden. It grows things, like children. It also grows adults, too. It grows a family.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My family grows a lot of vegetables in our garden, things like cucumbers, tomatoes, and zucchinis.
context-en2: When a member of an employee's immediate family dies, the employee is entitled to leave on any normal working day that falls within the three-day period immediately following the day the death occurred.
context-en3: I wanna tell you about my family vacation in Japan some time.
meaning-exp: Your house tribe is your family. They live in the same house as you and they're part of your "tribe." This is closer than family, though (depending on how you look at family). This is your immediate family because these are the people you live with and give birth to, etc.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My father is a super weak wrestler.
context-en2: This morning, I saw my father secretly crying in his room.
context-en3: My father eats his dinner by himself in the alley because everyone in my family hates him.
meaning-exp: Your father parent is your father.
reading-exp: The reading here is pretty weird. It's all kun'yomi. My guess is this translates literally to "father parent" (two different words, therefore uses the other readings). You should know the readings of these two separate words, though. It is ? (??) and ? (??).

context-en: I like the candy apples they sell from food stands at festivals.
context-en2: At the last Sunday's festival, me and my boyfriend held hands for the first time.
context-en3: Many Japanese festivals have connections to Buddhism or Shintoism.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: While at a festival, a guy named Matt has to go to the bathroom. Matt’s urine (???) has been filling up his bladder ever since he began drinking that 64oz cup of soda. Matt’s urine is ready to bust out at any moment. He really has to go to the bathroom.

vocab-meaning: First Floor, Floor One, First Story, Ground Floor
context-en: Do you have those snakes on the first floor?
context-en2: The ground floor is still wet.
context-en3: "Where should I put my stuff?" "Here, the first floor, the second floor, anywhere. You can put them any place you’d like." "Okay. Thank you."
meaning-exp: The one floor is the first floor (or floor one). Pretty simple. Unless you're British, that is. For you this is the ground floor!
reading-exp: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo kanji. Be careful of the ? though. It gets shortened and has a little ? in there.

context-en: Tofugu got first place five consecutive times in tournaments for unique Japanese learning tools.
context-en2: Out of the whole Tofugu team, I personally want Kristen to drive around in a moped the most.
context-en3: Hiro had been the top sales person in the company for five consecutive years until Akira joined the company.
meaning-exp: The ordinal number prefix one rank. Basically, this means "first rank" or first place.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: First Rate, First Class, Top Notch, Top Grade
context-en: That's something only first-rate pianists can do.
context-en2: My sister fell in love with a wealthy, first-class gentleman.
context-en3: Koichi is now a member of the upperclass. He will meet a bunch of celebrities and start going to champagne parties soon.
meaning-exp: This is a weird one. You have one stream. This is first rate stream material we have here, though. If you think about it, if you only have one stream (instead of a ton of streams), you can put all your effort and energy into it. When you do that, you're making sure it is a first rate stream in terms of quality and anything else.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "Which floor?" "Fourth please." "This elevator doesn't stop on that floor."
context-en2: Koichi lives on the top floor of a ninety-nine story apartment building.
context-en3: I live on the thirteenth floor of this apartment.
meaning-exp: You know that the kanji refers to a floor (as in the "fifth floor"). This word represents the version that comes after a number, shown with a ?. Essentially, this has the same meaning as the kanji you learned, making it nice and easy.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Don't type in the ? or you'll get it wrong!

vocab-meaning: Forty Second Floor, Floor Forty Two, Forty Second Story
context-en: Let's race to the forty-second floor!
context-en2: Koichi owns a forty-two-story condominium in Tokyo.
context-en3: It’s pretty annoying that there’s a lot of bureaucratic red tape involved in moving, and to make matters worse, sometimes the person in charge has an attitude problem. However, the worst part of my moving this time was that the elevator was out of service when I moved in and my apartment was on the forty-second floor.
meaning-exp: You know that ??? means "forty two." So, as long as you know floor you'll know this means forty-second floor.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm gonna level the ground in the yard today.
context-en2: I grow vegetables in our garden.
context-en3: I have a beautiful garden but my neighbor’s chickens keep eating my flowers.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add the meaning yard to your memory bank as well, if you'd like.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your garden. It doesn't meet your expectations so you decide it's time to get a newer (??) garden. Tear it all down, folks! Getting a newer garden, here!

vocab-meaning: Gathering, Meeting, Assembly, Party, Collection, Get Together
context-en: There’s a get-together with people from the lab today.
context-en2: Not many people showed up at today's drinking party and it was also very disorganized, eh?
context-en3: My younger brother brought his girlfriend to our New Year's gathering.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji gather, so it means gathering.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

context-en: This graduate student has a green thumb.
context-en2: That player who hit a grand slam is apparently an actual grad student.
context-en3: What kinds of things do graduate students do?
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ??? means "graduate school" and ??? means "college student?" Well smush them together and you have a graduate student!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I would like to visit the port city of Veracruz.
context-en2: Due to heavy rain, the road to the harbor is closed.
context-en3: There was a mysterious ship drifting in the harbor.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This is a single kanji with no okurigana, so it's using the kun'yomi reading.
