You don't know this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go down to the harbor and speak the secret password me natto (???) to buy some fresh natto. Imagine the salty air hitting your face as you whisper, "me natto." Now eat that yummy natto by the water! Mmmm!

vocab-meaning: Hearable, Audible, To Be Able To Hear, To Be Heard, To Be Audible, Can Hear
context-en: If you could hear me, you should've said something!
context-en2: You heard my fart, didn't you?
context-en3: I understand it sounds harsh, but I’m up to my neck in lame excuses.
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? by now hopefully. This is similar, but instead of meaning "to hear" it means hearable (or to be audible). Just think about that ?? hanging off there as the voice you can hear.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so if you know the reading of that word, you can apply it here.

context-en: Are there good mountains to climb in Hiroshima?
context-en2: I'm heading into the city from Hiroshima airport by city bus.
context-en3: The atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki instantly killed more than 100,000 people.
meaning-exp: The wide island... this isn't helpful on its own, but this wide island is Hiroshima (heard of it?). When you do the reading it will make more sense.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of both of these which is what you learned with the individual kanji. Just make sure you know those readings and you'll be able to read this.

context-en: This onsen is open for people with tattoos too.
context-en2: Let's go to hot spring after sweating a little bit from some light exercise.
context-en3: Neither my dad nor mom likes hot springs.
meaning-exp: A warm spring (like the water kind of spring) is a hot spring. These are really nice. You should go to them in Japan.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you wash it with hot water, you might be able to remove it.
context-en2: After going number two, Koichi washes his hands with hot water and soap.
context-en3: Could you boil some water?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: It's so hot I'm about to melt.
context-en2: It has been hot these days in Japan.
context-en3: It’s too hot and humid! I can’t sleep in this heat. Let’s go to the pool!
meaning-exp: This is the adjective form of hot... but we're going to call it hot weather. Why? Because there's a difference between something that's hot and the weather or atmosphere being hot. This is that kind of hot, as in..."Damn, man, it's hot out here!"
reading-exp: This uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, so you're good to go here!

context-en: Leave it to me.
context-en2: It was I who made the pun, "I get compensation from a doctor."
context-en3: This is my canned coffee!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
reading-exp: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. I certainly like that and I bet you do too.

context-en: If you miss the interest payment, Viet will probably bring some of his yakuza friends to your place.
context-en2: Koichi has enough money in the bank to live on his interest.
context-en3: I’m afraid there is no one here who can answer your question right now, but you can also check your interest rate online, if you can connect to the Internet.
meaning-exp: You receive profit at every breath. What kind of profit is this? It's interest. As time goes by and as you take more breaths you gain more bank interest.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: In The Beginning, To Begin With, To Start With
context-en: For this problem, please begin by listening to the question.
context-en2: Koichi's surprise birthday party went really well except that Kanae spilled soy sauce on his birthday cake in the beginning.
context-en3: What are the first words at the beginning of the Bible?
meaning-exp: You know the kanji part means begin. The ? on the end refers to a direction. So, think of this like "the direction of the beginning" which would be where things all started. That's why this word/phrase means "in the beginning."
reading-exp: The reading is kun'yomi (look at all that hiragana!) but that's the reading you learned with the word ???, so have no fear, you got it!

context-en: You can’t wear swimsuits on this island's beaches.
context-en2: My wife is the most beautiful woman on this island.
context-en3: I’m going to have you live on this island for a week.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: Please express your current feelings with kaomoji.
context-en2: I secretly read Viet's letter to Koichi, but everything was written in kaomoji.
context-en3: Don’t use kaomoji when you’re emailing a superior!
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ?? can mean "characters?" Well make a face out of those characters and you've made a kaomoji! ?(??? ) ?
reading-exp: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for ? added to the jukugo word ?? that you already learned. You've learned these readings before, so reading this word should be nice and easy!

context-en: The JR ad "That's it! Let's go to Kyoto." made me want to go to Kyoto, but I didn't have that kind of money.
context-en2: When I go to Kyoto, I want to eat tofu skin.
context-en3: Koichi has already left for Kyoto today. Shall I have him call you back first thing tomorrow morning?
meaning-exp: The capital metropolis back in the day was Kyoto. Now of course the capital is Tokyo, but kanji doesn't know this. That's why Kyoto is the capital metropolis!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What time was the last train?
context-en2: I've gotta go because it's almost time for the last train.
context-en3: "If you ever miss the last train, you can always call me." "Thanks, I’ll keep that in mind."
meaning-exp: We've seen a few times where ? refers to a train. They're big deals, after all, and use a ton of electricity. So, the end train for this word would refer to the last train.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you're lucky, you may be able to meet Koichi from Tofugu.
context-en2: I was just lucky.
context-en3: I might have run out of luck though, and I don't want to use it up on something like this.
meaning-exp: This takes the luck meaning from the kanji. Think of it this way: If you're "carrying" you're going to create your own luck. Now nobody will mess with you, kanji gangstah. You carry guns and have a ton of luck because of it.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! How... shall I say... luck-filled?

context-en: I caught this blowfish underneath the WaniKani bridge in the main stream of the Tofu River.
context-en2: Koichi is known for having a big influence on mainstream fashion.
context-en3: When you say mainstream Japanese literature, who is the first author that comes to mind?
meaning-exp: The origin stream, that's where everything comes from. That is the mainstream.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That member seems to be a huge worrywart.
context-en2: You may not be able to see it, but there's one more little member over there.
context-en3: Do you have a membership card?
meaning-exp: If you meet enough members you will become a member yourself!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: As a merchant, I'm thrilled.
context-en2: My dad is a wholesale trader.
context-en3: He told me that he was a shopkeeper, but I found out that he was actually a poor homeless man who supported himself by collecting empty cans.
meaning-exp: A merchandise person is a merchant. You want to buy something or you just looking?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Middle Of The Night, Late At Night
context-en: What's up this late at night?
context-en2: I got a bit hungry in the middle of the night.
context-en3: The environmental refugee bears crossed the border late in the night to find something to eat in a new country.
meaning-exp: The deep night is the middle of the night. It doesn't get any deeper than that before you start coming out of the night to start the next day.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I want to make up with my mother.
context-en2: My mother and her boyfriend ended up breaking up because apparently they had been gradually growing apart.
context-en3: "I’m sorry but I have to cancel lunch tomorrow. My mother got sick." "It’s no big deal. Let’s meet another time. I hope your mom gets well soon."
meaning-exp: The mother parent is the mother.
reading-exp: The reading for this is strange. It's the kun'yomi vocab reading, probably because the literal translation is "mother parent" and therefore consists of a couple words combined together into one concept. So, make sure you know the separate word readings of ? and ?. If you do, you should be able to read this too.

context-en: I want to try climbing Mt. Fuji.
context-en2: I never want to climb a mountain again.
context-en3: "How about we go mountain climbing?" "Well I don’t know about that."
meaning-exp: Climb a mountain. That is mountain climbing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note this uses the alternative ? reading, not to be confused with ?? (actually, very confusing, sorry!). Just imagine you cut your toe off with an ice pick while mountain climbing. You know it's a short ? because your toe is now short. And ?? becomes ?? thanks to our old friend rendaku.

context-en: I don't have any plans for that festival day.
context-en2: Do you have to work even though it's a national holiday?
context-en3: I forgot it was a holiday and I came to the office.
meaning-exp: The day you have a festival is a national holiday. That way everyone can come to celebrate without worrying about going to school or work. This is also known as a festival day (pretty obvious, right?).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: This job requires patience, huh?
context-en2: The reason for failure in most cases is a lack of perseverance.
context-en3: Keep studying Japanese persistently and you’ll be fluent someday.
meaning-exp: The root of your energy. You have to dig deep into your energy, all the way to the origin and source of it, to have enough patience to deal with this dumb kid who's eating away at your not-root energy. It's all you have, and you need to use it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can't sleep much during exams.
context-en2: I spent a period of my life in a deep mountain.
context-en3: We're selling Koichi's mustache for a limited time only.
meaning-exp: A period of time interval is still a period or interval of time.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Apparently Koichi can understand what plants are saying.
context-en2: This is mulch from the vegetation.
context-en3: I don’t have a green thumb but I like to grow plants.
meaning-exp: Plant things are plants or vegetation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You'll need to remember the ? reading as ??, though. Why? Because you like looking at plant butts. You get off on it. You're weird like that. Imagine this.

context-en: We have to fix our roof next year.
context-en2: It's leaking because we have a hole in our roof.
context-en3: Please clear the snow off the roof by noon.
meaning-exp: The root of your roof is still your roof. If it helps, imagine roots growing out of your roof. They protect you from the rain.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings. The kun'yomi for ? is ?. For a mnemonic, we'll use the sound a horse makes, neigh (?). Why is the horse neigh-ing? It's stuck on the roof.

context-en: First of all, you are fundamentally wrong.
context-en2: That couple had fundamentally different ideas about their kid's education.
context-en3: Kristen doesn’t eat bacon; where do you think the root of this problem lies?
meaning-exp: The root origin is the root of something. Possibly even more root than root, but we'll stick with root.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful, ? is ??, which is a weird rendaku.

context-en: You can eat the roots of this flower.
context-en2: It seems that this problem has really deep roots.
context-en3: You might think he’s a great person but he’s really a horrible man at heart.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: The root you have is a ne-root, used to perform necromancy (it's why it's called a ne-root). Grind it up and use it on some dead bodies to bring them back to life (in your imagination, of course).

context-en: A seaman will come pick you up this evening, okay?
context-en2: My grandfather was a sailor in the navy.
context-en3: Could I move into the room where that mariner checked out of today?
meaning-exp: A member of a boat is called a sailor.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I am planning to take Japanese and kimono classes with Fugu next semester as well.
context-en2: After this term ends, Koichi and Koichiko will have their wedding ceremony in Hawaii.
context-en3: Final exams are held in March so there's still plenty of time to prepare.
meaning-exp: The study period of time isn't the pitiful amount of time you spend studying. It's something much bigger: the school term. Ugh, how much longer is this study period of time???
reading-exp: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo word but ?? gets shortened to ??, so be careful. Maybe you just wish the school term would get shorter which is why you shortened ?? like that?

vocab-meaning: Second Floor, Floor Two, Second Story
context-en: The dentist is on the second floor of this building.
context-en2: We bought a second story home.
context-en3: Every afternoon I go to the same classroom on the second floor and teach two hours of English.
meaning-exp: The two floor is the second floor. Going up!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Shop Staff, Store Staff, Store Employee, Shop Employee, Clerk, Salesperson, Shop Assistant
context-en: I used to have a part time job where I taught English to the younger brother of that clerk.
context-en2: That shop employee was a real kidder, wasn't he?
context-en3: Well, while standing in the checkout line I heard one of the salespeople yell, "Shoplifter! Grab him!" so I grabbed him.
meaning-exp: The shop member is someone who is a "member" (aka employed by) the shop. This is the shop staff.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Isn't that skirt is a bit too short?
context-en2: The baby's short, flailing arms and legs are so cute!
context-en3: Wah! I didn’t know your tail was shorter than mine.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of short? It's short.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Please accept my apology in advance for this one, but if you're very short you may be a midget. And if you're a midget you probably drive a midget car (???).

context-en: First, please set a few short-term goals.
context-en2: I can't memorize this much in such a short period of time. My head is going to explode!
context-en3: My father told me that companies that cut back on leadership training to save money in the short term are a penny wise and pound foolish.
meaning-exp: The short period of time is the short term. You know not to think short term anyways, right? You're learning kanji, after all.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Where did you buy that tanto?
context-en2: Viet cooks very well with a short sword.
context-en3: My mother stabbed my father with a dagger and he died.
meaning-exp: The short sword is the short sword. What's another word for a short sword? It's a dagger.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Tonight is very quiet because my son is cramming for the exam tomorrow.
context-en2: My son works efficiently and goes home earlier than anyone else.
context-en3: I have the most beastly son. He sneakily ate up the rest of my cake last night.
meaning-exp: The breath child (that lets you release your breath when it's born) is a son. Nowadays it's cool to have a girl, but back in the day you wanted a son to carry on your underwater basket weaving legacy. That's why this is a son.
reading-exp: The reading of this is messed up. ? is ?, that should be okay. ? is ?? for some reason though. Why? Because you gave birth to a son, but he was a moose (??). You better hold that breath again, because this is not what you wanted.

context-en: Dammit! I hit the ball into a bunker.
context-en2: What was the formula for the volume of a sphere?
context-en3: Hey, I got a new baseball. Do you want to play catch with me?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Another meaning I'm going to add is sports ball because this is the word used for balls in various sports (soccer, baseball, etc).
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're holding onto a sports ball in your hand, let's say it's a baseball for this mnemonic's sake. You throw it at your friend who's going to catch it. As it flies through the air, though, it transforms into a tomahawk (??). Imagine your shock and fear as you see this happening, flying towards your friend! It's going to stick in his forehead. He can't catch this with his glove! Also notice that it has the same reading as the vocab word ?. So, if you know that one, you may know this one too! They're kind of similar. This can be read ??? too, if you're talking about more of a globe sphere than the ball sphere you throw.

context-en: We're drinking water from the spring.
context-en2: There are a lot of geese in that spring.
context-en3: Wow! You look beautiful! Did you go on a special diet? Or did you find the Fountain of Youth?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're looking at a natural spring in the ground. Water is bubbling up, but then something changes. It looks a bit clogged... something is poking out. Then, all of a sudden, Mario flies out of the springs, falls in front of you and yells: "izumeeeee (???), Mario!"

context-en: That office worker always got tasks done steadily.
context-en2: It seems like you're making steady progress on the project.
context-en3: The arrangements for it have been moving along steadily.
meaning-exp: Something you wear, and wear again, is something you steadily wear. You do it so often, it's reliable. Also, if you wear something this much it's steadily wearing away too.
reading-exp: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: This vapors coming out of Viet's forehead smell nice for some reason.
context-en2: That's still steaming hot, so be careful.
context-en3: To make good sushi rice, you need to mix vinegar into steaming hot, freshly cooked rice, using a paddle. Believe it or not, it actually takes skill to mix the vinegar into the rice without crushing the individual grains.
meaning-exp: Hot water's energy isn't the hot water itself, it's what comes out of it (when it's boiling, for example). This is the steam and vapor.
reading-exp: The ? part of the reading makes sense. The ? part for ? is a bit of an exception. Just think of yourself standing in the steams and vapors. You're getting all hot and sweaty, but the feeling makes you incredibly happy and gay (?). Then someone asks, as they look at you in the steam: "Hey, you gay?" (??). You answer however you want to answer.

context-en: Thank you so much. I've been learning a lot from you.
context-en2: I've been slacking off and haven't been studying as much recently.
context-en3: Keep up your English language studies. I’m always working on my Japanese too, so I know how hard it is.
meaning-exp: Your exertion is strong. You'd think this means you're working hard or something, but it means studies (like studies you have for a test or something). So for this, just imagine yourself exerting yourself really strongly on your homework. These are your studies / what you study.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I fell in love with Koichi's sunshine-like smile.
context-en2: Do you happen to know what the sun's temperature is?
context-en3: The symbol of Expo ’70 was the Tower of the Sun, created by Taro Okamoto, and it’s still standing in the Expo Commemoration Park in Suita, Osaka, Japan.
meaning-exp: The fat sunshine thing up in the sky... what is it called? Oh, that's right. It's the sun.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The population of Tashirojima is less than one hundred.
context-en2: There are no gas stations on Tashirojima.
context-en3: The most famous "cat island" is the island Tashirojima in Japan's Miyagi prefecture.
meaning-exp: It's an island where they use cats as a substitute for rice! Lovely Tashirojima. Don't worry, they don't eat them! ...or, wait, do they?
reading-exp: This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned this particular kun'yomi for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: When you go to Tashirojima, make sure you visit the old woman. You know what woman I'm talking about, the one who starred on Murder she wrote (??). She writes a lot about cats now, I guess.

context-en: I'm looking for a shop where I can buy tools for tea ceremonies.
context-en2: This water is known to be good for tea ceremony.
context-en3: In the world of tea ceremonies there is a saying, "Ichi-go ichi-e," which means "to treasure every encounter." This saying was also used as the subtitle for Japan’s release of Forrest Gump.
meaning-exp: The hot water of tea. That is part of the ceremony that goes into the tea ceremony.
reading-exp: The readings are both the readings you learned with the kanji. Now you can spend a little more time drinking tea at a tea ceremony and a little less time trying to remember kanji readings.

context-en: Do you think American and Japanese people feel temperature differently?
context-en2: Can you raise the temperature on the AC up to 24??
context-en3: It’s said to be very difficult to make sake because the slightest change in the weather or temperature during brewing can affect its taste.
meaning-exp: The warm degrees is how many degrees warm it is in here. Of course, there can be very few warm degrees as well, making it very cold. What is all this? It's the temperature.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The temperature fell suddenly.
context-en2: Today's highest temperature will be 40 degrees.
context-en3: There is a large temperature gap between morning and night.
meaning-exp: The energy of the warmth will cause the temperature to go up and down. Energy goes up? Higher temperature because of more movement and activity. Energy goes down? Well, temperature gets colder and slower.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You can not buy the Earth with money.
context-en2: I wonder what Koichi is doing right now, halfway around the globe.
context-en3: Who came up with the name Earth?
meaning-exp: The earth sphere! It's where we live and the planet we call home. It's the earth!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: The End, End, The Finish, Finish
context-en: This is the end.
context-en2: All is well that ends well, right?
context-en3: Work ends this week and Christmas holidays starts next week! Aww I can't wait for that.
meaning-exp: By now you should know that ??? means "to end" or "to finish." So what is this noun-version of that word? It would be the end or the finish.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ???. So long as you know that word, you can learn this word's reading as well!

vocab-meaning: The First, First, Number One, Best
context-en: You should put your health first.
context-en2: My first preference is Feb 14th and my second preference is Feb 21st.
context-en3: What was your first impression of the famous blowfish family?
meaning-exp: The ordinal number prefix one refers to the first thing. This is the number one place you can get. In fact, it's simply the best.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Today was the worst day ever.
context-en2: The worst case scenario is that I just have to sleep less and work, but it'll be okay.
context-en3: "My car was stolen last night." "Oh, no! That’s the worst!"
meaning-exp: The most bad is the worst. At least all there is is up now, right?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is probably my third favorite Beatles's song.
context-en2: If you are looking for Koichi, he's reading Harry Potter on the third toilet from the left.
context-en3: Did you know that Japan has the third highest number of inhabited islands in the world, after Indonesia and the Philippines?
meaning-exp: Remember ???? This is just like that, but with three, making it the third thing or simply the third.
reading-exp: Use your knowledge of the reading for ??? to remember the reading for this word as well.
kanji-name: Three, Number In A Series, Eye

vocab-meaning: Time, Season, Period, Time Period, Period Of Time
context-en: Why don't we just wait and see until the time is right?
context-en2: Hurricane season is just around the corner.
context-en3: It’s just a phase Takeshi is going through. Don’t they say people living in a foreign country usually experience a period of culture shock?
meaning-exp: The time period of time is a period of time of time. If anything, just notice how many times the word "time" is used and you'll remember this word means time. The meaning is a specific type of time, though. This is talking about a season or period of time, not the concept of time itself. That would be ?? or something.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: WaniKani's review count has quadrupled.
context-en2: Why not just pay me ten times more than usual on Christmas day at least?
context-en3: Since the introduction and subsequent spread of conveyer belt sushi shops, salmon consumption in Japan has tripled.
meaning-exp: Throw this onto a number and you have yourself the number of times something has increased. For example, 3? means something increased "three fold."
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Omit the ? when writing out the answer, though. That just represents that there should be something before the kanji in this word when being used.

context-en: I've just arrived at Narita Airport.
context-en2: Let me know when you figure out what time you will arrive.
context-en3: The train didn’t arrive on time.
meaning-exp: This word is tough, because there's another word in this level (??) that means "to wear" that is so similar. This word, however, means to arrive. You should have seen that meaning with the kanji ? as well, so I hope that helps. To differentiate between this and ??, though, zoom in on the ?. You want to be cool (?) so you arrive to the party late.
reading-exp: This uses a different kun'yomi reading than the one you just learned (sorry). To help you, think about this: You wanted to arrive on time but you showed up late. How late were you? Two (?) hours and two minutes late, to be exact.

vocab-meaning: To Begin, Something Begins, To Start, Something Starts
context-en: What time does the movie start?
context-en2: A fierce economic war between America and China has begun.
context-en3: The sound of the rifle means the pie eating contest has started.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something starts. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to start.
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as ???.

context-en: Going up this long, steep slope is really tough, eh?
context-en2: Koichi climbed up the tree as fast as a monkey and came down with bananas without breaking a sweat.
context-en3: A dream of mine is to climb Mt. Fuji at least once in my lifetime.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means climb so the verb vocab version would be to climb (or to ascend), if that's the kind of thing you're into.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This has the same reading as ?? which you learned all that time ago in Level 1. If you can remember that, you can remember this one!

vocab-meaning: To Come Together, To Gather, To Be Gathered
context-en: This much money was gathered by crowdfunding.
context-en2: The company retreat gives all the workers a chance to come together.
context-en3: Look! A group of miscreants are gathering over there!
meaning-exp: I bet you remember ??? which means "to collect." This is similar to that, except you're not doing the action of collecting, it's just happening. Instead of "to collect" it's to come together. You can remember this because a herd of Marus (the cat) will come together into one place if they sense a box there.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??? so if you know that word you'll know how to read this word as well.

context-en: Don't demand too much from him, okay?
context-en2: They are demanding we compromise on the price.
context-en3: When he demanded money from me I told him to kiss my ass. Then I was beaten up and he forcibly stole the money from my wallet.
meaning-exp: You hopefully know that ?? is a demand. When you make that a verb it becomes to demand.
reading-exp: The reading is just the vocab word ??. It's also the regular on'yomi jukugo reading.

vocab-meaning: To Drop Something, To Let Fall, To Drop, To Fall
context-en: This morning, I accidentally dropped a raw egg under Koichi's desk.
context-en2: You should immediately stop doing things that will make people lose faith in you.
context-en3: "Today I bought a book called 'How to Make a Man Fall In Love With You,' but I lost it somewhere on the way back home." "Aww. That’s too bad, but don’t be too disappointed. Your day will come."
meaning-exp: You've seen how ??? means "to fall down." Now you're doing the action of "falling something down," aka you're dropping it. You can remember this because you kind of toss (??) something and it drops to the ground, making this word mean to drop something.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ???. So long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here, too.

vocab-meaning: To Extinguish, To Erase, To Turn Off
context-en: I have a past that I want to erase.
context-en2: I erased all the data by mistake.
context-en3: After you leave the classroom, please don’t forget to turn off the light.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extinguish so the verb vocab version is to extinguish. You can also use this word to refer to turning something off (like lights). Technically you're extinguishing the lights or power, right?
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The kettle is getting too hot so it catches on fire. You have to extinguish the flames before your house burns down too, just because of this stupid little kettle.

vocab-meaning: To Fall Over, To Fall Down
context-en: It was funny that the player fell over after hitting a game-ending home run.
context-en2: Today, Koichi didn't cry even though he fell down for the first time in a long time.
context-en3: Koichi had almost fallen to the ground, but Viet, who was wearing a Superman costume, saved him.
meaning-exp: Do you remember the word ???? This is kind of similar, instead of rolling, this is more for when something falls and hits the ground. It means to fall over or to fall down. Just imagine someone falling off a chair face first into the dirt and making a ? sound.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ???. Hopefully you know that one well enough to associate it with this one, meaning you can read them both.

vocab-meaning: To Flow, To Flush, To Drain, To Pour, To Float, To Wash Away, To Set Afloat
context-en: You forgot to flush the toilet, didn't you?
context-en2: Do you know why they are pouring oil over the swamp?
context-en3: A Tofugu custom involves cutting paper into the shape of fugu and setting them afloat down a stream on Koichi’s birthday.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stream, but what in the world could "to stream" be (remember, there weren't streams of StarCraft II games back in the day when this word was made up)? Well, let's think water. If you're streaming water, it's going to flow. Alternatively, to flush works too.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you do with someone who is a nagger (one who nags)? You have to flush them down the toilet. Imagine someone nagging you to do your chores so you flush them down the toilet, somehow.

vocab-meaning: Tokyo Metropolis, Tokyo Metro, Tokyo Metropolitan Area, Tokyo Metro Area
context-en: There are a lot of first-rate restaurants in the Tokyo Metropolitan Area.
context-en2: Taro Yamada (pseudonym), who is in his 30s and a salaryman in the Tokyo Metropolis, is working in an industry that is notorious for its hard work and long working hours.
context-en3: The leaves started falling earlier this year than last year in Tokyo Metro’s Sumida Ward, where the Tokyo Sky Tree stands.
meaning-exp: The Tokyo Metropolis is, of course, the Tokyo Metropolis. Technically this is one of Japan's prefectures, but it's called a "Metropolis" instead. It's the capital and the largest city in all of Japan!
reading-exp: The reading is just ?? and ? (?). Really it's all just the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so you can think of it that way as well.

context-en: Something moved over there.
context-en2: Tofugu's servers operate twenty-four hours a day, so it can always be accessed.
context-en3: Shoot! My computer doesn’t work. How did this happen?!
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means move so the verb vocab version is to move.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is telling you to move. They are saying "you go (??) over there. Move! Move!" If it helps, have them pronounce "You go" more like "Ugo."

vocab-meaning: To Occur, To Happen, To Take Place
context-en: I never expected something like this would happen.
context-en2: Please calm down and think carefully about what's taken place.
context-en3: "Hey, do you want to kiss me?" "Absolutely no way would I ever want to kiss you in a million years. That would never happen even if heaven and earth were turned upside down."
meaning-exp: You know that ??? means "to wake up." This word, however, means to occur. Think of it this way. When an action "wakes up" in a way it is occurring as well. That's why this word means to occur. Just imagine a core (??) of uranium just occurring out of nowhere to help you to remember this word.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji and the same as ??? too, meaning you should be able to put together the reading on your own.

context-en: Your fly is open.
context-en2: What time does this shop open?
context-en3: "Excuse me. Is the Tofugu Museum open for business tomorrow?" "Yes, but it might be quite busy, so I suggest you get there early." "Okay, thank you."
meaning-exp: You should know ??? by now. This word is similar to that, except it has to do with when things are just open. It's the same thing, though. The meaning is also to open.
reading-exp: The reading can come from ???. So if you know the reading of that word (I hope you do!) then you can apply that knowledge here.

context-en: Her seventh tooth came in.
context-en2: I smoked so much that my teeth are yellow now.
context-en3: I’m thinking about buying one of those electric toothbrushes, but they’re so expensive.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading that you learned with the kanji is the same as this one. HA! Take that, kanji.

context-en: There are some cacti planted on the rooftop of the Tofugu office.
context-en2: I think you've planted more than enough tulips.
context-en3: Where do you plan on planting that seed?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plant, so the verb version is to plant.
reading-exp: You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decided to plant an uni (?) tree in your backyard. That's right, you can plant uni and they'll grow like fruit off a really spiky tree. Just picture it. And then you'll get to eat all the uni you want!

context-en: My stomach growled.
context-en2: Somebody's phone is ringing.
context-en3: Thunder rumbled but it didn’t rain.
meaning-exp: This is a lot like ??, which means "to chirp" (or some other animal noise). This has to do with noises too, but not so much animal and more like bells (including telephones). This word means to ring. If it helps, think of the ? as a hint, kind of like the first sound of the word "ring" (?). So, ? = "ring" and it's a verb, so to ring.
reading-exp: The reading can come from ??. So long as you know the reading for that word you can know the reading for this word as well.

context-en: When you sing, you should keep your abs tight.
context-en2: I don't like singing in front of people.
context-en3: "It’s raining outside. I just want to stay in and sing." "I’ll tell you what. Let’s stay in tonight and I’ll make dinner for you if you’ll sing songs for me."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means song so the verb vocab version of this is to sing, because you don't "to song," you "to sing."
reading-exp: Awesomely, this uses the same reading as the reading for the vocab words ?. Just throw the ? onto the end and you have yourself the reading. So, sing your heart out and learn this word easily. "IIIIiiIIIiiiII WILLL ALLllwaYYYs Loovvve YoOooOOooooOOOO ?!"

vocab-meaning: To Suit, To Come Together, To Meet, To Match
context-en: Red wine pairs well with meat dishes.
context-en2: You should try it on to see if it suits you.
context-en3: Indian cuisine in America is altered quite a bit from how it’s prepared in India to suit American tastes.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suit so the verb version is to suit. This word also means to come together as well. Presumably when something suits something else, it comes together with it flawlessly. That's why this word also has this other meaning (and it will be important for future vocab as well).
reading-exp: You want to find a pet to suit your personal style, so you get matched with an aardvark (?). An aardvark will match the ant mounds you use for chairs and couches, it's the perfect match.

speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Godan verb
context-en: I was waiting for five hours at the cafe, but he didn’t come.
context-en2: I'll be waiting for you at Starbucks.
context-en3: Wait! I might have forgotten my wallet at home.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wait so the verb version is to wait.
reading-exp: You need to wait for your mama (?) all the time. You want to go out? You have to wait for mama to drive you. Want to eat dinner? You have to wait for mama to make you food. Hmm. Maybe all this waiting is really a you problem.

context-en: I was so freaked out that I even wore my t-shirt inside out.
context-en2: Koichi is wearing an apron when he comes to office every day.
context-en3: I wore a knee-length black dress at my boyfriend’s birthday party the day before yesterday.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wear so this word means to wear or to put on. You'll need to differentiate it from ?? which means (to arrive), though. Just think of how the ? is the rude guy trying to get you to wear things you don't like wearing.
reading-exp: What do you want to wear today? How about a dress made entirely of keys (?)? Feel the metal on your skin and the weight on your shoulders. It's not a comfortable thing to put on. Maybe just stick with wearing a single key around your neck next time.

vocab-meaning: To Worry, To Be Concerned, To Be Anxious
context-en: Safety is that company's first priority, so you don't have to be concerned about that.
context-en2: If you are anxious about Tofugu's performance, please buy our tenugui.
context-en3: The snow is falling heavily outside and the roads are getting pretty icy, so I’m worried about being able to drive up the hill to my boyfriend’s house.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "a worry." What about the verb version of that? It would be to worry.
reading-exp: The reading comes straight from ?? so try to make sure you know that word so you can read this word! It's also all jukugo on'yomi reading, too, so you should be able to figure it out regardless.

context-en: Asian cosmetics are a recent craze among American women.
context-en2: Pokemon Go was selected as one of 2016's Fads of the Year by People Magazine.
context-en3: Hey, Fugu. I’m thinking of publishing a magazine that catalogues trendy hairstyles for fish, what do you think about that?
meaning-exp: Where the stream is going is where everyone's going. That's what tends to be the trend of things. Imagine a trend going on in your society right now. Imagine it going down a stream with everyone following it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We're planning on going to Cuba for a family trip during summer vacation.
context-en2: I want to travel around Southeast Asia before graduating from university.
context-en3: I know you want to ask about my trip, but first things first, how have you been while I've been away?
meaning-exp: When you go on a trip you're taking a trip. This is travel. You should try to do this occasionally! Perhaps a nice ?? to Japan?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My dream is to travel around the world.
context-en2: My wallet and passport were stolen and I missed the plane. It was the worst trip ever.
context-en3: I’m already prepared for our trip.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are going on your trip but you need to bring your little tabby (??) cat with you to keep you company. This cat keeps you calm and lets you leave your house, but the airlines won't let you take it on this trip. What to do?

context-en: I want to drink something warm.
context-en2: I'm a beginner, so please go easy on me.
context-en3: "Would you like some warm ice cream for dessert?" "No, we’re all set."
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of warm? It's warm.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Touch something that's warm... too warm! You pull your hand back and go "AH ta ta! (???). People make this noise when they touch something that's hot, I hear. It's almost like saying "hot hot hot" while dropping the "h" sound.

context-en: I've dived to depths of one hundred feet before.
context-en2: You don't have to worry because this pool is very shallow.
context-en3: While diving at a depth of ten meters, I found rainbow-colored seaweed.
meaning-exp: The water deepness is the water depth. You should check this before diving into the water so you don't hit your face.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Way Of Speaking, Speaking Style, Way Of Talking, Talking Style
context-en: The way he talks makes me really annoyed.
context-en2: Koichi's style of conversation is very cultured, eh?
context-en3: Wow! The way you talk sounds just like a native Japanese person.
meaning-exp: The way of speaking is your way of speaking (or it could be your speaking style). This is how someone talks. Some people have an interesting speaking style, after all.
reading-exp: The readings come from ?? and ?. By now you should have seen these words separately and should be able to read this word too.

context-en: I'd like to hire elves if I could, but It's difficult because of the language barrier.
context-en2: It's hard to put into words, but Koichi is a very special person to me.
context-en3: I was at a loss for words.
meaning-exp: A leaf of the things you say is like a leaf from a tree of speaking. That leaf is a part of the whole language, it is a single word, though it can add up to be a language or manner of speech.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is one you haven't learned. It's kind of an exception, in fact, though you might see it from time to time. You'll want to imagine yourself playing a koto (??). Each strum of the instrument sends forth several words from its strings, flying at the person you're talking to. You speak your words via music, specifically the koto (so think about using other instruments as well to communicate... they just don't work).

context-en: Who wrote this article?
context-en2: Koichi is such a good writer.
context-en3: I don’t like Haruki Murakami’s cheesy, pompous writing style very much.
meaning-exp: The writing chapter on its own is more like an article or something like that. Even if it's a sentence long. So it covers just about every type of writing there is.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You have such an admirable child.
context-en2: You earned my admiration by cleaning your room every single day.
context-en3: Katie earned the admiration of her co-workers with her hard work and attention to detail.
meaning-exp: Your feelings are in your heart. When your feelings are in your heart they are pure feelings. You can be happy for people and feel admiration for their successes. This is a great feeling to have in your heart.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Admission Fee, Entrance Fee, Entry Fee
context-en: Please pay the admission fee at the entrance.
context-en2: The entrance fee for the Tofugu Museum is too expensive.
context-en3: Could you give us an additional ten percent off of the entry fee?
meaning-exp: The fee for entering a public building is the admission fee. Gotta pay it if you want to get inside.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I heard that station master's kid is actually an adopted child.
context-en2: My friend decided to adopt a child in September.
context-en3: I scolded my adopted child because he has such a bad attitude.
meaning-exp: A foster child you bring into your family is your adopted child.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This apartment's residents' rooms are all neatly arranged.
context-en2: Organizing well is important.
context-en3: I adjusted the picture of my ex-boyfriend.
meaning-exp: When you arrange something according to reason, the result is an arrangement.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: As Much As You Want, All You Can
context-en: Every time I go to an all-you-can-eat restaurant, I end up eating too much.
context-en2: If we go to karaoke, why don't we choose the plan where we can sing as much as we want until the morning?
context-en3: If you purchase a lifetime subscription to Textfugu you can study Japanese as much as you want.
meaning-exp: Just release the topic... let it go free! Let it do whatever it wants. Sometimes the topic will be food... if that's the case, just release yourself and do whatever you want with the food (eat it all!). If it's drinks, drink it all! This word has to do with doing whatever you want and as much as you want. You'll see this attached to "all you can ____" words, so look out for them in the next couple levels.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That yakuza boss ended up getting assassinated.
context-en2: Have you already watched the Assassination Classroom movie? It was fun, isn't it?
context-en3: Hey, Viet! How did you come up with such a unique assassination plan?
meaning-exp: A dark kill is an assassination. It's done by someone who is in a ninja outfit and dark, hiding in the shadows for his moment to strike.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I have to go to the bank to withdraw some cash.
context-en2: There is a proverb that says someone who laughs over one yen will eventually cry over one yen, so I decided to go to the bank to put one yen in my account.
context-en3: When people rob banks they go to prison. When banks rob people they get bonuses. It’s so unfair, isn’t it?
meaning-exp: Time to go get your silver from the bank.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Beginning, In The Beginning, First Of All, To Begin With
context-en: To begin, please first slice the beef and then pan fry it.
context-en2: First of all, please don't improvise.
context-en3: R.I.P. Tofugu. At the beginning of this month my favorite Japanese learning site went bankrupt.
meaning-exp: This is a time based word (because of the ?). What is the first point of time when you are beginning something? That is the beginning.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning Haj (??). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).

context-en: Woah, he kissed me on the bridge!
context-en2: Could you sing a song with my daughter while crossing the bridge?
context-en3: The name of the bridge built in 1603 is Nihonbashi and it was truly the central point of Japan, as its name suggests.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! No need to burn any ?s with this word and its kanji.

context-en: Did you know that the prize money is actually on Koichi's head?
context-en2: I heard that Viet won a one-hundred-million yen cash prize from a horse race during his Japan trip this time.
context-en3: When do we get our prize money from the funny face competition?
meaning-exp: A prize of gold is so old fashioned. We use cash now, which is why this word means cash prize.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Adults have adult circumstances.
context-en2: The police must take all circumstances into account.
context-en3: Samantha neglected the fact that her mother's hospitalization was the reason she couldn't pay to use WaniKani.
meaning-exp: The feeling of the actions going on around you are the circumstances. For example: you feel like things are going pretty poorly right now, which is why the circumstances are looking pretty dire for you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This vessel is a relic of my mom's.
context-en2: What should I do? I accidentally broke the container of blowfish that Koichi cherishes.
context-en3: First you put some rice in a bowl, then you put a hamburger patty on the rice, followed by some gravy, and then an egg on top. Then, ta-da! Now, your Loco-moco is done!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also, you can call this a bowl, too, if you want.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have this container. It's upside down with a stick holding it up and a string on the stick. You're going to catch some U2s (like, the band). You put some food under it and wait. Then, out of the bushes comes Bono. He sniffs around for a bit and then goes under the container. You pull! U2 walked (???) right into the trap! Haha!

context-en: Can you make your iPhone screen a bit darker, please?
context-en2: I heard that Mr. Tanaka has nyctophobia, so he can't sleep in a dark room.
context-en3: Everything in the news has been depressing lately, but there is a great big silver lining to this dark cloud, you know. And... well... I kind of lost my train of thought, but, anyway, will you marry me?
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dark? It's dark.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're thrown into something dark and small. A lid is closed on top of you, and you are confused. What have you been thrown in? You find out you've been thrown in a cooler (??). Feel afraid like you would be if you were thrown in such a dark cooler like this. Is it cold?

context-en: Koichi is very dextrous with his fingers.
context-en2: Viet skillfully drank a coca cola while wearing a WaniKani mascot outfit.
context-en3: She is always a cheerful and agreeable girl but she’s not very skilled with her hands, so I’m wondering if I should fire her.
meaning-exp: Your task is to open this pickle container. Why you? Because you are so dextrous and skillful when it comes to opening pickles.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It's doubtful whether Koichi actually can't eat meat.
context-en2: Mr. Tashiro's behavior on that day is questionable.
context-en3: I like Mayor Fugu but if I was asked what he could do for our community, I still have my doubts.
meaning-exp: A doubt problem is caused by having too much doubt. Just think about it. Don't doubt yourself, it's why you're getting those vocab words wrong! :P
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My boyfriend is a drinker, so I'm worried.
context-en2: That alcoholic is drinking in the morning again today.
context-en3: My wife is a drinker and I’m worried about her becoming an alcoholic.
meaning-exp: When you like alcohol a lot, you're probably a heavy drinker.
reading-exp: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading here as you can probably guess from the hiragana sticking out on the end. You should know the readings of these as separate words already (? and ??) which means all you need to pay attention to is the rendaku of ?? to ??.

context-en: Drinking parties hosted by Tofugu are so fun!
context-en2: These days there seems to be an increase in the number of students who are forced to chug drinks at parties and die of acute alcohol poisoning.
context-en3: My mom says that I can’t go to the drinking party. Your parents are really chill about stuff like alcohol. I’m jealous.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is drink, so this has to do with drinking. Also, ? means meet, so when you meet to drink you're getting together with others to drink. It's a drinking party!
reading-exp: The readings come from the ?? vocabulary word and the regular kanji reading for ?. Hopefully you know both of those by now so you can apply them to the reading of this word, too!

context-en: The child was practicing hiragana with zeal.
context-en2: My heart was struck by how he practiced skipping enthusiastically every morning in front of the station.
context-en3: Tofugu’s new employees were all keen to show their enthusiasm and worked even when they could have been sleeping.
meaning-exp: When your heart is feverish and hot about something, it is obviously something you have a lot of enthusiasm about. Think about the things you've enthusiasm for. Then, imagine your heart beating and getting all hot from thinking about it. Why else would people get so upset when talking about religion and politics. It's their feverish heart! Their enthusiasm!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful of the ?? portion (normally is ??).

context-en: Even though the weather forecast said there was a hurricane, we didn't get any rain at all.
context-en2: "Excuse me, but may I ask you for a small favor?" "Sure, of course!"
context-en3: "Did you get that?" "I’m sorry. I’m completely lost. Could you say that again more slowly?"
meaning-exp: It's all nature out there. It's entirely nature and not at all city. This word is weird. It means two opposite things. Thanks Japanese! Just look out for a negative word after the ??. If it is negative it's "not at all" if it's not negative it might be "entirely."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That is up to all of you.
context-en2: I just want to get along with everybody. I absolutely do not have any ulterior motives.
context-en3: Hello everyone. I am hoping we can nail down some of the dates for the Tofugu seminars this week. I’ll talk to Viet in the next few days and then I will announce everyone’s schedule.
meaning-exp: Everyone + ?? (normal name ender). This is the normal way to say everyone
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: Okay everyone, the airplane will be landing in Los Angeles Airport soon.
context-en2: I wish everyone the best of luck and continued good health.
context-en3: "Could everyone take their seats, please?" "With all due respect, I don’t think that's a good idea. There is super glue on our chairs for some reason."
meaning-exp: Everyone (formal name title). This is just a polite way to say everyone (and you want to be polite to everyone, because everyone > you).
reading-exp: The reading for both kanji here are the same as the ones you learned with their kanji. Everyone can breathe easier now.

context-en: I can predict the future.
context-en2: My prediction that Koichi would be late again today turned out to be completely wrong.
context-en3: Due to unforeseen circumstances, the ice boat will not be traveling across the lava pool today.
meaning-exp: You have an idea of the concept beforehand, aka you know what's going to happen, or at least you have an idea. This is an expectation of what's going to happen next. But don't let your anticipation get the better of you!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please don't make such a scary facial expression.
context-en2: After looking at WaniKani's revenue report, Koichi's face looked very happy.
context-en3: The children’s faces all looked very lively.
meaning-exp: When you express a feeling it shows on your face. This is called a facial expression.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Are gas bills expensive in Japan?
context-en2: It's too hard to understand cell phone service fee plans. Could you explain them in a way that's clear and easy to understand?
context-en3: "I’m afraid this price is the best we can offer." "Well, that sounds fair. Okay, let’s finalize the deal."
meaning-exp: The fee gold (or money, if you will) that you have to pay are your fees and bills.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That person is nasty, isn't she?
context-en2: When I went to the office yesterday, I didn't get the impression that Koichiko was pregnant.
context-en3: What’s it feel like to be a company president, Mr. Koichi?
meaning-exp: This is a noun version of the kanji feeling. What is that? It's a feeling as well.
reading-exp: The reading for both on'yomi and kun'yomi of this kanji are the same, actually. So long as you learned the reading that was with the kanji, you can't go wrong. Feel good?

context-en: I can't control my emotions well when I get mad.
context-en2: This is important, so please judge it in good spirits rather than relying on your feelings.
context-en3: Do not give in too much to your feelings. There’s no point in letting your emotions get the better of you, right?
meaning-exp: Feeling + feeling = feeling! It can also mean emotion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I have a bit of a fever today so I can’t go out.
context-en2: OMG! I thought I was just a little feverish but my temperature is over 40 degrees!
context-en3: Touch this 500-degree-heat iron and write about your experience.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so don't get all feverish over this one.

context-en: Don't you think Maria has such a sexy mole on the tip of her left pinky?
context-en2: Koichi is in the habit of spinning a soccer ball on his fingertip while he's thinking.
context-en3: My fingertips are getting numb with cold.
meaning-exp: You know that previous part of your finger? The part I just chopped off? Well that was your fingertip! I only had time to get the tip. It used to be on your finger and now it's right here, in my hand. Sorry, I guess. Oh, but don't worry, I'll even things out and get the tip of your toe real quick too.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

vocab-meaning: Formal Name Ender, Formal Name Title, Sama, Very Formal Name Ender, Formal Name Suffix
context-en: Koichi-sama can't stand it if everything isn't exactly the way he wants.
context-en2: It would be rude if you don't attach the formal name ender, sama, to the recipient's name when you send letters in Japan.
context-en3: Mr. Koichi from Tofugu, party of nine. Your table is ready.
meaning-exp: Add this onto the end of someone's name. It's probably too polite, to be honest, unless you're talking to one of your customers or something. It's good to know, but you're probably not going to use it, despite seeing and hearing it fairly often.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: For The First Time, First Time
context-en: Since the first time we met, President Obama and I have gotten along very well.
context-en2: This is my first time dealing with banking and I'm really struggling.
context-en3: "Is it possible this is your first time in Japan?" "Yes, it is." "Oh really? How do you like it?” "I really like it!"
meaning-exp: You know that ? means "first" This word means for the first time. Think of ?? as "meet." Then think "when we met for the first time ____ happened."
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning Haj (??). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).

context-en: Do you think you'll be on good terms with Satomi?
context-en2: Tofugu workers are not on very friendly terms and don't speak to each other much.
context-en3: Once you get to know her you’ll understand why we say she’s a friendly drunk.
meaning-exp: When the relationship is good, that means you're friendly with that person. You're also on good terms.
reading-exp: The readings are kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned already, so hopefully we can stay on good terms, right?

vocab-meaning: Front Of Station, In Front Of Station, Front Of The Station, In Front Of The Station, Station Front
context-en: I'm looking for an apartment in front of the station.
context-en2: During the election period, lots of politicians make speeches in front of stations.
context-en3: Why did you just send that weird looking selfie taken in front of the station to me?
meaning-exp: The station front is the front of station. This word is great for telling people where you want to meet, by the way.
reading-exp: This is like two separate words put together into one, so you can imagine it's the kun'yomi readings. You learned the right reading for ? in the kanji, and you should know the vocab word ? by now. Combine the two together and you have yourself front of station.

context-en: This band's vocalist is from Fukushima.
context-en2: Look at the silver, starry sky in this drawing from a kid in Fukushima.
context-en3: Please CC me on all emails concerning the problems of Fukushima.
meaning-exp: The luck island wasn't actually too lucky. This is Fukushima where the nuclear meltdown happened after the 2011 earthquake. So, when you think of "luck island" this is where you should think.
reading-exp: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. If one thing is lucky, it's probably that.

context-en: Mr. Kawamura, what is your life's goal?
context-en2: I fired an arrow toward the target 50m ahead of me.
context-en3: Could you be a little more specific about Tofugu’s goals, please?
meaning-exp: The signpost you have your eye on is your goal and target. Just imagine looking at this signpost in the distance. You know you have to get to it from where you are. That is the goal of your hike and journey.
reading-exp: You've had the on'yomi reading of ? with ?? way back in level 6. For this vocab, you're trying to get to your goal, that signpost in the distance. As you're trekking towards it there are people standing to the side mocking you, telling you you'll never make it to your goal. Imagine this happening.

context-en: Is that god still waiting for someone to come and get him?
context-en2: Who comes to your mind when you hear the name "guitar god."
context-en3: That's probably just the god of mischief.
meaning-exp: God (formal name ender) is God! Or the gods, if you're talking to more than one. You have to be polite to them, so you add that ender on there.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too!

context-en: Can you cut this goddess doll's bangs kinda short?
context-en2: My jaw dropped from the female deity's selfish attitude.
context-en3: I came across a beautiful woman’s voice that sounded like a goddess’.
meaning-exp: A woman who is also a god is a goddess.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: This goddess has the most beautiful ? (?) you've ever seen. You can't stop staring into them. This must be how people know they've met a god.

vocab-meaning: Good Friend, Intimate Friend, Close Friend
context-en: I think they are just pretending to be intimate friends and they don't actually like each other.
context-en2: The other day I got a wedding invitation from an intimate friend of mine who lives in Japan.
context-en3: "What are you doing?" "I’m taking a crap. Leave me alone." "What? We may be good friends but you don’t need to tell me that. Good fences make good neighbors."
meaning-exp: You have a good relationship with someone. This is someone who is your good friend or intimate friend.
reading-exp: The readings are kun'yomi as you probably guessed from the hiragana sticking out, but that doesn't matter because you learned the kun'yomi readings already.

context-en: This boiled, green egg makes you lose your appetite, doesn't it?
context-en2: This is just my personal preference, but I want Koichi to dye his hair green.
context-en3: A: How do you like this tie? B: Hmm... Here. Try this green one. A: Okay. How’s this? B: Yeah. That’s more like it.
meaning-exp: The green color is the color green.
reading-exp: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined!

context-en: My husband's eye color is storm gray.
context-en2: Choosing a green carpet shows you have pretty bad taste, right?
context-en3: A: I like the red one. B: I prefer green. A: Oh. OK then, have it your way.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Heartfelt Desire, Heartfelt Wish, Prayer, Heart's Desire
context-en: We are touched by Salmon's prayer.
context-en2: My heartfelt wish is that the damage caused by the hurricane is less this time.
context-en3: I bought a charm at the shrine to help fulfill my heart’s desires.
meaning-exp: The thing your heart requests is what your heart wants. This is your heartfelt desire.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It's hard to see the answers to your homework because I'm looking at it from an angle.
context-en2: Can you take a quick look at my homework from today, please?
context-en3: "But, Mom! I..." "No buts. Now go to your room and do your homework."
meaning-exp: The lodge you're staying in has a topic around it. Think of it as a theme. This theme is doing your homework. So yeah, you just went to a nice lodge for vacation only to have to do homework everywhere.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please heat the bath to forty-one degrees.
context-en2: I'm planning to brew some tea. Would you prefer hot or cold?
context-en3: "Please eat it while it’s hot." "Thank you, but... well, it’s so hot that we can’t eat it yet."
meaning-exp: This is for when a thing is hot, making this word hot thing. When the weather is hot that's ??. This is when you touch something and you burn yourself.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This has the same reading as ??, so if you've learned that you'll know how to read this word as well. If you haven't run into that word, you've probably run into the kanji ? at least. That uses the reading ??. Two similar concepts, but there are two kanji to differentiate, which gets confusing.

vocab-meaning: Humanity, Human Feelings, Empathy, Kindness, Sympathy
context-en: I survive on the warmth of humanity.
context-en2: Koichi-sama is such a wonderful person with deep empathy, but Viet is such a devilish yakuza with not one atom of humanity.
context-en3: Our goal with the daily Tofugu articles is to depict human nature, emotions, and the everyday lives of Japanese individuals.
meaning-exp: The person (people) feelings are human feelings. That is what humanity is all about.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We sold five hundred million yen worth of this reach toothbrush this year.
context-en2: I really can't believe that little kid has gotten so big and now earns three hundred million dollars every year.
context-en3: Please keep all the receipts from your business trip. You will be reimbursed for your business expenses later, as long as they’re under two hundred million yen.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, presumably because it's normally attached onto other numbers to signify how many hundred millions of ____ there are.

context-en: We assume the picture of the many-armed deity will be hung here.
context-en2: It's not good to act on the assumption that you'll have something before you actually do.
context-en3: We will now conduct the disaster drill assuming there is an earthquake.
