meaning-exp: You're trying to determine the concept behind something but you have to test your hypothesis first. You have your assumptions, but you're not entirely sure you're right yet because all you have is the concept to go off of.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Don't use my picture without my permission!
context-en2: I submitted images as evidence to the police regarding Koichi's assassination case.
context-en3: What a shame. This picture is a little out of focus so you can’t use it.
meaning-exp: A drawing of an image is an image. Back in the day images were usually drawn. This is also portrait or picture, too.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Michael's daily routine is to tell all of his colleagues his thoughts on the anime he watched on the previous day.
context-en2: One of my shortcomings as a person who dislikes literature is that all I can say is "it was good" when I am asked for my impressions on the novels I've read.
context-en3: Please look at our site and tell us your impressions. Any comments would be appreciated.
meaning-exp: When you take your feelings and conceptualize them, you come up with your impressions and thoughts on the subject. That's why this word is thoughts or impressions.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Japanese Inn, Japanese Hotel, Inn, Ryokan, Japanese Style Inn, Japanese Style Hotel
context-en: When I travel to Japan, I would like to stay at a Japanese-style hotel.
context-en2: I'm traveling to Japan next month. Where do you think I should stay: a Japanese-style inn or a hotel?
context-en3: "Why are there so many cockroaches in this Japanese inn?" "I think it’s because of all the rain we’ve been getting."
meaning-exp: A public building for taking trips is a place you stay when you are taking a trip. Back in the day that would just be an inn or something. Now, this specifies that the inn is a Japanese inn or Japanese hotel. A lot of people even just call it by its Japanese name: ryokan.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Divine winds blow on this shrine.
context-en2: At the end of WWII, the Japanese army used the kamikaze corps to attack the American army.
context-en3: Five years ago, Koichi drove Viet’s troops back from his shores where they were swallowed up by a divine wind.
meaning-exp: Wind of the Gods. These are divine winds. More popularly, this is a word known as Kamikaze, which became known because of the kamikaze pilots during WWII. This was used before WWII, though, when the entire Mongol fleet was destroyed by a storm, preventing an invasion of Japan. How lucky.
reading-exp: The readings are kun'yomi readings for both, probably because this is two words put together into one. You know the reading of ? from previous levels, hopefully. Now all you need to do is apply your knowledge of the word ? to be able to read the rest.

context-en: The king loves cooking.
context-en2: That king is ridiculously stingy.
context-en3: The king wants to have a butt-wrestling match with a sumo wrestler.
meaning-exp: The king (formal name ender) is the king, and you're talking to him politely. He's the king after all! If you don't he might behead you!
reading-exp: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ?. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!

context-en: For some reason I'm always attracted to left-handed women.
context-en2: I'm buckling down on work for left-handed people.
context-en3: "May I ask the purpose of your call?" "I just want to know if you are left handed." "I’m afraid I’m not at liberty to disclose that information."
meaning-exp: If you profit from the left, you're probably doing everything on the left. That's your good side. You're probably left handed.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings, so combine the readings of the words ? and ?? together to get the reading of this one. It makes sense since this word is like two words put together.

vocab-meaning: Little Finger, Pinky Finger, Pinky, Little Toe, Pinky Toe
context-en: Why do you extend your pinky when you drink from a glass?
context-en2: Ouch! I just hit my right pinky toe on the corner of the dresser.
context-en3: That’s another air ball. I’m doing badly today because of this jammed pinky finger.
meaning-exp: The small finger is your little finger or pinky finger. Makes sense, but it's also used for the pinky on your feet. You know, your pinky toe.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

context-en: When I went there ten years ago, there weren't any lodgings like this at all.
context-en2: We still haven’t decided on a hotel yet.
context-en3: This inn is historically famous as well, so not only do inn guests visit but sightseers do as well.
meaning-exp: A lodge is a form of lodging. It is also considered to be an inn or hotel.
reading-exp: Yah do (??) what you must to get lodgings for the night. Whether that's an inn or hotel or whatever. Yah do what you gotta do.

context-en: The main building has a classroom for pre-school children.
context-en2: We are going to make a book that teaches the history of the main building from scratch.
context-en3: Lots of the people working in the main building of the department store act like someone is forcing them to work, compared to those working at the annex. They have awfully bad attitudes.
meaning-exp: One of the meanings of ? is main (which is what we're using here). The main public building is the main building.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Even if you use rote memorization to memorize them in the short term, you'll forget them again quickly, won't you?
context-en2: How many digits of pi can you remember, Sakuragi?
context-en3: He's the class clown and is always playing the fool, but he is very good at memorization.
meaning-exp: In the dark if you try to write down something it won't work very well. You can't see. So, how can you "write something down" in the dark? You write it down in your mind. This is memorization! Recognize this word? The SRS application "Anki" comes from this word, I'm guessing!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The larger the oceanic fish, the more mercury in its body.
context-en2: I wonder if it's a coincidence that we call both Mercury, the planet, and mercury, the substance, "mercury" in English.
context-en3: It’s so funny that people used to insert mercury thermometers into their butts.
meaning-exp: This is a fun one. Water silver is mercury, which makes a lot of sense. Mercury is liquidy like water, but it is all silver like silver. So silver water isn't some new mineral water you can get for $4 at the store, it's mercury! Or quicksilver, if you prefer.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Middle Finger, Second Finger, Middle Toe
context-en: A stray dog bit my second finger.
context-en2: My callus on the middle finger on my right hand is getting pretty hard.
context-en3: Don’t stick out your middle finger!
meaning-exp: The middle finger is the middle finger, of course! And because we don't see the difference, it's your middle toe too. Stick that up the next time someone makes you mad.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

context-en: I planted a flower in a flower pot next to the mirror.
context-en2: Koichi is a strange man who talks to himself in the mirror almost every day.
context-en3: "My mirror was stolen this morning. I just had my toothbrush and comb stolen a few weeks ago!" "Well, that’s life."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: Have you already watched the latest Ghibli movie?
context-en2: Even though I like romantic films, my husband only wants to watch war movies.
context-en3: "I’m going to be a movie star, buy a private jet, and you will be my wife." "Yeah, dream on, grandpa."
meaning-exp: It's a drawing that uses reflections to project the image. And, the image is moving! How amazing! What is this? It is a movie.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There is some truth to that mother's motive for murder.
context-en2: The company, which until now had specialized in online Japanese learning resources, has for the first time released a hard-core murder game.
context-en3: From a murderer's perspective, I am not very pleased with her because her methods of killing are so boring.
meaning-exp: When a person is killed, you have yourself a murder.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There are various different types of musical instruments. Which type do you like? I like percussion.
context-en2: Please start by trying to play your instrument note for note.
context-en3: "I forgot to bring your CD." "That’s okay. I can get it another time, but can you play an instrument for background music instead?"
meaning-exp: Remember how ? was used in ?? and meant "music"? Well this is that ? again. A music container is something that can produce music. It is a musical instrument.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful of how ?? turns into ??, though.

context-en: "Wow! You scored a one hundred on that test?" "Naturally."
context-en2: It's only natural that you must practice kanji little by little every day in order to become good at it.
context-en3: You are very lucky to have such a lovely wife. Don’t take her for granted.
meaning-exp: Something that's naturally right is something that's very obvious and natural. You know that, right? ??!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I love the nature of Japan.
context-en2: It was just natural that Koichi and Koichiko fell in love with each other.
context-en3: The US government told us to release Fugu into the wild.
meaning-exp: Self nature is nature itself. That is nature, like all those green things and ?? outside. Many apologies if someone hundreds of years from now is reading this. It used to be pretty green outside before the robots. If you call this "natural" then you are using the ? adjective ???, but I thought it pertinent to add that in here too.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Wait! Except ? is ? and not ?! That is because when you add the little dakuten you are adding to the ?. When it has no dakuten, it is in the form that nature intended.

context-en: Koichi has a one hundred million yen condo in Tokyo.
context-en2: I can't believe that Japan, a tiny island country, has one hundred million people living on it.
context-en3: I won a hundred million dollars in the lottery, but I donated it all to charity because I’m a trillionaire.
meaning-exp: One hundred million is one hundred million. That's a lot of zeros.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We don't get big orders of like one hundred million yen, but we do get steady orders.
context-en2: I received a notification saying Tofugu had decided to donate one hundred million yen to me.
context-en3: "I just lost a suitcase that had one hundred million yen in it.” "What! I hope you find it."
meaning-exp: One hundred million yen! So rich! You have one hundred million yen!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Orderly, Systematic, Well Organized, Natural Order
context-en: Even though there are many people in Tokyo, it is well organized.
context-en2: Darin always provides well-reasoned explanations.
context-en3: The neatly arranged wine bottles on the shelves of the Tofugu office were all emptied out by Mami.
meaning-exp: When you arrange things in the way that nature intended, you're doing things in a quite orderly fashion. This is the natural state of things, nice and arranged and natural. Orderly!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You can do whatever you want as long as you have passion.
context-en2: I can't believe how enthusiastic Viet is.
context-en3: Koichi decided to make his passion in life achieving a fusion between Japanese and American traditions.
meaning-exp: If you're feeling the fever, you're getting so into something that your body is heating up. You have a ton of passion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: PE Class, PE, Physical Education, Gym Class
context-en: I hated that time in elementary school when we had to do long-distance running in gym.
context-en2: Before the next PE class, please clip your fingernails.
context-en3: "Do you want to play volleyball with us on Physical Education Day?" "Oh, it’s a national holiday, right? Isn’t it October 10th or something?" "Yes, it’s a holiday, but is not October 10th anymore. Now it’s the second Monday of October because of the Happy Monday system."
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means "education?" Well, the ? here is referring to the education word, but this time it's a body education. What do you call the body education at school? Physical education or PE.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichiko broke up with Koichi after she learned Koichi is a man without even a shred of sympathy.
context-en2: In Japanese there is a proverb, "It is important for us to be compassionate toward each other as we travel through this world."
context-en3: I needed a 70 to pass the test, and even though I got a 69, I was given a pity pass.
meaning-exp: You have your feelings... these are the feelings humans have. When you ask someone to have feelings (Have feelings, KAY?? (? at the end)), you are asking them to pity or have mercy on you. Please! Have those human feelings that people have, like sympathy or pity. Don't kill me, man!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who are you begging to have pity on you? It's NASA. They have you hanging outside of the space station and they're going to push you towards earth where you'll burn up in the atmosphere. You don't want that, so you beg mission control for some pity. What will they do? You decide.

vocab-meaning: Please Help Me, Please, If You Would Be So Kind
context-en: Please God! I want to be fluent in Japanese.
context-en2: If you aren't an active member, please join!
context-en3: Could I have an aisle seat, please? I hate looking out the window.
meaning-exp: This is a tricky word that doesn't really have a good translation. The best ways I've seen it done in terms of getting a meaning across are please and please help me. When you say this word you're kind of saying "please help me out and I'm relying on you and you're kind of awesome too." Anyways, please is a pretty good way to do it. So, when you see this word you'll notice it has the request kanji in it. You can guess you're requesting something. What is that thing? It's help (please help me) and you're asking very nicely too (please).
reading-exp: You ask for help by saying please help me, and that person does try to help you... but the amount they do for you is so negligible that it hardly does anything to help you at all. Please try to help me again, this time better?

context-en: I like poems a lot, so I read them every day.
context-en2: I expressed the darkness of my mind in a poem. Can you take a look?
context-en3: Today’s homework is to write a poem in Japanese.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji as well! You are so happy that you could write a poem all about this... The vocab reading Is the same as the kanji Crabigator love How was that?

context-en: Salmon is a poet who represents the current century.
context-en2: One of my friends is a poet, and poems take up space all over the walls in his house.
context-en3: Even though you’re a poet and you like using metaphors, you have to speak clearer or people won’t understand you.
meaning-exp: A person who does poems is a poet.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I enjoy poetry every day.
context-en2: Fugu's secret skill is composing marvelous poetry.
context-en3: Shiika means Japanese poetry and that generally includes kanshi, waka, or haiku.
meaning-exp: A poem song is poetry. It's not quite a song but I think you can make the connection.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know these readings, but there's usually an extra ? in the middle. Don't worry, ?? is totally fine too, but ??? is more common. You got this!

context-en: After practicing for one year, was finally able to distinguishing between aspirated and unaspirated sounds.
context-en2: My daily practice bore fruit and now I can improvise on the guitar.
context-en3: I believe the reason I continue being ranked number one in the world is that I devote seven hours a day to practicing Japanese.
meaning-exp: You practice something to learn it. That's still called practice! The important part about this is that you're learning while you practice too. It's right in the word. So, when you practice kanji and Japanese vocab, make sure you're learning as well as practicing. If you're not learning, you're not really practicing, are you?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Pro Athlete, Sports Player, Professional Athlete
context-en: Who is that handsome pro athlete?
context-en2: These days, we can often see Japanese professional baseball players play in the major leagues.
context-en3: Koichi is magnificent pro kendo player.
meaning-exp: This is a strange one, but in one way it makes sense. Just make sure you're thinking of ? as the word for "person," kind of like ??? or something along those lines. If you do that, you can say "the person that you choose." One situation in which you'd choose a person to do something is in sports. That's why this is a pro athlete or sports player.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is what you'd expect. ? is the on'yomi reading as it is every once in a while, especially when it has to do with representing a person, so you'll have to remember that. I think you've seen ? using this reading enough to be able to remember it, though.

context-en: It would be a big problem for Tofugu if WaniKani's revenue were to drop.
context-en2: I tried to solve this math question for thirty seconds and I couldn't figure it out, can you do it for me?
context-en3: "Can you do me a favor?" "Sure, what is it?" "Can you look after my dog for the weekend?" "No problem. You can count on me."
meaning-exp: The problem topic is the problem or question you have to answer. If you think about it, topics as problems tends to be a school-related thing. So, when you have to answer a problem in school, that's ??.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When I look at this revenue chart I really feel like WaniKani is selling well.
context-en2: Even when I heard the news that my mother died, it didn't feel real at first.
context-en3: Only after I went to America did I realize how small Japan really is.
meaning-exp: Your truth feeling is when you feel something is true. You have the realization this is a real feeling!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading for ? gets changed to ?? so be careful!

vocab-meaning: Really Like, To Really Like, Love, To Love, Like A Lot, To Like A Lot, Like Very Much, To Like Very Much
context-en: I love my boyfriend's habit of fidgeting with his bangs.
context-en2: No matter what he says, Fugu still likes WaniKani a lot.
context-en3: You’re kind of goofy and that makes you fun to hang out with. I really like you.
meaning-exp: You've hopefully seen ?? by now, which is "to like." So, what happens when you have a ? (big) like? You really like something.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? which you've hopefully seen. Then, ? is the reading you learned with the kanji.

context-en: I heard that if you watch Michael's image on YouTube 4444 times, you'll be cursed.
context-en2: Since I watched Ringu, I can't get the reflection of Sadako coming out of that old well out of my head.
context-en3: Did you see that new Japanese movie? The movie itself wasn’t very good, but the shots they captured were beautiful.
meaning-exp: An image is reflecting on the mirror. You're looking at the mirror, confused. Don't worry, it is only a reflection, an image. It's not real.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I really like this retrospective scene in the movie.
context-en2: Koichi was reminiscing incoherently with his cat on the veranda.
context-en3: I know that Viet sometimes reminisces about his yakuza days during work hours.
meaning-exp: You think about the concept of a certain number of times, each time thinking of each time you've thought about this concept before. Each time you look back, that is retrospection on that concept. You look back more and more times until there are no more times to look back on.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My son is not right-handed.
context-en2: Although I am left-handed, my mom bought a right-handed baseball glove by mistake.
context-en3: I really liked her but I was turned off when I found out that she was right handed. I don’t know why.
meaning-exp: The right side of your body is the side you profit most from. So, you use it a lot more. That's because you're right handed.
reading-exp: Both kanji use the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, think to the words ? and ?? to learn how to read this one. It probably reads like this because it's two separate words come together (right + handed) rather than one word.

context-en: Please throw this Quoits ring quickly!
context-en2: If I go to parties, my circle of friends expands.
context-en3: Ew! Why are you wearing gold hoop earrings, Koichi?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You put on the ring you found, hoping it will be the one ring to rule them all (invisibility!). Instead, it turns out it's a special Walken ring, made out of Christopher Walken's bones. It talks up to you, telling you how he kept this ring in his (*ahem*) butt during the war so he could get it to you. First of all, why is this ring talking? Second, why is it talking like Walken. Third, eww, gross, it was in his anus.

context-en: Scholarship is always associated with literature.
context-en2: I personally think that universities aren't a place to learn, but a place to obtain the qualifications of a "university degree."
context-en3: You must not neglect your studies.
meaning-exp: How can you solve your study problem? With a little extra scholarship and studying.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I got promoted to section manager last month.
context-en2: I'm glad I was able to become a section chief, but my pay has actually decreased because I don't get paid for overtime.
context-en3: My section manager is kind of annoying. He is always trying to impress the other workers.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is the company president? This uses the same ? meaning (where it means something like "boss"). Since ? means section, this is the section manager.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This Shinjuku hotel's shower only has cold or lukewarm water.
context-en2: Shinjuku is always dead last on my personal list of places I want to visit each year.
context-en3: Shinjuku 2-chome is now known as a gay town but it used to be a sketchy red light district.
meaning-exp: The new lodge area is Shinjuku, a popular district in Tokyo. Perhaps there are many places to stay in Shinjuku. Either way, you should visit, it's fun! It will help if you've heard of Shinjuku before, too. Do some research about Shinjuku if you've never heard of it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be careful of the ??? changing to ???. Once again, will help if you've heard of Shinjuku.

context-en: For your wedding ring which would you prefer: silver or gold?
context-en2: No matter how old I get, I still like silver things.
context-en3: At the red light a silver pick-up truck pulled up alongside me.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji.

context-en: Please repaint this silver like I told you the first time.
context-en2: Could you sell Koichi's silver mustache to me, please?
context-en3: My dance partner is that guy in the silver costume. His name is Fugu.
meaning-exp: The silver color is just silver (the color).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Special Selection, Special Choice, Special Prize
context-en: The picture of our boss won the special prize at the contest!
context-en2: Here are the specially selected cosplayers.
context-en3: I heard that Koichi eats the best, specially selected black garlic before going to bed every night.
meaning-exp: If something is special you choose it. That makes it a special selection of yours and it gets a special prize that only you could give!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please get off the train at Shinjuku Station.
context-en2: There is a Tofugu pot sticker shop in front of Ueno Station that Koichi opened with one hundred million yen.
context-en3: It was nice finally talking to you in person. I never thought I would run into you at a station.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually this refers to a train station in particular, but can be any kind of station.
reading-exp: The kanji here uses ?? as both its on'yomi and kun'yomi, so no worries here. You can go to this station or that station, and both stations will use the same reading as the kanji it comes from.

vocab-meaning: Station Master, Stationmaster, Train Station Master, Train Stationmaster
context-en: My favorite idol was selected to be a one-day train station master.
context-en2: Because the stationmaster and Mr. Kawada are best friends, I heard that he secretly gets discount on fares.
context-en3: Oh my God! Did the station master just spit on the train? Did you see that?
meaning-exp: This word uses ? in the same way as ??, where it means something like "boss" or "manager." So, this ? is the boss of the station, right? What do you call someone like that? You call them the stationmaster (that is, unless you want to be thrown to the trains).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: South Korea has the highest suicide rate among East Asian countries.
context-en2: Apparently, over 130 Russian teenagers committed suicide as a part of a social media game called "Blue Whale."
context-en3: Could you email me that list of famous suicide spots in Japan? I’d appreciate if you could compress the file before you send it to me too.
meaning-exp: A self kill is when you kill yourself. That's suicide.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you want a sumo wrestler's autograph, why don't you go to Ryogoku?
context-en2: The sumo wrestler kept patting down his bangs on our first date.
context-en3: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for attending today’s conference regarding the repeated misconduct of our sumo wrestlers.
meaning-exp: A power samurai isn't a samurai at all. A Samurai's all about precision, after all. So, imagine someone that's a huge mass of muscle (and fat). This Japanese warrior is all about power... ramming into people as hard as they can to knock them over. This person is a sumo wrestler.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Sympathy, Same Sentiment, Concurrence, Agree, Empathy
context-en: I empathize with Koichi's views.
context-en2: I've never agreed with someone so much.
context-en3: "I hate Fugu." "I feel the same way."
meaning-exp: When you have the same feeling as someone else, you have sympathy for them, because you know how they feel. How kind of you!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Can you arrange these utensils on the table, please?
context-en2: Which utensils did you drop in the pond, the gold ones or the silver ones?
context-en3: "How come we have one extra place setting?" "Because you invited Fugu." "Oh, right. Sorry, but Fugu’s not coming anymore. His ex-girlfriend came to town the other day and they got back together, so he’s spending Thanksgiving with her."
meaning-exp: Your eating containers can be a lot of things. For a more general meaning, this can be your tableware. But, more specifically it can also mean your eating utensils or your utensils. Basically, it's stuff you use to eat your food.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to note the shortened ???.

context-en: Let's show our gratitude to everyone on Thanksgiving Day.
context-en2: Although I don't say it, I always appreciate my wife.
context-en3: I would like to express my gratitude to all our clients. Without you, we would not be here.
meaning-exp: You have feelings of apologizing. Strangely, this word means thanks and gratitude, though. Perhaps someone did something so nice for you that you want to apologize for how many nice things they're doing for you. You are this grateful to them!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you had to lose one of your five senses, which one would you give up and why?
context-en2: In my dream last night, there was a smell I didn't notice before... do all five senses work in dreams?
context-en3: Please study Japanese words and verbs related to the five senses, as well as some Japanese vocabulary related to the sixth sense.
meaning-exp: The five feelings that you have are what? Sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell (don't count the sixth one where you see dead people). These are the five senses that you probably have.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can't follow Koichi's thoughts.
context-en2: When I was watching the news yesterday, I was so shocked that it said Viet was arrested for thoughtcrimes.
context-en3: Koichi is the founder of Tofugu and one of the great modern Japanese thinkers.
meaning-exp: The concept you think about is your thoughts. It is your ideas.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Let go of my thumb!
context-en2: When I'm nervous, my thumbs shake.
context-en3: I’ve got a callus on my thumb.
meaning-exp: Your parent finger is your thumb! It's bigger than your other fingers, so that means it's in charge too! This goes for the fingers on your feet too, I mean, your toes. So the parent toe is your big toe.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

context-en: My motorcycle's tire came off.
context-en2: I heard that a car wheel was used in the assassination.
context-en3: Could I borrow your bike today? I don’t have mine right now because I’m having a tire replaced.
meaning-exp: The car rings are what part of your car? What's round and ringy? Those are your tires. So, a car ring is a tire.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Apologize to Koichi right now!
context-en2: If you apologize even though you haven't done anything wrong it makes me uncomfortable.
context-en3: I feel bad that you won’t get a satisfying result, but I refuse to apologize for something I didn’t do.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means apologize so the verb vocab version is to apologize.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you say you're sorry to apologize, you'd probably start with: "I am (???) sorry!"

vocab-meaning: To Be Emotionally Moved, To Be Moved Emotionally, To Be Moving
context-en: It was so moving, I can't stop crying.
context-en2: I heard the secret story of how Tofugu was established and was really moved.
context-en3: Oh my God! I just made the best Japanese learning material in the history of mankind! Everyone will be really excited!
meaning-exp: You know this is a verb from the ??. Your feelings have been moved. So, when your feelings have been moved, you are emotionally moved. This word is to be emotionally moved or simply to be moving. Just be sure to know this has to do with emotions.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Be Reflected, To Be Projected
context-en: The internal company document is being projected on the screen.
context-en2: Looking at my own face reflected in the mirror I feel "how beautiful my face is" every day.
context-en3: A tear rolled down Koichi’s cheek when he saw the beautiful mountains reflected on the surface of the lake.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means reflect. The verb vocab version means to be reflected. You're not doing the reflecting directly. You can remember this by thinking how rude (?) it is that someone's reflecting your image using a mirror for everyone outside the dressing room to see.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your reflection is getting reflected onto the mirror. You don't like it, it doesn't look like you. Impostor reflection! You take a hammer and you ?? (??) it as hard as you can, glass flying everywhere. Then some dubstep starts playing from the broken mirror: ????????. You're obviously on meth or something.

context-en: A horse was released from the stable.
context-en2: I worked hard and was finally released from my debts.
context-en3: I thought that I was finally free of having to care for my children but then my 53-year-old wife got pregnant again.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means release and the verb vocab version means to be released. You can differentiate this one from ?? (to release) by thinking that it's pretty rare (??) for you to be released by your arch nemesis. He just let you go, strangely. How rare.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??. As long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here as well.

vocab-meaning: To Bring Up, To Raise, To Bring Something Up, To Raise Something
context-en: Viet and Koichi love growing vegetables in their office.
context-en2: Could you raise this puppy instead? I would love to do it, but I need to relocate to Neptune next month.
context-en3: What did you raise as a class when you were in elementary school? Our class was raising tadpoles, hamsters, and eggplants, but all of the hamsters ran away and got eaten by cats.
meaning-exp: This is similar to ??, except now you're doing the raising of someone. This word means to bring up or to raise. You can remember this because of the ??. Your version of bringing a child up involves tearing (??) all their clothes to make them look poor so they can get the cheaper lunch at school. You're rich because of all the tax breaks you get from all the children you're raising, but you could always use more money to fuel your StarCraft addiction (we've all been there).
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??. So long as you know that one, you know how to read this one as well.

vocab-meaning: To Catch Up To, To Overtake
context-en: We took a car and less than five minutes later we overtook Koichi who had departed for Seattle on foot on the previous day.
context-en2: If you can catch up to Kristen in the hundred meter dash, you can compete in the Olympics.
context-en3: Tofugu’s coloring book was so popular that production couldn’t keep up with demand.
meaning-exp: You follow then attach yourself to the thing you're following. You have now caught up! This verb is to catch up.
reading-exp: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, but you can also just notice that this word includes ?? and ?? combined.

context-en: I can't choose who to kill.
context-en2: I stopped listening to my teacher and just kept thinking about which girl to choose.
context-en3: You chose a great Fugu costume.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means choose is to choose.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have the opportunity to choose. You choose, and a bright sign lights up reading "error" (??).

context-en: Don't look at it, feel it with your heart.
context-en2: Due to the rising power of WaniKani, Tofugu feels that it's been losing its place within the company.
context-en3: I feel like my older brother has been giving me the cold shoulder recently.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means feeling so the verb vocab version is to feel.
reading-exp: Guess what? Even though this would use the vocab kun'yomi reading, usually, the readings for both on'yomi and kun'yomi on this kanji are the same, meaning you can read this word no matter what. Feeling better now?

vocab-meaning: To Fight, To Battle, To Combat
context-en: Japan and America fought in WWII.
context-en2: We battle against this gigantic monster called kanji every day so we can get good at Japanese.
context-en3: Kendo is normally a one-on-one martial art, but 5 years ago Koichi had to fight against two guys at the same time.
meaning-exp: This is the verb version of the vocab word ??, which I'm hoping you learned earlier. The verb version of course means to fight or to battle.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? a word you've hopefully seen by now. Associate these words together in your mind and you'll be able to read them so long as you know the other one.

vocab-meaning: To Follow, To Stalk, To Chase, To Run After, To Pursue
context-en: Ms. Tanaka likes Mr. Yamada a lot, so she chases him every day.
context-en2: OMG! Koichi left for Japan without his passport. Can you run after him and give him this passport?
context-en3: I saw Fugu following a pod of killer whales.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "to chase." So, you're chasing something or someone, or something similar. Just think of the ??? as you being all "cocky" about it. You're not just chasing this person, you're following them too. So, this word is to follow and to stalk. Scary!
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? as well as the kanji reading you learned too.

vocab-meaning: To Foster, To Raise, To Rear
context-en: Does WaniKani foster Tofugu or does Tofugu foster WaniKani?
context-en2: We need to keep our eyes peeled so we won't be deceived by Koichi's ninjutsu.
context-en3: You should thank your husband sometimes. He has done a good job raising your family, hasn’t he?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means foster so the verb vocab version is to foster.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're offering to raise some girl as your own. After the paperwork is over, you can finally say: "Yah, she now (???) is my kid!"

vocab-meaning: To Help, To Assist, To Lend A Hand, To Give A Hand
context-en: Can you give me a hand in cleaning up the fridge?
context-en2: Viet asked me to help him assassinate Koichi because he purchased a 100 million dollar insurance policy for him.
context-en3: I’m sorry. I’d like to help but my hands are tied.
meaning-exp: When you transmit your hand to something or someone, you're putting out your hand to help them or to assist them.
reading-exp: Both of these are the kun'yomi readings that you learned with the kanji! The thing is, the ? goes to ? for who knows what reason. Perhaps you can ask for someone to help you to understand this dumb reading change.

context-en: Every once in a while Koichi will move in an unimaginable way while he's working.
context-en2: Can you imagine having a job where you visit temples and shrines to collect their red ink stamps in a book?
context-en3: If you want to learn how to vomit without sticking your finger down your throat, just imagine Koichi naked.
meaning-exp: To do a concept of an image (in your mind) would require you to imagine it, because it's just a concept and not real.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I will kill you!
context-en2: It tastes better to eat fish alive rather than killing it first.
context-en3: I think Cinderella was actually really keen on killing her step mother.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means kill so the verb vocab version is to kill.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You kill someone! Oh no, what are you going to do? Where will you put the body? You decide to stuff it into the core (??) of a nuclear silo. It will melt and disappear in there, right? At least, that's what you think. Imagine opening up the core of the nuclear silo and feel the burn of the radiation. You throw the body in and close the core, then run away. Unfortunately, this nuclear core will kill you too, eventually. Then, it will kill everyone in the area, because the body you threw in will overheat the core, causing a giant explosion.

vocab-meaning: To Look Back At, To Look Back On, To Look Back
speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Godan verb
context-en: I don't have time to look back on the past.
context-en2: The figure of the baby looking back at me is just too cute and totes adorbs.(*´?`*)
context-en3: There was a huge crash and I involuntarily looked behind me.
meaning-exp: Your seeing is returning on something. This is when you look back at something you've already looked at before. This word means to look back at.
reading-exp: The readings are just ? and the vocab word ??, combined together. So long as you know both of those you should be able to combine them into the reading for this word.

context-en: I ordered wrapping paper covered in silver glitter.
context-en2: I ordered Koichi's used briefs on Amazon by mistake.
context-en3: We could eat out or order takeout. I don’t mind one way or the other.
meaning-exp: You hopefully have seen the word ?? (order, request). This is just the verb version: to order / to request.
reading-exp: If you know the reading of ?? you should be able to read this one too. Also, it's just all jukugo on'yomi readings, so you should be able to read it anyways.

context-en: We went to buy the much-talked-about fugu.
context-en2: When I went to the office the next morning, everyone was talking about Koichi's wedding and his sudden divorce on the following day.
context-en3: I hope you’ve understood so far. All right, now let’s move on to the next topic. Did you know tomatoes are not only native to South America but they’re also Fugu’s favorite vegetable?
meaning-exp: The topic that we are talking about is the topic that we are talking about. It's the subject of our conversation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Separate, To Be Divided, To Part From, To Break Up
context-en: Koichiko separated from Koichi and started going out with Viet.
context-en2: We broke up due to a lack of communication.
context-en3: When I parted from her, I couldn't stop crying.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means separate, so you can guess the meaning is to separate or to be divided.
reading-exp: Remember the word ???? That word means "to separate" too. The reading is similar, though not the same, but we can at least use it as a jumping off point. We go from ??? to ????. It's like we've "separated" the ? and the ? and combined them in the middle. ?, making a ??, which gets you to ????.

vocab-meaning: To Share, To Own Jointly, To Co Own
context-en: Don't share dubious information.
context-en2: I don't like the idea of co-owning a car.
context-en3: Please teach me how to share videos.
meaning-exp: This is the same as ?? but the verb version.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? as well as the readings you learned via the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Train Station Employee, Train Station Staff, Train Station Attendant, Station Attendant, Station Employee
context-en: I think that train station attendant's irises are larger than most people's.
context-en2: All the station employees here eat bowls of 280 yen kake soba for lunch.
context-en3: You couldn’t tell from looking at him, but that station attendant is a really rich guy.
meaning-exp: A train station member is someone who works at the train station. They are a train station employee. Feel free to ask them if you need help knowing which direction to train in.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My university is big and famous, so foreign exchange students come here from many different countries.
context-en2: I think there are various ways to interpret that remark.
context-en3: Tofugu workers vary in size, shape, and color, depending on where they come from. They all have unique characteristics.
meaning-exp: This is a weird word, sorry ahead of time. You have the formal name title plus another formal name title (thanks to the ?). When you have several different kinds of formal name titles you have all kinds of fancy people that you're talking to. Each one of them is different. There are many various people!
reading-exp: The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. The second one is ?? however, which plays right into the "various" meaning of the word. There's even various ways to read ?? in this word!

context-en: I have the ability to use Google very efficiently.
context-en2: The ability to write weird sentences is required to create WaniKani example sentences.
context-en3: I’m a native English speaker, but my telepathic abilities are in Japanese.
meaning-exp: Your ability power is what you can do. This is your ability. It is also your capability.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Burdocks grow approximately two meters above the ground.
context-en2: Before that, I had about three years of experience in the stock trading field.
context-en3: About a million people have liked Tofugu’s Facebook page so far.
meaning-exp: The kanji means promise, but the meaning of this word is about, which is a little different. Just think about promises. When you promise something you really need to follow through... but only about as much as you need to for the other person to be happy. Someone asks for a puppy for Christmas, and you get them a stuffed animal puppy. It's approximately the promise you made. Close enough. *wink*
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. See? I promised this one would be easy and it was.

context-en: I asked an acquaintance if they could get me Koichi’s autograph from Tofugu.
context-en2: I’m consulting my acquaintance about my relationship with my boyfriend right now, so I probably won’t be able to join the karaoke party. Sorry!
context-en3: Don’t tell a soul but my boss is having an affair with a married woman who is an acquaintance of mine.
meaning-exp: You've probably seen the words ?? and ?? by now. This is someone you "know" because you had the chance to "meet" them, but that's pretty much it. You don't really know them, you just met them a couple times so you know who they are. This person is an acquaintance.
reading-exp: The readings are that of ?? and ??. So long as you know those words, you should be able to read this one too.

context-en: I personally thought I was able to give an American-style speech pretty well.
context-en2: I just personally love Koichi's mysterious smile.
context-en3: What do you mean by a Tofugu-like secret plan? Do you think you could be more specific?
meaning-exp: This is a strange word, I'm afraid. You'll have to bear with it. This, when added onto a word, is like adding an "-al" to a word (or a -like to a word). For example, add it onto ?? (Japan) and you have "Japanese-like," which comes out to "Very Japanese." It's a weird sort of modifying word that really depends on each situation it's in, though -al and -like often do a decent job. For now, just know this word means these things. We'll start applying it to various words in the future, slowly but surely.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, probably because this is usually added onto other words, making it behave like a jukugo.

context-en: The next year is Tofugu's 10th anniversary, so Koichi is planning an anniversary project.
context-en2: My family grazes dairy cow herds year round. This year is the 20th anniversary of their grazing business.
context-en3: Next Sunday we’ll celebrate Tofugu’s fifth anniversary at McDonald’s.
meaning-exp: When you wrap around the entire circumference of the year you've come back around to the start of it. This is the anniversary.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Taro Okamoto said, "Art is an explosion," but what the heck does that mean?
context-en2: My younger sister is learning Thai art at a university of fine arts.
context-en3: Aya should share her love of art and music to more people.
meaning-exp: The acting arts are the greatest arts of all. Back in the day they were the only arts, which is why the art of acting is just art itself. In fact, it's THE arts.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The Tofugu office has a very relaxed atmosphere, doesn't it?
context-en2: Michael is good at enhancing the mood of the Tofugu office.
context-en3: Well, the meeting ended with an awkward atmosphere, didn’t it? I can’t believe our president farted at the end. It was funny, though.
meaning-exp: The surrounding energy in the atmosphere is what makes up the atmosphere. I love it when it takes three kanji to represent what one of the three kanji already represents.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm planning to buy a fully-automatic front loading washing machine with my bonus.
context-en2: I set up my smartphone to automatically upload every single photo to the cloud.
context-en3: It’s Tofugu policy that workers caught eating Koichi’s bacon without permission are automatically fired.
meaning-exp: Something that can move by its self is something that's automatic.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When learning Japanese, it is necessary to learn from good examples as well as bad examples.
context-en2: Koichi is a cluster of bad examples.
context-en3: My parents never let me stay up late because they believed it would set a bad precedent for future bedtimes.
meaning-exp: A bad example is a bad example and is something you don't want.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Bad Feeling, Feeling Bad, Feeling Terrible, Unpleasant, Gross
context-en: I'm hungover, I have a bad headache, and I feel terrible. This is awful.
context-en2: Koichi called out to Viet with his sickly sweet voice.
context-en3: Stop bending your arms like that. It’s seriously weirding me out.
meaning-exp: The ??? (feeling) is bad. So, you can imagine how you feel isn't good, it's a bad feeling. You're feeling terrible, in fact.
reading-exp: The readings come from the words ??? and ??. Hopefully you've seen both and can combine them together to know the reading automatically. No bad feelings with this word, right?

context-en: Let's aim with that bone as our target!
context-en2: Kristen acted calm even when she fell and broke her arm.
context-en3: Last night, I dreamt that I was burning the Tofugu office. In the ashes of the ruins, I saw a mountain of fish bones.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Take a look at your own bones. They have been upgraded with special technology, allowing you to hone (??) in on targets, then shoot your bones at them. Go ahead and imagine yourself using this crazy new bone technology. Wolverine is jealous.

context-en: This is a compound bone fracture.
context-en2: Koichi had a bad car accident last year. Not only did he break his legs, but he lost his head and now he's a robot.
context-en3: It’s been a while since we all got together. How have you been? Things are pretty much the same with me except I broke my pinky toe. Lol.
meaning-exp: When your bone gets folded like paper, or something, you can bet you have a broken bone or fracture.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because ?? is shortened to ?? here.

context-en: Koichi has so much money that he can swim in it.
context-en2: If I remember correctly, I think they sell broccoli in bunches.
context-en3: I have to get some copy paper. Could you exchange a bundle of copy paper for this bouquet of flowers?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are counting your bundles. There are a lot of them, so you have to create tabs (??) in your notebook to properly categorize everything. Imagine yourself doing this (physically creating the tabs in your notebook, even though your notebook didn't come with tabs).

context-en: I was disappointed with this carrot soup.
context-en2: I gifted some carrot liqueur to the King, who loves alcohol, but he didn't like it.
context-en3: Please. I'll eat anything else, just not the carrot. Please.
meaning-exp: This meaning is a little weird, but I'm going to try my best to help you remember. Every person has to participate in eating carrots. I don't care if you don't like them, if you don't eat at least one carrot in your life you'll die. So if you're a person you better participate in the eating of at least a single carrot.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're craving a carrot, but you can't seem to find any. You look in your fridge, in your garden, and even in the trash. Finally you give up your carrot search and sit down when... ouch! The carrot was in your jeans (??) the whole time!

context-en: In many circumstances, we take things like towels, soap, snacks, or noodles.
context-en2: We try our best to respond your emails as soon as possible, but please note that we may not be able to respond immediately.
context-en3: In this case, I think it would be good to call the police.
meaning-exp: What suits a location? Or, another way to think about it, what happens when everything fits for that location? You have yourself a case or circumstance that happens because of the location and its suitability.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

context-en: I question Viet's character!
context-en2: Fugu has a very gentle personality, doesn't he?
context-en3: Koichi is a person of integrity. Every Sunday he goes to the orphanage and donates bacon.
meaning-exp: Your person status is where you, yourself, are a person. This is more than skin deep, though, this is your status after all. This is your character and personality. What's the status of your character? Good? Bad? Getting there?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Circumference, Perimeter, Edge, Surroundings, Locality, Neighborhood
context-en: I'm collecting coins with serrated edges.
context-en2: If there's something you love or are passionate about, you should stick with it regardless what the other people say.
context-en3: I'm worried about what other people are thinking about me.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji circumference, so it means circumference too.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You really want to measure the circumference of something but there doesn't seem to be anything round around. That's when you remember, "Mah Walnuts! (??)." The walnuts in your pocket have an easy edge to measure.

context-en: That comedian is sleeping like sleeping beauty.
context-en2: That comedian always almost makes it to the top, but never wins.
context-en3: He might be a natural-born performer.
meaning-exp: A person who does humorous acting is a comedian. You might think that this would be actor, but it's usually a comedian. Just think of them like more of a performer!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Tofugu is approaching perfection little by little every day.
context-en2: Unfortunately, Koichi has a perfect alibi.
context-en3: Oh jeez! Now you’ve completely distracted me. What was it that you wanted to talk about... office dog, was it?
meaning-exp: When something is all perfect it is complete. Not only that, but it's perfect (because it's ALL perfect, not just partially so).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Can you get me up before it's completed?
context-en2: Tofugu has accomplished a great deal in the last few days.
context-en3: Our new Japanese learning app will be completed in a month or so.
meaning-exp: When something has become perfect it has reached completion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Mission complete!
context-en2: The redevelopment that's been ongoing for a while in this town has finally been completed.
context-en3: I’ll call you back when my cellphone battery has finished charging, okay?
meaning-exp: A perfect finish is when everything is at total completion. Nothing is left over and all is done.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I don't want to give in.
context-en2: I couldn't compromise very well and everything came apart at the seams.
context-en3: At this job, compromise is not allowed.
meaning-exp: When you have gentle cooperation nobody has their way. You're very gently coming towards the middle, coming to a compromise. (Whether you like it or not.)
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My mother’s condition isn’t very good.
context-en2: You don't look great at all. Are you okay?
context-en3: I was a little under the weather yesterday.
meaning-exp: You have to find the right tool to suit your condition. If you have a health condition, the tool is a pill, or exercise, or real life friends. But it always depends on the condition you're in.
reading-exp: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ?. You've learned them both, so you should be able to read this word too!

context-en: There's a lot of fish on the menu. What is everyone getting?
context-en2: Mami mistook the cauliflower for white broccoli and cooked it.
context-en3: I can only cook simple cuisine.
meaning-exp: There is a reason for this fee that you have to pay to get in here. We are doing cooking and cuisine for you to eat while you're watching the show. If we weren't doing cooking, we probably wouldn't charge you this fee!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is the result of everyone's cooperation.
context-en2: Thanks to Koichi's cooperation, Viet successfully became a city council member in Seattle.
context-en3: Could you please cooperate or at least pretend to cooperate with us?
meaning-exp: Cooperation power is your level of cooperation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I await your response regarding the cycle of a pendulum.
context-en2: Actually, I've been practicing a song called "The Moon Cycle" because I wanted to play it for you, Kristen.
context-en3: Tohoku’s weather changes in short cycles.
meaning-exp: If you follow the circumference of a period of time, you end up back at the beginning and it makes a full cycle. Events in history always repeat, right?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Could you tell me the depth of this pool?
context-en2: The profundity of Koichi's wisdom is off the scale.
context-en3: Viet was bragging that he dug a hundred meter deep pit over the weekend.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji deep, so it means depth.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned ?? so you should be able to read this one too!

context-en: I wish so strongly for world peace.
context-en2: "I had a dream where I retired early and played video games all day, every day." "They say dreams reflect your desires. That must be what you desire."
context-en3: I want to get married but can’t find anyone that’s up to my standards.
meaning-exp: The hope you request is your desire. Just imagine yourself hoping and requesting some higher power for something you really want. What is this? It's your desire or wish.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm disappointed that there isn't a lot of whipped cream in this even though I asked for extra.
context-en2: That teacher isn't good at speaking English like I thought they'd be, so I'm disappointed.
context-en3: I’m really disappointed. I want to wear sleeveless shirts, but my chubby arms bother me a lot. My waist is getting flabby, too. My boyfriend tells me that he likes my pudgy fingers, but it doesn’t make me happy at all, you know?
meaning-exp: There is fault in your hope. It breaks, and everything falls apart. You feel massive disappointment and despair.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I miss Japanese erasers.
context-en2: The Tofugu team got one hundred pencils with rubbers on the end for Koichi's birthday present.
context-en3: "I could give you a chance to apologize to me, Koichi." "For what, Viet? For letting you throw me out of Tofugu office?" "It only happened because you stole my eraser! I need an apology!"
meaning-exp: You've seen the word ??, I hope. This comes from that. You're extinguishing something with ??. ?? is a word for either gummy or rubbery things. So, this is a gummy thing that extinguishes something. This is an eraser that extinguishes pencil markings.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so make sure you know that word so you can read this one!

context-en: I know you don't have any evil intent, but please understand that we could get hurt if you say something like that.
context-en2: I didn't do it out of malice, but I'm really sorry that I made you feel that way.
context-en3: By the way, how did you get the job without any experience in the first place? No offense, of course.
meaning-exp: Someone with bad energy is someone who has evil intent. Hopefully you don't have too much ??.
reading-exp: The reading itself has a lot of ?? with all the exceptions it has. The ? part is read like ??. Then, ? is rendaku'd. What an evil reading. Just think "what's the most evil reading I can come up with?" when you see this word. Then you should hopefully be able to read it.

vocab-meaning: Example Sentence, Model Sentence, Sample Sentence
context-en: I can't come up with a good sample sentence that uses the word "sample sentence."
context-en2: Please let us know which WaniKani example sentence is your favorite.
context-en3: For some reason my teacher always uses my name when she makes model sentences.
meaning-exp: Example writing is a piece of writing that is an example for maybe a word or a kanji or something like that. This is an example sentence.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: All the dishes at this restaurant are delicious without exception.
context-en2: Except for a few exceptional cases, I haven't actually seen this hospital successfully complete the procedure.
context-en3: Koichi usually sleeps in, but Friday is an exception because he has to wear a suit.
meaning-exp: Something that's outside the example doesn't follow the rules. It's not what it's supposed to be (the example), it is the exception.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: In recent years, there's been a gradual increase in the number of female politicians in Japan as well.
context-en2: This woman can squeeze onigiri very firmly with both hands, so Tofugu should hire her.
context-en3: I am not a girl. I’m a lady.
meaning-exp: Someone who's of the woman gender is probably going to be female.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I am taking a fine arts class at college.
context-en2: Leaders of companies need to have a sense for fine art, but Koichi doesn't have anything like that.
context-en3: Aya named her hideout the "Tofugu Terrible Art Gallery" because it was filled with her beautiful artwork-stuffed corpses. Koichi and Viet were to join her collection.
meaning-exp: The beauty art is not just any art. It's the best art. It's fine art.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: For example, let's say there was a person who used to be very popular but isn't at all anymore.
context-en2: For instance, what do you think Koichi would say when he almost bit his tongue?
context-en3: Hey, Sakura, why don’t you come over to my house, like, once or twice a week or something?
meaning-exp: This has almost the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. Instead of just simply being "example," though, it's for example. So, you could start a sentence with this and be all like "???, I am using ??? in a sentence."
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Using all kinds of "for examples" like this, you were taught (??) many things throughout your life. For example, you were taught about...

context-en: I think Darin's claim is fundamentally right, and that this formula is basic to mathematics.
context-en2: Koichi is learning the basics of Yakuza external economic policy from Viet.
context-en3: I’m a super beginner who doesn’t even know the most basic of basics of Japanese.
meaning-exp: The origin of your foundation is where you have to work from when learning something new. For example, the ?? portions of WaniKani are the earlier levels, especially the radicals. They are the foundation you need to learn your kanji and vocab later on.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you don't mind, why don't we play another game together?
context-en2: What was the outcome of the kendo match?
context-en3: "That baseball game was really terrible." "Yeah, tell me about it."
meaning-exp: An attempt to join together isn't just any get together. Imagine two people boxing. They attempt to knock each other out when they join together. That's why this word is game or match. Did you watch the ?? today? No! Don't tell me what happened, I recorded it on the VHS.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi ? for ? and the kun'yomi ?? for ?. You learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to put them together!

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to cut something that's extremely hard so you pull out your diamond cutters (??). Go ahead and imagine yourself cutting this ridiculously hard thing. Good thing you have diamond cutters, though.

You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You intentionally stub your toe (?) all the time! If you hurt your toe on purpose you can get out of class and work! It's a really simple injury, but you can't do other stuff while it's hurt, so you always do it on purpose to get out of things.

reading-exp: The reading is a bit strange using kun'yomi readings. Luckily, we taught you these already, so go put on that kimono of yours and relax at the ?? for a bit.

What about the personality of a male gender? Their personality status always seems to fit into gender roles, which is why the status of the gender dictates the personality. Make sense?

Just imagine telling someone your ??, only to have them laugh in your face and begin mocking ?? you for it. Now you're not so sure if your goal is going to work.

context-en3: I’m going on a date tonight. You can heat up some leftovers from lunch to eat for dinner. Love, Mom.

reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're waiting inside. The remainder of your forces are out there, fighting. You don't know who will survive... or if they even will. You have a secret knock (??), though, that you use to find out if it's one of the remaining forces outside or the enemy, broken through. You hear a knock. What is it? Is it your men or theirs? Imagine it out, focusing on the knock conversation that happens between you and the remainder.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned all of these readings already, good for you!
