When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You do your technique on a bad guy, coming at you. You flip him over and knock him out. He was (??) a threat, but now he's not. You look closer at the bad guy. Turns out it's Woz, the Apple Co-founder. He was just trying to hand you an iPhone12, not grab your wrist. Whoops!

context-en: The photos Viet took depict the beauty of the four seasons very well.
context-en2: My younger brother used to wear Japanese geta all year round.
context-en3: Can you tell me about Japan’s four seasons and what people do and eat during them?
meaning-exp: The four seasons are the four seasons. For some reason many Japanese people think that Japan's the only place with four distinct seasons. Obviously they haven't been to half the places on their latitude around the world.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ? is read using the on'yomi reading, which you've seen a few times over the course of WaniKani. Think of ? meaning "death" (like ?), and how with the four seasons there comes death every Fall and Winter.

vocab-meaning: To Be In Time For, To Make It On Time, To Be On Time For
context-en: If we get in a taxi right now, we might still make it on time.
context-en2: Sorry! I'm stuck in traffic, so I'm most likely not going to make it to the appointment on time.
context-en3: "Do you think we can make it in time?" "Well, it’s almost seven o’clock. Do the math."
meaning-exp: There is an interval (of time) that you need "to meet" (??). You need to be there before then. That's why this word means to be in time for.
reading-exp: You learned this reading for ? when you learned ????. And the reading for ?? is just that of the word ??. If you remember them both, you'll remember this word!

context-en: I have no idea what she's thinking, but I can relax when I'm with her.
context-en2: Viet calmed down the baby by giving her some scotch.
context-en3: "Damn him! I’m sick of my boss. I’m going to quit my job." "Whoa, whoa, whoa. Don’t be in such a hurry. Calm down."
meaning-exp: Hey. Drop yourself down and arrive back to me. You're going nuts over there. Lower down. Come back. Arrive. You need to do these things to calm down.
reading-exp: The readings come from ??? and ??. Hopefully you know these words so you can read this word as well! If you don't, just ???? and everything will be okay.

context-en: Let's go!
context-en2: This weekend I'm planning to visit my mom's grave.
context-en3: I visit a Shinto shrine every day.
meaning-exp: The kanji itself means participate, so you'd think this word would mean "to participate" but it doesn't (sorry!). It's a little more complex. Think of it as "to participate" but where you have to come or to go in order to do it. This is the humble way to say those things, so you're going to these places with your tail between your legs, just happy you can participate more than anything.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get to come to participate! "It's my (??) lucky day!" you exclaim.

context-en: It looks like this cat couldn't digest the fish skin and threw it up.
context-en2: Tofugu recommends that all employees use all their paid days off.
context-en3: I just ate 100 pieces of fugu sashimi. It’s gonna take a while to digest. (Burp)
meaning-exp: You know how ?? is "digestion"? Well, The verb form of that is this word, which is to digest.
reading-exp: If you know ?? you should be able to read this. Also, it uses the readings you learned with the kanji anyways, so no problemo there.

vocab-meaning: To Disappear, To Go Out, To Turn Off
context-en: WaniKani makes most of my income disappear.
context-en2: My eyebrows have worn off from my sweat.
context-en3: He waved goodbye until she completely disappeared from view.
meaning-exp: You've seen that ?? is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going to disappear on its own. How can you differentiate this from ??? Well, ?? allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin air (??). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it to disappear.
reading-exp: The reading is different from ??, unfortunately, so you can't use that. Just think about how after the object in front of you disappears you use a key (?) to open an invisible door. That's where everything's disappearing to! You see all your disappeared stuff on the other side of this invisible door which you opened with a magical key.

context-en: I'm quite susceptible to illness, so don't expect too much from me.
context-en2: The wife was anticipating that her husband would come back with clementines on their anniversary.
context-en3: I'm anticipating Valentine’s chocolate from girls other than my mother this year.
meaning-exp: Hopefully you know the word ?? by now (expectation). This is the verb version, which makes it to expect.
reading-exp: The reading comes from the word ??, so make sure you know that to know this one as well.

context-en: Please fold the gyoza skin over and make pleats.
context-en2: When I was folding origami at the cafe a girl approached me.
context-en3: When I was folding the paper I got a paper cut.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fold so the vocab verb version is to fold.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You fold your arm in half. "OH!" (?) you cry.

vocab-meaning: To Join Together, To Unify Together, To Unite, To Match, To Unify, To Bring Together, To Join
context-en: We joined all the red and white wires together.
context-en2: A man will only slow down to match a woman's pace if they like her.
context-en3: Hey, Steve. You’ve been living in Japan for a pretty long time now so don’t you think it’s time for you to adjust to Japanese customs? Stop being so picky and start eating fish.
meaning-exp: You know that the alternative kanji meaning for ? is join, which is what we're using here. The verb form of join is to join together, but we'll also call this to unify together.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so if you know that reading you'll know this reading as well.

vocab-meaning: To Make Someone Wait, To Keep Someone Waiting, To Make Wait, To Keep Waiting
context-en: It’s not okay to keep your senpai waiting.
context-en2: How much longer will I have to wait?
context-en3: Sorry for making you wait so long. I had to wait for the bus for such a long time.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wait so this word has something to do with waiting. Use the ?? as a hint. Someone "tossed" a ball off into a ditch, and then they had to find it. They made you wait for them to get the ball too, even though it's a cheap piece of crap. Feel upset about this.
reading-exp: You learned this reading from ??, congrats!

context-en: Almost all of my friends can push and move a truck with their hands.
context-en2: Koichi suddenly got up, started sleepwalking, and tried to move the massive grand piano.
context-en3: I can’t move my legs anymore because of that motorcycle accident.
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? hopefully, and know it means to move. This is similar to that, but now you're moving something else. You know this because as you go to move something the thing you're moving starts to cuss (??) you out because it's angry.
reading-exp: The reading for this can come from ??. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

context-en: That's so unfortunate.
context-en2: It was such a rare chance, so it's too bad that I missed it.
context-en3: "Is it true that I have to eat spiders on this TV program?" "Unfortunately, it is."
meaning-exp: The remainder of your thoughts are very small. You've thought of everything you possibly can to solve this problem. In the end, the remainder of your thoughts is left with one phrase: "too bad." There's nothing else to think but the remainder.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Pass A Test, To Pass An Exam
context-en: You worked so hard to pass the exam, so why did you quit university so suddenly?
context-en2: As of this morning, I didn't know if I passed the exam yet.
context-en3: I attended a cram school ostensibly to pass entrance exams, but I actually just wanted to hang out with my friends there.
meaning-exp: The status joins together. Think of this like a bunch of status messages on Facebook, all coming together at the same time. A big government test has just finished. Everyone's status' are joining on Facebook together to say they passed, showing to pass a test.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: To Put On, To Wear, To Pull Up
context-en: I wore earrings for the first time in a long time.
context-en2: Koichi has fun by secluding himself in his room and putting on masks from around the world every night.
context-en3: Could you promise me that you will wear this good luck charm all the time, please?
meaning-exp: Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: ?? (to wear), ?? (to arrive), and now ??? (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to ??, right? In this case, this word is like ???, which means "to attach." Think about how you're attaching your clothes to your body (and putting them on). That's why this is to put on or to wear. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??'s reading, but it might be easier to think it shares a reading with ???, which has a similar meaning. Put on clothes, attach on clothes, etc!

vocab-meaning: To Remain Behind, To Remain, To Stay Behind
context-en: Please stay behind if you think you're mysterious.
context-en2: We left for Portland, but Koichi remained behind in Japan.
context-en3: The new TextFugu will go down in history as the best Japanese learning material ever.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means remainder, so the verb vocab version is "to remainder." Let's make that sound better: to remain behind.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to remain behind. Everyone else leaves, and you think you're alone. Then, someone knocks (??) on the door. Your heart jumps in your throat. They knock again.

context-en: This Koichi doll revolves around this Viet doll at high speed by clockwork.
context-en2: Michael can make the ball spin without touching it.
context-en3: The swivel chair rotates like this.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means "rotation" or "revolution." So, what happens when you make it into a verb? It becomes to rotate and to revolve.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? of level 10. Alternatively, you can just use the readings of the kanji as well. EZPZ.

context-en: After the bicycle race, sweat was streaming down Viet's face.
context-en2: Which area does this river flow through?
context-en3: I like the sound of flowing water, so just let your tears stream down your cheeks. See? It’s so beautiful.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stream? It's to stream (though it's also to flow, a very similar word). You can differentiate this from ?? because with ?? you flush something down the toilet, which causes it to overflow so you sue (?) the toilet maker. With ??? you find a rare (??) jewel trying to flow down the river. You grab it, and see it's a rare diamond!
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??. So long as you know that you should be able to read this one as well!

context-en: It's important to log into WaniKani and study kanji every day.
context-en2: I like to study but I don't like to read.
context-en3: I’m too busy and I just don’t have enough time to study Einstein’s theory of relativity.
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? (study) by now, right? Well, this is the verb version of that. This is to study.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??. It's also the readings you learned with these kanji.

context-en: Circle the numbers on all of the correct answers.
context-en2: There are times when I wish I was surrounded by reporters again.
context-en3: Since Japan is surrounded by oceans, has salt always been available there?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surround so the verb vocab version is to surround.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been surrounded. They circle around you, calling you a chicken. "Cacko! (??) Cacko! Cacko!" Wait, this isn't the sound a chicken makes, right? You laugh at them, thinking their way of making a chicken noise is weird. Go ahead and join in with them and say "Cacko" with them as well.

vocab-meaning: To Travel, To Take A Trip
context-en: Not only is Aya traveling to South Korea, but she's also traveling to Japan.
context-en2: I went to a hair salon before taking my trip, but it ended up shorter than I'd wanted.
context-en3: Seriously, it’s already been a week since our trip together and he hasn’t called me back. I must have farted too many times while I was sleeping.
meaning-exp: You've hopefully seen ?? by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's to travel or to take a trip. These are fun to do. You should do them!
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??, but it also happens to use the reading you learned with the kanji anyways, so you should be able to read it.

vocab-meaning: To Wake Someone Up, To Wake Up, To Wake Someone
context-en: I tried really hard to wake you up, but it didn't work.
context-en2: We don't want to wake our sleeping baby, so please don't buzz the intercom.
context-en3: You are absolutely correct, Viet! We should definitely wake Koichi up right now!
meaning-exp: You've seen ??? which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are doing the waking up, which makes the meaning of this word to wake someone up. How do you differentiate between this and ???? Because of the ? on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and sue (?) you, making you wish you never woke them up.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???, so as long as you know that word you should be able to read this one. Of course, you can also imagine them yelling "OH!" when you shake them awake too, if that helps.

vocab-meaning: To Warm Up, To Warm, To Heat Up, To Heat
context-en: Please don't heat that bowl in the microwave.
context-en2: Before I go to bed, I like to heat up milk and drink it.
context-en3: Kombu seaweed releases its sweet flavor when it’s soaked in water and heated up.
meaning-exp: Have you seen ??? (warm) yet? Probably. If you have, you can guess that the verb version is to warm up or to warm.
reading-exp: The reading is the same like ???. As long as you know that word, you should be able to associate that reading with this word.

vocab-meaning: To Wish, To Desire, To Wish For
context-en: Koichi had a strong desire to lick his toenails.
context-en2: These days it seems like you can watch anything you wish on YouTube.
context-en3: I got a haircut but it just made me look even more childish. I was hoping to look like a stylish 35-year-old woman. Boohoo.
meaning-exp: If you have a hope and you turn it into a verb, you'd think it would be "to hope." But what is really behind a hope? It's a desire or wish, right? That's why this word means to wish or to desire.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your one wish that you have is to have a bigger nose (??). Feel your nose, it's too small. You wish it was two or three inches longer. Of course, if it helps to imagine you want a smaller nose or a nose at all, that's fine too. Just make sure you wish you have something nose-related.

context-en: At first, I thought the traveler was unsociable, but when I tried talking to her, I discovered she was actually very interesting.
context-en2: Normally we would not do this, but since you are a tourist, we'll comply with your request.
context-en3: Hey, look, look. Don’t you think that tourist is wearing clothes that are completely unsuitable for her age?
meaning-exp: You've seen that ?? is "trip." So who is someone who goes on trips? That is a tourist or traveler.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the reading of ?? already.

context-en: Koichi is wearing special boxers today.
context-en2: We must ship all of the underwear orders on time.
context-en3: Which underwear do you want? The plant or animal patterned ones? Pick whichever one you like.
meaning-exp: The things you wear below your other clothes. That is your underwear. You do wear underwear, right?
reading-exp: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. ? uses the reading you learned with ??, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that ? becomes ? here.

context-en: All the money my son worked so hard to slowly save up was used to pay his union membership fees.
context-en2: I have to attend an organization meeting tomorrow, so please wake me up at six.
context-en3: Hello. My name is Koichi and I am the events manager for the Portland Kendo Association here in Portland, Oregon.
meaning-exp: When you meet for cooperation, you're coming together to help each other. One form of this is when people form unions. They're all cooperating and coming together to help each other and themselves.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Verbal Abuse, Saying Bad Things, Insult, Slander, Bad Mouth
context-en: Viet started shouting verbal abuse at Koichi with a malicious grin.
context-en2: I've never bad mouthed my husband in front of my kids.
context-en3: I heard that all of my friends were saying bad things about me.
meaning-exp: Your bad mouth is saying bad things (as usual!). Everything that comes out of this bad mouth of yours is verbal abuse. One day someone's going to pop you in that bad mouth of yours.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings for these two kanji, probably because this word is just two words put together into one (bad + mouth). Use your knowledge of the vocab words ?? and ? to learn the reading of this word. Okay, I lied. You can also do ???? if you want. Sorry to say such bad things before.

context-en: I yearn for a Japan-style life.
context-en2: This anime is very Japanese, yeah?
context-en3: Fugu found a very Japanese gentleness in Salmon.
meaning-exp: Things that are targeted as Japanese are more than just Japanese, they are very Japanese. This word may be hard to understand at first, but there are many things the Japanese consider to be Japanese-only. These theories range from reasonable to ridiculous, but either way, you'll see them described as ???.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read ?? as well.

context-en: Start squatting in the meeting place on my signal.
context-en2: The waiting room was so cold that I got a bladder infection.
context-en3: I ran into a friend from a long time ago in the waiting room of the hospital and we chatted about the old days.
meaning-exp: The place you wait to join other people is a waiting room or a meeting place.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings, but it's like the hiragana that normally sticks out is stuffed in. ?? ? ?, ?? ? ? and is pronounced the same too. I know it's confusing, but once you get it down you'll never forget!

context-en: What are your desires?
context-en2: My mom told me that the more time and effort you can put into it, the closer you will get to making your wish come true.
context-en3: Just as Salmon had hoped, Fugu proposed to her.
meaning-exp: A hope is really a wish that you have inside of you (though it can still be a hope too).
reading-exp: What's your one big wish? It's to have a different nose (??). Alternatively, you could think "nose on me" for ???.

vocab-meaning: With Trouble, With Difficulty, Going Through The Trouble, Trouble With, Difficulty With, On Purpose, Deliberately
context-en: I appreciate your offer, but we're not making any more compromises on this matter.
context-en2: Are you going to throw away my kind advice?
context-en3: Well, it’s a good opportunity to make a long-awaited change to my look, so I might as well get it shortened in the back by about 30 centimeters.
meaning-exp: When you fold things at all sorts of angles you have quite a mess. It's not easy going through life with all these folds and angles. That's why this word means with trouble because you certainly aren't traversing along a nice and flat piece of space-time, are you? Nah, it's all angled and folded :(
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Watch out for the ?? changing to ??, though. Another thing you have to go through with trouble, I'm afraid.

context-en: If you have nothing to do, can you help me carry some wood?
context-en2: "Mokuzai" refers to raw wood material that is not yet processed, and "zaimoku" refers to wood that is a finished product and can be used immediately.
context-en3: I can make time on the second. Why don’t we meet up at the lumberyard and talk?
meaning-exp: Wood that is lumber is lumber wood.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: AD, Anno Domini, After Death, CE, Common Era
context-en: This caveman just calmly waited until he could finally get out of his slump in Common Era.
context-en2: I didn't know that the screw wouldn't go in straight if you do it forcefully until Anno Domini.
context-en3: Similar Fugu patterns can be seen on local earthenware made between 50 B.C. and 20 A.D.
meaning-exp: The origin is after the narrative. What narrative was this? It's THE narrative, to many. This is the narrative of Jesus. This was so important that they decided to start a new era after it, making this era after death* or AD. *Yes, I know it's not actually "After Death" but it's so commonly misconceived as such that I put it in there as the definition. You understand the meaning still, right? Anno Domini is also available as a definition too, so don't fret!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I wonder which one is a better deal, all you can eat or all you can drink?
context-en2: "Can you plan a drinking party, Kanae?" "Okay! What's the theme of the party?" "Well, it's for the presentation of Viet's cosplay collection that he bought in Japan." "Okay. Can we do it at a super cheap all-you-can-drink Izakaya?"
context-en3: "So, you went to an all you can drink place last night. Anything else?" "No, that’s about it."
meaning-exp: Drinking as much as you want is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an all you can drink place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!
reading-exp: The reading comes from the word ?? (????) and ?? (??). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.

context-en: I feel like my memory of going to the all you can eat restaurant with you is growing distant.
context-en2: I went to an all-you-can-eat cake cafe in Japan and I was actually able to eat more than I'd expected.
context-en3: Ok, the coast is clear. Let’s go get all you can eat yakiniku.
meaning-exp: When you eat as much as you want, you are getting an all you can eat deal.
reading-exp: The reading consists of the readings of ??? and ??. If you know those you should be able to read this too.

context-en: Did you see what's in that weirdo's closet?
context-en2: I challenged myself to set a new world record for acting like an oddball, but I was ten minutes shy.
context-en3: Your boss is a little eccentric but I think you’re going to fit right in.
meaning-exp: A strange person is an eccentric. They are also an oddball.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The building constructed by that company doesn't meet current quake-resistance standards.
context-en2: Can I see a breakdown of these construction costs, please?
context-en3: Many people are fascinated by the traditional architecture found in places like Kyoto and Nara and I’m one of them.
meaning-exp: When it comes to building and constructing, the thing that puts them all together into one is architecture. If you don't have any architecture, who knows what the building will look like.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please! Help me!
context-en2: "Can you do me a favor...?" "Of course. Name it."
context-en3: Smaller companies take on new challenges more rapidly, so they probably won't mind if we request a job like this.
meaning-exp: The noun form of request (don't be tricked by the ? on the end, it's not an adjective). So, request goes to a request.
reading-exp: The reading is the same like ??????. Hopefully you're able to read that by now so you're able to read this too.

context-en: The true commander of the Tofugu army is not Koichi, but Viet.
context-en2: How could we evade the enemy troops' pursuit?
context-en3: Let’s go back to the army base for now.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: Fall is my absolute favorite season.
context-en2: When you hear "fall" what do you associate it with? As you can probably imagine, I do think of "fall appetites."
context-en3: What? You’ve only gone out to dinner with him once so far this fall? Have you lost your mind? Don’t you think it’s strange to think about calling him your boyfriend? I don’t think you can say you’re dating him.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, ??.

context-en: That boss' coat was made of very durable material.
context-en2: It seems that my superior is very interested in Japanese history.
context-en3: Shark said you are the boss in name only.
meaning-exp: The director who is above you is your boss or superior.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Let's race and see which one of us can make it to that boulder first.
context-en2: At Tofugu, there is a rule that people should leave Koichi alone when his face looks like a boulder.
context-en3: Koichi woke up as a huge boulder fell toward him in a dream.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you can read this one!

context-en: It was very tough work persuading the stubborn British prime minister, wasn't it?
context-en2: A great number of people visit United Kingdom to golf every year.
context-en3: The UK has an antagonistic relationship with the US.
meaning-exp: The England country is where England is. This word can refer to Britain, the United Kingdom and England! Note that ???? is more common for "England" - but, since this is a kanji learning website you should learn this word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Viet has decided to leave the Yakuza group and follow the teachings of Buddha.
context-en2: Koichi is always as cool as Buddha and as strict as Yama, the King of Hell.
context-en3: There are some proverbs related to Buddha like, "what you don’t know can’t hurt you," and, "the crushed worm will turn."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go up to Buddha. You want to rub his head for good luck, because that's what you hear is good to do. Right before you touch him, he backs off and says, "Whoa! I'm hot, okay?" (???). You touch him and it burns your hand clean off. Imagine saying "hot, okay?" in a strange accent to help you to remember.

reading-exp: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. Remember the word ?? It has the same reading as this. Just think of everyone measuring the heights of things with bamboo (??) poles with markers on them. Okay, this one is 5 bamboo poles high!

When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about your husband even if you don't have one. What's his name? It's Otto (???), and he's always leaving you at home because he's working at the auto (???) shop.

context-en: What year did Shanghai Incident occur?

meaning-exp: An action that takes place that could change the locale or even the world has got to be a big incident. You'll sometimes see this on the ends of "incident" names, like the "Manshuu Jihen" (????), aka the "Manshuu Incident." You know that it isn't an unusual or strange incident (like ??) because the "strange" kanji (?) doesn't come first with this word. Instead, it comes after and means "change" in this case.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I want to tell my uncle that my mom passed away, but I don't have a way to get in touch with him.

reading-exp: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: When the go-between gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him two takes (??) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second.

reading-exp: The reading is the vocab word ? (?) and the reading for cat (??).

context-en: Recently we haven't been able to get our meal timing right, have we?
context-en2: Damn it! I just spilled my rice.
context-en3: Why is there a big ball of dried-up, cooked rice in Koichi's desk drawer?
meaning-exp: The ? just makes this word more polite and fancy. When it comes to food, it's nice to be those things. This has the same meaning as the kanji (meal) making it meal, but it also refers to cooked rice as well. So, "Come eat your ??" can be both "come eat your rice" and "come eat your meal." Really, since most Japanese meals come with rice, though, you can see how the overlap happens.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "hand" me another bowl of rice?

context-en: Oh no. I forgot to cook rice.
context-en2: Koichi would rather work for Tofugu than eat.

reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a meal... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a Mesh (??) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.

context-en: Oh no, I forgot to reply. What have I gotten myself into?
context-en2: It said "read," but I never got a reply.
context-en3: How’s it going? I thought I sent a reply to you, but it seems that I was too tired and fell asleep before pressing the ’send’ button. Sorry. Forgive me.
meaning-exp: You gotta believe it will return. What are you believing in returning? The reply. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I lost my precious ring and I feel awful.
context-en2: I can't get this ring off of my finger.
context-en3: "When I get a bonus, I’ll buy you a diamond ring." "You always say that, but words are just words."
meaning-exp: A finger ring is the kind of ring you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.
reading-exp: The readings come from the individual vocab readings, ? and ?. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as ???.

context-en: This elastic band is very durable.
context-en2: They suspected I was the rubber band robber, but I've now been cleared of all charges.
context-en3: Oh my God, I just totally love your dress! So many colorful rubber band pictures printed on it, eh? I’ve never seen a dress like this before.
meaning-exp: A ring of gum (??) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a rubber band.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is ?, making this word ???.

vocab-meaning: Serious, Terrible, Very, Difficult, Hard, Hectic
context-en: Acquiring Japanese is difficult, but do your best!
context-en2: They had a very healthy child.
context-en3: When there's a disaster, the phone and Internet circuits are overloaded and it gets hard to connect to them, so it's difficult to upload new blog posts.
meaning-exp: A big change is a really serious thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a terrible event. Also, in more recent history this has come to mean very as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This beach is shallow, so even kids can swim safely here.
context-en2: I don't want to become a person with shallow thoughts.
context-en3: Whenever I get drunk, I only get light sleep and wake up early in the morning.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shallow? It's shallow.
reading-exp: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, making this ???

context-en: It's simply because Koichi is a very hard worker.
context-en2: Koichi said, "To me, Tofugu is not merely for earning money. It's my life."
context-en3: In kendo, it’s important not simply to defeat your opponent but also to train your own mind.
meaning-exp: If you're moving towards (?) simple, you're saying simply or merely. This is one of those words that come at the beginning of a sentence. "Simply... "
reading-exp: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That temple stands at the top of this hill.
context-en2: Viet likes going down gentle slopes on his bicycle.
context-en3: The Tofugu baseball team has been on a downward slope since it lost its star player, Fugu.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as this one.

context-en: Because there are American military bases in Okinawa, there are a lot of soldiers.
context-en2: That soldier's brave acts saved a lot of lives.
context-en3: My boss told me yesterday that I am going to be fired, so now I’m seriously thinking about becoming a soldier.
meaning-exp: An army person is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're soldiers.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You should make the foundation as firm as possible.
context-en2: This car is solidly built.
context-en3: I had a really solid pair of glasses made by my optician.
meaning-exp: A stubborn height is a shorter, stockier height. It makes a person especially solid, firm, and stout.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I don't like bugs, so I don't like spring.
context-en2: "How did your team do in the spring tournament?" "Hehe. Epic win."
context-en3: I heard the reason the character for "spring" is used for spring roll is because people used to make spring rolls with vegetables that sprout in spring.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Ah, the beauty of spring! Err... ??, I mean.

vocab-meaning: Spring Break, Spring Vacation, Spring Holiday
context-en: During the spring holiday promotion, admission is only 1,000 yen for students.
context-en2: Any of these times during spring vacation would work for me.
context-en3: Are you over your cold yet? It sucks having a cold during spring break, eh? If it’s still bad, don’t stay up late. Get well soon.
meaning-exp: You've seen ??? and ???. If that isn't enough, you can see that this is a spring rest of some kind. That would be a spring break or spring vacation.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. The ?? part is the same as the vocab word ??, which hopefully you can read! If you know those readings, you can read this too.

context-en: I thought there was a strange man behind the pole, but it was just Koichi.
context-en2: It's absolutely absurd that men get higher pay than women despite doing the same work!
context-en3: That’s strange. I can’t find the email you say you sent me anywhere in my mailbox.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is more the "strange" meaning though, not the "change" one. As in, you ???!.
reading-exp: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. How strange! Or not.

context-en: Because of the sudden, strange incident, today's stock market is in a grave situation.
context-en2: All WaniKani users were worried that some unusual incident had befallen Tofugu.
context-en3: I always get excited during that ominous silence that happens before an unusual incident.
meaning-exp: A strange action that takes place is something that shouldn't have happened (but it did). This is a strange incident. The difference between this and ?? is that while ?? can also be used to describe a strange incident, it also can be used to talk about another type of incident as well. For example, the "Manshuu Jihen" is the "Manshuu Incident." This word, ?? is more just a strange or unusual incident.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My wife isn't very healthy and she gets sick often.
context-en2: This chair is so sturdy that even a sumo wrestler can sit down in it without it breaking.
context-en3: I know he’s a sturdy guy, but I’m a little worried about his excessive eating and drinking habits.
meaning-exp: With the height of my husband, he's very firm. Try to push him over. Impossible. He's so tall and sturdy due to his height.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

context-en: When I was syncing my iPhone, it turned off and I was a little freaked out.
context-en2: I wonder why Dropbox always freezes while syncing photos.
context-en3: It will probably show up soon. My Evernote is syncing right now.
meaning-exp: Something is making one thing the same as another inside a period of time. You'll see this word on computer-ish things a lot. This is syncing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi and Viet secretly keep some good-tasting whiskey in the office.
context-en2: I like trying little bits of many different tasty dishes.
context-en3: Recently, a lot of pubs with delicious food have been opening in the Tofugu office.
meaning-exp: Something with a beauty taste is something that is really tasty / good tasting / delicious. Mmmm, yum!
reading-exp: The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word ???? already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something delicious. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "OI (??). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"

context-en: Apparently, the body of someone who died accidentally was found at the temple last night.
context-en2: I lived next to a temple when I was a child and it was really convenient for studying Buddhism.
context-en3: I held a birthday party at one of the local temples in Japan. We got kicked out pretty quickly. I should have known that a temple wasn’t a good place to have a rock concert.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji too! You must have been praying to the kanji Gods at the local ??.

context-en: Nowadays it is very rare to meet somebody big like you, Mr. Koichi.
context-en2: Owing to recent trends, Koichi decided to have a Shiba-inu and a Jindo in our office.
context-en3: They say it's been a hard time for job seekers these days, but I'm sure you should be able to find a job if you're not picky about the company you work for.
meaning-exp: Previous from now are the times around now. They're these days.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that ?? changes to ?? as many K-column sounds do in situations like this.

vocab-meaning: To Arrange, To Put In Order, To Adjust, To Prepare
context-en: Viet arranges his mustache into a triangle every morning.
context-en2: My older brother put all the things in order regarding our father's funeral.
context-en3: We’ll introduce you to hormone balance adjustment methods.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means arrange, so the verb version is to arrange.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to arrange a bunch of food on a table for the people of OZ. You turn around to grab the last one and hear all of the plates start crashing to the ground. You turn around and yell, "Toto no (???)!" Your dog Toto jumped on the table and is knocking everything over. Now you'll have to prepare everything all over again. Dammit Toto.

vocab-meaning: To Arrange, To Organize, To Sort
context-en: I really appreciate that you organized the bookshelf.
context-en2: It takes a great deal of time and effort to arrange all of these documents.
context-en3: So let me get this straight. It’s okay for men to cheat, but not for women. Is that what you’re trying to say?
meaning-exp: When you arrange something with reason you're arranging it. That's why this is to arrange.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Be Fond Of, To Like
context-en: This Japanese sake is what my heavy drinker of a father liked when he was alive.
context-en2: Koichi likes eating black garlic.
context-en3: I’m sorry, Mr. Koichi. Whether you like it or not, your secrets might get revealed.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "like." Although ?? is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be to be fond of or to like.
reading-exp: The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is ??, so think of this. What is it that you're particularly fond of? Getting a cone (??) with your ice cream (which you're also fond of, who isn't?). Think of all the different cones you can get: waffle cones, sugar cones, oreo cones, yum!

context-en: Believe it or not, Viet turned out to be a spy.
context-en2: I'm the type of person who only trusts what they can actually see.
context-en3: I guess I've been irritated lately by the fact that I no longer believe in Santa Claus.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means believe so the verb vocab version is to believe.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is ?? no matter what! See, if you believe, good things will happen. You should be able to read this.

context-en: This man is well known for building very sturdy houses.
context-en2: The king built an unbelievably beautiful castle on top of the mountain.
context-en3: Our company is saving money to build a school for children in another country.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means build so the verb vocab version is to build.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? ???. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!

context-en: When you become an adult, it's difficult to change your way of thinking.
context-en2: Oh, please do not change the shape of Fugu's lips. They were inspired by Koichi's favorite food, cod roe. If you change them, Koichi will be sad.
context-en3: When you change the shape of your eyebrows, you look like a different person.
meaning-exp: The kanji is change, but this verb is to change. If you change one thing for another thing, you are going to change it, after all. This word refers to changing one thing for a similar thing.
reading-exp: I don't like this car. I would like to change it for another car (?).

vocab-meaning: To Clear Up, To Become Sunny
context-en: It's raining right now, but I think it will clear up by two.
context-en2: It was good that it ended up being very sunny yesterday.
context-en3: I’m finally getting married to Fugu and I want you to be at our wedding. I’ll send you an invitation with all the details later. The reception will be outside, so I hope it’s sunny that day.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means clear up, so the verb vocab version is to clear up. It also means to become sunny as well.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. One of those words where the kun'yomi's going to be more useful.

context-en: Aww. I'm so happy I'm about to burst into tears!!
context-en2: It's shameful that I cried onstage in public.
context-en3: I’m crying because my salary was cut. I want to transfer to a higher paying job.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cry so the verb vocab version is to cry.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember the kanji reading you'll have no problem with this word.

vocab-meaning: To Fire, To Hit, To Break Wind, To Let Loose, To Set Free
context-en: Koichi is known for being a volleyball player that can serve a very sharp curveball.
context-en2: That player let out a stinky fart as soon as he hit a home run.
context-en3: When are you thinking of letting this bird out of the cage?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned the verbs ?? and ??? but this one is a little different. This is a specific kind of releasing. It means to fire an arrow, or to hit a baseball. It even works when you're releasing a fart. Yes, it means to break wind too. What a great word!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

vocab-meaning: To Look Back At, To Triumph Over
context-en: I will be the Tofugu president and show Koichi, who looked down on me, what I can do.
context-en2: When I gave the kitten some sardines, she looked back at me with a face that was like, "Is this really for me?!" and it was super cute.
context-en3: You should look back over your test before you submit it.
meaning-exp: When you want to see something one more time before you have to return it, you need to look back at it. It might be your last chance to look at it, you know?
reading-exp: The readings are from the words ? and ?? put together.

context-en: Kristen knows the lyrics of the Sailor Moon's theme song by heart.
context-en2: I have to memorize every single line in the script by tomorrow.
context-en3: Memorizing sentences is more efficient than memorizing words by themselves.
meaning-exp: Hopefully you've seen ?? before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have to memorize.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.

context-en: I practiced pronouncing the word "meat" for six hours yesterday.
context-en2: I'm practicing the line in the play that goes, "I didn't raise you to be such an ungrateful child!
context-en3: "Dude, we were absolutely crushed." "Yeah, it was a complete failure. I guess we need more practice."
meaning-exp: You've hopefully seen ??, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have to practice.
reading-exp: The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word ??. You should be able to read this!

context-en: Can you start projecting slides onto the screen for me?
context-en2: Why don't we use this white wall as a screen to project the movie?
context-en3: Only Viet knows that Koichi really likes seeing himself reflected full-length in the mirror.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "to be reflected." Now you're doing the reflecting, which is really projecting (light). That's why this word is to project.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??. So long as you know the reading of ?? you should be able to read this one too.

context-en: Kanae distributed souvenirs to her colleagues after she had come back from Japan.
context-en2: I couldn't figure out the answer to the question asking to put the word "to like" in the past tense, so I just went home.
context-en3: "I’m hungry and my legs are sore," Bilbo said, just before turning to return home to the Shire.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return home so the verb vocab version is to return home.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can return home happily, knowing how to read this word!

context-en: The total number of the victims who were fished by Viet's scam came to one hundred.
context-en2: Can you come up with the total for me, please?
context-en3: I added the numbers over and over again and got a different sum each time. Am I stupid?
meaning-exp: When you join all your measurements together you have yourself a total.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Traffic Light, Signal, Traffic Signal, Stoplight, Semaphore
context-en: You stop at a red light and cross the street at a green light, okay?
context-en2: It's dangerous to ignore traffic lights, so don't do that okay?
context-en3: Listen carefully. Turn left at the sixth traffic light, walk another eight blocks, turn right and shake your butt toward someone you will meet there. That’s the secret sign, okay? Then, he will take you to our hideout.
meaning-exp: If you believe in the numbers, there will be no traffic because the traffic light will be functioning properly. Traffic lights are based all off of traffic data and numbers. You just have to believe and hope it all works out in terms of these traffic lights.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The Tofugu team completely trusts what Koichi says.
context-en2: Koichi's scandal has injured Tofugu's credit.
context-en3: I thought I would score some points with my wife if I cleaned the house, made dinner, gave her a massage, and sung her to sleep, but instead she divorced me.
meaning-exp: Your task is to believe. In order to do that, you have to have plenty of trust in what you believe in... not to mention confidence.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The police are investigating Koichi's unnatural death.
context-en2: "You look upset. Is everything alright?" "I just heard that Koichi died an accidental death and Tofugu went bankrupt. It’s a nightmare."
context-en3: The news that Koichi met a mysterious and unnatural death shocked the nation.
meaning-exp: A strange death is one that doesn't seem right. It's an unnatural death, and probably an accidental death (ie wasn't caused by natural causes).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi dropped the clock Viet had given him from the ship.
context-en2: We're gonna meet at the clock tower at 3 p.m., okay?
context-en3: Hey, isn’t that spit on your watch?
meaning-exp: A thing that gives you time measurements is a watch or clock. Most people have these in their phones instead of on their wrists now.
reading-exp: The reading for this is pretty weird. ? is all nice and normal, but ? is ? for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word ? (??), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your watch is a walky talky (???) and run with that?

context-en: I made a notebook for Japanese vocabulary.
context-en2: When I don't know the meaning of a word, I look it up in my dictionary.
context-en3: I created a Japanese word game. Do you want to try?
meaning-exp: The simple bits of language are the individual words. If you think about it, this is true. First of all, there are a ton of them. Second, they're tiny. They're just little bits of language and the "word" for these little bits is word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Did you sleep well last night?
context-en2: It was Labor Day in the U.S. and Canada yesterday.
context-en3: We had to read many epic poems yesterday for a university assignment.
meaning-exp: The yesterday day is yesterday. What a blast from the past!
reading-exp: Oof. The reading for this word makes no sense. You'll have to forget everything you've learned about the readings of the kanji and just go straight up mnemonic for the word on its own. Okay. Think about what you did yesterday, all day. You played keno (???), gambling away your grandmother's money. Yesterday was the worst day ever because you lost everything playing Keno. Today is different, not like yesterday, right?

context-en: My mom is out shopping, so my sister and I are house sitting.
context-en2: I visited Koichi's house, but he was not there.
context-en3: My husband is always away from home because of his business trips. I get very lonely so I call him at least five times a day.
meaning-exp: You have gotten a mission. You must go out and detain a dangerous criminal to protect your country. While you go do that, you will be away from home and have an absence from society.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My position as cook was confirmed by Koichi's letter.
context-en2: The chef ruefully said, "If you don't like my food, just leave it."
context-en3: The chef grabbed the bottle opener hanging from the freezer door.
meaning-exp: You've seen ?? and probably know it means "cooking." So, what is a person who does cooking? That is a cook or chef.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I heard that Koichi is going to be a pupil of the famous kendo master.
context-en2: I haven't completed the admissions procedure yet.
context-en3: Do you think that TextFugu is the best introduction to Japanese, even for someone like me who’s unfamiliar with it? Should I buy it?
meaning-exp: If you are able to enter the gate then you have gained admission and entrance to the facility.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Viet left the work unfinished and went on an adventure.
context-en2: We should reserve our energy for our adventure tomorrow.
context-en3: We went on an adventure trip up the Nile River, but my boyfriend caught West Nile Virus and he is still in the hospital.
meaning-exp: You dare to do something risky. It's adventure time! Imagine yourself daring yourself to do risky things. Is this an adventure? If not, make it so!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm not a doctor but I learned heart transplant techniques from a doctor.
context-en2: I learned the art of selling from the company I used to work for.
context-en3: I married a technically brilliant boxer.
meaning-exp: You've seen ? as a vocab word meaning "technique." This is sort of using that meaning. So, a technique of art is still art, but it's also your craft, your technique.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You can get a discount if you buy this item in bulk.
context-en2: He is a nice, manly person but he uses coarse language, so I find it a bit difficult to get along with him.
context-en3: A congratulatory gift for the new business’s opening arrived from Mr. Koichi and I put it on your desk. On the card he wrote that you overwhelmed him with your power and how fast you were able to open your business.
meaning-exp: This is the same as the kanji, at least in regards to the article or goods meaning, which means you can use this word to mean article or goods.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

context-en: I can't hide my wry smile at this artist's works.
context-en2: The artist asked his disciple to look after his house while he was away and left for Europe to study.
context-en3: How about running a marathon with a bunch of artists the month after next?
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is art so you'd think that ??? would be something like "art house." Well, it's not. Think of it this way: Who is the person who works for "House Art"? It's the artist.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That's an automated tweet by a bot.
context-en2: This train's doors don't open automatically.
context-en3: If someone breaks into your house this machine will automatically send a message to the security company.
meaning-exp: An automatical (?? + ?) thing of course isn't "automatical." A better way to say it is to cut off the -al and call it automatic.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the reading of ?? as well.

context-en: I feel betrayed by that car dealership.
context-en2: We are trying to set some money aside for a new car.
context-en3: I lost my driver’s license.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is automatic. So what is an automatic car? That is an automobile.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? and the kanji ?'s readings, combined.

context-en: This miniature garden work is made from a matchbox.
context-en2: The strange statue at the entrance of Tofugu office is a work of Koichi's from when he was fifteen.
context-en3: It’s been a while since I came across a work I like. Attack on Titan is so good that it might be one of my top three anime. I highly recommend it.
meaning-exp: A product you make is a fine work. It is a work you made. It is of your production.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: In my bag, there's a wallet, a bento, and a pack of cigarettes.
context-en2: I left some sides in my box lunch and gave them to a kitten.
context-en3: I think I’ll make a bento box for you tomorrow. Is there anything you’d prefer not to have?
meaning-exp: You know how ? means dialect and ? means success? Well, this isn't going to help you much, because this means bento or box lunch. Chances are, though, you know the word "bento" from English. So, if you read this word (which you should be able to) you can figure out it's ????. If you do that, you can realize this word means bento too!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi turned pale when he learned that his precious cardboard box had been thrown away.
context-en2: My husband bought tomatoes by the crate and we're having trouble eating them all.
context-en3: The box that arrived at the Tofugu office was crammed with dictionaries and dead puffer fish.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: Brand New, New Item, New Product
context-en: I dropped my brand new abacus onto the train tracks.
context-en2: I spilt some fermented soy beans on my new jeans and that ruined my mood.
context-en3: "I heard you bought a new computer." "Well, it’s not brand new. It’s a hand-me-down from Viet."
meaning-exp: A new product is something that's brand new or a new item. I like looking around the store for the brand new stuff because it's interesting!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice though that ?? changes to ??. This is because you're buying some brand new pins?

context-en: Can you put the Buddhist scriptures in this box?
context-en2: During peak hours, please be considerate of others waiting to use the Buddhist writings.
context-en3: Do you know how the Buddhist scriptures were translated from Sanskrit to Chinese?
meaning-exp: The Buddha rules are the rules Buddha made for Buddhists. These can be found in the Buddhist Scriptures and Buddhist Writings.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ?? gets shortened to ??.

context-en: Koichi demanded an explanation about the wet character dictionary from Viet.
context-en2: It suddenly started pouring rain and the kanji dictionary I was holding got soaking wet.
context-en3: I bought this calligraphy dictionary at a secondhand bookstore over there.
meaning-exp: The rules for letters can be found in a character dictionary. In Japanese, one "letter" or "character" can have a lot of information (we're talking kanji here). That means you need dictionaries for these individual letters as well! That's what this is.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi seems to like taking classical poses in photos.
context-en2: It's super shameful that I was deceived by such a classical fraud.
context-en3: That classical-style Japanese painter is the pickiest person I know. I can’t understand why she cares so much.
meaning-exp: When something is "old rules-like," it is not very modern. It is in the past. It is classical.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Complete Recovery, Healed, Fully Recovered, Fully Recover, Healed Completely, Heal Completely, Completely Cured, Fully Cured, Fully Healed
context-en: The doctor told me that it's difficult to recover completely and I'd probably have some permanent damage left over.
context-en2: Although I was observing the traffic rules strictly, I was hit by a truck and got a bad injury that would take a year to heal completely.
context-en3: When Viet suffered severe cuts from a gang war that would have normally taken six months to heal completely, Koichi healed him with his special healing powers.
meaning-exp: All cured! That means you've made a complete recovery! You're healed!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I like Japanese anime voice actors but I have no interest in foreign ones.
context-en2: What is your greatest concern at the moment?
context-en3: Thank you for your interest in our company, Tofugu, and our products.
meaning-exp: The things related to your heart are the things that concern and interest you the most.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Viet is a yakuza, but I can say for sure that he is not connected to that crime.
context-en2: Viet is wondering if he should cut his connections with the yakuza and just focus on his work at Tofugu.
context-en3: "He’s been married before and has three kids." "I know, but that has nothing to do with it."
meaning-exp: A connection related to another connection obviously has some kind of connection, at least between all those meanings.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My school was very conservative, so students were required to wear uniforms in accordance with the school regulations.
context-en2: Do you think the Japanese are conservative people?
context-en3: Koichi told Viet that people tend to become more conservative as they get older, but he doesn’t want to be like that.
meaning-exp: Who are all like "I want to preserve and protect what I have, get out of my business, government!"? That's why people who want to preserve and protect are conservative.
reading-exp: The reading doesn't match up for this word's ?. The reading is ??, but you can remember that because the conservatives want to protect and preserve their hoes (?) and their shoes (??) from the government. For some reason those get taxed a lot.

vocab-meaning: Covering An Event, Collecting Data, Data Collection, Interview
context-en: I'm wondering if you would allow us to get an interview?
context-en2: The clip where I was interviewed by a TV crew and I said that money isn't everything was used for a news program.
context-en3: I know it’s difficult, but isn’t there any way that I could collect some data on your husband? If you could help me set up the interview, I would really really appreciate it.
meaning-exp: Your job is to take materials from a bunch of different people because you're covering an event. This data collection needs to be thorough, so you try to take all the materials you can from as many people as you can find.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I've mastered the fundamentals of vulgar English.
context-en2: I heard a vulgar laugh from the distance.
context-en3: I’ll carefully read your crude email for you when I get back to the office.
meaning-exp: Things that are below normal products are the cheap knockoffs and bad quality items. These items are incredibly crude in their manufacturing and design. So much vulgarity!
reading-exp: You haven't seen this reading for ? yet (sorry there's so many for this kanji!). Those items are so crude that you can't even tell what they're supposed to be. Honestly they all just look like statues of lumpy geckos (?). That says it's a lamp but it looks more like a gecko looking at the sky. That chair? Definitely a bunch of geckos having a pool party. Are you sure you didn't get this stuff from a weird gecko artist?

context-en: It's dangerous, so just leave loading the baggage into the car to Viet, who's strong.
context-en2: They say if you find a four-leaf clover, you'll have good luck, but I got in a dangerous situation instead.
context-en3: I can’t believe no one opposed getting involved in the risky plan of such a risky company.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dangerous? It's dangerous.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is in danger! It's poor old abe (??) Lincoln. You try to save him, yelling out ????!!!!, but he gets shot in the back of the head anyways.

context-en: Why don't we make Wednesday the day we try speaking Japanese at the speed of native speakers?
context-en2: What day of the week is today?
context-en3: The bottom line is that we have to finish this Japanese assignment by Friday.
meaning-exp: The weekday day is the day of the week, as in "Monday" or "Tuesday." You'll be learning those on level 18, but first you should learn ?? to get you prepared.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi reading for ? and the kun'yomi reading for ?. You've learned both of these already, but be careful because ? of ? changes to ? here.

context-en: Is Tohoku dialect the most interesting Japanese dialect?
context-en2: I am bilingual because I can speak standard Japanese as well as the Kansai dialect.
context-en3: I think women who speak with a Hakata accent are really cute.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The ? is there to show this attaches onto things, like ???, meaning "Tokyo Dialect."
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Because it's normally attached to other words it uses the on'yomi reading like a jukugo word normally would.

context-en: When Koichi died, he left Tofugu a ton of dictionaries.
context-en2: This is the best selling dictionary in the world.
context-en3: I looked up the word "love" in my dictionary and wrote my boyfriend’s name on top of the definition, but he dumped me when he saw it.
meaning-exp: Take all the words you use in writing, put them together and you have a dictionary!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Can you put the dictionary back in the box after you use it?
context-en2: An electronic dictionary has various dictionaries in it.
context-en3: I don’t know how to use a dictionary.
meaning-exp: You need to know the word rules of the language you're learning, don't you? Then you need a good dictionary that can explain its lexicon!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: If you are looking for Koichi, he is staring at an encyclopedia on the lounge chair in the sunroom.
context-en2: The camera showed that you shoplifted an encyclopedia.
context-en3: I used my encyclopedia as a pillow because it was too big to be a book.
meaning-exp: Something filled with the rules of various actions is something that contains a ton of knowledge. It contains all things and actions, right? What kind of "thing" is filled with all this information (that existed during the creation of words and kanji?)? One thing would be an encyclopedia.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: As proof of our friendship, I'll give you this Mt. Fuji keychain.
context-en2: It might not be easy to show the evidence of his innocence.
context-en3: Your parents tell you off, even though they don't actually want to. It's proof of their love.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Someone left some evidence behind at the crime scene. You pick it up, it's a kashi (???) bar. It has genetic evidence on it, because the criminal was eating it at the crime scene.

context-en: We went on a school trip to the zoo.
context-en2: When spring comes, let's go on an outing to the ocean.
context-en3: We went on an excursion to Hanshin Koshien Stadium to watch a baseball game and root for the Hanshin Tigers.
meaning-exp: Far feet are feet that have gone on long excursions. These feet have been on some trips, man. They've seen some things.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Our bodies always need water for survival.
context-en2: In that world, titans were threatening the existence of humanity.
context-en3: The FBI searched all night for the survivor in the Tofugu office.
meaning-exp: Suppose that life is in existence on this planet... What would that say about life and survival in such an unforgiving place?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The police officer hurried to the scene of the crime.
context-en2: I sent thank you gifts express to the people who were nice to me.
context-en3: Oh noooooo! The express train left. Now I'm going to be late. I’m really scared of being punished by Koichi.
meaning-exp: Things that hurry and go faster than the other things are express. This is often used with trains or subways, so look out for it if you're looking to get somewhere in a hurry. Also be careful in case it doesn't stop at your stop, because ?? trains don't stop at every station (which is what makes them express!).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: On the surface, Viet looks like a nice guy, but he actually has a scary side.
context-en2: I'm married to a man who is an angel outside and a devil at home, and we bought an older home that has a fine exterior, but the interior is worn out, so I'm having a tough time right now.
context-en3: You shouldn’t be fooled by his outward appearance. I hated my instructor because he showed his superiors a nice face while he bullied subordinates, including me, behind their backs.
meaning-exp: The outside face to something is the exterior of that thing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This reading is usually for building exteriors and outside surfaces.
