The other reading ???? is used when a person's personality comes to the surface and is a bit of an exception, so you'll probably see it less often. Just keep those differences in mind!

vocab-meaning: Face Of A Person, Person's Face, Face
context-en: Tofugu workers' facial deviation values are all very high.
context-en2: I'm suffering from facial neuralgia caused by stress.
context-en3: I hit my face hard on the asphalt.
meaning-exp: The face of a face is a face, but more specifically the face of a person. Probably because the most face-like thing you can ever have is a human's face... at least in our eyes (by "our" I mean the human race's eyes, because I am totally with you guys on that one).
reading-exp: The reading for ? isn't the one you learned with the kanji. But, we're going to learn that reading right now. The worst thing that can happen to a face is if a face disappears. If it becomes totally gone (??). A man that is walking up to you with no face, is a man with a gone face. Those men are men who are a part of the gone men (????). Faces, totally gone!

vocab-meaning: Fail A Test, Failure, Fail An Exam
context-en: They found out that I'd cheated and I was rejected.
context-en2: I failed the entrance exam for a public university, which was my first choice, but I passed for a private college, which was my second choice.
context-en3: I’m so embarrassed I failed such an easy test. I wish I could sink through the floor.
meaning-exp: You know that ???? is "to pass a test," so what's the opposite of that? Fail a test or failure.
reading-exp: If you know the reading for ??, all you have to do is add ? to it! You've learned all these readings, yay!

context-en: Koichi's apartment is located about three hours from the Tofugu office, in some faraway woods.
context-en2: That newly-built condo was really nice but we gave up on buying it, because it was too far from the station.
context-en3: How far is Tokyo from Portland? Is it too far for me to walk?
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of far? It's also far (or it's far away).
reading-exp: You want to go far, far away when you see a toe... oh (??)! You realize there is a zombie toe on the ground and it reminds you of where you can go that's far from here—where the zombie that once had this toe went! (Remember the kanji mnemonic? It's that scooter zombie's toe that makes you say oh and want to go.)

context-en: Koichi is not good at giving insincere compliments.
context-en2: I don't like being complimented on my Japanese speaking.
context-en3: "Oh wow! You look so beautiful tonight. Like a princess!" "Flattery will get you nowhere, daddy.”
meaning-exp: When you quit your current generation to join an older one you need all the flattery you can get because you're starting to feel old. People probably still won't like you though, ya old fart.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I hereby certify that these pants are without a single fold.
context-en2: Please open the origami again after you fold it in half to add the crease.
context-en3: Could you put a crease in my trousers?
meaning-exp: A fold you can see with your eye is a fold or crease in something.
reading-exp: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings. You should have seen ?? by now which should help you to read ??. Then there's ?, which I'm guessing you won't have a problem with.

context-en: Viet always puts his good man-ness to the front.
context-en2: Please find a box that has green on both the front and back sides.
context-en3: Whenever we send a letter or a package, we put the Tofugu sticker on the front of it.
meaning-exp: The front face of something is the front or the front side of it (kind of like how ?? is the exterior because it's the outside face).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Basically, I have no interest in politics.
context-en2: I was told by my boss that I don't even know the fundamentals and that I'm useless.
context-en3: How often are you surprised by making basic mistakes?
meaning-exp: The things that are basic (??) like (?) are your basics and fundamentals. These are like the radicals you learn with your kanji. They're the fundamentals!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing how to read the word ?? will be helpful too.

vocab-meaning: Garbage Can, Garbage Bin, Trash Can, Trash Bin, Waste Can, Waste Bin, Rubbish Bin
context-en: There were boxed fresh fish in the garbage can.
context-en2: I had weakly hoped to find the wedding ring in the trash can.
context-en3: I think you are so sexy when you empty the garbage can— could you empty the garbage can for me please?
meaning-exp: ?? means "garbage." Add a box to it and you have a garbage box aka a garbage can or garbage bin.
reading-exp: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading, the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku though. ?? changes to ??.

context-en: Laborers hardened the ground before building a daycare.
context-en2: I had a part-time job where I packed apples in boxes at an apple orchard.
context-en3: I live near the botanical garden.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Lucky you, the word garden is read the same way as the kanji is read. Kind of a Garden of Eden for kanji and vocab, no?

context-en: Our house is right next to the house with a brown gate.
context-en2: If you pass under the big gate, you will see the holy shrine.
context-en3: The gate is locked.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: I’ll get good luck with this good luck charm.
context-en2: This fortune cookie says that fortune will come to you if you help unpack moving boxes for somebody.
context-en3: I'm guessing that the meaning of Koichi's name is the "most lucky" person. What do you think?
meaning-exp: When you carry happiness with you, you look at the good side of everything and end up having really good luck. Someone who carries happiness will be really lucky in life.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The U.S. government says that we must strengthen our defenses on the border.
context-en2: The government keeps their secrets very well, but they don't keep their promises to the people at all.
context-en3: We can’t believe that the government has prohibited our articles from being published. Tofugu has the right to criticize the government.
meaning-exp: Politics and government. They are needed to keep the government rolling.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: After the graduation ceremony, let's take a photo on the bridge together!
context-en2: Huh? Did you say that Beyoncé came to the graduation and sang for you guys? No way! You must be joking!
context-en3: I’m so excited for the trip after our graduation ceremony! Let’s relax in the hot springs and eat a lot of local delicious food. By the way, just making sure but you made a reservation at the cottage, right?
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is graduation so what about when you add ceremony to it? That makes it a graduation ceremony.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read ?? already as a word, too.

context-en: I heard that the workers at the grocery section are making demands for higher wages.
context-en2: "Salmon, we should buy some groceries in case of emergency." "Fugu, we don't need to buy them. We have food here!" "Where?" "If we have trouble with food, we just need to prey on each other."
context-en3: Could you tell me where the grocery section is?
meaning-exp: Products you're paying a fee to eat later are your groceries. Buy them now, eat them later, yum!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Fugu said that he'd rather live underground than underwater.
context-en2: Our front yard doesn't have any grass, so the earth's surface gets really hot during summer.
context-en3: Koichi gently stroked Fugu and placed him on the ground.
meaning-exp: The ground/earth face is the surface that makes up the ground or the Earth's surface.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is what you'd expect. ? on the other hand is ?, which is a bit different (though close sounding) to what you learned previously. Thank the Chinese and their ever changing language for this one. Think of Jesus laying on the ground, telling you how comfortable the ground is. You say "Jesus, you have to get off the ground, you have a dinner to go to," but he doesn't want to leave.

context-en: There is no guarantee that I could strengthen the organization well though.
context-en2: I am a lifetime member of WaniKani, but I don't really think I can use it for a lifetime, as there is no guarantee that Tofugu will still be around in five years.
context-en3: The grizzly bears will probably approach you, but don’t worry. It’s very, very safe. We guarantee it.
meaning-exp: Evidence that something will be preserved is a form of guarantee, at least as long as the evidence is strong enough. Also, ? also means guarantee, so use that to help you to remember this word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm setting the Hanshin Electric Railway colored jelly by cooling it with ice.
context-en2: I am thinking about buying a newly-built house in the Hanshin district. About how much is the market price?
context-en3: Oh my God! Hanshin Tigers fans dived off the Ebisu bridge down into the dirty river? Wow, they are nuts!
meaning-exp: The slopes of the gods! What could this be? Well, it's mainly just a company, known as Hanshin. They're based in the area between Osaka and Kobe. Think of it this way: ?? + ?? = ??! They're everywhere, though, and even have a baseball team (the Hanshin Tigers), so it's good to know.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I looked up some information about a religious group called Happy Science.
context-en2: In order to bring happiness to Tofugu, Koichi tried to make all of his employees buy a happiness fugu charm for $10,000 each.
context-en3: She was born under a lucky star and she has so much happiness in her life that she can’t help but cry every day.
meaning-exp: With a little luck and happiness you can achieve happiness, though that goes without saying.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I wish you happiness for many years to come.
context-en2: A fortune teller told Viet that happiness will come to him within the year.
context-en3: "I think money can buy happiness because watching fireworks makes me happy. If I had a lot of money, I could enjoy fireworks every day and feel happy all the time," she said happily.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji ?. Kanji means happiness and the vocab word means happiness.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're seeking true happiness. You visit a great guru who's said to help people find their happiness, but she keeps hitting you on the head while you try to talk to her. You end up with the special happiness chant, "She Ow! Say (????) I should say this." You can never get it out without saying ow, but you're pretty sure happiness is coming.

context-en: Forgetting something like a Memorial Day is the worst!
context-en2: My husband gave me a fully automatic washing machine for our wedding anniversary this year.
context-en3: On Independence Day, I'm selling clothes at a flea market.
meaning-exp: Some days are so special that you have to write down all your thoughts when they're done. These are special days like holidays and your anniversary.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of on'yomi for the first two and kun'yomi for the last one. That being said, all of the readings for all of the kanji are the readings you've learned already, so you should be able to read this word too. Just watch out because ? is rendaku'd into ?.

vocab-meaning: Image Of Buddha, Statue Of Buddha
context-en: Do I have to declare if I buy a statue of Buddha in Japan?
context-en2: Buddha statues are often made gold.
context-en3: Someone sends a Buddhist statue to our office every month. If you are that person, please come forward and identify yourself.
meaning-exp: You have Buddha's image. What is that? It's an image of Buddha.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What kind of love is imperfect?
context-en2: Aren't incomplete things better than complete things, since they have a humanness about them?
context-en3: The Tofugu softball team had an incomplete end to their season when the game they were winning was suspended due to rain.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means "complete" or "perfect." So, a not "complete" or "perfect" is something that is incomplete or imperfect.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also will help if you can read ??.

context-en: I was diagnosed with an incurable cancer and I've been given three months to live.
context-en2: My son is fighting an irreversible brain disorder.
context-en3: When Koichi fell incurably ill and died, his last words to Viet were, "We will meet again." True to his words, he came back to the office the next day and did everything the same as he had before.
meaning-exp: When you can not cure something, this is a problem of incurability.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Why is it more common for women to do insurance sales in Japan?
context-en2: Do I need a birth certificate to get insurance?
context-en3: Oh no, I left my health insurance card at home again.
meaning-exp: When you are able to guarantee against risk, it's probably because you bought some good insurance! What do you use? The gecko ???
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: He is an amusing guy, his only downside is that he gets angry over the smallest things.
context-en2: This manga is a bit crude but it's very interesting.
context-en3: Ahahaha! You crack me up, Fugu! That’s the funniest thing I’ve ever heard.
meaning-exp: The face of this object is so white! Why is it so white compared to everything else? This is so interesting...
reading-exp: The reading is unlike what you've learned before, at least with the ? part (?? is just like the vocab word ??). When you look at the white face of the object you say to your friend Moe: "Oh mo!" (??) because you want him to come over and look at this. Try to imagine someone you know named Moe, or at least a celebrity or something named Moe.

context-en: I have no time to waste on a stupid joke.
context-en2: Tofugu likes joking on their podcast, but sometimes they get angry emails from people who don't get the jokes.
context-en3: Stop joking around. Why do you want to go to a French restaurant? We shouldn’t break our pattern. If we’re just going drinking, anywhere is fine, right?
meaning-exp: When you discuss something superfluous you aren't being serious, you're telling a joke.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Michael has been consolidating his position as the number one comedian in Kansai.
context-en2: I heard that people from Kanto and people from Kansai are not getting along well. Is it true?
context-en3: This guy is a total noob in Kansai, so we’ll have to show him around.
meaning-exp: The Kansai region of Japan is the Southern Central part of Japan. It actually connects the East side of Japan (at least back in the day) to the West side, making it the "connection to the west." For our purposes, though, we should call it "Kansai."
reading-exp: Urgh, what a confusing reading! The ? is ?? instead of ??. Readings like this just make you want to sigh (??), no?

context-en: Did you know that you can even borrow ebooks from the library?
context-en2: If you go straight, you'll see the library's bathroom at the end of this aisle ahead.
context-en3: "When is your New Year's vacation? I want to go to the library with you." "I have five days off starting December 30th, but I’m afraid the library will be closed too."
meaning-exp: A public building where written things are all diagramed out in a way that lets you find said written things? That sounds like a library to me!
reading-exp: The ?? part should be readable by you, but it's the ? that's troublesome with an alternate reading from the one you learned. Imagine yourself at the library. You check out every single book you can about the human toe (?). You have a giant stack of books on it, then you drop it... ironically on your toe. You decide to show Khan (your buddy) your smashed toe.

context-en: We decided, spur of the moment, to take the limited express.
context-en2: When I had my checkup, they found something unusual in my EKG, so I have to go back for a complete physical at a university hospital in Osaka via the limited express train on Monday.
context-en3: I already got an express ticket for you, so if you leave now you can still catch the 3:50 express train.
meaning-exp: Something that's special and in a hurry must be special indeed. This refers to limited express trains in Japan. They go fast, they stop at fewer stops (because they're special!) and they hurry. Look out for these if you want to get somewhere in a jiffy.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the ?? goes to ??.

context-en: I'm worried about my baggage being examined in customs.
context-en2: A stroller full of luggage was left in the park.
context-en3: "Someone ought to unpack the luggage from the car…" "Alright. Say no more."
meaning-exp: A luggage thing is your luggage. It's also your baggage and load too.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You'll need to remember the ? reading as ??, though. Why? Because all your luggage just got thrown into various moats along the countryside. It's going to take you forever to collect your luggage from these moats and by then it'll be all soggy. Dangit...

context-en: On the Halloween night, I saw Viet wearing the Masked Rider costume and eating a whole box of chocolates.
context-en2: Ah, you startled me! Why are you wearing that mask?
context-en3: My dream is to go to the masquerade in Venice and meet a knight on a white horse.
meaning-exp: A temporary face is something you put over your face to cover it. It's a mask.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My grandmother was born in the Meiji era, and she devotedly practiced the Buddhist teachings when she was alive.
context-en2: I'm writing a paper about the Meiji Restoration.
context-en3: I was watching a drama series about life in the Meiji period and I was surprised that ten thousand yen was a large amount of money back then.
meaning-exp: It’s the era of Bright Rule! If this doesn't make sense, don't worry about it. Focus more on the reading, which is ???. Sound familiar? This is the famous Meiji Era or Meiji Emperor. If you don't know about it consider reading up, it's interesting history!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: WaniKani is Tofugu's hit product.
context-en2: Their merchandise is always guaranteed, so I tend to buy things from them.
context-en3: I believe this new product will be a big success and I’d like you to work on promoting it through in-store campaigns. I’m really counting on you.
meaning-exp: Articles of merchandise are still merchandise.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I liked the picture of Noah's ark that was displayed at the art gallery.
context-en2: I donated the ring handed down to me from my mother to the museum.
context-en3: "How can you be a tour guide in the museum? Don’t you have to be an art expert or something?" "No, not really. They give you all the information, it’s like memorizing a script."
meaning-exp: You know ?? is fine art. So what is a public building that contains said fine art? It's a museum.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Today, in Koichi's bento box, there were some origami instead of food.
context-en2: I'm a professional origami artist.
context-en3: I want to thank everyone who has shown me support over the years. Thankfully, I’ve finally mastered how to make an origami Fugu.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "to fold," so what about "to fold paper"? Ever heard of something that involves lots of folding of paper that is Japanese? Most likely you have. This is origami, aka the art of paper folding.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? and the vocab word ?. As long as you know those you should be able to read this. Also, you probably already know this reading because it's an English word, too.

context-en: I heard that not many cars obey the speed limit in Osaka, is that true?
context-en2: I was so excited about the Osaka trip that I totally neglected my studies.
context-en3: I’m afraid I won’t be able to make it next Wednesday. What about going to Osaka next Thursday instead?
meaning-exp: The big heights. What a nice area to be, it's where everyone wants to live! This magical place is Osaka. Heard of it before? It's a city, and kind of the rival to Tokyo.
reading-exp: The reading is pretty weird, but then again so are people from Osaka (just kidding, Osakazens!). The ? reads like ?? from ????. Then, ? uses the kun'yomi reading as well, which you didn't learn. That being said, doesn't this kanji look like ?, which also means slope? Well, it shares a kun'yomi reading as well, so if you've seen ? you can apply that reading over to here, making ????. Then again, if you know this word means Osaka you probably can figure out how to write it too. Don't forget the double ?? though!

context-en: Koichi's picture from high school was leaked.
context-en2: Look at this photo. Dad hasn't changed at all since then. Well, he's gained some weight, but nothing else has changed, right?
context-en3: Enclosed are the nude photos of Fugu you requested.
meaning-exp: A copy of reality is a lot like magic. How do you make a copy of reality, though? You take a photo.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi loves pitch black garlic and he often eats it so much that his tongue bleeds.
context-en2: When Viet came back, he was pure black, like a burned toast, because he'd gotten so thoroughly tanned at a Hawaiian beach.
context-en3: OMG, I just came across the cutest pitch black dress.
meaning-exp: The reality is that it's black. Like, so black that it's beyond fake black, it's reality black. This is so black it's pitch black.
reading-exp: The reading for the ? is the vocab kun'yomi reading. Think of what is pitch black. It's your poor Ma (?). She is so dark that she sucks in light, like a black hole... wait, she is a black hole, it explains why your Ma is pitch black.

context-en: My long held hope, which was to study politics in university, finally came true.
context-en2: Salmon's attitude toward the government is very conservative.
context-en3: Being mindful of the political turmoil occurring in Washington D.C., Tofugu has been creating employment for both the Republican and Democratic dominated regions.
meaning-exp: If you want to cure the government, you have to get into politics. Gotta join 'em to fix them... but can you survive that long without being corrupted yourself?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Important documents are being stored in the locked drawer of Koichi's desk.
context-en2: Breastmilk can be preserved for a long time, if you freeze it.
context-en3: "This bacon contains no food coloring or preservatives." "Well, then it really isn’t bacon."
meaning-exp: We try to preserve anything we want to exist with preservation. Want a special sea creature or bird to exist? Up conservation efforts! And, if you want to save data (like on a computer), you can use this word for that kind of saving, as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We have verification that Kristen is truly the well-protected daughter of a respectable family.
context-en2: Do you have something to verify your identity?
context-en3: Would you rather receive some sort of certificate proving you finished the TextFugu and WaniKani courses?
meaning-exp: Is the evidence bright enough to convince me? Is this really proof enough?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Public Order, Public Safety, Public Peace
context-en: This area doesn’t have bad public safety, but that area does.
context-en2: Viet's boss was arrested for disturbing the peace.
context-en3: The other day I saw Koichi, drunk, boastfully telling people that he's actually Superman and he's the one who keeps the peace around here.
meaning-exp: If your people can relax because you rule over them so well, there is public order. You don't want the people you rule being upset or stressed out, you want public safety and public peace for all!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: If you go straight down this road, there’s a park.
context-en2: I was playing with sand at a public park and it turned my hands as black as coal.
context-en3: "So, how was the park you and Fugu went to?" "That was actually the most enjoyable park we’ve ever been to."
meaning-exp: A public park is a park that is public. It's a public park.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Risky, Unsafe, Dangerous, Danger, Peril, Hazard
context-en: It's still a risky situation, but there is hope for his recovery.
context-en2: In stations, there is often an announcement that says, "It will be unsafe, so please stay behind the yellow line."
context-en3: That's true that our company is at risk of defaulting on its loan, but I believe that we have to keep taking risks and acting based on our faith.
meaning-exp: Something that is dangerous and risky is probably pretty risky dangerous, and unsafe.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When I watched the scene where the wife packs up and leaves, I saw myself in her and felt bitter.
context-en2: This phrase is useful in a business setting.
context-en3: I cried during the last scene.
meaning-exp: Everything on a location's surface is really just a part of the scene before you. This is the kind of scene that would be set in a novel. It's the setting.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

context-en: If you stare at computer screens for a long time, your eyesight will get worse.
context-en2: Lately, an obscene image of dogs keeps automatically appearing on our monitor, so yeah, we're having some issues.
context-en3: It’s weird. Viet is sitting glued to a screen for hours as usual, though his actual screen has been completely black since this morning.
meaning-exp: The surface of a drawing is a screen. Just imagine your computer screen. On its surface is a drawing, right? It just happens to move around all the time, but it's still a screen!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That smiling face proves Koichi's integrity, eh?
context-en2: The prince of this country is a very terrible man who kills his citizens with a smile.
context-en3: This smiling, lovely guy with me is Koichi.
meaning-exp: A laughing face is a smiling face (or just a smile!). ??s all around!
reading-exp: The reading for this word won't make you smile, though. You were smiling, but then you heard about the reading of this kanji. It made you yell out "EH??" (?).

vocab-meaning: Specialty, Speciality, Area Of Study, Major
context-en: That's out of my area of study.
context-en2: My older sister is a specialty pet eye doctor.
context-en3: My specialty is astronomy. I want to discover new stars.
meaning-exp: Your specialty gate is the thing you open to let out your specialty. Imagine the thing you're best at (your specialty). Now imagine opening a gate in your chest that lets it out, allowing you to be good at it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "My older brother didn't obey the orders of our parents and left to study abroad." "Where is his study abroad destination?" "It's in the U.S."
context-en2: When I studied abroad, I practiced speaking Japanese naturally a lot.
context-en3: Could you reschedule my appointment for next Sunday? On Saturday I have to go to the Japanese Consulate General to get some study abroad documents.
meaning-exp: You detain your study and take it away to a foreign place. That foreign place is having you study abroad.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for ? is the ??? version. You can remember this because Ryu (???) from street fighter is doing a study abroad program to learn more karate.

context-en: I was preparing to take my exams when my dad suddenly passed away.
context-en2: My superior died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday.
context-en3: I often argued with my boyfriend and I hated it, but I even miss the arguments now. I never expected that he would drop dead from a heart attack.
meaning-exp: When someone experiences a hurry death it's a very sudden death.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: A matchbox abruptly dropped from the sky.
context-en2: Oh, Kristen! Even if you tell me something like that immediately, I'm at a loss...
context-en3: Family Guy is famous for its random and stupid flashbacks.
meaning-exp: If you go towards something and hurry while you do it, you are doing it suddenly.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Suddenly you can read a new word!

context-en: I want to sunbathe on Totoro's big belly.
context-en2: My policy is not to bathe, but to sunbathe on weekdays.
context-en3: The Tofugu dog loves to sunbathe on the balcony.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is sunlight so when you add bathe you get "sunlight bathe" ... but that sounds dumb, so let's call this word sunbathe instead!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I'm looking for a tag to put on my suitcase.
context-en2: Please tell me how to write a package label.
context-en3: My hobby is collecting the labels of Kamonishiki's "Labeled Sake."
meaning-exp: A luggage tag is a tag you put on luggage. It's also a label you can put pricing and information on in stores or any other place with packaging.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji. You've learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too.

context-en: All of the Tofugu workers testified that they had seen Koichi eat Viet's meatball.
context-en2: Only Michael refused because he didn't want to testify against Koichi.
context-en3: When Fugu was suspected of placing some puffer fish poison on the teacher’s apple, all his classmates testified that he was innocent.
meaning-exp: Evidence that you say is testimony. Hopefully you won't have to give too much of this in your lifetime.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can't buy the Japanese textbook because it's too expensive.
context-en2: Please don't share the textbook. Each person must buy their own.
context-en3: I forgot to bring my textbook and I was kept an hour after school.
meaning-exp: The thing you use to teach a course with writings is a textbook. It's a book of writings you use to teach your course!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I'll go take a bath before dinner.
context-en2: We were afraid of being exposed to radioactivity and we ran away to this town.
context-en3: Fugu introduced me his best friend, Wild Red Sea Bream. He told me Sea Bream lives at great depths and is bathed in hardly any sunlight.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bathe so the verb vocab version is to bathe.
reading-exp: You want to know the best way to bathe? With a bunch of aardvarks (?) in the water. They use their sticky little tongues to clean all your cracks and crannies.

vocab-meaning: To Be Connected To, To Be Related
context-en: There is no room for compromise on this matter.
context-en2: Kristen is doing research connected to Japanese literature.
context-en3: While working at the Tofugu office, Viet received a call related to a shooting at his hideout.
meaning-exp: You know that ? means connected. So, when you add ?? to it you make it a verb. Now it means to be connected to.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: To Be Involved With, To Be Connected With, To Be Affected, To Have To Do With
context-en: I know Viet is involved with a dangerous organization, but I still don't think that he has anything to do with the crime.
context-en2: Don't get involved with people like that.
context-en3: If you ate blowfish without taking the poison out, it would be a matter of life and death.
meaning-exp: You know that the kanji means connection. This is a verb, so one meaning is to be connected with. There are many other ways to say this too. This word is a bit full featured. You can say to be involved with or even To Be Affected. Basically things that have to do with being connected with something else.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who have you gotten involved with this time? The "Kaw Kaw (??) Crow Gang" this time? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and stuff... You don't want to be connected with them.

vocab-meaning: To Break, To Snap, To Fracture
context-en: My heart breaks when you say that.
context-en2: When I was carrying a heavy load on my shoulders, my shoulder bone fractured.
context-en3: Every year, our tulips snap at the roots after they bloom.
meaning-exp: You already learned how ?? means "to fold." Well this is what happens after that. You folded it too far and now it's starting to break.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned ??, so you should know this one too!

vocab-meaning: To Come Off, To Be Removed, To Fall Off
context-en: A button came off.
context-en2: It might be difficult for this stain to be removed.
context-en3: Renting an office in the business district will be considerably expensive, but it’s important for our image and I think it will pay for itself in about a year.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes off. Something is removed. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to come off or to be removed.
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as ??.

context-en: We compromised on 100,000 yen.
context-en2: Koichi and Viet compromised by going to McDonald's.
context-en3: "Hey Salmon, did you and Fugu have to make any compromises when you first moved in together?" "Well, not me, but Fugu did."
meaning-exp: You know that ?? means compromise. So, what happens when you make it a verb? It becomes to compromise.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the vocab word ??, so if you know that you should be good (also, just the reading of the kanji works too).

context-en: You should take some aspirin to ease your period pain.
context-en2: What do you think of curing cancer by using an herbal remedy?
context-en3: Only Viet knows that Koichi has strange powers that can heal injuries and sicknesses.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cure, so the verb vocab version is to cure. Don't get this confused with ?? which means "to be healed." This particular verb is when you do the curing. How do you know that? Because when you try to heal them, you mess up, and then they try to sue (?) you.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I need you to heal him, and I need you to heal him right now (??). NOW NOW NOW! This also shares the reading for ??, a very similar word you learned previously, which means "to fix." I'm guessing that the Japanese word ??? was only one word ("to fix" and "to cure" are pretty similar, right?). Then, there were two Chinese words for it (as you can see with the kanji), so the one Japanese word got split into two very similar words.

context-en: After graduating from university, I was able to, uneventfully, get a job at my company of choice.
context-en2: Are you saying that you can't graduate from high school because you haven't attended enough? Don't be ridiculous.
context-en3: My brother overcame his disability and graduated from college. I’m very proud of him. His graduation is the result of his determination and effort.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "graduation." Make it a verb, and you have to graduate.
reading-exp: The reading is just the same as the vocab word ??.

speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Godan verb
context-en: Koichi left a note for Viet in a hurry and stayed in the toilet for an hour.
context-en2: Koichi heard that Viet broke down from working too much, so he hurried to the hospital.
context-en3: "Hey, hurry up! We’ll be late." "I just woke up, I’m coming."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hurry so the verb vocab version is to hurry.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone who is trying to hurry is someone who is not at ease (??).

vocab-meaning: To Know, To Be Aware Of
context-en: I was aware that workers were making demands for a pay raise.
context-en2: I didn't know that my wife had demanded that my brother pay the money back.
context-en3: This article will be posted during the busy end of the season, but I would appreciate it if you could read it.
meaning-exp: This is like a fancy and humble way of saying to know. Sure, the kanji means suppose, but think of it this way... When you say "I suppose" it's like a humble way of saying "I know." You're not being as direct about it this way, and in Japanese, that makes you more humble and polite. So, that's why ??? means to know.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. If you remember the kanji reading, you'll have no problem remembering this vocabulary reading as well!

context-en: Tokyo dialect is almost the same as standard Japanese.
context-en2: I rejected Koichi's request that I speak in Tokyo dialect.
context-en3: "I need to get some free Tokyo dialect lessons." "Ask Koichi. He’ll do anything."
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is Tokyo, and you know that ? is dialect, so you have yourself Tokyo dialect.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read ?? already, which you should.

context-en: That adventurer laughed and said he wants to leave his name to posterity.
context-en2: Kristen demanded an apology from Koichi while she laughed.
context-en3: "I had a date with Fugu last night." "How did it go?" "It was fun. I laughed a lot."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means laugh so the verb vocab version is to laugh.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can laugh freely, now!

vocab-meaning: To Leave Behind, To Leave Over
context-en: Why don't we leave this creamy chicken pot pie for tomorrow?
context-en2: Koichi passed away and left a huge amount of debt behind for Viet.
context-en3: Thieves broke into the Tofugu office and stole some of our stickers last night, but they were so stupid that they made the elementary mistake of leaving behind their fingerprints.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means remainder, but you can't really "to remainder." What is something that's similar that would make sense? How about to leave behind. This is when you're actually doing the leaving behind too. For example, you eat some food and you leave behind your rice because you're a bad child. You can remember this because of ?. Every time you leave some food behind your mom would sue you, because she was a terrible mom. Imagine this.
reading-exp: The reading for this word can come from level 14 item ??. Associate the two in your mind and you'll be able to read both.

context-en: You can harden clay with heat.
context-en2: Viet takes an hour to make his pompadour hard every morning.
context-en3: Koichi decided to fortify his position and send his troops to Japan.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hard so the verb vocab version? To make hard. You need to differentiate this from ???, though, which means "to harden" (the hardening happens on its own). This word means "to make hard," because you're doing the hardening. You can remember this because you want to make something hard. And to do that, you send special "mail" (??) to this thing you want to make hard, and this mail does that for you.
reading-exp: Since the reading for ? (??) is different than the one you learned with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. A caterpillar (??) forms a cocoon. The caterpillar's cocoon is hard and the caterpillar made it that way. Keep this in mind and you too will blossom into a beautiful butterfly.

context-en: "Let's get married when we grow up." "Promise?" "Yes. I promise."
context-en2: Can you promise that you won't tell this to anybody else?
context-en3: As they sang a song that goes, "If I lie, I'll cut my pinky off and drink a thousand needles," they pinky promised to make pancakes on Sunday together.
meaning-exp: ?? is a “promise.” So when you add ?? to it you’re making it a verb, meaning to promise. Now promise you’ll remember!
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ?? with ?? added. Make sure you know ?? and you'll know this word as well.

context-en: It may not seem like he's here, but he is always with you, protecting you.
context-en2: Koichi's dog protected him from danger.
context-en3: Listen to me, my dog. It’s your responsibility to defend your family.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means protect so the verb vocab version is to protect and also to defend.
reading-exp: You need to protect against breast cancer, so you get yourself a mammogram (??).

context-en: I followed the doctor's advice and quit my job.
context-en2: Who said Michael resigned from as chief editor?
context-en3: Since Fugu quit, I’m thinking about getting him a swim ring as a farewell gift. If anyone wants to join in on my idea, let me know.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means quit so the verb vocab version is to quit.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Hey, you going to quit?" "Yah (?) man, I'm going to quit."

vocab-meaning: To Request, To Wish, To Hope, To Want, To Expect
context-en: I'm hoping to study abroad in Japan.
context-en2: I was able to get into the university I'd been wishing for.
context-en3: It’s raining, so I request that we change our appointment and instead hold it underground, what do you think?
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is a "wish" or a "hope." So, when you "do a wish" or "do a hope." When you do that, that means to request or to wish.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??. It's also the on'yomi jukugo reading as well, if that helps any.

context-en: I finally got my driver's license!
context-en2: Can you take a mug from the shelf for me?
context-en3: I take full responsibility for my actions. I am truly sorry.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means take, so the verb version is to take something.
reading-exp: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You're the kind of person who likes to take things. "What things?" you ask. Little toes (?). Because that isn't creepy.

context-en: Even Japanese people are losing the ability to write, so WaniKani is just focusing on the readings and meanings of kanji.
context-en2: Koichi's handwriting is far from being good.
context-en3: Yay! I just hacked into Koichi’s Facebook account. Now I can make Koichi’s posts whatever I want to write about. Hehehe.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means write so the verb version means to write.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the on'yomi one, but this word is read with the kun'yomi, ?. So just be sure to remember the kun'yomi reading to read this word in the car (?) ... or to write it, or whatever.

context-en: Is it true that Tofugu has claimed 50,000 dollars in damages from a WaniKani user?
context-en2: My hope to find true love was destroyed.
context-en3: You’ve got to face the facts! Admit that you’re a momma’s boy after all. Your mother loves you and you love her too.
meaning-exp: The reality of the truth is nothing more than the truth and the reality. Doesn't get any more real than this.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You look as if you're in the depths of misfortune. Are you okay?
context-en2: There was a death in my family. Can I take tomorrow and the day after off?
context-en3: They say misery loves company, which explains why I’m dating you.
meaning-exp: When you do not have happiness, you have unhappiness and misfortune.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Unsold Merchandise, Remaining Stock, Unsold Stock, Remaining Merchandise, Unsold Product, Remaining Product
context-en: We sold the remaining goods at half price.
context-en2: You can return any unsold stock, so would you let us sell our products here?
context-en3: Before we leave the store tonight, let’s go ahead and count the remaining stock.
meaning-exp: The remainder products are the things that haven't been sold. It's the unsold merchandise. It's the remaining stock.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ?? changes to ??.

context-en: That guy suddenly passed away leaving his wife and two children behind.
context-en2: I took an urgent assignment, so I have to pick my kid up later than usual today.
context-en3: Sorry for the sudden request. We had to take an urgent order from the customer we cannot refuse.
meaning-exp: You only need to hurry to something if it's urgent and it happened all of a sudden. You didn't even have time to prepare.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: I'm in the dentist's waiting room now.
context-en2: There are waiting rooms for tourist groups in airports.
context-en3: I read an economics book the other day in the hospital waiting room and it was pretty interesting.
meaning-exp: A room where you join other people to wait. This is a waiting room.
reading-exp: Remember how you learned ?? already? Well throw the on'yomi for ? on the end of that and you have your reading!

context-en: The witness proved that Viet was guilty.
context-en2: In my husband's court case, the clerks of the bank where he has his accounts appeared in court as witnesses for him.
context-en3: As a witness, I won’t beat around the bush, I’ll answer your question frankly. Yeah, that Fugu was absolutely eating your pudding.
meaning-exp: An evidence person is a witness, because witnesses are people who provide evidence (you know, with their mouths or something).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Even yakuza can come to the zoo.
context-en2: The flamingos looked so beautiful when I saw them up close at a zoological garden.
context-en3: Many koala bears have an innate virus called koala retrovirus and it often causes a life-threatening diseases like lymphoma when they get stressed out, so please make sure not to use your camera's flash or speak loudly when you go to the menagerie.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means animal? Well when you add park it becomes a zoo. It's a park for animals. Except the animals can't leave. Ever.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The pharmacy department is absent today, eh?
context-en2: I fired him because he no call no show'd three times in row.
context-en3: I’m terribly sorry, but an urgent business trip has come up, so I’ll be absent from the reunion party tonight.
meaning-exp: When a seat is lacking the person it's supposed to have in it, there is an absence. Where is Johnny? Another absence? Ugh. Johnny. C'mon.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ?? is shortened to ?? as ?s often are when in a situation like this.

context-en: Absolutely, please come back to Japan.
context-en2: I'd absolutely like to attend at Tofugu's party.
context-en3: By all means, notify us if you know someone who may be interested in Tofugu products.
meaning-exp: Absolutely an injustice! We must absolutely punish the perpetrator, by all means.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It's absurd to cross such a busy road without a pedestrian crossing.
context-en2: Viet was drinking excessive amounts of awamori.
context-en3: He made the rash decision to try and swim in a pool filled with curry sauce.
meaning-exp: The tea supply is down to nothing??? That's absurd! For Americans, I imagine this word would be "?????" instead. Get it?? If you're a caffeine addict this word will make total sense.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: After All, Eventually, In The End
context-en: I didn't end up making umeboshi.
context-en2: I woke up to the alarm once, but I eventually fell back asleep.
context-en3: I went to buy some Valentine's chocolates for my friends, but in the end I only got some for myself.
meaning-exp: If you tie the bureau up with your delays this may not get done this year after all.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note the ?? gets changed to ?? as ?s in this situation often do.

context-en: There is a beautiful ume grove in Aichi Prefecture.
context-en2: Aichi Prefecture is gradually entering the rainy season.
context-en3: After Fugu moved to Japan’s Aichi Prefecture, no one knew of Salmon’s hopeless longing for him.
meaning-exp: The Love Know Prefecture! I want to live here, because people must know love! Of course, we don't call it that in English. You'll have to know the reading of the kanji to know the reading of this prefecture, which is Aichi Prefecture (jump to the reading to figure this out).
reading-exp: The reading here is all the on'yomi jukugo madness you can handle. If you learned the kanji, you should be able to read this. If you can read it, you can translate it to "English" even though only half of it is English.

context-en: My mom didn't always seem to be attracted to my dad.
context-en2: Lately, I'm usually asleep by ten.
context-en3: It takes some kids a while to realize their parents aren’t always right.
meaning-exp: Something that goes towards normal is something that happens ordinarily.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. In order to learn it, think of this: Ordinarily, I tune (??) my violin, but today I just said "screw it" and didn't tune it. So, now I sound like crap. Imagine this compared to how I ordinarily sound.

context-en: Fugu doesn’t want to die in anonymity.
context-en2: Among young artists, there are many unknowns producing good work.
context-en3: I heard that Ariana Grande is not a bit stuck up in spite of her talent and is very nice to unknown singers too, so I have a good impression of her.
meaning-exp: Someone with "nothing" for their name is trying to remain anonymous.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Dad is very proud of you because you became an architect.
context-en2: The doctor incorrectly diagnosed the architect with stomach cancer.
context-en3: My house was designed by a famous architect.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is architecture. So, someone of house architecture is someone who does architecture. They are an architect.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read ?? already.

context-en: We discussed whether using arms was right or wrong.
context-en2: I used to work at a chemical weapons laboratory.
context-en3: We received an email from a Tofugu user about the movement of the location of the nuclear weapons.
meaning-exp: The containers that soldiers use aren't just bowls and stuff, they're the things that hold their arms and weapons. Think spear and sword containers, full of weapons!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: As Usual, As Ever, The Same, As Before
context-en: As usual, you've got a cool nose ring, but I can see your nose hairs today.
context-en2: It’s interesting, as usual.
context-en3: Viet is muttering an oath under his breath as usual, yeah?
meaning-exp: A mutual change you make with other people will go so smoothly that it will seem like everything is working as usual. It will be like everything is the same as it was before because the change was mutual.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: In the future, I think I want to study atomic energy.
context-en2: What was the atomic number and atomic symbol of this atom?
context-en3: Aging nuclear power plants are a problem for many countries.
meaning-exp: The original child of everything is the atom. It is the child from which everything else is created, for it was the original child. Atoms are the building blocks of all things!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm afraid that my attendance will probably be irregular.
context-en2: I'm not planning to attend Koichi's birthday party.
context-en3: Could you put me on another flight? I really have to attend the annual G8 leaders summit.
meaning-exp: The people who exit their seats at the end of the show are the number of people who showed up, not counting empty seats. This is the true attendance.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note the ??? gets changed to ???, as many ?s do in this situation.

context-en: Please make it a habit to check that there aren't any cars coming before you cross.
context-en2: I consciously eat fruits and vegetables since they are good for your health.
context-en3: As soon as Fugu shows any attention to other girls, Salmon loses consciousness.
meaning-exp: The discerning you do with your ideas shows your awareness. It shows you're consciously thinking, because you not only know that you have ideas, but you think about them and discern them.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Those sandwiches look a bit unappetizing, don't they?
context-en2: His handwriting is kinda bad, don't you think?
context-en3: I’ve never eaten such disgusting miso soup.
meaning-exp: You've seen ???? by this point. This is the opposite of that. Instead of ? you have ? (not), so something that does not have flavor is something that doesn't taste good. i.e. something bad tasting. This can also refer to someone who's unskillful at something as well.
reading-exp: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you've run into. It's ???. Think about how you're going through this really long maze (??) and how you're promised a really tasty wonderful treat at the end for getting through it (you're a lab rat or something). When you get to the end, there's your treat! What joy! You eat it and... oh man... it is so bad tasting you can't even believe it. Be sure to imagine the terrible taste and the terrible disappointment after going through that difficult maze only to get this... this... terribly unappetizing cheese.

vocab-meaning: Before Christ, Bc, Bce, Before Common Era
context-en: Until about what year before Christ did the dinosaurs exist?
context-en2: This Kochi keeps insisting that he's a man who time traveled from pre-Christian, Ancient Rome.
context-en3: If time machines existed, I would want to go to 3000 B.C.
meaning-exp: Remember how ??? is "After death" or "AD"? Well, this is the opposite because it has a before (?) in it. It's BC or Before Christ.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read ??? already, because then you'll just have to remember the ?.

context-en: Both of my ears itch immensely.
context-en2: Two dogs nuzzled against me from both sides.
context-en3: A picture of Viet, with girls on both sides of him, was sold to the paparazzi.
meaning-exp: Both sides is both sides. Which side? Both sides.
reading-exp: The first kanji takes the on'yomi reading and the second takes the kun'yomi reading. Luckily you know both of them already!

context-en: There’s gum stuck to the bottom of your shoe.
context-en2: It's ridiculous to go swimming in the bottomless swamp.
context-en3: Thanks to Tofugu, I'm now fluent in Japanese. I thank them from the bottom of my heart.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This vocab uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. Well played!

vocab-meaning: Bottom Of One's Heart, Bottom Of My Heart
context-en: I'm sincerely happy that Koichi's incurable disease actually has been cured.
context-en2: I think Koichi hates me from the bottom of his heart.
context-en3: There are a lot of nice people in my new department and I feel tremendously relieved.
meaning-exp: The heart bottom is the bottom of one's heart. Do you want to learn kanji? Do you want to learn it from ??? Okay, fine, you can move onto the reading then.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too!

context-en: My nose twitched when I smelled the delicious breakfast.
context-en2: Our family always has rice, miso soup, omelets, and dried fish for breakfast.
context-en3: "Did you just tell Koichi about his surprise breakfast party?" "Oh! I didn’t know it was a surprise."
meaning-exp: You know how ??? is "dinner"? Well, that word is so 12 hours ago. This is morning and in the morning your meal is breakfast.
reading-exp: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. It's also like the vocab: ? is like the vocab version, ?? and ?? is like the word you learned, ???.

context-en: That British person with the straight nose speaks in a nasal voice.
context-en2: Apparently, this English person hasn't tried ume vinegar before.
context-en3: I got a friend request from some English person I don't know.
meaning-exp: You've probably seen ?? for "England" already. This is just another version I wanted to make sure you knew about. Not kanji, sure, but it's a little more common than ?? so I wanted to make sure you got it here. To stay with the spirit of "learning kanji" though, we've added ? to the end. I bet you can guess the meaning of this already. English + Person = English Person or British Person.
reading-exp: The first part's reading is just in katakana. The second part is the ?? from ?.

context-en: This is very nicely designed building, isn't it?
context-en2: It's only been a year since it was built, but this building is pretty dirty already, isn't it?
context-en3: "I’d like to go see the building with you so when would be convenient for you?" "Well, I’ll adjust my schedule accordingly."
meaning-exp: A thing you build is a building. There aren't too many other things you build, at least not to this extent.
reading-exp: The reading is a bit weird. It's kun'yomi readings across the board, meaning your knowledge of ??? hopefully can come into play here. A building is something you build, so how do you say "to build"? It's ??? (???). Since it's a thing you build, it's a ????. This reading is a bit confusing, but hopefully after a while you'll get it if you get it wrong too many times! Maybe if you think about the building you're in and call it a ?? a few times it'll sink in better?

context-en: The owner of this diner is so old fashioned that he insists that men shouldn't interfere in domestic matters.
context-en2: When I went to the Tofugu dining hall a while ago, there was free live music from some singer I didn't know.
context-en3: Do you want to eat lunch in the cafeteria? If so, I don’t have a second period class, so I could find some seats for us.
meaning-exp: An eating hall is a big room in which you eat. What big rooms do you eat in? How about a cafeteria or dining hall?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Since we married for money, not for love, we fought a lot and ended up getting divorced.
context-en2: Due to the wildfire of unknown origins, the town has been in such a chaotic situation.
context-en3: Don’t worry. Viet has already uncovered the cause of the bugs and is fixing it right now.
meaning-exp: The original cause is how you got into this mess. Forget all the things it caused, the first cause is the origin and source of what's going on right now. You can pinpoint one thing that caused all of this!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The movie is too sad. It should be called a tragedy, not a comedy.
context-en2: After watching a documentary about Chaplin, the king of comedy, I decided to pursue a career in comedy.
context-en3: It was so hot that I kept fanning myself while watching the comedy show.
meaning-exp: Rejoice drama isn't so much drama as it is comedy, since it makes you rejoice.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I was relieved that you guys have common sense.
context-en2: I took a common knowledge test, but my results were terrible.
context-en3: How about putting common sense aside and thinking outside the box for a second?
meaning-exp: Normal discerning is the discerning you do on a daily basis, without thinking. It is all the things that you do that are common sense.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This novel will be concluded in the next edition.
context-en2: I was about to ask a question, but I ended up coming up with the conclusion by myself.
context-en3: This manga hasn’t been completed yet.
meaning-exp: The perfect way to tie up a research paper is with a conclusion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My mother-in-law told me I lack an awareness for maternal responsibilities and that made me super upset.
context-en2: Please try to be conscientious about being a great WaniKani user and study Japanese hard.
context-en3: I’ve stopped smoking for three months now, but I still get the urge to smoke a cigarette every once in a while. Interestingly, when I really want to smoke, I’m not really aware of it. I only just realize it when I find myself chewing on my index finger.
meaning-exp: You can memorize with your self and your self is memorizing things. It's remembering them for later use, which means you have reached a state of consciousness that animals cannot achieve. They just think about things, they don't memorize like you do.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Hey, crybaby Ko-chan. Here comes a tunnel you like.
context-en2: Only Koichi knows Viet is a crybaby.
context-en3: My daughter's high fever doesn't seem to be coming down. She is usually a crybaby, but it seems like she doesn't even have energy to cry now and I'm worried.
meaning-exp: You've seen that ?? is to cry, so you can probably guess that ?? is just "cry." You've also seen how ? is rarely a nice thing to call someone. So what's a mean thing you can call someone who cries? How about a crybaby?
reading-exp: The readings come from ?? and ?. So long as you're okay with those two words you should be able to read this one too.

context-en: When I heard my wife sobbing, I finally realized that she'd had a tough day.
context-en2: I overheard Koichi talk with Viet in a tearful voice.
context-en3: I understand that hearing a crying baby can be unbearable, but that doesn’t mean that people shouldn’t bring their babies on the train, right?
meaning-exp: A cry voice is a sound of crying or a sob. Don't cry! Kanji will get easier someday!
reading-exp: The reading comes from the vocab words ?? and ?. So long as you know those two words okay, you should be able to read this word too!

vocab-meaning: Day Before Last, Day Before Yesterday
context-en: It's a bit late, but the day before yesterday, May 5, was Luffy's birthday.
context-en2: I was available the day before last, but this month all of my other days are entirely full already.
context-en3: The day before last I caught my husband cheating on me.
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ?? means "yesterday?" Well one day previous to that day is the day before last.
reading-exp: This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it: The day before last you bought an "O" toe toy (????). It's a kid's toy in the shape of the letter O that you put on your toe. You know it was the day before last because you wore it all yesterday, and now today your toe is sore. If only you could go back to the day before yesterday to tell yourself not to buy that O toe toy! Or at least not to wear it for the whole next day!

context-en: You are quite the expert on mackerel sushi.
context-en2: I'm sorry, but I'm not an expert when it comes to guns, so it would be better if I didn't touch them.
context-en3: "Oh, by the way, did you hear they’re getting married?" "Wow! Really? Tell me everything."
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of detailed? It's also detailed.
reading-exp: Things that are detailed... how about that plan you made to perform that coup, what (??)?? You're doing a coup?

context-en: This user often sends us very detailed feedback.
context-en2: Mr. Koichi, I heard you were born poor. Could you give me more details on that?
context-en3: I don’t have enough time to look up the details.
meaning-exp: A thing that is detailed and thin is the details. It will help to remember that ??? also means detailed, which is probably where this meaning is more coming from. Detailed + Detailed = the details.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Tonight's supper is salted, sun-dried flounder.
context-en2: Before the dinner, I drank down a glass of beer in one gulp.
context-en3: Koichi almost went insane when he saw how messy the kitchen was after supper.
meaning-exp: The night meal is the meal you eat at night. That is dinner.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I wonder why that diplomat doesn't get married and settle down.
context-en2: My uncle is a diplomat and a diplomat from another country gave him a rare guitar, which is one of only a few that exist in the world.
context-en3: I’m a diplomat and I really need to fly to Japan today, so could you put me on the waiting list?
meaning-exp: Someone from the outside who comes in to mix with the government is a diplomat. Really, that's what diplomats do, right? They come from the outside (country). They mix with the government, and they do what they're there to do!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I saw off the emperor, who was going to see the opera.
context-en2: The person who plays the role of the horse in Act II Scene III of this play is my older brother.
context-en3: The person next to me was constantly cracking their knuckles during the show and it was so annoying.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well (drama). Can also mean play or show as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji. No more drama from you, okay?

context-en: Three months after starting my diet, my body had changed dramatically.
context-en2: While it's not a dramatic increase, it does seem that they received quite a bit of revenue.
context-en3: I got tears in my eyes when my favorite team won the game with a dramatic home run.
meaning-exp: Something that is drama al is dramatic.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Because of the continuous, twenty-nine day drought, Fugu is about to dry out.
context-en2: The long, cruel dry weather killed all the vegetables in my field.
context-en3: The supply of bacon Koichi got for the starving workers was like a welcome rain after a drought.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is weather (and how ? often refers to sky things?). Well, when those sky things are dry, you have dry weather.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The agar factory is on the east side of that street.
context-en2: This is a dish that's eaten in the Eastern region of the Mediterranean.
context-en3: It’s on the east side of the airport, so just go east on Dundas for about thirty minutes.
meaning-exp: The East side is the East side.
reading-exp: Remember how ?? read as ?????? This word is like that too, with ? being read as ???. ? is read like you learned it with the kanji.

context-en: I think this e-brake might be broken.
context-en2: The emergency alarm suddenly went off and I was surprised. Was it some sort of emergency situation?
context-en3: It’s always good to keep some emergency rations at home.
meaning-exp: A normal injustice! It's a terrible thing that happened, and despite it being normal it's still an emergency.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It's futile to just cry every day.
context-en2: I feel empty today, for some reason.
context-en3: Don't you feel empty doing the same thing every day over and over again?
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of void? It's empty or vacant. Just think of what has to happen to make a void in the first place.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If everything in life seems empty and futile, even cows will be affected. Listen to them say, "Moo, nah (??), never mind. What's the point?" Nothing makes life seem empty like a cow saying "Moo, nah."

vocab-meaning: Everyday Life, Normal Life, Daily Life, Ordinary, Regular, Everyday, Usual
context-en: I want to know what Koichi's daily work life is like.
context-en2: My daily life is very ordinary.
context-en3: When you learn a new language, it’s more efficient to begin with everyday, practical words at first.
meaning-exp: Normal days are what you have in your regular everyday life. This is your normal life.
