reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Evil Breeds Evil, Evil Begets Evil
context-en: They say "evil begets evil" right? So they just got properly punished.
context-en2: If you do something bad, you'll get in trouble later because evil breeds evil.
context-en3: What does the Bible say about karma? Was it like "evil begets evil" or something?
meaning-exp: Things that cause evil are the fruits of evil. This is a nice little saying. In English, you might say it as evil breeds evil. Remember that.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The last ?? gets the ? shortened a little bit.

context-en: Please explain why you suddenly slowed down the train.
context-en2: How could he be fit to be company president with a terrible explanation like that?!
context-en3: I’m sorry, I don’t understand at all. What does your explanation mean?
meaning-exp: When you make your theory bright (and clear and easy to understand) you must have come up with an explanation for it. Before it was dark and murky in everyone's mind. But, when you give your explanation, it gets bright and easy to understand! Yay!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When this player failed to bunt, this other player was caught stealing.
context-en2: I think failure is still better than doing nothing at all and then regretting that you didn't even try.
context-en3: To be honest, this movie you made is a flop. However, you can’t let it get you down just because you failed once. Someone said that success is the ability to go from one failure to another with no loss of enthusiasm, right?
meaning-exp: A fault and a failure, all in one. This must have been one big failure and mistake you've made.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? gets shortened, though. Don't make that ??.

context-en: No matter how old Fugu gets, he still lives in a world of illusion.
context-en2: I sometimes cherish the sweet illusion that Koichi is my son.
context-en3: My older brother maintains the ridiculous fantasy that he is the king of the blowfish.
meaning-exp: An illusion that changes your concept of the world is a big fantasy (it's also an illusion). This makes sense, though, right? An illusion is an illusion, sure. But, when it changes your concept of the world, it becomes a total fantasy!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I like walking around eating free samples at Costco.
context-en2: WaniKani is available for free until level four.
context-en3: I don’t want to be alone for Christmas, have you made plans already? If not, I have two Paul McCartney concert tickets and I could give you one for free.
meaning-exp: When the fee is nothing it is free and without charge!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Out of all fruit, I like figs the best.
context-en2: My kid doesn't like veggies, but apparently he thinks the tomato is a fruit so he eats them.
context-en3: "Do you think you’ll finish your work before the fruit shop closes?" "Don’t worry. If I can’t finish, I’ll just leave it for tomorrow."
meaning-exp: A fruit thing is just fruit.
reading-exp: The reading for this is an exception, at least for the ? portion. To remember this part, imagine yourself asking for some fruit. Could I (??) have some fruit, please?

context-en: The team that won a glorious victory this time is Team Tofugu!
context-en2: I never want to be an adult who speaks nostalgically of the glory days.
context-en3: At twenty-two, Koichi’s moment of glory came when he became a champion blogger.
meaning-exp: You helped your city prosper, and a light shines out of you, so that the entire city can bask in your glory.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: No matter what happens, never misuse government money!
context-en2: Do you think dropping off a child at a daycare using a public car is a misuse of government money in any way?
context-en3: My best friend was arrested on Friday for the embezzlement of over $10,000 of government funds, but I doubt she actually did it.
meaning-exp: Government gold (aka money) is what makes up government funds.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi sometimes has hallucinations while recording podcasts.
context-en2: When you watch this video, you have to watch in a well-lit place, not too close to the screen, otherwise I heard you'll have hallucinations.
context-en3: Fugu must have been hallucinating from the hallucinogenic mushrooms he ate.
meaning-exp: You have memorized an illusion. You see it there, as if it's real, as if it's in your memory and brain. But it's not real. It's a hallucination.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My heart was broken because of my flat, red nose.
context-en2: Heartbreak is an everyday occurrence for me.
context-en3: I’m heart broken and it really hurts. I want to go shopping to get rid of my stress. Why don’t we go to the sale this weekend and have lunch together?
meaning-exp: The fault of romance isn't the romance itself, it's when everything falls apart. It's when you experience heartbreak. Have you ever felt the fault of romance? If so, remember back to that time, and think about how terrible of a fault it is.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It's truly an honor for us to be able to interview you, Mr. Abe.
context-en2: You should know that it's indeed a privilege for you to chat with King Koichi in person.
context-en3: I’m deeply honored to have this opportunity to work at the Tofugu headquarters. I’ll do my best to be of use to you all.
meaning-exp: When a light shines on how much you've prospered, it's a great honor. You don't feel like you did anything so special, but it's really a privilege for the light to come down on you like this. Don't confuse this with ??! With that one, you made things prosper and the light came after, making you look glorious. With this, light is shining on you, and you receive honor from it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi was humming while making his nose swell.
context-en2: Viet was happily riding his bicycle while humming.
context-en3: LMAO! You are just terrible at humming.
meaning-exp: Try singing a nose song. How does it sound? Like humming perhaps?
reading-exp: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings, probably because a ? is a body part, and body parts do that to jukugo words. You know ?'s reading from the kanji (??) and you know ?'s reading from the vocabulary word ? (??). Combine them together and you have a very nice humming tune and reading, ????.

context-en: I came up with the hypothesis that this soil is very good for citrus fruits like clementines and lemons.
context-en2: We need Koichi's help to prove that this hypothesis is correct.
context-en3: I think that’s interesting, but if you want to write an article about that topic you need to find data to prove your hypothesis.
meaning-exp: A temporary theory isn't one that's set in stone yet. In fact, it's not really a theory at all, it's more of a hypothesis.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm worried people think of me as an ignorant know-it-all.
context-en2: I made a mistake due to ignorance.
context-en3: You shouldn’t be ashamed of yourself after admitting your ignorance. They should be ashamed of themselves for hiding their own ignorance.
meaning-exp: When you know nothing (Jon Snow), you know nothing. This is ignorance.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You'll be able to see apparitions if you take this drug.
context-en2: I caught a phantom fish!
context-en3: After a series of ecstasy filled visions of Salmon, Fugu finally remembered she had been dead for 12 years, and he realized he was seeing an illusion.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add phantom to the meanings as well, because phantoms are kind of like illusions.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look up to see a crazy illusion. You can't believe it's real. Master Roshi, from Dragonball, is standing in front of you (you thought he was a cartoon!). Then, he splits into a million versions of himself, creating a mob of Roshis (????). This mob goes on to train many people to fight.

context-en: I'm looking for a textbook with illustrations.
context-en2: Aya made an explanatory diagram of the in-house Tofugu relationships.
context-en3: I think it would be easier to understand if there was an illustration with an explanation, what do you think?
meaning-exp: A diagram theory is an illustration that is used as an explanatory diagram. Just imagine a chalk board with all sorts of drawings of things, showing how they work, at least in theory.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi said that garlic is a cure for constipation, but I'd say curing constipation with garlic is impossible.
context-en2: Even though Koichi makes unreasonable demands, the Tofugu team manages to meet them by overworking themselves.
context-en3: It’s impossible to lick your own elbow.
meaning-exp: If you can do nothing within reason, then what you're trying to do is unreasonable and probably downright impossible. If you still try, you're probably just overdoing it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

context-en: Last night, Viet detected unauthorized use of the computers.
context-en2: Viet and his foot soldiers seemed to have sensed that the police would raid them.
context-en3: Our baby is very sensitive to the emotions and anxieties of his mom, Salmon.
meaning-exp: Okay, so you guess but you also kind of know. You can make an inference as to what the answer is... You're not 100% sure, but you think you know, even though you're guessing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ? gets shortened to ??.

context-en: I'll wait for you inside Resona Bank.
context-en2: I think I've got a splinter in my inner right heel.
context-en3: We need to lower the metal shutters and lock them from the inside to shut the zombies out.
meaning-exp: The inside side is the inside. A little redundant but makes a lot of sense.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With ? you've already learned it. With ? you'll have to remember the kun'yomi reading of ??. Combine them together and you have ????. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that pesky ?? portion. What is it that's drawn you inside? "Oo, cheese!" (??) Cheese has drawn you inside. You're so excited that you exclaim, "Oo, cheese!"

context-en: Koichi warned workers not to interfere in his private life.
context-en2: I assume that both sides want to avoid armed intervention.
context-en3: Koichi is definitely not the type of boss to interfere, but it seems he likes meddling in what Viet is doing for some reason.
meaning-exp: When you're fording a stream, and you suddenly feel dry feelings around you, that doesn't make any sense for something wet. This dryness is an interference. It's an intervention trying to stop you from fording.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Internal Cause, Actual Reason, Intrinsic, Endogenous
context-en: I was diagnosed with intrinsic asthma.
context-en2: When a traumatic thing happens, endogenous opioids, which are morphine-like substances, will be secreted.
context-en3: For a long time the actual reason I’ve been suffering was a mental disorder.
meaning-exp: The inside cause is an internal cause. Internal causes are usually the nastiest causes, if you ask me.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi is like a gold mine of information, isn't he?
context-en2: Tofugu employees are all very thirsty for knowledge.
context-en3: Do you want to acquire a good knowledge of Japanese? Don’t be afraid. It’s easy. You just need to learn how to express information in another language.
meaning-exp: You're discerning about what you know. You choose what to keep and what not to keep in your brain. This is the sum of your knowledge.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Everybody stands on the left side on this escalator I guess.
context-en2: They drive on the left in Japan the same as they do in England.
context-en3: When sleeping, I prefer to lie down on my left side.
meaning-exp: The left side is the left side. Simple as that.
reading-exp: The reading for this is vocab kun'yomi readings. Just take the vocab ? and add it to ? to have yourself ?????.

context-en: When you hear "a legendary Irish hero," who comes to mind?
context-en2: Girls love you, man. You are legendary, seriously!
context-en3: According to a legend, there is a fugu eating tofu in this ocean.
meaning-exp: Let me transmit to you a theory... a theory that perhaps a great legend is true.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You just have to remember that ? is read as ?? in this case. Just imagine yourself sitting in your den (??) as you get cozy and listen to this theory about a great legend.

context-en: We still have a consolation match left for the defeated.
context-en2: That dentist was born to be a loser.
context-en3: Whenever you watch sports, you identify with the underdog that tried their best. Is that fun? Do you feel like you achieve something? What’s the point? No point, right? You have to change yourself from a loser to a winner.
meaning-exp: The failure someone (person) is the loser or the defeated.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The cactus flower is a symbol of maternal love.
context-en2: I like fantasizing about office romance and in my latest fantasy, love grew between Koichi and Viet.
context-en3: I think money is more important than love. They often say, "love can move mountains," but in reality you can’t do that without money.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji. Now that is true kanji love.

context-en: When I'm in love, I'm usually way too into them.
context-en2: My kid has been reading romance novels all the time lately.
context-en3: Parting from someone you love is always painfully bittersweet.
meaning-exp: When you have romance and love all in the same package. Well, that is love! Ah, love! This is the word used when talking about love, though. You don't use this to say "I love you."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I wanted to fall in love, but I'd never actually fallen for anyone until now.
context-en2: Don't you think Salmon got prettier? I think it's because she's a woman in love, don't you?
context-en3: I can’t get Fugu out of my head! Is there love in the air?
meaning-exp: When you have romance you also have love! The romantic kind of mushy, gushy love. Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love really fast.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your love isn't toward a person, it's toward this giant Koi (??) fish you met the other day. The fish is just so... so... handsome! You get hearts popping above your head every time you think about this koi!

context-en: My parents were deeply affectionate people.
context-en2: I don't want to have a loveless marriage.
context-en3: It’s beef stew that’s full of love.
meaning-exp: Those love feelings you're having mean you're in love!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Koichi's lover had an attractive, slightly nasal voice.
context-en2: You couldn’t even be his lover!
context-en3: I'm ambivalent about whether a mistress is acceptable or not.
meaning-exp: The person you make love to is your lover. Woooh! Don't worry I won't tell. Have fun and be safe, kids.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My boyfriend started drooling when he saw some cute girl even though we were eating lunch together.
context-en2: Oh no, I was thinking of doing okonomiyaki for lunch, but I forgot that we ran out of sauce.
context-en3: Oh no, I just burned the toast again. That was the last slice. Now I have to find something else for lunch.
meaning-exp: The noon meal is the meal you eat at noon. What meal is that? It's delicious, delicious lunch.
reading-exp: The readings come from the words ? and ??. If you know how to read those words you can read this word as well.

context-en: The primary cause of my diarrhea is probably the soft serve I ate just now.
context-en2: The main cause behind the near-miss is that the train sped up when it wasn't supposed to.
context-en3: The main causes behind many conditions like cancer and autism are still unknown.
meaning-exp: The main cause is the main cause or the primary cause.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I worry about acne, so I tend to use medicinal soap to wash my face.
context-en2: Does this pharmacy have medicinal lip moisturizers?
context-en3: I have a horrible cough, so is it okay for me to take medicated cough drops while I’m pregnant?
meaning-exp: Something that's used for medicine is medicinal.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When I take medicine, I pinch my nose tight.
context-en2: His life is loaded up with drugs.
context-en3: My favorite kind of medicine is the suppository kind.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you're looking for medicine in Japan, look for this sign.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need some medicine, stat! But, nobody wants to give you any medicine. You keep asking your pharmacist, Yuri, if he'll give you some medicine. He says no. You get pissed off, and you cuss yuri (???) out. He gives you the medicine after you cuss him out.

context-en: Koichi screamed, "Stop doing drugs right now!" and pointed at Viet's nose with his index finger.
context-en2: Viet made a clean break from both the yakuza world and drugs.
context-en3: Have you ever had an allergic reaction to any medicines?
meaning-exp: Medicine things are medicines and drugs. Try not to take too many of these, now!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: All of the military personnel have colds and stuffy noses.
context-en2: The door was locked from the outside so that the military personnel wouldn't run away.
context-en3: As a result of the Tofugu army reform, Koichi had to reduce the amount of military strength they had.
meaning-exp: A soldier member (or a member of the soldiers) is a person that is of the military personnel. It also shows the amount of military strength an army has. The more soldier members, the more military strength and military personnel it has!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I happened to see the seaman saying something to the captain in a shaky voice.
context-en2: I found a cute sailor uniform and a sailor cap, so I bought them for my grandchild.
context-en3: The brilliant actor who played a navy soldier in the play really wow’d the audience.
meaning-exp: A water soldier is a soldier that is out to sea. That is a navy soldier.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Kristen is a professional negotiator.
context-en2: I'll try negotiating, but please don't expect anything.
context-en3: On their honeymoon, Fugu was very impressed to find out Salmon is very good at negotiating on prices.
meaning-exp: When you ford into the thick of things and mix everything up, you're getting involved in a negotiation. That's what negotiations are though, right? You gotta get right in there, fording through the muck. Then, you gotta mix things up and compromise between both parties.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi usually works without taking holidays.
context-en2: Kana and Mami are making WaniKani example sentences without any breaks.
context-en3: Tofugu’s website is always open, twenty-four hours a day, every day of the year.
meaning-exp: If rest is nothing then there are no holidays. If there are no holidays, then that means a place is always open.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Could you stop poking my nose and leave me alone?
context-en2: Can picking your nose make your nostrils bigger?
context-en3: Just because your nose issues are making you stressed, doesn’t mean that you have to take it out on us.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji. Smells nice, right?

context-en: If you have a mustache it'll be a pain if your nose bleeds, right?
context-en2: Excuse me. I just need a quick word with you. Your nose is bleeding.
context-en3: I tried to rush onto the train, but the doors closed, squished my nose and made it bleed.
meaning-exp: A nose with blood is a nose with a nosebleed. It is a bloody nose.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You already know ?'s reading from the kanji and vocab, and you should know the vocab reading of ? as well. Put them together and you have ???, though you want to change the ? to ?. Alternatively, it's possible (though less common, but it doesn't matter if you're turning it to kanji via an IME anyways) to write it as ???. I guess that blood added a little tenten (it represents the blood coming out of that nose!). Spurt spurt spurt.

context-en: I seriously love this novel. This is legit.
context-en2: Dad is glowing with pride because his novel is selling well, huh?
context-en3: “Here, wipe your tears and nose,” Koichi said, ripping off a page of the novel that he'd been reading and handing it to Kristen.
meaning-exp: A small theory is some idea you have that you put on paper. Perhaps it's an idea about life, that you write in the form of a novel?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I think your prayers will be answered soon.
context-en2: When Koichi goes to sleep he always keeps a piece of paper with his wishes written on it nearby.
context-en3: Japanese people visit shrines on important occasions not only to make wishes but also to offer thanks.
meaning-exp: You know that an ??? is a request, and that ? is a "thing" or "action." So, this is a "request action," in a sense. A better way to say that is one's wish or a prayer, because that's what you're doing when you do the action of requesting something.
reading-exp: The readings come from the words ??? and ?. If you know how to read those you should be able to read this word too.

vocab-meaning: Open Seat, Empty Seat, Free Seat
context-en: I went to see a movie on Christmas day in the U.S. and I was surprised to see that the theater was nearly empty.
context-en2: Could you tell me if there are any lessons with free seats left?
context-en3: Are there still many open seats left? If possible, I’d prefer to sit in the front.
meaning-exp: A sky seat is a seat full of sky (aka nothing!). This is an empty seat or open seat.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This opera's main character is a natural-born Frenchman.
context-en2: I played the role of a slave in an opera.
context-en3: We are going to increase our opera ticket prices by 2%.
meaning-exp: A song drama. Ugh, I hate these. They sing so much and they're so dramatic. This is an opera.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Comic book movies often lose the flavor of the original work.
context-en2: Have you read Shakespeare's original works?
context-en3: This manga was made into a TV anime and drama series.
meaning-exp: The original thing you make is the original work. It's always better to have the original, rather than a copy, I think.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I thought this door opened outward, but it actually opens inward, I guess.
context-en2: I usually put the key in the outside pocket though....weird.
context-en3: I tried to deep fry some salmon, but the outside got burnt and the inside stayed bloody and orange. I guess the oil might have been too hot.
meaning-exp: The outside side is the outside.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you learned the kun'yomi reading for ? with the vocabulary, you should be just fine here.

context-en: A very patriotic man entered Tofugu.
context-en2: Michael composed a very patriotic 8-bit song.
context-en3: I don’t like that the country is trying to instill patriotism in children through misguided education.
meaning-exp: When you have love for your country deep within your heart, that is patriotism.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The smell of umeshu hit my nose as I entered the police station.
context-en2: That police officer sneered at Viet's warning, so he later found himself in a miserable situation.
context-en3: One hour after meeting at the police station, the police officer and the robber had completely hit it off.
meaning-exp: They warn you and they guess when you've done something wrong (with evidence, of course!). They are the police.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That made me realize how tiny and powerless I am.
context-en2: I got a Yu-Gi-Oh! trading card called "Proof of Powerlessness."
context-en3: The police were powerless to do anything about the stalker and in the end she was killed.
meaning-exp: When your power is nothing you are powerless.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You also can know that ? uses its ??? reading because when you tried to pick up a tiny rock (???) you couldn't, because you were powerless.

context-en: I lost the prescription that the doctor had given me.
context-en2: The handwriting is so messy that I don't understand what's written on the prescription at all.
context-en3: Some of the old prescriptions were considered to be dangerous and have been removed from use in modern medicine.
meaning-exp: When medicine is sent to your direction it's going to you. That's your prescription.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Public Behavior, Public Behaviour, Official Stance, Public Position, Public Face, Tatemae
context-en: Viet is good at separating his public and private selves.
context-en2: Our official stance is that you can't see a doctor here without a letter of reference.
context-en3: It’s often said that "the contrast between one’s personal feelings and public behavior" is a characteristic unique to Japanese culture, but that exists all over the world.
meaning-exp: What you build up in front of other people is your public image. This is your public behavior, how you act around others you don't really know. This concept is surprisingly important in Japan, so you'll hear it often enough despite being such a strange concept in other places. You'll have to think of this like you're building buildings of personality in front of you. These show off who you are on the outside, but it protects what's on the inside.
reading-exp: The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like ?? in that it's read as ??, which is like the word ??? even though the ? isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like ??? but the ? gets pushed into the kanji.

context-en: I can't wait to find out the results of the AKB election this year.
context-en2: Koichi often says that results are all that matter.
context-en3: I’m not pleased with the results at all. My plans to help her always backfire for some reason and this time was no exception.
meaning-exp: You tie up all the fruit because you're going to use them to make giant fruit letters. These giant fruit letters will show the result of the big monkey election.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the ? gets shortened to ??.

context-en: The steering wheels of Japanese cars are usually on the right side.
context-en2: There's a lot of salt in the right-hand drawer of Koichi's desk.
context-en3: We took a picture of a ghost. Look. There is a little girl who wasn’t there on the right in the picture. Can you see her?
meaning-exp: The right side is the right side.
reading-exp: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading. You should know the reading of the vocab word ? by now. Also, the ? reading happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji as well as with the word ?.

context-en: The river is deep around there, so be careful.
context-en2: There's a lot of sand on the bed in this river.
context-en3: "What did you do during Golden Week, Salmon?" "I lost my wedding ring in a river, so I was looking for it. It took me three days, but I finally found it buried in the riverbed."
meaning-exp: The river bottom is the river bottom, also known as the riverbed.
reading-exp: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Just don't forget the rendaku for ?!

context-en: We are praying for the safety of you all.
context-en2: My parents retired and live their lives safely and peacefully.
context-en3: Are you sure the baby doesn’t understand our language? What if my twins are talking right now like, "The doctor told our mom that it’ll be a toss-up whether we would come out safe and sound from her uterus." Aww... Doctor, they must have been frightened by what you said.
meaning-exp: The actions around here are nothing. Absolutely nothing is going on. If nothing is going on, that means it is safe and sound for you.
reading-exp: One thing that's not safe and sound is the reading of the ? in this word. Instead of ? it's ?. Why? Because you thought it was safe and sound, but you were fooled. There are ghosts everywhere, all jumping out and screaming Boo! (?) at you. Feel the surprise. You thought it was safe and sound!

context-en: It might be better with a little more salt.
context-en2: Until your baby turns one, you shouldn't give them any salt.
context-en3: Oh my God! I can’t believe you could be so stupid! Replacing salt and sugar is not funny at all, even if it’s April Fool’s Day today. You are the fool!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, no extra salt needed.

context-en: I thought I had a good nose, but I couldn't tell which one was salt water.
context-en2: I think puffer fish dipped in salt water and dried in the sun would be pretty tasty.
context-en3: The temperature itself isn't that high, but the sun's rays are really strong, so why don't you take some salt water to prevent heatstroke?
meaning-exp: Water with salt in it is salt water. Best not to drink ??.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You know ?'s from the kanji and you know ?'s from the vocab word ?. Combine them together and you have ????.

vocab-meaning: Salty Taste, Tastes Salty, Salty, Salty Flavor
context-en: Maybe I could've used more salt.
context-en2: Lightly-salted potato chips aren't that popular.
context-en3: "Hey! I heard that if I make salty jello for Koichi, I’ll get a free TextFugu account." "It’s better if you don’t believe that. I think it’s a lie!"
meaning-exp: The taste of salt is a salty taste (it's also when something tastes salty).
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, take the readings of ? (you learned the reading with the kanji) and ? and you have yourself ????.

context-en: I'm afraid that we request that seated customers please order something from the menu.
context-en2: Let's put everybody's bags on the right side of my seat.
context-en3: "Excuse me. Could you move over and let me sit down, please?" "I’m sorry, this seat is taken."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the on you learned with the kanji. Have a seat and relax.

context-en: I've decided all by myself that today is self love day, so I'm gonna spoil myself all day long.
context-en2: I don't think you should make it your purpose in life, if it only works out at the cost of your self care.
context-en3: I sincerely hope you’ll take good care of yourself and don't catch a cold or anything like that in times like these.
meaning-exp: If you love your self that is self love. Some would call too much self love selfishness as well.
reading-exp: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, you self lover you.

context-en: The sensation in my tongue is gone.
context-en2: I like Tofugu's sense of humor.
context-en3: If you really want to quit smoking, you should see what it feels like to be someone with diseased lungs.
meaning-exp: You know how we use feelings to memorize things here on WaniKani? I ask you to feel angry or sad or happy while imagining out the mnemonic stories. I also ask you to use your senses, because feelings are memorized best when you use the senses.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm studying sexual love at university.
context-en2: Interfering with another married couple's sexual love is just indecent.
context-en3: I’m not sure if I’m asexual or have erotophobia.
meaning-exp: Gender love is that kind of love that has to do with gender parts. That's sexual love.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Can I be with you a little longer?
context-en2: Don't drift away from mom, okay?
context-en3: I'm thinking about putting a potted plant on the right side of the sofa.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: Can I get your signature here, please?
context-en2: Our goal is to collect 10,000 signatures for this petition.
context-en3: I knew I shouldn’t have signed the contract before reading the fine print, but the landlord seemed like such a nice person.
meaning-exp: When you write your name for a government office, they require you to write out your signature. Printing won't do for official government office business.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Every night I get a silent prank phone call.
context-en2: Tofugu workers seem to work silently, but they are actually chatting on an app called Slack.
context-en3: Suddenly, some random guy started lecturing me about how mothers feel affection for their children, and it freaked me out so much I went completely silent.
meaning-exp: When you have nothing to say you sit in silence.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for ? though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Nothing cuts through silence like a gong (??). Once it's done gonging you really notice how silent the world around you is.

context-en: I saw a man with an aquiline nose pick his boogers and put them in the nostrils of a sleeping man with a short nose.
context-en2: I'm collecting the snot I pick out with my finger on a tissue.
context-en3: Fugu accused me of being selfish. Talk about an eye crust laughing at a booger.
meaning-exp: Maybe you didn't know this, but if you're like everyone else learning a new language, you learn the cuss words first. ?? is sh*t / garbage, though it's not really a "bad" word in Japanese like it is in English. So, what is your nose sh*t? It's your snot and boogers. Ewwww, stop eating them!
reading-exp: The reading is just like what you learned with the kanji. ????.

context-en: I cannot get the soldier's cry out of my head.
context-en2: The soldier set Koichi’s car on fire.
context-en3: The soldier walked at a brisk pace thinking about how long distances feel much longer without any companions.
meaning-exp: A soldier samurai is still just another soldier.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That soldier threw donuts at helpless children!
context-en2: Many troops suffered from syphilis.
context-en3: The American army frequently gathers here.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: Why has Koichi been keeping that pharmacology book on his desk lately?
context-en2: He is a student of the pharmacy department at the University of Tokyo.
context-en3: Is that true that Koichi is thinking of hiring a pharmacologist?
meaning-exp: People who study about medicine are studying the study of pharmacy.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Let's meet up in the theater's lobby.
context-en2: I’ll see you at a bathroom in the theater then.
context-en3: My daily commute to the theater is over two hours each way.
meaning-exp: A drama location is where people do drama. This is a theater.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I think this thread is a bit too thin.
context-en2: Your fingers are slender and long like a pianist's.
context-en3: My dietary plan is basically to make all of my friends cupcakes. The fatter they get, the skinnier I look.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thin? It's also thin, though it can be slender as well.
reading-exp: If your garden is too thin, just get out the hose (??)! How about if your hair is thin? Point the hose at your head! Hoses can cure any thin issues you may have.

vocab-meaning: Tip Of The Nose, Tip Of Nose, Nose Tip
context-en: You got mustard at the tip of your nose.
context-en2: That police dog started twitching his the tip of its nose and sniffing at the stranger.
context-en3: When Fugu saw that the tip of Salmon’s nose was so red, he found it very cute.
meaning-exp: You know the previous part of your nose? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the tip of the nose. Time to cut off the rest, next!
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. With ? you learned that with the kanji. With ? you learned that with the vocab. So, you should have all the pieces to be able to read this. Remember, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings for some reason, no exception here.

vocab-meaning: To Be Changed, To Be Transformed, To Be Altered, To Vary, To Be Turned
context-en: Whoever said that fried bacon tastes the same no matter how you make it was wrong.
context-en2: The custom varies from country to country, so we should just get used to it.
context-en3: I can’t believe how much makeup can change a face.
meaning-exp: You've seen how ??? means "to change" something. This word means that something changed by itself, it means to be changed or to be altered.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

vocab-meaning: To Be Defeated, To Be Unsuccessful
context-en: The Blue Jays lost the game to the Red Socks with a score of 1-3.
context-en2: As we all expected, Koichi was defeated again in the singing contest.
context-en3: Did you hear that a guy got upset with Japan’s national hockey team when they were defeated in the first round of a preliminary game for the Olympics and threw some curry at them?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means failure, but "to failure" doesn't make sense. What happens when you experience failure, though? Well you get defeated, and you're also unsuccessful. So, this verb is to be defeated and to be unsuccessful.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been defeated. You lay there on the ground, and the fans around the stadium are disgusted with your performance. Some hipster walks up to you and says: "Yah, Boo" (??) referring to how poorly you did. "No boo!" you reply back. "Yah boo" they say again.

vocab-meaning: To Be Encouraged, To Be Lively, To Be In High Spirits, To Cheer Up, To Be Excited, To Be Inspired
context-en: That horse is acting too lively for me to bet on it.
context-en2: Koichi and Viet came into the office in high spirits.
context-en3: The boy left for his trip in high spirits.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means courage so the verb version is what happens when you have lots of it. Someone with courage is probably the kind of person to be lively and to be encouraged.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who is the one person who always seems to be encouraged and excited? Isabel (??)! She's so positive and always cheers everyone, including herself, up.

vocab-meaning: To Be Erected, To Be Built
context-en: New high-rise buildings are being built one after another in Tokyo.
context-en2: Koichi's bronze statue was erected at the White House.
context-en3: Salmon and I are discussing buying a pre-built home at the north end of the beach, but it’s a little expensive for us.
meaning-exp: You know that ??? is "to build." This is similar to that, but it's the version where you're not doing the building. Something is just getting built. That's why this word is to be erected and to be built. You can recognize that because of the ?, which tells you that two (?) guys are building the building while you watch. So you're not doing it, they are, and it's just happening.
reading-exp: The reading is shared with ???, so if you know ??? then you should be able to read this word as well.

context-en: She got dumped and she's very sad.
context-en2: Animals, as well as humans, are saddened by the deaths of their friends.
context-en3: Don’t be sad. Your Japanese is good enough for now. Just don’t stop learning and you’ll improve little by little.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sad so the verb form of that is to be sad. Boohoo.
reading-exp: If you're going to be sad about something right now, it will be kana (??). Don't use kana when you're trying to learn kanji! You'll be sad forever if you're stuck using kana your whole life, so don't let that habit start now, friend.

context-en: I told you not to put the sweater in the dryer but to hang dry it.
context-en2: I think that comedian has definitely been deprived of any chance to appear on television recently. Don't you agree?
context-en3: I wanted to put our laundry outside to dry, but our clothesline just broke.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dry so the verb vocab version is to dry.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why do you need to dry something off? Because someone used a hose (??) and got everything all wet. Ugh, you shouldn't leave that hose out anymore...

vocab-meaning: To End, To Be Finished, To Be Exhausted, To Die
context-en: I haven't slept for three days and I'm exhausted.
context-en2: I thought, I must not die here.
context-en3: The meeting continued without any sign of ending and the employees were getting fed up.
meaning-exp: If you tear (??) up a fruit, its life is going to end. Fruit can't go on when they've been beaten up so much.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The fruit's life is about to end and you laugh, "Hahahaha (?)!" And then you start tearing at it more! What's wrong with you? Weirdo...

context-en: I thought this city would be more prosperous.
context-en2: This used to be a prosperous silver mining town.
context-en3: There was a village in China flourishing from their production of stimulants.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means flourish or prosper, so the verb vocab versions of these would be to flourish or to prosper.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you flourish at? You're an amazing soccer (??) player who flourishes and prospers no matter where you go to play this wonderful (but not as good as baseball) sport.

vocab-meaning: To Guess, To Sense, To Presume
context-en: From Koichi's language and behavior, I presume he is very soft on women.
context-en2: My husband is not good at guessing my feelings.
context-en3: From reading a few articles, I sense that the Tofugu team has some kind of implicit plan.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means guess so the verb vocab version is to guess. Alternatively, you can learn this as to sense or to presume.
reading-exp: The reading for this is actually the same as what you learned with the kanji, but the ?? is shortened to ??. If you had to guess be sure to guess with the shorter ?.

context-en: Koichi loves Tofugu very much and often murmurs things like, "Oh my dear Tofugu-chan."
context-en2: I hurt the person I love.
context-en3: My husband loved our son, but never showed him any affection. I don't think he knew how.
meaning-exp: You know that ? means love. So, when you add ?? to it you make it a verb. Now it means to love.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: My son was very happy when he finally hit the ball with the center of the racket.
context-en2: My mom dyed her gray hairs for the first time, and now she thinks she looks at least ten years younger, so she is rejoicing.
context-en3: We were so pleased to hear that studying Japanese is your only joy in life. We’d be happy to offer you some tips, so feel free to ask us any questions at anytime.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rejoice so the verb vocab version is to rejoice. Though to become happy probably sounds a little more natural.
reading-exp: You start to rejoice by saying, "Yo, rock on (???)!" Now you know how to rejoice from now on. At church or temple? "Yo, rock on!" Perfect.

context-en: It was the beginning of my tragedy.
context-en2: Are you trying to act like the hero of some tragedy? Moping forever won't help anyone.
context-en3: Tragedy is suits you.
meaning-exp: A sad drama always ends in tragedy. That's what makes it sad.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Japanese plum trees started to bloom.
context-en2: "Where did you get this many ume?" "I visited an ume orchard today."
context-en3: As soon as payday comes, I’ll buy the high grade, pickled Japanese plums that costs 10,000 yen a piece.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It's also the same as the meaning of the kanji / vocab, though you can think of this as Japanese plum as well if you want.

vocab-meaning: Ume Wine, Plum Wine, Plum Liquor, Umeshu
context-en: When I open a can of ume wine after taking a bath, I can't stop until I've finished it.
context-en2: Is that okay to drink plum wine on the trains in Japan?
context-en3: Thank God it’s Friday! I’m looking forward to drinking homemade plum wine tonight.
meaning-exp: Alcohol that comes from ume is ume wine. It can also be called plum wine or plum liquor. If you're of age give it a taste, it's quite nice!
reading-exp: The reading is just the readings of the kanji that you learned. How about a toast to easy to read words!

context-en: Yesterday, I met a beautiful woman of unknown age.
context-en2: Wanikani is a monster whose sex is unknown.
context-en3: His real job is unknown, isn’t it?
meaning-exp: Something is not detailed at all. I don't know anything about it. No details whatsoever. It's a totally unknown entity.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Why is that US soldier wearing pince-nez glasses?
context-en2: Lots of American soldiers walk through here, so please make sure you're not in their way.
context-en3: "Wow. What beautiful weather! I feel like I'll finally be able to do 300 sit ups today," said an American soldier.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is "America." Well, more of that again. With ? representing "America" you can combine that with ? (soldier) to have yourself a US soldier / American soldier.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I don't like vain people, regardless of their gender.
context-en2: I get hurt by my own vanity from time to time.
context-en3: The first rule of Tofugu’s softball team is that you have to leave your vanity on the bench.
meaning-exp: When how much you prosper goes into your heart and just enters a void, it will rarely mean anything to you. A person who has this trait is going to have extreme vanity because he/she just needs to suck more and more prosperity into their bottomless pit of a heart. It's like a black hole. They need more and more and more so then they have to become vain.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Victory Or Defeat, Win Or Lose, Outcome
context-en: The game's outcome was decided on the morning of the day before last.
context-en2: That one word Koichi said made the difference between victory and defeat.
context-en3: My parents always told me that it doesn’t matter if I win or lose, as long as I try my best, but I didn’t like that. Of course, I care very much about winning and losing. If I lose after doing my best, then there’s no point.
meaning-exp: You have win and you have failure. When you are talking about both in one word, you have victory or defeat.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Whenever I see a weak child, I get worried.
context-en2: I have a weak stomach.
context-en3: My son was born with a weak constitution, so he can’t exercise.
meaning-exp: You have yourself a void of weakness. This means you are weak and feeble.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm working at the post office on the west side of this town.
context-en2: Which countries are considered Western countries?
context-en3: If you eat makizushi on Feb 3rd of this year, you have to face the west bank.
meaning-exp: The West side of something is known as the West side. Sorry, I have no story to go along with your West side.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You should know both of them, with ? being ?? and ? being ?? (what you learned with the kanji).

context-en: These grapes are seedless, so they are easy to eat.
context-en2: It was, without a doubt, the perfect speech.
context-en3: Could you cancel this deal for now?
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji nothing, so when you have nothing, you are without.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you are without you don't have anything to eat either, so you end up gnashing (??) your teeth together instead.

vocab-meaning: Advance Notice, Forward Notice, Prior Notice
context-en: You'll be alright. Koichi won't fire you without prior notice.
context-en2: I left my rent unpaid for three months and then I was given an eviction notice.
context-en3: A letter giving advance notice for a murder arrived at the Tofugu office.
meaning-exp: If you announce something beforehand you will have advance notice. Advance notice is always nice to give.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: In a book I borrowed from the library, there was a grocery store advertisement stuck between the pages.
context-en2: I have to go back home because I forgot the ad with the coupon.
context-en3: Viet informed Koichi that Aya created the strangest picture ever for Tofugu’s advertisement.
meaning-exp: When you announce something to a wide audience, you're just throwing your message out there for everyone to hear. This is just a big wide advertisement.
reading-exp: Sorry, you learned the kun'yomi reading with ?. So, think of it this way when you need to remember this word's meaning: You're advertising something. It's a big advertisement to advertise how terrible a person ???? is. Come up with some terrible things he's done so that you can imagine this crazy Koichi advertisement you made and ran on national TV.

context-en: Everybody laughed for some reason when I said that people eat KFC for Christmas dinner.
context-en2: I feel like he probably doesn't even know what he's laughing at anymore, but he just can't help it.
context-en3: It’s not like you to cry at movies. You always laugh really hard when there are any serious scenes in them.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "to laugh." This is the noun version, because the ? in ?? turns to ? (so don't confuse this as an adjective). What is the noun version of "to laugh"? It's a laugh.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??, so just make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

context-en: I came to the conclusion that kyudo is difficult.
context-en2: Why are Japanese bows for kyudo so powerful?
context-en3: "What are you working on?" "Japanese Archery."
meaning-exp: The path of the bow. This is archery.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm worried about whether they'll obey the agreement.
context-en2: You should make living arrangements with your roommate.
context-en3: According to the contract between our company and Ms. Salmon, it is unfortunate, but we did not make an agreement regarding her appearance in our competitor’s commercials.
meaning-exp: You've taken a decision from someone. By doing this, you've created a kind of arrangement with them. Imagine yourself pulling this decision out of the person. They don't want to necessarily give it to you, but they're letting you pull it out of them, kind of. When you've pulled it out, you've come to an arrangement, though they've pulled some of your decision out too.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, which you might have guessed already since there's hiragana sticking out of both of them. The ?? comes ?? and the ?? comes from ???. Put them together and what have you got? Bibbidi bobbidi ????!

context-en: The air was hot and stuffy from the black smoke.
context-en2: You're not the only person who inhaled the black smoke.
context-en3: I was looking forward to being a bus driver but then my son told me buses spread black smoke, and that if I still want to be a bus driver, then I should try inhaling some of that black smoke that comes out of my exhaust pipe.
meaning-exp: Black smoke is black smoke. It's also something you should avoid if you can.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My debt has now reached one million yen.
context-en2: If you write me an IOU, I don't mind loaning you some money.
context-en3: In Japanese, there are a lot of words that have been borrowed from other languages.
meaning-exp: The task of borrowing something is when you're borrowing something. It's also when you get a loan.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We can't find Koichi's bow anywhere.
context-en2: You have to stabilize your upper body to draw the bow.
context-en3: Yeah, Lawson is open 24/7, but, you know, I don’t think they carry bows and arrows.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have your bow and you use it to shoot things, sure, but you've also covered it in candy so you can eat it when you're waiting out in the woods waiting for a buck to come by. You lick your candy bow and say: "yummy!" (??). Imagine the taste of your bow. What taste would make you say yummy?

context-en: He has no brains.
context-en2: Use your brain when you think!
context-en3: Did you know that people eat brains in this country? It’s a delicacy.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Don't have to use your brain for that.

context-en: When my mom went brain dead, my dad said, "You never know what will happen next—that's life," as if he was trying to tell himself.
context-en2: Brain hemorrhaging may lead to stroke and, finally, brain death.
context-en3: I heard a few people who were considered brain dead came back to life in the UK last year and they remembered parts of conversations from when they were unconscious.
meaning-exp: If your brain is dead you have brain death.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If I could change anything about my body, it would definitely be my brains.
context-en2: I'm so tired today, my brains just aren't working.
context-en3: "Do you want me to crack your skull open and suck out your brains with a straw?" the ghost said angrily.
meaning-exp: Do you know ?? Soup and how miso goes in it? This is that miso. It's soft and strange feeling. Now, your brain miso, that's your brains or your gray matter. Essentially, if someone cuts your head open with a katana, this is perhaps what would come out.
reading-exp: Reading is just what you learned with the kanji. Just use your ? a bit and it should be easy.

context-en: The word "brainwashing" originated in the 1950s.
context-en2: The training you receive at Tofugu when you start working there includes brainwashing into the Tofugu hive mind.
context-en3: Many Japanese netizens liken the surge of Korean content on Japanese TV to an act of brainwashing.
meaning-exp: Give your brain a nice wash. No! Wait! It's not as nice as it sounds. This is brainwashing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That Buddhist priest will reach the age of ninety-nine in one month.
context-en2: Koichi's pun was so lame that the Buddhist priest looked like a deer in headlights.
context-en3: The witch set even the Buddhist priest’s heart on fire.
meaning-exp: A Buddha priest is a Buddhist Priest.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: After I heard that the human race may cause its own extinction, I couldn't stay calm.
context-en2: I'm kinda surprised myself, but I actually feel amazingly serene now.
context-en3: I easily lose my calm when I’m constipated.
meaning-exp: A place that is peace and quiet is a very calm and serene place. Ahh, so nice!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please give me a candy.
context-en2: Curry flavored candy has been trending in Japan.
context-en3: Are you the type of person who sucks on candy or just swallows them?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. Usually when we talk about this kind of candy it's hard candy though.
reading-exp: This word is made up of a single kanji, and it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

vocab-meaning: Caretaker, Housesitting, Looking After One's House
context-en: I took a housesitting job for 20,000 yen a day.
context-en2: In America, it's illegal to let small kids look after their homes alone.
context-en3: If you want to travel for two months, you need to hire a caretaker.
meaning-exp: You know how ?? means "absence" or "away from home"? Well, now that you're absent from your home, it's someone else's turn to come to your home and take care of it. This person is the caretaker, someone who's looking after one's house.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing ?? will be important as well.
kanji-name: Detain, Protect, Number In A Series

context-en: If there's someone out there who wants to wash Koichi's car, please email us at hello@tofugu.com.
context-en2: While I waited for the car wash to finish, the part-timer kept yacking at me and it was really annoying.
context-en3: Who would buy a car wash business to launder money?
meaning-exp: A wash that washes cars is a car wash.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Don't confuse this with the same-sounding ?? though... unless you're washing your ?? in a ??...

context-en: I forgot my bag with the certificate on the train.
context-en2: Do I have to show my credentials?
context-en3: Could I check your ID?
meaning-exp: You hopefully know that ?? means "proof." So, when the proof is written down, what kind of proof is it? It's a certificate of some kind. I'm going to need to see some ??? if you want to get in here, sir.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing ??'s reading will also be helpful.

context-en: How long can I have this charm for?
context-en2: It seems I forgot to pack my amulet.
context-en3: You shouldn’t wear multiple lucky amulets at the same time. It could bring you bad luck instead.
meaning-exp: You know how ?? is "to protect," right? This is like that, but it's the noun version. It's not really "a protection," though it kind of is. What things can you wear to protect you from things like bad luck, demons, and ancient aliens? That would be a charm or an amulet. You'll see these kinds of things sold at temples and such.
reading-exp: The reading is like that of ??, so if you know the reading of that word you should be able to read this one as well.

context-en: With hope swelling in my chest, I started working for Tofugu.
context-en2: I didn't tell anyone I got mosquito bites on my breasts, making them very itchy.
context-en3: The lyrics to the Tofugu theme song, which Koichi sings every morning, with his chest puffed out, cause a swell of emotions in my own chest.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. At least I won't have to bring up the image of you mooning people with your breasts or whatnot. Oh dang, I just went and did it.

context-en: Please classify Tofugu employees into three grades using pine, bamboo, and plum, based on their level of comedy.
context-en2: Koichi was delighted by the fact that he was classified as a sheep during animal fortunetelling.
context-en3: Terrorists generally fall under two categories according to how they treat hostages: the friendly kind and the unfriendly kind.
meaning-exp: You take a type of something and break it off into a part. This part is the classification of that item.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When Michael got a job at Tofugu, he moved to Portland, Maine by mistake. It's still a funny story we laugh about to this day.
context-en2: Koichi gets intensive comedy training from Michael every day.
context-en3: In my dream, I was a comedian and I had to fart on purpose in front of the TV audience, but I couldn’t do it. Then I was scolded by the experienced comedians who hosted the show.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "to laugh." This is a noun version of that, though it's not "a laugh," (that's ??). Add ? to that and you have the thing that makes you laugh. It's comedy. It's the joke that's elevated with ? because it made you laugh SOOOOO much. Haha!
reading-exp: The reading is the same ?? or ??. It's also the same as what you learned with the kanji.

context-en: Koichi complained incessantly about the Tofugu employee's JLPT results.
context-en2: I think Tofugu is, without a doubt, the best of the online Japanese learning tools.
context-en3: It’s funny that the Japanese word for complaint is pronounced like the English word monk.
meaning-exp: A paragraph in writing is what you send someone when you want to submit a complaint. You want to make sure these are in writing, though, otherwise you don't have proof of your complaint. Also, don't make it longer than a paragraph, because that's too long and nobody cares about how you think the shop staff mistreated your dog Fluffy.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "Why did you take so long for the confession?" "Because I didn't know how to do it."
context-en2: Jamal has been publicly declaring that he is a fan of Dragon Quest, but recently, he finally confessed that he is a secret admirer of Final Fantasy.
context-en3: After getting an assistant position in a finance office, she confessed that she is actually bad at math.
meaning-exp: You can often associate "good" or "pure" things with the color white. So when you announce something that's white (and pure) it's a confession. You're getting out the evil and making yourself white and pure with your announcement.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi speaks in a cute voice, don't you think?
context-en2: Who does this cute baby belong to?
context-en3: Fugu: S-Salmon...? Wow what a, what a cute name. Salmon: You think so? I’ve always kinda hated it.
meaning-exp: It's possible to love this thing. It's so gosh darn cute! Any really cute thing is possible to love.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is screwed up, though if we're lucky, you already know the word for cute. It seems to have injected itself into American and English culture a decent amount, anyways. If you are one of the lucky ones, you'll know that this word is read as ????. If you're not, think of the cute thing being a cow. Then you say, "that cow???" (???), or "that cow is good" because it's so cute.

context-en: I wanted to have new experiences, so I got myself in debt.
context-en2: Koichi owes Viet 50,000,000 yen.
context-en3: Excuse me, excuse me. I’m trying to get through here. I’m running away from a debt collector.
meaning-exp: The money (and gold) you borrow is your debt. Be sure to pay it back before the yakuza come for you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ??? gets shortened to ??? though, so beware. Just think of that like the little bit that you lost to the yakuza, because they weren't happy you didn't pay back your debt. *cut*

context-en: The dictionary form of ate is eat.
context-en2: I'm fine with dictionary form, but I have trouble with conjugated form.
context-en3: Write the dictionary form of this word.
meaning-exp: This is a combination of the word ?? "dictionary" and the suffix ?? or "form." Put them together and you get dictionary form!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The theme of today's Tofugu podcast is the inseparability of life and death.
context-en2: English contracts often have a severability clause as one of general provisions.
context-en3: As a general rule, divisible claims, like savings accounts, do not become the target of divisions of inherited property.
meaning-exp: When it's possible to separate something, it's divisible. Just imagine separating things into parts. It's possible. So, if that's possible, it's divisible. Now think of something that's nothing (i.e. "no candy bars"). That is not possible to separate into parts. That is not divisible.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This document is incomplete.
context-en2: I think the document is on my desk at home.
context-en3: "When do you want Tofugu’s secret documents?" "The sooner, the better."
meaning-exp: If you put writing into a category, you'd have to write it down after you've chosen what category it is in. Where would you write that down? Into a document, probably.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Sometimes my mom reveals her elegant mannerisms.
context-en2: My friend gave a speech using elegant language at a Mrs. contest.
context-en3: Kanae’s parents have always been very strict in telling her to use a knife and fork elegantly.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is "crude" and "vulgar" - this is obviously the opposite. This is elegant.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you really care about equality, you should make all the workers' workloads equal.
context-en2: Do you think the left and right balls are equal in weight?
context-en3: Even for people who aren’t nerds, using uppercase letters on the internet is equivalent to shouting.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of equal? It's equal (and also similar or equivalent). That "similar" one is a bit weird, because "similar" is not equal, though I'd lean more towards equal.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What should be equal above all things? I think each person (??) should be equal!

context-en: Koichi treat workers as his equals.
context-en2: I thought Viet was a fifty-fifty partner with Koichi.
context-en3: I can’t talk to you like an equal.
meaning-exp: It doesn't matter what you say versus equal rights. If you really want things to be equal, you have to support equality.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: You forgot to write an equal sign here.
context-en2: Koichi gets furious if the top and bottom lines of an equal sign are not the same length.
context-en3: You have to pay attention to whether the formula to the right of the equal sign is plus or minus.
meaning-exp: How do you represent an equal number? With an equal sign.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Viet was chuckling softly to himself, especially when Koichi was yelling.
context-en2: I finally passed JLPT N1 and I'm especially appreciative of Tofugu for that.
context-en3: It’s not especially cold today.
meaning-exp: When you take something and separate it into parts, you want to be especially careful not to give anyone an unequal share. This is especially important because we're dealing with money, and people will flip out and shoot you under the table if you aren't especially accurate.
