reading-exp: The readings come from the words ?? and ???. So long as you know those words you should be able to read this one as well.

vocab-meaning: Exchange Student, International Student, Foreign Student
context-en: That international student always forgets to tie his shoes.
context-en2: That class's foreign students look kind of innocent, don't you think?
context-en3: That exchange student is always photobombing pictures of my boyfriend and me. It’s kind of annoying.
meaning-exp: Remember ??, which means "study abroad"? Do you also remember ??, which is "student"? This word is like those two words mashed together (they share a ?), making it a "study abroad student." What's a better way to say that? How about exchange student!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Far Away, Distant, At A Distance, Distant Place, By Far
context-en: I'm not wearing glasses right now, so I can't see far away objects very well.
context-en2: I live far away from my family.
context-en3: A gunshot went off in a far off direction.
meaning-exp: This is the noun/no-adjective version of the kanji far, so it means far away or distant.
reading-exp: This uses the kun'yomi reading which you learned with ??. How convenient!

vocab-meaning: First Class, First Rank, The Best
context-en: You are in the first-class carriage, yeah? That's so like you, Koichi!
context-en2: They must be making a ton of money if they have an office at the best location in Ginza.
context-en3: I won this bacon keychain when I took first prize in the bacon costume competition.
meaning-exp: When you're equal to one you are the very top. You are first class and first rank. In fact, you are the best.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. ?? gets shortened to ?? though, so watch out for that if you want to remain the best, yeah?

context-en: I went to a post office and bought five postcards.
context-en2: I said I would need five sheets of copy paper, not three, didn't I? Why can't you even do something this easy, Koichi?!
context-en3: Sounds like a plan. I’ll give you five extra stickers as a bonus too.
meaning-exp: You know that ? is a flat objects counter. So, now we're counting! You have five flat objects.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Flat Object, Clothing Items, Sheets, Flat Object Counter
context-en: I have ten tickets for the soccer game on Sunday.
context-en2: My breakfast is usually just one slice of toast.
context-en3: I’d like to buy some Tofugu stickers, how much would one be?
meaning-exp: This is a counter that can be used with various "flat" things, which is why it is referring to a flat object. Other things it can refer to include clothing items, sheets, paper, stamps, dishes, and more. Notice how they're all kind of flat shaped?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Viet admonished his soldiers because gambling is forbidden.
context-en2: Tofugu was banned from publishing videos by the Youtube censors.
context-en3: Don’t take off your spacesuit! It’s one of the things that’s prohibited.
meaning-exp: Stop! That's prohibition (prohibited)! When something is prohibited and you're forced to stop, that thing is obviously forbidden. If you see this you should probably not do the thing it's telling you not to do.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It slipped my mind that the forecast had said that it would rain in the afternoon.
context-en2: The weather girl said the forecast is calling for hot weather, starting tomorrow.
context-en3: According to the weather forecast, this year Canada is expecting snow all year round.
meaning-exp: A news report that covers things beforehand (before they happen) is a forecast. For example, a weather forecast is a ????.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You haven't forgotten that we planned to go out for drinks Friday night, have you?
context-en2: Viet makes a backup of our data every Friday night.
context-en3: "When will my Fugu costume be ready?" "It’ll be ready by Friday afternoon."
meaning-exp: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has ?? in it. But what day of the week is it? The gold day of the week is the greatest day. It's the day that makes you feel like gold because it's the end of the weekdays and the beginning of the weekend! This day is Friday.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word ?? as well.

context-en: Please add me to your friends list.
context-en2: My friend told me that this is a no-parking area.
context-en3: "Thank you for taking my side." "What are you talking about? We’re friends, aren’t we?"
meaning-exp: A friend that you attain is your friend. This is the most common way to say "friend," so learn it if you want to make any!
reading-exp: The readings for both of these are readings you haven't learned yet, though maybe you already know this word since it's fairly common. Think of it this way. You have your friend Tom (??) Cruise. You like him, and he likes you. You're close enough friends that you can touch (??) each other too. Like, on the shoulder or on the hand or whatever, without it being awkward. So, you like to Tom touch (????) when you can, because he has nice skin.

context-en: It took forever to get through the traffic around Ginza.
context-en2: When my cousin was walking in Ginza, she was interviewed by a TV crew.
context-en3: If you want to find a clever lover, maybe you should go to Ginza, Tokyo.
meaning-exp: The silver seat isn't some crazy kingdom where the king sits upon a silver seat. It is a famous place in Tokyo. Perhaps if you read the reading it will become more apparent what the meaning is (since they're the same). This silver seat place is Ginza.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please write the name of the goods you'd like and reply to this tweet.
context-en2: There are almost no goods in the grocery store around this time.
context-en3: As soon as the item arrives, I'll contact you.
meaning-exp: A product thing is any type of general goods. It's about as specific as you can get when you're talking about things like this.
reading-exp: Think of it like a video game. The first time you see new goods there's a sheen (??) about it. But when you bring it back to your place, the sheen is gone. Then when you go back to the store, wow! All the goods you don't already own have that sheen! Gotta buy them!

context-en: Koichi's sketches have increased in value by as much as a million dollars at auctions.
context-en2: There used to be lot of graffiti along the underground passages at Shinjuku Station a long time ago, but we rarely see them now.
context-en3: Spray-painting graffiti is already a bit old-fashioned. The newer artists create works of art by scrubbing the dirt off the wall.
meaning-exp: When writing just happens to "fall" on the wall (whoops, wasn't me who did that, how strannnnge) it's writing that's not supposed to be where it is. This kind of writing is graffiti.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. ?, however, is kun'yomi in this case and also has rendaku. So just remember that it's read as ? for this vocab and you'll be fine.

vocab-meaning: Hand Baggage, Hand Luggage, Cabin Baggage, Carry On
context-en: Did you forget your carry on?
context-en2: You can leave your baggage at the front desk.
context-en3: I think it would definitely take more than thirty minutes to go through customs and baggage claim.
meaning-exp: Remember ?? and how it means "baggage" or "luggage." Add a hand to it and you have hand baggage or hand luggage.
reading-exp: If you know ?? and you know ?, then you should be able to Voltron the two together into one mega reading.

context-en: Luckily, an empty taxi just came.
context-en2: I'm happy that I was able to help you.
context-en3: Fortunately, it was not life-threatening.
meaning-exp: Happiness is happiness!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: If your life is filled with nothing but happiness, every time someone says something to you, all you can do is say, "Sigh, what (???)?" You sigh and say what. Because you're too happy to really listen. You're just sighing all day and not paying attention.

context-en: You have an extraordinarily high class technique like that, huh?
context-en2: My son is still an elementary school kid, but he is studying high grade mathematics at a cram school.
context-en3: Please tell me about higher education in your country.
meaning-exp: When you are higher than equal, you are above the very top, you are above everyone. You are high class.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: How Many Flat Objects, How Many Sheets
context-en: Bacon is so tasty that I can eat an unlimited number of strips.
context-en2: About how many tickets have you sold so far?
context-en3: How many stickers do you want? For a large amount, we could give you a discount.
meaning-exp: You have flat objects but what amount of flat objects? This word is asking that question: "how many flat objects are there?" If this doesn't make sense, think back to words like ?? or ?? which ask "how many ____" just like this one.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When I go to the beach, sunscreen is essential.
context-en2: What do you think would be essential to becoming fluent in Japanese?
context-en3: Tasty bacon is indispensable in promoting efficient work.
meaning-exp: It's not possible to lack. It is indispensable and essential, so don't lack it!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi doesn't want to distribute Tofugu's profits unevenly.
context-en2: Do you know the formula to find the area of a scalene triangle?
context-en3: I’m pretty good at simultaneous inequalities.
meaning-exp: When something is not equal it suffers from inequality.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Where did you get the information that they were brutally murdered in their beds?
context-en2: Does Tofugu have any data-handling rules?
context-en3: Well, I’d like to stop by later to exchange information on the WaniKani project, if it’s okay with you.
meaning-exp: The feeling of news is that it should give you information and data, not fluff.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I heard poop is called baba in Kansai dialect.
context-en2: It's really scary when people complain in Kansai dialect, isn't it?
context-en3: He said things to me like, “I hate you” and “go home” and it sounds awful, doesn’t it? But I actually thought it was pretty cool because he said it all using Kansai dialect. It was really hot.
meaning-exp: Do you remember ??, which is the Kansai region of Japan? Well, they have their own dialect, and it is Kansai Dialect.
reading-exp: The reading is the vocab ??'s reading and the kanji reading of ?, combined.

context-en: There are sure are a lot of different types of people in the world.
context-en2: This rose is actually a different type than that one.
context-en3: Viet has downloaded all kinds of programs to prepare against any unexpected situations.
meaning-exp: The kind and type is the kind or type. Basically, if you know the meaning of either of these kanji you'll know the meaning of this word as well, since they all share nicely.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "Kowtow" is what is called "dogeza" in Japan.
context-en2: Everyone in the room kowtowed toward the king.
context-en3: Since the man refused to kowtow, he was put into a jail.
meaning-exp: Strike your head against the floor to show your subservient respect by doing the kowtow bow. This is the most respectful bow you can possibly do. (Thank you China, for bringing this word into Japanese and thank you Japanese for bringing this into English.)
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: They used to make you kowtow every single time you came to ?????. That's full on head to floor kowtowing in front of everyone who is already in ????? to prove that you appreciate being there. They might even make you do it these days too, if you're not being respectful enough while you're there.

context-en: This kanji can be read with either the kun'yomi or on'yomi readings.
context-en2: Do you know this kanji's kun'yomi?
context-en3: I mix up kun’yomi and on’yomi all the time.
meaning-exp: The instruction reading may not make a lot of sense, but you've heard this word before. Jump to the reading and you'll know what the meaning of this word is.
reading-exp: The reading is the word ?? (like ??) and the reading you learned for ? combined, making ????. Sounds familiar? It's that kun'yomi reading you've heard so much about.

context-en: The larynx is one part of the Adam's apple.
context-en2: Laryngeal cancer is often caused by smoking and drinking.
context-en3: Because of my laryngeal inflammation, it's painful for me to even breathe or drink water.
meaning-exp: The body part that lives between your throat and your head is your larynx. Otherwise known as the voice box, because your vocal cords live in there.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you really want to get a larynx work out, go to ?????. It's loud, it's crowded, and you have to yell the entire time to get people to hear what you have to say. You also know 18 levels of kanji and you really want to shout them all out, which makes your voice box tired (but makes you happy).

context-en: What moral can you draw from Koichi's story?
context-en2: I'll keep this lesson in mind.
context-en3: Tell me about the biggest lesson you learned from your previous company.
meaning-exp: At least way back in the day, things that teach instructions to people are things that teach a lesson or moral. Back in the day, lots of learning was done through storytelling, and storytelling taught lessons and morals, thus, this word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Kristen's lullaby has reached the professional level.
context-en2: What's the most popular lullaby in America?
context-en3: It's a lullaby that was sung for me when I was little.
meaning-exp: A song you sing to protect your child while they sleep is called a lullaby.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are all kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you finish singing a lullaby to your child they always ask for more (??). It doesn't matter how many you sing, they always want at least one more before they will fall asleep.

vocab-meaning: Mankind, Race Of People, Humanity, Humankind
context-en: What do you think is the greatest enemy of mankind?
context-en2: You are a disgrace to the human race!
context-en3: Aya insisted that bacon is one of the most important things for humankind to hand down to future generations.
meaning-exp: If you categorize people into types, you have different races of people. Or, you can categorize people as one type of "people" in this universe. If you did this, you'd call us mankind.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you won't put all your eggs in one basket, you won't be a real master.
context-en2: Viet is a master of the camera.
context-en3: My dad is famous for being a world-level master in the realm of pizza delivery.
meaning-exp: A person who has "attained" is someone who knows much. He/She is a master or expert, obviously.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: On Monday, I forgot to turn off the bath, it overflowed, and our place was flooded.
context-en2: Please pay the examination fee through your bank by Monday.
context-en3: On Monday, I would like to watch some fun movies with you, like a steamy romance or blood-curdling horror film. How does that sound?
meaning-exp: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has ?? in it. But what day of the week is it? The "moon" day of the week is monday. Why? Because "Moon" is pretty much just "Mon," right?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word ?? as well.

context-en: All of my coworkers knew about the news report already.
context-en2: How will this terrorist attack be reported in Japan?
context-en3: According to the news report, twenty fish were transported to a local hospital after a pileup that occurred early this morning.
meaning-exp: The way of news is to do lots of news reports.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How could I forget that this is a no smoking area?
context-en2: I've decided to make every Monday a no smoking day.
context-en3: I told my mom to quit smoking and she told me that if she did, she would probably go crazy and my parents would get divorced.
meaning-exp: If smoke is prohibited you probably shouldn't smoke. Aka no smoking, okay?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Number Of Sheets, Number Of Flat Objects
context-en: Could you count the number of the origami paper?
context-en2: Can you guess how many credit cards Koichi has in his wallet at the moment?
context-en3: I’m not exactly sure how many stickers I’m going to order yet, but I think it will be at least one hundred.
meaning-exp: You have flat objects. You have a number of them. These flat objects are flat things, right? Flat things like sheets of paper, perhaps (or other sheets of things). So, this word is number of sheets.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That supervisor with the Osaka dialect always takes forever to get to the point, it's very annoying.
context-en2: I've put the past with my ex with the Osaka dialect behind me already.
context-en3: "Don’t worry. I won’t tell anyone that you speak with the Osaka dialect. Your secret is safe with me." "Thanks."
meaning-exp: Remember ?? (Osaka)? This is the dialect they speak, making this word Osaka dialect.
reading-exp: If you know how to read ?? you can just add ? to it and be able to read the whole thing, though maybe not in Osaka dialect. Okay, fine, it's probably the same thing in Osaka dialect.

vocab-meaning: Penmanship, Way Of Writing, Manner Of Writing
context-en: Kanji penmanship escapes me.
context-en2: Why doesn't Tofugu have an app to teach the ways of writing?
context-en3: I am bored out of my mind with studying hiragana penmanship.
meaning-exp: This is the way of writing (kind of like how ?? is the way of seeing). A better way to say this though would be to call it penmanship, though. How's your ???? Mine is terrible.
reading-exp: If you know how to read ?? and ? separately, you should be able to read this one too.

context-en: If you want to use WaniKani's example sentences somewhere else, please get Mami's permission.
context-en2: I got permission to interview one of Tofugu's hardcore fans.
context-en3: If you want to take a picture with Koichi, you need permission from Viet.
meaning-exp: I permit that it is possible. So, go ahead, do it. I give you permission.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I wonder where Koichi and the others went.
context-en2: Those gangs are all Viet's sworn brethren.
context-en3: Aren’t you still minors?
meaning-exp: You'll see this attached to other words to make them plural. That's why it's called a pluralizing suffix.
reading-exp: This is almost the same reading you learned with the kanji. Remember ??? Well this is read ??. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you want to pluralize something, touch (??) it to something else. One egg touches another egg, well now they're eggs. Plural eggs! One friend? No. Touch them! Touch them right on the face. Now there are two friends. Plural friends! Thanks to the good ol' pluralizing suffix touch! Oh, and don't type the ? out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

context-en: Hearing that it would be possible for me to put my daughter in daycare this spring lifted a huge weight off my shoulders.
context-en2: Please present a few more possible solutions.
context-en3: I’d say earning a hundred million dollars a year is possible.
meaning-exp: The ability is there, so it is possible... wait, there's enough ability to make this possible? Let's do it!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Could I borrow the postcard for a moment?
context-en2: I bought postcards at the post office, but it seems that I left them there after paying.
context-en3: I received a weird postcard saying that Koichi is actually the prince of a secret country, but he is living incognito as the Tofugu president in Portland, Oregon for some unavoidable reason.
meaning-exp: A writing that you put on a leaf is like something else. Instead of a leaf, think about writing you put on a leafish sized item. A postcard perhaps?
reading-exp: The reading is kind of weird, sorry. The reading for ? is the ? you know and love. Then, ? is ?? despite not having a ? on the end like you'd expect. So, it's weird. It's shortened like a postcard is a shortened letter, I suppose? Technically it is the ?? reading, but keep in mind that ?? gets rendaku'd.

context-en: I'm praying for my visa to be issued without any issues.
context-en2: Koichi can do the war dance of the Martians.
context-en3: "May Salmon’s surgery go well," Fugu prayed to God.
meaning-exp: You pray and request. This is your prayer.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: All people around the world are praying.
context-en2: I'll attend the peace memorial service for atomic-bomb victims tomorrow.
context-en3: Let’s pray for more and more growth and prosperity for Tofugu, cheers!
meaning-exp: Your thoughts are prayers. These pray thoughts are prayers.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Did you already see Tofugu's public, financial announcement?
context-en2: Tofugu decided to put up an important public notice about Koichi in an official telegram.
context-en3: There is a law in Japan called the Electronic Public Notice Regulation, do you have anything like that in your country?
meaning-exp: A public announcement is a public notice.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We'd prefer a house on a quiet street.
context-en2: I know you have diarrhea, but could you keep it down a bit more, please?
context-en3: When Koichi and Viet got in, the taxi quietly started to move.
meaning-exp: This is the ? adjective form of quiet, which is kind of just like the noun, anyways. What is the adjective version of quiet? It's also quiet.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to be quiet. She's (??) being nice and quiet, unlike you!

context-en: There's a wide variety of different races in this city.
context-en2: I don't really like racial jokes.
context-en3: My father is a racist and yet he tells me that it’s wrong to judge people based on their race.
meaning-exp: A kind or type of person is when you categorize a person into different types. How do we do that? Well, you categorize by race of people (or more simply by race).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'll never forget the look of Koichi's refined face.
context-en2: Koichi is trying to polish a rough draft of his poetry for the poem contest in October.
context-en3: I didn’t know that Salmon spoke in such refined Japanese like that.
meaning-exp: You take your practice and you wash it. Slowly chunks fall off and it becomes more and more simple. You are washing away the gunk on the outside to attain refinement and polish yourself, via practice.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'll start by consulting elderly relatives.
context-en2: Actually, President Obama is a distant relative of Koichi.
context-en3: He’s a really isolated guy who cut off all contact with his relatives.
meaning-exp: These people are kind of like a type of parents. Not quite parents, but kind of, in a pinch anyways. These are your relatives.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Renting A House, House For Rent, Rented House
context-en: You can't borrow money on a rented house.
context-en2: "Tenants' Rights" simply means you have the right to rent a house, right?
context-en3: I’m trying to talk to Salmon about renting a house instead of buying one, but she kind of keeps skirting the issue.
meaning-exp: When you borrow a house you are renting a house. Also, this is a house for rent.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but in this case the second kanji can be read as either the on'yomi or kun'yomi. You haven't seen the kun'yomi for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're renting a house, someone has to give you the keys and let you in and stuff. You're only renting, after all. So when they let you in they'll say, "Here's a shack for yah! (????) Enjoy!" By the way, in the secondary reading, the ??? goes to ???. You'll see ???? more often, though.

context-en: Shouldn't we report this to Koichi?
context-en2: Koichi gave an oral report of Tofugu's annual report for the workers.
context-en3: I’m thinking about the funniest way to inform my boyfriend that I’m pregnant so that he won’t run away from me.
meaning-exp: A news report that is to announce the news is a just a report. Just imagine someone announcing the news outside. They are giving you a report on the information going on with the news.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Yakitori is essential for my life.
context-en2: My husband was too busy running his yakitori restaurant and he totally forgot about our wedding anniversary.
context-en3: Don’t blame me! I didn’t eat your yakitori.
meaning-exp: A baked bird isn't just any bird, it's roast chicken. You may also know it by its romanized Japanese name: yakitori.
reading-exp: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings. With ??, you can use the reading you learned with the kanji. With ? just remember back to the vocab word, ??. Combine and eat.

vocab-meaning: Roast Meat, Grilled Meat, Cooked Meat, Yakiniku
context-en: I left my camera at the yakiniku restaurant.
context-en2: They say it's harder for the person left behind than it is for the one who leaves, but this doesn't apply when we're eating grilled meat, now does it?
context-en3: I find it really irritating when people chew yakiniku loudly.
meaning-exp: Mmmmm, yum! Take some meat and cook it. Then you have roast meat or cooked meat. If you go to Japan look out for ?? places (same meaning/reading). They are good, if you're into meat at least.
reading-exp: ?? uses the reading you learned with the kanji. ? does too. Combine them together onto one skewer and enjoy.

context-en: In order to write a good article, it is important to make a rough draft.
context-en2: Did you know Koichi keeps the rough draft for a poem he wrote in high school in his desk drawer in the office?
context-en3: I wonder if Aya usually makes a rough pencil drafts first or if she just draws freehand.
meaning-exp: Something below your writing isn't what you want to necessarily publish to the world. It's below your writing, after all. This is merely a rough draft.
reading-exp: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading, as you can maybe guess from the hiragana sticking out. If you know the readings of the words ? and ?? separately, you should be able to combine them into one reading.

context-en: Is this sun screen safe for babies?
context-en2: "Achoo!" "Are you all right?"
context-en3: Anytime is okay. I’ll go with whatever time is convenient for you, so it’s whenever you’d like.
meaning-exp: The big height of your husband makes everything safe and all right. Nothing you need to worry about when you have your super giant husband around to protect you. This is a really useful word, and it is used all the time. If someone asks: "Are you alright?" you could say in response "???" to mean you're doing all right.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

context-en: I completely recovered from the fatigue from Saturday.
context-en2: On Saturday, I truly realized that life is easy when you are a good-looking woman.
context-en3: My stupid boss just told me that I have to work Saturday. Plus, I just caught a cold. And on top of that, my girlfriend dumped me. My life sucks.
meaning-exp: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has ?? in it. But what day of the week is it? The earth day of the week is a day you find yourself close to the earth. Either you found you drank too much on Friday, so on this day's morning you're laying right on the ground of earth. Or, maybe you just want to sleep in after staying up late on Friday. Either way, this day you lay close to the earth is Saturday.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word ?? as well.

context-en: This seat's cushion is really comfy.
context-en2: I didn't know that I had to make reservations for seats.
context-en3: The moment Salmon leaned across the seat to kiss Fugu in the car, the traffic light turned green.
meaning-exp: A sit seat is probably going to be a seat.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How can you sit seiza for that long?
context-en2: I thought Koichi would make me do seiza, but he was as generous as a Buddhist priest and excused me for being late.
context-en3: I knelt in seiza for so long during the Buddhist memorial service that my legs were completely numb.
meaning-exp: The correct way to sit is this way: traditional Japanese sitting (this is when you sit on your legs and your feet, kneeling). You can also call it seiza. Learning the reading will help with the meaning.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The city of Portland was covered with fire and smoke.
context-en2: Hey! Smoke is coming out of the grill!!
context-en3: Viet was surprised to see smoke rising from the other side of Koichi’s computer because smoking is banned in the office.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're standing around a smoke machine. It's billowing up smoke. Strangely, your buddy Bill Murray is here too. For some reason, he loves the smoke, and he puts his head in it, breathing it in deeply until he goes into a coughing fit. You decide it's time to stop him. "Kay, Murray (???), it's time to stop that," you say.

context-en: None of Tofugu's employees smoke.
context-en2: Do you know where the smoking room is?
context-en3: Oh my gosh! That was just way too funny! Why did you think you could smoke with your nose? I am laughing so hard right now.
meaning-exp: If you consume smoke you are smoking.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How big is this steam ship compared to the rest in this country?
context-en2: We chartered a steam boat for our trip to Singapore.
context-en3: How can we finance our trip around the world by steam boat?
meaning-exp: A steam ship is a steam ship or steam boat. So fancy back in their day!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Steam Train, Steam Engine Train, Steam Engine
context-en: That station worker realized he forgot to stop the steam train.
context-en2: It was my favorite steam engine, so I took thousands of photos.
context-en3: "Excuse me, how often do the steam trains come?" "About every twenty minutes."
meaning-exp: A steam car is a car that runs on steam. No regular car runs on steam, but what thing that has things called "cars" does run on steam? How about a steam train? You can also think about ??s, which are electric cars (but means "train"). This is similar to that, but now it's run with steam, making it a steam train.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I was startled by what Kana said and couldn't help but stand still for a moment.
context-en2: This is just a still frame, but it looks like it's moving a little. What an interesting picture.
context-en3: In Japanese archery, you need to stand still for a moment with the bowstring fully drawn back before releasing the arrow. Is it the same in Western archery?
meaning-exp: Everything is quiet and stopped. The world is still and everything is at rest.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My father is a master of sugar sculptures.
context-en2: Have you ever made sugar sculptures?
context-en3: Apparently, the sugar goldfish is similar to real goldfish in shape and taste.
meaning-exp: Candy made into thin constructions are sugar sculptures. Usually these are in the form of sugar animals, but they can be anything, really.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi readings for the second two. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want your sugar sculptures to be made into cookies (?)! Cookies are your other favorite snack, so having a cookie that's really just entirely made of sugar is the absolute best. Also, watch out for the rendaku on ?, it's easy to miss if you're focusing on remembering this new on'yomi reading.

context-en: It seems like my daughter is deeply in love with that tan young man.
context-en2: Your back is super red from that sunburn.
context-en3: In Hawaii, strong sunscreen is essential and covers are also used to protect people from getting sunburned.
meaning-exp: When the sun cooks something, and that something is you, it is giving you sunburn.
reading-exp: The readings here are the vocab kun'yomi readings. You have ? for ? and ? for ?? (which you learned with the vocab). Combine it with some sunscreen and hopefully you'll prevent the sunburn.

context-en: After parents' day on Sunday, there is a parents-only meeting.
context-en2: We introduced ourselves one by one at a church on Sunday.
context-en3: On Sundays, I do things like play tennis and eat ice cream with my girlfriend, Salmon.
meaning-exp: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has ?? in it. But what day of the week is it? The Sun day of the week is Sunday. Doesn't get much easier than that for you. Lucky!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word ?? as well.

context-en: When I see sunsets, I feel empty for some reason.
context-en2: My friend firmly believes that sunrise is actually sunset.
context-en3: The sunset on the beach last night was so radiant it was like heaven. And because of that I went blind in my left eye.
meaning-exp: When the evening is burning with sun, it is the sun going down, getting all close to the horizon and earth. This is the sunset.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. Combine ? and ?? (you learned the reading via the kanji) and you'll have ????.

vocab-meaning: Taboo Word, Taboo Phrase, Dirty Word, Bad Word
context-en: I feel terrible. I don't know why I said that bad word! I apologize.
context-en2: I can't get the dirty word Koichi said out of my mind.
context-en3: The second rule of Tofugu’s softball team is that you have to keep in mind that "bacon" is a taboo word before lunch time because it makes us too hungry.
meaning-exp: A paragraph that is under prohibition is under prohibition because it contains a taboo word or taboo phrase. Do not say this word, please!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Tea House, Cafe, Coffee House, Coffee Shop
context-en: My iPhone was stolen, so I'm using the tea house telephone to call you now.
context-en2: I was drinking coffee at a cafe and the cashier forgot to hand me my change, but I also didn't notice and just left.
context-en3: "Last year I ran into Koichi in a cafe in Brazil." "Oh, really? Now that you mention it, I haven’t seen him in years."
meaning-exp: A tea shop where you consume (tea) is a tea house. Welcome! Sit down. Relax. Have some tea.
reading-exp: The readings are what you'd expect except for ?? getting shortened to ?? and ?, which has this strange ? reading. To remember that it's ? instead of ??, think of this tea house you're going in. You think it's nice and pleasant, and it is for a while... until someone starts working a saw (?) outside, ruining the atmosphere. BEWWEEEEHHHEEEHHHHHE gatatatatatat BWEEEHEEE.

context-en: In this temple, it's believed that eating well is vital for good health, so monks eat delicious meals every day here.
context-en2: I visited the places where the movie "Godzilla vs King Koichi" was filmed and this monastery was one of them.
context-en3: Nice to meet you. I’m Koichi. I’m scheduled to start working in this monastery today. I’m looking forward to working with you all.
meaning-exp: An institution for monks is going to be a temple or monastery. What a nice place to live, I'm sure!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Cats purr with their throats.
context-en2: Your throat's gotten slimmer lately, hasn't it?
context-en3: I have a sore throat. Can you sing on my behalf?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji (and is a body part) it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Remember the mnemonic from when you first learned this kanji? Well ???? is still in your throat and he doesn't want to get out. In fact, every time you tug on him, he shouts, "No Do- (??)" but you gag and can't hear the rest. People around you think you're saying "No Do-" but it's really just the weirdo living in your throat now. What a pain...

context-en: The gas pipe cracked on Thursday.
context-en2: I think I'm gonna do the laundry on Thursday.
context-en3: On Thursday, do you want to do something fun like making a snowman or building an igloo?
meaning-exp: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has ?? in it. But what day of the week is it? The tree day of the week is Thursday. Tree day comes after water day (which is Wednesday, for Water-Wednesday!). Trees need water to grow, which is why the tree comes right after the water.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word ?? as well.

context-en: I bid farewell to my girlfriend.
context-en2: Koichi announced to his employees that he would be hospitalized for hemorrhoids from tomorrow on.
context-en3: Viet told Koichi that Mami is much weirder than everyone imagined.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means announce so the verb vocab version is to announce.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'd like to announce... we're not having one baby, we're having two (?) babies!

vocab-meaning: To Attain, To Reach, To Get To, To Arrive At
context-en: We were a little bit late, but we arrived safely at our destination.
context-en2: Koichi's beard finally reached his waist.
context-en3: Only a little longer until we attain the target number of people.
meaning-exp: You know that ? means attain. So, when you add ?? to it you make it a verb. Now it means to attain.
reading-exp: This reading for this is a bit of an exception. You know the reading for ? is ??, but here it's shortened, to just ??. So make sure you remember.

vocab-meaning: To Bake, To Cook, To Grill, To Burn, To Fry
context-en: I achieved my goal to bake one hundred cheesecakes.
context-en2: I burned the letter when I made baked sweet potatoes.
context-en3: Does your hubby bake cakes too?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bake or cook. So, the verb vocab version is to bake or to cook.
reading-exp: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

context-en: I want to skim the scum off the top, so can I borrow your ladle for a second?
context-en2: I borrowed one of your loose-leaf sheets of paper, Kristen.
context-en3: "I’m sorry I lost the romance novel I borrowed from you." "Don’t worry about it. I won’t need it anymore anyway. I have a girlfriend now."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means borrow so the verb vocab version is to borrow.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Dude, can I borrow your car (?)? Please?

vocab-meaning: To Cut Off, To Cut Out
context-en: Can you cut out this cabbage's core?
context-en2: Today, I'll teach your how to cut a star out of a piece of paper.
context-en3: Why do you bother clipping coupons from newspapers if you never use them?
meaning-exp: If you cut and take something, you are going to cut it right off. So, this verb is to cut off.
reading-exp: The readings come from ?? and ??. So, know those words separately and you can combine them into this word.

context-en: Koichi pounded his chest with a fist, saying he would definitely deliver it by six.
context-en2: It completely slipped my mind that I have to deliver this flower today.
context-en3: My daddy is a pizza delivery driver. He can deliver pizzas faster than anybody else.
meaning-exp: You distribute the goods, they attain the goods. You are going to deliver to everyone.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Sorry, Kanae. We all totally forgot about how much effort you put into it.
context-en2: I almost forgot Koichi's face.
context-en3: Forget about it. It’s water under the bridge.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means forget so the verb vocab version is to forget.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Wait, what was (??) the reading? I forget... What was it?

vocab-meaning: To Harden, To Solidify, To Become Firm, To Become Certain
context-en: Why are you guys packed into the corner like this?
context-en2: My decision to quit Tofugu finally solidified.
context-en3: I think the pudding will finally harden soon.
meaning-exp: You've seen how ??? means "to make hard." This word means that something hardened by itself, it means to harden or to solidify.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

vocab-meaning: To Permit, To Forgive, To Allow
context-en: I have an important announcement! I’ve just farted in this broken elevator. Everyone, please excuse me.
context-en2: I thought this was an area where hunting was permitted.
context-en3: On Mondays, Tofugu workers are only allowed to wear clothes in subdued colors, like blue, light brown, and gray.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means permit so the verb vocab version is to permit. It also means to forgive, in that "I'll permit it this time... but only this time." Look out for ???? in TV shows, too. It means "I won't permit this!" or "I won't forgive you!"
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to allow it. You're (??) allowed to do it this one time, okay?

vocab-meaning: To Pick Out, To Take Out
context-en: A genius surgeon took out Koichi's brain and transplanted it into Viet.
context-en2: I saw a man in black clothes pick a wallet out of your bag, Michael.
context-en3: Can you take the blowfish out of the oven for me? I’ll be there in five minutes.
meaning-exp: To take something and then remove it, is when you reach in and grab something and choose it and pull it out. This is to pick out or to take out.
reading-exp: The readings come from the individual words ?? and ??. Put them together and you should be able to read this word too.

context-en: I prayed for the hurricane victims.
context-en2: I will pray for your success on the national exam.
context-en3: I don’t think many Japanese people know Japan’s national sport "sumo" used to be a ritual to pray for a bountiful rice harvest.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pray so the verb vocab version is to pray.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You gotta pray if you want Santa to bring you Christmas presents!" "I know (??), I know," you reply as you begin to pray to Santa. You should say this out loud to remember it better.

context-en: This is an autobiographical novel that Koichi wrote about his own forbidden love.
context-en2: The doctor forbade the pregnant woman from alcohol and cigarettes.
context-en3: In this room, whispering is prohibited.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prohibition so the verb version means to prohibit.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: The entire United States wept when they broke the news that Superman had died.
context-en2: I felt relieved when they reported that Koichi is safe.
context-en3: Tofugu covered an exclusive interview with Hatsune Miku.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means news report so you could try to say "to news report" but that doesn't make sense. What does make sense is "to report on," however.
reading-exp: The reading doesn't seem like it's the kanji's on'yomi reading, but it is. What an oddity! Do you think it's worth doing a news report on it? Koichi, reporting in on this strange reading that is readable by you right now. Signing off.

context-en: Please change the protagonist to Viet instead of Koichi and rewrite this story.
context-en2: I noticed that I wrote the examinee's number wrong at the very end of the exam period and rewrote it in rush.
context-en3: "Do you think we have enough time to rewrite this?" "I don’t think so."
meaning-exp: If you take your writing and fix it, you are taking your writing and rewriting it. This word means to rewrite, because the fixing is really heavy, so regular revisions won't do.
reading-exp: The readings come from ?? and ??. Know those and you'll know how to read this word too!

context-en: Could you not sit on the important documents?
context-en2: Koichi and Viet are always playing whoopee cushion pranks, so I'm always careful when I sit down on my office chair.
context-en3: When I’m sitting for a long time my butt gets sweaty.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sit so the verb vocab version is to sit.
reading-exp: The reading is unlike the kanji reading, so let's use a separate mnemonic to remember this. Just imagine yourself going to sit down. You sit down, and the ground collapses below you and you fall. When you land, you find yourself in a nasty, stinking sewer (??). It is so gross. Taste the sewage in your mouth. Smell it. Feel gross. You shouldn't have sat down on that spot, it was looking awfully dangerous, now that you think about it.

vocab-meaning: To Strike, To Beat, To Hit, To Knock
context-en: You have a talent for beating drums.
context-en2: Didn't I tell you to knock before opening the door?!
context-en3: Being hit with spiked bats really hurts!
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means strike or beat, so the verb version is to strike or to beat.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you're going to strike something over and over it makes a ta-ta (??) sound. Imagine you're about to beat a steel drum, for example. Now listen... ??! There! Did you hear it?

context-en: When you return home, please wash your hands and gargle.
context-en2: Viet is taking the day off today out of shock because his special jeans were washed by his girlfriend.
context-en3: Oh, we're using pre-washed rice, so you don’t need to wash it.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wash so the verb vocab version is to wash.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to wash a rock (??) you found. It looks shiny, but you can't tell until you wash it.

vocab-meaning: To Write In, To Fill In
context-en: If you could fill in your social security number here in this document, I can take care the rest.
context-en2: I wrote in my name on the marriage certificate.
context-en3: I want Koichi to make a Tofugu notebook so that we can write our Japanese study schedules in it.
meaning-exp: To insert what you write into something is to write in or to fill in.
reading-exp: The readings come from ?? and ???. Combine those two words to get the reading of this word.

context-en: We had a fire drill at the Tofugu office yesterday.
context-en2: We practiced how to use chopsticks at school today.
context-en3: I heard there's a secret organization that destroys Japanese language training camps.
meaning-exp: You've got your instruction and you have your practice. Time to start your training.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I was so busy I forgot to buy a train station bento.
context-en2: One fun thing to do during domestic trips in Japan is to compare various station bento.
context-en3: Oh, you forgot to bring the onigiri? We’ll have to buy a station bento for lunch.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is "bento"? Well, the ? in this word comes from that, so pretend it means "bento." Then, when you have a train station to go along with the bento, you have a train station bento. As you might think, a train station bento is just a bento that's sold at a train station. Easy!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm worried about whether what I wanted to say was conveyed properly.
context-en2: That's the only message I have.
context-en3: I’m researching the neural signal transmissions that occur while people are learning a new language.
meaning-exp: When you transmit something and you attain it on the other end, you've done a transmission.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: On one sunny, Tuesday morning, an old man with a white beard started talking to me while I was watering my flowers.
context-en2: I'm sorry, but I am busy next Monday and Tuesday.
context-en3: I got owned in baseball on Tuesday.
meaning-exp: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has ?? in it. But what day of the week is it? The fire day of the week is the day after the worst day of the week (monday). You set fire to everything because you're so pissed off about yesterday, which makes today Tuesday.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word ?? as well.

context-en: I advised him that he should pay back money he borrowed soon.
context-en2: That player gets a yellow card warning in every game.
context-en3: Do you intend to ignore this warning?
meaning-exp: When you announce something to warn somebody, you're warning them. Sometimes you're just trying to give them some helpful advice.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: We can split up what we have to do on Wednesday into three, big things.
context-en2: Every Wednesday after school I go to the pool and swim.
context-en3: He got drunk out of his mind Wednesday night and was run over by a truck.
meaning-exp: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has ?? in it. But what day of the week is it? The water day of the week is where the water flows from. Think of your entire week as a big hill, with Wednesday (hump day) being in the middle. This hump is a hill. What originates from hills? Water! That's why Water day is Wednesday.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word ?? as well.

vocab-meaning: Year End Party, End Of Year Party
context-en: As for what happened at today's year end party, I'll just let it go.
context-en2: I'm already really forgetful, so I don't need a so-called "forget the year party."
context-en3: In many Japanese companies, new workers are required to do a short performance at an end of the year party.
meaning-exp: Time to get together and forget the year... what a terrible year, good thing a new one is coming. This get together is a year end party.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The Zen meditation reached its climax there.
context-en2: I'd definitely love to experience Zen meditation when I travel to Kyoto.
context-en3: My friend is a monk and he does Zen meditation sessions in his temple. He told me that we could not only relax but also attain enlightenment and be free of desires and attachments with Zen meditation.
meaning-exp: When you sit and do zen you are probably doing zen meditation. Hummmmm.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The Zen priest literally understood the phrase "hunger is the best sauce."
context-en2: Although his efforts came to naught, the Zen priest did not feel upset in the slightest.
context-en3: If you want to be a Zen priest, you have to go through ridiculously tough training.
meaning-exp: A Zen priest is a zen priest.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What's the name of that Zen temple, again?
context-en2: I read somewhere that that Zen temple invested in the stocks of a company with excessive liabilities and they had a dreadful experience.
context-en3: The Tenryu-ji is a Zen temple I like that was built in the 14th century in western Kyoto.
meaning-exp: A zen temple is just what it sounds like, a zen temple. Sounds nice.
reading-exp: The reading is the two words ? and ? put together. The ?? gets changed to ??, though. In terms of when it's pronounced ???, if you put this word onto the end of the name of a ?? the pronunciation changes to ???. It makes sense - it's more like a jukugo word that way (not that the original isn't, but you can see the separation of words coming together which gives the hint that it's a kun'yomi combo reading). Anyways, you may need a zen temple to keep your mind pure enough to remember this, but it's a good thing to keep in mind if you can.

vocab-meaning: Academic History, Academic Background, Academic Record
context-en: Japan and Korea are academic background oriented societies, but isn't America like that?
context-en2: There are praiseworthy people who've had very little academic history.
context-en3: "Hey, mom! I got a perfect score on my test again." "So what? Do you really believe a person’s academic record is everything?"
meaning-exp: A continuation of studying is the time that passes that we study. This is academic history, so pay close attention!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Adjectives can be separated into three categories: na-adjectives, i-adjectives, and no-adjectives.
context-en2: I can't come up with a good adjective that can depict this situation well.
context-en3: At the job interview, I had to choose the most suitable adjective to describe myself, and explain why.
meaning-exp: A part of speech that creates the shape and form of a word is something that is descriptive (its shape and form are in there, after all!). This shape and form part of speech is an adjective. You are so beautiful!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Aiueo Order, In Aiueo Order, Syllabary Order
context-en: The town names are listed in aiueo order.
context-en2: In this list, the students’ names are placed in aiueo order by surname.
context-en3: The first Japanese dictionary arranged in Japanese syllabary order was the "Wakun no shiori."
meaning-exp: This is a little confusing for someone who didn't grow up with the Japanese language. You have fifty sounds. Then, they're in a certain order. So, these fifty sounds are the Japanese syllabary. That's hiragana / katakana, probably from back in the day when there were more sounds than there are now. So, the "fifty sounds in order" makes up aiueo order, where the "aiueo" is ????? representing the five columns.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Aren't you forgetting that I have an aversion to hot foods?
context-en2: I'm sorry. I can't eat hot things.
context-en3: Koichi doesn’t like hot food, so he can’t eat soup without blowing on it. Is this true or false?
meaning-exp: A cat's tongue is for some reason associated with an aversion to hot foods. I guess I haven't seen a cat drinking up boiling milk, but whatever. Just imagine a cat licking up something super hot and freaking out. Cats don't like hot things, which is why this is an aversion to hot foods.
reading-exp: The reading is the two vocab words separately put together, just as you'd expect from a body-part related kanji. So, ? plus ? = ????. Just remember that ? is read here as ??, and not ??.

context-en: The number of Tofugu believers exceeded 10,000.
context-en2: Did you know Korea has more Christian followers than Buddhist followers?
context-en3: My grandfather was a devout follower of the Aum Shinrikyo religious cult.
meaning-exp: A junior believer is a believer or follower. They certainly aren't the leader or anything because of their junior status, but at least they're there, and at least they're believing. Oh, and excuse me, may I take a moment of your time? I'd like to tell you about the glory that is the Crabigator....
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Would you like a booklet of bargain coupons?
context-en2: What's there to gain from doing something like that?
context-en3: I believe that having good looks is absolutely an advantage.
meaning-exp: When you are able to acquire whatever you want, you start to see the benefits of everything around you and begin to profit from them. Aren't you so amazing?
reading-exp: The reading for this is the same as with the kanji you learned. ??!

context-en: My mom reminded me not to forget my blanket.
context-en2: Can you put the blanket in the cardboard box?
context-en3: I can’t imagine myself washing one hundred blankets every day.
meaning-exp: A fur cloth isn't something you'd just throw away. You'd probably turn this warm fur cloth into a nice blanket.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Book Counter, Counter For Books, Books, Counter for Volumes
context-en: The city library has over 33,300 volumes.
context-en2: I wanted to give the book to my friends too, so I bought ten copies.
context-en3: Excuse me, I’m having trouble hearing you. Did you say how many Japanese textbooks you want?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as well. It's probably treated like on'yomi jukugo because it's attached to things (like numbers!).

context-en: Buddhists feel ashamed because there are a lot of Christians in this country.
context-en2: I happened to see that Buddhist stick her tongue out at the statue of Buddha and say, “Bleh.”
context-en3: If Japanese people are mostly Buddhists, why do they celebrate Christmas in Japan?
meaning-exp: You know ?? means “Buddhism” so a follower of Buddhism is a Buddhist.
reading-exp: Add the on’yomi reading for ? to the word you already know. Done!

context-en: I've been tired because of how busy I've been lately, and it's been making me tongue tied.
context-en2: I lead a busy life.
context-en3: I know how busy you are, and I feel terrible asking this, but would you mind saving my place in line for a few minutes?
meaning-exp: If you've had many busy days, then you're even more busy than you thought!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I'm so busy that my head is spinning.
context-en2: Don't expect a quick email response from Koichi, as he is really busy.
context-en3: Today was hectic. Just today, we learned 1000 new Japanese words.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of busy? It's also busy.
reading-exp: You're busy because you have to take care of your friend's ice ogres (???) this weekend. You don't know why you agreed to this, you were busy enough, but now you'll never get anything done running around taking care of these little ice ogres.

context-en: Michael gave me a detailed explanation about the relationship between Viet and the yakuza in chronological order.
context-en2: Should we make a list of our articles in chronological order?
context-en3: See this timetable for the detailed chronological accounts, please.
meaning-exp: You put years in order of the period they come in and you're really putting them in chronological order.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Can you change out this cloth for a new one?
context-en2: The cloth got caught in my zipper and it won't move right.
context-en3: I’ve heard that cloth diapers are better for your health than disposable ones.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You take your cloth and put it on top of your head. It's there because right at noon (??) the sun is in the middle of the sky and burns your scalp. So, you cover it with a cloth. Imagine yourself setting an alarm for noon to help you to focus on the noon part.

context-en: It seems my son has been keeping bad company, so I'm a bit worried.
context-en2: You shouldn't get close to a group of drunks.
context-en3: Those guys always have nothing but stupid conversations.
meaning-exp: People you want to take along to the middle of somewhere are probably people you know pretty well. They're your colleagues, they keep you company. These guys, am I right?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

context-en: The culprit escaped in the confusion.
context-en2: The wildfire brought utter chaos to the town.
context-en3: I’m afraid that your half-baked policy may cause confusion among the new employees.
meaning-exp: There's a riot and everything's getting all mixed up! Within that, there is of course a ton of confusion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The Tofugu team paid close attention to the content of Koichi's speech.
context-en2: While it seems like there is, there's never any substance to Koichi's presentations.
context-en3: Some of Tofugu's fans are well known for being relentless about substance and accuracy.
meaning-exp: Inside that form... there is something inside there. What are the contents?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The fisherman compared the two fish.
context-en2: Japanese life and American life aren't a good comparison.
context-en3: Who took the picture of Koichi’s nose? I really love the contrast between the light and the shadows.
meaning-exp: You're comparing something to another thing, each versus one another. When you do that, you look at both sides. You contrast each and then you come up with a comparison.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It's not good to take out debt if you don't know how to pay it back.
context-en2: Is it true that Tofugu has a large amount of debt?
context-en3: After Fugu’s assassination, it became clear that the only thing he left behind for Salmon was debt.
meaning-exp: The wealth you borrow is your debt.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Make sure you remember ?? over ??, though. Why? Because you got all this debt trying to buy your way into Zion.

vocab-meaning: Decreasing Order, Descending Order, Largest First
context-en: Our kid eats everything starting with the largest first.
context-en2: Arrange the following countries in decreasing order by area.
context-en3: We lined up the pictures of the models faces, largest first.
meaning-exp: When the order is from big (to small), you are talking about decreasing order. That's largest first.
reading-exp: The reading is the word ??? plus ?'s reading you learned with the kanji.

context-en: Then, finely chop this cabbage please.
context-en2: I only have small change.
context-en3: You can’t see the wood for the trees. Don’t just focus on the details, look at the bigger picture.
meaning-exp: Remember ?? and how it means "thin." Well, this is another adjective that comes from the kanji ? with a similar but different meaning (sorry!). If you think about something that's very thin, though, there isn't much surface area. In order to use this very thin thing (say, to put your favorite model railroad on) you have to zoom way in and get incredibly detailed with it. It's super small and fine, so get your magnifying lens out! You can remember that this one is "detailed" or "fine" because the ?? makes you think of coyotes. You put a ton of work into this detailed and fine model railroad on a very thin piece of land. Then, a coyote comes in and trashes it all, because you made the mistake of making it out of meat.
reading-exp: This word has a different reading from the ones you've learned so far (sorry), so here's a mnemonic to help you: After the coyote wrecks your pretty train things he bites you on the head, sending you into an indefinite coma (??).

context-en: All of the drama troupe members were sweating after practice.
context-en2: My goal is to join the Shiki Theater Company.
context-en3: I started to like an actor who belongs to a theater troupe from watching a drama, so I started going to the theater to watch his shows.
meaning-exp: A drama group is a drama troupe.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I know I'm a rookie, but I don't like only being assigned to simple jobs.
context-en2: We can easily expect that this will happen, can't we?
context-en3: Learning Japanese isn’t easy. You have to work really hard.
meaning-exp: The form in front of you is easy. Whatever it is, you'll be able to do it with ease.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Slicing meat very thin isn't a simple thing to do.
context-en2: It was easy for Koichi to maintain his delicate skin.
context-en3: During exams, I like solving the easy questions first.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of easy? It's also easy.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everything is so easy for you to do. Why? Because you don't do anything yourself. You ask others. You say things like "Hey, can you get me some water?" They say "yassah!" (??) very enthusiastically.

context-en: Because there are eight students, we will need eight textbooks.
context-en2: I have no money and I can't buy a chair, so I use eight books as a chair instead.
context-en3: I won’t call myself a fiction writer after only publishing eight books. If I publish fifty books, then I’ll call myself that.
meaning-exp: When you have eight books you have eight books. This is an example of how to count books, so if you have eight of them this is what you'd say.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ?? part gets shortened as it often does when put into situations like this, making it ??. The ? is all normal, and to the "book(s)." Har!

context-en: You will see the emergency exit when you turn left at that corridor.
context-en2: When you think of a place where bad high schoolers skip classes and procrastinate, it would be the staircases under the emergency exit, right?
context-en3: After putting Aya’s drawing under his coat, the thief slipped out through the emergency exit.
meaning-exp: You know how ?? means emergency and how ? can be some kind of doorway (like in ???, for example)? Well, if that's the case, then you have an emergency doorway. Usually you run away from emergencies, though, making this an emergency exit.
reading-exp: The reading is the words ?? and ? combined together. The thing that makes this weird is that it's a mix of the kun and on'yomi readings. I guess things get all jostled up when you have yourself an emergency.

vocab-meaning: Every Day, Day After Day, For Days On End, Daily, Prolonged
context-en: I was driving my car every day and the tires wore out.
context-en2: Every day at this time I get sleepy.
context-en3: This festival has had a great turnout day after day.
meaning-exp: What happens when you take along a day? It becomes every day.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The flute was entangled in the vines.
context-en2: My mom bought this dove flute for me at a festival.
context-en3: That guy holding the whistle is Mr. Koichi.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Pretend you're trying to whistle, but you can't. All that comes out is air. You make a "Fuuuuuuueh" sound over and over, because you can't get the whole whistling thing down. Go ahead and pretend to do that (or do it for real).

context-en: I'm totally fed up with politicians' duplicitous policies.
context-en2: He has a forked tongue, so you should be careful.
context-en3: True or False Quiz: In order to get the money for a life-sized Hatsune Miku doll, Viet used his forked tongue to cheat Koichi. True or false?
meaning-exp: You have two flat objects that make up your tongue. What kind of tongue is made up of two of anything? That's a tongue that's split, that's a forked tongue.
