reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that ? is read here as ??, and not ??.

context-en: I think I can see some improvements in the quality of this bedding.
context-en2: I am so embarrassed, I want to bury myself under a futon.
context-en3: I’m getting sick of these futon salespeople. Can’t they understand that if I don’t buy something after several visits, that I’m never going to buy it? So annoying.
meaning-exp: This one's a little weird. You have a group of cloth. Think about this. If you group together a bunch of cloth into one big cloth, you have something nice and soft. What can you use this nice and soft cloth things for? Well, you can sleep on it. This is the Japanese word futon, which you may have heard in English before (though the Japanese futon is quite different from the American one). You can also translate this to bedding or sleeping mat too.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for ? is the secondary reading that went with the kanji, though, so watch out for that. If you can figure out the meaning of this word, chances are you already know how to spell it, so carry that over to Japanese.

vocab-meaning: Good And Evil, Right and Wrong
context-en: Distinguishing between good and evil is difficult, even for adults.
context-en2: After hitting one year old, she started understanding what is right and what is wrong.
context-en3: He's just a baby, so he still doesn’t know the difference between right and wrong.
meaning-exp: You have morally good and bad. This is the battle between good and evil.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Good At, Skilled At, Strong Point, Specialty, Forte
context-en: What is your specialty dish?
context-en2: Darin is more skilled at mountain climbing than programming.
context-en3: Neither Koichi nor Viet is any good with salsa.
meaning-exp: When you're able to acquire ideas at a fast rate, you must be familiar with whatever it is you're doing. If you acquire ideas in this way, there's a good chance you're good at or skilled at this action.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This explanation about grammar particles omits some details.
context-en2: I learned how to use postpositions at school today, but I'm still so confused.
context-en3: In Japanese grammar, one of the most difficult things to master is particles.
meaning-exp: A part of speech that's just meant to help your grammar out are the little things. They tie grammar and words together, and that's about it. These are grammar particles or just plain old particles.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm not good at acting in a group.
context-en2: If you go to that country, you have to be careful about terrorist groups.
context-en3: Koichi broke out ahead of the crowd at the end of the race and won the Honolulu Marathon.
meaning-exp: A group that has collected together is a bunch of people. It is a group or crowd.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You'll benefit from studying history in the future.
context-en2: Around that time, I wanted to be a high school history teacher.
context-en3: Let me give you a brief explanation of Tofugu’s history.
meaning-exp: The continuation of history is history itself. This is the main word for "history" and you'll see it a lot if you're in school or something.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I think there's still room for improvement on this painting.
context-en2: Koichi has been trying to improve Tofugu's constitution.
context-en3: If you have any suggestions for the improvement of our site, please contact us.
meaning-exp: When you renew something and it ends up morally good it's definitely an improvement.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Increasing Order, Ascending Order, Smallest First
context-en: Excuse me, but could you hand out the payments in ascending order?
context-en2: If we line up the Tofugu employees in ascending order by mouth size, I'm sure I'll end up being first.
context-en3: Fill in the grid, and rearrange the numbers to put them in ascending order.
meaning-exp: When something goes from small and goes in order it's in increasing order, or smallest first.
reading-exp: The reading is the word ??? plus the reading for ?.

context-en: The potential form of the intransitive verb "to advance" is "something advances."
context-en2: One of the things I really dread is using transitive and intransitive verbs properly.
context-en3: You can easily judge if it's an intransitive verb or a transitive verb when you think about whether or not you can change it to the passive form.
meaning-exp: An automatic part of speech is an intransitive verb. Intransitive verbs are actions that just happen, aka you're not the one doing the action or thing. These are words like ?? or ???, where you aren't doing the action. That's why they're automatic!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This service is clunky. It's about time for some improvements.
context-en2: How have you stayed married to such an irresponsible man for twenty years? I can't believe it.
context-en3: Hey, Dad. Don’t you think it’s time for mom to stop being manipulated by pointless gossip from idly chatting with the neighbors?
meaning-exp: You add and you subtract. This brings you back to zero. There was absolutely no point in doing those actions. Completely pointless. In fact, I'd say that was downright irresponsible of you. The extra ?? is there to mean "good," as in "good, you've figured out how pointless that was, now stop."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The application for the enrollment was printed in small type.
context-en2: You won't gain anything out of joining that religious organization.
context-en3: The Tofugu baseball team will hold tryouts at the Tofugu office on Friday, October 23rd.
meaning-exp: If you enter a group you are going to join or enlist.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Joy, Delight, Glee, Rapture, Pleasure, Satisfaction, Gratification, Rejoicing, Congratulations
context-en: Nikka expresses joy by wagging her tail.
context-en2: Koichi beamed with delight as he officially launched WaniKani at last.
context-en3: I’m looking for a funny kaomoji to express my joy.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji rejoice, so it means joy and delight. You rejoice because there are lots of reasons for your glee.
reading-exp: You already learned this reading when you learned ?? so you should be able to read this one too!

vocab-meaning: Konbu, Kombu, Konbu Seaweed, Kombu Seaweed
context-en: I made broth with kombu.
context-en2: Please tell me the difference between wakame seaweed and konbu seaweed.
context-en3: "How dare you throw konbu seaweed at me!" "I’m sorry. I didn’t think it would be that big of a deal."
meaning-exp: This one is pretty weird. The cloth of our descendants is konbu. This is a type of seaweed that is very common in Japan. It is used in foods and in broths. It is everywhere, and delicious. If you're not familiar with it already this may be a hard word to learn, but I believe in you. Maybe if you read up on konbu for a bit it will help you to remember your descendants' cloth.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? part gets changed to ?, probably because if a food doesn't have konbu you say boo (?).

context-en: My boyfriend has a discerning palate and is very particular about what he eats.
context-en2: The meanings for "significant other" and "lover" are totally different, so please don't mix them up.
context-en3: "My girlfriend and I broke up last month." "It’s okay, you’ll find someone better."
meaning-exp: A person of romance is someone you do romancey things with. That person is your lover.
reading-exp: The reading is a bit strange. it's the two separate words ? and ? put together, making the reading ????. Oooh lala. Two words coming together like two people coming together. Rawrs.

context-en: That game was a free for all that we don't see very often.
context-en2: A melee occurred in the audience due to Koichi's speech.
context-en3: On the first day of the sale, the mall became super crowded, like it was some kind of battle royal.
meaning-exp: A riot of war is where things go nuts. This is a melee! A free for all!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi's radio-controlled helicopter crashed on the ground after hovering in midair.
context-en2: I like the face Koichi makes when he takes bills out of his pockets and throws them into the air.
context-en3: That problem is still up in the air and nobody tries to discuss it.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: It's rare for animals to mix breeds with one another.
context-en2: Koichi is a mix of Japanese and American.
context-en3: Apparently, one in thirty newborn Japanese babies is of mixed parentage.
meaning-exp: If you have mixed blood, some people might say you're of mixed race. Own it!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Can this noun be a no-adjective?
context-en2: Is this a countable or uncountable noun?
context-en3: You can’t use proper nouns in this game.
meaning-exp: A name part of speech is when you are naming something. What part of speech has names in it? That would be the noun.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Nuclear Power, Nuclear Energy, Atomic Power, Atomic Energy
context-en: We are talking about whether nuclear power is good or not right now. Don't try to confuse us with irrelevant facts.
context-en2: My dad used to work at a nuclear power plant.
context-en3: Koichi made a nuclear-powered Tofugu robot to fight Godzilla.
meaning-exp: The power of the atom (??) is nuclear power.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm panicking a bit because there are so many number words in Japanese.
context-en2: How did you memorize numerals, Koichi?
context-en3: I wish there was a game that could help me study Japanese numerals.
meaning-exp: A number part of speech is a numeral or number word.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: One After Another, Successively, In Succession
context-en: Employees came out of the office exit, one after another.
context-en2: There are a lot of people subscribing to WaniKani, one after another, and we're happy about it, but we're having some issues with it as well.
context-en3: I can’t wait for the day when new words pop up one after another on WaniKani.
meaning-exp: When you continue and then you continue again (that's the repeater kanji), you get things happening one after another. Continue continue continue!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This magazine costs 480 yen for one volume.
context-en2: Only one copy of this particular picture book exists in the world.
context-en3: I bought you a book to read during your trip. The title is "Map."
meaning-exp: When you have one books you really just have one book.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? portion gets shortened to ?? as it often is.

context-en: Koichi replies to his emails in order.
context-en2: I'm waiting for my turn to pay at the grocery store at the moment.
context-en3: Don't push and wait your turn, please!
meaning-exp: When you go in order of turns that's the order. It also represents one's turn in said order as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Her tongue lolled out and she passed out during the orgy.
context-en2: Hey, it's about time you quit it with the promiscuity, you've been putting everybody off.
context-en3: "I look so good today, I may be asked to join an orgy." "Haha. You wish!"
meaning-exp: A big mix of folks forming a kind of riot. You'd think this would be something more violent, but it's really just an orgy. Lots of mixing, I guess, and not very much organization on the orgy-organizer's part, at least according to this kanji sequence.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm getting sick of space life.
context-en2: What do you think there is at the end of universe?
context-en3: Fugu, Salmon doesn’t know that you wanna get back together. If she did, she might feel differently. She might not even go to space to see the moon with a different fish.
meaning-exp: The midair of outer space is the space that's in outer space which is outer space, space, and the universe!

context-en: Umeboshi is good for motion sickness.
context-en2: Umeboshi can be mixed with anything.
context-en3: Excuse me. May I get through? I’d like to buy that jar of pickled plums.
meaning-exp: This is a food pretty specific to Japan, making it a slightly weird one to learn. You have a Japanese Plum. Then you have dry. So when the Japanese plum is dried, it's not a dried plum (that would be too easy), it is a pickled plum or pickled ume. If you know the name of this food, you can call it by that too: umeboshi.
reading-exp: The reading for this one, like the meaning, is kind of strange. It's the kun'yomi readings, so apologies in advance for that. You have ?? plus ??, which comes from ?? though the ? is stuffed inside the ? for some reason. It's also rendaku'd. Basically, everything is all screwed up, so you know, deal with it. This food is awesome, and common, so you have to learn it. I guess the pickling process has mangled the reading of this word. At least it tastes good.

meaning-exp: This is a tough one. When you compare examples (in this case of numbers) you are figuring out the proportion / ratio. A ratio, for example, has one number on top of another. They are examples being compared. Same with proportions. Without two things to compare, proportion doesn't make sense. That's why when you compare examples, you are dealing with proportions or ratios.

vocab-meaning: Really, As Was Expected, Just As I Thought, As Expected

context-en3: I thought I might be able to meet Koichi at the cafe, and sure enough, I did.
meaning-exp: So this doesn't really make much sense in terms of the kanji and word, but it is what it is. Let's remember it this way: The kanji is fruit so the meaning is really? Like, really really? Because it sounds like you made that up. I really doubt it means really. It can also mean as was expected or just as I thought, but usually we use it as a way to say, "Really? I don't really believe you..."
reading-exp: To remember the reading, just imagine yourself snorting out a sharp "HA!" (?) right before saying the phrase: "HA! Just as I thought."

vocab-meaning: To Acquire, To Gain, To Obtain
context-en: Although Koichi lost everything, he was able to gain a best friend in Viet.
context-en2: It's not easy to obtain one's trust.
context-en3: I got a lot out of my experience teaching English in Japan.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means acquire so the verb vocab version is to acquire.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to acquire an elephant (?) for your elephant collection. If you don't acquire an elephant, you'll look like an idiot in front of your elephant collecting friends.

context-en: All I did was ask the store employee to break my 10,000 bill and he suddenly freaked out at me.
context-en2: I've only seen Fugu get that angry and act violently once.
context-en3: Viet got drunk and disorderly, but Koichi managed to calm him down.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means violence. "To violence" doesn't sound great, so instead this word is to act violently or to rage.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about to rage all over the place. You're going nuts. You're going to act violently. Then, a calm wizard steps in front of you and mutters "abara kadabara," (??) causing you to calm down immediately.

context-en: Please add two cups of milk and stir slowly.
context-en2: Can you include Koichi-kun in your group too?
context-en3: I added a pinch of salt to the dish President Obama made.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means add so the verb vocab version would be to add.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You hold a Christmas party every year. This year, instead of just Christmas you have to add other winter holidays to the mix so people don't get upset. First up? Kwanzaa (??).

vocab-meaning: To Be Decreased, To Get Decreased, To Decrease

context-en2: WaniKani sales decreased by 5% this month.
context-en3: My right shoe always gets worn down at the heels faster than my left one.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decrease so the verb vocab version is to be decreased.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your status is to be decreased amongst the eyes of the Gods. They decide your punishment is to be decreased into hell (??) where you will live the rest of your days.

vocab-meaning: To Be Entangled, To Be Tangled, To Pick A Fight, To Be Involved With, To Get Entangled
context-en: I hate people who get drunk and then pick fights.
context-en2: My hair got tangled around the button and I can't get it out.
context-en3: Oh no! Sticky bubblegum got tangled around my fishing line! How can I get it out?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means entangle so the verb vocab version is to be entangled. This is when something is entangled on its own (you're not directly doing the entangling). You can remember this because of the ?, which is you saying move (?) out of the way, I have to take care of this entanglement mess that just happened on its own.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The entanglement mess you're fixing is a couple of kids that got their hair tangled up. They were doing some sparring in their ??? class and one thing led to the other and suddenly both their hair was entangled together.

vocab-meaning: To Be In Disorder, To Be In Disarray, To Be Disordered, To Be Disturbed
context-en: School morals are in disarray these days.
context-en2: The Tofugu employees must perform a dance without getting disheveled in front of Koichi.
context-en3: After his divorce from Salmon, Fugu's life was in disarray.
meaning-exp: The kanji means riot, but this verb version word doesn't really mean "to riot." It's more like to be in disorder. But if you think about it, when things are rioting and crazy, they definitely are in disorder, so you can think of it that way. You can differentiate this from the future word ?? because with ?? you know it is rare for it to be like this. You aren't doing it, but it just happens on occasion (rarely) so you take advantage of it.
reading-exp: When everything is in disorder it's finally your chance! You run to the bar, break the windows, and grab all the mead (??) you can carry.

vocab-meaning: To Be Renewed, To Be Formal, To Be Altered, To Be Revised
context-en: The Japanese era name was altered to Tofugu.
context-en2: Koichi was very happy to see that Viet had reformed himself from his evil way of life.
context-en3: Don’t be so formal! President Koichi is very friendly.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means renew so the verb vocab version is to be renewed. You're not doing the renewing directly, it's just happening (as renewing often does).
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To be renewed you decide to go to a spa. You get in a bathtub and they pour in a lotta (???) leeches and eels to help you to be renewed. Feel the fear. There are a lot of them! Alternatively, you can imagine them pouring in a lotta Maru cats, because that's way fuzzier.

reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Look at this cooler (??). No look at this cooler. No, wait, we need to compare the two coolers. Think about all the features each one has and really compare, like you have a list or something.

vocab-meaning: To Get Mixed, To Be Mixed, To Be Blended With

meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb vocab version is to get mixed or to be mixed. This is when something is just getting mixed and you're not directly doing the action of mixing anything. You can remember this because the Tzar (??) of Russia is very impressed that things mix on their own and you're not doing the mixing. The connotation for this word is you can't distinguish the things you're mixing, like combining paints, which become one mixed color that isn't two separate colors anymore.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're not doing the mixing, in order for things to get mixed you call your ma (?) up and ask her to mix it. What a terrible lazy child you are.
