context-en3: No, thank you. I burned my tongue last night, so I don’t want to drink any coffee.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Uses the same reading that you learned with the kanji. Go ahead and use your tongue and say the reading out loud... "??."

vocab-meaning: To Put On Shoes, To Put On Pants, To Put On Boots
context-en: I wore yukata and put on some geta.
context-en2: Don't put sneakers on without socks! The sneakers will stink. How many times do I have to tell you this?
context-en3: Did you know that people started wearing high heels in order to avoid stepping on poop in the streets?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boots, but "to boots" doesn't make sense. What actions do you do with boots, though, usually? You put them on. That's why this word is to put on shoes (or boots, I guess). It's also to put on pants, probably because it's all kind of the same motion, no?
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to put on shoes. That will teach Mrs. Chou and her streets! "HA (?) HA HA!" you laugh out loud like a maniac.

vocab-meaning: To Take Along, To Bring With, To Bring A Person, To Lead, To Be Accompanied By
context-en: Koichi was accompanied by a woman.
context-en2: I remember my mom used to take me along to the support center.
context-en3: We have no choice but to take Fugu to the animal shelter.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means take along so the verb vocab version is to take along.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What are you going to take along? Whoa. That much? Why in the world do you have two (?) of everything?

vocab-meaning: Total Failure, Huge Mistake, Big Mistake, Debacle, Massive Failure, Epic Fail
context-en: I made the big mistake of farting during the silence.
context-en2: Our idea of having Mami watch Koichi's bacon was a total failure. She ate every single piece.
context-en3: In the meeting yesterday, Shark really made a huge mistake. I think he might lose his position.
meaning-exp: You know how ?? is a mistake? Well, a large mistake is going to be a total failure or a huge mistake. So terrible!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know ?? on its own as well.

context-en: I can't help but unconsciously tongue the cavity in my tooth with the tip of my tongue.
context-en2: That involuntary habit of biting your nails should be fixed.
context-en3: We’re awesome because we can be unconsciously creative.
meaning-exp: Know how ?? is "consciousness"? What about when this consciousness doesn't exist (aka it is nothing)? That's when it becomes unconsciousness.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read ??, though.

context-en: English is a "subject-verb-object" language.
context-en2: What is your favorite verb in Japanese?
context-en3: If you had to choose one verb to describe yourself, which verb would it be?
meaning-exp: A part of speech that represents moving is a part of speech that describes actions. That is a verb.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Strawberries are out of season now, so they are very expensive.
context-en2: The tongue is an exceedingly important speech organ.
context-en3: President Koichi’s approval ratings are extremely high.
meaning-exp: When something is moving towards emergency (??), it is something that is very, extremely bad. Like, exceedingly so. It's nuts.
reading-exp: The reading comes straight from the word ??, which you hopefully know okay by now!

context-en: I hate violent people!
context-en2: That man got arrested for assaulting a girl.
context-en3: "Dad, my friend says I’m violent." "So what? Who cares what he thinks? Just beat the stupid guy up!"
meaning-exp: Riot and violence. That sounds terrible! That sounds like a place full of violence, because rioting is violent and violence is violent too!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi took away my tamagotchi by force.
context-en2: I couldn't stand the domestic violence, so I left home.
context-en3: Do you really think that parents should limit their children's exposure to violent movies and video games?
meaning-exp: The power of violence is more violence, and it is a force to be reckoned with.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: In Korea, it's customary to have wakame soup on your birthday.
context-en2: I'm busy so I simply made dressed wakame and cucumber.
context-en3: My mom made a miso soup with wakame seaweed and tofu. Do you want some?
meaning-exp: A young cloth for some reason is the seaweed wakame. If you've never heard of wakame before, go look it up. It's delicious and really good for you. Seaweed is kind of like cloth in the sea, right? Well, this young cloth is nice and soft and thin, like wakame. I imagine young people are soft and thin too, which is why the young cloth gets to be wakame.
reading-exp: The reading doesn't make any sense, except for how ?? has ?? in it. If you can figure out the meaning, though, you can use that to remember the reading (since they're the same).

context-en: I forgot my wallet at home, but that saved me ten dollars.
context-en2: My mother follows fengshui and replaces her purse every year.
context-en3: "Hold up! You dropped your wallet!" "Thank you, but what would you do if I said I dropped it on purpose?"
meaning-exp: Your wealth cloth is your wallet. Really, a wallet is just a piece of cloth you keep in your pocket that has your wealth in it, right? This can also be your purse, especially if you live in the ol' UK.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The instructions for the ice cream maker I bought yesterday were missing.
context-en2: When you play a new game, are you the type of person who reads the instructions first or do you start playing without reading them?
context-en3: We are currently looking for someone who can translate some instructions written in Japanese into English.
meaning-exp: An explanation (??) in writing is a written explanation. I guess sometimes you don't want to do your explanations in person, huh?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Viet made a considerable profit on a black market deal when he was young.
context-en2: Koichi studied in Japan when he was young.
context-en3: You do realize that young woman is way out of your league, right?
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of young? It's young.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Oh how nice it is to be young and to be able to remember that.

context-en: That young person was observing cicadas very closely in the park.
context-en2: Apparently that young person's money is involved in this matter.
context-en3: This young man is terrific. You should get his autograph before he becomes a big-shot.
meaning-exp: A young someone is a young person.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is a pain. ? is the same as what you learned with the kanji (??), but ? is ??, which isn't what you learned. Think of this: A young person does what they want. They don't follow tradition or do anything the way you'd want them to, just like the reading of this word. Also, their actions make you really want to moan (??) because ugh, young people. Get off my lawn.

context-en: Koichi's really had his youthful appearance forever.
context-en2: Don't you think that type of fashion is a bit too young looking for you?
context-en3: My Grandmother is in her nineties and she looks younger than some people in their sixties. She says that feeling young and chewing foods a lot are two big secrets to her youth.
meaning-exp: A young young thing has youthfulness on their side. Oh to be youthful again!
reading-exp: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Same goes for the repeater kanji.

context-en: The accomplice was indeed like a bug that flew into the fire in summer.
context-en2: There is high probability that the accomplice has already fled the country.
context-en3: He was a really wonderful criminal who could easily get out of the most dangerous situations by himself. He boasted that he would never need an accomplice.
meaning-exp: Someone who does crime together with you is your accomplice in crime. It's best to "take care of these" before the coppers get to him/her.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi doesn't know the accurate number of WaniKani users.
context-en2: Michael completed his mission to memorize Koichi's lunch request perfectly and order it.
context-en3: Actually, I’m pretty annoyed at how you have a comeback for everything and how what you say is so accurate.
meaning-exp: It is correct and you're certain of it. When you've done this much checking and you're this sure, your measurements must be very accurate and precise.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The aftershocks are still coming so we need to be careful.
context-en2: How many aftershocks have you felt today?
context-en3: The earthquake was followed by aftershocks.
meaning-exp: A surplus (that's an extra!) earthquake is a quake that comes after the main (non-surplus) quake. That's an aftershock.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I've already booked the airplane tickets.
context-en2: I was super excited when Koichi sat down next to me on the plane.
context-en3: I dislike airplanes, so I would never be able to go to Japan.
meaning-exp: The fly and go machine is some machine you get into that flies and goes places. It's an airplane.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: On my answering machine, I got a message from Koichi saying he's flying to Hawaii tomorrow.
context-en2: He challenged me to a debate on my answering machine.
context-en3: I've been calling the Tofugu office over and over again, but I always get the answering machine.
meaning-exp: You hopefully know that this has something to do with housesitting (???). So, a telephone (??) that does housesitting for you is what? It's your answering machine.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
kanji-name: Detain, Protect, Number In A Series, Electricity, Talk

context-en: Koichi's father's specialty is cultural anthropology.
context-en2: In order to get along with the African ethnic group that she wants to research, she started interacting with the villagers naked.
context-en3: I wonder why your sister wanted to take an anthropology course.
meaning-exp: The study of mankind (??) is known as anthropology.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi and the others are discussing whether we should take a plane or a boat to Japan.
context-en2: The article that Michael wrote drew controversy.
context-en3: Koichi and Viet argued on what to eat for dinner for hours without reaching a decision.
meaning-exp: There is much deliberation and theory exchanging when you are trying to present an argument. Of course, it's a very nice one. Lots of thinking and stuff, you know? That's why there's deliberation and theories instead of just screaming. That kind of "argument."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When I learned my company would go bankrupt, I looked up at the sky and saw a beautiful contrail.
context-en2: That company is under suspicion of bankruptcy.
context-en3: Last year there were more than a hundred bankruptcies in this city alone.
meaning-exp: Say you give birth to a baby. Then, after that everything falls apart and your life is overthrown. You lose it all because of this baby (babies are expensive). When you have your baby and everything is overthrown, you yourself are thrown into bankruptcy.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Let's not play the blame game because we are both old and our blood pressure might go up.
context-en2: I am having trouble getting up in the morning because I have low blood pressure. When I had my blood pressure taken today, it was 85 over 30. Can you do something for me, Dr. Koichi?
context-en3: When I told my doctor that I still have high blood pressure, even after taking blood pressure meds, he told me the importance of reducing stress to control it.
meaning-exp: Check the pressure of your blood. It's your blood pressure.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Regardless of what you say, there's still a possibility that we won't be able to find a tenant, right?
context-en2: When we advertised that Koichi used to live here, the house went right away.
context-en3: That apartment still doesn’t have any tenants because it’s rumored to be haunted.
meaning-exp: The hand who borrows is the borrower.
reading-exp: You'll want to know the words ??? and ? to be able to read this one. Combine them to know the reading.

context-en: You need to be patient if you want to shoot a deer with a bow and arrow.
context-en2: That night, my parents discussed whether or not to sell the bow and arrow.
context-en3: We used to use bows and arrows for hunting rabbits.
meaning-exp: A bow and an arrow. Put them together and you have a bow and arrow.
reading-exp: The reading is the vocab readings, ? and ?, put together. This is probably because this word is like two separate words put together, thus the "and" in the middle of the English translation.

context-en: When I go to high places, my butt itches.
context-en2: There's nothing in the world that's cuter than a baby's butt.
context-en3: I bet most Japanese people have never heard of a birthday spanking.
meaning-exp: The ? is just there to be nice to your butt. This word simply means butt.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: I'm certain I saw Koichi fly about one hundred meters with my own eyes.
context-en2: It seems like it might be difficult to operate this machine.
context-en3: Tofugu has certainly delivered a one-two punch to the traditional Japanese language learning industry.
meaning-exp: This is an adverb, but it has the same meaning (basically) as the kanji. It means certainly, and it can also mean surely.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is certainly weird. To remember the reading for this word, just think how you're certain that if you stash the treasure, nobody will find it here.

context-en: The chairman got through the crisis.
context-en2: The man in the black suit sitting in the last row of the bus is the speaker.
context-en3: I am acting as chairperson of this meeting.
meaning-exp: The person in charge of long discussions is the chairman, or the speaker. They also say who gets to talk and for how long.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Conference Room, Council Room, Meeting Room
context-en: Koichi hurried to the conference room to help Viet.
context-en2: Viet and Koichi went in the meeting room and still haven't come out.
context-en3: I’m staying in the conference room now.
meaning-exp: A room where you meet for discussions is known as a conference room.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: We are running short on conger eel, so we need to place an order for them soon.
context-en2: Since it is difficult to get conger eel in America, freshwater eel is used instead.
context-en3: "Do you want another piece of conger eel nigiri?" "Sure. Why not?"
meaning-exp: A hole child isn't some kind of creepy hole child (not sure how else to describe it). It's a conger eel, a type of tasty eel eaten in Japan. It might be easier to learn the reading first, though, and use that, because the second meaning option is anago, the Japanese word for it (also used in English).
reading-exp: The reading is the two kun'yomi vocab readings combined. So, ? and ? to make ???.

context-en: I wish mayonnaise flavored cough drops existed.
context-en2: Do you happen to have a throat lozenge?
context-en3: Don't you think cough drops taste like the science room?
meaning-exp: Throat candy is the kind of candy that should make your throat feel better. That's right, it's a cough drop or a throat lozenge. Don't just eat regular candy when your throat hurts! Use the right kind.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

context-en: I was happy to see my mom so absorbed in patching holes.
context-en2: I fell in love with a waitress who is mad about a dishwasher.
context-en3: "Salmon, well, you probably don't know this, but back in high school, I was, um, crazy about you." "I knew, Fugu."
meaning-exp: Even in the middle of your dream you're thinking about your body pillows. You're crazy about them, wrapped in absorption.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I was involved in a crime and almost got killed, but I was able to escape death by the skin of my teeth.
context-en2: The police raced to the crime scene after the phone call.
context-en3: The reason crime among youths is increasing is because kids like that get bigger but they don’t change. Don’t you think?
meaning-exp: You have crime and you have guilt. Sounds like you did the crime.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I had an argument with the culprit, but I couldn't get anywhere.
context-en2: The criminal realized that the things he said truly were evil.
context-en3: I’ve been struck by a smooth criminal. I lost everything and he didn’t even leave one fingerprint.
meaning-exp: A crime person is a criminal.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I'm hoping they'll overcome this crisis soon.
context-en2: Tofugu is currently in a critical situation.
context-en3: Did Tofugu run into trouble during the global financial crisis of 2008?
meaning-exp: A dangerous machine is walking through your town, destroying everything. This is a huge crisis!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The husband was always criticizing his wife for not being able to do housework properly.
context-en2: Because of the article, Tofugu opened themselves up to public criticism.
context-en3: I had already expected a critical look from you, and even without it, I felt bad.
meaning-exp: A difficult injustice to take from someone is a criticism. Ugh, what a pain to be criticized! So difficult, and besides, it's an injustice, because I'm perfect!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Tofugu suffered a great loss from an office burglary.
context-en2: This town wasn't damaged by the wildfire.
context-en3: We are going to send our profits from today's business to the area with flood damage.
meaning-exp: When you incur damage you are doing damage and harm.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Diet, The Diet, Congress, Parliament, Assembly
context-en: They are trying to obstruct the proceedings of Parliament by any means necessary.
context-en2: To be honest, it's extremely troublesome having to explain it at Congress.
context-en3: The Diet has already come to a decision.
meaning-exp: The place you meet for deliberation in Japan is called the Diet. It's their version of congress.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The patient has turned the corner after a difficult surgery.
context-en2: I think it would be difficult to leap across this ditch.
context-en3: "How do I do this?" "It’s not as hard as rocket science. Give me that. Let me show you."
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of difficult? It's also difficult.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It's awfully difficult to load a cow into your Moo-zooka (???). Click. Boom!

context-en: Kristen hates Queen Beryl.
context-en2: Koichi glared at me with a look of disgust in his eyes.
context-en3: Just seeing his face makes me seethe with hatred.
meaning-exp: You dislike someone so badly that it turns to disgust and hate.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you feel disgust for someone all you can manage to say when you see them is, "Oh... (?), it's you." Feel the anger when you see their face, "Oh, you again. Bleh."

vocab-meaning: Dishwashing, Doing Dishes, Washing The Dishes, Washing Dishes
context-en: Kristen was just so cute when she was doing dishes and I couldn't help staring holes into her.
context-en2: I feel that time passes slowly when I'm washing dishes.
context-en3: Is it true that there is a ramen restaurant in Japan where you can wash dishes to pay your bill?
meaning-exp: You know the word ? (plate) and the word ?? (to wash), right? You can probably guess dish washing is happening here, but this is a noun, so it's the idea of dishwashing or doing dishes.
reading-exp: The readings are the individual vocab words (you can tell because there's a bit of hiragana stuck on there). It's the reading for ? and ?? combined.

vocab-meaning: Dislike, Hate, To Dislike, To Hate
context-en: There were fill in the blank questions on the test, which I hate.
context-en2: I don't like busy work. I think we should have it done by machines.
context-en3: I’m sorry to cause so many problems. You may think I’m unpleasant, but please don’t hate me.
meaning-exp: You know that ? means dislike and this vocab word means the same thing: dislike!
reading-exp: Of all the things out there to dislike the thing I dislike the most is the killer (??) of people. People should never kill people.

context-en: Reluctantly doing a job you don't like isn't good for your health.
context-en2: Ewwwwwww!!!! Nooooooo!!!! There is a spider! Gross!
context-en3: "That’s my final offer. If you don’t like it stop coming back." "Alright, alright. I’ll take it."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is pretty weird. It's different than the ?? word you will see in this level too. It is ??, so when you think of something you dislike, just think "iyah, I dislike it." Also, think about that eww feeling it gives you when you think of the thing you dislike most.

vocab-meaning: Do Not Enter, No Entry, Entry Prohibited, No Trespassing, Trespassing Prohibited
context-en: This door says Authorized Personnel Only.
context-en2: The backrooms of grocery stores are usually for staff only.
context-en3: That is wild! I can’t believe you went into a place marked "Do Not Enter" and then peed in there!
meaning-exp: Standing and entering are both prohibited (??). If you see this sign, it's essentially saying do not enter or no entry.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is weird. ? is ?? and ? is ??. It's like you're taking the words ?? and ??? and stuffing their hiragana parts back into the kanji (and changing it to ?? in the case of ???). So, that's something you'll want to try to remember. ?? is normal, though, so at least you have that.

context-en: I heard that you sell dreams. How much does one dream cost?
context-en2: Yesterday, I had a dream that Koichi was giving me a shiatsu massage.
context-en3: My dream is to become a manga artist. I hope it will come true.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're having this crazy dream. The dream allows you to do anything you want. Every time you ask "hey, can I do this?" The answer is always "you may" (??). Think of some things you'd want to do if you could do anything. Ask permission and get this answer in your imagination.

context-en: The press severely criticized the government's earthquake preparedness.
context-en2: When an earthquake occurs in a place where they rarely have them, some people call the police.
context-en3: "I want to talk to you about the earthquake last night." "I’ll totally listen to what you have to say."
meaning-exp: An earth earthquake is just another way to say earthquake.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice that ? is read as ? instead of ?. You've seen this happen a few times before, so just try to remember that this is the case here.

context-en: Because of the earthquake disaster, there are a lot of potholes on the ground now.
context-en2: I still can't forget the trauma I experienced from the day of the earthquake disaster.
context-en3: When I go to Japan, I want to see the single pine tree that withstood the giant tsunami caused by the Great Tohoku Earthquake in 2011.
meaning-exp: An earthquake disaster is just that, an earthquake disaster. These are no good.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for ? is the ?? reading because *sigh* earthquakes suck man.

vocab-meaning: Earthquake Intensity, Earthquake Magnitude, Magnitude, Seismic Scale
context-en: The earthquake's magnitude was at a three, but it felt quite strong.
context-en2: What’s the difference between magnitude and seismic scale?
context-en3: They say the aftershocks from the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake hit a magnitude of seven, and that they'll continue for the next hundred years, even the big ones.
meaning-exp: The earthquake degrees is how you measure an earthquake. The ?? is the earthquake intensity.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Please turn off all personal electronic devices or set them to airplane mode on this plane. Thank you for your cooperation.
context-en2: We manually check electronic equipment one by one to make sure there are no defects.
context-en3: Why did some airlines start relaxing their rules about the use of electronics during flights?
meaning-exp: You have an electronic (??) container machine. This is just a machine that contains electricity and electric parts. It is, basically, just electronic equipment. Though, you can say electronics if that's easier for you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: To buy a very popular game on the release day, I went to a store before they opened, but there was already a line from the store that was about 200-meters long to the end.
context-en2: I saw Kristen at the end of a line for a shop I passed by yesterday. I wonder what she was playing hooky from work to get.
context-en3: The end of the line is this way.
meaning-exp: You already know that ?? means "end" so the tail end is the end of a line.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. It isn't the same as ?? though, so watch out for that! It uses the other on'yomi reading you learned with the kanji!

context-en: There were no existing flood-control measures in this town to begin with.
context-en2: So does that mean there were no holes in the ozone layer originally?
context-en3: "I can’t believe Koichi exists..." Fugu said.
meaning-exp: I exist, I suppose... this is the kind of existence I have. I'm not really sure either way, and I don't care. Existence is futile, I suppose.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I've never had the experience of traveling by plane.
context-en2: Has anyone else had the experience where you try to help a friend and then you get blamed instead?
context-en3: "Oh! Have you tried marriage counseling yet?" "Of course. We experienced that a long time ago but it went badly."
meaning-exp: Through various tests over the passage of time, you have gained much experience. Time and testing is all it takes.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How did a fire disaster cause heavy floods?
context-en2: I have to fill the hole made by the fire disaster by the end of today.
context-en3: He cooked a steak in a frying pan without running the ventilation fan at 2AM and the fire alarm went off.
meaning-exp: A fire disaster is a fire disaster. Maybe you'll get to meet a sexy firefighter if things go well...
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Fire Prevention, Fire Fighting, Fire Proof
context-en: I put my knowledge of fire prevention in writing.
context-en2: If you can invent a paint that makes woods 100% fireproof, you'll be super rich.
context-en3: How often does Tofugu have fire drills?
meaning-exp: Trying to prevent fire? Better get into fire prevention.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Viet and Darin are recovering the data that was lost from the water damage.
context-en2: The flood left 5,000 cats homeless.
context-en3: I grew up on a flood-prone island.
meaning-exp: Water damage is so bad they call it water damage. Doesn't get any clearer than this.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Forgotten Item, Something Forgotten, Forgotten Thing, Lost Property
context-en: I'm not blaming you just because you forgot to bring something.
context-en2: When Koichi's plane arrived at Narita Airport, Koichi realized that he forgot something, so he returned Portland on the same airplane.
context-en3: I feel like I forgot something today, but I just can’t remember what it is.
meaning-exp: Remember how ??? is "to forget"? Well, a thing you've forgotten is a forgotten item.
reading-exp: Since you didn't learn this reading for ? with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. If you study this vocabulary out the wazoo ??, it'll never become a forgotten item!

context-en: Koichi always surprises people with his very flexible ideas.
context-en2: I'm looking for an adjustable leash for dogs.
context-en3: That man can manipulate minds at will.
meaning-exp: When you can exist all by yourself, then you can do things freely as you please.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The criminal was found guilty and sentenced to death.
context-en2: Two of the five guilty people appealed to the Supreme Court.
context-en3: I can’t drive because then I’d be guilty of drunk driving.
meaning-exp: Someone who have (has) guilt is someone who is guilty.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Hand Washing, Bathroom, Restroom, Lavatory, Washing The Hands
context-en: Koichi is angry with his workers because they don't wash their hands and gargle, regardless of how many times he's told them to do so.
context-en2: Can I borrow your bathroom?
context-en3: You can’t use a washing machine for Tofugu T-shirts. You have to wash them by hand.
meaning-exp: You remember how ?? is "to wash"? Well, when you wash your hands you're doing hand washing.
reading-exp: The readings are the vocab readings ? and ?? put together.

context-en: It'll be hard to make up for the big losses Fugu made by the end of the year.
context-en2: When I face a hard task, I get excited.
context-en3: My grandmother has difficulty walking, so I have to help her go shopping today.
meaning-exp: You're distressed and it's difficult. This is quite the hardship you're feeling.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: There was an earthquake with a magnitude 6.2, but it was harmless.
context-en2: What's with people who troll even harmless tweets?
context-en3: Don’t worry. Tofugu doesn’t have any poison. He’s a harmless blowfish.
meaning-exp: Psh, that guy's damage is nothing. He's what I'd call "mostly harmless."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How many times can you jump rope when you're suffering from heartburn?
context-en2: It may be because of my age, but I get heartburn when I eat deep-fried food.
context-en3: Don’t you get heartburn from eating katsu-don in the morning?
meaning-exp: When your chest is cooking and burning, you have what's known as heartburn.
reading-exp: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings (hint is that there's hiragana sticking out there). So, just make sure you know the word ? and ??. If you do, you can combine that knowledge into this word, and hopefully not get any heartburn in the process.

context-en: I am so embarrassed, I wished I could sink into the floor!
context-en2: I heard that bats are living in the cave.
context-en3: He has the natural ability to dig deep, magnificent holes.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. No holes in your knowledge!

vocab-meaning: Hole In The Wall, Little Known Good Place
context-en: This is a good blowfish restaurant, which isn't known to the public.
context-en2: This Izakaya restaurant is called Kagaya and this is one of the best holes in the wall in Tokyo.
context-en3: Ever since then I’ve never wanted to have that kind of experience again, or to cause trouble for others, so I’ve stopped going to the little-known place where you can fish for fugu.
meaning-exp: A hole place is what's known as a hole in the wall. This is a place that looks small, hidden and dingy, but probably has awesome food.
reading-exp: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

context-en: That husband and wife had a long, heated argument on whether discussions are indispensable for a good married relationship.
context-en2: Everybody looked at Mr. and Mrs. Koichi with disapproval.
context-en3: Mr. and Mrs. Fugu were such smooth operators that they sold tons of seaweed to their neighbors.
meaning-exp: You have a husband and a wife. Combine them together and they're husband and wife.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Viet and Koichi are inseparable from each other.
context-en2: I'm pretty sure it is an indivisible obligation on the contract.
context-en3: As we all know, Tofu and Fugu are inseparable.
meaning-exp: If something is not divisible (??), then it is indivisible.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know how to read the word ??.

context-en: It won't make sense if we go by that logic.
context-en2: Can anyone teach me about the logic of syllogism?
context-en3: I understood her frustration, but I just wanted her to think about the issues between us logically. Then she told me that I’m always trying to find out whose fault things are, which was not true at all.
meaning-exp: Using theory and reason, you are one who uses much logic. Imagine this type of person, I bet you know at least one.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is a machine for digging holes in the ground and that's a machine for threading needles.
context-en2: Today the machine is not working very smoothly.
context-en3: Did Koichi buy a batting cage machine for the office?
meaning-exp: A machine contraption is just a machine
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi bought an airplane as a strategy for reducing his taxes.
context-en2: Time is ripe for Koichi to be the president of the United States.
context-en3: I'm still seeking opportunities.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: I started getting hungry during the assembly.
context-en2: You ditched the conference to watch a serial TV drama!? What the heck!?
context-en3: The purpose of this meeting is to discuss our current situation and go over new plans.
meaning-exp: A place where people meet and do deliberation. Sounds boring, but also sounds like some kind of meeting or conference.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Member Of The Diet, Diet Member, Legislator, Assembly Member
context-en: Becoming a member of the diet is Michael's longterm dream.
context-en2: When I was a college student, I was interning for a city council Diet member. It was a good experience.
context-en3: I lost my Diet member badge.
meaning-exp: A discussion member talks about all the really important things that need to be discussed for the sake of the country. They are a member of the Diet. The Diet is Japan's version of congress. Diet members discuss really important matters.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Fortunately, I was overseas at the time, so I was able to escape the disaster.
context-en2: Today at school I learned a proverb that goes, "calamity is the touchstone of a brave mind."
context-en3: I wonder why misfortune is always following that guy? Is it just by chance or is there something wrong with him?
meaning-exp: A disaster that is difficult is particularly difficult, making it more of a misfortune. Obviously a disaster that wasn't difficult wouldn't really be that bad, so a difficult one gets the "misfortune" or calamity label.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi gets in a good mood for three o'clock snack time, every day like clockwork.
context-en2: What kind of mood is mom in today?
context-en3: "Her mood's terrible in the morning." "Yeah don’t I know it!"
meaning-exp: Machines dislike everything. Their mood is very sour. What about your mood?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. ?? gets changed to ??, though, so don't let that ruin your mood.

context-en: There is nothing scarier than natural disasters.
context-en2: I can't understand why they built the nuclear power plant on a potential disaster site to begin with.
context-en3: Each room has been prepared with flashlights and water bottles in case of a natural disaster.
meaning-exp: A disaster that does damage. Usually these are natural disasters, though they could also just be regular disasters as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The lead actor got sick all of a sudden and we couldn't find another actor to fill in for him. It was such a nightmare.
context-en2: I had a bad dream that I turned into a fat cat that couldn’t walk.
context-en3: I heard you can make yourself have nightmares if you sleep with your arms folded across your chest, so I tried it and I had a dream that I was cleaning a toilet nonstop from morning to night.
meaning-exp: A bad dream is also known as a nightmare. Ah! Noooooo!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "Aren't the shapes of Koichi's nose holes a bit weird?" "Really? I think they are cute."
context-en2: When Koichi has a nose bleed, he sticks a tube-shaped fish paste cake in there to stop it.
context-en3: "Your nostril..." "What? I can’t hear you." "Well never mind. It’s nothing." "Now you have to tell me. What were you saying?"
meaning-exp: What's your nose's hole? How about your nostril?
reading-exp: The reading is the readings for ? and ?. Smell that fresh air through your nose hole.

context-en: If you don't stop interfering, I'm going to sue you for obstruction.
context-en2: Since we've come pretty far, the risk of being intercepted by the enemy should be almost zero.
context-en3: Someday I want to be arrested for interfering with police officers, like in the movies.
meaning-exp: Something that obstructs and also does damage is an obstruction. No obstruction is ever good and if left too long it really will cause damage and interference as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: One Small Thing, One Thing, One Small Object, One Object
context-en: You've got one big hole in your back teeth.
context-en2: Those strawberries were one hundred yen each, but they flew off the shelves.
context-en3: Viet likes cream puffs so much that he eats at least one every single day.
meaning-exp: The counter ?, which means individual on its own, refers to "an individual thing." This is usually a small thing, so it's used to count small things. This word here talks about one individual. A better way to translate that would be to call it one small thing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ?? gets shortened, but I bet you knew that already.

vocab-meaning: On'yomi And Kun'yomi, Chinese And Japanese Readings
context-en: Please teach me how to differentiate between on'yomi and kun'yomi.
context-en2: This is a Chinese and Japanese reading chart of commonly used kanji.
context-en3: The Japanese and Chinese readings for kanji are so confusing, I hate them.
meaning-exp: You've seen (hopefully) ??? and ???. This is a combination of the two. This is on'yomi and kun'yomi, aka the Chinese and Japanese readings.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How do you manage your overseas assets?
context-en2: We are currently checking on the safety of Japanese residents abroad.
context-en3: Before casting an overseas ballot, you have to submit an application to the Japanese embassy or the Japanese consulate.
meaning-exp: When you exist outside (outside of what? Japan, of course), you are overseas or abroad.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: These people are really talkative, eh?
context-en2: People in Texas are very friendly, aren't they!
context-en3: There are some people who make fun of my dad for being a pizza delivery man, but I’m very proud of him.
meaning-exp: The kanji ? pluralizes things sometimes. So, when you have a plural amount of a person you have more than one person, you have people. Take note! When using this word, you want to attach it to the type of "people" you are talking about. For example, ???? (those people over there). Other examples: ????, ????, ??????, etc. You don't use this by itself, instead you use it with something describing what kind of people you're talking about.
reading-exp: The readings are both kun'yomi readings of the kanji. The readings come from the word ? and the ?? of ??, though now it's ?? because it hasn't been rendaku'd. You like to touch (??) people, you perv.

context-en: What percent relies on machine translations?
context-en2: The ratio of boys and girls in the Tofugu office is 5 to 2.
context-en3: I think Tofugu has a capital-to-asset ratio of 100%.
meaning-exp: You compare the percent and by doing that figure out the percentage and ratio of something.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is my personal opinion, but I hope Viet finds a good wife.
context-en2: I don't know if it's because he's American, or if it's just him, but Koichi really loves beer, right?
context-en3: I don’t really see the difference between being an individualist and simply being selfish.
meaning-exp: In terms of an individual person... well, that's personal, and depends on the individual. Whatever it is, an individual person has personal tastes, so make sure to think of that.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is a lucky charm that protects you from misfortune.
context-en2: I believed in the phrase, "turn disaster into advantage," and it really worked.
context-en3: It seems like Shark wishes misfortune upon other people.
meaning-exp: This is the noun form of disaster, though it is more like a personal disaster or personal misfortune. Just picture that flood from the kanji sweeping you up into your own personal disaster—one only you experience.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When a personal disaster strikes, you start moaning and groaning. Say it along with me: "Wahhhhh! Zaahhhh! Waahhhh!" (???). Be careful of the ? on the end, it can be tricky and make you think it's an adjective when it's a noun.

context-en: In Japan, pollution became a huge societal problem between 1950 and 1960.
context-en2: We are all responsible for the pollution problems.
context-en3: My son is suffering from a pollution-triggered respiratory illness.
meaning-exp: Public damage is something that affects everyone, the whole public. What is in the air and gets into everything no matter where you are? How about pollution?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Japan used to approve of polygamy too.
context-en2: "I can't believe polygamy exists," Viet said accusingly. "You can turn that finger around,” Koichi retorted with a smile.
context-en3: It’s not like all men support polygamy.
meaning-exp: One husband, many wives. Sounds a bit sketchy. This is polygamy.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the ? gets changed to ?? and the ? gets changed to ? from ?? for some reason. You can imagine that this is because when you are the type that has many wives, you're probably the type who makes them clean up your poo for you as well.

context-en: I think the possibility of a war breaking out is low, but I'm worried.
context-en2: It seems like the likelihood of it snowing on Christmas Day is very high.
context-en3: None of the ideas we came up with sounded likely, but we didn’t give up easily.
meaning-exp: Your possible (??) gender is one of two things. This means there's a possibility you'll either be a boy or a girl. Or maybe something else! Who knows?!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to be able to read ?? as well.

context-en: I made the pressure cooker explode, but luckily I didn't get injured.
context-en2: The pressure that a rocket is under when it's entering the atmosphere is very strong.
context-en3: We must keep the pressure on Koichi to get WaniKani out of beta.
meaning-exp: The pressure power is the pressure. This can also be stress as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If we had a better risk management, we would have been able to prevent this accident.
context-en2: If you go to that country, please make sure to take medicine to prevent malaria beforehand.
context-en3: Do Japanese people get a tetanus vaccination every ten years, too?
meaning-exp: To prevent beforehand is still prevention.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The police have prevented crime from spreading in this town.
context-en2: Today we discussed the prevention of global warming at school.
context-en3: Japanese currency is known for incorporating the world’s most advanced counterfeit prevention technology, but Viet is planning to defeat it.
meaning-exp: To prevent and stop someone from doing something is prevention. It's good to have prevention instead of letting something bad happen.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When you have small kids, the existence of izakaya with private rooms is appreciated.
context-en2: Koichi's been living in a shared house without his own room for more than five years now.
context-en3: I reserved a private room for our year-end party.
meaning-exp: An individual room just for you is your own private room. How nice!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The probability of Koichi accidentally falling into this pit is at about 20%.
context-en2: What's the likelihood of Koichi being someone who's kind to his friends?
context-en3: Viet told Koichi that the chances of Tofugu succeeding were 200%.
meaning-exp: You're certain there is this percent chance it will happen? You know that this is the probability?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My mom always did housework quietly and mechanically.
context-en2: I was just ignoring my super-angry wife and calmly cleaning our place.
context-en3: The duchess gracefully entered the room and kissed the duke.
meaning-exp: Quiet quiet! Do it quietly, please.
reading-exp: You know how ?? is ???? Well, this is the same reading as that. Say it in a whisper with me: "????." Shhh!

context-en: Tofugu readers paid for my plane tickets.
context-en2: Tofugu has many readers all over the world.
context-en3: Among Tofugu readers, how many are Japanese language learners?
meaning-exp: The reading someone is someone who is reading. They are the reader (of a book, blog, article, etc).
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. This reading is ??, and you can remember it by thinking about how you are the reader, and as the reader you choose where to read. For you, the best place to read is a peaceful dock (??). Sit on the dock and relax. Be the reader.

context-en: Badgers really exist, huh?
context-en2: When do you feel that God really exists?
context-en3: There’s a rumor that Tofugu’s face was modeled after a real person.
meaning-exp: The truth is that you exist in reality. Well, that makes sense, I suppose.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: What's this month's remainder as of now?
context-en2: It would be difficult to return to Earth with the remaining fuel.
context-en3: "Have you guys discussed the residual risks, too?" "Not yet. We all forgot the formula to calculate residual risk, so we can't have the discussion."
meaning-exp: The remaining surplus is the remainder or residual left over.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I became friends with an American who was residing in Japan.
context-en2: In order to extend your residency, you have to leave the country and then come back.
context-en3: Visas and residence status are two different things.
meaning-exp: The place you're detained is where you exist. As long as you're in this place, this will be your residence. Note: mainly means "residence" in the broader sense and is parts of words like "residence card" or "foreign residents."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Right after graduating from his senior high school, Koichi joined the navy.
context-en2: There was a senior high school, that was famous for celebrities going there, near the condo I used to live in when I was little.
context-en3: I’m the vice principal of a senior high school.
meaning-exp: Remember when you learned that ?? means "high class" and ?? means "school?" Well put them together and you have senior high school! It's the most high class school you've got (unless you go to university, but that's considered to be separate). Fun fact: ?? is the abbreviation of this word. Neat, right?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Shiatsu massage can help with stress and anxiety.
context-en2: I got a boyfriend who is an acupressurist, but he won't give me a shiatsu massage unless I pay him.
context-en3: Some people say that getting too many shiatsu massages isn’t good for you.
meaning-exp: Finger pressure is nice to have. When someone puts finger pressure on you, what kind of massage is that? It's shiatsu. Perhaps if you take a look at the reading you'll be able to know this word's meaning better?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Mami's crime of eating Koichi's bacon is more serious than she thinks.
context-en2: My company president has been found guilty of accounting fraud crimes.
context-en3: I don’t think Koichi would hire anyone who has committed the crime of murdering innocent civilians.
meaning-exp: If you have guilt then you have committed a sin or crime. Come here and confess to Father Koichi.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you come to confess your sin to me, you start claiming it wasn't you. You say it was some other version of you! What? How could this be? Well, you say "there are two mes (??) out there!" One is doing the bad stuff, and the other is you, and you haven't done any sins!

context-en: The entire town is smoky now due to the wildfire.
context-en2: The smoky fireworks made me cough.
context-en3: It’s so smoky! When the heck are you going to quit smoking? This really smells awful.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of smoke? It's smoky.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All this smokiness is from a terrible chemical (??) spill that happened nearby. It was acid, so it burned everything up real good, causing the air to get pretty smokey.

vocab-meaning: Stinky, Stinking, To Be Stinky, Smelly, To Be Smelly
context-en: The flooded area smelled really stinky.
context-en2: Excuse my garlic breath. It smells terrible, right? I just ate ramen.
context-en3: My husband's morning breath was too stinky to bear, so I decided to divorce him.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stinking? It's also stinking (or stinky).
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji can be used here, too.

context-en: Tofugu has quite a bit of room in the budget this year.
context-en2: We still have enough room for a few people.
context-en3: I’d love to buy a new computer and some AKB48 figures, but I can’t afford to right now.
meaning-exp: You have an abundant surplus! How nice it must be to have a surplus with so much leeway.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Our suspicion that Viet is a yakuza cannot be wiped away.
context-en2: I'm under suspicion from the police.
context-en3: Viet dispelled suspicions of Koichi being a murderer.
meaning-exp: I dislike him and I have doubts about him. I therefore have much suspicion against him as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Koichi can look at a fish's tail and tell you what kind it is based on that alone.
context-en2: Without tails, birds would have difficulty landing.
context-en3: Why do you think the custom of shortening dog’s tails started?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You look down and you've sprouted a tail! You're so shocked that all you can say is "Oh. (?) Oh okay..." This your life now. A life with a tail.

context-en: Koichi's theory was not supported by anyone.
context-en2: Koichi is learning leadership theories in order to become a good company president.
context-en3: I’m bad at giving theoretical explanations.
meaning-exp: You have reason behind your theory, making it a real theory (unlike those that don't have reason, I guess?).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There are about five pages missing near the end of this thesis.
context-en2: My friend is a warrior who published many essays during her graduate school years.
context-en3: If things work out well, I’ll be able to finish writing my college graduation thesis today.
meaning-exp: A writing of your theory is usually a thesis. Remember how school teachers always wanted you to present theories in writing? And to make sure you have a thesis in that paper? I do.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I wonder how a hole was made in this thick fence.
context-en2: When I visited the Tofugu office, I received a very warm welcome.
context-en3: Koichi found a sick earthworm resting on some thick moss.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thick? Also thick.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No thick books needed to understand this reading, yeah?

vocab-meaning: Three Small Things, Three Things, Three Objects, Three Small Objects
context-en: I put three milks and three syrup cups in my coffee.
context-en2: I bought a box of soap that comes with three bars.
context-en3: After eating three cheeseburgers, three teriyaki burgers, and several nuggets, I feel really awful.
meaning-exp: Three individuals is three small things. The kanji ? can be used to count small objects, just like this! Try other numbers as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My house was burned in a fire.
context-en2: This bread is toasted well.
context-en3: "This meat is thick, so I think it'll be a while until it's cooked." "I think it'll cook while you're doing the dishes."
meaning-exp: You know how ?? is to cook? Well, ??? is to be cooked. This is when you're not doing the actual cooking, and the cooking is just happening. Can also refer to when something burns, making it to burn as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??, so just use that knowledge and apply it here to be able to read this too.

vocab-meaning: To Be Distressed, To Be Troubled, To Be Perplexed, To Be Annoyed
context-en: Phlegm is stuck in my throat and it's annoying me.
context-en2: I am studying Japanese, but I am in trouble because I don't understand the meanings of nouns, particles, and so on.
context-en3: "Why don’t you stay open later?" "Sorry, it’s not really my call. I just work here."
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distressed and troubled. The verb versions of those are to be distressed and to be troubled.
reading-exp: You know who seems to be distressed all the time? Little ?s. ?s are always crying about something. Always. And when adults are distressed they can look like ?s too.

vocab-meaning: To Be In Surplus, To Remain Left Over, To Exceed, To Surplus, To Be In Excess
context-en: We caught more than enough fish ice fishing, so please take some if you'd like.
context-en2: From the way they live, they seem to have quite an excess of money, don't you think?
context-en3: There is an abundance of apples in our orchard.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surplus so the verb version would be to be in surplus or to remain left over. Too much!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "I have a surplus of kittens from that last batch we made, Reddit. AMA (ask me anything, ??)."

vocab-meaning: To Commit A Crime, To Perpetrate, To Make A Mistake, To Rape
context-en: I'm going to confess to the sin I committed during the war.
context-en2: I don't think it's worth doing if we have to break the law.
context-en3: Viet is incapable of making mistakes. For Viet, nothing is impossible.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crime so the verb vocab version would be to commit a crime (because you don't just "to crime," right?).
reading-exp: You go to commit a crime. How did it go, you think? Well, I thought it went okay (??). Imagine yourself committing a crime and it going just okay. Not great, not bad... meh. Okay.

vocab-meaning: To Defend, To Protect Against, To Prevent
context-en: We need to discuss how to prevent accidents.
context-en2: While Viet and the others were defending themselves against the enemy, Kristen had Prince Koichi escape to Japan.
context-en3: This down jacket will really protect you from the cold.
meaning-exp: You're doing a prevention. When you prevent something, what are you really doing? You're trying to defend against something from happening. That's why this verb is a little weird and means to defend or to protect against. It can also be to prevent, too, but just make sure you're thinking of it more like you're defending something with your prevention.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to defend yourself? You should probably put out that fuse (??) attached to that giant bomb first then.

context-en: When we arrived at a park, there were a lot of bubbles floating in the air.
context-en2: He may not look like he is able to do something like that, but he can actually jump very high.
context-en3: Tofugu’s latest e-book is flying off the shelves.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fly so the verb vocab version is to fly.
reading-exp: When you try to fly, the main thing holding you back is your toe (?). It's like forty pounds and holds you down.

context-en: I heard that person just gave birth to a baby last winter and that she'll have another one this fall.
context-en2: A lot of baby mantises came out of the egg that the mantis laid.
context-en3: Dr. Koichi: Okay. You ready to push again? You are going to have twins! Salmon: I already gave birth to one baby. Leave me alone. Fugu: Okay, okay, come on, you can do it. You can do it!
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give birth so the verb vocab version is to give birth. PUSH. PUSSHHH! You know another ?? as well (??). This ?? is more sciency, but both are good to know.
reading-exp: You know another "to give birth" word (??). Guess what!? They share readings!

vocab-meaning: To Knock Over, To Knock Down, To Bring Down
context-en: Who knocked over the perforated ladle?
context-en2: I'm gonna bring him down, so don't worry too much.
context-en3: My dad and I knocked down some trees and chopped them up for logs this Sunday.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means overthrow or collapse. This is when you are doing those things to something else. If you do, you're going to knock over whatever it is you're trying to knock over.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You use the power of the Tao (??) to do all of your knocking down. Imagine yourself contemplating Tao philosophy, then using those pleasant thoughts to knock everything over around you. BLAM!

vocab-meaning: To Obstruct, To Prevent, To Hamper
context-en: I heard that company is trying to hamper Tofugu's success.
context-en2: You should get rid of things that obstruct productivity.
context-en3: I don’t understand why people try preventing aliens from reaching the earth.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obstruct, so what is the verb vocab version? It's to obstruct.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your woman friend (see radical) is trying to obstruct you. "Sama(n)tha!" (???) you yell. "Let me pass!"

context-en: I was so into the game I didn't notice the time pass.
context-en2: How many years have passed since Tofugu started?
context-en3: "Do you think they will have a happy marriage?" "Time will tell."
meaning-exp: You know how ? means passage of time, right? Well, this is the verb form of that. What does time do when it passages? It passes. So, this verb means to pass.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you say to time as it begins to pass you by? "Ta ta (?), Time!"

vocab-meaning: To Put On A Hat, To Put On, To Wear A Hat, To Wear, To Put A Hat On
context-en: We should put hats on when we go out in summer.
context-en2: The one with the Konan mask who is playing innocently is Koichi, and the other one next to him who is carefully watching over Koichi is Viet.
context-en3: On a rainy day in Osaka, I saw a middle aged woman wearing a plastic bag on her head while riding a bicycle.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means incur so you'd think this would mean "to incur," but it doesn't. This is to put a hat on. Yep, it's the verb that's made for putting on hats. So, think of it this way. You "incur" a hat when you go to put on a hat. Pretty weird but you'll get it if you put on your thinking cap.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The hat that you put on is none other than a hat made from a bear cub (??). The mother bear comes for you and takes it back the hard way.

context-en: I never once thought they'd given me troublesome tasks.
context-en2: You've taken on such a difficult job!
context-en3: Mark my words. That Fugu boy is going to cause trouble.
meaning-exp: When you're looking straight into the face of a collapse it means trouble and difficulty coming soon.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ?? goes to ??, though. Agh, what a ??.

vocab-meaning: Unneeded, More Than Enough, Too Much, Excess, Unnecessary
context-en: This is one too many chairs, isn't it?
context-en2: The car noises disturbed my sleep and made me extra upset.
context-en3: I knew it wasn’t really my business to be sticking my nose in other people’s affairs, but curiosity got the better of me.
meaning-exp: I've measured the surplus and it's all unneeded and more than enough. Maybe we should get rid of all this surplus?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: All the victims of the flood said they wished they'd had waterproof furniture.
context-en2: If you want it to be 100% watertight, you have to use this.
context-en3: These waterproof boots are far from being waterproof. My feet got soaking wet from just walking around here.
meaning-exp: Something that prevents water is waterproof and watertight. Time to take a bath with my ?? cell phone...
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: As if the depression was someone else's problem, Koichi became wealthier and wealthier.
context-en2: I think Viet comes from a wealthy family.
context-en3: My parents are not super rich but they are relatively wealthy.
meaning-exp: You have such abundant luck! When you have abundant luck, most people probably would think you also have a lot of wealth, because lots of wealth equals lots of luck, right?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I just felt that it was troublesome to check the weather forecast beforehand.
context-en2: The weather forecast said it would rain this afternoon.
context-en3: The weather forecast was crazy off.
meaning-exp: This is a combination of the words ??, meaning "weather," and ?? meaning "forecast." Put them together and you get the weather forecast!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: For my wife's birthday, I got her a seaplane.
context-en2: My wife went to Koichi's concert and she said it was fantastic, though her seat was in the last row.
context-en3: My ex-wife says, "You’ll never find someone like me." Well exactly! That’s the plan!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is used to refer to your own wife, though, for the most part.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your wife does everything for you. She feeds you, she bathes you, she cleans up after you and even wipes your butt when you poop. Really, she is doing too much (??), and you should stop being a baby.

vocab-meaning: Wife And Kids, Wife And Children
context-en: My hungry wife and children are waiting for me at home.
context-en2: Even though Koichi has a wife and kids, he visits his favorite hostess every night. Don't you think he's terrible?
context-en3: Now that I’ve been transferred to the new branch store, I’m feeling really motivated. Working hard to find a good man has become one of my daily routines. I don’t care whether he has a wife and kids, you know? lol
meaning-exp: You have your wife and you have your child. These are your wife and kids.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It's a mystery how time flies on your day off.
context-en2: Marvelous things often happen when I am near Viet! The other day, for example, we were joining the end of a line but all of the people in front of us let us cut, one after the other.
context-en3: We all depend on Koichi, but we also wonder why he seems so oddly cheerful all the time.
meaning-exp: This is not what you thought would happen during your deliberation. You thought it would be very normal. Instead, it's the opposite. It's full of wonder and mystery.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How many clients does Tofugu actually have at the moment?
meaning-exp: On this occasion it is the truth. It actually, really is the truth.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? is shortened to ?.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help to know how to read the word ?? on its own, too.
