meaning-exp: Take all the separate parts. Now untie them, unraveling the connections between the two parts. In this way we can do our analysis and breakdown.

meaning-exp: Your big enemy is your worst enemy. Your arch enemy.

meaning-exp: With the whole body. Do it as a whole instead of as a part, or something.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Biker Gang, Motorcycle Gang, Japanese Bikers, Bosozoku

meaning-exp: A tribe that runs wild (??) is what the Japanese call a biker gang. Just imagine them riding around on their bikes, running wild. They're also close, like a family. How nice!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning-exp: A writing that has been evaluated has gotten a book review.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can’t eat something so strange.
context-en2: I thought a mysterious man was looking at me, but it turned out to be Koichi from Tofugu.
context-en3: I suddenly felt as if something unidentifiable was coming towards me at furious speeds and I started sweating with fear.
meaning-exp: With time your body will acquire a certain type of character. It shows your true nature as a person. Note: We almost always use this word in the phrases ???????/???????, so check out the context sentences to see what kind of "character" we're talking about.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

context-en: I was surprised that pinworm tests aren’t commonly administered in North America.
meaning-exp: We're going to need to examine and inspect you for our annual checkup, mmk? Now drop your pants and cough, please.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Hachi is a target of jealousy in the dog world.

Just think of how cows muuuuu (?) get all bunched up and crowded, which is why this word is to be crowded.

You know that this is the version where something just unties on its own (you're not doing the untying) because you don't have a care (??) in the world. You just watch things getting untied and don't do it yourself.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In fact, while you're sitting there with no cares, waiting for things to become untied, you stare down at your toe (?). Really imagine doing that while things around you are getting untied.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the reading of ??.

context-en: I need to persuade my dad to become a rock musician.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is persuasion, so what is the verb version of that? To persuade.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also immensely help to know the reading of the word ??.

vocab-meaning: To Plan, To Scheme, To Attempt
context-en: "What is it?" "Ah, nothing!" "You’re planning something, aren’t you?!"
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plan so the verb vocab version is to plan.
reading-exp: What are you trying to plan? No. Wait. How could you? You're trying to plan a coup? Whadda (???) you thinking???

vocab-meaning: To Put In Disorder, To Throw Out Of Order, To Disturb
context-en: Kids with ADHD typically can’t stand having the rhythm of their lives thrown out of order.
meaning-exp: You know how ??? is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going to put in disorder things. Just imagine all the people who will try to sue (?) you for your actions.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???, so make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Recognize, To Perceive, To Acknowledge, To Approve, To Admit
context-en: I hate to admit it, but I think Fugu is doing a great job this time.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recognize so the verb vocab version is to recognize.
reading-exp: The reason I was able to recognize you is because your face was covered in meat (??). Your face was always covered in meat all those years ago too!

context-en: President Koichi appointed Viet as the next Secretary of State, but he refused.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off. What happens when you do the action of cutting someone off? You're going to refuse them of whatever it is they want.
reading-exp: By trying to refuse this person, you're going to start a ? war (a war of actions). They will do one war-like action, then you will do a war-like action until it escalates into a ? war (????).

context-en: I can’t believe that I’m nominated for the Mustache Award.
meaning-exp: When you raise something you are causing it to rise.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The reading for this is the same as the other "to rise" word, ???. Nice how that works, right? So, just associate the two and you have yourself a reading.

context-en: I use this lifehack in the morning so I can wake up properly.
meaning-exp: If your eyes are awake then you're going to wake up. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know? This word can also mean to awaken but it's like when you to come to your senses, not literally waking up.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you start to wake up in the middle of the night, it's because of the wake up wizard (?). He sneaks into your house when you're sleeping and pokes you with his wand. Wizards like when you wake up. They're weird.

vocab-meaning: To Work As, To Serve As, To Be Employed As
context-en: My father worked as a police officer for forty years until last year.
context-en2: Koichi served an important role of taking care of aliens from various planets.
context-en3: Mr. Tamura was employed as Ms. Tanaka’s private secretary for one year, but it didn’t really work out.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means task so what's the verb vocab version? Well, when you do a task, you are going to work as or to serve as something to do that task.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To work as my secretary, you will have to complete a task. A task where you bring me two toes (??)! Don't ask me why! You want to serve as my assistant, right? Just get me those two toes then!

context-en: Is memorization the only way to learn if the verb is transitive or intransitive?
meaning-exp: Remember how ??? was "intransitive verb"? Intransitive verbs are when something just happens. You aren't doing the action to them. This word, however, is the other kind. A transitive verb is when you are directly doing something to something else. That's why it has other in there, because it's a verb (??) you do to another thing, directly.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My dog doesn’t come to my whistle because I’m bad at whistling.

reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi readings put together. Thank ? for being a body part, which tends to cause this to happen. So, you have ? (??) and ? (??) put together, though ?? changes to ??, maybe because you can't whistle properly? Buuuweeee. Buwwweee.

context-en: Unlike the West, Japan does not have a history of strong women’s rights movements.
meaning-exp: A woman's rights consist of women's rights.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If birth rates are declining, why are waitlists for schools increasing?
meaning-exp: You want a machine to wait so you put it on alert. If the machine is your computer you put it on standby. You just want it to stay there and do nothing until you're ready, that's all.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: In my presentation today, I will cover three main plans.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Lucky for you, even though this word is a single kanji, it uses the same reading you learned, meaning you know how to read it already. Time to plan and scheme for your next vocab/kanji.

vocab-meaning: A Response, Response, A Reaction, Reaction
context-en: Could you tell me how to force quit an unresponsive application, please?
meaning-exp: Whoops, this one comes out weird. You have anti respond though the meaning of this word is a response. Maybe you're "anti respond" but you have no choice, you have to give a response despite that fact?
reading-exp: The ? reading is all good and merry, but the ? reading gets a bit wonky, turning into ??. This is probably because it's just way easier to say than ???? and sounds basically the same too. So, ???? goes to ???? and everyone's happy. Do you have a response? The reading ???? is also going to be included since it's technically correct though a less common spelling.

context-en: Your assistance is vital to the success of this fart plan.
meaning-exp: If you aid and help someone you are giving them assistance. How kind!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Well, how can we get this baby to stop crying? We already tried feeding him, changing him, and burping him. Oh, here is something! It says to try holding the baby close to your body and then rocking it quickly from side to side.
meaning-exp: Here's a weird one for you. You have a red monk. What is this? It's a baby. Think about it. Babies, when they come out, are all red. Also, they have a shaved head, just like a monk would. So, a "red monk" is really just a baby. I wonder who's getting the shorter end of the stick here, the monk or the baby? Probably the monk.
reading-exp: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of ? (you learned this with the kanji) and the reading you learned for ? as well.

reading-exp: The ? reads like you'd expect. Unfortunately ? is an exception and read ?. Just think of a zoo that holds Buddhist priests in captivity. How sad, these Buddhist priests.

context-en2: The business hours for the Tofugu office are from nine to six PST.
meaning-exp: Managing a business? That's business!

context-en: The reason I’m here today is to introduce our latest crime prevention products.

context-en: I’m not used to speaking in front of crowds, so my hands are already shaking.
meaning-exp: You have a large force at your disposal. This large force is a group of people (just think about when this word was probably made up... a long time ago, and the biggest force you could have was a huge group of people). This group of people force is also known as a crowd.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is the ?? reading (like ???). Nothing you can do about that but remember it. Then, ? is rendaku'd to become ??. Also something you'll just have to remember. Say this word a few times in your head, then you'll be able to come up with an idea of what sounds right and what sounds wrong so that you can figure it out next time this word comes up.

context-en: The train was derailed, but nobody was injured.
meaning-exp: When you undress from the line it's like you're peeling something off the line, going off in another direction, and then causing a digression in whatever the line was about. It's like when you're talking and you digress. Think of your speech as a line. Then, undress a part of it and let it fall away. That is your digression.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It seems that each person has their own way of eating potato chips.
meaning-exp: You have each each which is each (or every, or "respectively"). Kind of goes along the lines of "each and every" in English.
reading-exp: The reading is weird. So sorry. Just imagine you look at each item. Every single one is messed up in some way. Possibly they are robots all accidentally programmed to need to kill humans. You say "oh no oh no" in quick succession because this is a bad situation.

context-en: First, choose a representative for each team.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji, though it's kind of like an add-on for other words in a sense, which makes it behave like jukugo, I think. Don't confuse this with ?? though. That one does use the kun'yomi reading, which is strange when you consider this one doesn't. Every kanji has its own "perks" I suppose.

context-en: My family had to move from place to place because of my dad’s job.
meaning-exp: Each ground is its own ground. It is each area.

You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What's that figure / shape in the distance? Is that who I think it is? Is that Sugar Tom (???)??? You'll have to make up some lore about this "Sugar Tom" but whatever you do be excited about him. He's a dude who gives you tons of sugar, I'm guessing, and you always see him coming from a long ways away because of his Sugar Tom hat, or something like that.

meaning-exp: When the machines meet, you finally have the opportunity to take them all out at once. DIE MACHINES!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m afraid no one in the Tofugu office is available at the moment. Every worker overslept today.
meaning-exp: You sleep like a monk, as in you never stop sleeping (because you sleep while you meditate). When you sleep like a monk like this you constantly oversleep, probably because you're up late doing sutras or something. I have no idea why monks wake up late, but figure something out to make this stick in your brain cage.
reading-exp: These are the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My husband is so busy with the imperial court service that I haven’t seen him for four weeks.
meaning-exp: This shinto shrine you're staying at? Turns out you go inside and it is magically turned into this amazing palace. Wow! I'm totally becoming a Shinto monk.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

context-en: My eyes have never watered from onions before.
meaning-exp: If you surpass the past then you're going backwards in time (at least if you're coming from the "present.") If this is the case, then you are definitely in the past.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I can’t believe that all the students in the class received punishment for cheating.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji... and you thought I was about to punish you because it was a single kanji vocab word. Now get over here. Time for a dirty spanking for thinking such a thing.

context-en: Actually, it’s sort of an embarrassing story, but my father is so perverted that he was caught in a massive child porn ring.
meaning-exp: Your appearance is strange. You're abnormal. Oh, and you're a pervert because you look so abnormal. Though you could just be a caterpillar going through your metamorphosis to become a butterfly. You just look really weird while the changing is going on.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the opportunity to make this presentation about our policies today.
meaning-exp: A plan made by the government is usually known as a policy. "The government passed a policy prohibiting the use of guns on zombies, dooming us all."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: On your mark, get set, go!
meaning-exp: Go ahead and put a rank on something. This one is rank #1, so its position is up higher. Then you put a rank #67 on something. That one's position is lower.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Your poor posture is probably causing your neck pain.
meaning-exp: Put a force on your figure to make it into a certain shape. This is your posture.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Presentation, Submission, Filing, Handing In, Turning In
context-en: Could you tell me what a Tofugu writer applicant needs to submit and what skills are required?
meaning-exp: Go ahead and present then exit. This will be your presentation of the materials.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Look, he loved his job as president here. And let’s face it, you’re not gonna find anyone who did it as well as he did it. Isn’t that true?
meaning-exp: When you big unite in a territory you need a great leader. Someone like a president, perhaps?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well

context-en: The cost is a little too high.
meaning-exp: When you value status you really care about how much the price of things are. The more things cost, the more you value them.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: In Japan, it seems that prices have begun to go up.
meaning-exp: Things with value have prices. This is just the general prices of things.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ?? changes to ??, though, so hopefully that doesn't change the price you're willing to pay for this vocab? Right? Please give me your money.

context-en: This item doesn't have a price tag.
context-en2: The king always buys stuff without looking at the price tags and the queen gets angry at him.
context-en3: After checking the price tag, I decided not to buy it.
meaning-exp: A price tag is... a price tag!
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too.

context-en: My parents own a private green onion garden.
meaning-exp: Anything that's privately managed is private and privately run.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "So what did you think of the proposal?" "Well, I think it was just okay."
meaning-exp: Please present your plan in the form of a proposition.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Public, Government Run, Run By The Government
context-en: If your income is really low, you may be able to live in a cheap public apartment.
meaning-exp: Something that is publicly managed is something that is public aka government run. Compare this to ?? which is private / privately run.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Could you tell me when Japanese land prices are announced each year?
meaning-exp: Please indicate this in a public way. How about a public announcement?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Could you send me the receipt for the Tofugu products I bought from you last week?
meaning-exp: Please accept this territory. Oh, you want some writing to make the deal official? Okay, here's a receipt.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Superman rushed food and fresh water to that region.
meaning-exp: The region that is this ground is the region / area. Just think of each area of ground. Each area is each region.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My father's various experiences led to his resignation.
context-en2: Motivation became resignation before long.
context-en3: You are too young to be resigned.
meaning-exp: When you give up and just try to enjoy the view, that's resignation. You know things aren't going well, and you know you can't do anything about it now, so you resign yourself to what's to come.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Run By The City, City Run
context-en: Osaka City built a very unique, city run incineration plant in Maeshima.
meaning-exp: Something that is managed by the city is run by the city / city run.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Run By The Prefecture, Prefecture Run
context-en: Fugu was scolded for making out with Salmon in the prefectural library by a librarian.
meaning-exp: Prefecture managed things are run by the prefecture.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: As a side business, my boyfriend works for a company using multi-level marketing techniques.
meaning-exp: A side business is a side business.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Can I have a sightseeing brochure?
meaning-exp: Let's go view some sunlight! Oh wait, we can't do that here. We will have to go sightseeing to go see this amazing sunlight thing.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Hey, your sleeve seems dirty.
context-en2: This polo shirt's sleeves are so short that people mistakenly thought they had none.
context-en3: I can't tell anyone that I almost got hit by a car because I couldn't stop staring at the blood vessels that were showing on my senpai's arms from under his sleeves.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You only wear sleeves because your soap is dead (??). If it wasn't, you would go sleeveless forever! But, your soap is dead, so you have stinky armpits, which you hide in these sleeves.

context-en: I haven’t picked out a souvenir yet.
meaning-exp: Are you visiting a neat place? Grab some dirt and bring it back with you. Then pretend to give birth to it in front of your friends. That dirt is now a special souvenir! It's the best present you could ever give someone!
reading-exp: These readings are exceptions, sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you: When someone asks you who gave you a souvenir, just say "Miya gave (???) it to me." Who's Miya? No idea. But neither do they. You never have to remember who gave you anything ever again! Miya gave you everything you own. She's probably a great person.

context-en: Her writing is very subjective but that’s what makes it so very unique.
meaning-exp: People mainly view things through a lens of subjectivity. People mainly look at things from their own point of view and biases. It's hard to take a step back from yourself and lose that subjectivity.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I came up with a killer subheading for my book last night.
meaning-exp: The side topic is the subtitle or subheading.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Who the heck is that enthusiastic and vocal supporter?
meaning-exp: You must respond with aid in order to show your support for someone who needs it. You can usually show your support if you root for them.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Thank you for your hearty and farty support.
meaning-exp: To support and aid is to support.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That cute Shiba came towards Koichi wagging its tail and jumped on him.
meaning-exp: Your butt tail is just your tail, though I wonder why they had to specify that it was your butt tail. Where else do you have a tail, I wonder?
reading-exp: The reading for this word is a bit of an exception. You kind of already know the reading for ? from the kun'yomi ?? you learned already. Here it gets shortened to ??. The reading for ? is totally different from what you learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The animal with the best tail in the world is the polar (?) bear. They're stubby and white and cute. Only polar bears have tails like that!

context-en: My parents taught me how to be a kind person when I was little, but they were arrested on charges of tax evasion.
meaning-exp: To undress your taxes is to throw them away. Just throw it out, who needs 'em? I'm not going to pay these taxes, therefore I am committing tax evasion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Tentatively, For Now, Just In Case
context-en: For now I made a backup of all the data on this hard drive, just in case.
meaning-exp: Okay, only one response for that, and that is that tentatively we have an agreement... for now. Just think of the one response you have, and that one response is to just get everyone off your back, so you agree with them... for now.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We don’t want to touch on the territorial disputes between nations on our blog.
meaning-exp: The soil that makes up your territory is your territory. Ain't nobody goin' set foot on my soil nuh'uh.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Why won’t you just obediently say thank you?
meaning-exp: Some people have a difficult time saying thank you. But not you now that you know how! Did you know this is an abbreviation of ????????? You can also spell it like this: ???.
reading-exp: You've heard people say ????? before right?!

context-en: The kids criticized their parents for hiding the scandal.
meaning-exp: Know how ?? is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word to criticize.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word ?? to start.

context-en: The criminal, who had received a heavy sentence, broke out of prison.
meaning-exp: You undress and run out of that room. You had to take off your clothes in order to escape, but now you can run and start to flee. Just imagine some sort of contraption that holds you in place via your clothes, and you need to escape from it by taking said clothes off. Now imagine running away from that place naked. Escape!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ?? changes to ??, though, so be careful of that.

vocab-meaning: To Exceed, To Be Over, To Surpass
context-en: He is too classy for me.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surpass so the verb vocab version is to surpass or to exceed.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order to surpass your rivals you will have to sue (?) them. You're bad at this sort of thing, so you have to cheat.

context-en: I think that life after death exists.
meaning-exp: Know how ?? is existence? Well, make it a verb and then you have to exist.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Get Knocked Over, To Get Knocked Down, To Collapse
context-en: The marathon runner collapsed from exhaustion right before the finish line.
meaning-exp: You've seen how ?? is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very rare (??) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself.
reading-exp: The reading is the same like ??. If you knew ?? you will know the reading of this one too.

context-en: Even if you die, don't give up on learning kanji!
context-en2: Koichi finally abandoned his dream of becoming a Pokemon master.
context-en3: Doing a mountain of reviews without giving up or resetting—it's a difficult choice.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give up or abandon so the verb version is to give up or to abandon.
reading-exp: Just before you're ready to give up on something, you yell, "AKIRA (???)!" You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky. I just did it while trying to write this mnemonic!

context-en: The restroom is straight and to the left.
meaning-exp: You know that ??? is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add ? you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the toilet or restroom or bathroom. Ewww. Poop goes there.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ???, so if you know that you'll know this too!

context-en: Don’t promise me anything. Actions speak louder than words.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means indicate so the verb vocab version is to indicate or to show. This isn't used for "showing" a physical thing, this is more like when "a study shows that ...."
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Studies seem to indicate that She-man (??) is way more powerful than her boyfriend He-man. I mean, to show you I can just point to her. Look how much bigger her sword and biceps are. Why didn't She-man get her own show?

vocab-meaning: To Let Fly, To Send Flying
context-en: Fugu sent a triple flying over center field.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is to fly? This is when you make some thing fly. So, this word is to let fly or to send flying. You can remember this because you use your massive strength to let fly a bus (??). You're that buff.
reading-exp: The reading is just like ??, so if you know that reading you can figure out this one.

vocab-meaning: To Make Sure Of, To Verify, To Confirm, To Make Certain
context-en: You should make sure the door is properly locked.
meaning-exp: Like with ??, which means certain, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going to make sure of something or you're going to verify something.
reading-exp: This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with ???, you should know this one!

context-en: This new site will overwhelm other Japanese language sites.
meaning-exp: The pressure used easily collapses whatever it's pushing against. That's why this verb means to overwhelm.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ?? goes to ??, as you'd probably expect.

context-en: Koichi punished the employees who leaked Tofugu’s secrets.
meaning-exp: When you do a penalty to someone you are trying to punish or to penalize them.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Just remember that the ? becomes a small ? so I don't have to punish you.

vocab-meaning: To Put Down, To Set Down, To Place
context-en: Fugu and I are putting some distance between us right now.
meaning-exp: When you put something you don't just put it, you have to put down this item or even (to) set down the item. Basically, you have to put something down with this verb. It's a little different from the kanji meaning you learned but not that different.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just imagine you're putting down Oreos (?). One after another. Each oreo that you try to put down say in your head "Hello Mr. Oreo, I'm going to put you down.. ooh yes, you like that don't you?" REPEAT.

vocab-meaning: To Reside, To Stay, To Remain
context-en: What do foreigners need when they stay in Japan?
meaning-exp: If ?? is residence, then the verb version of that would be to reside.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? so you should be able to read this one already!

context-en: Do you think they will respond to our request for a 20 percent discount?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means respond so the verb vocab version is to respond.
reading-exp: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji! Not too shabby.

vocab-meaning: To Run A Business, To Manage A Business
context-en: My parents run a massage therapy business, so I can get ’all-you-can-take-massages’ at home.
meaning-exp: The kanji means manage, but when you manage something, what are you usually managing? How about a business? So this word means to run a business even though the kanji is manage.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to run a business. Your business is to make people eat who don't want to eat. "HEY, YOU EAT NOW!" (???).

vocab-meaning: To Shake, To Shiver, To Quake, To Tremble, To Quaver, To Quiver
context-en: My alcoholic father’s hands always shake.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earthquake so the verb means to shiver and to shake, like you would if there was an earthquake happening right now.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You start to shake in an earthquake because you're really full (??) from eating lunch. Now your full belly is shaking and quaking with the ground! Ahh it's awful! You never want to be full again!

vocab-meaning: To Sleep, To Go To Bed, To Lie Down
context-en: Alright, I’m gonna go to bed. Sleep well. See you in the morning.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lie down so the verb vocab version is to lie down, but what you're really doing is trying to sleep.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. So, you can go ahead and lie down for a moment before moving on to the next item.

vocab-meaning: To Smoke, To Suck, To Inhale
context-en: I’m going to quit smoking once and for all.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suck so the verb vocab version is to suck, but it's usually used to talk about what you do to cigarettes, so a better translation I think is to smoke.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You smoke too much, and that gives you cancer. You decide to sue (?) the cigarette makers.

vocab-meaning: To Undress, To Take Off Clothes
context-en: "Alright, I’ll take my clothes off no matter what the temperature is." "Good! That’s the spirit."
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means undress and the verb is to undress.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to undress your goal is to become nude (?).

vocab-meaning: To View, To Spectate, To Watch
context-en: I can’t decide which movie to watch.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means view so what is the verb vocab version? It's to view. This is mainly used for spectators who are viewing something.
reading-exp: The reading here is actually the same as ??. This is easy to remember because the meanings are so similar too, not to mention it has a ? right inside the kanji itself!

context-en: What was the name of that traditional Japanese costume we saw yesterday? I completely forget the word.
meaning-exp: When you transmit something that unites the people, you are probably pulling on tradition. Tradition is what unites us all and transmits who we are to everyone else. What is your ???
reading-exp: The reading is ?? for ?, which you've seen a few times by now. For ? it's just the reading you've learned.

context-en: Cutting the grass with a sickle every day is such a bother.
meaning-exp: Something is a trouble (??) and it is smelly (??). So what is something that's smelly and a trouble? Well, something that's troublesome or a bother, I suppose. Basically you can ignore the smelly part. For some reason someone threw that back in, but smelly things are a bother, I suppose.
reading-exp: The reading is the words ?? plus ?? added together. Just make sure you know those words and you'll know this one too!

context-en: I thought learning Japanese would be very difficult for me, but unexpectedly, it actually wasn’t that bad.
meaning-exp: Something that happens outside the plan is something that happens unexpectedly.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Do you think the day will one day come when all countries are united under one government?
meaning-exp: Unite and join together. It is unification time. Integration!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Put'm together.

context-en: I’m always filled with disgust when I talk with you.
meaning-exp: Bad feelings that you dislike are unpleasant feelings. These unpleasant feelings include things like hatred, disgust, revulsion, and fear. All of those are considered to be a part of the term unpleasant feelings.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already so you should be able to read this one too!

context-en: I can’t agree with this price. It’s just not right.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Okay, this is a great value. Wait, what is? A tie (???). Get a tie, and it will make you more professional which will help you to get a better job. Great value, right there, just for a tie.

context-en: A life without computers isn’t worth living.
meaning-exp: A value and a value. Obviously this is something that has much value.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: A down quilt is expensive, as I expected.
meaning-exp: The value is the value, though it's also the price.
reading-exp: If you want to find out how much value a horse has, you just have to make it neigh. If the horse can't neigh, you know you can lower the price you were going to pay. This works with other things you want to buy too. Don't spend too much on a pair of socks or sunglasses if they can't neigh. #Lifehack

context-en: The crime was so brutal that not only the victim’s family, but everyone else, is hoping that the judge will sentence him with the ultimate punishment.
meaning-exp: The someones (people) who incur damage are the victims. WILL SOMEBODY THINK OF THE VICTIMS HERE???
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word ?? as well.

context-en: What’s this Wisteria Combo on the menu?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned! Now you just have to make sure you know what a Wisteria is... This word is often found in names, like a lot, so look out for it in that way.

context-en: When plants get water, how long does it take for them to absorb it?
meaning-exp: You suck something in and obtain it. Shhheewwwwww! When you suck something in and obtain it into your body, you have done absorption because it's been sucked inside of you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That actress’ acting ability is magnificent.
meaning-exp: Your performance skill allows you to be great at acting and doing awesome performances.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My boyfriend is the actor performing the part of the horse.
meaning-exp: A superior haiku requires someone really famous and well known to read it... it's just on that level. Who is super well known and who deserves to read this superior haiku? A great actor, perhaps?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: A homeless guy said seriously, "I’d like to try to win the award for best actor."
meaning-exp: A man who is superior to you is someone who's super famous and awesome like Brad Pitt. What is Brad Pitt besides a superior man? He is also an actor.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Didn’t you actually say that a while ago?
meaning-exp: The present time is the time you're actually in. You aren't really in any other time, because that's not how time works!
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: I got a lot of money this month.
meaning-exp: Swamps and mountains happen a lot in Japan. That's why we use this to mean many! Because there are many of them!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. This word is usually written in kana though, so keep that in mind when you're writing it to use kana and not these kanji!

context-en: The lawyer, Goodman, faked an illness because he didn’t want to see Walt.
meaning-exp: A samurai who uses speech to defend people. This samurai does their battle in the court of law. This "samurai" is an attorney or a lawyer.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I could hear nothing, save for the rolling thunder of a Shinkansen passing by.
meaning-exp: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading first. Technically this is the "New Tree Trunk Line" but you wouldn't realize this is the Japanese bullet train aka Shinkansen from that, would you? Maybe going to the reading will help you after all.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Read this to be able to remember the meaning, too, which is Shinkansen.

context-en: Is this bus going to stop at the bus stop? Hey, is this bus going to stop at the bus stop!? Yo, bus driver! Are you deaf?
meaning-exp: This is where the bus (??) halts. It's the bus stop.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I started reading Naoya Shiga’s novel, "At Cape Kinosaki" today.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: If I won the lottery, I would build my own castle in the back yard.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: You should stop flip-flopping on important issues in the committee, it’s irresponsible. Everyone finds it annoying.
meaning-exp: There are member(s) of a committee (??) all getting together to meet. This is the committee itself.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know ?? as well, since it's 2/3rds of the word.

context-en: He expressed his understanding with a weak nod and walked away.
meaning-exp: When you've finished solving something, you've come to a point of comprehension and understanding. Also, used in (often radio) communication to signify you know what's up. It's like saying "roger!"
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My parents are both teachers and extremely old-fashioned conservatives.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "-ism." Add that ism to people who want to protect and conserve their country so it stays just the way it is (forever). That's conservatism and they're conservative people.
reading-exp: This word uses the reading of ??? for the first half and then the regular kanji readings for the second half. Combine those things and you'll be a master of righteousness and / or kanji.

context-en: Hey! Stop this weak act and show us your true form, you demon!
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Demons are mean. This particular demon bites you on the knee, creating an "O" shape on your knee. He tells you he has cursed you with the "O" knee (??).

context-en: I made a mistake on such a simple division problem.
meaning-exp: Divide and calculate? Why, that's just division!
reading-exp: This is the kun'yomi reading for ? and the on'yomi for ?. And the ?? reading is rendaku'd into ??. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

context-en: That doctor appeared on TV twice, though just for short amounts of time.
meaning-exp: A medicine expert is someone who knows a lot about medicine. Those people are (I hope) generally doctors.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Even in modern times, many Japanese homes continue to use tatami mats.
meaning-exp: Your dwelling house is your dwelling (or residence).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I work full time five days a week and part time six days a week because I’m in a tough financial situation.
meaning-exp: ?? is economics. So, something that has to do with economics is the economic or financial situation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know ?? as well.
kanji-name: Passage of Time, Come To An End, Target

context-en: I don’t know the first thing about economics, so I decided to go to school.
meaning-exp: You know how ?? is economics, right? Well, add study to that and you have the study of economics, aka economics.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know ?? as well.
kanji-name: Passage of Time, Come To An End, Study

context-en: I met a guy online who is in his thirties and has a job, but he also has a kid.
meaning-exp: When you have employment you are probably employed.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Do you remember who is responsible for the enforcement of this law?
meaning-exp: When you go to carry out something, you are carrying it out. That's why this is carry out (that is ???). Alternatively, when you go carry out something, you are making sure something is getting done. You are doing enforcement on that thing that you're carrying out on.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Another alternative reading is ???, which is more often used when talking about something law related.

context-en: I'm jealous of people who can speak Japanese fluently.
context-en2: I'm envious of you for being successful in business and looking good in sunglasses.
context-en3: If I told my little sister that I got a boyfriend I think she would be jealous.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with hiragana that ends in an ?, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of envy? It's also envious!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading, so you should be able to read this already!

context-en: Last night in my dream, our baby told me that it’s time for her baby teeth to come out and she can’t express in words how itchy they are.
meaning-exp: When you express something that's of the present time, you are saying something that only people of the current time understand. These are expressions or figure of speech. You say these things during the present time, not the future, not the past, the present time. Otherwise nobody would understand.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I don’t want to do anything extravagant for my twentieth birthday. All I want to do is read a good book.
meaning-exp: A luxury swamp. Really? You got yourself a luxury swamp? That's not even a thing, not to mention probably really expensive. You are being too extravagant.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Wearing false eyelashes isn’t fair. Don’t you think you almost look like a different person.
meaning-exp: An anti rule is when you break the rules. It's when you do a foul.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Fugu is a bit on the wild side, but very kind despite his appearance.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of gentle? It's gentle (but also kind or warm hearted).
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do people who are gentle and kind say when someone asks of them a favor? Always "yessir" (??). Always, always "yessir"!

context-en: She is a bit careless, but she’s a very good guide.
meaning-exp: Take your finger and lead with it. Just point at things. Tell people where they need to go, what they need to do, all with your finger leading them. This is guidance you are providing.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

context-en: The haiku he composed today was so romantic, wasn’t it?
meaning-exp: A haiku paragraph is just a haiku. Haikus are little haiku paragraphs. You will learn kanji The Crabigator watches He feeds on reviews
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The camel was delivered by the express home delivery company today.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go home now.

context-en: If I take the job overseas, my income will probably be half what it is now.
meaning-exp: Please enter what you've obtained in here. We'll divvy it all up later. But we have to enter it all here so we know our income.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’d like to quit my job at the children’s nursing home because it’s too hard, but, at the same time, I don’t want to go burning any bridges.
meaning-exp: Go ahead and carry out the task and establish the institution. To carry out and establish something is to institute it too. What do you institute? An institution.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Don’t worry about being unemployed. I’ve been job hunting for almost two years now.
meaning-exp: Ugh, time to request employment again. Time to go job hunting.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I heard that there is a disease affecting children called Kawasaki Disease, but what kind of disease is it?
meaning-exp: This is one of those words that's easier to know if you jump to the reading first. Why? Because it's the name of a city / a name. It's Kawasaki.
reading-exp: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, making it Kawasaki.

context-en: If you can memorize every legal term within one month, I will pay you a million dollars.
meaning-exp: Though there's no law about two kanji with the same meaning producing the same meaning, a law law is probably a law.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Fugu bought crocodile skin sandals in Japan.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Leather is the skin of a cow, right? How do you say "skin" in Japanese? Remember ? aka ??? It has the same reading as that, and they're both skin, so hopefully that makes it easier to remember.

context-en: After washing it several times, my leather jacket’s color has started to fade. Now I’m wondering if I was even supposed to wash it.
meaning-exp: Skin leather is really just leather because leather is also skin. It's also hides.
reading-exp: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

context-en: The local train has just passed through a tunnel.
meaning-exp: A car that halts at each station. These trains aren't the big and fast ones, they're the local trains, and you'll need to ride them to get to smaller stations.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "Good morning. Here’s your milk." "Oh, thanks. That hits the spot. There’s nothing like a great glass of milk to start the day."
meaning-exp: Cow milk is cow's milk, though most people just call cow's milk milk.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I saw a gigantic alligator near a swamp in Florida.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word also means mountain stream. Think of it this way, the water for a swamp has to come from somewhere right? It starts out up in the mountains and drains out into a swamp in the valley. The life cycle of a mountain stream into a swamp!
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The beginning of the word swamp is actually pretty similar to this word's reading. ?? = "swa"? I'd say it's close enough to make a mnemonic out of in your head.

context-en: I bought some Nagasaki sponge cake for you as a souvenir.
meaning-exp: This word will be easier if you jump to the reading, since it's the name of a place, Nagasaki.
reading-exp: The ? is the kun'yomi reading, which comes from ??. The ? part is the same reading that you learned with the kanji (though also kun'yomi). Combine those together and you have ????. Sound familiar? It should. This is the city of Nagasaki, one of the cities in which the A-bombs fell.

context-en: When I saw all the blood spurting out of your nipples, I couldn’t help but panic!
meaning-exp: What is a milk neck? Think about where milk comes from. Now, think of what looks like a little neck on the thing that milk comes from. What is that thing? It's a nipple.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is an exception, at least for the ? part. It's read as ?, and ? is read as ??. You can remember the reading of nipple by thinking of a very special "nipple" you have on your face. A bee has burrowed into your cheek, and it squirts out milk from its butt, which sticks out of your cheek. You can't get it out, so you've decided to call this little cheek bee nipple your cheek bee (???). Buzz buzz *milk*

context-en: The nurse faked a laugh to her patient.
meaning-exp: An expert who watches over and defends people at all hours is the nurse. That's what nurses do, 24/7. They have to check up on people, defend their health, and watch over them, making sure they're okay. What a tough job.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Is her occupation being a model? She comes out really well in photos.
meaning-exp: Your employment business is your occupation. What is your employment business?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Let’s face it, Fugu. Salmon hasn’t fallen in love with you, yet. But I can turn that around! You should invite her to your home this weekend.
meaning-exp: Your self home is your own home. It's one's home.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There isn’t a more optimistic guy than him.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "-ism." If you add that to being comfortable like you're in heaven then you have lots of optimism. You're sure you'll be okay in any situation!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Where can I buy tickets to the performance?
meaning-exp: A performance art is a performance. It is entertainment! Lights, action! Welcome to Broadway!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Can you tell me the time of the Lion King performance?
meaning-exp: When you perform above the stage it's a performance. This word is usually used for musical and theatrical performances.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I’m not a teacher, but I am part of the school staff.
meaning-exp: The members of employment in your business are your personnel or staff. You employed them, so they're your personnel!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If a rabbit jumps straight up in the cabin of a high speed train, according to the law of inertia, it will land in the same place.
meaning-exp: It's both a law and a rule. This usually refers to something that is a physical law, but also can simply be a law, too. Anyways, lots of rules. Lots of laws. It's both, so the stronger one (law) takes precedence.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Place Of Work, Workplace, Place Of Employment
context-en: If you want to stay in this workplace, you’ve got to quit your habit of making everything out to be big deal.
meaning-exp: Your employment location is your place of work or place of employment. It's also your workplace.
reading-exp: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. So, are you playing WaniKani at your ?? right now? Wouldn't that be funny.

vocab-meaning: Power Outage, Cutoff Of Electricity, Power Cut
context-en: Why do I keep flipping light switches on and off if I know that there is still a power outage.
meaning-exp: When you halt electricity you experience a power outage. Makes sense. When the electricity stops you don't have any more power.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Good morning, your breakfast is ready!
meaning-exp: I will provide you with the standard things you need. You can use these for your preparations. It's what everyone gets and it's what you will get too. If it helps, imagine getting some actual things, and use them to prepare for something else. Imagine everyone else getting these standard things to prepare with too.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How many emails are you getting a day now?
meaning-exp: In the present time we exist. What time is it? It's present and now. It is the current time!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I knew nothing about her except that she worked in the prime minister’s office.
meaning-exp: The prime minister's (??) government is where he does all his governmenting. It's where the Prime Minister's office is located as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know ?? beforehand as well.

context-en: We should put priority on developing a new flavor of bacon.
meaning-exp: It was superior previously, so we need to go back there. That, amongst all the other things, is our highest priority.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: In Japan, noodles that contain one hundred percent buckwheat flour are called Juwari-soba.
meaning-exp: Divide then join something back together. When you join it back together, it won't be whole again, but you can see the two parts you divided apart. You can also compare them and see which is bigger and by how much. You can easily find the ratio this way, too.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

context-en: "For God’s sake, face reality! This isn’t cake, it’s poop!"
meaning-exp: The present is the truth. It is what's going on right now. It is reality.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’d like to return this. Here’s the receipt.
meaning-exp: I obtain some territory, so I want a written record of it. How will I get a written record of my obtained territory? How about with a receipt? Emailing one will do just fine.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My boss told me flat-out that I was disposable, so I left the company.
meaning-exp: If you quit your place of employment, you are quitting, aka putting in your resignation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The situation changed for the better after the revolution.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This morning, I saw a lot of rabbits jumping rhythmically in my garden.
meaning-exp: The law of movement is governed by rhythm. Imagine moving around to a boss beat. As you move, you start to feel the rhythm in your step. Go ahead and walk around your room and feel this rhythm. Note that ??? is probably going to be more common of a word to use for rhythm, but this is a kanji learning site after all. One thing you will see more often is ??? which means "rhythmic."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The internet will play a more important role in future elections.
meaning-exp: Let's divide the duty up amongst various people. Each person will have their own role in completing this duty.
reading-exp: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. See how we divide up the duty of learning kanji into radicals and kanji and vocab? Makes it nice, right? Each piece is its own ??.

context-en: "Those are the rules. Understand?" "I understand."
meaning-exp: A standard rule is just one of the rules or regulations. Nothing weird about these rules.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I swear I followed the rules and didn’t drink, not even a drop.

context-en: Let’s hope that what actually happened at the scene of the crime will come to light soon.

reading-exp: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

context-en: He may have a strong sense of responsibility, but to me he seemed a little rude and selfish.
meaning-exp: ?? is responsibility. If you add ? you get a "feeling of responsibility." That's not really a thing people say. What people do say, however, is sense of responsibility. Do you have one?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You remember these long speeches well.

reading-exp: The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you: The only font the machine can print speeches in is serif font (???).
