context-en: I don’t like that teacher because he is always flip-flopping on historical facts.
meaning-exp: A teaching expert/teacher is a teacher.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: "This blowfish is too expensive. Can you give me a discount?" "We’ll give you a 10% discount."
meaning-exp: One division is ten percent. You'll just have to imagine this in terms of tens going by. Must be some old Japanese percentage system that carried over or something. Just remember that one wari is ten percent, two waris are twenty percent, and so on.
reading-exp: The readings are the same as what you learned with the kanji. You know much more than ten percent of this word's reading already.

context-en: My cat will probably appear around mealtime.
meaning-exp: The kanji means present time, but when something "does present time" it is making itself known in the present time. It is showing itself. When it does present time, it causes it to appear or to emerge (as in right now, during the present time).
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It looks like something is going to appear in front of you. You are so scared and surprised you can't even speak properly: "Are what??" (???) you ask, trying to figure out what's appearing in front of you.

context-en: He saved your life so you should invite him to your birthday party.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call so the verb vocab version is to call or to call out. As in "HEY, YOU!"
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you should be good here. Just imagine yourself calling out to someone: "YO (?)! You!"

context-en: I was so relieved when I confirmed that our company finally got out of the red.
meaning-exp: ?? is confirmation. When that's a verb, you have to confirm or to verify.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help immensely if you know the word ?? already as well.

context-en: The bird pecking at worms over there is actually an endangered bird species and is to be protected worldwide.
meaning-exp: To Preserve and defend something is to conserve and to protect. I won't let you destroy this land I'm trying to protect!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My boyfriend gave me a hard candy after harshly criticizing me.
meaning-exp: ?? is criticism so the verb version of that would be to criticize.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will be much easier to read this if you know ??, as well.

context-en: Take into account that you don’t know what you could do while you’re drunk, so you should really cut yourself off from drinking alcohol.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off so the verb vocab version is to cut off. Don't confuse this with ?? which means "to refuse." You know this is to cut off because of the ?, which hints that you have had two (?) too many chocolates, and it's time to cut you off.
reading-exp: URGH! The reading isn't even the same as ??, how frustrating. To Cut Off is read as ??. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater tots (??). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have to cut off tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.

vocab-meaning: To Divide, To Split, To Break
context-en: It took me an hour to figure out that 7 divided by 2 equals 3 with a remainder of 1.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means divide so the verb vocab version is to divide.
reading-exp: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you'll use here. It's the ? one, though, making it ??.

context-en: We elect a Tofugu Chairman every year.
meaning-exp: Election is ?? so when you make that word into a verb, you have to elect.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, the reading just comes from ?? so if you know that you know this as well.

vocab-meaning: To Examine, To Inspect, To Check
context-en: If you use this coupon, you can save ten dollars when you get your blood checked.
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is inspection, so the verb version of that would be to inspect.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know ?? already as well.

context-en: The only thing I excel at is picking my nose. In fact, I have never made my nose bleed.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means excel so the verb vocab version is to excel.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "He-e (??) is going to excel," you stutter. "He-e is!"

context-en: I swear I didn’t do anything. I was just running some errands there for my dad this morning.
meaning-exp: Remember ?? and how it means "to come to an end." This is like that, but slightly different. This is to finish or to settle, because this is when you're doing the coming to an end action. You can remember this because you're coming in to finish the score uno mas (??) time. This is the last time.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with ??, so if you know that you'll be able to finish this vocab.

context-en: I save all my homework for the weekend so I can spend more time with my family on weekdays.
meaning-exp: Remember how ??? is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means to increase something. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (??) to increasing something, and did it yourself.
reading-exp: The reading is the same like ???. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.

context-en: It came out that the man is a murderer, but the statute of limitations already ran out, so no one is legally able to place judgement on him.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means judge so the verb version is to judge.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to judge people, there are different types. The one you truly hate the most, however, is the sobber (??). "The Sobber" is the worst kind. They just sob and sob and sob and it's really hard to move on to your next judging.

context-en: Judging from what I’ve heard, the best seems to have been saved for last.
meaning-exp: ?? is judgement. Make that into a verb and you have to judge.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know ?? before learning this, but if you don't I won't judge you (the Crabigator will).

vocab-meaning: To Know, To Understand, To Be Aware Of, To Consent, To Agree
context-en: Does anyone know who this woman is?
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ?? means "knowledge"? Well the verb version of that is to know. (You know it deep in your heart.)
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I think you misunderstand my father. He’s not the type of person who would lead someone into committing a heinous crime.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lead so the verb vocab version is to lead.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is a bit difficult, but there's a hint in the kanji. See the ? in there on the top? What's the reading for the vocab version of that kanji? It's ??. That's the first part. Now, who are you leading? Let's say you're leading a bee back to its nest, via the road. It's a ? Bee (???)!

context-en: I am very honored to be able to play such an important role.
meaning-exp: If ? is performance then the verb version of this would be to perform.
reading-exp: The reading looks weird, but it's actually just the reading you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: To Provide, To Furnish, To Equip, To Prepare For
context-en: Brace yourself and prepare for your opponent’s attack!
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means provide so the verb vocab version is to provide.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to provide your friends with their own sauna (??) because they don't want to use your shower. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.

vocab-meaning: To Raise, To Elevate, To Bring Up
context-en: I held my wedding ceremony in city hall, but I’m not ashamed of that.
meaning-exp: Remember ???, which means "to rise"? Well, this word means to raise or to elevate, and this time you're the one doing the raising.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.

vocab-meaning: To Solve, To Solve Something, To Untie, To Untie Something
context-en: I like untying the bows on presents.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means solve so the verb vocab version is to solve. It also means to untie and you know this verb is when you are doing the actual untying because you think it's super coo' (?) to untie things, which is why you do it nonstop.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???, so if you know that you can read this one too.

speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Godan verb
context-en: Who put up the volleyball net?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch so the verb version is to stretch.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine yourself trying to stretch (or better yet stand up and do it). Every time you stretch you start to laugh uncontrollably. HA (?) HA HA HA HA HA. Go ahead and laugh like that out loud while you stretch, it will help you to remember this reading.

context-en: I understand you love him, but I can’t forgive him for kissing you.
meaning-exp: ?? is understanding, so the verb version would be...? How about to understand or to comprehend? Well, do you?
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know ?? already this one is easy to comprehend.

context-en: You should remove the ivy winding around the tree trunk.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: When you cut the tree down to produce a tree trunk, out jumps Mickey Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.

context-en: This piggy bank contains the eighty dollars I’ve saved from my allowance, but I guess it is not close to enough to file a lawsuit.
meaning-exp: You're going to get judged times two. Judge and judge again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole trial here.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ?? goes to ?? though, so be careful.

context-en: He would be the perfect husband, save for one thing - he has been unemployed for ten years.
meaning-exp: When the status of your employment is "nothing" then you're probably experiencing unemployment.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That vampire told me that he wouldn’t even suck my blood because I am too much of a phony.

reading-exp: ?? should be easy for you to read. The ? part uses the reading you already learned with the kanji, ?. Easy, no?

context-en: "Don’t sell yourself short like that. You’re a magnificent woman."
meaning-exp: An element of clear up (like the sky clearing up!) is so wonderful and splendid. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome.
reading-exp: The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, you've learned both of them already. ??? is ???. That's the reading you use here, though ? goes to ?.

context-en: As stated above, both employees and employers can terminate an employment contract at any time for any reason.
meaning-exp: Above mentions are above mentioned. Look above to see where I mentioned it, okay?

context-en: I cut off the snail’s antennae because I didn’t know its eyes are on the tips of them.
meaning-exp: The angle of the touch is important with an antenna. Think about antennas. An ant's antenna wiggle around and move in different angles, touching things, to understand the world around them. Imagine their tiny bug antennas touching your arm to figure out who you are.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. ??? goes to ???.

context-en: "What do you think of Fugu?" "To be honest, I don’t like him. I prefer a guy with muscular arms like Kinnikuma."
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: "Can I bring a friend to your birthday party?" "Of course! The more people we have, the more fun it will be."
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is birth? If you add day on there, you have a birthday. Happy birthday!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but with this word ? uses the kun'yomi ?, which is turned into ? due to rendaku.

context-en: She was in a car accident when she was just about to head off to Tokyo, and now she is getting a blood transfusion in the hospital.
meaning-exp: Transport of blood. Only time you do this is during a blood transfusion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning-exp: Both arms are both arms!

You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You walk up to the boundary. You're there to pick something up to take it across. This thing you're smuggling across the boundary is a sockeye (???) salmon. You take it across the boundary and sell it for a big profit.

meaning-exp: You lose. Because of that, you have to carry this burden and responsibility.

Remember this by thinking how much children love domo-kun. Also, ??? is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. ?? is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. It's still used quite a bit though, but the second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.

context-en: If you opened a sealed envelope marked "Confidential" without permission, it could be considered as an unlawful opening of a letter and you could be punished with imprisonment with work detail for under one year, or a fine of up to 200,000 yen.

You know this one is "to be delivered" (aka it's just getting delivered, you aren't doing the delivery) because when this item arrives at your house you say "coo'" (?), it arrived.

vocab-meaning: To Be Published, To Be Reported, To Be Printed
context-en: My interview as the representative of the entry-level employees was published in the spring edition of the company newsletter.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means publish so the verb vocab version is to be published. Books can be published, magazines can be published, and I guess even your gross blog posts get published too.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Hey, were you able to be published yet?" someone asks, and the answer is always NO (?)! It's never your time to get published. The answer is always no... because no one likes (sniff) what you write (sob).

context-en: I really like burning things until they’re reduced to ashes.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burn and the verb vocab version is to burn something (or to burn).
reading-exp: This is when you're burning something. To remember this meaning, you have to remember the ? part. So, just think of your friend Moe (?), and how you're going to burn him... uh... just a little bit.

context-en: If I go to Japan, I’d like to carry a portable shrine in a parade.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carry so the verb vocab version is to carry. This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike ?? which is not necessarily literal (you'll learn it later). And in this case, you carry it on your shoulder(s). You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats on your shoulders.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You love to carry things, especially cats (??). You hoist them up onto your shoulders and carry them all around town.

context-en: We are going to a Chinese restaurant to celebrate grandpa’s 60th birthday on Sunday.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you celebrate something, you have to yell out your celebrations. Yell out ??? three times! It's kind of like a combination of the word ?? (good) and "wow." ??wow! ??wow! Just make sure the ?? gets shortened, because it's getting combined.

meaning-exp: A time limit is a time limit.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: This is a great opportunity for all of the workers to absorb knowledge about the new system.
meaning-exp: If ?? is "absorption" the verb version is to absorb.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Our cat is usually in our bedroom upstairs.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means alive so the verb vocab version is to be alive.
reading-exp: Do you know the word ??? This is it. This is when you're referring to the existence of something alive and moving. If you've been studying Japanese up to this point (level 25) you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!

context-en: I was a little sad to reach an age where I can be called a middle-aged woman.
meaning-exp: If ?? is "to call" then this is something similar. This is when you are called by someone (and you're not doing the calling). This word is to be called.
reading-exp: The reading is shared with ??, so remember that and you'll be able to read this too.

vocab-meaning: To Be Caught, To Get Caught
context-en: At first I was just stopped for speeding, but I ended up being caught for drunk driving.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the intransitive verb vocab version is to be caught. This is a literal, physical catch. So, for example, you can catch a criminal using this verb but not catch the drift of an idea, which would be ???, coming up in level 27.
reading-exp: The reading is ??, so to remember that with to be caught, think about how you're a police officer trying to catch some criminals. Unfortunately, they have split up into two cars (??) meaning you won't catch both of them, since you only have one car.

vocab-meaning: To Become Accustomed To, To Get Used To
context-en: Could you bring the hem up for me? I’m not really used to sewing.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accustomed so the verb vocab version is to become accustomed.
reading-exp: What have you become accustomed to? All the Narwhals (?) you hang out with. They take some getting used to.

vocab-meaning: To Be Divided, To Be Separated, To Break
context-en: He needed to poop so badly that he almost broke the door from pounding on it with his fists.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is "to divide"? Now you're learning the similar intransitive version. Instead of you doing the dividing, something just gets divided. This is to be divided.
reading-exp: The reading is shared with ??.

context-en: I’m looking for the most effective medicine for treating lung cancer.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means effective. The verb vocab version is to be effective (since "to effective" doesn't make sense).
reading-exp: What is particularly effective? It's your key (?). It's effective at opening your house door.

vocab-meaning: To Belong To, To Fall Under
context-en: Whose group were you in when you were in grade four?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means belong so the verb vocab version is to belong to.
reading-exp: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. This kanji is going to belong to you.

vocab-meaning: To Be Replaced, To Be Substituted, To Be Switched
context-en: Would you mind switching seats with me? I’m with her and our seats are separate.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace. This word means to be replaced. You can differentiate it from ???, which has you doing the action of replacing, by thinking that with ?? Wario is doing the replacing for you, not you, making this to be replaced.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: "This one will cost about a million yen more." "I still don’t mind. I’ll take it."
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means care so the verb vocab version is to care about.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you care a lot about grammar? I don't care, unless it has to do with commas (??). Then I do flip out.

vocab-meaning: To Catch, To Grasp, To Perceive, To Captivate
context-en: A glass filled halfway with water can be perceived as "half empty" or "half full," depending on the person.
context-en2: It's hard to grasp what Japanese clients are really thinking.
context-en3: Immediately after the show started, the circus troupe captivated the audience's hearts.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the verb version is to catch. Try to remember the mnemonic from the kanji with this one, because this word isn't used for physically catching things, but for ideas or meanings that you are able to grasp, metaphorically speaking.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

vocab-meaning: To Cross, To Cross Over, To Go Across
context-en: After crossing the bridge, please turn right.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit, but when you think about "to transit" this doesn't make too much sense. When you "transit" something, though, you're going across it. That's why this word is to cross or to cross over.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: To Echo, To Reverberate, To Resound
context-en: To win a major contract, we’ll need a great business proposition that resonates in our customers’ hearts.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means echo so the verb is to echo.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: He be (??) echoing... He be (??) echoing... He be (??) echoing... He be (??) echoing... He be (??) echoing...

context-en: Can you leave out the wasabi?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extract so the verb vocab version is to extract.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Just go ahead and extract it out of your memory so you can use it here.

context-en: Let me start off by thanking you all for coming and giving me such a great opportunity to show my presentation.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give so the verb vocab version is to give or to grant.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to give a bone to your dog. Atta (??) boy, Sparky! Atta boy.

context-en: When he handed me the pen my heart was pounding.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are transiting one object over to another person (the word is to hand over), though, so it kind of makes sense. You see the ?? You're suing somebody, so you hand over the papers telling them you're suing them. Don't confuse this with ?? which is "to cross over." ? is sue.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: Since his death, I don’t know where I should hang the picture he gave me.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hang so the verb vocab version is to hang. This is when you hang something, like a picture. You can remember this because you don't really care (??) about where you hang it, as long as you're the one to do it.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

context-en: The entrance to the Secret Garden is hidden.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hide so the verb vocab version is to hide.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Hide your cock (??)! You have a ton of roosters but you don't want people to know about them, so you gotta hide your cocks. What did you think I was talking about?

context-en: What kinds of benefits does a hot spring containing alkali have?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means include so the verb vocab version is to include.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: They don't want to include you in their game? Well, "F*** (??) you!" you yell at them, because they wouldn't include you.

speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Godan verb
context-en: Sugar will make it much sweeter, you know.
meaning-exp: It's another verb with the kanji ?! This one means to increase too! But! These are unconscious increases, whereas ??? are usually for conscious increases.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What increases with time? Your love for your mama (?)! Your love for her will grow and grow the older you get! I love you, mama!

context-en: Of course, your studying of the Japanese language is limited to Tofugu.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means limit so the verb vocab version is to limit.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to limit your use of face cream. I know you have a super kaggy (??) face but if you don't limit your use bad things will happen.

vocab-meaning: To Look Out Over, To Survey, To Sweep, To Glance Over, To Take An Extensive View Of
context-en: The sunflower field went on as far as the eye could see.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji mean see and transit, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are going to transit your eyes over an area to take in what you see. So you're really going to look out over everything. This word is usually used when you're looking at landscapes or a really large area.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Hang in there, you can do this.
meaning-exp: ?? is to stretch. You're stubborn and want to stretch out what you're doing right now. Although you're stubborn, you keep doing it. You persevere. That's why this word is to persevere.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is the reading for ? and ?? put together but the ?? part gets rendaku'd so keep that in mind.

context-en: Finish your breakfast before getting ready.
meaning-exp: You've seen that ?? is preparations. This is the verb version, so you get yourself to prepare.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ??.

vocab-meaning: To Replace, To Substitute, To Switch, To Exchange
context-en: I already asked dad to change the bulb.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace so the verb vocab version is to replace. You know that you're doing the replacing because of the air (??). You're replacing the air as quickly as you can because if you don't you wouldn't be able to breathe in this small room.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: I spend two hours curling my hair, but it still doesn’t curl well.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scroll. But, you don't "to scroll." What do you do to scrolls, though? You roll them up, making this word "to roll" or "to roll up."
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you are rolling up is your ma (?). She's going wild again, so you throw her into a blanket and roll her up to hold her down.

context-en: I’m searching for my grandmother. She has Alzheimer's and hasn’t come home since yesterday.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means search so the verb vocab version is to search for.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're searching all around for a "sagger" (??) on your body. This is a flap of skin that is sagging on your body really far, and you probably should get it removed.

context-en: I knew that she would show her true colors in the end.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means present time, but you can't "to present time." If you try to do present time, the best you can do is try to show it. Kind of a weird connection, but if you think through it a couple times it might get better.
reading-exp: Do you remember learning ???? This has the same exact pronunciation!

vocab-meaning: To Store, To Achieve, To Score, To Finish, To Come Into Power, To Dedicate
context-en: What should I do to finish the fight?
meaning-exp: When you obtain something you need to keep it safe, so you decide to store it somewhere. Then you can always go back and look at the thing you managed to achieve and no one can take it from you.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to store all of the old saws (??). You were able to finish and to achieve everything you wanted with them, so it's time to put them away so they'll be safe.

context-en: My younger brother was strangled by a sheep.
meaning-exp: The kanji means strangle and this vocab is the verb version of that: to strangle. There is another word, ?? which means "to wring out" that looks very similar. You know that this one is "to strangle" because it has ?? sticking out of it. Imagine that in the mail ?? you get a letter that says "I'm going to strangle you!" When you get this in the mail, you know it's about strangling.
reading-exp: The thing that is threatening to strangle you is actually a sheep (?)! The sheep comes to your house and says, "here's the sheep mail!" and then tries to strangle you. It puts its hard feet on your neck though it's pretty ineffective.

vocab-meaning: To Sue, To Accuse, To Appeal, To Complain
context-en: A couple weeks ago, my direct supervisor was let go because many female workers complained about his sexual harassment to the branch office manager.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sue so the verb vocab version is to sue.
reading-exp: YOU TAKE (???) MY THINGS, I AM GOING TO SUE YOU!

context-en: To compensate for the empty spot, I joined the bowling game.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means supplement so the verb vocab version is to supplement.
reading-exp: Oh, gee, now (???) you're going to supplement it? That would have been helpful earlier. Might help to say "oh gee now" with a ? sound instead of "ji" sound out loud, too. This is a tricky reading, won't be learned too easily, so think about it a bit now.

vocab-meaning: To Surpass, To Outstrip, To Excel
context-en: Nobody outstripped Keiko senpai back then.
context-en2: Tofugu surpasses the other Japanese learning materials in terms of uniqueness.
context-en3: Koichi is excellent at making plastic natto models.
meaning-exp: This is the verb version of the kanji superior, so it means to surpass. Someone who is superior is always going to surpass and to excel beyond others. That's what makes them so superior in the first place!
reading-exp: Remember how ??? means "at once"? Well that's the key to surpassing others. You have to do everything ???!!!

context-en: In this company, every year all the workers have to vote to choose the CEO.
meaning-exp: Throw a ballot in the ballot box to vote.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You may have to think back to some other words using ? to remember the on'yomi reading, ?? for example.

vocab-meaning: To Wring Out, To Squeeze, To Narrow Down
context-en: Here is the juice I made from wringing out a dust cloth.
context-en2: Let's narrow down our ideas at the meeting.
meaning-exp: You've learned the word ??? as "to strangle." ??, however, means to wring out or to squeeze. You can remember this one doesn't mean "to strangle" because a male (??) is statistically more likely to strangle someone. But you're not into strangling people, so you just try to wring out towels instead.
reading-exp: This word starts with ? just like ???, but it has an extra ? in there, making the reading ??. You can remember this, because if you're going to wring out a towel, you're probably quite bored (??). Strangling is not a bore, though we don't recommend it.

context-en: I work part time as a tutor.
meaning-exp: This is a combination of the words ?? and ??. A "teacher" who only teaches when you're with your "family" is known as a tutor. They don't teach you at school, they're a private teacher that comes to your home to help you learn.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The new personnel manager brilliantly solved the problem regarding mandatory overtime without pay.
meaning-exp: Alright, so it's not quite the same, but something that is fresh is also vivid and splendid. I know those are a couple things I'd associate with freshness. Try to make the connection here before moving on.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This vivid and splendid fresh fish is MINE! You grab the other (??) one that's not as vivid and splendid. This one is mine.

context-en: Due to the hit-and-run accident, the beef he bought became ground beef.
meaning-exp: The actions he took as well as the particular circumstance is what caused this accident. It all aligned too perfectly.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: It’s amazing to think that acupuncturist techniques have come this far.
meaning-exp: Needle medicine is when you stick needles into people to cure them. This is done via an acupuncturist.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for ? and the on'yomi reading for ?. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you do acupuncture and stick a bunch of needles in your back it's going to look really hairy (??). Needles look just like metal hairs when they're coming out of someone. Just picture hairy little needles all over your body and you'll never forget this reading!

context-en: They may bring forward a petition against our landfill project again.
meaning-exp: Again with that occurrence? That occurrence has now happened again.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that there's a ? hiding in there!

context-en: If you can, you should lick your elbow again.
meaning-exp: This is the adverb version of ?, so it shares the meaning again and also has the meaning once again.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Once again, you put a footer in your note because you can't remember the reading to this word because the mnemonic is so bad (sorry!).

context-en: He lives alone.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is different from the one you learned (this is kun'yomi). There's an easy way to remember it, though. ?? and ?? share the same readings and mean almost the same thing. Just try to remember that this ??? is used to emphasize solitude and independence.

context-en: Expanding into new markets was not a mistake.
meaning-exp: We waited an interval of time, and at each interval it was different. They're all supposed to be the same. Is there some kind of mistake?
reading-exp: Take the reading of ? (? from ????) and ?? and you'll have the reading for this word too.

context-en: The diplomat was stabbed by Android No.18.
meaning-exp: A person created item is artificial, not "real."
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That guy has eyes like a beast, he’s scary.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: A beast... what do you think of when you think of a beast? How about a thing (?, ??) full of fur (?, ?), aka a ??? (fur thing)? A beast is a fur thing, and in Japanese that's ???. Punnnns.

context-en: I’m thinking of moving, but just about everywhere prohibits birds and animals.
meaning-exp: Things that are of the beast type or animal type are within the beasts and animals category.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: There is a big difference between a hard wooden chair and a soft cushy chair.
meaning-exp: ?? is difference, so a big one of those is a big difference.
reading-exp: The reading is ?? plus ? of ??? (??) put together. You can remember this because when you see the difference (the BIG difference), you say "oohhhhh" (?), because you were surprised you didn't see it before.

context-en: I like working for this brewing company because they offer all these perks like free gym membership, free food, and even free sake.
meaning-exp: The act of alcohol creation is done via brewing and distilling.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: He came back on the line and asked for our company address, so I told him that it’s on my business card.
meaning-exp: Take your name and stab someone with it... using your business card. Your business card has your name on it. Also, you "stab" it at people who are willing to take it and read it. Not a real stab, but a metaphorical.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You can skate on the canal during the winter.
meaning-exp: It can carry a river. It's a canal.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? goes to ?, probably while floating down said canal.

context-en: When I was a little, my dream was to live in a house made of candy.
meaning-exp: A cake for a child is the candy and sweets that children like to eat. Mmm, candy.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: His personality is characterized by indecision and immobilism.
meaning-exp: A special indication on something or yourself is a special characteristic. It's a distinctive feature that exists.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: If you directly compare a false diamond with a real one, you’ll know which one is which right away.
meaning-exp: A compare and contrast will give you a comparison of something.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Congratulation, Congratulations, Celebration, Festival, Congratulatory Gift
context-en: You have to bring a moving gift.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji celebrate, so when you put a ? before it to raise it up, it means congratulations! When someone has something to celebrate you should congratulate them.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

context-en: Can you call Tofugu Corporation to make sure the fax went through alright?
meaning-exp: This company (??) has done the ritual required to create stocks for their company. When a company has stocks, they become a corporation.
reading-exp: The readings for everything here are the readings you learned with the individual kanji, though not all are on'yomi. This word is usually rendaku'd too, but sometimes you'll see the non-rendaku version when it comes to English language legal stuff, so keep that in mind.

context-en: Dancing around in a snow storm in nothing but your underpants is just too crazy.
meaning-exp: Your energy is ... well ... different. That's the nice way to put it. You're crazy, actually. WARNING: We're teaching you this word because it's used quite a bit still (especially online) and we want you to be able to understand it if you see it. But please keep in mind that this is considered to be a discriminatory word against people with mental illnesses, so we strongly recommend you do not use or direct this word toward anyone. Think of it like a really inappropriate swear word that makes you really uncool if you say it. Please!
reading-exp: The reading is ? plus ??.

context-en: My little sister is very creative.
meaning-exp: Create! Create! If you do this, you are doing creation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I participated in the discussion about salary cuts and the reduction of pensions.
meaning-exp: I'm going to chastise you about this theory. When I do this, this is a debate. Doesn't it feel like you're being chastised when people are debating with you sometimes, especially with your own theories? I think so.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’ll become the best dictator in the world.
meaning-exp: When one person is in a position to judge everyone alone by themselves, they're definitely a part of a dictatorship. One person should never be alone to judge everyone because that's how dictators are made and they're not so great.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I heard that you two ate my bacon directly from him.
meaning-exp: I'm going to direct and adjoin the routes together. No more multiple stops. This is direct.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When it leaked out that I have a disability, the job offer I had was cancelled.
meaning-exp: There is damage that hinders you from doing things normally. This is a disability.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
