context-en: My recent hobby is brewing homemade beer.
meaning-exp: When you create something you make something. This type of creation is usually for large things that you'd want to manufacture so you can make a lot of them.
reading-exp: The reading is like ??, which means "to make." They have very similar meanings, but different kanji. Use ?? to help you to remember the reading of this word.

context-en: Can you narrow the width a little more here?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means narrow, so the verb version is to narrow.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to narrow the gap between yourself and your enemy so that you can sabotage (??) them. You're trying to get through this already narrow air vent, so you can sabotage all of their plans! (But because your windpipe is so narrow in this air vent, it comes out more like sebatage.)

context-en: What do you think what would happen if I didn’t obey his orders?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obey so the verb vocab version is to obey.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I am going to obey you, but just know I think your order is a bit of shit, ? (???) I'll do it and obey you.

context-en: I heard Tofugu is thinking of cornering the bacon market.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means occupy so the verb version is to occupy.
reading-exp: What is it you want to occupy most in the whole, entire world? Your own flock of sheep (?). Also, a fortune teller (this kanji also means fortune, remember) told you that if you occupy her sheep, you'll have good luck! Gotta do as she says!

vocab-meaning: To Publish, To Place On Top
context-en: I’m a little uncomfortable publishing my own picture on the Internet.
meaning-exp: You remember how ?? is "to be published"? This one is to publish, as in you do it yourself. You know this because you self (??) publish, which makes it so you're able to publish something (no publishers would accept that rubbish about the vampires, sorry).
reading-exp: The reading is shared with ??, so as long as you remember that you can remember this.

vocab-meaning: To Save, To Put Something Aside
context-en: We need to save up some funds before we can start a big business.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means savings, so the verb vocab version would become to save or to put something aside. Basically, you're saving up, which is good to do, I'm told.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to save, so you take one (???) and put it aside, then take another and use it. This way you will have saved at least half.

vocab-meaning: To Shake, To Wave, To Swing, To Dump, To Reject, To Break Up With
context-en: "I can’t believe he broke up with me." "You cheated on him. You had it coming."
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake so the verb vocab version is to shake. It's also used for when you shake things your hand, aka to wave. This word can also be used when you shake someone off in the less physical way. It's to dump or to break up with them.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The building starts to shake. The most unfortunate thing here is that you're totally full (??), and you throw up because of the shaking (and you're full, gross!).

context-en: Our electricity stopped because we fell three months behind on our utility bill, so we had to spend the hot day without an air-conditioner.
meaning-exp: ??? is to surpass... ??? is to spend time on... for some reason. I suppose if you surpass something or someone, you must spend time to do it.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???. Time to surpass this kanji? Or, maybe it's time to spend time on it instead.

vocab-meaning: To Stab, To Poke, To Jab
context-en: "Well then, how much money do you need to be happy?" "Ah. You can really poke at my sore spots."
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version must also be to stab.
reading-exp: If you're going to get stabbed, don't get stabbed two (?) times. You can remember that this is the "two time stab" stab because it has a hole that's big. The hole is big because you got stabbed twice.

vocab-meaning: To Stab, To Pierce, To Poke, To Sting, To Stick, To Shank
context-en: Although I had stabbed my mom with a knife, I slept soundly that night.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version is to stab.
reading-exp: If you're going to stab someone, use a saw (?). It may seem more difficult to stab them with a saw at first, but when you see the damage, plus how hard it is to get back out, you'll realize a saw is the ideal stabbing tool.

vocab-meaning: To Take Responsibility, To Assume Responsibility, To Take On A Burden, To Carry
context-en: My company’s profits soared 70% over last year and I played an important part in achieving that.
meaning-exp: ?? is more like when you're carrying something physical. ?? is when you carry a responsibility, which is why this word means to assume responsibility. You can remember this because YOU (?) are responsible for this. You assume this responsibility.
reading-exp: What is your responsibility? To raise this girl named Nina (??).

context-en: These spices have a unique aroma.
meaning-exp: It is alone and special. Nothing is like it. It is very unique.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Up To Now, So Far, Usual, Traditional
context-en: So far, first year employees are given zero paid holidays in this company.
meaning-exp: You've come and you've obeyed the whole way up to now. I guess it's time for you to know my secret. So far I've really been a... *ahem* This word can also mean usual or traditional when it's modifying a noun or phrase with ?. It makes sense if you try to think about it: a "so far" book is just a weird way of saying a "traditional" book.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My father gave me a vending machine as a birthday present.
meaning-exp: Remember the super long vending machine that is ?????? This is a shorter easier to remember and say version. Basically every other kanji is removed, making it ???.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know ????? already.

context-en: Going to that veterinarian has the best benefits. Of course he’s kind and intelligent, but not only that, you can split up your bill into separate payments.
meaning-exp: One who does beast medicine is a veterinarian, taking care of all them animals.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I like feeling the vibration of an engine in a car.
meaning-exp: The movement that has to do with shakes is vibration and oscillation.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I was caught speeding.
meaning-exp: If you're anti- something in a way that's different from the norm then you'll be in violation of the law! The laws that the "not" different people made. Either way, those people will give you a hard time for your anti-stance against the thing they like, and say it's a transgression.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you find yourself in violation of the law just pull out your pet eagle (?). Eagles are so majestic, they'll forget all about your transgression and let you go. If you're going to go be anti-something make sure you bring that eagle. People seem to care more about animals than other people like that.

context-en: I thought I finally got my call through to the weather agency, but they hung up on me. Unbelievable.
meaning-exp: The energy phenomenon agency sounds like something that could be really cool but it's really just the weather agency / meteorological agency. Nothing shady going on here.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I found a really nice shop selling small kitchen appliances, like coffee makers, so do you want to go there with me week after next?
meaning-exp: You know how ?? is next week? Well, if you do next week again, you have the week after next.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How do you think you’ll get your revenge?
meaning-exp: When you want to know what the circumstances are around you, you have to ask why. Why do things happen around you? Asking why is very important if you want to understand the world.
reading-exp: The reading for this is an exception. The reading for ? is just the first ? from ??. You can remember the second part this way: No one knows quite how or why that big zeppelin (?) crashed in the 1930s. People are still asking today and no one has any answers. We have to keep asking until we get some.

context-en: That couple is exactly like the Beauty and the Beast.
meaning-exp: A field beast/animal is one that lives outside and not under human care. It is a wild beast / wild animal.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Put the cursor over the brush icon and click the left mouse button twice.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: For as long as you can remember, your family and another family has had a bloody feud (??) over this one writing brush. Just think of all the people killed over this brush. This feud has to end.

context-en: We should propose a two year contract that lasts until the year after next.
meaning-exp: You have next year (??), but then you do a year again. That's the year after next.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Allowance, Wages, Pay, Salary, Gross Pay
context-en: We transfer your monthly allowance to your appointed bank account.
meaning-exp: The salary I give you is your allowance. It is the wages you earn.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I have a relative who is suffering from amnesia.
meaning-exp: A healthy bit of forgetting symptoms means you might have amnesia.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My parents have decided to go to Antarctica this summer.
meaning-exp: The extreme south is the extreme of south. It's about as south as you can go. That place is known as Antarctica.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: In Japan, you usually can’t go to the dentist and get everything done in just one visit.
meaning-exp: A visit problem is when someone makes a visit, because you're the type of person who doesn't like visitors, since they're usually so inconsiderate and you have to feed them. That's why a visit is a visit problem.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: A Worry, Worry, A Trouble, Trouble
context-en: I don’t mind hearing your advice about my troubles, but I’m running out of money. If you want to eat out with me, it’s your treat.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of worry, making it a worry or a worry.
reading-exp: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done, no need to have a worry about it.

context-en: She cried as she realized that her bad influence filtered down to her children.
meaning-exp: ?? is influence, so an evil influence is a bad influence.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: That bastard got promoted to sales manager. I’m sick to my stomach.
meaning-exp: Ugh, that field guy. He's the worst. Always in the fields, making us look bad, quite the bastard. Really though, he's just this guy, but for some reason I sometimes don't like him.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You are getting a little fat around the belly, aren’t you?
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: If anyone ever tries to touch your belly make sure you yell "Sekuhara (??)! Sekuhara!” Sekuhara is short for sexual harassment in Japan. And if you don't want someone to touch your belly, but they're trying to, then that's sekuhara!

context-en: While laying in his hospital bed that night, he decided he would get a nice pair of rain boots for his wife next day.
meaning-exp: Long shoes aren't long in that the feet part are long (that wouldn't make sense). Instead, the top part is long, making them into boots.
reading-exp: The reading is a bit weird. Double kun'yomi, so think along the lines of ?? and ? getting added together. ? is the reading you learned with the kanji, however. It also gets rendaku'd.

context-en: Beneath the endless sky, students had to listen to the principal’s endless and boring speech.
meaning-exp: I retreat! I yield! I can't take it anymore, it's so boring. Just imagine yourself giving up on whatever you're doing because you're so darn bored. You can't stand it. You have to retreat. You are ready to yield. Booooooring.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My mother apologized for forgetting to bring me a change of clothes.
meaning-exp: You know how ??? is to replace? Well, you're replacing what you wear. That's a change of clothes.
reading-exp: The reading is ?? and ??? put together. The ? goes to ?.

context-en: Have the police found any clues regarding the mystery of the vanishing bacon?
meaning-exp: It was a hand which hangs the things we're looking for: a clue! Clues really are usually put down by people quite often. Or, perhaps, think of a hand hanging on something as your clue.
reading-exp: The reading is ? plus ??? put together.

context-en: There are too many coward employees who resign before being promoted to management.
meaning-exp: If you extract your waist you're pulling your body from the situation and trying to escape. What a coward. Or, picture a little kid trying hiding behind their mom. Try to extract them from behind their mom's waist. They're holding on! They don't want to come out. What a coward of a child! There are lots of different kinds of cowards.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you've learned already. Go you!

context-en: I’ll get back to you on your blood-alcohol concentration.
meaning-exp: The degree of human thickness in the area will show the amount of people. Higher degrees of human thickness = more people. Lower degrees of human thickness = less people. That is the population density of the area, or the concentration of people.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I should consult a doctor about my wife’s neurotic hysteria.
meaning-exp: See this on the end of a word, and you know that it is a ______symptom. When you have a _____symptom, you have some kind of disease or sickness (otherwise why would you have a symptom of some kind?).
reading-exp: Since this is attached to things, it's treated like a jukugo word, so the on'yomi reading is used here.

vocab-meaning: Don't Worry About It, Don't Worry
context-en: I’ll be home soon so don’t worry.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is "to care about"? This is when you tell someone to not care about something, aka don't worry about it.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so if you know that you know this!

context-en: Well, don’t worry about the results, just try your best!
meaning-exp: Remember ???? This is just another form of that, this time you're telling someone to ???, making this word mean something along the lines of good luck or do your best! Speaking of which, ???, you!
reading-exp: The reading comes from ???.

context-en: I saw a big tear drop falling from the corner of Koichi’s eyes.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This refers to a literal edge, not a figurative one.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you're on edge, just eat some hash (??) browns to feel better! And if you're going to the edge of the world, hash browns will probably help you make it there too. Hash browns are so useful!

context-en: Performance based salaries are the most effective and fairest ways to attract good workers.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means "effect"? Add ~like to that and it's effective!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: We meet on a monthly basis to discuss employment regulations.
meaning-exp: Settle in to the business. You've been here a while and you have employment now.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: You may be able to perform miracles, but I want you to avoid doing extreme things.
meaning-exp: At the extreme edge, which is just the extreme.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Finding Employment, Finding A Job, Getting A Job, Accepting A Job
context-en: "I’ve had several job interviews, but I haven’t received any job offers yet.” “Join the club.”
meaning-exp: Settle in for employment, well, that is, if you can even find a job at all, you lazy bum. Finding Employment is what you need to do to settle in for employment.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m glad to hear that my Japanese is gradually getting better.
meaning-exp: Step by step. If you take step by step, you're moving up gradually, taking steps.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: My life may be incomplete, but I would never dream of joining the mafia.
meaning-exp: Take the middle route, half on the edge. You don't do anything the full way. Just to the middle. Just to the half. Not to the edge. This was really half finished and half assed of you.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ? at the end is the only tricky part here since that isn't a common reading (or the one you learned before) for the kanji. Just watch out for that, and you'll be fine.

context-en: I discussed my frequent headaches with my mother.
meaning-exp: Head pain is when you have a headache.
reading-exp: The reading for ? should be okay. The reading for ? isn't one you've learned before, however. Just think, every time you go to the zoo (?) you get a terrible headache. Must be the animal feces floating around in the air.

context-en: Is company-paid health insurance included in the fringe benefits?
meaning-exp: You're so healthy it puts you at ease. That's your health! So healthful, go you!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: How far in advance do you usually make vacation plans?
meaning-exp: The rest you do in your spare time is your time off. It is your holiday.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I don’t want him to think of me as a stupid country bumpkin.
meaning-exp: ?? is to extract. If you extract yourself for an interval of time from the world, you won't learn anything and become an idiot.
reading-exp: The readings come from the ? reading of ? and from ??.

context-en: Working with him is so stressful that I got insomnia.
meaning-exp: The not sleep symptom shows you have a disorder that involves not sleeping. That is insomnia.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: The door opened and an old woman walked into to the Izakaya restaurant by herself.
meaning-exp: An alive alcohol shop is a place that does a lot of alcohol. In Japan, these places are often izakaya, or, if you don't know Izakaya already from English, you can consider it to be a Japanese Style Bar.
reading-exp: The readings here are a bit weird. If you know what an izakaya is already from English, you can use that to remember the reading quite easily.

context-en: "Guess what? I got a promotion at work!" "Really? That’s awesome! Congrats!"
meaning-exp: Ascend and advance! Congratulations, you ascend and advance by getting a new job promotion.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Hosokawa thanked Kojima for helping him stage a large-scale rally against resuming nuclear power plant operations.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? is scale? Well, this is a big scale, which is on a large scale.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Why don’t you leave school early with me?
meaning-exp: An early retreat means that you leave early.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m thinking of getting a life-size model of bullet train with sleepers but they’re limited edition and only three will be sold in Japan.
meaning-exp: The selling (??) of something has a limit (??). This kind of item is one of limited edition.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Living Room, Sitting Room, Parlor, Parlour
context-en: Dad is watching TV in the living room.
meaning-exp: A room that comes alive in intervals is your living room. You don't spend all your time in there, so it can only be alive sometimes. This word is usually used for western style living rooms by the way, so don't mistake it for a traditional Japanese one.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Lost Child, Lost Kid, Lost Person
context-en: I was just trying to find the parents of a lost child, but I was accused of attempted kidnapping.
meaning-exp: A child that's astray is a lost child. Help them home, don't invite them into your windowless van, please.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is an exceptional reading. The ? comes from ?. Think of the ?? as the child asking: "Where is my (??) mommy???"

context-en: Nobody found their way out of the maze.
meaning-exp: A road where you're astray is a road that goes all around in different ways, tricking you and making you lost. This is a maze.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

vocab-meaning: Money Exchange, Make Change, Currency Exchange
context-en: I’ll review today’s lesson about how to exchange money in Japanese later.
meaning-exp: I can replace both of your moneys for other moneys at this money exchange. I can also make change for you too, if you'd like. You'll probably see this word the most in Arcades where you can go to the ?? machine and get coins to feed your UFO catcher addiction.
reading-exp: The reading here is a bit weird. Instead of just being ? (it changes to ? for the rendaku), it is ??. Just think that if you want change exchanged, I'm your guy (??).

context-en: No, that’s okay. I don’t want dinner. Sorry, but I’m so stressed that I have no appetite.
meaning-exp: ?? is something like "fine" or "alright." This is just a little more polite. You can use this to say no thank you to someone trying to offer you something.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??.

context-en: "Can you come over right now?" "Sure, I’m actually on my way now." "Huh? Do you know where you’re going?" "Nope, I don’t."
meaning-exp: If you're in the middle of the planned route you're on the way / en route.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I’m Sakuraba, the man responsible for making the promotion decisions for this organization.
meaning-exp: A group that's weaved together so tightly with hierarchy and everything else is a little more complicated than a group. It's an organization.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: Our company should designate an outdoor smoking area because the smoke gets in my eyes in this room and it hurts.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pain? It's painful. It's also when you say ow and ouch.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: An eater (??) is someone who eats. But, the eater hurt his mouth. So now it's painful to eat.

context-en: The novel about a man who went to paradise by mistake was made into a movie.
meaning-exp: This place has extreme comfort. It is paradise.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I got a pay cut and my boss is mean so I’m seriously thinking of quitting and looking for a different job.
meaning-exp: A decrease in salary is a pay cut.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: When the industry made an economic comeback I applied for a raise, but it didn’t work out.
meaning-exp: When you ascend in salary you get a pay raise at work.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I think all people should learn the history of persecution and discrimination in the world.
meaning-exp: Your urge is to damage things. You are always trying to commit persecution onto others.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context-en: I gave up my dream to become an astronaut because I couldn’t stand the pressure.
meaning-exp: The pressure is urging outward. It's the pressure, so much pressure!

You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You can only retire from your life and go up to heaven if you are found innocent (??) of all the bad things you did on earth. Just like your job won't let you retire with good benefits if you weren't found innocent of eating your bosses cookies everyday. So if you want to have a good retirement, you better be innocent.

Unlike the other climbing words, though, this suggests there's no effort involved. That's why you're "ascending" and not climbing, because climbing is a bit of work.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You move to beckon your friend over. You can't see him well, so that's why you invite him to come closer. He is hiding something, and it turns out to be his long, luxurious horse mane (??). Why does he have a mane!? Horse steroids?

vocab-meaning: To Attack, To Assault, To Assail

reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you (I'm talking about you) attack something, you don't use weapons or thinking or anything silly like that. No, you use your intense sexiness (?). Bam! So sexy. Attack!

You know this is the version where things are just lined up (you're not doing the lining up) because you keep saying boo (?), why is everyone already lined up? I should have got here earlier so I don't have to wait (if you were doing the lining up yourself, you'd put yourself in the front, duh).

If you don't know about Nara and its deer, you should look it up, they're pretty awesome.

It just happens, and you can watch and be entertained (obviously you need to go watch some Maru videos if you haven't on YouTube, just saying).

What makes it different from ???, though? With ???, you tend to be doing something for fun but with a purpose. So, if you were visiting Tokyo for sightseeing, you could say ???. Unfortunately, we don't have a name for these in English because they're so unique and special, but they come up more than you'd think, so get used to ukiyo-e!

Or if you already know the word ukiyo-e, that works too!

context-en: I do aerobic exercises every afternoon.
meaning-exp: The acid element is oxygen. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck. Or you could just imagine all the oxygen you breathe has turned into acid (oh no!), and it sucks to breathe. Whatever works for you.

reading-exp: The most strict creature in Japan is the key bee (??). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!

vocab-meaning: Strictly Forbidden, Strictly Prohibited, Strict Prohibition, Ban
context-en: Private conversations with coworkers are strictly prohibited.
meaning-exp: Something with strict prohibition is strictly forbidden / strictly prohibited.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I’ve never seen such a tall hobbit before.
meaning-exp: This is the words ? and ?? put together to make one adjective. When your height is tall it means you are a tall person. This word is only used for tall people though, not anything else that's tall like a building or a tree.
reading-exp: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!

context-en: "Have you got everything, Koichi?" "Yes, mom." "Oh, wait. I forgot to put the teriyaki salmon in your bento box." "What! Hurry, mom!"
meaning-exp: You illuminate and then bake some food. To illuminate it, you put on some shiny sauce. Then, you cook it. Sound familiar, in terms of a type of food? This is teriyaki, though I have to warn you it's quite different from what you get at "teriyaki shops" in the west.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??? and ??. Put them together and you have something delicious.

vocab-meaning: To Be Chilled, To Get Cold
context-en: I’m really sensitive to the cold, especially my feet which are always cold.
meaning-exp: If ??? is "to chill something," then this would be the version where something is just chilled. You're not doing the action of chilling anything, it's just that way. You know this because if you get involved, there's always some kind of chilling error (??). So, you step back and let the fridge do its job without messing.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ???. Know that and you know this as well.

context-en: Disney Land is always crowded, even if it is a holiday.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crowded and the verb vocab version is to be crowded.
reading-exp: Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here.

vocab-meaning: To Be Happy, To Be In High Spirits, To Feel Happy

reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so if you know that you' are going to be happy.

context-en: I’m worried about him because he tends to hide his feelings.

context-en: Hair dye damages your hair.

reading-exp: When you damage something, though, how does it feel? Does it hurt, like ??? Wait, what's the reading of this? It's ????, just like ??'s reading. That should be easy to remember, unless I accidentally damage your brain with these mnemonics or something.

meaning-exp: If fire illuminates your face, you're going to feel hot. Sometimes you start to flush when you're embarrassed and it just feels like there is fire making your face light up.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing: When are you going to feel hot? When is your face going to flush? When I ask you to go to a hotel (???) with me!

reading-exp: When you gather things, you go around and take things from their original location to put them together in your gathering spot. In Japanese, when you take something, you could say ??, right? This word has the same reading: ??.

reading-exp: Things seem to get dirty easily around here, which is why you go (??) to great lengths to keep things clean.

You have to go somewhere to wait and welcome them, which is why you are going to pick someone up or going to meet them. Something like that anyways.

The "correct" reading is still ?????. But we've added this reading too for you chattygattors out there.

You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to get thin, just join the Yankees (?). They run their players around those four bases so much they all get thin quicker than you can throw a ball.

Ok, I like what I'm hearing. I am going to consent what it is you said. I am going to be informed now that I received the information and have revolved it around my brain a bit. Thank you.

vocab-meaning: Sword, Sabre, Blade, Double Edged Sword

context-en: None of them bought train tickets and they were caught for riding without paying.
meaning-exp: This is he but plural, and includes ladies too. The "ra" makes it plural, making it "they" or "them." While this gennnnnnerally refers to a group of males, it can include ladies too.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

vocab-meaning: To Be Drunk, To Be Seasick, To Be Carsick
context-en: Everybody got seasick and puked all over the ship.
context-en2: Never drive when you are drunk.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drunk so the verb vocab version is to be drunk. This drunk feeling also happens to some people in boats and cars. But we call that to be seasick or to be carsick. You aren't actually drunk, but you feel like you are (and you're probably gonna puke, yuck!).
reading-exp: I'm not drunk, yo (?). YO. I'm not drunk, yo. YO. Yo, I'm not drunk. Yo.

context-en: If the flight is delayed, can I get some kind of compensation?
meaning-exp: If something or someone is slow, and they "do slow" they are going to be late.
reading-exp: What is slow and probably going to be late all the time? A big oak (??). Oaks have trouble moving, and are slow, and therefore are always late, too.

context-en: The landlord visited a guy who was six months behind with his rent and found him dead in the house.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stagnate. The verb vocab version is to be overdue. This is probably because something that has stagnated is running late, and therefore causes it to be overdue.
reading-exp: The reading for this one is wildsauce. I'm going to leave this one to your capable hands. Just think of Tod (??) and some coot (??) doing something wild even though they're overdue for something else, or something. Anyways, best of luck to you on this one.

vocab-meaning: To Be Satisfied, To Be Settled, To Be Paid, To Be Supplied, To Be Delivered
context-en: I don't think they will be satisfied with just money.
meaning-exp: If ??? is "to supply" or "to deliver," then this word is when things have been delivered: so it's to be satisfied or to be settled. You aren't doing the supplying, and you know this because if you were to be caught supplying your reputation would be marred (?? for life).
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???.

vocab-meaning: To Be Shut, To Be Closed

You know this because you put your hand in the door to open it, but then it shuts (on its own) on your hand, marring your hand forever.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as ???.

context-en: Say! Isn’t it said that breastfeeding causes saggy breasts?

But we usually use it to talk about bringing something up again and again in conversations or arguments. That's why it means to rehash or to bring up again. You're bringing up memories from the past and steaming them up again.

You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: People think you're dancing, but you're really jumping from the mice (??) running on your floor. You don't want the mice running up your legs so you have to hop from one to the other, making it look like you're dancing.

You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You're staring really closely at this deer, but something looks off. You get closer, slowly, and you realize it's a sheep in a car (??) shaped like a deer. The sheep car deer suddenly turns toward you rushing forward, legs raised. Ahh, get outta there! (The lesson here is to never get too close to a deer. You never know its true form until it's too late.)

speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Godan verb

So, it's kind of like recruiting, but instead of people, you're recruiting for things and actions. This verb can also be intransitive (oh my!) and mean to grow violent or to become stronger. It's like all of that recruiting is happening inside of you and causing some weird things to happen to you!

reading-exp: Know how ?? means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.

You know you're doing the action of returning someone or something because when you do, they just sue (?) you because you broke the thing you were supposed to return before returning it.

This struggle is fairly figurative, too. It's more like "the struggle against terrorism" or "the fight against drugs." Not so much a fight with people, which would be ??.
reading-exp: Your neighborhood is fighting a struggle against car theft. Sadly, your car was stolen. So, you say: "ta ta, car (???). Ta ta."

Note how ??? is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? and ???. Let the excitement build as you realize you know the reading already.

context-en: I’m going to show my mother the famous sights of Tokyo by car tomorrow, so do you know any good ways to avoid the traffic?

Because when they get drunk you'll have to dodge the yo-yos (?) they spin at you. Sake makes you want to toss the ol' yo-yo around. Avoid them or you'll have to get good at dodging!

vocab-meaning: To Be Leaned, To Be Tilted

meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean, and the verb vocab version means to be leaned or to be tilted. You aren't doing the leaning or the tilting, though, you're just watching, which is why you say "cool" (?) when you see it, because it's already done.
reading-exp: You cut a moo (???), that is, a cow, in half. Then you request it is leaned up against the fence so you can start harvesting its meat for sustenance.

You start to exceed the amount you were meant to do it. If you ultra drive a car, you exceed the speed limit. If you ultra study, you exceed your brain capacity. Get it?
reading-exp: Who likes to exceed everything? Your ? (?)! Or you, when you were a ?. No bedtimes, parents, or other limitations could stop you! You were able to go over them all!

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something that happens frequently is something that has really caught on. People want to do this thing frequently, because it is so chic (??).

vocab-meaning: Genius, Person Of Exceptional Talent, Exceptionally Talented Person

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: You look happy today, for some reason.
context-en2: When you were born one hundred years ago today, I was happy. Happy birthday.
context-en3: Nothing happy has happened to me lately.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of glad? It's also glad!
reading-exp: Whenever you're really glad to be alive, you look up at the sun's rays and sing, "Ooh, rays (??), I'm so glad you're here!" Then your Uncle Ray comes dancing into the room and sings back, "Ooh, Ray is happy you're happy!" The sun's rays and Uncle Ray both make you really happy.

context-en: Right after I was told to be careful with the wine glass, sure enough, I broke one.

reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so if you know that you'll have a good handling of this one.

context-en: As soon as they get pregnant, they will happily let us know.

context-en3: Koichi returned safely and the village was filled with joyful voices.
meaning-exp: You're so glad, you get glad again. Wow, you're just happily going through life, aren't you? Joyfully accept that gladness into your life! This word is pretty old, and it's used like a noun with ?(??) added to make it an adjective or ?? added to make it an adverb. Make sure to check out the context sentences to get more familiar with this classical word.
reading-exp: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned... twice! You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning-exp: In your knee there is a small priest named Kneecap. This is a really common, cute way of talking about your kneecap. It's usually used by kids and adults alike, and it's more common in spoken Japanese than ??. Kind of like how we use "kneecap" instead of naming the "patella" bone all the time.
reading-exp: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for ? plus the on'yomi readings for ??. You've learned them all already, so you should be able to read this as long as you remember them all.

context-en: Please tell Lord Nobunaga.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is put on people's names, though most likely you'll only see this when someone is being sarcastic or if you're watching a samurai TV show. "?????????!?????!"
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Who is your great lord? Imagine it being someone named Don (??). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.

context-en: I can’t help but worry about the sacrifice fly.

meaning-exp: Remember when you learned ?? Well it can be used as a counter for clusters of fruit. Like a section of an orange or a bunch of grapes! Yum!

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning-exp: Concurrently with my current business I have a side business. It's really a second job, actually.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning-exp: You're singing and you're chanting. It's a gay ol' time. You're singing and singing and singing!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I don’t want to listen to the patriotic school song.
meaning-exp: You're chanting and you're singing and you're having a gay ol' time. You're singing all your songs and even the chanting sounds like singing. It's so fun.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: There is a lot of easy prey for us to swindle in this city.
meaning-exp: A seized thing is something you've seized from your victory. It's your spoils. It's your trophy!
reading-exp: Since you didn't learn the kun'yomi for ? with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. Eh (?)? We won the game? Ehhhh?! No way! To the victor belong the spoils! Yay!

context-en: Is there a laundry service for the stationed troops?
meaning-exp: A resident detained in a location who is in the army is a member of the stationed troops at this location. They could also be the occupying troops as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: There’s a cricket chirping somewhere in the tatami room.
meaning-exp: A sitting spread is a spread of tatami mats, making up the tatami room in a Japanese house.
reading-exp: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I ran my car into a telephone pole today.
meaning-exp: An electricity pillar is a telephone pole. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My copier is printing with lighter ink. I have to buy new toner.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dilute? It's dilute. And something that's been diluted is now thin.
reading-exp: This drink is way too diluted. You sue (??) the makers for their thin drink.

vocab-meaning: To Be Luxuriant, To Grow Thickly
context-en: The hag’s garden had grown thick with weeds.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means luxuriant and the verb vocab version is to be luxuriant or to grow thickly.
reading-exp: She gave (??) me a razor because my beard was starting to grow thickly... too thickly. But, I won't shave my awesome beard no matter what she gave me.

vocab-meaning: To Be Transparent, To Be See-Through
context-en: If you put a silver scratch card over a bright lightbulb, sometimes you can see through the silver part at what’s written underneath.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transparent and the verb vocab version is to be transparent (since usually people can't "to transparent" something).
reading-exp: To remember the reading, just think about something that is supposed to not be transparent, but is transparent after you give it to someone for a while. You're so upset that your (dog/cat/plant/car/etc) is transparent that you sue the guy who was supposed to not make it transparent.

context-en: Be patient and don’t give up. Tomorrow’s wind will blow tomorrow!
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blow so the verb vocab version is to blow.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: When the tall wizard uttered the magic word, there was a moment of total darkness.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chant so the verb vocab version is to chant.
reading-exp: Really, when you are going to chant, the most important thing to do is to figure out your tone (??). If you get the tone down, the rest comes naturally.

vocab-meaning: To Combine, To Double As, To Be Unable, To Have Trouble Doing
context-en: I prefer to have a kitchen-cum-living room if possible.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concurrently, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "to combine" or "to double as." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from.
reading-exp: For example, a car (?) can double as a place to sleep at night when not enough people become members of WaniKani.

vocab-meaning: To Decline, To Restrain, To Refrain
context-en: Tomorrow is my physical check-up, so I’d rather not have alcohol today, if that’s okay.
meaning-exp: If ?? is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is to decline or to restrain.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the reading comes from ??.

vocab-meaning: To Engage In, To Participate, To Take Part In
context-en: I didn’t want to participate in an evaluation of my coworkers, but I didn’t have a choice.
meaning-exp: Somehow the kanji portable turns into the verb to engage in or to participate or to take part in. I suppose if you are portable, you're able to engage in all kinds of things, since you can move all over the place, participating everywhere you can (rather than being not portable and being stuck in one place).
reading-exp: A Taz saw (???) is a saw owned by a Tazmanian, and it is particularly portable. It allows you to participate in all kinds of things, like cutting down trees, or being in a horror film.

context-en: My senior and I found shelter under a cherry blossom tree when the rain started suddenly.
meaning-exp: If you know that ?? is "evacuation" then you know that this is the verb form of that: to evacuate.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know the reading of the word ??.

context-en: We burst out laughing when we saw the teacher dashing down the hallway with his arms folded.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gallop and the verb vocab version is to gallop.
reading-exp: If you're going to gallop you'll get there fairly fast on your horse. But... if you really want "to gallop" fast you'll jump in your car (?).

context-en: We’ve arranged to go around to five temples today.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means patrol, but what do you do when you patrol? You go around, which is to go around.
reading-exp: You're going around patrolling to protect the house of Meg (??) Ryan. Just imagine Meg Ryan's house, and you walking around it. Imagine Meg Ryan looking out at you.

vocab-meaning: To Hang, To Depend On, To Be At Stake
context-en: I’m worried if he is okay.
meaning-exp: If something is suspended, it is going to hang or to depend on your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on!
reading-exp: We're depending on you to help us to get this car (?), okay?

context-en: People hung on Koichi’s every word.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean and the verb vocab version means to lean.
reading-exp: You learned this reading already with ??, so remember that and you'll know this one too!

vocab-meaning: To Let Go, To Let Escape, To Set Free
context-en: I missed the perfect shot when my husband sneezed.
meaning-exp: You know that ??? is "to flee" or "to run away." This is when you do fleeing to someone else. You let them go, or you let them escape, making this to let go or to let escape.
reading-exp: Here's a mnemonic to remember the kun'yomi for this word: There's someone you really like but you have to let go. Why? Because this school's policy is no guys (??)! You should just set him free now, because you aren't allowed to be together here.

vocab-meaning: To Look Back On, To Reflect On
context-en: Honey, can’t you concern yourself with your own child a little more?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means review. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning to look back on or to reflect on.
reading-exp: For the reading, think about another word that is similar: ??. With ?? you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. ?? ? ???.

context-en: Please feel free to loosen the necktie.
meaning-exp: ?? is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning to loosen or to relax.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so you can use that!

context-en: I’m going to handle that topic in the next article.
meaning-exp: To take and then handle means you're taking it and handling it, causing you to manage or to handle something. You got it because you took it.
reading-exp: The readings come from ?? and ??.

context-en: I thought your hair had multiplied somehow, but you had hair replacement surgery, huh? I see.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means multiply and the verb vocab version means to multiply or to increase.
reading-exp: What is multiplying? Your use of the word "fu" (?) for when you laugh. You used to say just "ha ha ha" like everyone else. Now the occurrences of you saying fufufu is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word ???, which means "to increase." This has a similar meaning and the same reading, use that to your advantage!

context-en: I was doing my Wanikani reviews every day and the teacher praised me for my diligence.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means title, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this to praise or to give praise to you.
reading-exp: After they go to praise you, you're all like "I don't need praise! Ta ta (??)! I'm outa here."

context-en: I’m bad at being complimented because I don’t know how to respond.

context-en: He must be a good salesman because he made the most sales during the past year and was promoted to be the youngest manager in the company’s history, but he definitely feels like the top dog right now and he’s being really arrogant. I don’t like him and I will never respect him.
meaning-exp: Take my majesty and stretch it. Your majesty is so stretched! That makes me so proud! That's why this word is to be proud or to be arrogant.
reading-exp: The reading is from ? and ??.

context-en: Petticoats prevent skirts from rubbing against your skin.
meaning-exp: The kanji means grate (as in, "to grate" on something). The verb vocab version is to chafe and to rub, which is pretty close.
reading-exp: If you're going to chafe on me like that, I'm going to sue (?) you. It's making me very uncomfortable.

context-en: Our dog consoles us whenever we get depressed.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consolation and the verb vocab version is to console.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to console you for what happened to you. The nag saw (???) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.

context-en: They are trying to ruin Japan by manipulating information.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy and the verb vocab version is to destroy and to annihilate.
reading-exp: You are going to destroy the hoe roe. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.

context-en: We were surprised that fans had gathered to wait for us when we arrived at the airport.
meaning-exp: Remember ???, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!
reading-exp: The reading is a little different from ???, though. There's an extra ? in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small ? (??). There's a ? reunion going on, that's why.

context-en: You got turned down by her three times already and you still haven’t learned, have you?
meaning-exp: The kanji means chastise but the verb vocab version is to learn by experience. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising).
reading-exp: As a child (?) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).

vocab-meaning: To Pass Through, To Pass Under, To Evade, To Dive Underwater, To Get In, To Go Underground
context-en: My dog learned a trick to jump through a hula hoop.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, but the verb vocab version is to pass through or to pass under. Technically, you're concealed, but it's a little more active. You're passing through unnoticed, or passing under something. You're evading.
reading-exp: Why are you trying to pass through without getting seen? Because there's a cougar (??) hunting you, and if it sees you... well... you're dead meat.

context-en: How many New Year’s cards should we print this year?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means printing so the verb vocab version is to print.
reading-exp: When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to sue (?) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.

context-en: He is watching the broadcast of the Academy Awards ceremony and sinking into the sofa.

reading-exp: When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "she's (??) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.

context-en: You look a bit depressed. What’s on your mind?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink. You know this is when something is just sinking on its own (you didn't sink it), because of the ?, which shows it's a cow sinking. The cow stepped into some quicksand and now it's sinking, not because of you.
reading-exp: You look at the cow. Poor cow. She's (??) sinking.

context-en: I was jealous of her talent, so I tore the canvas she was painting for an art competition to pieces.

reading-exp: In order to get it open, you need to tear and rip up a sack (??). Sacks don't have tabs or zippers or any of those fancy things. If you want to get at the stuff in a sack you have to tear the top right off!

I have no idea why you'd hide it, but you can come up with a compelling reason that makes sense to you.

vocab-meaning: To Become Clear, To Become Transparent

vocab-meaning: To Be Damp, To Be Moist, To Be Wet
context-en: I sweat a lot when I was sleeping last night and my bed is a little damp.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means damp so the verb vocab version is to be damp or to be moist. Ewww.
reading-exp: You have to think of something that's damp and moist. To do that, think of He-Man's girlfriend, She-Man (??). She has been hanging out in a greenhouse and is now kind of damp. He-Man hands her a towel to dry off.

vocab-meaning: To Be Destroyed, To Be Annihilated
context-en: If the earth is going to be destroyed, why should I resist eating bacon?
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy so the verb vocab version is to be destroyed. You know you're not destroying things because of the beer (??). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr.
reading-exp: "THE HORROR!" (??) you cry, as your beer is about to be destroyed.

vocab-meaning: To Be Exhausted, To Be Tired
context-en: The toilet was clogged and it flooded before we used the plunger, so I had to clean it up early in the morning and I’m really exhausted.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means exhausted making the verb version to be exhausted or to be tired. Don't confuse this with "to be sleepy." No, this is a different kind of tired, like a physical or mental one, like you just worked out or studied a ton.
reading-exp: For example, if you tried to lift two cars (??) you'd become exhausted for sure. So, think about that as you learn this word's reading.

vocab-meaning: To Curse, To Put A Curse On

vocab-meaning: To Earn Income, To Make Money
context-en: Do you know how much more money the incumbent president earns than the former president?

reading-exp: You earn your income, and every time you're paid, you're given your money in a briefcase (??). Imagine getting your income from a briefcase, opening it up, and grabbing the money from within. Then, you have to give the briefcase back at the specified dropoff.

context-en: It looked just like a phoenix soaring high in the air.

reading-exp: To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are coming (??) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!

reading-exp: To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is ??, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's ??, just like ????'s kanji-part reading.

meaning-exp: Open up cultivation back on this land. It was closed before, due to it being a wasteland, but now it's time for reclamation and cultivation of this land.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: This pumpkin pie is delicious right after it’s been baked, but we recommend refrigerating for a short time before eating it.
meaning-exp: I'd like to infer and encourage this item to you. It is my recommendation. It is my endorsement.
