vocab-meaning: Red Light District, Pleasure Quarters, World Of The Geisha
context-en: I’ve always dreamed of experiencing the red-light district.
meaning-exp: The red light district (??) world of the red light district is the red light district, though this can refer especially to the "pleasure quarters" or "world of the geisha" as well.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I resigned myself to undergo weight loss surgery.
meaning-exp: I've memorized this to the point of comprehension. It was my resolution to learn all this to comprehension. This way I have readiness.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I want to make my restaurant a place of rest and relaxation for busy salarymen.
meaning-exp: If ?? is to rest, then this noun version (I know it looks like an adjective, but it's not) would be rest.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so if you know that you can rest easy.

context-en: The man they arrested is suspected of breaking into the rest area.
meaning-exp: A rest (??) place is a rest area or rest stop.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

context-en: I can’t remember the name of the guy who tried to force me to buy an expensive rosary.
meaning-exp: A number of pearls, put together on a string. This refers to a rosary or prayer beads. You'll see these a lot in Japan, for sale or with monks wearing them.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is different from both of the kanji readings you learned. This word sounds a lot like Jews (???), so we'll have to go with that. Just imagine a Jewish rosary or prayer beads, with a Jewish person using it.

context-en: The fortuneteller predicted that I would receive the scholarship and she was right.
meaning-exp: Encourage study money is money that you give to a kid to encourage him to study. That comes in the form of a scholarship or stipend.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: When my mother died from old age, I didn’t fail to hear my wife mutter, "that parasite is gone, good riddance," to herself.
meaning-exp: An elderly person in decline is someone who is old and in decline. They are experiencing senility or senile decay.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Slang, Common, Vulgar, Local Manners, Local Customs, Mundane
context-en: People who went from rags to riches are commonly called nouveau riche.
meaning-exp: Things that are vulgar are things like slang, local manners, and just plain common stuff.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: She is not my mother, she’s just a chaperone.
meaning-exp: The kanji means solely, and this means solely, but also other related things like only or merely. They're all pretty close, so try to remember a few!
reading-exp: To spice up something you'd describe with words like only and simply use Ta da! (??) to spice it up. It's like magic! Now it isn't just a gift, it's a TA DA surprise gift.

context-en: Mild contractions are starting in 15 to 20 minutes intervals and I called the hospital to see if we should go now.
meaning-exp: I'd like to isolate this interval of time. Take it, make it separate, and then look at it. Now there is a space there. An interval, if you will.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Splitting The Cost, Splitting The Bill
context-en: I can’t drink because I get drunk easily, so it would be nice if we didn’t split the alcohol bill.
meaning-exp: I will divide the intuition up. For some reason when I say "intuition" I mean "money" because this is referring to splitting the cost, like when you're at a restaurant.
reading-exp: The reading is ?? and ?, put together.

context-en: I believed hard work and persistent efforts would pay off some day, but it was wrong.
meaning-exp: If ?? is "to be sticky" then the noun version is stickiness.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??.

context-en: The teacher didn’t have the guts to deal with the problems in the classroom.
meaning-exp: A spirit of approximation is the approximation of spirit. My approximation of your spirit? I think you have a strong spirit. I think you have backbone.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: It’s great that the temperature is rising, but we’re worried about a flood from the melting snow.
meaning-exp: Immersed in water. That sounds like submersion. Possibly like a flood, even.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: "Hey, did you just call me a liar?" "No, but I called you a crook." "Huh? What are you talking about!? I seriously can’t believe you."
meaning-exp: You know that ?? is "fraud." An expert at fraud (??) is someone who does this a lot and possibly for a living. A swindler, some would say.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of ?? as well.

context-en: Taking various circumstances into consideration, quitting the job was the best option for me.
context-en2: I try to take into consideration how I would feel if things were said or done to me.
context-en3: What kinds of risks have you taken into consideration concerning this investment?
meaning-exp: Using our intuition we will come up with a plan. We'll be taking into consideration the information we have along with our intuition, so don't worry.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Thank You, That's Enough For Today, Good Work
context-en: When my wife puts my jacket on the hanger she always says, "Thank you for working hard again today."
meaning-exp: You are a ?? (tired) ? (honorific that kind of refers to whoever's being mentioned with this word). You say this to people after a day of hard work or after a good practice, etc. ???????! I suppose the assumption here is that everyone worked until they were tired, so it was a good work, and then you thank them for it and mention how tired everyone is.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ?? and ?, combined together into one word.

context-en: He hates me now, so I’m pretty sure that I'm even more inferior to him than a nodding acquaintance.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inferiority and the verb vocab version is to be inferior to.
reading-exp: When thinking about cars, an automatic (??) car is inferior to a manual car. Sure, manual is harder, but way more interesting to drive.

vocab-meaning: To Be Moist, To Be Damp, To Be Watered
context-en: If you use this lotion it will moisturize your skin so that it’s firm and soft.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means watered. When something is watered, it is moist and damp. That's why this verb is to be moist or to be damp or to be watered.
reading-exp: If you get moist and damp, then you're all (???) wet. It's just how it is.

vocab-meaning: To Be Overturned, To Be Reversed, To Be Retracted, To Topple Over
context-en: I didn’t always like sports, but that was overturned once I went to see a baseball game and now I’m a big fan of the Mariners.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means capsize but the verb version is what happens when a plan or idea capsizes. It going to be overturned. It was a bad idea, go back, don't do it or we'll all sink!
reading-exp: Of all the ideas that need to be overturned, it's the ones from the ? guy (????). He thinks we should only wear shoes. Not shoes and nothing else, but shoes all over out entire bodies. Yikes, now that's an idea I'd like to be retracted, ? guy.

vocab-meaning: To Be Soaked In, To Be Submerged, To Be Flooded
context-en: I was reading Hawthorne’s "The Great Stone Face" that I borrowed from a library in the bath and thoughtlessly soaked it in bathwater.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed. Things that are immersed are described by verbs like to be soaked in or to be submerged or to be flooded.
reading-exp: What is soaked and submerged in water (that shouldn't be)? It is your heater (??). It's all soaked and doesn't work anymore :(

context-en: We are going to simmer this fatty autumn salmon today.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boil and the verb vocab version is to boil.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: They’re plotting a dramatic assassination in front of the Statue of David in Florence.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conspire and the verb vocab version is to conspire or to plot.
reading-exp: A group of hackers (??) are getting together and trying to conspire and plot to take down the mainframe! Those hackers!

vocab-meaning: To Decline, To Decay, To Become Weak, To Wither
context-en: When I had this beef several years ago I was really impressed by how well it was aged and marbled, but the taste seems to have declined a bit and I’m really disappointed.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decline and the verb vocab version is to decline.
reading-exp: You're wandering through the jungle exploring, when you come upon a deep pit. Since you're looking for treasure, you decide to go down into the pit to look for some. You take out your handy auto rope (???), made of organic, environment friendly materials, and easily rappel down into the pit. Unfortunately, you get lost down there, and it takes you fifty years to get back to the pit you came in from. But your auto rope is gone! This is the last time you buy an organic rope, made to decay and to wither away when left in the wild.

context-en: You can insert the DVD from here.
meaning-exp: ?? is "insertion" so the verb version is to insert.
reading-exp: The reading comes from ??, so if you know that you can insert this reading into your memory no problem.

vocab-meaning: To Isolate, To Partition, To Separate
context-en: In my apartment, the bathtub and the washroom are separated by a single shower curtain.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means isolate and the verb vocab version is to isolate or to partition or to separate. You get the idea, anyways.
reading-exp: Why did you have to isolate him from the rest of the soccer players? Because all he could do was headers (??) and that was getting pretty dangerous. He would head everything in his reach. He was going crazy with headers. He had to be isolated!

vocab-meaning: To Mow, To Reap, To Harvest
context-en: My parents are farmers who raise rice so I have to help them harvest rice this weekend.
meaning-exp: If you prune and take from what you pruned, you're going to mow or to reap or to harvest whatever it is you're pruning.
reading-exp: The reading is the reading you learned with ? and the reading from the vocab ??.

vocab-meaning: To Panic, To Hurry, To Rush, To Be Upset
context-en: Please don't don't rush—just drive safely.
context-en2: I panicked, thinking there was a fire, and threw some water, but it was just a candle.
context-en3: Don't hurry, do it carefully.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means confused or bewildered but this is usually just used when someone starts to panic. They're so confused and bewildered that they try to hurry through things.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Whenever you start to panic you can't help but blurt out, "A wha- (??)?" to everything people say and ask. For example, "Would you like a mint?" "A WHA?!" Yeah, you really do sound upset.

vocab-meaning: To Pity, To Have Mercy On
context-en: I heard her grandmother grumble, "That girl’s shyness should be pitied."
meaning-exp: If something is pathetic then you should try to pity that thing.
reading-exp: Awww (??), you're so pathetic it's cute! I will pity you. Reading also comes from ??.

vocab-meaning: To Prune, To Mow, To Cut
context-en: I’ve finished mowing the grass, so turn him loose.
meaning-exp: Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prune and the verb vocab version is to prune (or to mow or to cut).
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

context-en: When the hunchbacked old lady was sent to a detention center for being an illegal immigrant, she realized that it would be where she met her death.
meaning-exp: If you have comprehension, then you are probably going to realize something about something else. Comprehension leads to realization, after all.
reading-exp: You realized something so amazing that you couldn't believe it. That comprehension, wow! The realization was so big that you sat (??) down in disbelief. If you didn't you would have fallen on the ground.

context-en: You must first conquer your fear of the ultraviolet rays.
meaning-exp: The purple outside line is the color spectrum that's outside purple. Those are ultraviolet rays (the lines are the rays).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I can’t say that tax rebates are unconditionally good things.
meaning-exp: We're moving towards one approximation. It used to be more approximations, but now it's just one, and because it's just one it's not really an approximation anymore. It's unconditionally set. It's set as a rule.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: He looks like a strong warrior of long ago, but he wailed when I accidentally pressed a blister on his foot.
meaning-exp: When you are sturdy and healthy you are full of vigor and virility.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: She always wears a violet colored vest over her school uniform.
meaning-exp: A purple color is a violet color, mainly, for some reason, though I'll let "purple" slide as well.
reading-exp: The reading for ? is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "??" (????) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.

context-en: When I was saying my wedding vows I knew I was marrying the wrong man.
meaning-exp: This looks like an adjective, but it's actually a noun. This word is the same as the kanji meaning: vow (or oath).
reading-exp: This has the same reading as ?? (???). Just think about how when you're making a vow or oath, you become closer to the thing or person you're vowing to. You belong to them, in a way, which is why you become close (??).

context-en: Here is the written pledge. You need to sign it here and here.
meaning-exp: A vow promise is the promise that you made with your vow. It's the oath you sweat to keep!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Your Majesty, His Majesty, Her Majesty
context-en: Your Majesty, I’m sorry to impose but you were supposed to attend the meeting.
meaning-exp: Your highness I am so below you because your majesty is so great and amazing!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I didn’t think of the idea to burn the account book.
meaning-exp: A notebook that is also a record book is an account book or register, showing the records of all the transactions that have gone through.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: It’s too good to be true. What are you scheming?
meaning-exp: You're so adept! That makes you adept at that thing. Skillful and clever are other ways to do it too.
reading-exp: Remember ??, which means "delicious"? Remember how it also means "skillful" and "clever"? It's the same with this word, and the reading is the same as well.

context-en: This alligator statue is in the way.
context-en2: You can handwrite the kanji for WaniKani without looking at anything? That's amazing!
context-en3: I have a stuffed alligator displayed in my room.
meaning-exp: The great alligator! This can mean both alligator or crocodile, because really, they're not so different, are they? No crabigator, that's for sure.
reading-exp: The reading is a reading you've known your whole life. It's like you were born with the reading, whispering in your ear, ready to emerge at just the right moment... and that moment is now.

context-en: The number of people visiting the ancient tomb has been increasing in recent years.
meaning-exp: An old tomb is an ancient tomb though it can refer to the ancient mounds (of the Jomon, I'm assuming).
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I wonder why my aunt didn’t come to our wedding ceremony.
meaning-exp: The chief mother isn't your own mother, but she is the chief of your mother. She's your mother's lady sibling, who has always owned your mom. She's the chief mother. She's your aunt.
reading-exp: The reading for the ? part is just the first ? in ??, rendaku'd. You can also think of your aunt as a sheep, too, if you'd like.

context-en: How much longer will it take you to decide which brand to recommend to your customer?
meaning-exp: The inscription's pattern shows what brand or make this item is. If the pattern of the inscription is an apple, you'll know the brand is Apple. If it's a Window, you know it's Microsoft. Etc.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to slap them together and know the reading of this word!

context-en: I unexpectedly ran into a friend from high school at the airport.
meaning-exp: Accidentally but naturally (as in nothing was set up artificially before). So, the accident was a true, natural accident. This kind of accident is something that happens by chance, unexpectedly.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: We need to carry out all of our work by 7pm on Sunday night.
meaning-exp: Transport and exit these goods from here (by transporting them). Take it away. It's time to carry out.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I stumbled into the cave and sprained my ankle.
meaning-exp: A cave hole is a cave or den.
reading-exp: The reading of ? is one you've learned. The reading of ? isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this cave, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be ketsup (??). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say ????, but then you'd never learn that reading for ?, and where's the fun in that?

context-en: The eerie cave stood silently in the outskirts north of the village.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Hoe Ra (??), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a cave for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.

vocab-meaning: Change One's Mind, Change Your Mind
context-en: I swear, I will absolutely not change my mind about this marriage.
meaning-exp: When you flip your idea of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is change one's mind.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: How about giving Fugu the title of an earl, and calling him Count Fugu?
meaning-exp: The chief of this district is that guy, the count. He's also the earl of another district, and the chief of yet another.
reading-exp: The reading is the ?? reading you learned with the kanji.

context-en: "Why aren’t you coming to your mom’s funeral?" "’Cause I caught a cold."
meaning-exp: A wind that is wicked comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a cold.
reading-exp: Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of ? (??). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.

context-en: I didn’t like my dad’s bento because he never really took coloring into account and all of it was brown.
meaning-exp: This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: coloring.
reading-exp: The reading has ?? (like ?) in it, then a ?, so think about an ? dog, running around coloring things, because that's what an ? dog does.

vocab-meaning: Comic Dialogue, Two Man Comedy Act
context-en: Watching two man comedy acts and laughing loudly relieves my stress.
meaning-exp: A manga genius! For some reason, this is a comic dialogue or two man comedy. Look up "manzai" on YouTube for some good times if you don't know what this is. It's not exactly the same, but ? DOES refer to manga, which is a type of comic book. Take the "comic" part from "comic" book, then change it to the "haha funny!" meaning of "comic," and then imagine people doing a dialogue. Then, you have a comic dialogue. Lots of steps, but hopefully it'll get you there.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

context-en: If I make a mistake in Japanese would you mind correcting it on the spot for me?
meaning-exp: When you revise something to make it correct you are doing a correction and revision.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Counter For Bundles, Counter for Bunches, Bundle Counter, Bunch Counter
context-en: Wow! A bunch of spinach is only ninety-eight yen!
meaning-exp: The kanji refers to a bundle, but this refers to a counter for bundles. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my!
reading-exp: Saying "1 bundle" and "2 bundle" takes too long, so you decide to call these bundles what they look like: ? for walrus (?)!

context-en: Do you know how much longer we will be in this courtroom?
meaning-exp: The law courts are the courts you visit to get law distributed. The room in which you do this in is a courtroom.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I’m getting hungry. I’m looking forward to having crab for dinner.
meaning-exp: The meaning is the same as the kanji's meaning, crab. If you know this word, and you know the word ? as well... then, well, you know something, though I'm not sure what that something is.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But you knew that already, didn't you?

context-en: This crystal comes in three sizes; small, medium, and large.
meaning-exp: A water crystal is just a crystal. I guess crystals are clear and look kind of like water, yeah? That's why it's being referred to as a water crystal, making it really just a crystal.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: One day, my son suddenly started speaking Japanese fluently, as if a dam in him had been broken.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context-en: We were deeply impressed by his piano performance.
meaning-exp: A feeling of inscription is the feeling one gets when something so strong happens that it's like the feeling gets inscribed into your soul. This is something that left a very deep impression.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: He’s such a cunning guy and he’s very good at feigning innocence too.
meaning-exp: Someone who is bad but also clever (??) is someone who is using their cleverness for evil. When you refer to clever evil people, usually you describe them not as "clever" but as devious, cunning, or other things.
reading-exp: The reading is ?? and ?? combined together into one word. Be careful of the rendaku.

context-en: When the mast broke and my yacht started drifting out to sea, I got a little pessimistic.
meaning-exp: Drifting down the stream. Something that is doing this is drifting. It could also be the drift of something.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Imagine a wounded baby whale drifting ashore onto a sandy beach.
meaning-exp: Something has drifted to the point where it has arrived. Where do drifting things arrive? They arrive on shore (as they drift on top of water). That makes this word drifting ashore.
reading-exp: This word uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You'll need to remember the on'yomi reading of ? for this word by looking back at the word ?? where you first learned this reading.

context-en: Each member of my family has this photo.
meaning-exp: You look at this inscription then you look at that inscription and you notice that each one is an individual inscription.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The water is almost running over the embankment, so you should be careful.
meaning-exp: The embankment prevents the water from going over the edge. It's an embankment.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The village head decided to bury a human sacrifice in the embankment to prevent it from collapsing.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: The reading is like the reading of ??, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an embankment that's made purely from bundles and packages. These ?? (???) are the only thing holding the water in!

context-en: Every time I ignore a stop sign I get excited.
meaning-exp: My interest is stirred up! I'm feeling excitement and stimulation from all this stirring up, in fact!
reading-exp: The reading for ?? is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of ??? it's ??, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to ????. So just think of ???? exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.

context-en: My man is in the middle of the fist fight in the club.
meaning-exp: Remember ??, which means "to assault"? This is when your assaults are join with other assaults. By "joined" I mean your fist is coming in contact with their face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. This is a fistfight.

context-en: I am from Ehime Prefecture.
meaning-exp: The prefecture in Japan where they love princesses is Ehime Prefecture.
reading-exp: This reading is a little messy. This reading for ? is an exception, ? uses the kun'yomi reading ??, and ? uses the on'yomi reading ??. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading for ?: If you ask anyone outside of Ehime Prefecture what they think of princesses they'll respond with, "Eh" (?). They don't really care either way. If someone from Ehime heard that they'd says, "EH? EH?! Princesses are the BEST!"

context-en: Please throw away empty bottles here.
meaning-exp: A sky bottle is a bottle that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty bottle.
reading-exp: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. You learned this reading for ? when you learned ???. If you can remember that, you can remember this too! Oh and sometimes you'll see this written ?? without the kana too. And when that happens it can be read ????! So if you learned it one way and not the other, don't worry, we'll take both here. Just know that seeing it as ??? (and pronouncing it ????) is way more common.

context-en: Please take off your shoes in the entranceway.
meaning-exp: The most mysterious thing that's connected to a house is the entranceway. When you're walking into one you never know what's coming next. You just take off your shoes and hope the rest of the house isn't really weird or something. If it is, the entryway is then your only way out.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: You need to formally explain this.

context-en: I think that explanation is wrong.
meaning-exp: Even if you untie an explanation it's still a pretty good explanation anyway.

context-en: My grandfather farms.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The only thing a great person doesn't do is make errors (??). That's what makes them so great. They can always sense when an error is about to happen and they correct it before it even has a chance!

context-en: December is a hectic season for restaurants.

meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? all the way at the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. Confused is already an adjective and this word is a little different. Usually when you get confused it's because you were already hurried, busy, and things were hectic. So this adjective is what causes your confusion.

context-en: You might have the decency to return my nod with a nod.

You're so uncomfortable that you can't think of words and "eh" is all you can manage to get out.

context-en: That was the first time I’d heard that surname.

context-en: My grandfather was born the year the Great Depression occurred.
context-en2: The Great Depression affected many countries.
context-en3: The Great Depression raised unemployment and even suicide rates.
meaning-exp: ?? means "world" and ?? means "panic" or "scare," so when you put them together you get a scare that made the entire world panic. This is how we refer to The Great Depression. It was caused by and subsequently resulted in everybody in the whole world panicking together about money.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

vocab-meaning: To Boil, To Grow Hot, To Get Excited
context-en: I’m waiting for the water to boil.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boil, so the verb version is to boil. It can also be used to mean to get excited, because you're boiling with that excitement.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want to boil for dinner tonight? Walrus (?). Boiled walrus is a delicacy where you're from, and the only way to be able to eat its yummy walrus flesh is to boil it for a long time until it's soft. Mmm smells good.

vocab-meaning: To Cover, To Hide, To Conceal
context-en: My garden is covered in fallen leaves.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cover, so the verb version is to cover or to hide.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to cover yourself with a sheet because you want to pretend to be a ghost. But covering yourself isn't enough. If you really want people to believe in your disguise you have to say, "??!" Otherwise they'll think you're a covered chair or a bush. If you ?? at them they'll definitely know you're a ghost covered in that sheet.

vocab-meaning: To Humbly Receive, To Humbly Accept, To Humbly Eat, To Humbly Drink
context-en: Thank you very much for your congratulations.
meaning-exp: If you humbly do something you are going to humbly receive, to humbly accept, or eat or drink it. Basically you're humbly doing a lot of things. And you can use this word for all of them!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You technically already know this reading! You know how people say ??????? Well that's the same as this! You're humbly receiving your meal. So to humbly receive is ????!

vocab-meaning: To Put Between, To Sandwich, To Insert
context-en: I put the egg and ham between the bread.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means between, so the verb version is to put between or to sandwich.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

vocab-meaning: To Respectfully Call, To Respectfully Invite, To Respectfully Eat, To Respectfully Drink
context-en: Your older sister was called by the gods.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call, so the verb version is to respectfully call. It can also be used as to respectfully eat or to respectfully invite too. It's a really useful word like that. As long as you remember it's the respectful/honorific way of doing things you should be fine.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to respectfully call out to someone you need to make sure you don't look them in the ? (?) because that's super rude. Always remember to turn your ? away to show respect.

context-en: A drunk guy is shouting.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to shout at someone you should pick a word that will really hit them. Give them a big whammy (??) to the face! Hey, that word works. Shout WHAMMY!

vocab-meaning: To Soak, To Steep, To Dip

meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed, so the verb version is what happens when you immerse something in a liquid. It's to soak or to dip.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned ??, so you should know this one too.

vocab-meaning: To Till, To Plow, To Plough, To Cultivate

That's either when you have a yard full of live tigers, or you plant bushes and shape them into tigers. I hope it's the second kind of tiger yard. Either way, you have to plow the land to get it ready.

Right as you're about to get crushed you scream, "Oh CHEESE (???)!!" You can't swear for real or you'll go to hell when this cave in crushes you to death. And OH CHEESE felt right as your last words.

vocab-meaning: To Go Through, To Pierce, To Penetrate, To Persist, To Stick To
context-en: My father stuck to his beliefs until the end.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pierce, so the verb version is to go through or to pierce.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to go through someones mind or a college campus is to run nude (???). So if you really want to pierce someone's mind and soul remember this!

context-en: The favorite for the championship is the genius batter Tofugu Academy has.

reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: Have you ever encountered blatant racial discrimination?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means encounter, so the verb version is to encounter or to meet.
reading-exp: Remember how ?? also means to meet? Well they're both read ?? too! So if you know that one, you know this one too!

vocab-meaning: To Swell, To Expand, To Be Inflated, To Distend, To Bulge

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone comes up to you and asks, "Hey, do you want your stomach to swell like that?" How dare they ask you about your stomach. You respond with, "F@#$ (??) you!" It's none of their business how much you want your stomach to expand.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your mom started to admonish you so you instantly sat (??) down. Maybe if she sees you sat down right in front of her, looking guilty and feeling remorseful, she won't yell as hard.

vocab-meaning: To Oppress, To Persecute, To Tyrannize
context-en: That man always oppressed his wife and children.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means oppress, so the verb version is to oppress or to persecute.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to oppress someone is to make it so they can't use the sh*tter (???). Just imagine any kind of oppressive monarch from history. They know your weakness. They know you need to poop at some point. What would it be like 48 hours from now if you didn't have a place to poop. If you didn't have your "sh*tter." To help you to remember that there's an ? in there, think about an eagle, as we often do for ?. This eagle represents "American Freedom." If you had this freedom you'd be pooping all you want and nobody would take your sh*tter away from you.

vocab-meaning: To Relax, To Feel At Home

It's a road with a bunch of old coots who don't bother nobody. They just kinda sit around and complain. That's where you like to relax. Something about being surrounded by a bunch of old coots on old coots road makes you feel at home.

So it still means to respectfully eat, but raising it makes it a higher politeness level.

context-en: If I warm it up and eat it, it becomes even more delicious.

reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When do people tend to use the word furthermore? Right now (??)!

context-en: The black dog ran through the river bed like a gust of wind.
meaning-exp: A rapid wind is a gale or a strong wind.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Gem, Treasure, Article Of Rare Beauty, Fine Article
context-en: This Japanese Black steak is a gem chefs obsess over.
meaning-exp: Deviate from normal, everyday products and buy lots of gems and treasures! Especially if you're buying presents. Normal stuff just isn't going to cut it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: It will be assigned to the general affairs department this time.

context-en: Poisoning symptoms develop when I eat too much ginkgo.
meaning-exp: Silver apricots are called ginkgo nuts. Okay, they aren't really apricots, but they are silver and they sure look the same.
reading-exp: This word is an exception. You'd think it would be the same in Japanese as it is in English, but it's not. And it has two different readings and meanings. Yikes, sorry. Here's a mnemonic to help you out: Before you read this PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER this is NOT a jukugo word. It's weird. You're gonna want to type ???? but that's wrong. Stop that now. When you think of a ginkgo tree think about this: Ginkgos are a favorite nesting place for eagles but evil Mrs. Chou likes to eat eagles AND whole gingko trees. She prefers eating eagles WHILE THEY'RE IN THE GINKGO TREES AND ARE STILL ALIVE. So ????. Eagles and Mrs. Chou. And gingko trees. It's horrible to think about. Just like this reading not being jukugo. The other meaning is the ginkgo nuts themselves. They taste like ? (??) naan (??). Mm mm soft and metallic, but still not the jukugo word though. How sad for you and all Japanese learners everywhere.

context-en: I want to solemnly react to the results and face it next time.
meaning-exp: If everyone is acting solemn and strict then you should probably pay special attention to the gravity of the situation you're in. Don't start playing the trumpet when you're supposed to be bowing your head!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My parents’ home is in Ibaraki prefecture.

reading-exp: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for ?, and exception for ? and the on'yomi for ?. Phew! You haven't learned this weird reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ibaraki prefecture is famous for making keys (?)! It's their biggest export. The key to knowing this reading is in the keys they make! Or, just knowing that it's the same in English and Japanese.

context-en: If you only talk of idle complaints, nothing will change.

You didn't learn this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you don't treat an illness right away you'll end up paying (??) with your life. And if you don't die, you'll still have to pay a lot for doctor and hospital fees. Yuck.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Intense heat will show (??) on your face. You'll turn red and get all sweaty. You really can't hide it.

context-en: I’m going to introduce an exercise that improves my metabolism.

Picture your body using food you eat by setting it up in an exhibit in your stomach. But it gets bored of it and wants to substitute it with a newer one, so it makes you hungry again, digesting the food fast.

context-en: The molester was arrested this morning.
meaning-exp: Okay... so before I get into this, you can't get mad at me. I didn't make this word up. I didn't make the Japanese language and I have nothing to do with this. And don't blame Japanese people for it either. So apparently a stupid Chinese person is a molester. Our theory is, that in China "Chinese" just meant "person" so a molester was just a stupid person. But in Japanese we think of ? as Chinese, so there you go. Either way, you'll probably never ever forget this one. You're welcome!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Jesus (?), of course. I mean, you look just like him. Look in the mirror if you don't believe me. Look, there he is. Wait, what do you mean he isn't a cruel guy? I guess you're the cruel one then. Sucks to be you.

You didn't learn this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To help you understand the solemnity of a moment of silence, usually a gong (??) will play a few times. As you listen to the echo and silence that comes after it. The gravity of what you're being silent for really sinks in.

context-en: It’s bustling during the day, but at night pedestrian traffic is sparse.

reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are sparse, you won't have food or toys or internet. It's hard for everyone. So your mama would baa (??) to entertain you and get you to stop thinking about how thin you and her were getting. Mama baaing made you calm and happy. Thanks mama.

context-en: The boys sprinted around the station.
meaning-exp: A rapid run is called a sprint or a dash.

context-en: Can you eat rose stems?

reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

vocab-meaning: To Burst Out, To Spout Out
context-en: The anger that had built up burst out at once.
meaning-exp: "To Remove" an eruption it needs to burst out of the earth or volcano it's in.
reading-exp: Remember how you learned the word ????? Well this is read the exact same way and means almost the exact same thing. If you know one reading, you know both!

vocab-meaning: To Expand, To Swell, To Get Big, To Become Inflated
context-en: My hopes just got bigger.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swell, so the verb version is to swell or to expand.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If someone comes up to you and says, "Hey it looks like you've really started to expand around the middle." Go ahead and say a big old, "F@#$ (??) you!" If someone is rude to you, dish it right back out. F@#$ that guy!

vocab-meaning: To Follow, To Stick With, To Stick To, To Go Through
context-en: He stuck to his beliefs until the end.
meaning-exp: This is a combination of the words ?? meaning "To Go Through" and ?? meaning "To Let Pass." So when you're trying to go through an area and also let someone pass with you, you start to follow them. Not intentionally, but you're both trying to go through at the same time so you decide to stick with them.
reading-exp: This is a combination of two words you already know, so you should already know this too!

vocab-meaning: To Grow Senile, To Be Mentally Slow
context-en: That actor is really good at acting senile.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock. What happens when you're so old that your brain goes into shock? You start to grow senile. It's sad, but lots of people can't handle being old and they get like this.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you start to grow senile you'll make a new friend. It's Bobo (?) the clown! No one else can see him though, but that's okay! He'll become your very best friend. And he won't leave until you finally kick the bucket.

vocab-meaning: Tone Deafness, Tone Deaf, Off Key
context-en: I’m tone-deaf so I’m bad at karaoke.
meaning-exp: If you're stupid when it comes to sounds, then you're tone deaf.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: To Neglect, To Be Idle, To Slack
context-en: A person who works hard talks of hope but a person who is idle talks of dissatisfaction.

reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to neglect everything. Your school, your family, even your own name (??). You've managed to slack for so long that you can't even remember your name? That's pretty impressive, actually.

context-en: Will you sell these goods wholesale?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wholesale, so the verb version is to sell wholesale.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

context-en: She quickly averted her eyes.

reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to turn away from this movie because it's not worth watching. I mean, it isn't bad, but it isn't good. It's just so-so (?). But that's not enough to keep your interest.

context-en: Only the king can wear this cap.

So here's a mnemonic to help you remember them: The traditional caps can have three different styles. A can (??) shape, a camel rib shape (???), or a canned 'murica (????) shape (it's a bald eagle in a can). Can you picture them all in your head? You only need to choose one at least! Yay!

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What have all your friends started to be absorbed in? Their ?s (?). They all keep having kids and now that's all they seem to care about. Damn kids.

context-en: The beginning of the Yayoi Period was approximately 300 BCE.

context-en: She’s beautiful, smart, and yet she has a terrible personality.

vocab-meaning: To Be Amazed, To Be Shocked, To Be Astonished

vocab-meaning: To Get Tired Of, To Lose Interest In
context-en: I’m at a place where I’m starting to lose interest in my new lover.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bored, so the verb version is to get tired of or to lose interest in.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you start to get tired of something you can't help but yawn "Ahh (?)." It doesn't matter how hard you try to hold back. The "A-ah's" keep coming out.

context-en: We sewed dust cloths in home economics class.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sew, so the verb version is to sew or to stitch.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to sew yourself some clothes because if you don't you'll be completely nude (?). You don't want anyone to see your bits! Sew quickly!

vocab-meaning: To Squeeze, To Press, To Wring
context-en: Can I squeeze lemon over the fried food?
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means squeeze, so the verb version is to squeeze or to wring.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A diehard fan comes up and says she would like to squeeze your hands. You let her and she bows (??) over and over as she squeezes your hand really hard. You don't know why she bows so much, but you don't know how to tell her to stop.

Even if you don't do it often, if you stray, say sorry!

vocab-meaning: To Brew, To Cause, To Give Rise To, To Distill
context-en: The idol’s bold statement is giving rise to public criticism.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means brew, so the verb version is to brew or to distill.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to brew up some beer but not the regular boring stuff. You're going to make it from the water in the hump of a camel (??). Camel beer is definitely not a horrible idea, right?

You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you want to interrupt and to intercept is your roommate's sighing guitar (???). He keeps playing it and all it does is make these horrible, long sighing sounds. You want to interrupt it any cost.

reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Spinning And Weaving, Weaving And Spinning
context-en: The Japanese textile industry was revived mainly by cotton spinning and weaving and synthetic fibers.
meaning-exp: Spinning and weaving means spinning and weaving. Yay!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you're spinning and weaving you are always absolutely shocked (???) by what you make. You never really know when you start and then BAM! You made elephant slippers. That's just how it works and it shocks you every single time.

context-en: This blog introduces me to the moe characters in my favorite anime and manga.
meaning-exp: What is a spout doing? It's sprouting and budding. A crush you have on someone can sprout too.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about that newly sprouting moe (??) character you have a crush on. Yes, this is the same moe. Congrats, you already know it!

context-en: US armed forces are stationed over there.
meaning-exp: Resident soldiers live in barracks when they've been stationed in another country. They have to serve their occupancy for a certain amount of time before they get to go back home.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I hit my Achille’s heel on a shelf.
meaning-exp: You should congratulate a person who speaks lots of different dialects because they have to be a really strong person to be able to do it. You think learning Japanese is hard now, just wait till you hear Osaka-ben and Hokkaido-ben. It takes a really strong person to learn all those dialects, so congratulate them and tell them how strong they are! Fun Fact: ?? is the name of an actual historical figure who was really strong. They were so strong, that we now use their name to refer to all strong people. Think of it like calling someone Hercules or Achilles in Western languages.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Why do you immediately become subservient?
meaning-exp: A lowly person who yields to everyone is really subservient. They'll do everything people tell them because they don't have the nerves to speak up and just say no.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: It’s often said that your hands and feet are plucked off when you commit a taboo, is that true?
meaning-exp: Prohibition of something with a punishment so serious that you'll end up in mourning after is a taboo.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: To Become Hollow, To Be Dented, To Sink, To Collapse
context-en: I’m sinking in unrequited love.
context-en2: I'm super sad because I made a dent on my new car already.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hollow, so the verb version is to become hollow and to sink
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You feel like you've started to become hollow when you have a head cold (??). You may be all stuffed up, but it's making you so sad that you feel hollow somehow.

vocab-meaning: To Be Pickled, To Be Well Seasoned, To Be Submerged, To Be Soaked
context-en: I soaked and relaxed in the onsen.
meaning-exp: You already learned that ??? means "to pickle," so this means "to be pickled."
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned ???, so you should be able to read this one too.

context-en: People who compose haiku are called haijin.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compose, so the verb version is to compose.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to compose a poem but all you have for inspiration is what's in your pocket. You reach in and find a yo-yo (?). Ah yes, this will do. So you compose a poem about your yo-yo: One string to rule them all, One string to find them, One string to- hey wait a minute...

vocab-meaning: To Despise, To Disdain, To Make Light Of
context-en: You shouldn’t make light of it just because it’s a child.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means despise, so the verb version is to despise.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of all the things you start to despise and to disdain. Now come up with some anecdotes (???) for each one of those things. Be sure to think in your head, "I'm coming up with anecdotes for things I disdain, why am I coming up with anecdotes?"

vocab-meaning: To Endure, To Bear, To Stand, To Put Up With
speech-type: Intransitive verb, Transitive verb, and Ichidan verb
context-en: In the end, I couldn’t bear reading the work.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure and to bear.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're at your friend's house and you have to bear with what they made for dinner. It's tacos (?). Normally you can't stand tacos but tonight you'll have to endure. It's rude to refuse food when you're a guest. But tacos are so gross!

reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

context-en: That man unconsciously looks down on people.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You start to scorn your boss because she's been wearing that same sage suit (???) for a month now. She knows you want to wear a sage suit too but you can't wear the same color as her! It's really making you start to despise her. Uhg!

context-en: A long time ago thread was spun in this way.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spinning, so the verb version is to spin and to make yarn.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Before you start to spin you have to let out two moos (??) as tribute to the cows that gave you their fur to make yarn out of. Go on, two moos, right now. Hey, out loud, not in your head!

vocab-meaning: Tsukemono, Japanese Pickled Vegetables, Pickled Vegetables, Preserved Vegetables
context-en: Who pickled these tsukemono?
meaning-exp: Pickled things are Japanese pickled vegetables! Or tsukemono if you've already been eating yummy pickled ginger, daikon, and umeboshi!
reading-exp: You already learned ??? meaning "to pickle" so just take the ? off there shove the ? into the kanji. You read it still, but it's hiding. It probably shrunk in the pickling process. Stick some things (??) on there are you know the reading! Not bad! By the way, sometimes you'll see this word spelled like ??? too.

context-en: My uncle is the principle of this school.
meaning-exp: An uncle on your father's side is still your uncle. This uncle always has to be younger than him though.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the ?? which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all!

context-en: I’m worried that the floor is a little uneven.
meaning-exp: Remember how you learned that ?? means "uneven?" Well spin something uneven around and it's still uneven! Just kinda backwards, just like this word!
reading-exp: However, just because the meaning stays the same when you flip it, doesn't mean the reading does. Doing that actually made the reading change from on'yomi to kun'yomi readings! You haven't learned either of these yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you have the convex parts first and the concave parts second in something uneven is ends up looking like a deco box (????). An art deco box that is. They have lots of stuff stick out of them on the outside, but you can open them up and put stuff on the inside.

context-en: I think it’s a really universal theme.
meaning-exp: Remember how ?? means "universal?" Well when you add like it's still universal! Easy!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Please erase this disgusting memory somehow.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of mourning? It's unpleasant or disgusting. Nobody said mourning was fun.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your mourning is especially unpleasant because it's your pet eagle (?) you're mourning for. Your parents wouldn't let you bury him so you're just staring at his week old, dead eagle body. It's super disgusting, actually.

context-en: It’s not a very good article, but please read it if you’d like.
meaning-exp: Clumsy and immature people end up being really unskillful. You can't do your job if you're always dropping things and whining, can you? They're usually also really childish, if you didn't already guess that.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: That doesn’t mean all Gypsies are poor, nomadic people.
meaning-exp: Wander from stream to stream and you'll get really used to wandering. You'll love it so much that you'll convert to nomadism. The open sky is your home!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: 70% of vagrants do some kind of work and earn a daily cash income.
meaning-exp: Someone who floats and wanders from place to place is a vagrant. They don't really have a home, but they keep hanging around yours. It's kind of annoying. (This word has a negative connotation, you wouldn't use it for someone who is just homeless, unless you're really mean.)
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for ? yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the vagrants you know are fools (?). They just left their homes and now they float around your city for no reason. You ask them why and they shrug. You've never seen a better definition of a fool before in your life!

context-en: If that sort of thing is true, I’m very sorry.
meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're very tired and very giggly, you'll try to say your friend's name but start laughing right away so it ends up sounds like, "Hannah ha ha ha (???)."

meaning-exp: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading-exp: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Swim into a floating group of seaweed and shivers will go up your spine. It feels so gross and slimy that you can't help but moan (?) out in distress.

context-en: Can you eat this seaweed?
meaning-exp: Sea seaweed is still seaweed!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Around 1-2 liters of gastric juices are secreted each day.
meaning-exp: Part of you is starting to secrete some kind of secretion. It's kinda gross, so maybe you should go to the doctor to check if it's normal.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Shameful Sight, Disgraceful Behavior, Disgraceful Behaviour
context-en: They were exposed to an unimaginably shameful sight.
meaning-exp: Something with an ugly appearance is a shameful sight. You feel bad just looking at it. It probably feels bad too.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: My type is a guy who likes reading in silence.
meaning-exp: Tell a widow to shut up and she'll be silent for the rest of the day. That wasn't very nice. You're a mean person.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: I wrote this song with my older brother.
meaning-exp: A shamisen song is a shamisen song, yes. But did you know it's also... a song?! Oh, you did? Well okay then.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context-en: Sooner or later, I intend to make my son company president.
meaning-exp: Your daughter's groom will become your son in law. He's a great guy! Congratulations!
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: Southern Barbarians, Nanban, South Sea Countries
context-en: If you have a good, simple recipe for chicken nanban, please let me know.
meaning-exp: Southern barbarians are called Southern barbarians! They're pretty commonly called Nanban people in English if you've read the history. There's yummy food named after them too!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Underground water that naturally comes to the surface is called a spring.
meaning-exp: A well of water that pops up naturally is called a spring and that water is spring water.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: When I counted the boxes there were 400 total.
meaning-exp: Measure that shape on the paper with your eyes. It's got four sides.. it's.. it's a square! Or a box from above maybe... But it's definitely the kind you fill in on a graph.
reading-exp: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: There’s sulfur in this hot spring.
meaning-exp: Sulfur that's yellow is still sulfur. It smells like rotten eggs, which are also kinda yellow.
reading-exp: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: This sulfur smells like an eagle's OOHHH (???)!! Oh no. Sulfur smells... it smells... like an eagle's... OH.. Oh eww no.

context-en: Pranks are popular among children right now.
meaning-exp: A bad kind of playing is when you tease or prank someone. It's mean and you shouldn't do it!
reading-exp: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you tease someone with a prank that makes them eat zoo rats (????), you're a jerk. That's less of a prank and more like abuse. Cut it out.

context-en: I don’t think it’s a good idea to force a higher amount of frugality on yourself just because you want to buy your own home.
meaning-exp: I promise this will be a really thrifty place because it's a thrift store! They wouldn't lie about that!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: To Adore, To Miss, To Yearn For
context-en: I adored him like an older brother.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yearn for, so the verb version is to yearn for. But that sounds kinda old fashioned, so you can just use to adore too.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You realize you're starting to yearn for someone way more than you used to. "Sh*t (??)... " you say to yourself. This wasn't supposed to happen. Anytime you start to adore someone like that you always know you're getting into a bunch of sh*t you don't want to deal with. Damn these emotions!

vocab-meaning: To Become Muddy, To Become Impure, To Become Cloudy
context-en: The air in the room is getting cloudy with tobacco smoke.
meaning-exp: You already know that ?? means "to make muddy," but this is when you're the one getting muddy. It means to become muddy.
reading-exp: This has the same reading as ??. If you can remember that one, you should be able to remember this one.

context-en: My older sister was brutally tortured by the mafia.
meaning-exp: Torture may be a problem but that doesn't stop people from using torture to get their way.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

vocab-meaning: To Sing, To Recite, To Chant
context-en: My uncle is a singing accordion player.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Shamisen song, so the verb version is to sing.
reading-exp: Remember how ?? means "to sing" too? Well it has the same reading. If you know that one, you know this one. Yay!

vocab-meaning: To Well Up, To Gush Forth, To Spring Out, To Surge
context-en: Bitter tears welled up.
meaning-exp: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an ? sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means well, so the verb version is to well up.
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're fishing in a hole in the ice when suddenly the water starts to well up and to gush forth out of it. A huge walrus (?) splashes out and jumps on you. No wonder there weren't any fish! This is a walrus hole.

context-en: They’re digging a tunnel somewhere 20 miles underground.
meaning-exp: A pit that's used as a road is called a tunnel. Or a mine, if they're taking valuable things out of it.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: The old woman’s ghost glared at me with her ugly face from over there.
meaning-exp: Someone who is ugly and mean can't hide their ugliness or meanness from the rest of us! If you're really mean, it shows on your face.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: That woman’s face is beautiful but her heart is ugly.
meaning-exp: This is a single kanji with an ? on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of ugly? It's ugly still!
reading-exp: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The most ugly thing you've ever seen was a mini cookie (???). Why would any one want a tiny cookie? Cookies should be huge, and enough to fill you up. The more you look at the mini cookie it seems to become uglier and uglier to you.

context-en: I was hospitalized from a urinary organ disease.
meaning-exp: The containers your urine secretes into are your urinary organs.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: We can overlook the beautiful valley from the onsen’s bath huts.
meaning-exp: A valley in a valley is still a valley!
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Please explain widow deductions to me in detail.
meaning-exp: A widowed wife is a widow.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context-en: Being in a foreign country, I constantly yearn for my mother.
meaning-exp: If you can't stop thinking about how much you yearn for someone, that yearning can drive you crazy. Try to keep it in check, and enjoy how you can hold such deep affection for someone.
reading-exp: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
